1929 or 1989 ?
paris – as the economic crisis deepens and spread , the entire world has been looking for a similar outcome in history to help us understand what is happening .
in the first place , many people likened the crisis to 1982 or 1973 , as it would have been , given that both episodes mean a typical cyclical recession .
today ’ s mood is too high , and many people are beginning to see the crisis in 1929 and 1931 , even if some governments seem to be showing the same recession as they do in 1929 and 1931 .
the current trend is either excessive restraint ( europe ) or an extension of efforts ( the us ) .
europe has become cautious in avoiding debt and defending the euro , and the us has already acted in many ways to take advantage of this ideal moment to implement much-needed structural reforms .
but , as a purely strategic scientist , the year of 1989 , both politically and economically , is 1989 .
of course , the collapse of lehman brothers had nothing to do with the fall of the berlin wall .
in fact , the two seem to be entirely the opposite : a fall in the fall of the berlin wall , a symbol of repression and artificial fragmentation , and the collapse of a seemingly indestructible financial capitalism .
but , as in 1989 , it may well be seen as a transformative change in 2008-2009 , with the sobering consequences that will still enable us to feel .
what happened in 2009 may have threatened the positive results of the 1989 revolution , including the peaceful reunification of europe and the triumph of democracy over nationalist tendencies , if not xenophobic tendencies .
in 1989 , liberal democracy triumphed over the socialist ideology fostered and promoted by the soviet bloc .
for many of the supporters of president ronald reagan , the escalation of the arms race was an escalating arms race , pushing the soviet economy to the brink of collapse , fully revealing the superiority of liberal societies and free markets .
of course , the situation is strikingly different now .
first , perhaps the most important , the 1989 revolution and the subsequent collapse of the soviet union ended global bipolarity .
by contrast , 2009 is likely to pave the way for a new form of bipolarity , only china replaced the soviet union .
second , democratic institutions and market capitalism may be more vulnerable than expected , as the winners were .
and in 2009 , as the global crisis spread , it is difficult to distinguish between winners and losers ; everyone seemed to lose , even if some countries were more affected than others .
the history of history is unfair , though the united states is more responsible for today ’ s global crisis than in most countries .
the us will be better off , but it is not the only country that can recover .
as a visiting professor at harvard and mit , i would like to see what a post-crisis world looks like .
we can feel that a world dominated by the us and asia is emerging .
from the media lab of a first-class mit lab to mathematics and 经济系 in harvard university , asians - especially china and indians – are everywhere , like those who have learned from athens in the century to the end of athens .
but , before the emergence of this new order , the world may face a broader muddle , if not utter chaos .
for example , what happens to egypt , an important and fragile country , for which hundreds of thousands of egyptians have been forced to return to their homes in the gulf , but now in the gulf , but what happens to egypt ?
when the rich are less rich , the poor are poorer .
and , with the foreign workers who are pursuing the “ european dream , ” they now face the potential of the xenophobic mentality that should be open to european countries , and what happens ?
the results of the 1989 revolution , which did not include many observers , have been considered less enduring .
we can only hope that the crisis in 2009 was as dramatic as we have seen in the way that we are now in our intuition and history .
a hundred years of servitude
berlin – the global financial and economic crisis that erupted in 2008 was the most severe economic stress test since the great depression , and the most serious challenge to social and political institutions since world war ii .
not only does it threaten financial markets and currencies ; it also exposed serious regulatory and governance shortcomings that have not been fully addressed .
indeed , the 2008 crisis will most likely be viewed as a watershed , but not because it led to reforms that strengthen economic resilience and eliminate economic vulnerabilities .
instead , leaders failed to learn from the lessons of the great depression , let alone a preventive response that could trigger a new set of economic and other crises for decades to come .
a century later , a century later , historians are likely to despair about our shortsightedness .
they will see the analysts and regulators , by strengthening the regulatory regime , focusing narrowly on repairing the financial system .
though this goal is not worthless , it is not the only thing that historians have pointed out , as historians have pointed out .
to address the challenges posed by globalization and technological progress in ways that ensure sustainable and balanced growth , governance institutions and institutions in both the domestic and international governance must be upgraded .
but this is not enough .
making matters worse , because part of the financial system will bring further globalization , these measures will eventually exacerbate existing problems , because the move has increased pressure not only on financial , but also in other economic and technological sectors , to impose regulatory and regulatory frameworks .
moreover , massive financial investments focused on higher returns on return are likely to drive technological innovation , further increasing pressure on financial and other regulatory systems .
major technological innovations , fueled by cheap money , can make market change so fast that policy and institutional change can not be adapted .
at the same time , the emergence of new markets could yield huge returns for early adopters or investors , and can continue to benefit from the leading domestic and international regulatory institutions .
this is precisely what happened before the 2008 crisis .
new technology-enabled financial instruments create opportunities for some to earn large profits .
but regulators can not keep pace with innovation , and eventually create the risks that affect the entire economy .
this reflects the fundamental difference between the global crisis of the twenty-first century and the great depression of the 1930 ’ s or the great depression of the past .
the financial sector ’ s continued growth has led to more participation in the short term , from inadequate short-term regulation and weak governance , making it harder to prevent current crises .
complicating matters further , the system affected by the current crisis extends far beyond the purview of any regulatory body .
this has caused the crisis to become even more dangerous and makes it harder to predict the consequences of the crisis – including the long-term consequences of social and political areas .
the next crisis – increasing the likelihood that nationalist sentiment is becoming more likely and overlooked – may involve finance , but it may also involve areas like migration , trade , cyberspace , pollution , and climate change .
in all of these areas , both domestic and international governance institutions are weak or covered by weak or 覆盖 actors , including independent actors such as transparency and accountability .
this is not only making it harder to prevent crises – especially because it provides opportunities for participants to escape and shirk responsibility – and it is increasingly difficult to take steps to address the crisis .
the 2008 crisis exposed how weak we are in the face of disasters , especially because the main causes of the disaster are decentralized governance .
to be sure , humans have made some progress in preparing and managing crises , as the 2018 school of governance report shows .
but we must beware of development – from finance to digital technologies to climate change – to hedge the governance of domestic and international institutions .
we should be in the midst of a crisis in all of these areas , and the emergency plan to develop a crisis , while adopting stronger measures such as debt levels to reduce risk , with debt levels in advanced economies far higher today than they were before the 2008 crisis .
moreover , we should ensure that the regulatory responsibilities and resources that empower international institutions are needed .
by punishing those who exacerbate risks for their own interests , we can strengthen the legitimacy of global governance and its institutions .
for now , inadequate cross-border coordination and international agreements are a major obstacle to crisis prevention and management .
but the world ’ s 兴起 model of national sovereignty is being reinvigorated not only by the problem , but also by a variety of crises .
unless we change course soon , the world will have enough reason for the world to despise us .
where is 2008 ?
berkeley – to solve the problem , it is not enough to know what is done .
one must actually implement solutions – and , as it turns out you know , will be willing to change course .
this is the message of two new books , which tells you what you need to know about the 2008 financial crisis : what caused the financial crisis to prevent it from recurring , and why not yet .
the first book is the change of change and shocks , the authors of conservative english journalist martin wolf .
for starters , he argues that the wealth of the richest 0.1 % of the world ’ s richest and 0.01 % , which has created mounting pressure on people , governments , and companies to become increasingly unsustainable .
as a result , market regulation is relaxed , making it easier for assets to be considered safe but not safe .
as a result , systemic risk has proliferated , and more than the most daring of central bankers .
untested and ultimately false assumptions created a policymaking environment that can only be described as hubris .
officials underestimated tail risks .
they set inflation targeting around 2 % – meaning that they have little room for maneuver when the water got choppy .
and , most audaciously of all , the eu introduced the euro as a common currency .
indeed , policymaking in the direction of the wrong direction lasted long after the crisis began .
politicians ’ response to deteriorating economic conditions is a strong antidote to the wrong medicine , and they have nothing to do with the worst economic disaster since the great depression .
wolf ’ s prescription for countering the crisis is simple , smart , and unassailable .
in the short term , he has proposed that countries with reserve currencies increase spending ( especially public-sector investment ) , issuing more debt .
these countries ’ central banks , he argued , should raise inflation targets to 3 % or even 4 % per year .
in the medium term , wolf argues that countries need to implement regulatory measures to reduce debt levels and prevent excessive debt .
the eurozone must also address its internal contradictions , either by disbanding the eurozone or by introducing “ institutional and policy portfolios ” that enable monetary union to function normally .
wolf ’ s long-term solution includes containing inequality , “ more globalized regulation , ” and more “ individual countries ’ own decisions to determine the ways of the game , ” and that the free-market ideology has left us in crisis .
but , while wolf ’ s proposal is worth the recommendations , there is little .
the reason can be found in the second book : hall of 镜厅 , my friend , teacher , and “ boss ” barry eichengreen .
according to eichengreen , we have responded to tepid responses to the crisis , which goes back to the triumph of economists of the keynesian and minskyite colleagues of milton friedman – at least in explaining the causes and consequences of the great depression .
when the 2008 financial crisis erupted , policymakers tried to use friedman ’ s proposed great depression proposals .
unfortunately , it turns out to be wrong , as the monetarist interpretation of the great depression was wrong in many ways , and incomplete .
the resulting policies would be enough to prevent the post-2008 recession from turning into outright depression ; but the price of this partial success is huge , and that it has made it difficult for politicians to declare that the crisis has been overcome , and that it is focused on structural reforms .
the result is economic stagnation now , characterized by anemic growth and possible new normal .
the loss of 10 % of potential wealth in the us and europe , without strengthening financial-sector regulation , has given the world a new major crisis .
wolf and eichengreen would argue that the main flaw that led to the 2008 financial crisis – and that continues to undermine our inadequate response to the crisis – is intellectual intelligence .
indeed , the only real lesson of the crisis so far is that its lessons have never been taken seriously .
a comeback strategy for europe
马德里 – last november , pope francis likened the eu to his grandmother ’ s european parliament – benign and 和蔼 , but no longer the vitality and energy of the past .
as francis put it , the eu ’ s leaders must escape their 懈怠 image , recognize the strategic challenges that europe faces , and build a clear policy toward the challenge .
to be sure , the pope ’ s characterization is very accurate in some respects .
but , while europe seems lassitude , it retains considerable strengths .
but the world is changing : the asia-pacific region is increasingly shaping the global economy and other developments .
the trans-pacific partnership ( tpp ) , established by the united states and 11 other countries , is likely to accelerate this change ( if china eventually will join ) .
though the tpp ’ s distance from the final deal will require a wide range of hurdles , its potential to expand asia ’ s economic power will not be allowed to remain .
europe must work to ensure its position in a new world order – first to strengthen its own trade and investment ties with the us .
as the tpp negotiations continue to advance , the eu-us transatlantic trade and investment partnership ( ttip ) will be constrained by domestic contradictions , and the entire project is likely to die .
business leaders on both sides of the atlantic believe that a successful ttip agreement would bring enormous economic benefits – a perception that many studies have reinforced .
but some subtle problems – such as “ chicken with chicken ” ( “ chicken with chickens ” ) and disputes over investors ’ settlement settlement – still dominate debate .
the ttip ’ s goal is to release the transatlantic economy – which is still the world ’ s largest market , accounting for three-quarters of global financial activity and more than half of world trade .
( if the ttip is open to other economies , such as turkey , mexico , and canada , the benefits will be higher . )
but , more than the benefits of reaching a deal , the success of the negotiations could be devastating .
first , the breakdown of the ttip negotiations would significantly strengthen the uk ’ s advocacy of the eu ’ s campaign ; conversely , if the ttip is implemented , it would not be wise , so it will not happen .
moreover , europe ’ s internal squabbles have left it a strategic opportunity to waste a strategic opportunity that could prompt the us to accelerate its departure from europe .
and russian president vladimir putin is bound to view europe ’ s failures as an opportunity to influence more of europe .
all of this highlights a fundamental new strategic risk : if the ttip fails to make progress or fail , progress on the tpp will be made , and the global balance will move toward asia – most likely to be unable to revive its economic and geopolitical influence .
when the ttip first proposed , europe seemed to recognize its value .
indeed , the united states , which has been pushing for europe ’ s initial commitment to europe , launched the process of negotiations in june 2013 .
at the time , the intention was to complete the negotiations .
no one wants to postpone the talks long – or endure the political pain that it brings .
but eu leaders effectively abandoned the project , and that , too , confirms america ’ s concerns .
trade negotiations are struggling to move ahead , while anti-globalization groups control public opinion , portraying the ttip as a threat to everything – from european democracy to europe ’ s health .
this is a dangerous false statement , and eu leaders must make a strategic case to advance the ttip , thereby preventing this statement from gaining greater market .
they must also revive the promise of successful negotiations in 2015 .
this is not to say that addressing the ttip negotiations will be easy .
but a trade agreement , especially the trade agreements that contain so many regulatory problems , is never easy , because it must account for the complexity and 易变性 of modern economies .
indeed , completing the challenges contained in the ttip is no more intractable than the challenges that eu leaders have faced during the last few years .
the ttip negotiations will be revived next month , when eu leaders must push for genuine progress and aim at the end of the year .
the good news is that the recent midterm elections in the united states are likely to increase their chances of success .
us president barack obama is now likely to get the so-called fast-track negotiating mandate from congress .
if so , the us congress will approve or reject a negotiated agreement , rather than on the shelf .
that is why europe ’ s leaders have no time to waste .
they must seize economic opportunities – and avoid strategic disaster .

another year of slow global growth
washington , dc – last april , the international monetary fund predicted that the world economy will grow by 3.5 % in 2015 .
in the ensuing months , this forecast was gradually lowered , to 3.1 % in october .
but the imf continues to insist that it has , in the last seven years , had little semblance of predictability – and will be better next year .
but almost certainly , the imf is wrong .
first , the world ’ s trade grew at an annual rate of barely 2 % , compared to 8 % from 2003 to 2007 .
trade growth has been much higher in recent years than world gdp ( an average rate of 4.5 % ) , but recent trade and gdp growth is roughly equal .
even if gdp growth exceeds that of trade this year , it could not be more than 2.7 % .
the question is why .
according to christina and david romer of the university of california , berkeley , the aftershocks of the modern financial crisis have lasted only over 2-3 years .
harvard economist carmen reinhart and kenneth rogoff say that a country needs five years to emerge from the financial crisis .
and , indeed , the financial turmoil of 2007-2008 has largely disappeared .
so what accounts for the sluggish economic recovery ?
one popular explanation is the fuzzy notion of “ secular stagnation ” – a long-term decline in demand for goods and services that undermined investment and hiring incentives .
but demand will continue to slow only when people are confident about the future .
the only logical explanation for this lack of confidence is logical , just as northwestern university ’ s robert gordon has painstakingly documented and argued that productivity growth is slow .
before the crisis , especially in 2003 , slow productivity growth was obscured by an illusion that much of the world was thriving .
in some countries – especially the united states , spain , and ireland – rising profits , speculative construction , and financial risk-taking reinforce each other .
at the same time , countries are amplifying each other ’ s growth through trade .
at the heart of this global boom is china , where the rising behemoths export cheap exports to the world , containing global inflation .
equally important , china imports huge amounts of commodities , thereby boosting many african and latin american economies ; it also bought large quantities of german cars and machines , enabling europe ’ s largest economy to sustain its regional supply chains .
this dynamic reversed in march 2008 , when the us rescued its fifth-largest investment bank , bear stearns , from bankruptcy .
in a boom years , world trade spread , and world trade is spreading .
as countries ’ gdp growth slows , imports are slowing , and the growth of trading partners slowed .
the us economy began out of recession in the second half of 2009 , largely owing to aggressive monetary policies and measures undertaken by the financial system .
instead , european policymakers rejected monetary stimulus and implemented fiscal austerity , ignoring the intensified bank pressure .
the eurozone thus dragged the world into a second global recession .
and the emerging economies began to collapse , as the recession seemed to be on track .
for years , observers have been touting these countries ’ leaders how to implement reforms and growth-enhancing reforms .
in october 2012 , the imf praised emerging economies ’ “ resilience . ”
at this point , the dream of 撑不住 has exposed an uncomfortable truth : high commodity prices and factors such as large-scale capital inflows masked severe economic weaknesses , as well as rampant inequality and rampant corruption .
today , these problems are compounded by the global trade ’ s pillars – china ’ s growth slowdown .
the worst is yet to come .
china ’ s massive industrial overcapacity and real-estate excesses have yet to digest ; the hubris driving its global acquisitions must be contained ; and its corrupt networks must be broken .
in short , the factors holding back the global economy in 2015 will continue to persist in the new year – and even intensify .
emerging economies will remain weak .
a temporary 欧元区 of austerity would be constrained by weak global trade .
higher interest rates on corporate bonds portend slower us growth .
the collapse of chinese assets could trigger financial instability .
and policymakers are adrift , without political means to contain these trends .
instead of updating growth forecasts , the imf should issue warnings : the global economy will continue to remain weak and fragile , unless world leaders focus on stimulating innovation and growth .
such measures should have been implemented long ago .
trumpian uncertainty
new york – every january , i will try to predict a forecast for the next year .
economic forecasts are extremely difficult to do ; harry truman , who had asked him to ask him for a 独臂 economist , was unable to say , “ on the other side , ” my prediction was sound .
in recent years , i have been right to predict that the recovery from the great recession of 2008 will be slow , without stronger fiscal stimulus ( as in europe or in the us ) .
at the same time , my forecasts rely more on analysis of basic economic forces than on complex econometric models .
in early 2016 , for example , it was clear that a shortage of global aggregate demand in the last few years will be unlikely to change dramatically .
so i believe that forecasters who believe that strong recovery will be robust are too optimistic , and that actual economic development is consistent with my projections .
the same is true of political events in 2016 .
i have been arguing for years that unless the growing inequality problem in many countries around the world ( especially in the united states ) is addressed , some political consequences are inevitable .
a study by anne case and angus deaton shows that life expectancy in most of the us is declining , including the anger of angry residents of the so-called northern rust belt .
and , because the income growth of 90 % of those at the bottom of the population has stagnated for almost one-third of the last century ( a large proportion of which has declined ) , data on health data clearly confirm the conditions for most of the us .
but the us may be at such a trend , and it will be better elsewhere .

donald trump grasped the spirit of the zeitgeist : many voters would have changed the point .
but now they will realize the truth : there is no longer normal , but there is no more uncertainty .
what policies trump will pursue remains unknown , let alone which policies will succeed or the consequences will be .
trump seems hell-bent on launching a trade war .
so how will china and mexico respond ?
trump knows that his proposal would violate wto rules , but he estimates that the world trade organization needs a long time to overthrow it .
by that point , america ’ s trade account could be rebalanced .
but the game is twofold : china can adopt a similar but subtler operation .
so what will happen if a trade war erupts ?
trump may feel that he could win ; after all , china ’ s reliance on exports to the us is stronger than america ’ s exports to the us .
but trade wars are not a zero-sum game , and the us will lose .
china ’ s retaliation may be more targeted , enough to bring serious political pressure on the us .
the chinese may respond to the crisis that the other has imposed on the other .
who is to be expected to be more productive : the united states , where the average citizen has long struggled ?
or , even in difficult times , can china achieve more than 6 % growth ?
more generally , the republicans ’ agenda – tax cuts even more favorable to the rich than the standard republican proposals – implies that these policies are based on trickle-down exuberance , which has been earned by the rich to spend more on consumption , and the continuation of supply-side economics .

five years after the attacks in new york and the pentagon in washington , “ 9/11 ” is no longer just a date .
it has been remembered as a starting point for change or a new era of time .
terrorist bombings in madrid and london , as well as elsewhere , will be remembered ; but , just as “ 9/11 ” has become a catchphrase .
but was it really a war of september 11 , 2001 ?
not everyone agrees on this american view .
when irish terrorism is rampant in the united kingdom , successive british governments are struggling to concede to the irish republican party that they are engaged in a war .
“ war ” would mean accepting the terrorists as legitimate enemies , with the meaning of a bloody war with a sense of belonging to an accepted war .
this is neither the right description of acts of terrorism nor the useful word . terrorists should be more accurately called criminals .
but , by calling it a war , and targeting al qaeda and its leaders , osama bin laden , the us government provides some reason for domestic change , which was not accepted by any liberal state until 9/11 .
most of these changes are embodied in the so-called “ usa patriot act . ”
although some changes involve only administrative rules , the patriot act ’ s overall effect has been to erode the liberal pillar of liberty , such as habeas corpus , the right to seek relief from an independent court , regardless of state .
for a long time , the prison camp at guantánamo bay in cuba became a symbol of unheard , namely the arrest of the “ illegal combatants ” who were deprived of all human rights .
today , the world is unsure about how many more people are suffering from inhuman people .

when such restrictions are adopted , they have not faced public opposition .
on the contrary , in general , critics , not supporters , found themselves in trouble .
in the united kingdom , prime minister tony blair supported the us attitude , introducing a similar approach , and even proposed a new theory .
blair first advocated security as the first .
in other words , freedom is not an individual ’ s right to determine their lives , but the right to restrict individual freedoms in the name of security , and only states can determine what security means .
this is the beginning of a new authoritarianism .
this problem exists in all countries that are threatened by terrorist threats , though in many countries it has become very specific .
in most continental european countries , 9/11 has become an american day .
even the debate , and indeed the evidence , is that participation in the “ war on terror ” has actually increased the threat of terrorist action .
germans certainly use this argument to stay out of the action .
this stance , however , is not preventing the spread of what has been said in germany .

people feel uneasy , especially when traveling .

one of the worrying features of 9/11 is that it is hard to see their purpose in addition to the perpetrators ’ hatred of the west and its way of life .
but the west ’ s main feature , the democratic and the rule of law , has been severely damaged by the defenders of democracy and the rule of law .
most important , two steps will need to be taken to restore confidence in liberal confidence in the major countries affected by 9/11 .

second , and more importantly , our leaders should seek to calm , rather than exploit , public anxiety .
the terrorists who now “ fight ” can not win , because their dark views will never win broad public legitimacy .
that is why democrats should take , first and foremost , to defend their values .
september 11 , 2017

moreover , efforts have been successfully implemented to push back against terrorists .
intelligence resources have been redirected , and national borders have become safer , and societies have become more resilient .
international cooperation on terror has increased significantly , in part because governments have felt that they need to strengthen cooperation in this area , despite disagreements over other areas .
military force has also played a role .
al qaeda lost its base in afghanistan , where the taliban government , which provides sanctuary to it , was overthrown .
osama bin laden was eventually found and killed by us special forces .
military drones play an extraordinary role in killing the country ’ s terrorists .
weak governments can be strengthened , and governments that tolerate or even support terrorism must be held accountable .
terrorists and terrorism can not be eliminated , as we can not eliminate disease from the planet .
there will always be attempts to use force against innocent people to pursue their political objectives , whether for men , women , or children .
in fact , terrorists are advancing in some areas .
pakistan continues to provide sanctuary to al qaeda and some of the world ’ s most dangerous terrorists .
owing to instability , weak government , and ideology , yemen , libya , somalia , and nigeria have also become fertile ground for terrorism , where they are organized , training , and implemented , as in afghanistan a decade ago .
the old organization was devastated by the new organization .
the danger of homegrown terrorism is growing .
we see this in the united kingdom and the united states .
the internet , the great inventions of the modern western world , was treated as weapons , incentives , and training those who seek to harm the world .
in october 2003 , then-us secretary of defense donald rumsfeld offered a question that still makes good sense : “ do we capture , kill , imprison terrorists , and 改造 terrorists every day , more terrorists than islamist schools and radical religious extremists have recruited , trained , and mobilized against us ? ”
if all equals , we may have done it .
but any small success of terrorists , which would mean high lives and money costs for open societies , is worth the cost .
what is to be done ?
alas , there is no single way .
the palestinian state is not enough , because the terrorists want to eliminate the country ’ s states ; on the issue of kashmir , they can not meet pakistan ’ s terrorists ’ greater demands for indian territory .
reducing unemployment is certainly a good thing , but many terrorists are not the poor .
helping societies in the middle east and elsewhere to become more democratic would help to ease the marginalization and deter extremism , but that is easier said than done .
of course , we need to continue to do so , making us less vulnerable and the weaker terrorists .
but most important is to prevent terrorism from spreading in any way , especially in arab and islamic societies .
in 2009 , a father in nigeria told the us embassy in lagos that he feared that his son would make terrible things , thereby preventing the latter from sending a bomb to detroit .
only when more parents , teachers , and social leaders behave in such a way can the terrorists dry up , and law-enforcement authorities will be able to cooperate on the ground .
terrorism must lose its legitimacy in places where tradition has traditionally supported or tolerated terrorism .
transatlantic trade for all
washington , dc – negotiations on the creation of a transatlantic trade and investment partnership between the european union and the united states have been widely welcomed .
british prime minister david cameron has called the ttip “ only one chance , ” arguing that it would yield some 亿英镑 billion ( $ 亿英镑 billion ) to the eu and the us , with 亿英镑 billion in potential benefits for the rest of the world .
for a world that awaits the 冗长 doha round of the world trade organization , even bilateral initiatives are like a 恩惠 恩惠 , especially the “ bilateral ” relationship that the financial times recently pointed out , including the world ’ s two most recent “ bilateral ” relationships .
but risk is also huge : the agreement could hurt developing countries ’ exports , unless the eu and the us act together to protect these actors ’ interests .
the most excited aspect of the plan ’ s agenda – the emphasis on regulatory barriers such as mandatory product standards – is in fact the most important concern .
the european union and the us tariffs are low – on average , less than 5 % – so further caps do not have serious implications for other countries .
as a result , third countries ’ choices will depend on how the ttip standards are set : by harmonizing ( shared standards ) or recognizing ( accepting a set of goods and services that meet each other ’ s rules ) .
the first option would enable producers everywhere to take advantage of economies of scale .
but , in some cases , harmonized standards are more stringent than some of the previous standards .
while new standards would apply to suppliers of all exporting countries , compliance costs are often different , which means that a higher standard of firms will suffer .
in the late 1990 ’ s , the eu decided to coordinate the standards of 黄曲霉素 ( a toxic form of toxic 族 ) , with eight members – including italy , the netherlands , and spain – contributing to a $ 6.7 billion decline in national capital , fruit , and the fall of european exports .
if mutual recognition is taken , the eu and the us will recognize each other ’ s standards or compliance procedures , and firms will choose less stringent than in various criteria .
if the policy expands to third-country firms , it would have a significant liberalizing role .
malaysia ’ s tv producer , for example , may choose to meet , say , a safe standard for security in the us , and then sells the same products in both the us and europe , both of which enjoy the benefits of the economy .
but , if the ttip excluded third-country firms from mutual recognition , their competitiveness relative to european and american companies would be severely weakened .
in fact , our research shows that when mutual commitments include restrictive restrictions on origin , intra-regional trade will increase , trade with other countries would weaken , and developing countries suffer most .
indeed , the eu ’ s previous recognition of the agreement ( for example , in terms of professional services ) suggests that the rules of excessive discipline are problematic .
while brazil , which is allowed to sell in portugal , could sell the entire eu , access to portuguese engineers and accountants still will have to meet their own practice in the rest of the european union , which has forced 工人 bureaucratic procedures for the labor movement , which is undermining much-needed labor mobility .
moreover , in terms of tariffs and standards , wto rules are not equal .
while wto rules protect countries that are excluded from bilateral and regional tariff agreements , thereby ensuring that integrated markets do not receive additional advantages , conservation efforts to protect third countries are virtually non-existent .
even without international law , the eu and the us can take two steps to ensure that the ttip does not hurt developing economies .
for starters , they can agree to not enforce strict rules , which would allow all countries to enjoy the benefits of bilateral mutual recognition .
second , in areas where coordination is considered , they can favor less stringent standards , unless there is ample evidence that doing so would undermine the relevant regulatory objectives .
this is akin to the wto ’ s current test of international standards .
if the eu and the us implemented both , the rest of the world will be able to track the ttip with hope , not fear .
a balanced view of us-china trade
beijing – before july 2007 , most economists regarded global growth as the most significant threat to global imbalances .
they feel that america ’ s net foreign debt – the consequences of a chronic current-account deficit – would lead to a sharp reduction in the flow of money , thereby weakening the dollar , then rising interest rates , and eventually plunging the us economy into crisis .
but this scenario failed to materialize , in fact , in the wake of the us sub-prime debacle , and immediately dragged the global economy into the worst recession since the 1930 ’ s .
most economists couldn ’ t foresee the real economic drivers of the crisis , because they lack sufficient attention to the rapid growth of the us total .
in fact , they have focused on america ’ s foreign debt , neglecting the problem of household debt ( mortgage and consumer debt ) , public debt , business debt , and financial debt .
they should pay more attention to the sustainability of us mortgage and consumer debt .
in 2007 , these two liabilities had risen to more than 90 % of gdp , compared to just 24 % of net external debt .
of course , the different components of debt are very different from their respective properties and sources of funding – and the same is true of sustainability .
but the components of a country ’ s total debt and its funding are certainly connected .
second , a part of the problems caused by total debt will affect the rest .
after the subprime crisis erupted , households in the us can pay mortgages and consumer debt to pay for their mortgages , or to abandon their repayment .
the decline in america ’ s total debt , and the narrowing of the fiscal gap between gross debt and domestic capital , has made the us current-account deficit significantly improved in 2008-2009 , as fed chairman ben bernanke has shown .
in fact , despite the dollar ’ s appreciation in safe-haven demand , the us current-account situation has been consolidated .
unfortunately , as the private sector deleveraging and rising household savings , the us economy , driven by debt and consumption , is mired in recession .
to reduce the negative impact of private-sector deleveraging on growth , the us government pursued expansionary monetary and fiscal policies .
today , the household debt situation after the government intervened heavily in the aftermath of the government ’ s intervention , while the fiscal position deteriorated sharply , with the current-account balance falling again .
the sustainability of public debt has replaced private debt as the biggest problem in financial stability in the us , and the focus of debate on the us current-account position has shifted from the sustainability of external debt to the impact of diminishing growth and employment .
american policymakers are now in a quandary : to promote growth and reduce overall debt levels .
the most important way to achieve these two objectives is to increase exports through increased us competitiveness .
but this increase in competitiveness comes from ?
reducing the dollar ’ s value in the short run will boost us competitiveness in the short term , but not for the long term .
because the rapid deterioration of fiscal positions already worries investors about capital losses on their us government securities , the devaluation will make foreigners less willing to finance america ’ s budget deficit .
without foreign funds , the yield on us government debt will be forced to raise and the us economy will relapse into recession .
in the long run , america ’ s development model must be driven by the reliance on debt and consumption to be innovative in the us .
only then can the us truly increase its competitiveness and allow the government to reduce private and public debt to a sustainable level while maintaining a reasonable growth rate .
but neither increased competitiveness nor reduction of total debt can be achieved overnight .
whatever the country ’ s bilateral trade surplus , america ’ s current-account deficit will continue to exist in the short run .
as a result , china ’ s continued investment in its trade surplus is vital to us economic growth and financial stability .
given america ’ s significant interest in buying us treasuries in china , it is hard to understand why the us government and congress tend to complain about the bilateral current-account deficit in the us .
at the same time , it is difficult to explain why china is reluctant to reduce its bilateral trade surplus , because massive holdings of us government securities are extremely low and large capital losses are lost .
the good news is that , in chinese president hu jintao ’ s recent visit to the us , china and china have made positive efforts to address bilateral imbalances .
this portends a more rational and constructive dialogue between the united states and china , which would benefit the global economy .
the banking union first
brussels – when the financial crisis began , people used charles goodhart to describe banks : “ international , die , and national . ”
at the time ( 2008-2009 ) , the international megabanks had to bail out their home governments in distress .
but now europe ’ s problems are in the opposite direction , with banks “ in life , and europe . ”
in spain , for example , local savings banks are financing providers of 地产 booms .
as prosperity becomes a depression , the resulting losses are over to the country ’ s entire country , which has become a problem for europe , because it is about the survival of the euro .
national supervisors always try to minimize domestic problems .
their instinct ( and their bureaucratic interests ) is to defend the “ national champion ” bank ’ s performance abroad .
but their resistance to recognizing problems at home is even greater .
until recently , the spanish authorities did not insist that the country ’ s real-estate sector is temporary .
recognizing the truth means that they ignored the unsustainable construction of a thriving construction boom that is now in danger of insolvency .
in ireland , the initial situation was not very different from spain .
when the problem began , the finance minister , then , declared that ireland would implement “ the minimal cost of bank bailouts . ”
predictably , national regulators tend to ignore domestic problems , so the cost of clearing insolvent banks should be borne by countries themselves .
as a result , even in the eurozone , banking supervision remains largely a matter of national isolation .
the newly established european banking authority has the authority to do much more than national supervisors , whose daily work is largely based on domestic conditions .
but reality has shown that this approach is not tenable .
the problem may begin at the national level , but , given the monetary union ’ s presence , they quickly threatened stability throughout the eurozone banking system .
at the june summit , european leaders finally realized that fixing the situation and transferring the functions of eurozone banking supervision to the ecb would be essential .
as a monetary union , financial integration is very strong in the eurozone , making it a no-brainer for the ecb .
moreover , the ecb has already borne the role of maintaining a stable eurozone banking system .
so far , however , the ecb must continue to borrow massively in terms of banks ’ solid degree of lending , because all information is in the hands of national supervisors , which have gone on the hands of national regulators , and that it can not survive until it failed .
allowing the ecb to exercise this function would also help to stem the ongoing integration process , which , though not yet in public discourse , has become a real threat .
just ask any large international bank headquartered in distressed eurozone countries .
consider the case of a bank headquartered in italy , which has an important subsidiary in germany .
germany ’ s subsidiary naturally has a surplus of money ( on average , on average , on average ) .
the parent bank wanted to use this money to strengthen the entire group ’ s liquidity .
but germany ’ s regulatory authorities argue that there is risk in italy , so it is resisting transfers .
the interests of the home country ( italy ) have the opposite interest .
it wants to see the “ internal capital market ” operations , better .
here , the ecb is right to act as a neutral arbiter to respect these opposing interests .
but , while allowing the ecb to exercise banking supervision , it will also create another problem : will national supervisory authorities continue to bear responsibility for the 储蓄银行 savings banks that are no longer regulated ?
the logic of economic ( and political ) logic means that the eurozone needs a common bank bailout fund .
this need not be officially recognized .
but this is a typical practice in the european integration process : incomplete measures in one area require follow-up steps in the relevant areas .
but the financial crisis made it possible for policymakers to explain why , as the past has done , there is another step .
they need to accelerate their efforts to save the euro considerably .
the new promise of abenomics
tokyo – the liberal democratic party ( ldp ) scored a decisive victory in the december 14 parliamentary election , because japanese voters overwhelmingly supported prime minister shinzo abe ’ s macroeconomic policy agenda .
while voters voter turnout or relatively low – largely owing to some technical nature of such issues – the message is clear : most japanese are reluctant to return to economic trajectories before “ abenomics ” is not .
when abenomics is the first arrow of the fiscal stimulus – the fiscal stimulus program – the asset market responded positively .
the second arrow of abenomics – monetary easing – reinforced this effect .
in the last two years , the stock market ’ s market capitalization has almost doubled , enabling consumers ’ wealth to grow .
moreover , the yen has depreciated by nearly one-third against the dollar , from around 80 yen to nearly 120 yen , leaving japan ’ s export industries booming .
more encouraging is the evolution of labor markets , unlike in asset markets , which reflect outcomes , not just expectations .
here , too , there is good news .
labor markets have been consolidated , unemployment remains at 3.5 % , and the ratio for job seekers and job seekers is higher than in 1 % .
to be sure , there are some setbacks : japan ’ s gdp shrank in second and third quarters .
but this downward fall in the consumption tax ( from 5 % to 8 % ) will not be blamed for abenomics .
indeed , abe is just following a law that was passed by the previous democratic government of japan ’ s government .
the first two arrows of abenomics were aimed at stimulating demand – and they are extremely effective .
while the consumption-tax hike will be needed to keep the two arrows flying smoothly , unfortunately , the increase has been hindering both of these policies .
the good news is that the tax hike is only temporary , and will soon begin to disappear , with industrial production approaching full capacity .
when demand begins to exceed supply , demand-side stimulus policies will become ineffective , beginning with the third arrow of abenomics : growth-enhancing structural reforms .
such reforms are necessary to boost productivity growth and improve japan ’ s economic competitiveness .
four imperatives stand out .
the first priority should be to eliminate – or at least reduce – the vast number of government regulations that are needed to curb economic dynamism .
the current system is so cumbersome that it will take more than 30 years to open a new medical school in tokyo .
likewise , flights to 羽田机场 转接 , a convenient conduit for the tokyo city area , were restricted .
this is certainly not a recipe for long-term economic prosperity .
moreover , the japanese government should intensify negotiations on the trans-pacific partnership ( tpp ) , which has already been involved in the negotiations , from mexico to the united states to vietnam .
such a partnership would improve japan ’ s trade prospects considerably , including in sensitive sectors like agriculture , where exports of rapid consumer goods like flowers and vegetables would benefit .
japan ’ s leaders must also expand the labor force that is severely constrained by its rapid aging .
in the absence of large-scale immigration , japan is not ready to open up immigration , and a relatively simple solution would be to integrate more women into the workforce .
finally , abe ’ s government must cut the corporate-tax rate to align it with international standards .
in an increasingly intense battle against foreign investment , reducing corporate tax rates will actually increase japan ’ s tax revenue , by driving firms to invest their vast cash reserves .
now that abe ’ s government has received a new mandate for japanese voters , it must follow through on its promise – a firm and comprehensive undertaking of structural reform .
this will require some sacrifices .
in fact , japanese households are already suffering the hard way that their consumption-tax hikes are raised .
the next step in abe ’ s government is to use its political capital to 制服 the vested interests of vested interests – including political and business .
this means forcing firms to abandon some of the special tax benefits that they currently enjoy .
politicians must engage in the taxpayer identification system .
and government officials have to abandon some of their rights .
if these groups come together with japanese citizens to accept a reasonable sacrifice , abe ’ s government will fulfill its promise and build a thriving economy .
for the sake of japan ’ s entire interests – not to mention a world economy that needs new sources of dynamism – that promise is worth fulfilling .
the missing arrow of abenomics
tokyo – soon after japanese prime minister shinzo abe took office in 2012 , he introduced a policy of massive fiscal stimulus and aggressive monetary easing .
since then , japanese policymakers have been working to launch what abe calls the third “ arrow ” of the third “ arrow ” : a major reform program in important industries , and to dismantle the structural barriers to growth .
but focusing on public policy allows the “ 第四支 arrow ” – the private sector – to be hollowed out .
this is unfortunate , because the government can not address japan ’ s ills alone .
annual productivity growth is extremely weak , and less than 2 % over the past 20 years , which suggests that opportunities are missed , and costs are declining .
japan ’ s productivity plummeted in the entire economy ; labor and capital productivity in almost all sectors – even in japan ’ s signature advanced manufacturing sector – are stagnating .
labor productivity in the transport sector , for example , is roughly half that of germany .
this trend implies that annual gdp growth will averaged only 1.3 % by 2025 , and a third decade of stagnation .
this outcome coincided with adverse demographic trends – and will amplify the effect of the latter – to limit fiscal revenues and increase costs for universal health care and pensions .
whether japan can escape this trajectory depends on individual companies ’ decision to invest , change workplace policies , adopt new technologies , and try to do business .
abe ’ s structural reforms will take time , and the political will to implement , but japanese companies must not wait .
they can and must act , not to mention government change .
in many cases , bottlenecks are not regulation , but from entrenched ways of doing business .
new research by the mckinsey global institute examines japan ’ s advanced manufacturing sectors , retail , financial services , and health care – all of which have significant untapped productivity potential .
first , japanese firms must become more integrated into the global arena .
exports to the fastest-growing overseas market are clearly one way to overcome sluggish domestic demand .
but , rather than just selling products abroad , japanese firms need to expand their operations and organize a wider international 人才网 .
this process must first understand what customers want and are determined to provide solutions accordingly .
managing strict closed r & d operations must become more liquid , open , and more open to customers and suppliers .
japanese companies also need to improve their capabilities in areas such as marketing , pricing , and talent .
while some of japan ’ s top-performing companies are performing well in these areas , most are still severely lacking .
to compete in global markets , they need to achieve similar consistency with traditional areas of strength .
many japanese companies have yet to digitize the paper and update outdated information-technology systems .
other companies can move beyond basic digitization to next-generation technologies ( 如大 analytics ) and benefit from it .
companies can also address labor shortages with smart software systems and robotics .
manufacturers can expand or replace assembly lines with technologies such as the internet and 3d printing .
more broadly , japanese companies must organize for performance and discipline .
as policy changes unleash market forces , businesses will face greater competition .
some firms may need to restructure or exit unprofitable markets ; some companies may have to mergers with mergers and acquisitions to achieve economies of scale .
finally , shareholders and executives should tie their performance to incentives .
some large japanese companies have started to transform their traditional 年资 model into performance-based pay structures .
other companies should follow suit .
promoting younger , more diverse talent can be injected into new ideas .
if japan ’ s private sector raises the challenge , it could push the economy into a faster growth path .
a company ’ s 创新奖 has forced competitors to make more competition , thereby boosting the entire industry .
for example , toyota introduced more efficient production processes in the 1950 ’ s and 1960 ’ s , and was ultimately adopted by the entire auto industry .
japan should not meet the future annual gdp growth rate of 1.3 % , and it can reach about 3 % annual growth by 2025 .
doing so would require a doubling of labor productivity , but it remains achievable .
more than half of growth gains can be achieved by adopting the best practices used in global companies , and technology can fill most of the remaining vacancies .
japanese business leaders need to combine big thinking with detail and detail .
they need to create innovative products , penetrate new markets , and invest actively in equipment , technology , and talent , while careful review of every aspect of their operations .
traditional ways of doing business must be abandoned .
but there is plenty of room for progress , spurring faster economic growth .
huge trade flows , the rise of billions of new consumers in the emerging world , and technological breakthroughs are transforming the global economy rapidly .
japan could turn this wave of disruption into opportunity and escape its current trajectory .
单恋 russia

the berlin consensus ?
hong kong – my recent visit to berlin recalls my own last visit , in the summer of 1967 , in the summer of 1967 , when i would continue to divide and suppress the wall of the entire german society .
now , with the german people ’ s hard work and the sacrifice of unity , berlin has become dynamic , and the new economic thinking centers ( the institute for the new economic thinking ) are right to set the stage for the meeting .
the theme of the conference is the “ lost of paradigm , ” more than 300 economists , political scientists , 者 , and ecological scholars , and the challenges posed by the challenges of today ’ s rising inequality , rising unemployment , global financial dislocations , and 气候变化 .
almost all delegates agree that the old paradigm of neoclassical economics has failed , but there is no consensus on how to replace it .
as the nobel laureate economist amartya sen noted in the meeting , europe ’ s crisis stems from four failures – political , economic , social , and intellectual .
the global financial crisis – beginning with the sub-prime subprime crisis in the united states in 2007 and eventually became europe ’ s sovereign-debt ( and banking ) crisis – raises questions that we can not afford to answer , owing to excessive specialization and fragmentation .
and , to be sure , our world has become far more complex , so that it can not be explained by any simple , 高度 theory of economic , technological , demographic , and environmental changes .
particularly important , the rise of emerging markets has challenged western mores and inductive logic .
as a result , we can predict outcomes in the context of the principle ( law ) and the causes .
by using 归纳法 , we can infer the principles of the middle .
the idea of the east , by contrast , is 因式 , from pragmatism to guessing the next step .
溯 is pragmatic because it is pragmatic , focusing only on outcomes , by pointing out the principles , and thus setting out why .
for example , the science theory is written by the victors , and it was influenced by a particular 时代背景 and the social dimension of the time .
the free-market ideology evolved from anglo-saxon theorists ( many of them from scotland ) , and they are moving to the new shores of the world , allowing individuals with wealth to feel that consumption will grow indefinitely .
the continent ’ s ideas are mainly in the quest for urbanization and the pursuit of social order , which emphasizes institutional analysis of political and political systems .
as a result , neoclassical economics was largely influenced by newton and descartes ’ s the physical physics of the nineteenth century , from 定性分析 to quantifying human behavior , assuming that these actions are both rational and irresponsible .
this idea of “ 预先 equilibrium ” – the belief that markets always self-correcting – leads to policy paralysis until the great depression hit , and john maynard keynes argued that the gap between the unemployment rate and the consumption of output was taken seriously .
by the 1970 ’ s , the neo-classical equilibrium school was persuaded to persuade keynesians that “ finance is just a 包装纸 ” in the real sector , and thus little knowledge of the destabilizing role of financial markets .
economists like hyman minsky tried to correct this mistake , but then led the profession as the champion of milton friedman and the smallest governments , such as milton friedman , which was only silent .
but then the technology , demographics , and globalization of globalization have brought unexpected challenges to neoclassical economics .
with the leverage of the world ’ s advanced countries through the leverage provided by derivatives , 40 billion of the world ’ s population has begun to enter middle-income status , not only for global resources , but also for environmentally ecological sustainability .
the same is true not only for the west , but also in the east .
the historian 黄仁宇 黄仁宇 explained in 1987 about china :
“ as the world enters modern times , most countries that bear the brunt of internal and external pressure must be rebuilt to build governance models based on a commercial model based on the rules of commerce ... but that is a good thing . ”
the renewal process will affect the two classes and inevitably need to reintroduce institutional ties between the two .
comprehensive destruction will be the norm ; and it often requires decades of work .
using historical frameworks , we can see a new , multipolar global system that produces complex structural structures that interact with many of the country ’ s inflation , europe ’ s debt , and even the arab spring .
we are witnessing a wide range of simultaneous global convergence ( the narrowing of income , wealth , and knowledge gaps among countries ) and local divergence ( increasing income , wealth , and knowledge gaps within countries ) .
adaptive systems struggle between evolving order and innovation .
as the british philosopher bertrand russell put it : “ security and justice require centralized government control , which is bound to expand as a global government if it is to be effective .

the big opportunity for smallholder farmers
new york – the g-8 ’ s program of $ 20 billion in smallholder farmers , launched at the recent summit in l ’ aquila summit in l ’ aquila , italy , may be a historic breakthrough against hunger and extreme poverty .
if this new funding is serious , africa ’ s food production will increase substantially .
in fact , the new plan and other health , education , and infrastructure are likely to be the most effective measure of the millennium development goals , the international agreement on the millennium development goals , which set extreme poverty , disease , and hunger into half by 2015 .
in 2006 , i led the millennium development goals under secretary general kofi annan to manage the united nations millennium development goals .
“ smallholder farmers ” are the basis for this project , and the term “ smallholder ” is the name of farmers in africa , latin america , and asia that are not more than one-tenth of farmers ( 2.5 acres ) .
they are hungry because they are unable to buy the high-yield seeds , fertilizer , irrigation equipment , and other tools that increase productivity .
this has led to a dearth of crop yields , and it is not enough .
their poverty causes low agricultural productivity , while low farm productivity has exacerbated poverty .
this creates a vicious circle , technically known as the poverty trap .
the vicious circle of the 饥饿 working group , led by the united nations millennium development initiative , should be broken , under the auspices of the two world ’ s leading scientists , and the group ’ s conclusions should be broken .
the millennium plan proposed a dramatic increase in global funding for this area , which annan ’ s call for the launch of a green revolution in africa and donor countries was on the agenda in 2004 .
many of us , especially the current un secretary-general ban ki-moon , have made hard efforts to achieve this goal , with the secretary-general repeatedly claiming that the global food , financial , and energy crisis caused by the global food , financial , and energy crises of the past two years was particularly problematic .
the g-8 declaration reflects these efforts , of course , with us president barack obama , spanish prime minister josé luis rodríguez zapatero , australian prime minister josé 陆克文 , the world bank president robert 伯曼 , the european commissioner for european commissioner , and others .
the key is to get things done .
the lessons of history are clear .
the seed and fertilizer ( and sometimes free , delivery ) of smallholder farmers to smallholder farmers will produce lasting results .
not only can food be raised in the short term , but farmers can use high incomes and better health to accumulate a wide range of wealth : cash surpluses , soil nutrients , livestock , and health care and education .
the accumulation of assets , in turn , will kick-start local credit markets , such as micro-finance firms .
farmers can buy money in ways that make loans or improve their creditworthiness .
there is now agreement on the need to help smallholder farmers , but there are problems in practice .
the main risk now is that the “ bureaucracy ” is trying to compete for $ 20 billion in funding , to spend as much as possible on conferences , expert consultations , administrative costs , reports , and more meetings .
the “ partnership ” of donor countries is likely to be costly and expensive , with no effect on any delay .
if donor governments do value the outcome , they should take money from 30 or more independent bureaucratic aid agencies to manage them , and the authorities , most obviously , are in washington the world bank and the united nations international fund for agricultural development .
these two agencies will have billions of dollars in poverty reduction .
the famine in the region , especially in africa , offers the details of the national action plan , which provides details about how to use donor funds to provide high-yield seeds , fertilizer , irrigation , irrigation , warehouses , and advice advice .
an independent expert panel would review the national program ’ s scientific and managerial coherence .
if the plan passed , the fund ’ s funding will quickly be disbursed .
then , each national program is monitored , audited , and evaluated .
this approach is straightforward , effective , accountable , and scientifically sound .
the recent two successful donors are using this approach : a successful vaccine for vaccines for children in the global vaccine , as well as the global fund for aids , tuberculosis , and malaria providing support for these deadly diseases .
both institutions have saved millions of lives over the past decade , paving the way for a new and more efficient approach to development assistance .
it is not surprising that many un and affluent aid agencies compete for this .
but such contests are often in power , not in the most effective way to help the poor .
as a result , obama , rudd , zapatero , and other visionary leaders can make a significant difference by fulfilling their commitments at the g-8 summit .
