a common agricultural policy
the netherlands – born of the common agricultural policy ( cap ) in 1957 – is now more than 50 years old , and the european commission is proposing a health check on its middle-aged offspring .
while the work involved was intended immediately , the plan was implemented in 2013 , but we also need to think far more carefully .
common agricultural policy was originally designed to provide reliable food sources to the six member states of the eu , when it was food importers and tried to achieve certain self-sufficiency .
all citizens deserve good , healthy , and cheap food ; increased agricultural productivity would benefit rural areas and make farmers a match in the eu ’ s growing wealth .
the methods needed to achieve these goals are developed , and food security is achieved .
soon , the cap was viewed as the jewel in the crown in the european project .
with the eu ’ s evolution and expansion , the food system has become more complex , not only in terms of production , processing , supply-chain organizations , and wholesale and retail 配销 , but also on the use of new issues such as health , environmental protection , and a more serious surveillance .
in 1991 , a study by the dutch government policy committee , which faced a choice of choice , showed that reducing 50 % of farmland , 80 % of pesticides , and only half of the cost , the eu ’ s food supply needs to be met .
at the same time , pollution would be cut by 70 % , and greenhouse gases would be reduced by 70 % , thanks to lower elements of the surface surface surface .
given that these figures are only 15 members of the eu , the eu is now 27 , so its potential may become even larger .
a dutch analysis of land use has shown that , by using best technologies and ecological means on the best available land , food production could increase significantly .
so it is no longer surprising that the number of farmers needed has been significantly reduced .
from the standpoint of food security and the wealth of rural areas , the main means of a common agricultural policy are needed to introduce new policy proposals .
perverse subsidies must be abolished , and new subsidies for products such as bio-fuels have recently been reconsidered .
the status quo certainly needs to change .
the eu ’ s agricultural policy has been reduced too frequently to provide income guarantees to rural communities ; but this attitude is undermining change .
competition must be encouraged , because more rural businesses will strengthen rural communities , causing farmers to decline and farms become better off .
a common agricultural policy would encourage cleaner , more productive , and efficient agriculture .
for the eu ’ s standing in the world , there is another additional benefit : once developing-country farmers are assured , the world trade organization will be able to restart the doha round of doha negotiations .
and , as long as renewed policy is in place , the role of common agricultural policies in europe ’ s political and social integration can be restored .
but such renewal can not be left at the mercy of global markets , because it may not necessarily benefit european agriculture and society .
if markets are “ 失当 , ” farmers are trapped in poverty and will be ignored in europe .
this is a real enough danger to policymakers , who should be seriously concerned about reforming agricultural policy under five important principles .
the eu needs a knowledge and innovation policy that strengthens european agriculture ’ s competitiveness .
this policy has been successful in the netherlands , which has contributed much to the development of the country ’ s agribusiness .
ten of the 21 branches of the dutch agricultural firm , including gardening , 观赏植物 , 种用 potatoes , and 小牛肉 , are among the largest industries in the country ’ s economy and trade balance .
as a whole , the eu ’ s policy of promoting scientific excellence and a more consistent study of more consistency within the european intellectual system would boost agricultural competitiveness and help food security and sustainable development .
and europe needs a restructuring policy on land use .
many structural improvements in the european level have been funded , but agricultural production and land use are not .
the development of agricultural actors will compliment the european ecological structure .
three and three policy responses to the european food system are joint calculations of production , processing , distribution , logistics , and retail .
consumption patterns are also integral to such systems .
preliminary studies by the european science foundation – “ the outlook for the european food system ” – would provide a helping policy for the eu .
in a world of rapid urbanization , 都市型 farming can produce high-quality agricultural products with a small amount of land .
this provides a answer to how to meet the growing demand for food , while providing a answer to environmental vice versa .
5 and new cap should include a solution that protects europe ’ s landscapes .
but not everywhere , cultural heritage should be preserved , and it should not be ignored .
and it should not be a defensive policy that focuses on poor-quality land .
these five key principles involve stark choices , but they may require less money for european taxpayers , not more .
they will make real contributions to cleaner , more productive , and efficient agriculture and land use , and they can carry out social needs .
the breakthrough of hunger
new york – today ’ s world hunger crisis is more than unprecedented .
nearly a billion people are suffering from chronic hunger – a population that is likely to increase 100 million years ago .
spain is leading global leadership in combating hunger , which will invite world leaders to converge madrid in late january to move words .
with spain ’ s leadership and un secretary general ban ki-moon , several donor governments are proposing to concentrate their financial resources in order to enable the world ’ s poorest farmers to grow more food , thereby escaping poverty traps .
the benefits of donor support would be remarkable .
africa , haiti , and other impoverished regions are currently planting crops without high-yield seeds and fertilizer .
the result is that food production ( corn ) is about one-third more than in the case of better agricultural inputs .
african farmers produce only about a ton of food per hectare per hectare , compared to a large number of chinese farmers using fertilizers .
african farmers know that they need fertilizer , only to afford it .
with donor help , they can use fertilizer .
at that point , these farmers would not only feed families , but also begin to earn market income and save the future .
with a few years of savings , these farmers could eventually become banks with bank credit , or enough cash to purchase necessary inputs on their own .
a broad consensus today is the need to finance africa ’ s small farmers ( with two hectares or less of land , or poor livestock dwellers ) .
one of the un secretary general ’ s guidelines concluded last year that africa ’ s agricultural sector will need to finance roughly four million donor contributions annually – roughly four times the size of the existing size – with improved seeds , fertilizer , irrigation , and extension training .
beyond direct aid to small farms , donors should help to develop more of the necessary r & d , thereby developing more variety of new high-yield seeds , especially to foster a temporary crop that can tolerate temporary flooding , excess nitrogen , 盐质 soil , pests , and other sustainable food production .
today ’ s technologies help the poor , while investing in better technologies in the future is the best division of labor .
the return on research and agriculture , such as the international rice research institute and the international maize and wheat research institute , has produced a research center for the study of “ green revolution ” in asia .
these centers are not well known , but they are heroes .
dozens of low-income , 赤字 countries ( and perhaps 40 to 40-50 ) have announced emergency plans to increase food production in small farms , but they are powerless to support the lack of donor funds .
these countries have asked the world bank to finance the world bank , and the bank has been engaged in a new “ global response to food crisis ” in 2008 .
but the bank ’ s funding is also inadequate in meeting these countries ’ emergency needs , and it will have to limit aid to aid , making it a small fraction of what it needs to be effective and efficient funding .
at the same time , nearly a billion people are trapped in hunger .
many donor countries claim that they are prepared to increase funding for small agriculture , but now seek a proper mechanism for implementation .
the current aid structure is inadequate .
the bilateral and multilateral aid agencies are highly fragmented , and their size is inadequate , both individually and collectively .
while many professionals have worked hard , the response to the hunger crisis remains inadequate .
the 2008 planting seasons took the same step , and the additional aid that poor farmers received during this period remains very little .
african countries are quietly seeking the small amounts of funding needed to purchase fertilizer and improved seeds .
as the advisory board member of the spanish government , my colleagues and i recommended that donors pool their money into the same international account that we call “ financing coordination mechanisms . ”
these pooled funds enable farmers in poor countries to obtain much-needed fertilizer , improved seeds , and small-scale irrigation devices .
poor countries can obtain immediate and predictable financing for agricultural inputs from a single account rather than with dozens of separate and highly fragmented donor donors .
by pooling financial resources to a single FCM , the government can maintain the administrative costs of a lower bailout program , and the flow of aid flows would be guaranteed , while poor countries do not have to negotiate for their assistance .
the time for business is over .
donors promised to double aid funds by 2010 , but they are still a long way off .
indeed , over the past two decades , they have actually cut aid for agricultural programs , and only now have started to return to normal .
at the same time , one billion people live in the shadow of hunger every day .
i need a breakthrough , with a demonstration effect , public , clear , and persuasive ; it can inspire public and emotional resources and demonstrate success .
we can create history in madrid when the world ’ s richest and poorest countries work together to seek solutions to the global hunger crisis .
the lives of the billion poorest people depend on it .
a breakthrough opportunity for global health
new york – every year , millions of people die from preventable and treatable diseases , especially in poor countries .
in many cases , life-saving drugs can be produced cheaply , but cost them at low cost .
more people die simply because they lack treatment or vaccines , which is why it is too late for the world ’ s talent talent and limited resources to treat the poor .
this is reflected in the failure of economics and law to be corrected .
the good news is that the opportunity to change is now in place , mainly through a international initiative spearheaded by the world health organization , which will begin to address loopholes in intellectual property development and lack of access to the problem .
today , drugs are unavailable to the two main issues .
one is that drug costs are too high ; or , more correctly , the drug price is too high , while production costs are only a fraction of the price .
the poor have little money to spend , so , under existing arrangements , pharmaceutical companies have little incentive to investigate diseases that afflict the poor .
it didn ’ t have to be this way .
pharmaceutical companies argue that prices are necessary to finance research and development .
in the united states , however , most of the health relevant r & d activities are the government – or , through public support , directly financed by the public support foundation , the national science foundation , and indirectly financed by drug purchases ( such as medicare and medicaid programs ) .
part of the failure to finance government finance is not traditional markets ; many individuals ’ spending on prescription drugs is insured .
governments finance health research because improved medicines are a public good .
the resulting knowledge will prevent infectious diseases from preventing infectious diseases and harming the economy and human health , thereby benefiting everyone .
to be effective , it must be shared as widely as possible when it is acquired .
thomas jefferson famously compared knowledge to candles : using a candle to light the light , and does not diminish the light of the first one .
by contrast , this makes all things brighter .
but , in the us and most of the world , drug prices are still high and the spread of knowledge is severely constrained .
this is because the patent system that we created gives innovators a temporary monopoly on their 创之物 , which motivated innovators to help their knowledge of knowledge .
this system makes innovation profitable , and it does provide incentives for some kinds of research ; but pharmaceutical companies have been able to innovate , and the incentives that they receive are not necessarily compatible with social returns .
in the health sector , it is more profitable to work toward “ saturation ” drugs than to develop a cure .
the patent system may even be counterproductive , because the most important input in research is the leading idea , while the patent system encourages secrecy .
the solution to the problem of high prices and research is to replace the current model with the government incentives fund .
with a reward system , innovators are rewarded for new knowledge , but they are no longer a monopoly of new knowledge .
as a result , the forces of competitive markets will ensure that , as long as drugs are developed , they can be accessed as low as possible ( rather than inflated monopolies ) as a patient .
fortunately , some us lawmakers have strong interest in this approach .
the prize for the hiv/aids act , which senator bernie sanders has proposed , is just the beginning .
the sanders bill includes an important part of the effort to encourage open-source research , which would push existing research models from secrecy to sharing .
but , globally , our innovation system will require much more change .
the world health organization ’ s effort to promote broad reforms at the international level is crucial .
this spring , the world health organization released a report that includes a solution similar to that of sanders ’ s bill – the world health organization ’ s solution .
one thing is important : using research and development to meet developing countries ’ health needs ( “ r & d ” in developing countries ) , there is a comprehensive approach to allocating health research in developing countries , including the government ’ s mandate to health research , and the international forum for monitoring the most pressing needs ; and monitoring the world ’ s most pressing needs .
in late may , the international community will begin to implement these ideas at the world health organization ’ s congress , which will be a moment of hope for world health .
reforming the innovation system is not just an economic issue .
in many cases , it is a matter of life and death .
it is therefore vital to decouple r & d incentives from drug prices , encourage greater sharing of scientific knowledge .
for the world , the world health organization ’ s proposal has been a rare opportunity to revamp long-standing and persistent injustices on health inequalities ( and , more broadly , a new model of global public goods that are appropriate to the age of globalization ) .
we must not let this opportunity slip away .
india ’ s 换防
singapore – in august , raghuram rajan was appointed governor of the reserve bank of india .
to some extent , it was a declaration that many expected – after all , rajan was considered the most famous indian economist .

absent-minded killers
as a species , humans have a large self-control problem .
we humans are now so 大肆 , hunting , logging , and planting crops around the world that we are actually moving other species from the planet to the planet .
we are extremely desperate to take all of what we can take from the nature of nature and leave little for other creatures .
when the world ’ s governments first pledged to address human-induced global warming in 1992 , they also vowed to prevent the extinction of other species .
the convention on biological diversity , adopted in rio de janeiro , confirms that “ biodiversity is a common concern for humankind . ”
the signatories agreed to conserve biodiversity through saving species and their habitats , and use biological resources ( for example , forests ) to use biological resources .
in 2002 , the treaty ’ s signatories went further , pledging to “ slash the current loss of biodiversity ” by 2010 .
unfortunately , as with so many international conventions , the convention on biological diversity is largely unknown , and has not been promoted without being promoted .
this omission is human tragedy .
few cash inputs are needed , and even in fundamental need , we can preserve the nature of nature and thus protect our own lives and livelihoods .
we are not the only ones who must kill other species , but we are too negligent to do so .
consider several notorious examples .
rich countries like spain , portugal , australia , and new zealand have fishing fleets that are so-called “ bottom trawling . ”
bottom trawling is dragging heavy weight off the ocean at the bottom of the ocean , thereby destroying a large number of proven and endangered marine species in the process .
because bottom trawling is a “ low-cost ” approach to fishing fisheries in some deep waters , some complex and unique ecology , most notably underground underground , is cut off .
one species called 橙连鳍 , which is used for commercial fishing only about 25 years , but is already on the verge of collapse .
similarly , in many parts of the world , tropical rainforest has been cleared to pasture land and food crops .
the result is a massive loss of habitat and the destruction of species , with small economic benefits at the expense of huge social costs .
after being cut off in a rainforest , soils often lose nutrients quickly , unable to feed crops or 让 grasses with nutritious meals .
as a result , new pasture or farmland is quickly abandoned , with no opportunity to return to its unique ecosystems .
bottom trawlers should simply be shut down ; compensation to other activities during the transition to the fishing industry is easy and expensive .
deforestation , on the other hand , is best stopped by economic incentives .
simple restrictions on development land may not work , because farm households and communities will be tempted to avoid the temptation of legal restrictions .
on the other hand , fiscal stimulus may be successful , because cutting down grazing land is not profitable , leaving farmers abandoning payments to protect their land .
many rainforest countries have proposed a 提议 fund in recent years to create a 雨林 fund for small farmers to protect the forests .
a well-designed fund would slow or halt deforestation , protect biodiversity , and reduce carbon dioxide emissions from burning forests .
at the same time , small farmers will receive a steady income , which they can use to improve household wealth , education , and health .
beyond eliminating bottom trawling and creating a global fund for avoiding deforestation , we should designate a global network of marine conservation areas that prohibit fishing , 划船 , pollution , 挖泥 , drilling , drilling , and other harmful activities .
these areas can not only recover species , but also provide 生态效益 areas to the adjacent regions .
we also need a regular scientific process to demonstrate the world ’ s evidence of species prosperity and extinction , just as the process of climate change is .
politicians do not listen to individual scientists , but when hundreds of scientists have spoken , they have to do so .
finally , countries should negotiate a new framework in 2010 to slow human-induced climate change .
climate change , no doubt , is one of the greatest threats to species ’ survival .
when the earth ’ s warming , rainfall , and storm patterns change dramatically , many species will be in a climate area that is no longer supporting it .
some species migrate , but , unless we take decisive action to stop climate change , other species ( for example , polar bears ) risk extinction .
these goals were possible until 2010 .
they are economically affordable , and they will eventually deliver significant net benefits .
most important , it would make us a global promise .
humans will destroy millions of other species and threaten our own future , and to believe that this is too painful .
doing with more
berkeley – in the united states , the goods that produce and deliver us are just three million workers .
everything we extract , cultivate , design , engineer , engineer , and transporting all things – always from a hotel kitchen to a customer in a hotel kitchen – is about 30 % of the us labor force .
the rest of us will spend time on planning and deciding what we make , and to fulfill our personal services , make our personal services , talk about each other , and track what we are doing .
and while we obviously have the capacity to produce much more than we need , we do not seem to be blessed with riches .
one of the paradox of our time is that workers and middle-class households continue to struggle for life in an era of unparalleled plenty .
people in the developed world want to meet their basic needs .
we have a lot of organic carbon to break our calories to us ; we have lots of vitamin and other nutrients to help us maintain health ; we have a lot of housing to keep us dry ; we have a lot of capital to keep us dry ; and we have a lot of entertainment to keep us warm .
we produce all of this , and we need less than two hours out of work home .
in 1930 , when keynes ’ s famous prediction predicted the “ economic problem , ” a struggle for survival could “ be resolved within a century or at least a solution . ”
yet there are no signs that american workers and the middle class are better off than they were 35 years ago .
more strangely , productivity growth does not seem to be accelerating as much as you expect ; in fact , productivity growth has slowed under john 费 , the federal reserve bank of san francisco and 王兵 .
growth prospects are even worse , because innovation hits a wall .
one way to reconcile changes in the job market with our experience of living and those statistics is to note that many things we produce are different from what we have made in the past .
for most of human history , what we produced can not easily be shared or used without permission .
what we previously made is what economists call “ rival ” or “ excludible ” goods .
“ competitive ” refers to two people ’ s inability to use the same product simultaneously .
“ excludible ” refers to the owners of products that can easily prevent others from using it .
these two features make it a great deal of bargaining power for those who control production and distribution , making it ideal for a market economy based on private property .
money naturally goes to places where utility and value – and these flows can easily be tracked in national accounts .
but many things we produce in the information age are neither competitive nor excludible – changing the entire situation .
the manufacture of the information age is difficult to impose ; their distribution is difficult to monetize ; and we lack the tools to track them easily in national accounts .
as a result , people are willing to see a growing gap between the quantity and the growth that the population pays for a given service .
in other words , we produce a much larger amount of production and consumption than economic indicators suggest – and those products are not adequately compensated .
this raises a set of unique problems .
to ensure the benefits of today ’ s and tomorrow ’ s workers , we must redesign our economic system to stimulate these new goods .
in addition to finding a way to record this new wealth , we need to find ways to make product demand work for those creators .
only by finding ways to measure the value of the goods we produce is we to sustain middle-class societies , not from the social tycoon and their services serfs .
giving academia fresh life
cambridge – academic freedom is a precious commodity that is essential to ensure that political or ideological forces do not impede truth .
but this does not mean that intellectuals should hide from academic 掩体 , and to protect ourselves from “ non-experts ” while allowing oneself to be rampant , allowing oneself to focus on other issues that are irrelevant to anyone .
we experts should explain ourselves to the outside world .
first , this means that researchers should work on their findings in ways that are accountable to their own findings , thereby ensuring that the use of public money and education benefits is in the interest of taxpayers .
the obligation of public research also ensures that the public is educated , not just the subject itself , but also to the practical workings of academic research .
academic books and journals often leave the impression that the truth is revealed through a neat , orderly , and logical approach .
but scientific research is far from pure terrain ; indeed , it is more like a battlefield , replete with errors of calculation , failure of trial , and ultimately discarded assumptions .
the road to the truth often goes hand in hand , and people who go to the truth often face intense competition and professional intrigue .
some argue that it is better to hide the facts .
in 2014 , for example , physicists who participated in the effort to participate in the project thought that they had detected 引力波 waves in the early days of the universe .
some of my colleagues fear that the news will affect confidence in other scientific predictions , such as climate change .
but is it really better to conceal the truth about the public than to create a transparent culture of science and scholarship ?
perhaps not .
in fact , it is possible to maintain an honest understanding of the status quo and create more space for innovation , in which a rational public accepts the inevitability of scientific risk , at the expense of research and development .
another way to ensure that academia continues to perform relevant innovations is to break the traditional boundaries of the discipline between disciplines – often born in these disciplines .
to achieve this , universities should upgrade their organizational structures to avoid clear frontiers of departments , in order to create a 艺术 , scientific , humanistic 统一体 .
universities should encourage students to learn more multidisciplinary courses in order to integrate experience and experience into new knowledge systems .
to make the process more sustainable , universities should ensure that the curriculum that it offers can help students adapt to new technologies that require rapid change in the labor market .
this means not only opening the course of innovation now , but also updating a new discoveries and trends in artificial intelligence , big data , and 基因 fields .
for professors , they should become mentors of future leaders in fields like science , technology , art , and humanities , rather than trying to bring students to their own academic mantle .
of course , the latter approach could be effective if the goal is to increase the availability of research programs and to ensure that their own ideas and views can survive .
but that is incompatible with academia ’ s basic mission .
the louder the echo chambers in academia face the consensus , the more it inspires the sense of self-awareness of those who do .
but history shows that , like albert einstein ’ s early career , it has sometimes been better to advance progress .
truth and consensus are not always one thing .
diversity of opinion – meaning diversity of gender , ethnicity , and background – is critical to supporting innovation and progress .
this is why the prize can not be used to strengthen mainstream opinion , instead of using them to encourage independent thinking and reward innovation .
but this does not mean that all views should be considered equal , meaning that other views should be explored , and that they are based on the only reference .
we academia can ’ t continue to look back at ourselves , busy celebrating our privileges and failing to look at the world in a new way .
to defend the free press , we must restore dialogue with the broader public and ensure that the correlation of our work is fully understood – including our own .

a new brain drain in science
dubai – in december 2013 , the nobel laureate economist peter higgs said that if he were in a position to work in academia today , “ i would not be considered the most efficient . ”
as a result of a breakthrough in 1964 , the higgs believes that no university today would hire him .
academics are familiar with the concept of “ publish or perish . ”
they must increasingly publish their work in peer-reviewed journals to climb the career ladder , keep the job , and keep the research on their institutions .
but what do those studies have to do with the scientists and other scholars who have little to do with the academic journals that can make or destroy academic careers today ?
scholars and organizations that have high rates of publication in well-known journals have a higher score on efficiency scores , and thus more rewarding in their careers and research funding .
but , sadly , the impact of their published field on the field of research can be measurable .
the incentives they face mean that quantity is often more important than quality .
academic journals determine the rankings of scientific research in scientific research , which leads to only hiring and retaining scholars who are efficient .
the resulting double problem raises a deeper problem : academic journals have become too large , and they encourage empirical research .
on the first issue , journals are gradually replacing institutions as the quality of academic outcomes .
scholars in almost any field who want to work in a “ 级 ” study must be published in a section of a 几本 杂志 .
the editorial boards of these journals increasingly favor positivist theoretical work – that is , research based on empirical data analysis .
qualitative research – such as 民族志 , participatory surveys , and case studies – is often framed as just a 适合 or C journals .
scholars who engage in empirical research are a significant advantage , because they can use efficient software and powerful computers to test their assumptions quickly and calculate the effects of different variables .
such jobs can also be reduced , because individual data sets can produce multiple journals .
to be sure , the use of technology , or the use of a more sophisticated software set and more sophisticated software , is a normal phenomenon .
but adoption of this quantitative approach should not be the only measure of measuring scientific excellence and shaping career trajectories .
the positivist trend today is particularly problematic for developing countries , where data sets are scarce , and often poor .
as a result , scientists working in developing countries face a prisoner ’ s dilemma : or study with rich countries that have rich data , or risk doing business in a professional and poorly adapted study .
scholars who have moved from rich countries like europe and north america to underdeveloped countries like the middle east often face such problems .
as researchers at my institution in abu dhabi know , conducting survey data for qualitative research may be feasible ; but the data that are collected from scratch are extremely difficult .
at this year ’ s international conference on science and technology , an african scholar of african soil reported that , in the field he studied , only 5 % of the publication works from african researchers .
but when he studied his research , he found that 50 % of his understanding of african soil came from african researchers , and the results of these researchers are unlikely to be published in international academic journals .
countries where english is not the lingua franca are particularly disadvantaged in science , not because their academic research is low , but because the science of english-language journals is a charge .
英语 academic journals are simply not subject to the same attention in science .
as a result , many countries can have limited research issues , so they must struggle to keep scientific talent in the country .
this is especially true in the middle east , where governments are working hard to diversify their economies , thereby enabling national economies to grow .
because the empirical research journals in english have reinforced the control of the professional success channels of scientists , developing countries must invest heavily in domestic data infrastructure to keep domestic researchers in a more competitive research place .
but even if – or especially – developing countries do have a serious impact on science .
because academic journals in the world ( most ) from the united states , scientists do not actually migrate as part of the new brain drain , scientists ’ focus on research , questions , and methodologies will turn out to be the 实证主义 study .
closing the financial services gap
kampala – last month , the united kingdom hosted the first-ever global disability summit , helping the world to focus on the needs of the disabled .
the agenda includes a focus on building equitable education , removing discrimination , and opening technology to the disabled – especially poor countries in the global south .
but there is a challenge that is not subject to concern that is often ignored : access to financial services .
this is an opportunity for an effort – not just for the world ’ s one billion disabled people , but also for institutions that should serve them .
increasing access to financial services is good for both business and economic growth .
according to research by barclays , if customers with disabilities can manage their money , economic vulnerability would be reduced , and overall economic health improves .
moreover , the so-called disability market has $ 1 trillion in disposable income , one of the largest potential customers in the world .
so why do most firms reverse the opposite ?
one reason is the lack of awareness .
with people with disabilities often less income than those with disabilities , service providers often lack the incentive to extend support to them .
but , with a growing share of the market ’ s potential , financial institutions are starting to adjust their product lines .
in the process , four issues must be addressed in order to reach customers with access to financial services .
for starters , financial-services companies must work harder to understand current and future clients ’ demand .
with better data , for example , banks in a market would improve access to mobile banking platforms .
in india last year , when it was in india , its employees developed a 语音 system to help a visual range of customers access online accounts .
second , engagement must not be limited to innovation ; it must also be extended to the labor market .
in short , financial-services industries should hire more people who are disabled , investing in 辅助 technologies and alternative and inspirational communication devices .
the need for diversity of employees is particularly acute in the us , where one-fifth of us people have disabilities .
third , it must always be incorporated into discussions about how to expand and strengthen financial independence .
in 2013 , the lloyds banking group established a focus group to examine the impact of dementia on clients ’ behavior , and that exchanges with customers culminated in the 章程 charter .
this innovative document specifies how banks should tailor products to 客户服务 clients .
future proposals should follow this collaborative model to ensure that all levels of decision-making are designed to be designed at all levels .
finally , governments should work to address this problem , following measures like the united kingdom , where the uk will be linked to funding for the disabled .
with the right support , these complex challenges can be made decisively ; for example , in uganda , where i work , the financial services that we use in the united kingdom to expand the disabled in rural areas have been expanded .
our vision is to encourage similar programs elsewhere .
already , 91 countries have signed an alternative protocol protocol on the right to the disabled , with sufficient political support for these projects .
the challenge now is to keep promises to action .
in the coming decades , the world ’ s disabled population will grow as medical advances make people living longer and healthier , healthier , more fulfilling lives .
putting the disabled in financial services and products is one of the best ways to prevent discrimination and promote long-term empowerment .
the full financial inclusion of the “ world ’ s fastest-growing minorities ” is slowly approaching .
the task among activists , advocates , enlightened business leaders , and policymakers is to emphasize successful social and economic interests .
surgery for everyone
boston – when i recently travel to india , i employed a 黄包车 黄包车 , i quickly discovered that the driver ’ s leg was a lame man .
a few weeks ago , the driver had been hit by a car in a busy and busy streets in new delhi .
while he has managed to get the medication from local pharmacies – a dramatic pain that could result from his leg – he has neither the time nor the money to see the surgeon .
this type of tragic calculus is striking .
according to the lancet , roughly 50 billion people – almost 70 % of the world ’ s population – are unable to secure safe , economic , and anesthetic services , and three million people are saddled with prohibitively high health costs .
unsurprisingly , the vast majority of the world ’ s poor : while low-income countries account for nearly 35 % of the global population , they account for just 3.5 % of the population .
financing is the biggest obstacle to universal health coverage – the united nations has been declared globally .
moreover , it may sound paradoxical that the best way to expand access to cover funds is to expand the reach of surgery .
relatively high health problems – such as injuries injuries and injuries caused by pregnancy-related complications – are one of the main causes of death and disability in low- and middle-income countries .
but untreated or untreated treatment , however , requires surgery also hurt economic productivity .
for example , according to the lancet study , failure to improve surgical treatment in developing countries could lead to $ 12.3 trillion of massive loss of economic output by 2030 .
failure to maintain strong surgical capacity may even weaken the economic gains made by middle-income countries , affecting about 2 % of gdp annually .
as a result , when a tough budget choices are faced , governments tend to be more inclined to fight for chronic and infectious diseases , leading to the plight of people like me .
but a growing body of evidence suggests that such views are not accurate .
when 哈佛大学医学院 researchers analyzed surgical interventions in low- and middle-income countries , they found a significant disconnect between economic assumptions and reality .
for example , they calculated that money spent on caesarean sections and joint surgeries would yield higher benefits than money spent on the management of hiv or heart disease .
to be sure , chronic and infectious diseases also need to take our attention ; we can not restructure the entire health system overnight , and we should not abandon those who care for the treatment of 疾病 diseases .
but reforms that focus more attention on the importance of surgery can boost economic productivity and help create a fairer health environment for all .
first , the health ministry and the physician should formally recognize that surgical and anesthetic care are an important component of universal health coverage .
to prove this , health-care agencies should strengthen their collection and analysis of data outcomes , thereby increasing the transparency of data like mortality and morbidity , and strengthen accountability .
the lancet commission ’ s core indicators of “ preparedness ” for surgical treatment , “ implementation ” , and “ 术后 ” can be used to guide decisions about the delivery of services .
second , to focus on risk and guard against costly overruns , countries that are considering universal coverage policies should be incorporated into surgical care programs in public funding programs .
while part of the funding for expanding surgical services can come from taxation , health-care providers should also explore innovative financing methods – the “ social justice model ” that people can pay according to their economic conditions .
finally , in order to streamline resource use and strengthen surgical capacity , hospitals should explore the task of sharing , 将 病例 cases to nurses and physician assistants .
longer-term strategies include investing in medical education to build the ranks of doctors and surgeons .
vibrant and ambitious young people have been driving the strong economic rise in recent decades .
one of the most effective ways to sustain this growth and development is to ensure that the security and cheap care , including surgery , can be included .
while the cost of providing surgical services may be high , the cost of providing a surgical services is no less costly .
polluters must pay
new york – when oil companies and their partners in the united kingdom and its co-authors , swiss drilling , have triggered oil spills in the gulf of mexico in 2010 , the us government not only asked bp companies to take the charge of cleaning up the cost , but also accept criminal penalties for the disaster .
bp has already committed more than $ 20 billion to cleaning up remediation and penalties .
according to a deal last week , bp would pay the largest criminal penalty in the us – $ 45 billion .
the same environmental accident should be used to clean up standards for international companies operating in poor countries , which are often so large that many companies are so large that many companies are at the exclusion of the exemption , and that the environment has little or no responsibility for the environment .
as we enter a new era of sustainable development , impunity should turn to responsibility .
polluters must pay the price , whether in rich or poor countries .
big companies should assume responsibility for their actions .
nigeria has been a case of corporate environmental impunity .
for decades , major oil companies , including shell , exxonmobil , and chevron , have been extracting oil in the niger delta , a fragile ecological environment with freshwater swamp forests , mangroves , 低地 rainforests , and coastal barrier islands .
this fertile habitat supports extraordinary biodiversity – or , in the case of oil companies , to undermine it – and more than three million inhabitants depend on the ecosystem .
twenty years ago , the world ’ s natural protection of the niger delta as a region with vast oceans and coastal and coastal diversity – 树种 , fish , birds , and mammals – makes it a high priority .
yet the alliance also points out that , because the region is rarely protected or protected by the region , its biodiversity is at stake .
a study estimates that these companies have accumulated roughly 100 million barrels of oil over the last 50 years – twice the size of the bp spill .
the data are not accurate : there have been hundreds of thousands of oil spills over the past 50 years – often in the absence of detailed records , and the volume of oil spills is often hidden or even ignored by companies and governments .
indeed , just as bp has suffered a new criminal penalties , exxonmobil reported the oil pipeline leak in the niger delta .
the environmental degradation of the delta is only part of a long list of events : corrupt companies with corrupt governments to take advantage of self-interest .

saving capitalism from economics 101
the introductory course is often taught in a much reassuring sense : if markets are allowed to play out , good outcomes will be good – such as productivity growth , wage growth , and widespread shared prosperity .
unfortunately , as james guo , i put it in my book economics , in his book economics : the rise of bad economics and inequality , “ introductory economics ” goes far beyond all aspects of the discipline , or even to guide sensible policies .
markets are likely to be good , but they are also vulnerable to a wide range of abuses – some of the leading private-sector workers .
this is not theoretical questions ; it is at the heart of our current policy debates , including the newly proposed legislation .
a central problem is that market incentives reward self-interested private behavior , without considering the interests or costs of society .
we often overlook the spillover effects of our actions on others or “ externalities . ”
the “ primary economics ” textbook , while indeed in some instances of events ( for example , pollution ) has been discussed , and it is widely agreed that , if clean air , clean water , and reducing other pollutants , it requires regulating environmental behavior .
unfortunately , president donald trump ’ s administration is not in this “ general agreement , ” because it is busy rolling back environmental protections in a series of activities .
the new york times reports 76 procedures that are currently underway .
the idea of such a policy directly stems from a few dozen minutes of the “ economics 101 ” : 别去 the market .
in this case , the us has only a greater pollution – including more greenhouse-gas emissions .
there is a deeper problem here .
one of the main assumptions of introductory economics is that firms should maximize their profits , and that is the best of their shareholders and societies .
but the concept of such a “ firm ” is that people who are organized in a particular form are people – not businesses – who are making decisions .
to understand the nature and impact of these decisions , we need to focus on the incentives of corporate executives and board members .
since the 1970 ’ s , those who run firms have increasingly become more focused on paying salaries , stock options , and stock options .
stock values have grown significantly , but most of the richest 10 % are among the richest .
at the same time , median wages have barely increased – much more than during the period since world war ii , when productivity increases and wages grow steadily .
today , businesses are serving the interests of top managers and board members .
investors sometimes gain good benefits , though there are plenty of cases in which insiders take excessive advantage of risky practices or implement other more fraudulent practices to capture their benefits .
the idea that the compensation committee will pay a corresponding salary on the basis of a real showing on some indicators is almost comical .
this is the context in which senator elizabeth warren of massachusetts has proposed new accountable capitalism .
very large firms need federal permits ( rather than a current state permit ) , which would include specific obligations – especially the interests of all companies , including workers .
to make this more meaningful and overall transparency , ordinary ( 非 ) employees should be represented in the boardroom .
this approach works in germany , and germany is a country where workers are long respected .
warren also supports a proposal from john bogle , the founder of vanguard ( a common fund company company ) that requires major corporations to spend only on the overwhelming majority of shareholders and directors .
the basic legal theory behind these proposals is sound , and it is clear in a letter signed by robert 霍克 of cornell law and other distinguished figures .
big firms have been granted significant rights , including the limited liability of individual executives , and the pooling of large amounts of money from a group of 不 ( or corporate sponsors ) .
the first purpose was to enable the private sector to undertake large-scale venture investments that have broader potential consequences , such as building canals and railroads .
in fact , the enforcement of antitrust law has been dramatically reduced in recent years , under both republican and democratic administrations .
warren has proposed a broader rethink .
big companies can still make contributions , but they will need to take responsibility for their actions more transparently .
incentives for senior executives will adjust , and the operation will no longer be confined to fill their pockets .
workers will no longer be treated so badly , and more people may even begin to believe that the american dream of a shared prosperity can be shared .
under the accountable capitalism act , capitalism ’ s legitimacy – private ownership and reliance on market mechanisms – would be strengthened significantly .
as a result , it will be a final exam .
the absence of a centralized euro
cambridge – is the youth unemployment rate reaching 50 % in the eurozone countries , such as spain and greece , to say that it is a generation to sacrifice a single currency for a large number of countries that are unequal to each other .
if the answer is yes , would enlargement of the eurozone ’ s member states really help europe to achieve a clear goal of maximizing economic integration without achieving a politically integrated and comprehensive political unity ?
the good news is that economic research does have some effect on whether europe should use the single currency as a single currency .
the bad news is that , at least for large countries , the currency area is highly unstable , unless its borders and borders are equal .
after all , monetary union requires at least a confederation , with a tax and other policy power that is concentrated in the eurozone ’ s leaders .
what the nobel laureate winner robert mundell famously predicted in 1961 is that national and monetary borders need not overlap .
in his book the american economic review theory , the “ optimal monetary theory theory ” of the currency , mundell argued , the currency area could create a balanced equilibrium in exchange rates as long as workers move freely in the currency area .
the nobel laureate economist dan meade , who attributed an understanding of the importance of labor mobility to labor mobility , also noted that meade ’ s explanation for this view is too strict , especially when european integration appeared .
mundell did not emphasize the financial crisis , but he surmised that labor mobility is more important today than it was in the past .
unsurprisingly , workers are leaving the eurozone crisis , but the target is not necessarily a stronger northern bloc .
indeed , portuguese workers are fleeing to booming old colonies , such as brazil and macau .
irish workers are moving to canada , australia , and the united states .
spanish workers are flocking to romania , which has previously been the main source of agricultural labor in spain .
nonetheless , if liquidity within the eurozone can be similar to that of mundell ’ s ideal , today we will not see the spanish unemployment rate as low as 25 % of germany ’ s unemployment rate .
subsequent researchers began to recognize that successful monetary union would also have other key elements , which are difficult to achieve without deep political integration .
kenen argued in the late 1960 ’ s that if exchange-rate movements were not a shock absorber , the monetary union needs fiscal transfers as a way to share risk .
in normal countries , the national income tax constitutes a huge automatic stabilizer in the region .
in the us , when oil prices rise , incomes in texas and montana rise , which means that the old league will contribute more to the federal budget , thereby helping the rest of the us to escape the quagmire .
of course , there is no large central tax authority in europe , so this important automatic stabilizer is absent .
some european scholars have tried to argue that fiscal transfers like the us are not necessary , because , in theory , they can be achieved through financial markets .
this is a mistake .
kenen was mainly concerned with short-term transfers that smooth out cyclical ups and downs .
but , in a monetary union where income and development disparities vary widely , the time “ short-term ” is likely to be very long .
many germans now rightly feel that any financial transfer system could be permanent , just as italy ’ s northern league of southern italy did the last century .
indeed , for more than 20 years in germany , west germany still has not yet seen the costs of reunification .
later , maurice obstfeld pointed out that , in addition to fiscal transfers , monetary union would also require a clear definition of lender-of-last-resort rule .
otherwise , bank runs and debt panics will be rampant .
obstfeld have imagined a bank bailout scheme , but it is now clear that the state and the state of autonomous regions need the last lender of last resort .
given the premise made by 柯南 and obstfeld , even from mundell ’ s labor mobility , a logical corollary is that the monetary union can not survive without political legitimacy – most likely to be a regional election .
without a coherent european political framework , europe ’ s leaders are unlikely to be able to achieve large-scale transfers across countries .
today , european policymakers often complain that the eurozone would not suffer if the us financial crisis was not .
perhaps they are right .
but the financial system must be able to withstand shocks , even if it is a sharp shock .
europe may never be a “ optimal ” currency area , in any case .
but , without more far-reaching political and economic integration – and perhaps will not be included in the current eurozone member states – it may not be even that decade .

a roadmap for education 2030
london – earlier this year , i visited camp camps in jordan , where i met some children and told me what education means for them .
for syria ’ s young people who are forced to leave and lose everything , education matters much more than qualified or scores ; it relies on hope for the future .
and millions of children in the camp and millions of children worldwide are at the center of the international commission on financing for education worldwide .
i joined the committee last september , and it was committed to the fourth , sustainable development goals in the united nations sustainable development goals , to “ ensure inclusive and equitable quality education for all . ”
for too many children , this is a distant goal .
with so many development problems requiring us to focus on , policymakers should bear in mind that education is not just a good thing ; it is also a catalyst for many other development gains .
as the old african proverb goes , educating girls is the whole country .
ensuring high-quality education for children , especially girls , reduces child marriage , child labor , and exploitation .
education also has long-term benefits : in addition to increasing political participation , educated children can bring intellectual capital and pursue entrepreneurial opportunities after they grow up , thereby boosting economic growth .
overcoming the education challenge must begin with two principles of the united nations sustainable development goals .
first , “ all ” means that we must focus on lagging children .
millions of children are out of school because of their families or regions .
according to the un high commissioner for refugees , refugee children are five times more likely to keep out of school than children in the country .
bringing these children to school will require a new approach that goes to the exclusion of their exclusion , to make schools genuinely accessible and important .
the second is “ quality ” : education must be effective , so that children are actually learning .
for 21 million children who can not afford primary school , formal education is out of reach .
but , equally urgent , more than one-third of the primary-school age of primary-school age – 2.5 million people – is not learning .
half of these children are already in school at least four years .
we must eliminate the barriers to learning from classrooms and homes by improving the quality of teaching and classroom conditions , teaching parents how to support children .
upholding these two principles will require increased investment .
last year , unesco estimated that governments must double their education spending as a share of national income to complete 2030 .
this will require increased revenue from tax revenues and stronger and weaker taxes .
donor countries also need to follow through on their aid commitments and targeted aid .
less than a third of education aid , for example , has gone to africa , where the number of out-of-school children accounts for nearly two-thirds of the global population .
moreover , education budgets are often regressive , with almost half of spending in the poorest countries headed to the top 10 % of the population .
increased investment in education requires action in two key areas .
for starters , we need a fair financing , with more spending on early care and development , and in areas where returns are highest .
the budget must focus on the most excluded children , primary education must be free , and can be made to attend school .
we urgently need more transparency and accountability , so that budgets are visible and socially sound .
second , we need to strengthen domestic education systems so that governments regard the government as a guarantor of quality schools for citizens , rather than 自甘堕落 to external development institutions .
in particular , we should promote cooperation between governments and businesses to boost domestic educational education , eliminate illicit capital flows that impede government financing , such as tax evasion and cross-border money laundering .
with these priorities , the education council will issue its advice on september 18 , the un general assembly , and the un secretary-general will be able to act accordingly .
if we can use money and political will to ensure that each child , regardless of its income , location , or social status , is successful , the education council has succeeded .
to this end , our work can be done .
sustaining progress in transition countries
new york – in the world bank ’ s most recent book doing business , half of the east asian and central asian countries that participate in the global ranking are among the top 50 .
as a measure of economic maturity , doing business confirms what many international development circles have long known : the region is rising .
in the last decade , eastern europe and central asia have experienced a strong pattern of progress , relying on ambitious markets and public-sector reforms .
the question now is how to ensure that this progress – which has tripled the size of the middle class – is maintained .
signs of this region ’ s social and economic prosperity are everywhere .
in azerbaijan , income rose sharply in recent decades , with only 5 % of the population living below the poverty line – a proportion close to 50 % in 2002 .
in other countries , estonia ’ s per capita startups are among the third-largest in europe , one of the fastest internet speeds in the world .
but in our view of the region ’ s inevitable prosperity , structural bottlenecks are holding back progress , especially in the western balkans , southern caucasus , and parts of central asia .
to maintain the united nations sustainable development goals ( sdgs ) , the leaders must address three key issues .
for starters , the region ’ s economies need to become stronger incentives for smarter , more sustainable growth .
fossil-fuel subsidies , for example , should be reconsidered , because they impede investment in energy efficiency and impede the development of renewable technologies .
likewise , public financing of pension and welfare programs needs to be taxed to the labor force , while most of the region is suffering from unemployment ; and the western balkans have few jobs .
job creation is a pressing challenge for all countries .
second , in many countries , the marginalization of civil society is becoming narrower , as a threat to pluralism and accountability .
to prevent conflict , give voice to marginalized groups , tolerance , tolerance , and respect for human rights must be the core elements of governance .
finally , the region must develop a strategy to overcome the changes that automation and artificial intelligence have brought to the labor market .
leaders in some countries , particularly belarus , are seeking to shift economic output from heavy manufacturing to technology startups .
but national authorities can do more to boost resilience .
fortunately , governments , technology companies , civil-society groups , and journalists recognize the salience of these issues and are working together to build more transparent and accountable institutions .
in many countries , heads of government are using the sdgs to guide national planning and legislative reforms .
some central asian countries have even enshrined the sdgs in the development roadmap .
changes like these can help to translate development ambition into action .
in armenia , the government recently established the world ’ s first national sdg innovation laboratory , a joint partnership for “ accelerating ” the sdgs .
the initial research program will focus on increasing the tax collection , improving education systems , and boosting the renewable-energy industry .
meanwhile , moldova ’ s plan has used crowdfunding to raise millions of dollars from the diaspora to finance sustainable development projects .
a renaissance program includes a public plaza and expansion of a public plaza in the capital .
the region ’ s private sector is also actively engaged in sustainable development efforts .
from siemens ’ green heating and air conditioning systems to unilever ’ s “ equal pay ” policies , multinational companies operating in eastern europe and central asia regard sustainability and equality as a viable business model .
in just a few decades , people in eastern europe and central asia have experienced deep political and economic changes .
to capitalize on the development achievements that have already been made , countries and organizations must learn one another , according to local conditions .
this is the main topic for the istanbul development dialogue ( undp ) , which the united nations develops this week , at the united nations development programme .
as the united nations development programme ’ s strategy for 2018-2019 2018 points out , cooperation is a key component of sustainable development strategies .
if a country ’ s measure can be calculated by doing business in its borders , eastern europe and central asia have a bright future .
the region ’ s recent progress will not be accompanied by strong leadership that has changed the region ’ s economic , modern institutions .
the achilles ’ heel of trumponomics
new haven – donald trump ’ s economic strategy has serious shortcomings .
this will further crowd out national saving , leading to an already large widening trade gap .
this dynamic exposes the achilles ’ heel of trumponomics : blatant protectionism and protectionism and trade deficits that sustain us economic growth .
trump ’ s policies will not gain a strong and sound economy from their predecessors .
since the great recession , the pace of recovery has been only half the normal cyclical rebound – and the anemic pace of recovery is particularly disconcerting , given the magnitude of the contraction in 2008-2009 .
and saving , as the seed seed of the future , remains severely underfunded .
in 2006 , the so-called net national saving rate – the sum of 企业 firms , households , and governments combined – was just 2.4 % of national income .
although this has been an improvement in relative negative saving positions between 2008 and 2011 , it remains far from the 6.3 % average of the final three decades of the twentieth century .
this is important because it explains the pernicious trade deficits that trump continues to rail against .
lacking in saving and wanting to grow , the us must import surplus saving from abroad .
and the only way to attract this foreign capital is through massive current-account and trade deficits .
the numbers explain everything : since 2000 , the current-account deficit has widened to 3.8 % of gdp – nearly four times the gap between 1970 and 1999 .
similarly , net export deficits – the broadest measure of a country ’ s trade imbalance – have been 4 % of gdp since 2000 , compared to 1.1 % in the final three decades of the twentieth century .
trumponomics has the tendency to reverse the causality .
trumponomics has focused on the specific sources of trade deficits , such as china and mexico , but neglecting these bilateral deficits only a symptom of a deeper us saving problem .
assuming that the us is closing trade with china and mexico by imposing tariffs and other protectionist measures , including the renegotiation of nafta and the construction of border walls in mexico , it is the first and fourth largest source of trade deficits .
this will not solve america ’ s longstanding saving shortfall , which will redistribute the trade deficit from china and mexico to other countries – possibly a more costly producer .
as a result , the functional equivalent is to raise taxes on beleaguered middle-class families .
in short , multilateral issues can not be solved through bilateral approaches .
in 2015 , the us ran trade deficits with 101 countries – a multilateral problem emanating from a saving shortfall that can not be solved by “ treatment ” against specific countries .
this is not to say that america ’ s trading partners can get rid of unfair practices .
but it does mean that if the us does not start saving again , the hope of resolving the long-standing trade deficit – and the associated domestic job losses that are attributable to these imbalances – is limited .
alas , the situation becomes more complicated .
in the coming years , trumponomics may worsen america ’ s saving shortfall .
analysis by the tax policy center , the tax foundation , and moody ’ s analysis suggests that the federal budget deficit will rise to at least 7 % of gdp over the next decade , according to trump ’ s economic plan .
trump ’ s senior economic advisers , peter navarro and 布尔 ross , argue that these estimates have shortcomings , because they have failed to account for the “ surprise windfall ” from regulatory and energy reforms and the sharp contraction of the us trade deficit .
indeed , the 分析 analysis suggests that fully 73 % of the income windfall that trump ’ s trumponomics has facilitated is attributable to a significant improvement in overall trade balance in the decade ahead .
but , as 如上 文所 emphasized , this prospect is highly dubious if national saving does not rise .
creative accounting – the long-term hallmark of supply-side economics – is not so sure .
this brings us to the most glaring twist in trumponomics .
even the most conservative federal budget deficit estimates that a depressed net national saving rate could slip back into negative territory sometime in 2019 .
this will create new pressure on the current-account and trade deficits , making it difficult to reverse employment and income losses – and politicians immediately blame it for america ’ s trading partners .
ironically , in the coming period of negative saving , the us will increasingly depend on surplus saving from abroad .
if the trump administration targets the main foreign lenders – namely , china – its strategy could quickly backfire .
at least america ’ s borrowing conditions will be adversely affected ; that may mean higher interest rates – signs that the evidence is already apparent – that the dollar will suffer downward pressure .
of course , the worst-case scenario is a global trade war .
protectionism , inadequate saving , and deficit spending create a profoundly toxic combination .
under trumponomics , it will be difficult to make america great again .
a clarion call for emerging markets
ithaca – as we get into 2012 , we should consider how a decade of strong economic growth in emerging markets has triggered a political transition of last year .
from dramatic events in the middle east , the support of the anti-corruption movement in india , with the support of the anti-corruption movement in india , sends a clear signal to leaders in emerging markets that growth is not enough .
ignoring this message will be paid .
in the first decade of the twenty-first century , emerging-market economies grew steadily , and even the global financial crisis did not stop them .
but the economic benefits of corruption are rampant , and corruption has destabilized the deep reforms needed to sustain growth momentum .
corruption takes many forms , but , in emerging markets , a confluence of factors are forming a cancer that eventually upended the existing system .
in these countries , unbridled low-level corruption has enraged the poor ; indeed , it has left poor people unable to acquire social services and basic government functions that they depend on .
another corruption would be massive kickbacks from large-scale projects .
in india , for example , with supply in supply in supply , the sale was rigged , and the government would lose up to $ 30-40 billion in revenue .
for ordinary people , massive corruption is not necessarily visible , because , despite the sheer number of people involved , the cost is not as direct as it is in the case of corrupt graft .
but , as rapid growth exacerbates inequality , people ’ s perception of such large-scale corruption has changed .
in countries like china and india , rapid economic growth has lifted many people out of poverty .
but the benefits of globalization and rapid growth are not evenly distributed , and the rich have become richer , while most people remain impoverished .
the problem with rising income inequality is far from confined to emerging markets , but open corruption and widespread inequality have created a delicate and delicate threat to the reforms needed to boost and strengthen economic interests .
in many emerging-market countries , the lack of political freedom is fueling the fire .
corruption , injustice , and political repression have created enormous pressure , and there is no institutional mechanism for such pressure .
but political freedom is no panacea .
in democratic countries such as india , politically well-connected benefit from a flawed growth benefit .
in each election cycle , the people have an opportunity to “ throw the rascals out ” to some extent , but not to root out the problem .
it is difficult to predict what triggers popular protests , but economic factors are critical .
as urban populations grow , reducing their pressure will become increasingly difficult .
some countries ’ response to recent events was the combination of political repression , information blockades , or a combination of authoritarian measures .
china , for example , blocked media coverage of egyptian protests .
the arab spring , however , showed the fragility of repressive political regimes , and the legitimacy of the rule by restricting information flows can not work .
the main lesson for emerging-market countries is that focusing on gdp growth may ultimately undermine economic and political stability .
despite rapid increases in national income , they are vulnerable to popular opposition if leaders can not distribute economic growth fairly .
tackling corruption is essential to improving long-term growth and maintaining social stability .
these countries need to take steps to help lift the poor out of poverty traps , and to improve their economic welfare opportunities .
such measures include broadening financial markets , enabling more people to acquire credit and investment ; strengthen social safety nets to protect the economy ; and increase access to education and quality .
these lessons are also true for advanced economies , where the advanced economies are also suffering from rising inequality and a corrupt pattern of corruption .
but , for rich countries , restoring decent economic growth is needed .
emerging markets are facing a golden opportunity to make economic gains , lock in growth , and stability through deep problems like corruption .
events last year suggest that the costs of inaction are high .
