a confederation for kosovo
time is running out for kosovo .
if a un resolution resolution is not forthcoming in early december , the province ’ s majority albanian majority is likely to declare independence unilaterally .
that would be a catastrophic move .
russia is furious , because it fears that kosovo , regardless of whether it is divided , will further trigger an independent movement within the former soviet empire .
serbia would even be more vocal .
塞尔维亚 洛 , serbia ’ s state minister in kosovo , has said that his country might use force to defend his sovereignty .
even if the government remains hesitant on this issue , extremist nationalist groups could force the army to send the army , which is currently weak in kosovo ( only 40 “ military observers ” and 2116 police ) , but there are likely to be any armed conflict in the presence of dozens of nato troops there .
after eight years of international regulation , kosovo ’ s albanian majority has taken the form of freedom , and is eager for full independence .
but serbia claims that the province has been an important part of its history and cultural tradition .
moreover , independence can not be accepted by serbia ’ s public , which has already watched as a little more than a narrow “ serbia , ” and it has lately been a 黑山共和国 .
serbia is ready to give kosovo only “ enhanced autonomy , ” and parts of the international agreement .
yet , while both sides seem unlikely to be reconciled , it is not too late .
but this can be achieved only by reviving and updating the old mechanisms of an international community : a confederation of countries .
through a binding un security council resolution , kosovo could be granted full and exclusive authority to its citizens and territory , as well as limited authority on the international level .
it can be allowed to sign trade agreements and agreements with individuals ( for example , allowing foreigners to enter and operate within their borders , or extradition ) , and to seek to join the un ( which does not require full sovereignty and independence ) .
kosovo will thus gain some important external symbols of statehood .
as a result , kosovo and serbia will form two different international actors , bound together by a confederation that combines it with a common decision-making body .
of course , the alliance is not symmetrical , because the serbian government ’ s sovereignty over other parts of serbia will not be affected and limited , and the kosovo government ’ s “ sovereignty ” vis-à-vis kosovo would be constrained .
in order to avoid the dominance of either side of the two parties , the common decision-making body will be represented by four representatives from serbia , representatives from kosovo , and three representatives from the eu , which would require support from the eu .
moreover , the eu should establish a small but effective military force , for example , to support the decisions made by the common decision-making body .
as with any compromise , the parties involved in this arrangement would have a downside .
serbia will save face , and will continue to hold a voice on the major issues concerning kosovo , including kosovo ’ s ethnic minorities .
kosovo would gain limited independence , and its status will rise from a province of a sovereign state to an international actor capable of signing a deal with other countries , even joining the un .
by bringing stability to a highly volatile region , the eu would benefit from it .
as a result , the eu will regulate kosovo , and prevent any dispute that might lead to riots .
the final benefit of this solution is that it will be temporary .
in history , the confederacy has turned into federal ( as occurred in the united states , germany , and switzerland ) or , driven by forces , divided ( like the arab spring in 1958 , which divided egypt and syria three years later ) .
the confederation i advocate would thus be a intermediate step ( lasting 5-10 years ) , in which the last kosovo could be fully independent .
delaying a final solution in this way could provide a moment to validate kosovo ’ s membership in the eu , thereby providing a moment of “ sovereign power ” with other independent states , as well as a calming demand for the country ’ s dangerous construction .
the calculus of global warming
the british government recently issued the most comprehensive report on the economic costs and risks of global warming , and has proposed measures that would reduce greenhouse-gas emissions , and to avoid some of the worst consequences .
the report ’ s chief economist in the world bank , nicholas stern , the world bank ’ s leader , made it clear that the key is not whether we can afford to meet global warming , but whether we can afford the consequences of inaction .
the report ’ s proposed cost amounts to just 1 % of annual consumption , but it would cost the world five times more risk .
the cost of global warming is higher than in earlier research , because it will increasingly reflect new evidence , such as global warming , which is a highly complex and non-linear process that is more likely than we previously thought .
indeed , the study could actually underestimate the costs : for example , climate change , for example , will cause a greater variability in weather , and that the change in the gulf of mexico ’ s wall has disappeared – a problem that is particularly worrisome in europe .
when i took office in 1995 on the “ intergovernmental panel on climate change , ” the scientific body of scientific research on global warming has shown that the concentration of greenhouse gases has increased significantly in the atmosphere since the beginning of the industrial revolution .
the increase in concentrations of greenhouse gases will have a strong impact on climate and sea levels , but few recognize that the arctic ice cap is melting at the current rate .
but there is still some suggestion that , because there is no serious global warming , we should do little or nothing .
in my view , uncertainty should make us act more resolutely today .
as my scientist friend put it : if you drive your car in a mountain of water , to a cliff , and the car ’ s brakes are likely to be problematic , should you be rushing to become more cautious or more likely ?
global warming is a rare concern for the scientific community .
scientists have glimpsed the future .
as the stern report points out , as in many cases , poor countries are the most vulnerable .
by the end of the century , one-third of bangladesh will be submerged .
the maldives and some pacific island states will disappear : the twenty-first century of our twenty-first century .
pollution is a huge global externality .
developed countries may not be deliberately damaging bangladesh and those that are disappearing , but even war is not so destructive .
the best way to deal with a global externality is through a globally agreed tax rate .
this does not mean the increase in overall taxes , but only in a country that replaces some of the existing taxes in a 污染 ( carbon ) tax .
a tax on pollution like pollution makes more sense than good things like saving and work .
despite president george w. bush ’ s claims that the market works , he has called for voluntary action .
but the more sensible approach is the power of the market – the power of incentives – not to rely on goodwill , especially on oil companies that regard the impact of maximizing interests as the sole objective of maximizing interests .
exxon ’ s estimate of some so-called “ think tanks ” has been provided to weaken confidence in the science of global warming , just as the tobacco industry supports the “ research ” link between smoking and cancer .
some companies seem to be celebrating the melting of the polar ice cap , because it would reduce their cost in the arctic ocean .
the good news is that there are many solutions that can be reduced by improved incentives ( greenhouse gases ) , one of which would be to eliminate subsidies for inefficient use of energy .
the us subsidizes ethanol for ethanol products , while imposing tariffs on ethanol in sugar , hidden by massive subsidies to oil and gas .
most important , the price signals that show the real cost of energy derived from fossil fuels encourage innovation and conservation .
small changes in women ’ s behavior can make a difference if millions of people practice it .
for example , the color of the color of homes in a warmer region to reflect sunlight , or trees around home trees can make a lot of savings in energy neutrality .
we should treasure it only one planet .
global warming is a risk that we can no longer afford to ignore .

a crisis , two interpretations
chicago – the world ’ s advanced democracies are mired in crisis , with two competing voices at stake and remedies .
the first well-known diagnosis is that demand is collapsed because of high debt accumulated before the crisis .
households that are most prone to spending ( and national ) can no longer borrow .
to revive growth , other families and countries must be encouraged to spend – and governments that still borrow to borrow should expand deficits , while low interest rates should stop saving .
such an argument , according to this view , is a virtue , at least in the short term .
in the medium term , as long as growth can be boosted , debt can be paid off , and the financial sector is depressed , so that it will not create another crisis in the world .
this view is standard keynesian , and that the argument is that a correction in the debt crisis has been supported by most government officials , central banks , and wall street economists .
the virtue is that it is clear to policymakers that the direction of action is clear , and the expected return on the political cycle .
unfortunately , despite the stimulus , growth remains weak , and , in the short run , it is increasingly difficult to find a new source of additional spending .
so people ’ s attention began to shift to the second point of view that the advanced economies ’ basic ability to grow through useful things has been sustained for decades , characterized by the use of debt to prop up spending .
more such spending can not deliver sustainable growth for these countries .
instead , they must improve the environment for growth .
the second point of view begins with the 1950 ’ s and 1960 ’ s , when rapid growth in the west and japan followed .
several factors – including the revival of post-war reconstruction , the protectionist revival of the 1930 ’ s , and new technologies for electricity , electricity , transportation , and cross-border communications – have fueled long-term prosperity .
but , as tyler cowen has argued in his book great stagnation , these “ low-hanging fruit ” has become increasingly difficult to boost growth since the 1970s .
at the same time , 沃尔夫冈 斯特里 wrote in the new left-wing review that democratic governments faced a seemingly rosy outlook for innovation and growth in the 1960s , and thus entered the ranks of the welfare state .
but , when growth began to slow , this means that government spending has swelled ( though it shrank its resources ) .
for some time , central banks bear the burden of spending .
the resulting high inflation raises widespread discontent , especially given that growth has barely boosted growth .
trust in keynesian stimulus has fallen , though high inflation does reduce public debt .
since then , central banks have embarked on stable inflation as their primary goal , and are increasingly independent of the executive .
but the government ’ s deficit spending has not slowed , and the share of public debt in advanced countries has risen steadily from the late 1970 ’ s , this time with no inflation to lower the real value of debt .
the us came from jimmy carter ’ s presidency and ronald reagan ’ s term in terms of the need to search for new sources of growth and deregulated industries and financial sectors , while margaret thatcher adopted similar moves in britain .
for years , the productivity of these countries has increased significantly , affecting the continent ’ s countries , mostly driven by the european commission .
public debt continues to increase .
and the moderately educated middle class has not benefited from the growth of deregulation ( though it has benefited as consumers ) .
in the latest phase of the advanced economies ’ frenzied search for growth , countries have been 八仙过海各显神通 .
in some countries ( in the united states ) , credit booms in the private sector have created a massive number of jobs , such as construction , while residents borrow to sustain consumption booms by 房地产 real estate .
in other countries ( as in greece and in parts of spain and italy ) , the government ’ s leadership 招工 provided employment protection for less educated workers .
in this “ fundamental ” view , the advanced countries ’ pre-crisis gdp growth was unsustainable , with the 堆 of borrowing and unproductive jobs .
“ borrowed ” prosperity – that is , keynes ’ s model – could create a normal illusion that can be silenced after a deep crisis , but not a solution to underlying growth problems .
if this diagnosis is correct , developed countries will need to focus on restoring innovation and productivity growth in the medium term , while redefining the pain of the welfare state in the short term , and in the short term to reduce the suffering of truly extreme people .
for example , the southern european countries ’ growth potential may lie in easing the regulation of services , reducing employment protection , and creating more private-sector jobs in the government ’ s job creation .
in the us , the imperative is to improve the match between potential jobs and workers ’ skills .
individuals know better than the government knows what they need and act accordingly .
for example , a large number of women are leaving low-income jobs so that better skills are open to the doors of high incomes .
the government ’ s attention is inadequate in these areas , partly because its benefits will be felt only after the end of the incumbents , and partly because the effectiveness of the government ’ s program is not high .
tax reform can spur people to participate in retraining , and they can encourage people to continue working , and to fill the fiscal hole .
three forces can help create more productive jobs in the future : better use of information and communication technologies ( and a new fee ) , as the development of alternative sources of energy , and the rapid demand for high value-added products in emerging markets .
the advanced countries have options .
they can defend ( though consumers , as well as a funk , “ animal spirits ” ) .
they can also view the crisis as an opportunity to fix the debt that has been generated in the last few decades .
in any case , the argument that governments and public choices believe will determine their future – and the future of the global economy .
financing the next development agenda
washington , dc – as the 2015 deadline for the millennium development goals approaches , the united nations has intensified the debate about the next round of global development efforts .
the outcome of these discussions will determine policies and investments aimed at stimulating gdp growth , strengthening human capital , and promoting more inclusive prosperity .
by 2050 , the world ’ s population is expected to reach nine billion – a large proportion of which will reside in developing or less-developed countries – and the international community must improve access to education , health , and employment opportunities worldwide .
at the same time , global temperatures are expected to rise above 2º celsius above pre-industrial levels by the end of the century ( which will trigger global warming the most dangerous effects of global warming ) , and investments in sustainable urbanization and social safety nets .
two factors pose a challenge for us , in the long run , more sustainable patterns of production and consumption .
governments , civil society , and the private sector must address this challenge , with cooperation seeking and implementing creative solutions .
but , first , we must expect that financing requirements – financing requirements soon exceed the capacity of governments and international donors to present themselves ; and we must now take action to activate sound and reliable resources .
first , governments should design evidence-based targeted policies and support the development of reliable institutions .
this would make government services more effective , while helping to stimulate traditional donors ’ increased development assistance and mobilize private-sector funding .
broadening the tax base , improving the tax system , and narrowing the difference in the value-added tax will enable low-income countries to change substantially , in such countries as a share of gdp , with high-income countries accounting for 20-30 % of gdp .
more equitable taxation would have a positive effect on governance , and governance is another important tool for mobilizing domestic resources .
improving companies and public governance , making clear shifts in pricing policies , and making a fair contract with extractive industries will enable the resource-rich countries to negotiate fair contracts with extractive industries , gradually balancing income and spending , and managing its natural-resource endowments more transparently .
progress on these fronts would help governments to spend their money on the top .
for example , only 8 % of fossil-fuel subsidies in 2010 reached the poorest 20 % of the population .
targeted support programs would significantly increase the efficiency of spending , freeing up resources for education , health , and poverty reduction .
moreover , promoting financial deepening and inclusion can accelerate private-sector growth and create more opportunities .
in fact , access to financial services could help developing countries around four million ( estimated ) , small , and medium-size enterprises thrive , while allowing the world ’ s 2.5 billion people currently to be able to build their assets .
more deepening , more efficient financial sectors would also reduce transaction costs and facilitate risk management .
local-currency bond markets can help to develop domestic investors ’ basic disease and mobilize domestic savings to support long-term investments .
at the same time , the international community should work to improve the availability and efficiency of official development assistance ( oda ) .
a gdp target of 0.7 % of gdp in monterrey , mexico , in 2002 , should be able to spur countries to increase their contributions .
they can also take steps to increase the predictability of oda year .
donors should design aid structures to ensure good national development policies and programs , not to meet their own narrow interests .
this is particularly important as emerging development partners – particularly the brics ( brazil , russia , india , china , and south africa ) – offer new forms of assistance and the new forms of assistance to non-financial aid .
private philanthropy – which has been a powerful tool for innovation in areas like health , environmental , and education – provides valuable insights into how to use aid more effectively .
more generally , improving coordination among donors would help maximize the impact of aid programs .
oda remains an important source of financing for fragile low-income countries , but it accounts for only 7 % of net financial flows to developing countries , and foreign direct investment , remittances , long-term debt , and portfolio investment .
donors should use aid to “ grow the pie ” and diversify the world ’ s poorest countries by providing risk guarantees , innovative investment vehicles , debt overhangs , and common financing arrangements .
attracting even a small fraction of institutional investors , sovereign-wealth funds , and public pension funds could boost development finance considerably .
diasporas are another major source of development finance .
reducing the cost of remittances – an estimated 9 % of the value of transactions – would make more money to the hands of those who need them most .
tailored financial products for the diaspora can attract resources , while strengthening immigration and other linkages with their native countries .
finally , the international community has a special responsibility to diversify global public goods .
the responsibility to protect the environment , stem the spread of infectious diseases , strengthen international financial architecture , promote developing-country participation in the global trading system , and enhance knowledge exchange is the intersection of national development priorities and global interests .
duty-free , quota-free access to oecd markets , together with simpler , more transparent rules of origin , would raise gdp by 1 % , leaving millions out of poverty .
investing in statistical capacity helps governments and businesses around the world to make policy decisions better , and account for the associated costs and benefits .
the challenge of the post-2015 development agenda lies in finding creative solutions to support prosperity , equality , and sustainability .
the government , civil society , international organizations , and the private sector will work together to improve access to finance and quality of development , providing a better future for all .
prague – when the czech republic prepares to be the european union ’ s rotating presidency , some europeans are talking about my speech , as if they were a 张伯伦 of neville chamberlain ’ s notorious remark about czechoslovakia ’ s notorious remarks .
a few years ago , donald rumsfeld wanted to spread europe ’ s 分出 “ new europe ” and “ old europe ” , but his rhetoric 确 this attitude .
in fact , there is no “ new europe ” and “ old europe , ” which has historically been no one .
european reunification and a break with communism are now nearly two decades old .
we czechs are 100 % of europeans , and in the iron curtain we are doing more from a democratic europe .
indeed , our pro-eu sentiments are stronger , as the eu and the eu have just gained freedom .
so europe does not need to worry about what the czech republic has , or the odd agenda , to impose on the eu .
on the contrary , the international drama has imposed an agenda that we can not escape .
the main , and most pressing , problem facing us is the financial and economic crisis that is sweeping the eu .
unfortunately , the situation across the eu will be worse before it is better .
recent social unrest in greece could spread , because the recession ’ s impact on europe ’ s young people may be even more severe .
thus , the eu needs to help turn despair into hope .
we czechs know this , because we experienced a hard economic transition in the 1990 ’ s and told us that much of the right policies can break the grip of despair .
europe must continue to cooperate in order to contain today ’ s financial and economic crisis .
in the 1930 ’ s , the continent faced a similarly brutal economic downturn , which now exists in the european union , particularly the euro , which has prevented the competitive devaluations of europe ’ s currency from competitive devaluations and making poor countries poorer .
but we can not be complacent that national egoism will be restricted .
so far , the eu ’ s governments have coordinated fiscal stimulus policies , and populists often blame the eu for the fate of individual individuals .
more policy coordination is needed to address the crisis and to re-establish eu rules when the storm starts to disappear .
the european stability and growth pact has become more flexible in this particular period , with the rule of law , which ensured the success of the euro ’ s first decade .
if europe is to return to the path to sustained growth , these rules will have to be restored , and there is a consensus on how to make that happen .
the second key challenge that we will face during our eu presidency is russia .
we must negotiate a new partnership and cooperation agreement between the eu and the russian federation .
negotiations should have been taken seriously last year , but the war in georgia has stalled .
these negotiations have now been restored , but the context for negotiations has changed dramatically .
russia ’ s economy is now much worse than the eu .
the collapse in the price of international oil and gas has damaged russia ’ s budget , and russia ’ s energy sector has been losing the output that has been predicted for years to come .
so far , russia ’ s concern about the deal is not as strong as the eu , because russia ’ s exports to the eu are about two-thirds of the natural resources that have been produced by natural resources , thus providing cash revenue even without the agreement ’ s hard provisions .
but , because the economic situation has changed dramatically , it is in the interest of russia to reassure international markets that it is in its own interest , and the new deal is an ideal signal .
and , without a new deal , europe will feel compelled to sign more bilateral deals with russia .
but the bilateral deals that the game brought to the fore sometimes hurt other eu member states , and could undermine the entire eu ’ s internal balance only by establishing a framework based on rules that can provide a solid basis for countries and the eu .
although multilateralism undoubtedly matters , the main force of european diplomacy is not its commitment to the creation of a rules-based multilateralism , but unity .
when the georgian crisis erupted , europe united , calling for russia to withdraw .
the czech republic ’ s task , as well as the task of the presidency , is to maintain solidarity when negotiations are negotiated .
in the 1990 ’ s , the us and europe ’ s goodwill ignored russia ’ s efforts to make mistakes , and now , if russia seeks to delay negotiations , the eu president , which wants to be a more assertive eu president , wants to be a far weaker one .
we , like other eu presidencies , will push for broad eu interests at the time of negotiations .
赞美 fragmentation
london – emerging markets have again become the focus of others .
investors and banks are suddenly unwilling to finance their current-account deficits .
south africa , for example , has had to raise interest rates , despite slow economic growth .
turkey ’ s interest rate is also striking .
for them , and for other emerging countries , 2014 may prove to be a tumultuous year .
if volatility becomes extreme , some countries may consider limiting capital outflows , and the imf now believes that this approach might be useful in a particular situation .
but the fundamental problem is how to respond to the impact of short-term capital inflows .
until recently , economic theory thought that the problem was not established .
financial liberalization was lauded as a result of its ability to move capital to the most productive places , thereby facilitating national and global growth .
but empirical support for the benefits of capital-account liberalization is weak .
the most successful development stories in economic history – japan and south korea – were characterized by a sharp domestic financial regulation and capital controls that have produced decades of rapid growth .
similarly , most cross-country research finds that there is no evidence that capital-account liberalization is good for economic growth .
as the economist jagdish bhagwati pointed out 16 years ago in his article , capital fiction , there is fundamental differences between trade in goods and trade .
trade liberalization in goods and services would promote economic growth , while a comprehensive capital account would not .
one reason is that many modern financial flows do not play a useful role in capital allocation , as economic theory assumes .
before world war i , capital was flowing only in one direction : from richer countries like the united kingdom , investment demand to australia or argentina exceeded domestic savings .
in today ’ s world , however , net capital mobility is often channeled from poorer countries to rich countries .
huge two-way capital flows are driven by a shift in the perception of instantaneously , which has replaced long-term capital investment ( borrowing in low-yielding currencies ) replacing long-term capital investment .
moreover , capital flows often promote consumption or unsustainable real-estate booms .
yet , despite the growing evidence of the contrary , the hypothesis that all capital flows benefit is a long way off .
this reflects its power not only from vested interests , but also from some of the ideas that have already been established .
a popular orthodoxy is disturbing to be overturned .
it is time to stop looking for these false benefits , and to distinguish between capital flows in different categories .
some are valuable , and some are harmful .
foreign direct investment ( fdi ) , for example , can boost economic growth , because it is a long-term , involving investment in the real economy , and often associated with technological or skill transfer .
equity portfolios may involve price volatility as a location for ownership , but at least it means a permanent commitment to business firms .
long-term debt financing for real capital investment can play a useful role .
by contrast , short-term capital flows , especially if they rely on short-term money by themselves , would create a risk of instability while creating a risk of instability .
the best policy response is to leave a little room .
because capital controls always can be manipulated , we can not simply reap the benefits of free trade and fdi without giving short-term investors some opportunities .
china has not yet opened its capital account , but the short-term inflows are now more upward pressure on the renminbi ( and the pboc ’ s larger accumulation of hedge reserves ) than the current-account surplus and fdi flows .
this could serve as a case in which capital-account liberalization , based on the impossibility of effective control , is a case in point .
while a better policy is absent , some effective control can still play a role if the threshold for short-term inflows and domestic credit cycles is directed .
after all , when capital inflows drive up real-estate consumption or real-estate speculation , the biggest disruption will be .
the necessary policy responses should be integrated into the consolidation of domestic financial regulation and capital-account management .
tax tools and reserve requirements that impede short-term capital inflows should be associated with countercyclical measures , such as additional capital requirements to curb domestic credit activities .
if global banks operate in the form of subsidiaries operating in emerging countries and use global funding reserves to provide domestic credit , the effectiveness of such measures would be undermined .
but this danger can be prevented by requiring banks to operate legally in legal registration , partial adjustment capital and liquidity reserves , and strong regulations to fund them .
such demands will not prevent useful capital flows : global banks can invest in emerging-market equities , and to fund their subsidiaries ’ balance sheets with long-term debt .
in banking , as in other sectors , investments in long-term technological transfers are highly beneficial , meaning that foreign banks should be allowed to compete with domestic banks on the same basis .
neither mandatory subsidiarization nor capital controls based on taxes or regulations can address all problems .
but , overall , they can stem the volatility caused by short-term capital flows and help ease the domestic credit cycle .
many financial sectors insist that these measures , like many economists , remain wedded to the old orthodoxy .
updating capital controls , they claim , would allow global financial markets to “ fragment ” their ability to allocate capital efficiently .
in the past , policymakers have been struggling to stress that such fragmentation is not permissible .
but we need a spade a spade : free movement of short-term debt leads to misallocation of capital and harmful instability .
when global capital markets arrive , fragmentation can be a good thing .
high-tech , 接触 economies
london – a recent study revealed that the five richest households in britain are more wealth than the poorest 20 % of the british combined .
in their wealth , some are from new firms ; but two families are the duke and 伯爵 , whose ancestors had the land of london in the nineteenth century .
cities and wealth are not just london .
in many countries , most of the wealth – and the bulk of the increase in wealth – contributed to the contribution of housing and commercial property , which is not the value of construction , but the value of the construction city .
that may seem odd .
though we live in the hi-tech virtual world of the internet , what is most tangible – land continues to rise relentlessly .
but there is no contradiction : land prices rise precisely because of rapid technological progress .
in the age of information and communications technology ( ict ) , we will inevitably value what the ict economy can not create .
ict has given us a remarkable new product and services ; but , as dani brynjolfsson of mit and andrew mcafee have shown in their recent book the second machine age , real change is not yet underway , and robots and software will be “ automated . ”
one result is a surprising phenomenon : a few labor inputs can create huge wealth .
facebook stands at $ 170 billion , but only about 6,000 employees .
the investment of the software that works in the construction of facebook is a matter of 5,000 software engineers .
this remarkable technology has driven up average incomes and will remain so .
but the distribution of this wealth is very unequal .
most of the growth has gone to the top half of those at the top , 10 % , or even 1 % .
but , despite getting richer , the bulk of its income growth has not been spent on ict-intensive goods and services .
the number of ipads and smart phones that one needs is limited , and their prices have been declining .
on the contrary , a growing share of consumer spending is being used to purchase goods and services that are rich in fashion , design , and brand brand values , and in residential locations .
but if the supply of lofty houses and apartments is limited , the price increase becomes inevitable .
so , in london , new york , shanghai , and many other cities , the value of the city ’ s land is rising – partly owing to consumer demand .
but the increase in the value of land makes them an attractive asset class for investors , because the future price will rise .
moreover , real estate returns have fallen sharply in the past 25 years ( far since the 2008 financial crisis ) .
the reason for low interest rates is debatable ; but the cost of a business investment based on hardware and software is a decline in the cost of commercial investment in hardware and software .
if a $ 170 billion company is created to engineer only 5,000 software engineers , it would not have to borrow much .
the fact that technology is so strong is not just that the physical land has become more valuable ; it also means that future employment growth will be around the world , especially in services that can not be automated .
the us bureau of labor statistics estimates that the fastest-growing occupations will be “ healthy support ” ( care , care , and 侍从 ) , as well as “ food preparedness and services ” – that is , most of the low-income jobs .
in short , ict creates a “ high-tech ” and “ 接触 ” economy – a world in which robots and apps operate alongside fashion , design , land , and face-to-face services .
that economy is the result of our ability to solve the capacity to produce productive problems and be excluded from automation .
but the economy could have two adverse effects .
first , it may be inherently unstable , because the more wealth they gather in real estate , the greater the financial system ’ s leverage to support real-estate investment , which is at the heart of the worst of the world ’ s financial crisis .
this will require major changes in financial and monetary policy , and the extent to which change will be dealt with by the 2008 crisis has overshadowed the response .
second , unless deliberate policies are designed to encourage and sustain inclusive growth , a highly unequal society is almost inevitable , and the increase in the value of land and wealth will amplify the distributive distribution of income that ict poses .
the trade delusion
london – since 2008 , global trade has grown slightly more slowly than global gdp growth .
the doha round of world trade organization talks failed .
the transatlantic and trans-pacific trade negotiations are struggling , owing to the resistance of special interests .
while many experts fear that protectionism will undermine globalization and threaten global economic growth , slower global trade growth is likely to be avoided , and the importance of trade liberalization is declining .
to be sure , the rapid growth of trade has played a crucial role in economic development over the last 65 years , leaving the advanced economies ’ average tariffs on average from more than 30 % to below 5 % .
the creation of a single european market facilitated the growth of intra-european trade .
japan , south korea , and taiwan have achieved rapid economic catch-up with export-led growth .
china has followed the same path over the last 30 years .
from 1990 to 2008 , trade grew twice as fast as global output .
but trade is unlikely to grow faster than gdp .
indeed , even without trade barriers , trade growth could be significantly slower in some periods than gdp growth .
several factors make us entering this period .
first , consumption patterns in advanced economies have changed .
the rich are increasingly spending the share of their income on services , which are either impossible to trade ( for example , meals in home meals ) or are difficult trade ( such as health services ) .
non-tradable sectors account for a growing share of employment and economic activity .
for decades , this trend has been offset by a growing volume of tradable commodity exchanges , which often flow through complex supply chains .
in the future , however , non-tradable consumption may dominate .
indeed , even trade intensity in manufacturing goods may fall .
trade is partly driven by differences in labor costs .
so far , a sharp increase in chinese manufacturing reflects low wages .
but with real wages in china and other emerging economies , incentives for trade will decline .
the more global incomes converge , the more trade will be traded .
moreover , as the mit economist erik brynjolfsson and andrew mcafee put it in the second machine age , rapid advances in information technology can make the use of automation increasingly widespread .
some production activities , though few jobs , are likely to return to developed countries , because proximity to customers ’ advantages and lower transport costs have gradually reduced differences in labor costs .
global trade as a share of global gdp is likely to decline , but it will not adversely affect global economic growth .
rising productivity does not require increasing trade intensity .
after all , while the planet does not trade with other planets , its economy remains growing .
optimal trade intensity depends on many factors – such as relative labor costs , transport costs , productivity , and economic effects .
even if it does , international trade will still play a critical role , and preventing the reversal of past trade liberalization is essential .
but further trade liberalization is bound to reduce the importance of economic growth .
with industrial tariffs already dramatically reduced , the potential benefits of most trade liberalization have been developed .
the benefits of further trade liberalization are often surprisingly low – not more than a few percentage points of global gdp .
this was small compared to the 2008 financial crisis , which led to a 10-15 % decline in economic output in many advanced economies than it did before the crisis .
and that is relatively small relative to the economic performance of countries that have managed to achieve catch-up economies – for example , china – with relatively little economic performance in the same countries that have the same access to global markets .
the main reason for slow progress in trade negotiations is not the growing protectionism of trade protectionism ; it is not the result of a complex trade-off with further liberalization .
the doha round ’ s failure was seen as a setback for the developing world , while some liberalization – for example , cotton imports in advanced countries – would undoubtedly benefit some low-income countries .
but a comprehensive trade liberalization would have a complex impact on the least-developed countries , some of which may lose access to the market for the advanced economies that they now enjoy , only to compensate for them .
this means that further progress toward liberalization will slow .
but this slow progress is only a minor impediment to development , relative to the debt that developed countries face , or the infrastructure and education gaps in many developing economies .
the truth is often overlooked .
past trade liberalization has led to a bias in global policy that is supposed to produce the same outcome .
but while the potential global benefits of trade liberalization have been reduced , the decline in trade intensity will continue to impede economic development in some countries .
in the last 60 years , only a few countries have fully caught up to living standards in developed countries , which are dependent on export-led growth and boosting productivity and job creation through manufacturing .
in the future , it will be even harder to rely solely on this model .
china is large , so it must develop domestic drivers of development at an earlier stage of the country , taiwan , and south korea ; so its exports will inevitably fall ( relative to gdp ) .
at the same time , for some low-income countries , the manufacturing and service automation proposed by brynjolfsson and mcafee , whether in advanced or chinese , is likely to make them more difficult to move toward high-income status than in the advanced economies .
this poses a serious challenge to development policy , and further trade liberalization is only marginally outweighed .
rethinking the monetization taboo
london – there is now a full discussion of the fed ’ s “ tapering ” of asset flows , and it will gradually shift to expectations about rising interest rates .
but there is another question : how will central banks achieve a final “ export ” of unconventional monetary policy , and to restore the balance sheets of unconventional monetary policy to “ normal ” levels ?
for many , a larger problem must be addressed .
the fed ’ s tapering is merely slowing its balance sheet .
if it is to return to the pre-crisis level , the authorities would need to issue worth $ 3 trillion .
but a largely recognized truth is that central banks need not shrink their balance sheets without shrinking their balance sheets .
they can remain larger and larger ; for some countries , such long-term conditions will help to mitigate public-debt burdens .
as a recent imf paper published by carmen reinhart and kenneth rogoff points out , the advanced economies face a debt burden that can not be reduced only through a series of austerity , delays , and growth .
but there is no purely public liability for public debt if a central bank is holding its own bonds .
even if central banks ’ holdings of government bonds were converted into long-term bonds , there is no real change , but it is clear that some of the previously issued public claims will not have to be repaid .
this amounts to “ helicopter money ” after the debt .
in 2003 , then-fed chairman ben bernanke believed that japan , faced with deflation , should increase public spending , or cut taxes , to fund these measures by printing money rather than issuing bonds .
he thought that this would ultimately increase national income , because the effect of this direct stimulus would not be offset by fears of future debt burdens .
but his advice was not adopted ; a large number of japan ’ s fiscal deficits were financed by debt .
but the debt held by the boj is still written off .
for japan , this would reduce government debt equivalent to 40 % of gdp , and could even reach 60 % if the creditor purchases of the 2014 plan were purchased .
the focus is on two risks : central banks ’ losses and excessive inflation .
but both outcomes can be avoided .
central banks use their own interest rates to buy government bonds with interest rates or ultra-low interest rates .
as a result , as interest rates rise , central banks may face spending exceeding income .
but even if central banks raise the policy rate , they can choose to pay zero interest payments on a part of the bank ’ s savings .
they can also demand that commercial banks hold the equivalent of zero interest rates on their loans , and thus prevent inflationary growth in private credit and currency .
monetization of long-term government debt is undoubtedly technically feasible .
whether this is desirable depends on expectations of inflation .
when inflation is returning to target levels , debt monetization could become unnecessary and dangerous .
the sale of central-bank debt , though bound to be inevitable , is also appropriate .
but if deflation is real , permanent monetization may be the best policy .
i predict that japan will de facto monetize some government debt in fact .
after 20 years of low growth and deflation , japan ’ s gross public debt has exceeded 240 % of gdp ( more than 140 % of gdp if the debt is calculated ) ; the debt burden continues to grow .
according to the international monetary fund , if it is to reduce net public debt to the equivalent of GDP80% by 2030 , japan will have to shift its current peak budget deficit into 6.7 % by 2020 , and to sustain this situation by 2030 .
this will not happen , and any attempt to achieve this goal will bring japan into a severe recession .
but japan ’ s government does not need to repay the 140 trillion ( $ 1.4 trillion ) debt that the boj has already held .
the boj will continue to expand its balance sheet until the 2 % inflation target is reached .
its balance sheet ’ s net value in its balance sheet will stabilize and maintain a steady decline in gdp at a certain rate of gdp , but its absolute size may never be reduced – a possibility that will not cause any concern .
this is precisely what happened when the fed ’ s balance sheet ended in 1951 , after the end of the us government ’ s wartime and postwar bonds .
even if permanent monetization occurs , the truth may be obfuscated .
if japan ’ s government bonds were to continue to be repaid in the bank of japan , it is often offset by a new central bank bond purchases , while the net effect of the bank of japan ’ s deposit interest rate to zero , which is a symptom of a “ normal ” central bank .
central banks can monetize debt without being pretending .
in the past , germany ’ s weimar government , today ’ s zimbabwe government , reflects this risk .
so , even if permanent monetization occurs – almost certain that japan will carry out and other countries may be – it may never mention that term .
this silence may help to achieve a beneficial purpose .
but that is not the kind of policy tool that central banks and governments forget that such policies can be used to cope with current debt overhangs .
the perils of financial freedom
london – in 2007 , china ’ s then-prime minister wen jiabao famously observed that “ china ’ s economy remains unstable , unbalanced , uncoordinated , and unsustainable . ”
today , imbalances remain , and china ’ s economy is too focused on investment and excessive reliance on credit .
the current chinese leadership has committed to building a more balanced development model and believing that the market will play a “ decisive role ” in achieving that goal .
but when some areas require stronger regulation , chinese officials should not expect the free market to become a panacea for the financial sector .
in fact , china ’ s current economic imbalance is partly a reflection of the crisis created by competition in credit markets .
even before the 2008 global financial crisis , china ’ s annual 投资 ratio reached a staggering 40 % , while economists are calling for a shift toward a more consumption-led growth .
in 2012 , these ratios had risen to 47 % , and the stimulus industry had already accounted for 40 % of total output .
the total volume of credit has soared from 130 % of gdp to 200 % , and both bank loans and “ shadow banking ” credit are expanding sharply .
both china and the global economy have benefited from this stimulus , and that is in danger of driving up aggregate demand .
but it also led to massive waste of waste in heavy industry , real estate , and urban infrastructure , leaving china the challenge of deleveraging and bad loans .
in many areas , strengthening market discipline does play a real role in addressing the structural causes of imbalances .
wasteful construction investment encouraged the construction of 农村土地 land .
the absence of normal ownership relationships between the central government and state-owned enterprises allows the latter to pay minimal dividends and invest too much in business development .
the cap on interest rates on bank deposits led to a massive subsidy for household savers .
and soes are more likely to borrow from state-owned banks than private companies .
but japan ’ s experience in the 1980 ’ s attests to the belief that financial liberalization will make the economy a balanced one .
as joe 斯蒂 has shown in his book asia , neither japan nor south korea is a economic miracle through the provision of free-market credit , on the contrary , they rely on deliberate credit flows to industrial development rather than real estate or consumption .
when japan loosened its grip on banking systems in the 1980 ’ s , it was a huge real-estate bubble and subsequent economic collapse , owing to two decades of slow growth and deflation .
china ’ s per capita income is equivalent to just one-quarter of japan ’ s , and it would be tragic if china had a similar setback for living standards in the developed world .
yet one notable feature of china ’ s economy is the construction of real-estate and urban infrastructure – housing , large industrial sectors , the conference centers , stadiums , and museums – that are more important than japan and south korea in the same phase of economic development .
this reflects the interaction between two chinese characteristics and one inherent feature of all banking systems .
the first great factor is the authorities ’ emphasis on “ urbanization , ” but the urbanization itself is an end , not a byproduct of industrialization .
the second is china ’ s decentralized approach to economic development , with competition among regions , cities focusing on grandiose urban infrastructure projects .
the common nature of this hybrid is that banks around the world can create private credit , money , and purchasing power , which would have a natural incentive to invest these agents in real estate , thereby driving up land prices .
ireland and spanish banks , before the crisis , have the same capacity to finance excessive real-estate construction as china ’ s state-owned banks .
thus , even if china introduced more market controls to achieve a positive success , it must plan to limit credit creation to the credit instruments of the advanced economies before the 2008 crisis .
extensive applications should be applied to loan-to-value ratios and 贷款额 ratios .
and capital requirements for banks should reflect higher risk weights on real-estate lending than banks ’ assessments of credit risk assessments .
the people ’ s bank of china should maintain the requirements of commercial banks ’ capital reserves to limit credit creation , rather than viewing it as obsolete as the advanced economies did before 2008 .
the credit supply of shadow banking must be tightly regulated .
control of the credit cycle is essential to free markets .
china thus faces a serious challenge .
it must adopt a transition not to the western model that led to the 2008 crisis , but to a new model that combines some market discipline and strong public policy constraints .
whether this transition can be handled smoothly is important for the entire world .
by the early 2020 ’ s , china ’ s gdp will be $ 20 trillion .
if the debt/gdp ratio reaches 250 % at that point , the value of total lending and debt securities would reach $ 50 trillion , three times larger than the sub-prime mortgage in 2008 .
today , most debt payments are within the state sector , such as soes and state-owned banks .
but , as the private sector continues to grow , soes are constrained by strict budget constraints , and external capital accounts are being liberalized , which will lead to mounting global financial risk .
we want the chinese government to recognize the virtues and risks of free markets better than advanced-economy policymakers before the 2008 crisis .
if not , another crisis – and more dramatic than the last – would be inevitable .
the great credit mistake
london – in 2008 , most advanced economies ’ private credit grew faster than gdp .
then , credit growth collapsed .
whether the collapse of private credit reflects low demand or constrained supply may be a technical issue .
but the answer has important implications for policymaking and economic growth .
the official answer is probably wrong .
popular arguments often emphasize supply constraints and policies to correct it .
impaired banking systems , it is argued , allowed firms to become less expansionary , especially in small and medium-size enterprises .
in september 2008 , us president george w. bush hoped to “ liberate banks to flow to american families and businesses . ”
the stress tests and recapitalization of us banks in 2009 were subsequently called the key to banking systems and economic recovery .
by contrast , the ecb ’ s insufficient stress tests in 2010 were widely cited as why the eurozone ’ s banks were too weak to provide a restructuring credit .
in the united kingdom , the banks have been criticized for failing to lend the reserves created by quantitative easing to the real economy , leading to the bank of england ’ s introduction of “ 专用 for lending ” scheme in 2012 .
in the eurozone , one hopes that this year ’ s asset quality review and stress tests will eventually quell doubts about bank solvency , freeing up credit supply .
taxpayer-funded banks ’ bailout policies , higher capital requirements , and extreme monetary policy are essential to overcoming limits on credit supply .
but there is ample evidence that when the immediate crisis passed , demand for credit demand will be far more constrained than supply constraints .
this persuasive argument has been made by 提夫 mian and amir sufi in the house of debt .
the important new book has analyzed us data , 米安 , and sufi visits to us shows that recession was caused by a collapse in household consumption , which has caused households to face the largest wealth relative to home prices in the run-up to pre-crisis borrowing and crisis .
it is these counties , too , that local companies cut their artificial 最猛 .
for small and medium-size enterprises , lack of customers , not a lack of credit , constrains its borrowing , employment , and output .
and the customers are lacking because the pre-crisis credit boom caused them to borrow too much .
in the uk , many business surveys from 2009 to 2012 offer the same conclusion .
weak clients ’ demand for customer demand is much more important than credit availability .
economic growth , even if credit supply is no longer restricted and cheap , is likely to remain deeply depressed .
in the early 1980 ’ s and early 1990 ’ s , many japanese companies were overleveraged by the boom in credit and real-estate booms .
by the late 1990 ’ s , the bank of japan ( boj ) provided loans to companies at near-zero interest rates .
but , instead of borrowing , companies cut investment to pay down their debt , thereby fueling two decades of stagnation and deflation .
since 2011 , the european central bank ’ s analysis of anemic eurozone growth has stressed the adverse effects of impaired and decentralized financial systems , and the excessive debt conditions and excessive bank recapitalization in the periphery .
the main progress to address these problems has been achieved .
the european central bank ’ s latest report , the bulletin of the bulletin , is certain to suggest that the availability of credit availability and prices are improving .
nonetheless , the rate of contraction in private-sector lending has accelerated in the last year – from -0.6 % to -2 % – and has sought to find a major reason for depressed credit growth .
while private deleveraging and fiscal consolidation are simultaneously limited to the limits of credit supply , the eurozone ’ s growth restrictions are far from limited .
but , despite the ecb ’ s evidence , the policy focus remains on the need to correct credit supply through asset quality review and stress tests , and by the ecb ’ s own lending mechanism ( announcing june 5 ) .
this suggests that official policy debates , particularly in the eurozone , are concentrated in addressing the problems that are more difficult to address .
fixing impaired banking systems after the crisis is critical and achievable .
moreover , while the cost of public aid is inevitable , the economic damage caused by the financial crisis and the post-crisis recession has been largely minor .
on the contrary , large debt overhang is tricky unless the policy orthodoxy is challenged .
in the 1990s , japan used massive public deficits to offset private deleveraging .
the us has moved away from recession faster than the eurozone , not only because – not even primarily because – it fixed its banking system faster , but also because it has pursued more stimulative fiscal policies .
but fiscal stimulus has been limited in the eurozone , with eurozone members no longer issuing their own currency , so “ sovereignty ” has defaulted on the risk of default .
aggressive monetary expansion , achieved through quantitative easing , is also more complicated , politically righteousness , because there is no federal debt to purchase a federal debt that central banks can buy .
to survive , the eurozone will need to become more centralized , with some common fiscal revenues , spending , and debt .
of course , this scenario implies very difficult political choices .
if eurozone policies think that resolving banks ’ problems will solve the economy ’ s problems , europe ’ s future will be like japan ’ s in the 1990s .
inequality by the click
london – when pope francis warned in november , “ ideological ideologies that defend the absolute autonomy of the market ” are causing rapid expansion of inequality .
is he right ?
in a sense , francis is clearly wrong : in many cases , inequality among countries is declining .
china ’ s average household , for example , is catching up with america ’ s average household ( though still a significant gap ) .
but such examples do not justify the importance of widening inequality within countries .
both china and the us are very unequal societies , and are becoming increasingly unequal .
in the us , the numbers at both ends of the income distribution are striking .
the bottom quarter of us households ’ real ( inflation-adjusted ) income has barely grown in the last 25 years .
they no longer share the fruits of the country ’ s growth .
but , at the top 1 % of americans , the real income of the top 1 % has increased by almost three times , accounting for 20 % of national income since the 1920s .
in many emerging countries , rapid economic growth has increased at least some of the lives of almost everyone , but the share of the rich and the ultra-rich is growing significantly .
once these countries achieve average income levels in developed countries , declining growth to typical rich-country levels , their future may be similar to that of the us today .
globalization partly explains why the us and other advanced economies have stagnated .
competition from lower-paid chinese workers has driven down wages in the us .
but technological change may be a more fundamental factor , affecting all countries .
technological change is a source of economic growth .
we have become richer because we learned how to maintain and increase output with fewer employees , and because innovation creates new products and services .
successful new technologies tend to create jobs in some sectors , but new jobs in other sectors offset the impact .
tractors destroyed millions of agricultural jobs , for example , but tractors , trucks , and cars created new jobs .
but new technologies are subtly different , and their economic consequences differ fundamentally .
today ’ s new technologies are far more disruptive than the technology of the 电机 era .
suppose that 30 years ago , someone invented a mantra that would enable us to talk to any friend in the world – one that only “ john maynard keynes , ” you can negotiate with john kerry .
the inventors have given their intellectual property , so the world ’ s wealthiest people ; his lawyers and those who provide him with luxury goods and services will become rich .
but , beyond that , there is no new job creation .
information and communication technology is not costless magic ; but , compared to innovation in the age of 电机 , they are closer to a 成本 魔法 .
the cost of computer hardware followed moore ’ s moore ’ s law as moore ’ s law .
and once software is developed , the marginal cost of copying it is almost nil .
but the number of jobs created is dwarfed by the number of jobs created .
in 1979 , general motors employed 850,000 workers .
today , microsoft employs only 100,000 people worldwide , google is 50,000 , and facebook is only 5,000 .
in this ocean of the ocean of the global labor market , it is only a small fraction of the number of jobs that information technology is “ automated ” by the information technology .
but rising unemployment is not inevitable .
we can create unlimited jobs in retail , restaurants , hotels , and a variety of personal services .
for example , walmart employs two million people , whereas the us bureau of labor statistics forecasts that the us will create a million additional jobs for the next ten years .
but the wages that markets are preparing for these jobs may generate greater inequality .
there is no reason why politicians ’ general answer – “ raising labor skills ” – will reverse this trend .
however many people learn cutting-edge it skills , facebook will always need a few thousand employees .
and access to well-paying jobs may depend not just on absolute skill levels , but also on relative skill in the winner-take-all world .
but , at least it products and services are very cheap , so even relatively poor people can afford it .
this may make a very unequal society more stable than many fear .
in his new book , 告别 , the economist tyler cowen has a deliberate provocative view : though new technologies will create an uneven group , the relative losers of a computer game and internet entertainment , the relative losers of the 最低 , and the 互联网 of the internet will be a 良民 .
cowen may be right ; the poor may not rebel .
but extreme inequality still worries us .
more than a certain threshold of inequality inevitably leads to a greater number of opportunities for inequality ; both the result and the extreme inequality that is both the result and the chance of opportunity undermine the notion of equality .
so pope francis is right : though capitalism is undoubtedly successful in creating economic growth , we can not simply rely on market forces to create a socially desirable social outcomes .
all new technologies create opportunities , but the way the fruits of the new technology to allocate new technologies may be very unequal .
today , the challenge of offsetting this outcome is greater than ever .
protectionist shadows over solar power
cambridge – the world ’ s largest anti-dumping dispute reached a settlement in late july , with china agreeing to export solar panels to the eu at the lowest minimum price .
the final solution , which has moderated many of the results , has been reduced by the fact that the european commission ’ s tariffs on solar panels in china will rise to % % , if the european commission decides that the share of china ’ s share of the european market is up .
but reconciliation is a bad outcome for consumers and the environment .
the dispute between china and the eu is similar .
last autumn , after the us department of commerce decided that china was “ dumping ” ( generally defined as a lower price than cost ) , the us imposed tariffs on imports from chinese imports from china .
china , for its part , argues that the us is dumping its vital materials for dumping solar panels in china , and tariffs on imports of us imports exceed 50 % .
the solar-power dispute may seem narrow , but it addresses the core issues of long-term debate over globalization .
the most powerful argument against anti-globalization activists is that even if free trade favors economic growth , it could undermine important public goods such as environmental protection .
but trade may have a favorable impact on the environment .
specialization in countries allows people to get more of what they want , especially when income levels are high , and clean air and water are more in anticipation of people ’ s expectations .
while trade lowers costs , it can benefit environmental areas as well as benefits .
so , is trade globalization on the whole , or for good reason ?
some empirical studies of cross-country data found positive effects on indicators of environmental degradation such as local sulfur-dioxide air pollution .
as long as a country has effective governance institutions at the national level , trade and economic growth will give them a way to clean up their air .
but there is also evidence that trade and economic growth will exacerbate other forms of environmental degradation , especially co2 emissions , because the existence of free riders can not be addressed at the national level .
the solar industry is a perfect example of how trade benefits air quality .
skeptics of solar power have long argued that , because they are too expensive to offer alternative solutions , their share in electricity generation will not exceed a few percentage points .
proponents of solar power have similarly argued that temporary subsidies for moderate subsidies would expand the industry ’ s size , and the size of the economy and experience in the economy will reduce costs dramatically .
but supporters of the government have largely ignored the government ’ s subsidies , which have had a positive impact on the development of solar technologies in recent years , and china ’ s extensive peer resources have reduced costs .
the current protectionism may reverse progress .
without cheap solar panels from china , subsidies for european industry development , and because of fiscal reasons , are still far from environmentalists ’ expectations .
but “ discovery ” of “ dumping ” against foreign markets , of course , requires a response ?
indeed , it is not .
first , even those who are generally sympathetic to 贸易市场 tend to believe that they aim to combat “ predatory pricing , ” which is the result of a failure to drive a competitor ’ s bankruptcy at the cost of cost , and then can drive up prices .
but it is often not subject to such rules , much less compliance .
simply put , anti-dumping measures , such as the us and europe ’ s solar panels , are designed to contain , rather than promote , competition .
so , what if predatory pricing is not an incentive for producers to sell below costs in these cases ?
in the united states , europe , the united states , and globally , overcapacity is straining the solar panels industry .
as a result , maintaining a global market price is lower than the long-term average cost per unit of production .
but these market prices are not low compared to the short-term costs of construction after construction .
in other words , production firms are selling “ below cost ” because factories are already built , and their costs would be more costly if their fees are higher than competition prices or simply stopped production .
when the us or the eu concluded that china ’ s “ dumping ” solar panels , or when china considers the us “ dumping ” 多晶硅 , they consider the average , not marginal , cost .
according to this standard , dumping a store is dumping .
some would limit the negotiations between china ’ s solar panels exports and “ voluntary export restraints ” ( “ voluntary export restraints ” ) , or “ orderly marketing arrangements ” ( vers ) , especially in japan in the 1980 ’ s , when japan pledged to export its exports to the us .
but japan ’ s precedent for voluntary export restraints on the auto industry during this period makes sense .
american automakers are increasingly difficult to compete with smaller , more fuel-efficient japan .
when free trade was finally restored , america ’ s wallets and air quality benefited ( and the us auto industry was forced to become more efficient ) .
the same is true of solar equipment today .
westerners should thank chinese panel producers for their role in maintaining solar power , rather than punishing them through anti-dumping measures that protect them .

living with climate change
rotterdam – for all those who still see the consequences of global warming , the summer of 2018 , and the hottest summer in history , should have tilted their scales .
in far-flung 精度 and latitudes , regions are struggling to cope with the impact of large-scale climate events .
in the southern united states , cities and towns that were hit by hurricane florence in september were nearly dry up before hurricane michael in october .
in california , 消防人员 is trying to extinguish the largest wildfire in the state ’ s history .
and in parts of latin america , europe , africa , and asia , agricultural output is in freefall , owing to months of 闷热 weather .
cooler weather hardly alleviates this suffering .
according to the united states ’ national oceanic and atmospheric administration , “ the moderately ” conditions for “ exceptional ” drought cover the united states .
but “ extreme ” and “ exceptional ” drought – the worst category – expanded to cover 6.3 % of the country ’ s territory , above 6 % in mid-september .
many of australia ’ s regions are fighting the worst drought in a generation .
indeed , for a growing number of people around the world , floods , landslides , and heat waves – in short , japan – have become a new normal .
a recent study by the public scientific library predicts that the incidence of heat-related deaths in the united states is more than five times higher than that of hot heat ; the outlook for poor countries will be even worse .
the reason is no longer the primary target of climate debate ; it is fossil fuels and human activity .
on the contrary , the problem is how billions of people and businesses face the risk of rapid adaptation and ensure that their communities can recover as much as possible .
even if the world achieves the paris climate agreement to limit global temperatures to 2º celsius above pre-industrial levels , it will be essential if extreme weather is now a new normal .
some communities have recognized this , and local adaptation efforts are being implemented .
in melbourne , australia , for example , planners are doing everything to reach the city ’ s 树荫 by 2040 , an approach that reduces temperatures and reduce heat-related deaths .
likewise , in the western world ’ s population of more than seven million of the country ’ s population , the government launched a massive operation in rooftops , aimed at reducing the “ 热岛 ” temperature , which is known as a 城市 urban area that can absorb the sun ’ s heat , and even urban life at night .
this is just two of the infrastructure responses that communities around the world are implementing .
but adapting to climate change will also mean managing the long-term economic effects of extreme weather , which countries are just beginning to take seriously .
consider water scarcity .
according to the 2016 world bank analysis , water crises in africa and the middle east are likely to reduce their gdp by 6 % by 2050 .
this is painful anywhere in the region , but in areas where political instability and humanitarian crises suffer , the consequences will be disastrous .
at the same time , rising sea levels will wreak havoc on coastal areas .
the decline in the value of real estate would have a profound impact not only on individual wealth , but also on the tax base in communities and in sectors that serve the real estate sector .
there is also a related problem , because the frequency of weather-related disasters and businesses around the world will eventually fall into 保额 or even uninsured .
no international body or government can provide a solution to the problems raised by climate change .
but some are taking key leadership roles , driving governments and local communities to act more urgently .
the global commission on adaptation , launched this week by former united nations secretary-general ban ki-moon , microsoft co-founder bill gates , and the world bank ’ s chief executive , is a promising plan to accelerate the response .
over the next 15 years , around $ 90 trillion will be spent on infrastructure reform .
how these programs are deployed , and whether they have a low-carbon features , may lead the world to more adapting to climate change – or , if not , in the coming decades .

a day for planetary justice
princeton – we now know about the planet , our children ’ s actions , and the poor – making greenhouse gases – the greatest moral malpractice committed by our generation .

this measure also highlights the depth of the current problem , as current co2 levels have reached 386ppm , increasing at a rate of growing annual rates .
with predictions of global warming – and , in a few years , “ alarmist ” rhetoric – the need to cut greenhouse-gas emissions became clear .
and we are moving to a dead-end end , regardless of how the vicious cycle will continue , and to keep the planet warm .
the melting of arctic ice is one example .
four decades ago , explorers tried to find a “ northeast passage ” from the 方向 to china .
but they are finding the arctic ice impenetrable , and they have been left behind .
this year , commercial vessels successfully navigated the northeast passage .
this example is only one of those striking phenomena , and the climate is becoming warmer and warmer than the past .
but the arctic ocean is not just a symptom of global warming , but also a cause of further warming : the sun can reflect the sun ’ s light .
a land that is not covered by ice will absorb more sun heat , in other words , our greenhouse-gas emissions , by creating enough heat from the arctic ice , which , in turn , will continue to operate .
the other cycle shows a similar danger .
in serbia , large quantities of methane ( a heavily influenced greenhouse gas ) have been used to be called “ 冻土 ” areas , because people believe that land in these regions would permanently be in the state of 封冻 .
but now the land started to unfreeze and releases methane , resulting in further warming – and the release of more methane and more methane .
developing countries recognize the unconscionable nature of current greenhouse-gas emissions .

kagame thus proposes to give countries a year per capita co2 emissions , and allow countries that emit below their quota to sell their emissions to countries that exceed their limits .
sri lanka , too , has taken the same stance , according to the united nations climate change group in 2008 , where environmental permits can not be more than 公斤 kilograms per person .
but the fact is that the world ’ s per capita emissions are 76 kilograms , or more than double .
yet , when rich countries emit far more than their limits , sri lanka ’ s per capita emissions are at 660 kilograms .
as sri lanka ’ s government pointed out : “ this means that we can not emit more emissions , because we are already in the rich and globally polluting countries , where the space is already available . ”
this disparity in injustice is one of the nineteenth-century colonialism of western powers – and perhaps even worse – in the nineteenth century .
the correction must be implemented at the copenhagen climate conference in december .
while many politicians favor strong action against climate change , most people believe that “ strong action ” is not enough to bring us back to co2 levels of 350 ppm .
and , in some countries , including the united states , even more modest measures are needed to confront them .
on october 24 , people in almost every country will take action , and to reinvigorate the need for an international treaty that would lead people to 350 ppm .
it would also be marked by the himalayan 上拉起 横幅标语 , which will gradually melting melting , and in australia ’ s great barrier reef , the threat of climate change .

you can find out how you can find your way around and participate in the web through the web site .

one day your grandchildren will ask : “ what did you do when you ’ ve faced the most difficult moral challenge of this era ? ”
the day of liberation
during my seven years , my grandmother ’ s grandmother , in 1960 , taught me that 8 may 1945 was the meaning of 1945 : nazi germany surrendered , and world war ii ended in europe .
