they will emphasize that if the lessons of history are not learned , history will be doomed .
these are perfectly true .
but , as individuals , i also remember my grandmother ’ s sentence : “ thank god , we lose the war . ”
thank god for all of the allies who sacrificed their lives for defending europe ’ s freedoms .
crashing the sdr
santa barbara – the chinese government ’ s effort to enter the international monetary fund ’ s reserve asset , the international monetary fund , is now on the verge of success .
last week , the imf recommended that the renminbi joined the basket of currencies that determines the value of its so-called special drawing rights ( sdr ) .
the sdr basket currently includes the dollar , the euro , the british pound , and the japanese yen , adding the renminbi to china ’ s opportunity to raise its prestige .
more important , it would facilitate the chinese government ’ s policy of internationalizing the renminbi .
but it is also a mistake .
the long-term consequences of such a move could be regrettable .
from a purely technical perspective , it is doubtful that the renminbi will qualify for the sdr basket .
the imf has traditionally called for two criteria : issuers of currencies must be the world ’ s leading exporter ; and the currency must be “ freely usable ” – that is , widely used and traded .
as the world ’ s largest exporter , china clearly meets the first condition .
the second condition , however , remains inadequate .
the renminbi is still no match for the sdr basket ’ s four currencies .
in 2014 , the renminbi ranked seventh in global central-bank reserves , eighth international bond issuance , and 11th international transactions .
moreover , the renminbi is still non-convertible for most capital transactions , and china ’ s financial markets are primitive , and transactions in exchange rates are still set daily by the monetary authorities .
indeed , until august , the imf expressed skepticism about whether to join the people ’ s inclusion in the sdr , arguing that it will still need “ great jobs , ” and recommended that it postpone the decision until 2016 .
so why has the imf changed ?
the answer is obvious : china has brought together hard and hard change .
in august , the renminbi ’ s exchange-rate regime was loosened slightly .
london issued renminbi-denominated government bonds , and several financial centers in europe have proposed plans to create new trading platforms .
it is clear that china ’ s policymakers made it abundantly unpleasant to make their decisions unpleasant .
their pressure worked .
western governments have joined the renminbi , despite its practical limitations .
the imf received this message , and now responds .
the proposal to expand the sdr basket was supported by christine lagarde , the imf ’ s managing director , and is expected to decide the imf ’ s final decision at the end of the month .
many will say that this is a positive development .
obviously , it would appease chinese leaders , with greater incentives to continue to act within existing international monetary regimes .
china ’ s recent actions , particularly the establishment of the asian infrastructure investment bank , have led people to fear that it is intended to establish a new international institution to compete with organizations like the west .
the decision to incorporate the people into the sdr basket would mitigate this danger .
on the other hand , the decision ushered in yet a somewhat different precedent , putting politics out of a policy area that had been guided by objective economic considerations .
one can imagine that , in the long run , china ’ s success in enabling the renminbi to join the sdr basket also opens the door for lobbying by other governments to join the sdr basket .
why not join the swiss franc or the canadian dollar ?
or , for the same reason , why not join the russian ruble or indian rupee ?
once an accepted elite monetary club , it is now a political non-starter .
of course , one might argue that china ’ s recent economic trajectory suggests that the renminbi can be a matter of the sdr .
after all , the internationalization of the renminbi has been growing exponentially .
likewise , the use of the renminbi for the purpose of invoicing and settling trade with china is bound to continue to increase .
but for the most important role of the currency – investment vehicles or reserve assets , the renminbi ’ s prospects are not so good , because capital controls in china remain tight , and the level of financial development is low .
whether to join the sdr basket would boost the renminbi ’ s internationalization , as many believe .
some central banks may follow suit , incorporating renminbi-denominated assets into their reserves to match the composition of the sdr basket .
but this increase is small – and perhaps $ 40 billion in the coming years .
today , more than $ 10 trillion in global reserves is a tiny sum .
the political reasons for inclusion in the renminbi are clear .
unfortunately , the risk of doing so is less clear .
the retreat of international tax cooperation
new york – much of the world ’ s governments are eager to mobilize more tax revenues to finance development finance and to curb pervasive tax avoidance ( such as the so-called luxembourg leaks revealed by the so-called luxembourg leaks ) .
but at the third international conference on financing for development , held in addis ababa last month , strengthening international tax cooperation abruptly stopped .
developed countries blocked the creation of a intergovernmental tax authority within the un to replace the current un committee on taxation .
these countries ’ insistence on tax cooperation will only be carried out under their control of the oecd .
other countries should hope that this is a temporary stop for international cooperation , not an end to the international development finance conference , which began 13 years ago in monterrey , mexico .
two years later , in 2004 , the united nations economic and social committee ( ecosoc ) upgraded its tax experts to a permanent committee .
this means that experts will convene regularly , and their authority will be expanded , not just updating the 双税 treaty .
four years later , at the second conference on financing for development in doha , qatar , policymakers acknowledged that they were doing too little , and asked ecosoc to consider strengthening institutional arrangements .
in the first year of the addis ababa conference , the un secretary-general suggested that it supported the need for a “ intergovernmental panel on tax cooperation under the un framework . ”
the secretary-general ’ s support , together with strong support from ngos and international companies and international companies , has made demands for developing countries more powerful in developing a global tax code .
until the 11th hours of the negotiations in addis ababa , they were determined to demand a global framework for international cooperation on international tax cooperation through power and resources .
yet , with little : the home countries of the united states and the united kingdom – the home of “ luxembourg ’ s leaks ” – have managed to block the progress that this global governance desperately needed .
in the end , the addis ababa action agenda stipulates that the current commission will continue to function according to its 2004 mandate , adding three meetings each year to voluntary contributions .
this is a profoundly disappointing outcome .
the advanced countries have their reasons – but not convincing .
in fact , the oecd , comprising the world ’ s 34 richest countries , is clearly capable of developing international tax standards .
but a small group of countries dictates that , in reality , the global-governance structure of global governance is already out of touch with globalization .
the monterrey consensus reached in 2002 called for strengthening “ developing countries ’ voice and engagement in international economic decision-making and norms . ”
but while the oecd has invited some developing countries to participate in the discussions , there is no decision-making power .
the oecd is thus an inferior substitute for a globally representative intergovernmental forum .
despite disappointment in addis ababa , the call for reform of the international tax system is unlikely to be silenced .
on the contrary , the voices of all sides will increasingly increase the demand for a unilateral tax change in the oecd as the advanced countries ’ counterproductive refusal to make concessions on international tax cooperation led to a tsunami of unilateral tax measures in the oecd .
the formation of jihadism
madrid – the belgian historian henry 皮雷纳 has linked europe ’ s birth as a christian continent to the eighth century .
perhaps never mind that brussels will someday reach a muslim ghetto , much less imagine that it will become the center of jihadism , and it is seen as being marginalized and angry from europe ’ s borders .
divorce is not realistic at this stage .
but it can not be allowed to continue the kind of marriage that islam scholar ramadan ramadan advocates .
ramadan , the grandson of the egyptian muslim brotherhood ’ s founder , is a swiss citizen , with a resident of the united kingdom , who argued that islam ’ s moral and values should be injected into the european system .
europe is not only tolerant of islam , but also accepting it as an integral part of its own .
the problem with ramadan ’ s vision is that europe is a continent with a secular , 势力 continent that has deep and forward-looking ideas on moral grounds .
islamic societies , by contrast , are deeply religious and deeply embedded in the past .
when islamists talk about political and social reform , they are generally looking back at the time of the past , hoping that the era of renaissance , from gender equality to gay marriage , is in place .
even muslims who support islam ’ s modernization tend to dismiss europe ’ s moral vision .
ramadan ’ s flaw in the solution to european jihadism is a reflection of his flaws in this phenomenon , which blames jihadism for european involvement in the middle east , europe ’ s so-called collusion with israel , and its support for arab dictators .
“ we can not , ” he writes , “ support the dictatorship , when civilians are killed in our borders , and hope that we will not be responding to the injustice and humiliation of the injustice . ”
but the us launched the war in iraq and afghanistan , offering unconditional support to israel and repeatedly supporting arab autocrats .
europe has always been criticized for such policies – often with fierce rhetoric .
but the us has not suffered from a vengeance in jihadist sentiment .
us president barack obama ’ s gradual retreat from these policies might help to ease resentment of the us .
in the arab spring uprisings , for example , he quickly cut off support for tunisian president zine el abidine ben ali and egypt ’ s president hosni mubarak and allowed protesters inspired by western democratic models .
the us , or europe , certainly did not support the return of egypt ’ s dictatorship in 2013 by abdel fattah el-sisi ’ s coup coup , and both the us and europe supported the democratically elected muslim brotherhood .
in recent years , europe has even provided more direct help to arab countries .
if not in europe ’ s military intervention , libyans will still live under a brutal muammar el-qaddafi .
indeed , europe could have done more to prevent the ensuing chaos in libya .
but libya ’ s citizens certainly should be responsible for the proliferation of militias that refuse to unite the country to save the country into outright collapse .
more broadly , while the west – especially the united states – has made serious policy errors in the arab world over the last 50 years , outsiders can not be held accountable for the region ’ s crisis .
the current situation is the result of a profound civilizational crisis – one that only citizens in the arab world can address .
if europe ’ s foreign policy does not take responsibility for the current chaos in the arab world , it certainly should not be a reason for the rise of jihadism within europe .
the real problem is the domestic : it is the very effective policies that are lacking from the social justice , education , housing , and employment of the european muslim youth community .
the vast majority of europe ’ s jihadists have shown that such linkages do exist .
they lack the real understanding of the islamic teachings of islam , and lack the practical opportunities to improve their lives , so easy prey for extremists .
jihadism , in its sense of absolute certainty and solemn sense of purpose , offers a sense of purpose , pride , and identity – not to mention the opportunity to take risks – and provide them with an export of “ home ” anger that deprives them of their rights .
america ’ s muslim status quo underscores the failure of europe .
american muslims , like most americans , still believe in the american dream .
they are mostly middle class , and , despite all the talk of growing economic inequality , they have not given up faith in hard work and proactive us efforts .
the us is a country of immigrants , and its dynamic economy has repeatedly enabled new migrants to succeed .
the opposite is true for europe , where a person ’ s social standing has always been difficult ; and , with the economy stagnating and unemployment alarmingly high , it is understandable that raising social status is more difficult .
in the social sphere , the us also gives muslims some of the tolerance they can not give .
america ’ s fundamental religious culture makes muslims a greater sense of identity than in secular europe .
indeed , the core values of american personal responsibility and constitutional patriotism are more acceptable to muslims than europe ’ s more radical secular liberalism .
as a result , the integration and assimilation of muslim migrants are easier to achieve .
all of this suggests that europe must look inward to address homegrown jihadism effectively .
this does not mean that it must change secularism , much less to change liberal values .
on the contrary , europe must inject new dynamism into the “ european dream , ” ensuring that all people have real opportunities to improve their lives .
otherwise , it will face a lost generation of millions of young europeans – both muslims and the rest of europe .
the new climate economics
new york – the latest assessment of global warming by the united nations intergovernmental panel on climate change ( ipcc ) shows that the world ’ s climate scientists are set to define human activities more than ever before – mainly burning fossil fuels – that are stoking temperatures and rising sea levels .
in recent years , a series of extreme weather events – including hurricane sandy in new york and new jersey , floods in china , and droughts in the american midwest , russia , and many developing countries – have caused serious damage .
last week , mexico experienced hurricanes in the pacific and the gulf of mexico , and , in the case of hurricane closures , towns and cities were 俱毁 .
climate change is an important factor in such events , and we are facing a growing situation .
this brings a new debate to the center : how to reconcile a growing number of actions to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions accompanied by strong economic growth .
this debate has been lost in controversy .
most countries are already making serious investments in renewable energy , and many are beginning to implement carbon pricing and regulations , while critics accuse them of impeding growth .
the global economy is still recovering from the financial turmoil of 2008 , higher energy prices – which can not be offset by an increase in energy efficiency – for business and political leaders .
the advent of shale gas makes the energy debate more uncertain .
replacing coal with coal is a shortcut to a low-carbon future .
what is shocking , however , is that the dirtiest fuel – coal – is the dirtiest fuel .
companies and investors , by taking a modest amount of resource efficiency , investing in a few low-carbon assets , but not much change in their high-carbon portfolios and practices .
advocates of stronger action respond , with a much more robust and cleaner growth .
they point out that energy efficiency will save , and the market for clean-energy technologies can lead to market opportunities .
they have sought to prove that a more sustainable development model would provide the world ’ s cities , ( by reducing air pollution ) and providing many benefits to energy security , providing the poor with more energy .
they recommend green bonds , urging the investment bank to use the world ’ s low interest rates to finance new infrastructure and employment , and to fund new infrastructure and employment .
these are serious economic debates , but they often evolve into ideological disputes about the appropriate response to the economic crisis and the values of government intervention markets .
this is regrettable .
climate change is not a partisan struggle , and climate policy is fundamentally market-based .
this is a problem about correcting market failures so that markets and entrepreneurship can play a proper role in ensuring innovation and efficient resource allocation .
to escape this impasse , we helped create the global commission on the economic and climate commission .
the commission ’ s new climate economy project brings together seven leading research institutes in six continents , leading to a panel of experts from the former heads of government , finance ministers , and business leaders of the world ’ s leading economists .
the purpose is to provide new evidence of how governments and businesses can deliver stronger economic growth while addressing climate risks .
few governments or investors are starting on climate change .
they want to boost investment and economic growth , create jobs , stabilize public finances , expand markets , deliver profits , ensure reliable energy and food supplies , produce goods and services , reduce poverty , and build cities .
as a result , the main question we need to ask is not whether to reduce emissions , but how public policy can help to achieve these core goals while reducing emissions and building a climate-resilient economy .
here , too , many experience worldwide can follow .
when the stern review of the economics of climate change was published seven years ago , this topic was largely theoretical .
today , countries at every stage of development are pursuing a new economic-growth model for new thinking .
for example , germany is planning the world ’ s most ambitious low-carbon economy , based on energy efficiency and renewable energy .
south korea is set to develop “ green growth ” as a core economic goal .
mexico ’ s 2012 general law , the general law on climate change , will be used to use a major increase in clean power .
china will develop green technologies as the top priority of its agenda .
ethiopia is seeking to develop low-carbon agriculture .
brazil has dramatically reduced the rate of deforestation in the amazon .
some big firms provide a powerful example of what can be done .
unilever has pledged sustainable agricultural and forest products .
coca-cola is phasing out all kinds of hydrofluorocarbons .
the retail giant wal-mart is driving emissions reduction throughout its supply chain .
at the same time , the world bank and the european investment bank are no longer lending to high-cost coal plants .
but the real problem remains – at how fast the economy can move toward a low-carbon path , and what it means to achieve the most effective .
any structural change includes costs , trade-offs , and uncertainties , and properly understood these factors .
of course , powerful vested interests oppose all low-carbon transitions , suppressing even the beneficiaries of a low-carbon transition .
that means clarifying the choice .
science has clearly demonstrated the urgency of climate problems , and it is time for economists and policymakers to explain how to respond to this urgency .
the click of bluster
cambridge – until recently , the focus on cyber security was mostly computers and 阴谋 .
the internet ’ s creators – which belong to a closed narrow circle – are comfortable with the safety of security concerns .
today , however , there are three billion internet users , which have become serious vulnerabilities ; indeed , it is threatening the internet ’ s vast economic opportunities for the world as a whole .
the “ cyber attack ” could appear in countless forms , including simple probes , 涂鸦 web sites , denial-of-service attacks , espionage , and destruction .
the term “ cyber war ” is also a 千变万化 – though the best definition is that hostilities in the best possible definition is a reflection of a series of “ wars ” from armed conflict to work together , such as the “ 减贫战 . ”
cyber warfare and cyber espionage are mostly linked to states , and cyber crime and cyber terrorism are often issued by non-state actors .
the biggest costs currently come from espionage and crime ; but , over the next decade , cyber warfare and cyber terrorism are likely to pose a greater threat than today .
moreover , the alliance and the evolution of tactics are increasingly overlap .
terrorism can buy malware from criminals , and governments may be taking the strings behind them .
some argue that deterrence is in cyberspace , in cyberspace , because its source is difficult to determine .
but this is facile : inadequate attribution affects deterrence among countries , but deterrence is often used .
even if the source of “ false flags ” can be successfully masked by the source of “ false flags , ” the government may be able to rely on a 对称 relationship that has backfired .
china , for example , may suffer from a loss that severely damaged the us economy , and vice versa .
the unknown attacker can also be deterred by cyber-security efforts .
if the firewall is strong , or redundancy and resilience enough to enable it to recover quickly , or the risk of self-reinforcing response ( “ 电围栏 ” ) , it becomes less attractive to implement attacks .
while accurate attribution of the ultimate source of cyber attacks is sometimes difficult , it is not a mistake .
with false flags and rumors of attacks on the sources of attacks widely regarded as reliable ( though untested ) , the reputational damage to the soft power of attacker soft power could also deter .
finally , the reputation and openness of the 攻击能力 policies also helped to strengthen deterrence .
of course , non-state actors are harder to detect , so improved defenses – such as preemption and human intelligence – have become important in such cases .
but , among states , even nuclear deterrence is more complicated than at first glance , and even more so in cyberspace .
for its part , the internet needs some degree of international cooperation .
some call for the formal arms-control treaty of the internet .
but differences in cultural norms and the difficulty of verification will make such treaties difficult to negotiate and implement .
at the same time , pursuing international rules that prevent conflict is important .
russia and china sought a treaty to establish a comprehensive international oversight of the internet and “ information security , ” which would prohibit fraud and 嵌入 , which can be activated when the war occurs .
but america ’ s view that arms-control efforts to limit 攻击能力 control will weaken defenses against attacks , and are difficult to justify and enforce .
likewise , in terms of political values , the us has rejected agreements that could legitimize authoritarian governments to legitimize the internet – such as the “ great firewall of china . ”
moreover , cultural differences prevent any broad agreement on regulating online content .
nonetheless , it is possible to identify illegal practices such as cyber crime in domestic jurisdictions .
preventing all intrusions may be impossible , but it can start with cyber crime and cyber terrorism involving non-state actors .
to this end , it is in major countries ’ interest to limit damage by agreeing on forensics and controls .
transnational cyberspace poses new questions about the meaning of national security .
some of the most important responses must be national , unilateral , and focused on hygiene , redundancy , and resilience .
but it is very likely that large countries will soon find that the incomplete cooperation created by non-state networks will require close cooperation among governments .
a practical agenda for revolutionary times
oxford – as the world ’ s financial leaders gather at the international monetary fund and the world bank spring meetings , many of the world ’ s working-age people are demanding radical change , because their voices are not heard .
their supposed representatives should not continue to ignore this anger and frustration .
according to the 2017 edelman trust report , public confidence in the status quo has plummeted , owing to widespread concern about globalization , innovation , immigration , social values , and corruption .
at the same time , the reaction of elites who regard themselves as the guardians of economic growth has sometimes made matters worse .
if they believe that they can only explain the benefits of the current global economic system , and to adjust the policy to compensate marginalized groups , they will be met with a wake-up call .
earlier this month , the international monetary fund , the world bank , and the world trade organization issued a joint report detailing trade as a driver of productivity growth , competition , and consumer choice .
this argument is not new , and the recommendations proposed by the report ’ s proposed “ active labor-market policies ” support the recommendations of those who lose jobs and livelihoods .
the new situation is that repeating these views , while addressing people ’ s deeper concerns , is likely to do more harm than good .
global public opinion has changed dramatically in recent years .
most of the world ’ s population – with 72 % of the population in france and italy – now believes that the system has failed them .
moreover , only 29 % of the population in 28 countries trust government leaders , while three-quarters of respondents say they trust reformers who would upend the status quo .
these findings suggest that the defenders of free trade have lost credibility in the crowds they hope to persuade .
world leaders need to recognize that today ’ s populist revolts are being driven by a sense of loss of dignity – a perception that has not been taken into account in most policymakers for economic growth and compensatory payments .
working-class voters , because they feel economically abandoned , are socially despised and culturally despised .
their votes are their only means of fighting the establishment .
addressing public concerns requires a set of agendas .
the first priority is to reach out to the people who feel that no one was listening or represented .
during the us presidential campaign , trump used this sentiment , pledging to punish all companies that move jobs to china or mexico .
the fact that a populist plutocrat can do this has made america ’ s labor movement dead .
the party that came from the labor movement has long gone to the “ center . ”
today , they are accepting the political contributions of large corporations , and they have pursued a banner of shared prosperity and “ consensus politics , ” which makes many jobs that fail to benefit from such a prosperity and consensus .
second , the quality of work , and the status of work , must be improved .
in rich countries , instability , low wages , and even dangerous forms of employment are becoming increasingly common .
a new bloomberg ’ s report on the bloomberg business barometer describes every passing worker in 亚拉巴马州 零件厂 that can earn only $ 7.25 per hour , and it must be safe in hazardous situations .
in 2010 , these workers had 50 % higher 汽车零件 workers than 工人 workers elsewhere .
as the oecd has pointed out , “ non-standard ” work is rising globally .
this trend has led to the deterioration in working conditions , making workers feel increasingly vulnerable and vulnerable .
reversing this will require rigorous standards to ensure that the workplace is safe , fair pay , and the right to participate in collective bargaining arrangements .
governments need to intervene in these criteria , just as they did in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries to improve the environmental environment in factories .
otherwise , businesses will not be able to function decently , because they face the self-defeating race of unscrupulous competitors .
finally , there must be more opportunities for future generations – not just economic opportunities .
since the 2008 financial crisis , many governments have reduced their investments in health , education , housing , and other forms of human capital .
many governments also cut support for the unemployed , homeless , and indebted .
as a result , marginalized groups have been deprived not only of resources , but also from the 机会 .
the imf , the world bank , and the wto argue that free trade and globalization have undoubtedly expanded the size of the economic pie .
in principle , this should boost the government ’ s ability to compensate those left behind and create conditions for them .
indeed , the opposite is true , owing to the government ’ s austerity policies since 2008 .
the establishment ’ s agenda has long failed .
and when elites continue to advocate free trade and globalization , they can only continue to widen the chasm of public trust .
over the past year , this distrust has exploded in many countries , and voters rejected the status quo in a single election .
piecemeal curbs on globalization is not enough to calm the revolt .
instead , world leaders should emerge from their echo chamber , take the public ’ s concerns seriously , diversify their views , and consider why so many have lost faith in the system .
the development costs of homophobia
london – as a gay man living in nigeria , my biggest challenge is to choose between sexual orientation and work .

at the time , i had just moved away from school and played a role as a “ richard ” ’ s role in expanding television stations in nigeria ’ s most popular television station , the “ richard , ” a wealthy family whose only son was a 罗曼史 .

almost immediately , my role was eliminated .
lost jobs also lost financial security .

the debate is also underway in the world bank , where president jim yong kim recently announced that “ institutionalized discrimination is bad for human and social . ”
kim ’ s statement has invited criticism and controversy .
normally , as in uganda and nigeria , we tend to hear such voices : against official discrimination against gay , lesbian , bisexual , and transgender , “ western ” values imposed on africa .
but this claim implies that homosexuality is “ not africa . ”
and , while there is no evidence that there is no one in any country or continent without homosexuality , the contrary , and the contrary , many african leaders have taken this view .

other leaders , such as 总统 Jammeh , and zimbabwe ’ s president robert mugabe , are equally similar .
these official attitudes have caused africa ’ s gays to suffer .
indeed , in many african countries , the costs of homophobia are obvious : legal damage , social exclusion , mob justice , and so forth .
but this is precisely what africa ’ s anti-gay leaders miss : legal protection is not only a human-rights issue , but also an economic problem .
kim ’ s statement is the right thing to measure , measuring research on the economic costs of homophobia , and to explore the relationship between the law and the exclusion of same-sex sentiment and poverty .
at the world bank meeting in march 2014 , 经济学家 经济学家 , an economist at the university of 安姆赫司 , showed preliminary studies of the economic implications of homophobia in india .
the total cost of health loss alone totaled $ 257 billion in 2012 , owing to the depression , suicide , and aids treatment gaps caused by anti-gay stigma and discrimination .
in addition to these concrete costs , it is possible to become violence , loss of jobs , family exclusion , harassment in schools , and pressure to marry .
as a result , many gay education is low , poor productivity , less income , poor health , and shorter life expectancy .
in nigeria , i founded an independent project for equal rights in 2005 , in order to respond to an increasing number of people who have lost jobs in response to skepticism about their sexuality .
in the first year of the plan , we supported dozens of support .
one young man , “ 奥鲁 奥鲁 , ” was left out for him because she was gay .
another man called “ 乌奇 ” has lost his job for his sexuality .
it helps him to find accommodation and provide capital for a catering business .
for almost ten years , they can not safely use their names .
across africa , the economic costs of discrimination are increasing , and , accordingly , employers , landlords , health-care providers , educators , and others are excluded from lgbt people and others .
today , the world bank and other development agencies are setting priorities for development agendas after the millennium development goals ( mdgs ) , which will officially end in 2015 , including by promoting gender equality , increasing women ’ s rights as a strategy for economic growth .
looking ahead , the world bank should take the same approach to lgbt rights , with legal protections for sexual orientation and gender identity as conditions for countries receiving loans .
international investment and aid can help to improve economic performance and strengthen respect for basic human rights by working for the same protection to lgbt populations .
the world bank has always worried about its “ politics ” problem , emphasizing that it is not a global human-rights extension .
but it is also increasingly acknowledging its role in helping the bank member states to recognize their human-rights obligations .
lgbt rights should be a test for the bank .
aid to governments that allow specific social groups to be excluded could have a very realistic economic cost .
in considering new loans , steps should be taken to ensure that its benefits are as inclusive as possible .
at the moment , the world bank ’ s lending to nigeria is estimated to be $ 55 billion , and it is expected to increase by $ 2 billion annually in the next four years , and the bank is on track to follow suit .
africa ’ s lgbt people desperately need these powerful allies in the struggle for human rights and economic rights .
democracy in myanmar ?
tokyo – historical transformation has always been surprising .
in the cold war ’ s darkest days , gorbachev launched a liberalizing policy of reform and new thinking , while us president ronald reagan introduced strategic missile defense systems and war proxy wars in afghanistan and elsewhere .
deng xiaoping ’ s economic opening was followed by china ’ s bloody invasion of vietnam in 1978 .
and south africa ’ s last apartheid leader , clark , was initially regarded as yet another defender of the old regime , with few thought that he would unleash mandela and end the minority of whites .

in the end , however , hardliners in the system are gaining ground , stifling hope for reform .
but suu kyi and most burmese opposition are beginning to acknowledge that today ’ s political liberalization may be true .
because burma ’ s generals are almost always silent about public opinion , it is difficult to see why they would allow the election of thein sein to take power , and it is difficult to explain why they are willing to talk to the opposition .
recent events have shown a possible explanation : burma ’ s rulers are beginning to worry about stifling positions – and that is the result of the country ’ s international isolation .
indeed , myanmar ’ s public opposition to china ’ s commercial exploitation of the country ’ s natural resources has been so widespread that the government has had to halt the 瓦底 dam projects that might have serious environmental damage .
thein sein ’ s decision to halt the project is clearly a clear policy shift .
moreover , it is signaling that myanmar ’ s new government is more willing to care than all of its predecessors about public pressure and international public opinion – both strongly opposed to dam construction .
at the same time , thein sein has offered a stronger message , suggesting that the government is a totally different government : he unleashed political prisoners and invited suu kyi and his direct talks with him .
in fact , suu kyi now has the most liberal life since her nobel peace prize 20 years ago , and the national democratic league recently declared that the organization will choose the upcoming parliamentary election candidates .
for aung san suu kyi and thein sein , every step that starts now will be delicate , and people will be able to demand the liberalization of their countries ’ liberalization of their countries with the liberalization of their countries .
but the international community must act carefully .
there is no doubt that thein sein ’ s willingness to see a large number of economic and political sanctions imposed on myanmar is being canceled , but it will be premature .
the outside world , however , should make clear : any progress toward greater political openness will receive international political and economic returns .
the japanese investment bank ’ s decision to invest in myanmar ’ s port development – which would be important if the economy is open – is a positive signal that the world will drag on thein sein ’ s progress .

a currency devaluation solution
cambridge – this year is likely to be a make-or-break test for the euro .
if the eurozone is to survive , it needs a credible proposal to address its long-standing sovereign-debt crisis , which , in turn , requires addressing external imbalances and fiscal imbalances , which are at the heart of the crisis .
the crisis has exposed a significant gap in economic competitiveness within the eurozone .
from 1996 to 2010 , germany ’ s unit labor costs rose 8 % , with france rising 13 % , compared to 24 % in portugal , 35 % in spain , 37 % in italy , and 59 % in greece .
the problem is compounded by the fact that the eurozone ’ s internal trade deficit and public debt are large , owing to the fact that the problem is much more complicated for foreign creditors .
should the eurozone ’ s disintegration solve these imbalances ?
if portugal exits the eurozone , reintroducing a 埃斯库多 ( portuguese currency unit ) , the subsequent exchange-rate depreciation would have reduced the price of exports in portugal , with import prices rising , fueling much-needed economic growth .
but leaving the euro would be a tricky affair , given that the financial turmoil that it brings will outweigh any short-term gains in the competitiveness of any currency .
with such a simple solution , southern europe ’ s economic difficulties need not give up the euro , or to discount their exchange rates .
this would include raising the value-added tax , while cutting payroll taxes .
recent research shows that such “ fiscal devaluations , ” whether in gdp , consumption , or employment and inflation , have the impact on the economy ’ s exchange rate relative to undervaluation .
currency depreciation works , because it would make imports more expensive , export goods cheaper , and higher vat , and reduce payroll taxes .
raising the value-added tax would raise the prices of imported goods , with foreign firms facing higher tariffs .
to ensure that domestic firms do not raise prices , they will have to cut the payroll tax , while raising the value-added tax .
moreover , because exports are exempt from vat , the price of domestic exports will fall .
since then , even without leaving the eurozone , the exchange rate has depreciated , and it would enhance economic competitiveness and gain the same effect .
this policy also helps .
exchange-rate devaluations do strengthen competitiveness , which has positive effects on economic growth , improving the fiscal position by raising taxes .
moreover , an important advantage of fiscal devaluations lies in the additional revenue that the country ’ s trade deficit is on .
fiscal devaluations , as well as exchange-rate devaluations , have winners and losers .
both have the role of wealth leverage : inflation means that bondholders suffer from actual losses , which are commensurate with how much their wealth is commensurate with their wealth .
if the capital tax is not adjusted , domestic equity holders suffer similar losses .
by comparison , many transfers , such as unemployment benefits , health benefits , public pensions , and so on inflation , have sustained its real value .
the same is true of the minimum wage .
the impact of these allocations on the exchange rate has played an important political role in weakening exchange rates , which are reflected in the fiscal devaluation .
the fiscal devaluations have received some advocates .
indeed , french president nicolas sarkozy ’ s government has just announced a plan of fiscal depreciation .
if some worry that fiscal devaluations will clash with one another , the german government has been able to take a similar initiative , in 2007 , by implementing a similar program ( without public clarity ) in 2007 .
in short , there are other simple fiscal proposals to address southern europe ’ s short-term competitiveness problems , except for exchange-rate depreciation .
to be sure , feasible fiscal devaluations must be put in place to limit their size .
but , with debt restructuring , loose monetary policy , the ecb ’ s liquidity support , and the necessary structural reforms , these feasible fiscal devaluations can be achieved in the eurozone , without triggering a severe economic downturn stemming from austerity .
a dissident in china
tokyo – for china , 2009 was a good year .
in the image of a global recession , china ’ s economy is the tip of the world economy , a sharp leap forward ; us president barack obama was more like a man who , in his china ’ s visit to the imperial court , has been able to do so , not to mention the country ’ s most powerful global superpower .
the chinese government , under the communist leadership , has good reason to feel confident .
why , then , has a gentle old literary professor ( liu xiaobo ) been sentenced to a prison sentence for free speech and the end of one-party rule ?
liu was a petition for the 2008 petition , a common author of the book charter , which had already secured thousands of signatures .
liu was not a violent rebel , expressed in the articles expressed in the internet , and entirely devoid of 气 .
nonetheless , he was jailed for “ inciting subversion of state power . ”
it is patently absurd that liu xiaobo , or the ability to overturn the ccp ’ s huge power , is patently absurd .
the authorities , however , have apparently believed that they had to be honored , to prevent others from expressing similar views .
why is it perceived to be so dangerous for a purely consolidated regime , or even a petition for peace ?
that may be because the regime is not as secure as it seems .
without legitimacy , any government can not rule .
a wide variety of legitimacy is given to the political system : liberal democracy is only a recent innovation , often based on a hereditary monarchy that has historically been based on a totalitarian monarchy that has historically prevailed in some modern dictators , such as robert mugabe .
china has changed dramatically over the past century , but , in one respect , it has remained : a religious notion of politics remains the country .
the legitimacy of this view is not based on giving , bargaining , and the necessary compromises ; these forms of behavior form the basis of economic dogma , which is a pillar of the liberal democratic system .
on the contrary , the cornerstone of religious politics is a shared belief that is enforced by ideological legitimacy .
the ideal of the confucian state is to “ harmony . ”
if everyone follows a particular belief , including a moral code of behavior , conflicts will disappear .
in such an ideal system , ruled , as children obey their father , naturally obey rulers .
after the revolutions of the early decades of the twentieth century , confucianism was replaced by chinese-style communism .
marxism is attractive for chinese intellectuals , because it is in a sense of 气息 , introducing a modern moral orthodoxy ; and , in the form of marxism and confucianism , the conflict was based on a promise of perfect harmony : in communism ’ s utopian utopia , there would be no conflict .
chairman mao ’ s rule was a combination of the chinese imperial system with communist totalitarianism .
yet this orthodoxy is bound to fade away .
few chinese are still faithful devotees of marxism , and even in the communist party ’ s top ranks .
this left a ideological vacuum , which was quickly occupied by greed , corruption , and cynicism in the 1980 ’ s .
that crisis led to protests across all of china , and they were 笼而统之 as “ tiananmen square . ”
liu xiaobo was a vocal spokesman for student corruption in 1989 , and demanded a more liberal campaign for freedom .
soon after the bloody crackdown on tiananmen , a new orthodoxy replaced chinese marxism , which was china ’ s nationalism .
only one-party rule ensures that china will continue to rise , and for centuries of national humiliation ; the communist party represented a great power in china .
it is a mistake to hold doubt on the point of suspicion , or even “ anti-chinese ” behavior .
in doing so , liu ’ s critique is indeed subversive .
these views cast doubt on the official orthodoxy , and thus raised questions about the legitimacy of the state .
many people ’ s rejection of the chinese government ’ s refusal to negotiate with students in 1989 , or to the critics of today ’ s critics , is a misunderstanding of religious politics .
negotiations , compromise , and accommodation are a feature of economic politics , which can be traced ; in contrast , it is impossible to assume the price of negotiations .
this does not mean that economic dogma is an entirely unfamiliar model for chinese , and that , too , does not mean that religious politics is somehow religious .
in china , however , the insistence on orthodoxy remains strong enough to continue to serve as a default against political critics .
these developments can be reversed .
other confucian societies , such as south korea , taiwan , and japan , now have a thriving liberal democracy , with no reason to believe that china can not experience such a transition .
but external pressure is unlikely to bring about such change .
many foreign people , including me , have signed a letter on the jailing of liu xiaobo .
people are just hoping that this would be comfortable , and the moral inspiration for those who are working with liu was a moral inspiration ; but , for those who believe the prevailing orthodoxy in china , that move is unlikely to be shaken .
until china is liberated from religious politics , liu ’ s ideas are unlikely to take root .
this does not bode well for china ( and , indeed , the rest of the world ) .
