a global “ new deal ” ?
athens – the international monetary fund belatedly acknowledged that it grossly underestimated the damage that austerity poses to the eu ’ s growth rate , which suggests that the “ orthodox ” prescription for addressing the debt crises that occurred after the 2008-2009 financial crisis is self-defeating .
conventional wisdom suggests that , for individual countries ( or a group of countries ) , consolidation means lower interest rates , currency depreciation , and improved trade .
but , given that this can not happen simultaneously in all major economies – a country ( or a group of countries ) – the demand for such policies will eventually lead to a beggar-thy-neighbor scenario .
indeed , keynes opposed this dynamic precisely because it led to the great depression of the 1930 ’ s .
one component of today ’ s problems is that private demand in the developed world ( especially household consumption ) is weak , inadequate to compensate for the loss of demand from austerity .
for the past 20 years , consumption has driven these countries ’ economic growth , with its share of gdp reaching record highs .
moreover , major developed countries such as the united states , germany , and japan face an aging , long-term fiscal problem that is too large for the long term , straining their needs .
the current policy of monetary easing is right , but it has not been a game changer so far .
because domestic demand is the engine of growth , policies should shift resources from investment to consumption .
despite the size of the size of the size , it must be done , and it will lead to lower quality of growth , high unemployment , and the loss of life in the world ’ s poorest .
international economic policy coordination should be emphasized in order to respond effectively to changes in such a scale .
start with europe .
there is no doubt that austerity and domestic reform will not be enough to tip the eurozone ’ s periphery into recession .
it is increasingly recognized that the current policy is failing , which is causing social discontent , domestic disorder , and political instability to end the latest italian election and the growing resistance to greek reform efforts .
to bring back the eurozone ’ s periphery to growth , structural reforms and fiscal consolidation are not enough .
the eurozone ’ s economic governance system must also have radical reforms , aimed at restoring financial stability , reducing borrowing rates , while boosting external demand to offset the consequences of austerity .
reforming governance means a significant step toward economic union : through eurobonds , which would mobilize enough rescue funds ; allowing the ecb to intervene in the bond market ; and establish fiscal and banking coalitions .
this seems unlikely , because most eu member states are reluctant to cede power to european institutions .
but europe should be committed to this direction .
otherwise , speculation about member states ’ national debt will not stop , leading to borrowing costs at levels that are inconsistent with maintaining economic recovery .
when it comes to external demand , intra-european aid within a strong country is unlikely to be sufficient , owing mainly to domestic fiscal and political conditions .
the european internal version of marshall plan , adopted by mobilizing eu budget resources and increasing the european investment bank ’ s lending to the weaker countries ’ financial investments , could be an alternative , but without political support .
globally , neither the us nor japan has provided significant external stimulus .
only asia ’ s emerging and developing countries can effectively boost global demand by pursuing policies aimed at boosting domestic consumption – which , in turn , could spur more investment .
the imf ’ s latest experience suggests that , through appropriate coordination , private funds can mobilize participation in large companies , combining demand expansion and infrastructure investment .
in other words , we need a global “ new deal ” – combining policies aimed at an orderly and orderly global consumption and investment .
advanced countries should promote productivity-enhancing structural reforms with renewed vigor .
the eurozone should solidify its monetary union .
to make this new deal possible , some preconditions must be met .
first , the g20 must intensify international policy coordination , which can be considered by establishing a permanent secretariat to consider policy proposals and recommendations for macroeconomic and financial development .
the secretariat should be actively cooperating with the imf to analyze the results of the latter , especially with regard to exchange rates .
second , global financial reform must be accelerated .
the financial sector needs to strengthen regulation , strengthen oversight , and require international consensus mechanisms to address problems caused by too big ( or too complex ) to address the problems posed by large , global institutions .
such reforms are essential if the international financial system is to become a massive resource source ( and that is the basis for the changing structure of global demand ) .
finally , a new trade pact – which may be ( but not necessarily ) in doha – is to ensure that major trade powers can enter the foreign market .
this is vital to inspire confidence in asian countries , and to persuade them to develop internal , rather than external , sources of demand .
moreover , trade liberalization would also increase consumer confidence worldwide .
the new global agreement is at the time that the goal should be to boost growth , eliminate crises in some parts of the world , and rebalance the global economy so that it returned to a strong , robust growth path .
the other financial crisis
newport beach – the two variants of the financial crisis are continuing to wreak havoc on the west economy , exacerbating unemployment and poverty : a financial crisis that we often read in the newspapers ; and the other is not the same as the crises of the other .
before the two crises are addressed properly , the west will continue to bear the burden of losing growth , persistently high unemployment , and excessive wealth and wealth .
the sovereign-debt crisis is well known .
to avoid a depression , governments have implemented fiscal and monetary stimulus during the global financial crisis .
it succeeded in offsetting the severe economic dislocations caused by the private sector ’ s deleveraging , but it is in order to disrupt its fiscal balance and the costs of destabilizing central banks ’ balance sheets .
while the quality of sovereign credit has deteriorated almost completely – and it is likely to continue to deteriorate – its impact on countries is different .
some western countries – for example , greece – were at first a bad government accounting for their government ’ s books , so soon a crisis of secular continuity is long .
these countries will remain mired in crisis , even a long period of hope for their citizens .
other countries have been fiscally responsible for the past , but they are unable to cope with the debt ( for example , in ireland ’ s budget ) that they have incurred .
other countries – including the united states – have no direct threat , but are unable to make progress on some long-term issues , and several countries like germany have deep economic and financial resilience through years of fiscal discipline and institutional reforms .
it is not surprising that countries ’ responses vary .
but , in fact , these policies have only one ( and disappointing ) common denominator : the inability to rely on rapid economic growth to deleverage for its excessive debt .
greece has actually defaulted on some debt .
ireland and britain have opted for austerity and reform .
the us is gradually transferring resources from creditors to debtors through financial repression .
and germany is gradually adapting to a steady relative expansion of domestic demand .
so much of what i think about sovereign-debt crises , because the impact on its national , regional , and global implications is abundant enough .
after all , it was called sovereignty , because they have the power to collect , regulate , or even extreme .
and , as i know , small and medium-size enterprises in the west have experienced a significant decline in credit access – not only to new financing , but also to newer credit lines and ability to borrow and borrow .
the immediate causes of this credit crisis are clear .
its range covers the banks ’ efforts to curb lending to unusually risky risk aversion , from credit instruments to the collapse of credit intermediation to some institutions .
this credit constraint is one reason why many countries ’ unemployment rates have continued to rise – often at a worrisome level , for example , with 25 % unemployment in greece and spain ( where youth unemployment is already above 50 % ) – and a high rate of unemployment in countries like the united states ( which is not high in the united states ) .
this is not just a problem of productivity loss and rising poverty ; long-term unemployment also leads to social unrest , mistrust of domestic political leaders , and the risk of a lost generation .
indeed , unemployment data in many advanced countries are largely characterized by long-term unemployment ( often defined as six months or more ) .
the gradual loss of skills is a problem for those who had previously worked , and the first employment unsuccessful means not only that unemployment is so simple , but also the risk of not hiring .
governments have done too little to address the private credit crisis .
in theory , they must first address the sovereign debt of the crisis ; yet it is not yet clear whether most officials have set a comprehensive plan .
policy asymmetry among countries most acutely affected by the sovereign-debt crisis is most glaring .
in these countries , governments have largely left the private sector to fend for ; most households and businesses are struggling , so that the long-term economic collapse has intensified .
other countries have embraced a “ land of 寻梦 ” – known as “ the establishment of the platform , ” which has been “ built ” – to deal with private credit markets , such as in the us , where the fed ’ s policy measures , for example , reduce interest rates on mortgage mortgages .
the ecb is also taking an indirect approach .
in both places , however , other policymaking entities with more powerful tools seem neither willing nor able to assume their role .
in this case , the central bank ’ s actions will remain insufficient to gain traction .
in fact , only the uk has made clear that a more coordinated and direct way to offset the long-term shortfalls caused by the private credit crisis would be to offset the long-term shortfalls caused by the private credit crisis .
the “ lending package ” designed by the united kingdom to join banks and finance ministries was designed to “ increase the incentive for banks and building societies to lend to the uk ’ s families and non-financial firms , ” while also requiring responsibility for their actions .
british examples matter ; but , given the scope and scale of the challenges , the proposal is relatively conservative .
this program may spur some beneficial credit intermediation , but it can not have a major impact on the factors that continue to impede strong economic recovery .
the proper access to credit for the production sector is essential for a well-functioning economy .
otherwise , economic growth will be depleted , and it can not create full employment , rising wealth and income inequality , and erode social fabric .
that is why any comprehensive approach to restoring the economy and financial dynamism in the advanced countries must focus on the proper resumption of private credit flows .
toxic politics and better economics
new york – the relationship between politics and economics is changing .
developed-country politicians are trapped in a strange and often harmful conflict , rather than in an increasingly consistent economic consensus about how to escape an era of low inequality .
this trend must be reversed , or it will undermine the structure of the advanced economies , and to put emerging economies into trouble .
obviously , political infighting is not new .
but , until recently , people believed that if professional economists were able to agree on a given policy approach , political leaders can listen .
even if more radical parties try to pursue a different agenda , powerful forces – whether from the g7 governments to exhortations , private capital markets , or the strings of the international monetary fund and the world bank – are almost always sure that a common approach will eventually prevail .
the multilateral institutions have adopted the washington consensus mechanism amplified by the washington consensus , which drives the broader process of economic and financial globalization .
the incoming government – especially those that are governed by non-traditional movements – is able to rely on domestic anxiety and frustration with the prevailing political parties – sometimes the appropriateness and relevance of the washington consensus .
but , as brazil ’ s president 卢拉以 卢拉以 demonstrated in his 2002 policy priorities , the washington consensus is usually a triumph , and has long dominated the script until greek prime minister alexis tsipras took a similarly dramatic turn .
but after years of unusually sluggish and strikingly non-inclusive growth , the washington consensus is unraveling .
advanced-country citizens ’ citizens have been disappointed by the “ establishment ” – including economic “ experts , ” mainstream political leaders , major multinational corporations – and increasingly blame them for economic hardship .
anti-establishment movements and figures quickly seized this frustration , using inflammatory and even 战斗性 rhetoric to win support .
they do not even need to win elections to disrupt the transmission mechanism between economics and politics .
in june , britain was discredited by the brexit vote – a decision that directly repudiated the economic consensus that remained in the eu ’ s best interests .
the reason for the united kingdom ’ s referendum was that , in 2013 , then-prime minister david cameron feared that he could not secure his conservative party ’ s base in the year .
so he used the temptation to hold a referendum on euroskeptic voters .
why should cameron worry ?
the political disruptions created by the uk independence party ( ukip ) , the anti-establishment british independence party , won only a seat in parliament , and then in a muddle .
now , the floodgates have opened .
at the recent conservative conference , prime minister theresa may and his cabinet members suggest that they are prepared to pursue “ hard brexit , ” which would make trade arrangements that would benefit the uk economy .
they also attacked the “ international elite , ” and the bank of england ’ s policy played a central role in stabilizing the british economy , with the bank of england ’ s policy having succeeded in creating a coherent brexit strategy .
other advanced economies are experiencing similar political developments .
in germany , the far-right alternative für deutschland has performed unexpectedly in recent state elections , and it has already begun to influence the german government ’ s behavior .
in the united states , the fact that even donald trump ’ s campaign can not bring the republican party back to the white house ( an increasingly unusual possibility of a presidential campaign that has lately been masked by a remarkable presidential campaign ) could have lasting implications for american politics .
if management is mismanaged , italy ’ s constitutional referendum in december – prime minister matteo renzi ’ s government to consolidate his support for his support – would be counterproductive , as cameron ’ s referendum proposals have done , impeding effective action to address italy ’ s economic challenges .
make no mistake : credible and credible policy options are available .
after years of mediocre economic performance , a broad consensus is that the excessive reliance on unconventional monetary policy is needed .
as imf managing director christine lagarde put it , “ central banks can not be the only game . ”
but they are .
in the only game that i published in january , i argued that countries need a more comprehensive policy approach , including pro-growth structural reforms , more balanced demand management , and better cross-border policy coordination and organizational coordination .
and there is a need to address serious excessive debt problems – the ongoing greek crisis highlighted this – the disruptive impact of the problem extends far beyond the immediate victims .
the new consensus on these issues is good news .
but , in the current political environment , translating this consensus into action could be too slow or impossible to achieve .
the risk is that , as bad politics crowds out good economics , popular anger and discontent will intensify , making politics more harmful .
we want enlightened political leadership to take full control of the game , and voluntarily put in place the 中途 , lest clear economic and financial crises compel policymakers to focus on minimizing the impact .
new haven – one of the most recent surprises of inflation is real .
in the united states , the so-called core cpi ( cpi ) , which excludes food and energy , has returned to a downward trajectory .
in the three months ending in may , the core consumer price index remained unchanged , keeping it at 1.7 percentage points above its previous year .
for the us economy , which is widely believed to have reached full employment , this is a damning mistake – and the most embarrassing is that the fed , the most embarrassed , is trying to bring inflation back to 2 % .
on the other side of the world , a similar story is continuing in japan .
but the story is much tougher for japan ’ s highly prone to deflation .
in april , japan ’ s core consumer price index was basically flat , and the economic performance of tokyo ’ s metropolitan areas showed that may .
for the bank of japan ( boj ) , which used unprecedented unconventional policy buffers to stem the cumulative 年 of deflation ( 1994 ) , it is not just a cold 冷水 , but a fiasco .
the story applies to global reach .
of course , there are notable examples – such as the united kingdom , currency pressure , and a one-time holiday distortion – to the core inflation rate to 2.4 % , as well as malaysia ’ s elimination of the overall inflation rate , but the core inflation rate is at around 2.5 % .
but they are exceptions in the inflationless world .
the imf ’ s latest forecast suggests this .
despite the global economy ’ s modest growth , the advanced economies ’ inflation levels are expected to be just below 2 % in 2017-2018 .
the story of this story was written years ago in japan .
from asset bubbles and excessive leverage to the exchange rate and declining productivity , japan ’ s experience – the so-called “ lost decade ” – shows that a large economy may have made all the mistakes that a large economy could make .
but no lesson is much more profound than a series of policy mistakes made by the boj .
not only is the use of reckless monetary easing laying the groundwork for japan ’ s decline ; the country ’ s central bank will also cut policy rates to zero ( or even lower ) , implementing qe and manipulating long-term interest rates to revive the economy .
this creates an unhealthy dependency .
while japan has learned many lessons since the early 1990 ’ s , the rest of the world has ignored it .
the research papers have written countless , seminars , and , as former us federal reserve chairman ben bernanke promised , never will repeat japan .
yet another major central bank – especially the us federal reserve and the european central bank – will suddenly follow , with the equally dire consequences .
the inflation surprise of 2017 provides three key insights .
first , the relationship between inflation and depression – the so-called phillips curve – has broken down .
as a result of the so-called “ second partition ” of globalization ’ s “ second division , ” the world is replete with excess supply and increasingly decentralized global supply chains .
the outsourcing of these supply chains greatly expanded the global supply curve , radically altering the concept of slack in labor and product markets , and the inflationary pressures of such depressions .
second , today ’ s globalization is inherently asymmetric .
as a result of a variety of factors – the ongoing recession in japan and the us – domestic precautionary saving , combined with weak consumption in europe ’ s productivity , has been severely impaired .
then , in the context of ever-expanding supply , the imbalances are inherently deflationary .
third , central banks are powerless to respond to the changes in the so-called 流动性 liquidity trap .
sound familiar ?
today , the use of 新花招 is a growing global supply curve .
this makes today ’ s central banks more impotent than they were in the 1930 ’ s .
this is not an incurable disease .
in a globalized world – apart from protectionism led by the us 主义者 – the solution should focus on the demand side of the equation .
the most important lesson from the 1930 ’ s , and from the experience of modern japan , is that monetary policy can hardly afford a long-term lack of aggregate demand .
addressing this problem primarily depends on the financial sector , and the idea that central banks should consider renewed promises to raise its inflation target is unreliable .
at the same time , fed chair janet yellen has made the right decision , pushing for the fed ’ s policy normalization , ending a trial that is long overdue , owing to the futility of doing nothing .
the danger has been that when it comes to unconventional monetary easing , it will not gain traction in the real economy , which has injected liquidity into the us and global financial markets , which led to asset bubbles , reckless financial risk-taking , and the next crisis .
moreover , because unconventional easing is designed for a strategy that no longer exists , the fed has made no ammunition to deal with the inevitable next recession and crisis .
our neglect of history is very dangerous .
the recent disappointment of central banks targeting inflation is not a surprise , and the related decline in long-term interest rates is similar .
a careful look at japan ’ s lessons must benefit considerably .
a stop in europe
princeton – in a forthcoming speech , german chancellor gauck gauck conceded that the growing level of inequality among member states is generating “ disturbing feelings , even false anger , ” which increases the risk of state humiliation .
he points out that , in addition to the economic crisis , there is “ a crisis of confidence in a european political project . ”
while gauck stated that he remains a staunch pro-european , he emphasized the need for a deep european future , particularly the eurozone ’ s future .
on the cusp of further integration , europeans hesitate , “ don ’ t know whether we should be moving forward . ”
he has said that to quell this hesitation is a symptom of a deep sense of “ more europe . ”
gauck may not go far enough : an ever-closer union is likely to be a 政治婚姻 .
any meaningful progress that makes the eurozone more stable will require a significant – and largely open – fiscal commitment , and the eu is not ready to cross the threshold of one threshold .
repeatedly pretending to move forward , then a tipping point back then , increases political uncertainty and economic vulnerability .
it is now not encouraging to pursue a more unified time , but to restore the effective sovereignty of eurozone authorities .
doing so would alleviate anxiety in the short term , thereby giving europe a restructuring opportunity to prepare for a more integrated europe and a stronger euro .
to this end , eurozone leaders must implement three fundamental measures .
dysfunctional european fiscal governance should be abolished ; fiscal responsibility should be returned to member states ; and , in order to minimize the future of excessive borrowing , private creditors should be charged with the loss of unsustainable sovereign debt .
the problem with europe ’ s fiscal governance is clear .
before the crisis , the single-minded emphasis on limiting the budget deficit to 3 % of gdp led to the abuse of this approach .
the german and french economies , such as germany and france , openly ridiculed this goal , while others manipulate the numbers ( that is , the eurozone ’ s common phenomenon , not just greece ) .
after the crisis erupted , 3 % of the deficit was the focus of unrelenting austerity – a form that the anthropologist coined as “ 内卷化 , ” which occurs when a process arises from external or internal pressures .
in other words , eu leaders have begun to strengthen fiscal governance , ultimately creating the inevitable inefficiency and bureaucratic conundrum .
as fiscal metrics become more complex , monitoring of fiscal behavior is becoming increasingly easy to undermine .
the question of returning fiscal responsibility to national authorities is also large – not least because centralized fiscal authorities have proved highly ineffective .
the people of troubled countries bear the fiscal burden of the crisis , so that they are irresponsible to claim that they are irresponsible .
the current strategy of exchanging good behavior in favor of good behavior encourages a game of purpose .
despite the government ’ s risk of fiscal temptation , the people ’ s suffering is likely to contain future excesses .
national fiscal sovereignty promotes the final key measures : the creation of more sophisticated relationships with private creditors .
the eurozone is the creation of the “ no bailout ” principle : if member states can not repay their debts , creditors must bear the losses .
but the creditors chose to disregard this threat – the fact that they are right .
instead of imposing a precedent for bailing out the no-bailout principle , debtor countries use official loans to service private creditors .
as a result , these countries have pushed themselves into sustained austerity , low growth , and high debt while cutting off any future incentive to impose fiscal discipline on sovereign borrowers .
unless the burden of this burden is placed on private creditors , debtor countries can not escape their debt .
in the us , states are responsible for their fiscal management , without having to comply with the single model .
states are not regulated by the federal government ; they are constrained by the recognition of their debt .
the system worked well : in contrast to the eurozone ’ s fragile member states , the us states have sharply reduced deficits and debt ratios .
so far , european integration is largely a process of “ walking forward , ” and every drop becomes a lesson of a stronger union .
but this uncertain approach may be enough to claim that the basis for good intentions , but it does not inspire the confidence needed to make the profound fiscal commitments that countries urgently need .
europeans deserve a chance to regain their footing .
the return to fiscal responsibility to national authorities means not only the end of the fiscal situation , but also the sense of frustration and the lack of a meaningful sense of representation , which is a breeding ground for the euro pessimism .
simply put , taking back a step would be an opportunity to reset , rethink , and engineer a more stable and integrated europe .
for a fiscal union that can work – however unlikely – a solid foundation is essential .
as the 高克所 explained , europeans “ are pausing ... the next step , ” and the next step ( itself ) , the next step , is to enter uncharted territory . ”
giving europeans time and space to choose a more europe would help to strengthen the core values that underpin integration for more than six decades .
continuing to stumble forward , however , inevitably leads to weakness or even decline .
a european-style cure for the balkan downturn
vienna – much of europe ’ s politics is shaped by events and anniversaries .
but while events are often unpredictable , anniversaries are not .
after five years , europe will mark the 100th anniversary of the outbreak of world war i , which did not only lead to other events , but also through a series of events that led to the emergence of today ’ s eyes .
it is not hard to imagine that sarajevo will be the site of the brutal and bloody twentieth century of the twentieth century .
but what in five years will sarajevo be in five ?
will it still be the capital of the country ’ s citizens , whose citizens have totally lost touch with voters , and whose politicians have totally lost touch with the electorate ?
or is there any chance that european leaders will draw the anniversary , declaring that the remaining balkan countries have been integrated into the eu ?
but , just as recently , a survey of gallup europe has delivered 20 years since the fall of the berlin wall and a decade of war in kosovo , in serbia , 黑山共和国 , macedonia , albania , croatia , bosnia , and herzegovina .
and the findings seem to indicate that the next five years will be a key moment for the region ’ s future development .
the report shows that , while the vast majority of citizens believe that further armed conflict within the region is unlikely , the public ’ s mood – except kosovo and albania – is bleak .
the only thing they can offer is peace , and development is nowhere near .
trust in political elites , state institutions , and eu institutions is declining .
just last year , the majority of citizens suffered a decline in living standards , and it was still thought that there were more opportunities abroad .
the rate of pessimism among young people is alarmingly high , and government corruption and mismanagement are considered widespread .
so those who are worthy of praise for the region ’ s stability are worth watching .
indeed , most citizens of bosnia and herzegovina believe that their leaders are not interested in joining the eu .
the majority of citizens who are surveyed believe that their country is wrong .
less than a decade of croats ( the country will join the eu in the near future ) believes that their country is on track .
the region is now facing two options : the choice of “ shock consolidation ” to integrate all of the balkan west into the european union , and , for good or worse , for all of the eu ’ s countries , but the expectation is that these countries would be extremely dangerous .
so the eu ’ s goal in the region should not be the “ stability of stability . ”
and the eu will have more problems in the future if it continues to operate in places like bosnia and kosovo , where the benefits of the future can not be fulfilled .
for serbia , in particular , the old doctrine of non-alignment will be central to the country ’ s foreign and security policy if the delay is delayed .
as the best and brightest believe that their future is in a distant country , the chaos in the balkans will breed its own dynamic when “ stability ” is only synonymous with political and economic stagnation .
so if europe ’ s leaders do plan to meet in sarajevo in 2014 , they now need to act .
in fact , the lisbon treaty has added a long-term vision of european politics to a long-term vision of european politics , and the enlargement of the eu is no longer institutional obstacles .
today , unlike a year ago , we have been able to understand how many countries in the balkans have , and the balkan watch results indicate that these countries want to join the eu .
in addition to what the eu ’ s recent parliamentary elections have learned from the recent parliamentary elections in bulgaria , in contrast to conventional thinking , the impact on these countries ’ influence in brussels is growing .
the fact that the eu ’ s decision to ease serbia ’ s visa restrictions on serbia , 黑山共和国 , and macedonia – and , as george 帕 , the eu ’ s leading architect of the eu ’ s balkan integration strategy – is a source of optimism .
for the balkans , either they are now joined or never joined .
relaxing a visa would be a strategic step toward “ shock integration , ” but if the eu fails to make clear political action , it is just a new one .
in short , the moment of world war i ’ s 100 anniversary was not just the commemoration , but timing .
closing europe ’ s strategic gap
but there is a problem with almost no one : russia ’ s annexation of crimea and the invasion of eastern ukraine mean what europe ’ s foreign policy has meant for european foreign policy .
in the early stages of the crisis , germany , which had made great bets on russia , opposed any action that could have consequences .
but , as the crisis deepens , german chancellor angela merkel managed to persuade its european counterparts to implement a broad and draconian sanctions .
this is undoubtedly a step in defense of defense , but failed foreign-policy approaches to addressing the ukraine crisis , the failure of europe ’ s response to the european union , and the chaotic energy approach – that europe ’ s misguided neighborhood policy ( enp ) – will not help .
on both fronts , europe has a lack of strategic vision that gives people the impression that russian president vladimir putin is playing with applause .
the crisis in ukraine has increasingly shown signs of “ frozen conflict ” – the expertise of russia ’ s foreign policy .
in fact , the situation in ukraine demonstrates that russia has achieved a tactical victory , and a ceasefire that has been maintained – and thus to the vast political autonomy of donetsk and luhansk – has allowed russia to create a conflict in the eyes of the eu .
moreover , the lack of implementation of the eu ’ s association agreement with ukraine is a clear indication that russia ’ s current domination of the 欧盟 marriage is the case .
in europe , the kremlin has been able to pursue a successful divide-and-rule strategy , a remarkable example of hungary ’ s decision to suspend gas flows to ukraine .
hungarian prime minister viktor orbán ’ s government has been incompatible with the european union ’ s democratic standards in recent years , and now openly supports authoritarian regimes that have brought serious shadow to europe – especially putin ’ s regime .
nonetheless , the timing of the current ceasefire – that is , the european commission ’ s transition to a transition – is highly favorable , as is putin ’ s shortsighted emphasis on tactical victories .
eu leaders should use the battle for combat to stop reacting and start anticipating .
the eu can look at long-term strategy , overcoming and ultimately undermining putin ’ s short-term successes .
such a calculation must include a redefinition of the enp .
the plan ’ s task – helping to guide political , social , and economic transitions in neighboring countries – is not inherently problematic ; the problem is that the task is to be interpreted and implemented .
for starters , the enp assumes that all of the eu ’ s neighbors – whether the southern or eastern neighbors – ultimately want to achieve european values and structures at home .
in other words , the enp fails to account for the development , culture , and 志趣 differences among eu partners .
in practice , the enp has overly stressed the technical approach , with a lack of strategic vision and a lack of strategic vision .
in the run-up to the ukraine crisis , for example , the european commission was focused exclusively on the technical details of the association agreement , fully ignoring the potential consequences of the process – for example , in russia .
to be sure , the eu recognizes the need for a coherent strategy , and seeks to address this problem by establishing european external action service , the eeas , and high representative of foreign affairs .
but the eeas finally survived the european commission ’ s impasse , and outgoing senior representative catherine ashton has not moderated this tension , because she was unwilling to get into the eu ’ s internal disputes .
tellingly , ashton has made progress only in areas with ample consensus , such as negotiations on iran ’ s nuclear program and the pact between kosovo and serbia .
further constraining europe ’ s effectiveness is its fragmented approach to securing energy supplies .
countries have largely controlled their own energy policies , and european energy markets become inefficient and excessively dependent on russian supplies .
eu-wide energy policies exist , but they are linked to renewables , not geopolitics and energy security .
but we remain hopeful .
the new european commission president , jean-claude juncker , has made a stunning restructuring of europe with a much-needed strategic leadership .
indeed , juncker has already expressed a message to the incoming high representative federica mogherini to participate in the european commission ’ s policy agenda .
this new structure – which will guide the burden and coordination of multiple members , including the responsibility for trade , the enp , and the climate – should strengthen the unity and collegiality of eu policies , especially after she completed the global strategy to assess her european council ’ s appointment .
to do that , mogherini must make himself a leader supported by juncker and the european council president donald tusk .
most important , all eu member states must commit to cooperation .
ukrainians have demonstrated the power of europe ’ s values .
in fact , europe has plenty of tools ; it is simply a need to understand how to use it .
if it can , europe can not only respond better to russia ’ s challenges , but also to many other challenges in today ’ s rapidly changing global environment .
the women of europe ?
paris – will european women turn to the engine of political change ?
experience and common sense tell us that progress in the economic cycle , accountability , and hard work begins with women and depend on them .

but the main question is whether , as women engage in the rise of female politics , will they create a new vision of voters ( or protesters ) , and the new leadership model ?
a eurozone sabbatical
munich – under constant external pressure , the eurozone countries that have been hit by the crisis have finally abandoned their longstanding resistance to make their budget cuts .
a sharp reduction in wages , while cutting public employees , wants to keep the new debt at a tolerable level .
but these countries ’ competitiveness – especially greece and portugal – have not improved .
the latest eurostat figures in the european union show that , regardless of the country ’ s 价格指数 price index ( inflation-adjusted ) price index , there is no tendency to move toward substantial depreciation when the price index of the country is to be restored .
and only if the real price declines , the lower unit labor costs can translate into competitiveness .
after all , it was the introduction of cheap credit after the introduction of the euro , resulting in price inflation that eventually led to lower competitiveness in these countries , with current-account deficits and accumulation of large foreign debts .
now that capital markets are to fill these deficits , the price should be reversed , but it is clear that it is not happening .
in 2010 , inflation in some of the eurozone ’ s crisis-stricken countries was only slightly lower than that of the 同区 competitors .
but the recent eurostat figures in the european union showed a very different picture in the third quarter of 2011 : the price level of portugal and greece has remained intact after a year of disaster , and italy and spain have risen slightly , even slightly , by 0.3 % and 0.3 % , respectively .
only ireland continues to fall rapidly – from the country ’ s real-estate bubble in 2006 , and so far has fallen by 2.2 % relative to its prices .
overall , ireland ’ s relative price relative to other eurozone competitors has been almost 15 % cheaper relative to other eurozone competitors .
this internal devaluation was rewarded in return : ireland ’ s current-account deficit in 2008 amounted to 5.6 % of gdp , while the european commission expects the congress to run a surplus of GDP0.7% % in 2011 .
true , given that ireland can repay its own foreign debt only 1 % of its foreign debt , this is merely a relief problem .
but ireland ’ s surplus trade is actually improving further .
much of ireland ’ s reversal owes much to its efficient export sector – the authorities ’ backers have the ability to promote political u-turn .
instead , the lobbying forces of greece are powerful .
as greece ’ s economy minister 米 赫里 has put it , it would have to be tempted by the eu ’ s policy of subsidies , to be entrepreneurs to pay for the import sector .
today , these importers have developed a powerful barrier to resisting any possible deflation , even though lowering prices – and thus by shifting greek demand from external to internal production – is the only way to put the greek economy back on track .
because greece ’ s current-account deficit as a share of gdp is three times higher than ireland ’ s , greece ’ s price level will have to fall by half as much as it did .
but who does not believe that greece will be able to achieve this as a member of the eurozone without a massive social unrest – and perhaps even the brink of civil war .
the situation is quite intractable .
many people believe that debt relief and socialization of debt are the only way out .
but such measures have been implemented long ago .
the recent agreement to cut the greek 2370 billion ( $ 3160 billion ) debt is more than 30 % higher than the net national income of greece ’ s 180 billion ( $ 3160 billion ) . but such aid merely strengthens the wrong prices – and the low state of state competitiveness .
these debts will be reinvigorated like a tumor , one day more than a day , while undermining the creditworthiness of moderate eurozone countries .
if that happens , the euro will eventually collapse .
only lower prices can create current-account surpluses and enable them to repay their foreign debts .
it is time for europe to face this grim reality .
those countries that do not want to act lower their prices should receive a temporary exit from the eurozone to reduce prices and debt .
in other words , they should give a euro sabbatical – as the american economist kenneth rogoff recommends .
after the ensuing financial crash died , the sun will soon be 普照大地 .
the creditors may bear the brunt of the enormous losses incurred by debt relief , but the benefits would be even greater relative to those who would otherwise have been left to stay in the eurozone , because the prosperity that these countries can prosper through leaving them is the only chance to recover all assets .
turkey ’ s fair treatment
turkey appears to have received an ultimatum from the european commission : open ports to ships from cyprus in a month , or , otherwise , the danger of postponing the current accession talks .
at the same time , the commission ’ s latest report on turkey ’ s progress toward accession shows that political reforms have slowed , further questioning the possibility of the country ’ s future membership .
the european council will study the european commission ’ s progress report next month .
in this case , europe ’ s leaders should ask themselves that , in the case of cyprus , are the eu fair to turkey ?
is the eu always supportive of turkish political reform ?
what is the eu ’ s long-term interest in turkey ?
if the answers to the first two problems are not , as i believe , the third question is important .
indeed , turkey ’ s closure of ( greece ) has closed its ports , which violated the agreement .
but it is also true that , in part , turkey is denied access to free trade in parts of northern cyprus and other interests .
this is because cyprus remains a divided island .
at the time , when cyprus joined the eu in 2004 , it would be unified .
turkey accepted the united nations unified approach .
but , given that greece ’ s leaders did not adhere to an implicit agreement with the eu to support such a proposal , it voted against the proposal .
but cyprus became the eu ’ s member , but only greece .
this is obviously a mistake , because it makes the eu part of the conflict .
it has given greek cypriot leaders the possibility of blocking progress between the eu and turkey .
turkey ’ s political and legal reforms in recent years have been very broad , as turks ’ desire to move closer to the eu has facilitated these reforms .
but the turks are increasingly feeling that they have not received fair treatment , so the turkish public ’ s support for eu membership has fallen sharply .
that way , it has added new powers to those who want turkey to develop in another direction : they want turkey to move toward a more islamic society , not a modern secular state .
as a result , the eu ’ s move could largely explain the lack of progress in recent turkey ’ s reform process .
this raises the third question : what kind of turkey does the eu want ?
there should be no doubt about this question : turkey ’ s democracy and the economy continue to be strengthened in the eu ’ s interest .
more than four decades ago , the eu pledged that once turkey meets its membership , it would welcome its accession .
now the eu ’ s leaders should take this promise seriously .
a sad fact is that most voters within the eu oppose turkey ’ s accession .
but they are merely reacting to the current situation .
if they are , they want a reformed turkey as partner , with more people inclined to say .
europe ’ s leaders must therefore accept two challenges .
first , they should make clear to their constituents that the eu must adhere to turkey ’ s commitment to turkey , and that it is also in greater interest for all europeans .
second , they must be treated in the negotiations with turkey .
the litmus test of europe ’ s leadership is about the use of ports .
on this issue , finland , the eu ’ s rotating president , proposes a realistic and considered solution to the conflict .
all european leaders should support finland ’ s proposal .
at the same time , efforts should be made to restore the united nations ’ proposal for cyprus .
this should be the case if that means putting pressure on some eu member states .
永别 ( glorious ) war
in a recent few days , the italian government failed to fall after the congress ’ s proposal to deploy troops in afghanistan , and the uk and denmark announced their intention to withdraw their forces from iraq .
the bush administration has been moving toward an additional 名 us troops in iraq and urged allies to increase their troops in afghanistan .
they are increasingly convinced that “ victory ” is unpredictable in any asymmetrical conflict between the armed insurgents and the strength of its religious drive , regardless of how powerful and their religious forces are driven .
donald rumsfeld ’ s assessment of the military “ transition ” – the technological upgrading of military power to achieve decisive victory with fewer troops – has failed in iraq outright .
israel , even with a strong technical advantage , failed to defeat hezbollah in lebanon .
the rockets and missiles that fell into northern israel over 33 days were more than the attack on the united kingdom during world war ii .
so the israelis now must confront this new phenomenon : an asymmetric entity with a national firepower , hezbollah .
so the fierce debate about whether the size of us forces in iraq should be expanded is meaningless .
neither the soviet experience in afghanistan in the 1980 ’ s nor nato today demonstrates that the army ’ s number is the most important factor on the modern battlefield .
the great military thinker carl von clausewitz ’ s idea of equating “ decisive battles ” as the “ center of gravity ” of war has not lost its usefulness in a conflict of “ pivot . ”
indeed , while there was one such center of gravity ( which was a massive concentration of military force that could be devastating for enemies of enemies ) in 1991 , despite the defeat of rome in 1991 , the war between those industrialized countries has become a historical aberration .
most countries now have legitimate legal boundaries , and they are increasingly abiding by international norms and codes of conduct during times of war .
indeed , the obligation of countries to abide by humanitarian rules of code of conduct , and its wanton assault on its enemies , makes asymmetric warfare particularly difficult to reconcile .
moreover , in an era of global media and international war crimes courts , the conditions for state use are becoming increasingly complex .
where strategic frontiers exist , the armed conflict between the border and pakistan ’ s borders , the border between india and india , and the north-south border is likely to occur .
in this context , war , as egyptians showed in 1973 , can still be a means to resolve conflict .
syrians may try to attack israel in order to break the deadlock over the future of the golan heights .
yet , on kashmir , asymmetric conflicts now involving proxies and terrorist groups may not degenerate into a full-blown war , precisely because both india and pakistan have mutual nuclear deterrence .
the changing nature of the battlefield means that the idea of war as a defining event for international conflict has become obsolete .
clausewitz ’ s notion that military action will eventually lead to a political solution is no longer convincing .
the “ victory ” won ’ t bring peace , because there will always be no war on the other .
so , for example , the conventional war in kosovo has lasted two months , opening the stage for an asymmetric conflict .
likewise , the 三周 “ shock ” campaign launched in iraq in 2003 ended in “ victory , ” but opened the door to the occupiers and ordinary iraqis .
after the merciless pounding of southern lebanon , hezbollah has not been weakened .
nor does the return of the taliban in afghanistan six years after the overthrow of the taliban seemed to be in the cards .
the occupier ’ s weakness was revealed during the war of the last war , and continued deployment was the goal of increasing the deployment of the insurgents , while the occupying forces have no time to adapt to changing battlefield conditions .
insurgents in iraq , like the british , have been able to deal with their enemy ’ s technological advantages in just three years , and the irish republican army , which has spent 30 years failing to do so , did not .
the iraq war and israel ’ s war with hamas and hezbollah demonstrated the limits of military force , as well as the role of diplomatic and conflict resolution .
in responding to complex political and cultural conflicts , international and regional alliances revolve around a legitimate purpose .
it is naïve to believe that the idea of using force and deterrence is unnecessary .
but the purpose of using military force is to connect with such a recognition : in today ’ s asymmetric conflicts , victory can no longer be obtained on the battlefield .
a smarter foreign policy can produce more sustainable outcomes only if it is to cope with genuine anxieties about civilization in crisis .
a farewell to nuclear weapons
moscow – 25 years ago , in october , i and ronald reagan discuss how to cut and destroy the horrors of the terror of the two parties in reykjavik , which had been destroyed by the two countries 200 years ago .
despite the many disagreements that exist , it was strongly agreed that civilized societies should not put such horrors on the ground .
though we did not have the highest aspirations in reykjavik , reagan ’ s phrase was “ a turning point in search of a world of security stability . ”
the next few years will determine whether the dream of a nuclear weapon from the planet will be realized .
critics point out that nuclear disarmament is not realistic at best , and it is a dangerous utopian dream .
i strongly opposed this view as someone who used to use nuclear weapons .
nuclear deterrence is always a brittle guarantor of peace .
the us , russia , and other nuclear-armed states are using the world to introduce a future of nuclear weapons without a comprehensive plan for disarmament .
we must first be put to stop this catastrophe .
as george shultz and george shultz noted five years ago , as i pointed out five years ago , as the number of nuclear states grows , nuclear deterrence has become increasingly unreliable and dangerous as the number of nuclear states grows .

affirmative action , or “ positive discrimination , ” or “ positive discrimination , ” began university admissions .

the rationale behind affirmative action is that , after a long-term systemic injustice , it is not enough to ensure equal opportunity for all of race and gender discrimination .
these policies are often thought to be contrary to basic american values : admission , lending , and hiring decisions should be based on individual achievements , rather than ethnic categorizations .
but three decades later , these policies remain .
indeed , leading american companies , such as general motors , general electric , and walmart , have created affirmative action programs on people ’ s employment and suppliers choices .

of course , affirmative action programs have always been targeted by those who can not benefit from it .

but the supreme court ruled that the policy is in the constitutional spirit , citing the principle of “ enforceable national interests ” in ethnic diversity .
“ the members of all ethnic and ethnic groups effectively participated in our citizens ’ lives , ” said the decision , are essential to a country ’ s indivisible dreams .

affordable green energy
copenhagen – despite growing skepticism about global warming , the scientific community has reached an unprecedented consensus on the phenomenon : man-made climate change does exist , and we ignore the risks it poses .
but if the problem is ( and should be ) addressed , one equally important and important question is urgently needed : what approach is it ?
one solution is increasingly popular , and it seems plausible that the world must cut its greenhouse-gas emissions dramatically by a day .
specifically , the goal is to reduce global co2 emissions by 50 % by mid-century .
even proponents of that solution know that achieving this goal is not easy – and they are right .
indeed , they are right to make their own mistakes .
and i ’ ve heard it :
most renewable energy sources come from burning wood or other biomass in the third world , and are often unsustainable .
fossil fuels account for more than four-fifths of the world ’ s energy diet .
so , if we are to halve global carbon emissions by mid-century , it is clear that we must obtain more energy from those who do not emit carbon .
can we do this ?
according to the international energy agency , we must do the same by 2050 : we must do the same by 2050 :

this is not a good bargain .

fortunately , there is a better , smarter approach to tackling global warming .
instead of having hundreds of billions of dollars in energy plants – or , intentionally , the cost of raising carbon fuel – the world ’ s billions of people live in poverty , making green energy cheaper .
so far , solar panels are expensive – more than ten times the cost of energy exports – only in the west , where rich and desperate ( and often subsidized ) westerners can .

everyone in the world , including china and the people of india , will turn to a cheaper and cleaner alternative – and global emission-reduction targets are automatically realized .
so , can we achieve this technological miracle over the next 20 to 40 years ?
in short , yes .
the price of solar power will fall steadily in the next 30 years – roughly 50 % per decade – and we can accelerate the rate of decline further if there is plenty of money to study .
so , “ a lot of money ” ?
as long as a mere 0.2 % of global gdp ( roughly $ 100 billion ) is invested in research , the belief that breakthroughs will be groundbreaking is not limited to solar power , and that other alternative energy technologies will benefit .
my confidence in the potential of technological progress is that some climate activists believe it is naïve .

it is a successful precedent for clean energy .
don ’ t try to subsidize inefficient technologies or to try to increase the price of fossil fuels , in turn making it more difficult to fund basic research , which makes green energy cheaper .

a free lunch for america
berkeley – former us treasury secretary lawrence summers has an imaginative idea at this year ’ s imf meeting : the approach of national governments , as well as the patient ’ s failure to do so .
summers is in a position to focus on minor issues like greece ’ s focus on the greek problem , and the imbalances between the north and south of the south – the imbalance between the northern and southern governments , the reckless banks ’ creditors , and poor government governments – is more serious a day than one day .
but , on the other side of the atlantic , americans have no reason to feel smug .
summers ’ s analogy can also be described as a way to describe the us – the long-term funding dilemma for the americans , while ignoring the us macroeconomic and unemployment crisis .
the us government ’ s 30-year debt ( inflation-adjusted ) interest rate is about 1 % per year .
assuming that the us government will spend $ 500 billion in the next two years , and to spend the money on infrastructure – even if these investments are unproductive , their social returns are only 25 % annually .
assuming that , as it stands , it is simple keynesian government spending multiplier that is right .
thus , the $ 500 billion additional federal infrastructure spending in the next two years will produce an additional $ 1 trillion in output of goods and services , creating an additional seven million additional jobs , and lowers annual unemployment by two percentage points .
moreover , as the labor force affects the effect of the labor force , the unemployment rate will decline by just 0.1 percentage points in the indefinite future .
the stakes are not limited .
better infrastructure would mean $ 20 billion a year of income and social wealth .
lower unemployment in the future would mean a $ 20 billion increase in annual production .
and half of the extra $ 1 trillion of goods and services will show up for us households and services .
consider the benefits : higher employment today , $ 500 billion in additional goods and services in the next two years , and more than $ 40 billion in additional income flows and production .
so what is the potential cost of $ 500 billion in infrastructure spending over the next two years ?
first , $ 500 billion of extra government spending could be offset by a tax increase of 300 billion , from higher economic activity .
the net result is that the national debt will increase by $ 200 billion .
america ’ s taxpayers must therefore pay $ 2 billion a year to pay for this extra debt for the next 30 years , and then pay the $ 200 billion to roll over the debt .
but , by increasing economic activity by about $ 40 billion per year , an extra $ 40 billion would generate additional tax revenue .
with some of the interest payments to pay for the debt , and saving the remaining part of the savings , it would be more healthy in the form of a healthier economy , which would be able to eliminate the increase in the national debt .
in other words , taxpayers will be winners , because the benefits of a healthier economy will compensate for higher interest costs on the national debt , thereby enabling the government to provide more services without raising taxes .
businesses are also winners , because goods and workers will be able to use improved infrastructure .
the unemployed are winners , because many people will be employed .
even bond investors are winners , because they get their money back to work , and they have the interest in the contract .
what is bad ?
no .
one might ask me why ?
but two things are different today .
for starters , the us labor market has failed , so that the expansion of government spending does not create resource costs for a society as a whole .
second , bond investors are stupid in reality .
today , the s & p 500 could yield 7 % annual benefits , so it is supposed that a us government 30-year inflation-adjusted bonds – yields only 1 % annually .
the difference in the difference in real yield on the 60 percentage points is a testament to bond investors ’ unusually irrational panic .
they are willing to pay 6 % annual interest payments for “ security . ”
at the moment , however , governments can create “ security ” by printing bonds alone .
as a result , the government is also the winner , and it can get around 6 % of the value of every year in the next 30 years , and those who now see the winner are likely to see their portfolio performance as a result of their portfolio performance during the 2041 period .

a new start for europe
when europe ’ s leaders assembled in portugal , it is time for the new , 精减 reform pact to pretend that the european integration of the past 50 years had never occurred .
let us imagine what europe needs to meet the most pressing challenges , especially if it can escape the political constraints of the eu ’ s bargaining and ramshackle institutions .
until then , let ’ s hope that , while the eu ’ s “ 零年 ” would mean that we have no basis for a half-century of intra-european cooperation , the eu is still eager to implement long-term common policies .
so let ’ s suspend our doubts and imagine how europe can and should do what it takes to address the most enduring and difficult policy challenges that will determine whether the next half-century will be constructive .
or , in other words , let us take the potential of these problems and the eu to create long-term new policies , and then ask ourselves why the eu did not realize its potential , .
europe ’ s policymakers , for their part , can do better at the national and eu levels : europe can play a greater role in global challenges ; in the context of the european union and the world , it has created and strengthened the efficiency of the eu ’ s own political machinery .
europe needs a clearer and more recognizable global agenda .
it needs to boost leadership on climate change by implementing more stringent eu objectives , and then using its international economic and trade clout to lead the new global standards .
on the conflict and security issues , europe should enter a new phase , with a clear and strong stance on the issues ranging from nuclear proliferation to the sanctions regime .
doing so would aim to make europe a strong and fair player on the world stage , rather than a “ 大圣堂 ” of different views .
the goal is to establish europe ’ s global role , as “ soft power ” tools like eu development assistance and economic partnership are linked to growing political and security guarantees .
of course , this means that the eu should seek to expand its transatlantic mindset so that the eu and the united states are more closely aligned – and thus in the world ’ s interest – to define their common interests in the world .
this is not even a euphemism for the creation of a common foreign and security policy for the eu .
building more human capital in europe and around the world is a crucial factor in the eu ’ s future activities .
education is the highest level of investment that the eu can undertake so far , so it should initiate the most ambitious program in history , creating new recruits and job opportunities within the world , while helping the world ’ s poorest countries expand their education .
europe must also address the endemic problem of migration policy – a problem that has eluded generations of leaders .
we need a european immigration code that seeks to reconcile europe ’ s external labor with widespread demand for the labor force through widespread fear of cultural stress and social unrest .
a europe that is building a fairer and more multi-cultural europe is not easy , but it will have a much heavier price on this issue .
for the same reason , european governments should be doing more to strengthen their shared sense of history and common values .
a stronger european identity is the strongest foundation for creating a culture of culture that is inevitable .
meanwhile , doubts remain over the political and institutional machinery that the eu needs to achieve its ambitious ambitions .
the agreement that the european union ’ s leaders agreed on in a comprehensive review of the organization ’ s decision-making mechanism is a relief , but whether the new agreement will be ratified remains uncertain .
but we believe that the new pact ’ s provisions , which are increasingly being used by the member states , are increasingly using the effective majority of the treaty ’ s approval .
thus , even if the eu ’ s few member governments can not ratify the treaty , it would not be as intimidated as its predecessor , the constitution , in 2005 .

africa at risk
addis ababa – climate change has hit africa the first , and hardest hit , continent .
beyond antarctica , africa is the only continent that has yet to industrialize .
indeed , in the 1980 ’ s , the continent ’ s industrialization process has been reversed overall .
africa has thus failed to play any role in the accumulation of greenhouse gases for industrialization .
moreover , africa ’ s current carbon emissions are minimal , with all of africa ’ s carbon emissions coming from deforestation and the degradation of forests and farmland .
but climate change is the biggest blow to africa , because it affects the continent ’ s fragile agricultural sector , which has consumed 70 % of africa ’ s population .
all estimates of global warming may have shown that most of africa ’ s regions will become drier , and the continent as a whole will experience greater climate change .
we already know the impact of periodic drought on tens of millions of africans .
we can therefore imagine the impact of climate change on agriculture .
africa is hit only hardest , and it is first .
indeed , the impact of climate change is already being felt .
much of east africa is experiencing a drought – a direct relationship with climate change – and is more severe than ever .
the upcoming climate negotiations should be targeted against specific parts of the world ’ s poor poor regions .
the first step , the first step , is to keep global warming within the seemingly inevitable range of two degrees celsius , which would make poverty and vulnerability impossible to afford .
second , adequate resources should be provided to poor and vulnerable countries and regions , so that they can adapt to climate change .
climate change , which has been driven by developed-country activities generally , has increased poverty and vulnerability to poverty and vulnerability , exacerbating the development environment .
the resulting losses , however much they spend , are not enough .
but scaling up adequate funds to mitigate the damage may be part of the solution .
as a result , the advanced countries have an obligation to pay for a portion of the compensation needed to pay for poorer countries and regions .
there are various estimates of the investment required to invest in these countries .
one conservative estimate has raised the $ 50 billion annual investment rate by 2015 , to $ 100 billion by 2020 – a proposal that is likely to be adopted precisely because it is conservative .
a transitional financing program will be implemented from 2010 to 2015 .
some argue that , in the current economic mess , the advanced countries have no such amount .
but no one has so far suggested that the loss of growth in poor countries and regions is less than offset by compensation for adjustment costs .
the reason is clear : the losses are several times higher than the amount of compensation required .
even so , the advanced countries can not afford to pay these amounts , regardless of the actual amount of losses .
but we all know that these countries and their central banks have the ability to spend trillions of dollars in a few months to bail out banks that they earned when they were operating smoothly .
when the good times ended , taxpayers and governments were prepared to rescue them , ensuring that they continue to receive additional dividends .
how can it be impossible to do so if the advanced countries were able to show trillions of dollars to clean up banks ’ mess , and how can it be unable to make a dent in the threat that the world can create to its own people ?
the key to the problem is not the relevant resources , but the inappropriate priorities of resource allocation .
the key to the problem is that in some values , the banks should be bailed out , even if banks want to be responsible for the chaos that they have created , and that they are threatened by the chaos that the world ’ s poorest people have already caused .
i can not believe that people in developed countries will support the aid banks and oppose a partial contribution to poorer countries when they know the facts .
i can not believe that they will allow this injustice .
if they do not express outrage about this injustice , they can only be given the truth about facts .
africa ’ s three humanitarian challenges in 2018
nairobi – in the decade since the outbreak of somalia , the outbreak of somalia was virtually paralyzed , and health experts were the worst prepared to prepare .
so far , drought , malnutrition , and poverty remain stubbornly 难除 , and a fatal scenario in which deadly diarrhea is paralyzed seems inevitable .

but it also reminds us that local capacity is vulnerable to crisis .
while some african countries have become self-sufficient in public health , others remain heavily dependent on international aid .
for these areas , cooperation is the best way to minimize risks .
in particular , three major challenges this year are likely to be most difficult to test for africa ’ s ability to manage humanitarian crises .
the first challenge is violence in the drc .
last year , the drc ’ s central kasai region was displaced with 1.4 million people , leaving the total population of the country at 4.1 million – the largest domestic refugee group in africa .
violence has exacerbated food security , with more than three million people severely undernourished .
unfortunately , the kasai crisis will continue to worsen in 2018 .
a recent assessment by the drc ’ s red cross warns that the number of displaced people will continue to grow , and the threat of a rapidly spreading cholera epidemic in the region is urgently needed .
the second challenge this year is somalia ’ s food security problem , which , according to the famine early warning systems network , somalia ’ s food security problem will intensify this year .
in 2017 , lower rainfall levels impede harvests , and most regions have not fully recovered .
as humanitarian aid continues to flow to somalia , long-term solutions must be developed , such as improved agricultural output , education , and economic opportunities .
historically , most aid to somalia has been used to provide emergency relief ; even collective cholera responses are narrowly focused on short-term health .
but somalia desperately needs a more holistic long-term development strategy .
finally , last year ’ s disaster was overcome in somalia , and this year will be sorely needed elsewhere in the region .
yemen ’ s cholera epidemic has reached the largest , with more than one million cases of diagnosis , and , despite years of international support , africa remains beset by cholera .
over the last four decades , african countries have reported three million new cases , and in africa ’ s 中东部 and southern regions , new cases emerged this year .
fortunately , somalia ’ s containment of cholera in 2017 hopes to be replicated , as long as social and personal awareness of cholera and its related risks is clear , and the resources that local actors can receive .
the global task force , the global task force for cholera control , is responsible for improving local and international support for improved health care and sanitation , which has already issued a global roadmap for ending the global road map by 2030 .
though this is an ambitious goal , it is achievable as long as international organizations and local governments work together .
natural and manmade crises will continue to rage in africa , but my and other organizations are working hard to build a brighter future through improved capacity .
but , to succeed , local and international development partners must change their thinking : humanitarian aid alone is inadequate to address africa ’ s huge challenges .
money is clearly needed , but it must be spent more strategically , to improve the structural weaknesses that have sustained instability .
for example , if more money is available to health care at the community level , local organizations would be better positioned to lead when outbreaks occur .
in short , the international development community must invest more in grassroots solutions , empowering africans , rather than treating them as subcontractors to their own difficulties .
local organizations are better equipped to cope with complex cultural and linguistic environments ; but , if they fail , the costs are larger .
last year was a disastrous year for many africans , with millions suffering drought , hunger , and violence .
but in somalia , a coordinated response to severe health threats makes sense of a new hope for a safer future .
for many african countries , there is a long and confident first step toward building resilience than the next one .

these two themes may look different , but they are in fact interconnected .

capitalizing on africa ’ s demographic dividend
洛美 – africa has the world ’ s youngest and fastest-growing population .
over the next three decades , as many as 20 million young people join labor , and africa faces opportunities to transform local and global growth balances : employment .
but that is not the final regime .
african countries will need to be educated and trained to take advantage of this demographic dividend , and have ample employment opportunities .
meeting these conditions will not be easy .
our time is uncertain .
the threat of trade tensions between the us and china threatens the integrity of the global value chain , which is likely to lead to greater disruption .
the international monetary fund ’ s forecast of its october forecast warned that as historic economic engines stall , global growth will likely fall to 3.7 % this year and next , with previous projections slowing by 0.2 percentage points .
but as this slowdown is reflected in the world stock market , the new growth engine will emerge .
africa is well positioned to become one of the new engines .
according to the world bank , six of the world ’ s ten fastest-growing economies are in africa .
intra-african trade may become a gateway to future local and global growth , and its vibrant population will create many opportunities for transnational opportunity .
most important , africa ’ s labor force is coming to a boil .
today , 60 % of africans are younger than 25 , compared to less than 15 .
by 2050 , africa ’ s youth population is expected to reach 840 million .
but this huge pool of future talent is a double-edged sword .
despite strong gdp growth over the past decade , most young africans are unable to grasp economic opportunities .
moreover , the african union reports that africa ’ s development dynamics 2018 will emphasize that africa ’ s young people will suffer the most if unemployment trends continue .
unable to employ africa ’ s young people sufficiently to be marginalized for a generation , they will push them to the path that they may not be prepared to undermine .
if not , if high-quality employment remains scarce , the economic expansion that africa can achieve will not happen .
in other words , african governments face the deadline to match job growth with skills training .
unfortunately , few countries can effectively meet this challenge .
according to the african development bank , youth unemployment in africa stands at twice that of adults .
indeed , young people have been left out before they start looking for work .
for example , too many primary schools are severely underfunded , while gender discrimination has left millions of girls in school .
to overcome these shortcomings , it will require significant political and financial capital .
some leaders are moving in this direction .
at the paris peace forum ( ppf ) , held earlier this month , african and global leaders gathered to discuss a powerful concept : international cooperation is crucial to resolving global challenges and ensuring lasting peace .
on the sidelines of the ppf , the focus is on african youth .
as one of the 119 projects chosen to participate in the ppf , the au youth cooperation center has attended discussion of the union ’ s youth agenda .
the program aims to make african and european youth participate in the current and future decisions , aimed at creating strategies that enable african and european cooperation to address challenges like demographic dividend .
one way to capitalize on africa ’ s demographic dividend is to expand training programs to align employers ’ needs with african talent .
as a former member of the ibrahim leadership program , i can attest to the transformative power of good education , as well as the value of 孵化器 incubators .
africa ’ s success depends on its ability to equip young people with technological and innovative skills , as a catalyst for economic growth , thereby capturing the demographic dividend .
this includes training and 训练项目 programs , along with the value chains of raw materials from africa to industries and markets across the continent .
by 2030 , one in five people worldwide will live in africa .
on that scale alone , the size of africa ’ s workforce will likely be the engine of global growth for decades .
to do that , however , africans must undertake unnecessary reforms now .
as our demographic dividend matures , governments , institutions , and organizations must help young people prepare for success .
if african countries can overcome this challenge , long-term economic growth – both domestic and foreign .
africa ’ s path out of poverty
beijing – all low-income countries have the potential to achieve dynamic economic growth .
we know this , because the past has been repeated : poor rural economies have morphed into middle-income and even high-income cities for two generations .
the key is to seize the window of opportunity for industrialization created by the light of light manufacturing in high-income countries .
that was true in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries , and today it remains .
japan seized this opportunity after world war ii , with labor-intensive industries ( such as preventing and simple electronics ) driving the economy , until labor costs contained comparative advantage in these sectors .
this shift , then , led to a similar role for low-income asian economies – south korea , taiwan , hong kong , singapore , and some – malaysia and thailand .
of course , china is the latest traveler on this old path .
