and now china has lost its comparative advantage in labor-intensive industries , and other developing countries – especially in africa – are on the verge of replacing china .
indeed , since the industrial revolution , the rise of light manufacturing has driven significant increases in national income .
the british economic transformation began with textiles .
both belgium , france , sweden , denmark , italy , and switzerland are light manufacturing sectors .
likewise , in the united states , cities like boston , baltimore , and philadelphia are the production centers for textiles , apparel , and shoes .
until recently , few believed that africa could also be the center of modern manufacturing .
but , with the right policies , there is no reason to believe that african countries can not follow the same trajectory .
consider land-locked ethiopia , which , ten years ago , seemed to be hopeless .
but it has subsequently built a industrial park near addis ababa to invite china ’ s 制鞋 to make a plant .
the company opened its doors in 2012 , with two production lines and 600 workers .
by the end of that year , the company hired 2,000 ethiopians and doubled ethiopia ’ s exports .
today , the company has 3,500 workers in ethiopia , producing more than two million shoes annually .
in 2013 , inspired by the international success of 受华建 , the ethiopian government built a new industrial park that includes 22 factory units .
in three months , all units were leased by export-oriented companies from turkey , south korea , taiwan , china , and elsewhere .
the world bank provides $ 2.5 million to support continued construction of industrial parks .
ethiopia ’ s success story is only a start .
as investors learn about africa , they will increasingly see africa ’ s plans .
indeed , africa ’ s labor costs are large , and ethiopia can even attract companies such as bangladesh .
africa ’ s agricultural labor force is too small to rest .
as long as foreign firms operate in labor-intensive industries with comparative advantages in africa , they can train local labor .
some workers will be managers .
they will be familiar with technology and learning how to maintain the quality of their production .
they will contract with international buyers and investors .
at the end of the day , some of them will be able to raise capital for their own start-ups – the african people ’ s own export companies .
mauritius is a case in point .
in the 1970s , the government built industrial parks to produce textiles and garments for export .
back then , owners of some factories came from taiwan and hong kong ; today , more than 70 % of the country ’ s industrial companies are in their country .
a carefully focused export strategy is essential .
international development institutions and many african governments want to move in the region to regional integration , linking markets to market linkages in 55 african countries .
today , africa accounts for just 1.9 % of global gdp , compared to 21 % in the us and 23 % for europe .
developing countries must devote limited resources to the most efficient places , and there is no doubt that africa ’ s most attractive opportunities are yet to be found .
for example , 埃塞 russia should not invest heavily in the infrastructure needed for regional integration , investing in building industrial parks and road links with ports in djibouti .
with the right growth strategy , we can see far-reaching changes – and even change – in lifetime .
my native taiwan is now a high-income economy .
but when i was born in 1952 , the island was poorer than almost every country in africa .
then again , i experienced this shift .
i went to mainland china in 1979 , when china ’ s per capita income was less than one-third of sub-saharan africa ’ s .
china is now a high-income country , and it is likely to be high-income status by 2020 .
i hope to see a third economic transformation in my lifetime – in ethiopia and other african countries .
if they are able to insist that other countries have tried and tested , my hope is very likely .
the promise of digital health
basel – africa has changed dramatically since the young in angola 20 years ago , and the better .
but the most obvious is the mobile technology of africa .
africans – indeed , all those in low- and middle-income countries – are seizing the opportunities provided by technology to use mobile phones to distribute mobile phones and access to health care .
the advantage of mobile technology lies in access .
barriers to geographical distance and resource scarcity have long hampered billions of people from the care they need , and these barriers can easily be overcome in the digital age .
in fact , technology can be used countless ways to improve access to health care and delivery .
of course , this is not new news , and a growing number of technology-based health-care innovations have been made in recent years .
but only a few innovations have created scale and sustained long-term sustainability ; most projects have not yet endured the experiments .
as a result , digital solutions are highly fragmented – in some cases , adding extra constraints to existing health-care systems .
the first step in addressing this problem is to do nothing – and which obstacles impede success .
here , the most important observation relates to how the solutions relate to reality .
after all , technology is the result of innovation in health care , which is not an end in itself .
solutions that focus on end-users – whether doctors or patients – are most likely to succeed .
the key to this approach is to recognize that what users need is not necessarily the most advanced technology , but rather the ability to use and implement solutions .
indeed , seemingly outdated technologies such as voice and text messages can become tools for the expected users , far more useful than the most up-to-date innovations in APP or , say , nanotechnology .
consider ghana ’ s community-based health improvement program , which i led , and 360 360 , which i led .
the program supports patients through regular mobile health care to remind them of their functions , and to manage recommendations in the necessary way of life .
the penetration rate of mobile-phone penetration is 80 % , but only a few people have smartphones , but such a simple solution is still the most effective .
for health-care workers , digital solutions must make them more efficient , rather than adding to their already costly workload .
people working with the rich world to achieve health-care services in low-resource settings can help to ensure that the solutions are implemented .
for example , the telemedicine networks that novartis and its partners have joined with ghana ’ s ministry of health are directly responsive to the demands of health-care workers to expand coverage of health-care professionals .
the network gives the frontline health workers a phone call to a center for referral hospitals , which work hours for hours , with doctors and specialists at the time .
from the outset , the project was designed to respond to the need to expand coverage of health-care experts , and that the ministry of health workers operate responsibly , enabling the model to achieve scale and sustainable sustainability .
to realize the potential of digital health , solutions must be integrated with national health systems .
only then can digital technologies accelerate progress toward universal health coverage and address national priorities .
cooperation on health care and ict – including private and public cooperation – is essential .
multidisciplinary partnerships , driven by sustained leadership by senior government officials , must be guided by the planning stage .
governments working to finance a digital solution to digital health solutions and effective governance mechanisms are key to success .
digital technology provides a huge opportunity to improve health care .
to seize these opportunities , we must learn from past experience .
by focusing on the reality of end-users and the most important medical needs , rather than lost the latest technologies , we can achieve the promise of digital health care .
confronting africa ’ s water challenge
abidjan – the world is essential , but many of the world faces water scarcity .
because of the impact of climate change , africa is experiencing the worst drought in 1945 , especially in south sudan , somalia , ethiopia , and northern nigeria .
these fragile regions now need international support .
we need to build resilient systems that ensure access to potable water for all , and to improve water supplies and sanitation in africa ’ s rapidly growing cities .
we should start by raising africans ’ ability to harness wastewater .
through investment and appropriate management , wastewater can continue to provide wealth for many africans , and to boost human health , agricultural productivity , and sustainable environmental protection .
over the past six years , the african development bank has invested $ 33 billion to expand access to potable water and sanitation , with roughly $ 2.2 billion in urban services for at least seven million people .
the african development bank supports a comprehensive urban model of water management , which seeks to keep the un sustainable development goals under article 8 of the un sustainable development goals , ensuring sustainable income from urban liquid and solid waste .
a comprehensive city of water management requires considerable initial investment , and the cost of money and operational operations is significant .
only a few african cities collect and treat more than 20 % of wastewater through centralized wastewater-management systems .
the remaining 80 % have a potentially large amount of potentially valuable liquid and solid waste .
with appropriate investment , foresight , and commitment , these sources of resources can create jobs and generate sustainable growth .
the 管理 is thus central to the african development bank ’ s focus on the quality of life , which aims to increase africans ’ quality of life , promote public health , achieve gender equality , create jobs , and make society more vulnerable to climate change .
meanwhile , water will play a critical role in achieving the high 5s ’ industrialization and sustainable agricultural goals .
and one of the $ 40 million invested in health programs in the african development bank helped to reduce the proportion of the city ’ s 雅温得 population from 16 % to 12 % .
in abidjan ’ s capital , abidjan , côte d ’ ivoire , the value of the $ 30 million in the value of the afdb ’ s investments has dramatically reduced the number of floods in the 古鲁 basin , significantly improving the lives of 28 million inhabitants .
in zimbabwe , in the wake of the outbreak of the cholera outbreak in 2008-2009 , the african development bank and other donors financed the $ 4 million emergency water supply and sanitation programs that have been allocated to the city ’ s more than 25 million emergency water and sanitation programs .
all the african development bank supports the sustainable development principle , in order to ensure that it improves economic gains and the affordable costs that local communities can afford .
these projects also help countries to harness wastewater and waste by converting sewage to fertilizer and fertilizer .
moreover , the african development bank ’ s african water facility ( AWF ) program complements its program by attracting downstream funding to water infrastructure .
in february , flooding and 飓风 尼奥 of tropical storms devastated the coast of mozambique , severely affecting the local population ’ s production .
but just a few weeks later , the water facility in africa has launched a feasibility survey that aims to improve the capacity and livelihoods of 莫桑比克 , mozambique , which suffered a storm attack .
the gpe , together with the global water partnership organization , is implementing a comprehensive urban water management program in five african cities , including the democratic republic of congo and in zimbabwe .
by 2030 , in the democratic republic of congo alone , comprehensive urban water management can help to improve water delivery and sanitation .
the bill & melinda gates fund also uses the african development bank ’ s expertise to support the afdb ’ s urban health-care program by providing $ 88 million .
this effort would help to foster commercial innovation that offers affordable , sustainable , and sustainable services to africa , which could benefit two million residents directly , and another six million people through subsidiary projects .
africa ’ s wastewater-management challenges are huge and complex .
but the afdb is determined to provide opportunities for africans to deliver dividends , regardless of public health , improved health , economic development , or environmental protection .
improving the quality of life in all africans requires political resolve , public-private partnerships , and active public engagement .
under the high 5s framework , the afdb is working to integrate all three ingredients .
africa and all stakeholders in africa must redouble their efforts to ensure clean , affordable water for all , and provide assistance to african countries suffering from historic droughts .
doing so is a moral obligation .
after all , water and life are connected .
is africa still rising ?
washington , dc – from 2000 to 2014 , africa achieved strong growth , creating a belief in the “ africa rising . ”
but , since 2015 , growth in sub-saharan africa has slowed , while the gloomy outlook for commodity prices has raised questions about africa ’ s economic future , with many questioning the emergence of “ africa ’ s rising ” narrative – a point that some have claimed to be dead .
to some extent , such skepticism is understandable .
the 2014 oil-price shock hit some african economies very serious , and the overall growth rate has fallen from 5-6 % between 2004 and 2014 to 2.5 % from 2004 to 2017 – a growth rate that is still less than population growth .
moreover , africa ’ s three largest economies – angola , nigeria , and south africa – have experienced a dramatic decline .
last year , angola and south africa have stagnated , while nigeria has experienced the first real contraction since 1991 .
recent projections suggest that these economies ’ recoveries will be slow for years to come .
but africa ’ s skeptics overlook many important factors .
first , if you exclude three largest economies , sub-saharan africa ’ s overall growth rate will rise from 2.5 % to close to 4 % this year .
in fact , five of the ten fastest-growing economies in the world are in africa .
over the next five years , about half of sub-saharan economies will be at as much as the average growth rate of “ africa ’ s rise . ”
moreover , high commodity prices are only one factor in the region ’ s strong economic performance between 2000 and 2014 .
many african countries have made great strides in macroeconomic management , governance , and business conditions , and entrepreneurship is booming .
even if commodity prices fall , these developments can still support many african economies .
today ’ s skepticism may reflect memories of the dark ages , as well as concerns about africa ’ s progress .
from the 1970s to the mid-1990 ’ s , many african countries were ruled by dictators , and the institutions needed to sustain strong economic growth were fragile .
the civil war has repeatedly bedeviled social structures in many countries , and decades of economic growth in africa have been slow .
by 2000 , africa had become the economist ’ s “ hopeless africa . ”
but these days are gone .
african policymakers have maintained the reforms of the 1990 ’ s , laying the groundwork for continued growth .
while much work remains to be done , the economic and business environment in many african countries has continued to improve , and institutions and governance have become stronger .
thanks to new information and communications technologies , africans , especially young africans , are learning more about information and more actively in civil and political affairs .
information and communication technology has also unleashed a wave of innovation and entrepreneurship in africa .
these positive trends are difficult to reverse , and will continue to improve africa ’ s economic conditions , even if commodity prices can not rebound .
after all , from 2000 to 2004 , the rapid rise in commodity prices did not begin , with average growth in africa at 5.6 % .
but this is not to say that africa will not face daunting challenges for years to come .
around the world , economic conditions are even worse for africa ’ s economies .
in major advanced economies , interest rates will soon rise , and political opposition to globalization may force governments to abandon their commitments to development aid .
faced with all of this uncertainty , african policymakers should look inward , focusing on mobilizing financing policies for national resources and economic agendas .
these agendas should include a set of critical priorities .
african countries need to diversify their economies to withstand future shocks better , while the entire continent needs to accelerate the pace of industrialization .
governments must find a way to create decent jobs for the 11 million africans who join the labor force each year .
they also need to take steps to reduce poverty , ensuring that prosperity is shared by all .
these objectives are particularly important for angola , nigeria , and south africa .
angola and nigeria need to reduce their dependence on oil ; south africa still needs major reforms to address structural problems that have plagued it since the apartheid era .
these projects will require a capable leader to uphold the principles of good governance .
failure could lead to long-term growth .
but even if africa ’ s three largest economies eventually fall into depression , the story of “ africa ’ s rising ” story may not be entirely rejected .
from the 1960s to the 1990 ’ s , the “ asian tigers ” narrative was confined to hong kong , singapore , south korea , and taiwan , and none of the other developing economies in china , including china , were in the same place .
likewise , the gap between africa ’ s economies is widening , and thus should be assessed on the merits of their respective economic policies .
africa still rising
johannesburg – is the honeymoon over african economies over ?
less than a decade ago , with a staggering gdp growth and development in many countries , the continent ’ s economic dreams seemed to be becoming a reality .
now , as the continent becomes increasingly vulnerable to the challenges of challenging external conditions , it is difficult to sustain the growth rate .
in china ’ s economic slowdown , the sharp drop in commodity prices , and the drag on security crises , africa ’ s annual gdp growth rate was just 3.3 % in 2015 , just as fast as that of the population – a sharp slowdown compared to the record in 2000 .
but deeper observations suggest that the situation may not be as severe as it seems , with two main reasons .
first , while average growth has declined , some african countries have thrived in recent years .
in fact , the oil exporters ’ economic woes and security crises in the sahel and north africa have been in place since 2010 ; but , in other parts of africa , gdp growth accelerated , from 4.1 % in 2000 to 4.4 % between 2010 and 2015 .
second , africa is experiencing a deep long-term transformation characterized by rapid digitization , urbanization , and the working-age population , which will surpass china and india in 2034 .
such a demographic trend could unlock future economic growth by advancing economic diversification , spurring domestic consumption , and supporting industrialization .
indeed , today ’ s high-growth countries – including côte d ’ ivoire , ethiopia , kenya , and tanzania – have made substantial progress in reducing dependence on commodity exports , developing trade , investment , and domestic consumption .
and many slow growth countries can take a similar path .
according to the mckinsey global institute ( mgi ) , total spending by african consumers and firms has reached $ 4 trillion .
by 2025 , private spending could reach $ 5.6 trillion – $ 2.1 trillion from the household sector , and $ 3.5 trillion from businesses .
this creates enormous opportunities for manufacturers in africa .
we believe that africa can almost double manufacturing output by 2025 , and 75 % of the growth is closely tied to local markets .
the question is whether manufacturing firms can exploit the growth potential of the past .
african firms have not yet proved capable of meeting existing domestic demand .
africa ’ s food , beverages , and similar processed products still depend on imports , while the association of southeast asian nations imports only about 20 % , and south america ’ s mercosur group imports only about 10 % .
even a 15 % of africa ’ s cement is dependent on imports , though africa has abundant raw materials .
to be sure , african firms have made considerable progress in recent years .
today , 400 african companies have achieved more than $ 1 billion in annual income , and there are more than 500 million annual annual income .
in general , these large firms are growing rapidly – and increasingly lucrative – than their counterparts in the rest of the world .
but there is a long way to go .
the average annual income of $ 2 billion in large african firms ( except in south africa ) has averaged half of brazil , india , mexico , and russia .
and more than 40 % of the continent ’ s large companies can be equal to other emerging economies .
one key factor limiting corporate growth is the fragmentation of african markets , with the existing african market comprising small economies with limited economic and political ties .
only egypt , morocco , nigeria , and south africa are ranked top 100 in the global connectedness index of the mckinsey global institute .
in addition to trade barriers , africa suffers from inadequate links to free movement of people and transport .
africans need visas for more than half of their continent ’ s countries .
the recent launch of the african union passport is a step in the right direction – but only a step forward .
stronger market integration will not only create the economies needed to compete for african businesses ; it can also attract institutional investors .
building such markets therefore must be a top priority for african leaders , so that it can unleash the continent ’ s economic potential .
it is equally important that african leaders work hard to improve the business environment .
although some progress has been made over the last two decades , non-tariff barriers remain high .
indeed , regulatory issues remain severely constrained .
many african businesses – almost half of nigeria ’ s businesses , angola and egypt – emphasize that electricity supplies are unreliable to them .
almost 40 % of the world bank ’ s survey of investigative firms has limited competition for informal firms .
some of these problems are being addressed faster .
since 2007 , for example , rwanda has made significant progress in establishing the business environment in rwanda .
in less than a decade , the commission has led the creation of the “ 一站式 center ” for promoting investment , the rapid application of regulatory structures , and a fixed fee for a fixed fee for property registration , customs extension , and 海关检查 海关检查 .
as a result , rwanda ’ s global ranking in the global business environment jumped from 143 in 2008 to 32 in 2014 .
the rest of africa can certainly replicate such success .
despite the challenges facing african countries , the continent has enormous economic potential , thanks to the optimistic demographic trends , rapidly growing cities , thriving domestic markets , and digital revolutions .
africa will still have a rising opportunity as long as he , carrying out it , and decides to do so .
africa ’ s moment of development
new york – the african development bank has just released its economic outlook for africa in 2018 .
a revised version of the version of this year – more than a year ago , a more appropriate structure of analysis , and no exaggeration – reflects the continent ’ s own transformation , because it may finally see the hope of the continent ’ s long-awaited economic development .
africa ’ s rise has been constant .
in the 1960 ’ s , there was strong hope .
an independent generation of leaders – including ghana ’ s kwame nkrumah and kenya ’ s 乔莫 kenyatta – received the advice of the world ’ s top economists .
the 加勒比 nobel laureate arthur lewis became nkrumah ’ s chief economic adviser .
in india , we read these leaders ’ friendship with our own post-independence prime minister , jawaharlal nehru , and see all emerging economies new .
and many emerging economies do take off .
in the late 1960s , some east asian countries were growing rapidly .
beginning in the early 1980 ’ s , china embarked on a decade-long rise .
but africa remains stagnant , mired in poverty .
ironically , the continent ’ s resource wealth has impeded economic progress , owing to the conflict between the government and the militants eager to control them .
the resulting political instability attracts outsiders keen to exploit government weaknesses .
the indian poet and nobel laureate 拉宾 tagore coined the “ african 颂歌 ” in 1936 , when he expressed his views on civilization , noting that the continent became the prey of a “ civilized world , ” as the arrival of 殖民者 殖民者 becomes more dynamic .
eventually , in the turn of the twenty-first century , things began to change in africa .
some dynamic leaders , active democratic events , and emerging regional cooperation led to poverty reduction and growth rates .
commodity exporters experienced some setback in 2014 , when prices plummeted .
but this has gradually evolved into a 变相 , because it forced countries to increase production and diversify their economies – factors that underpin new growth .
the african development bank reports that africa ’ s 54 economies grew by 2.2 % in 2016 , and 3.6 % in 2017 .
the african development bank predicts that average growth will increase to 4.1 % in 2018 , while the world bank expects ghana to grow by 8.3 % , ethiopia ’ s 8.2 % , and senegal by 6.9 % , and the world ’ s fastest-growing economies .
these figures are not wishful thinking : ethiopia ’ s gdp grew by 7.6 % in 2016 .
of course , africa faces serious challenges .
south africa , the continent ’ s strongest economy , is now facing a difficult task of addressing entrenched corruption .
but , because the anc is now clearly determined to replace president jacob zuma ’ s scandal with the government of president jacob ramaphosa ’ s administration , there is reason for hope .
more broadly , many african countries need to find ways to create more jobs quickly .
the share of the working-age population in africa is rising faster than any other region .
this “ demographic dividend ” could have enormous potential .
but if job creation stalls , the unemployed or under-employed will most likely feel frustrated – and thus conflict .
consider tanzania .
thanks to president john 马古夫里 ’ s efforts to mobilize more domestic revenue to support additional development spending , the economy is now doing well .
but , with some 800,000 children joining the workforce each year , tanzania needs more working , better infrastructure , and education reforms aimed at ensuring that workers have decent jobs , resources , and opportunities to ensure decent employment .
the same is true in ethiopia .
in the last few decades , the country ’ s export-led growth has made considerable progress , supported by industrial growth and massive investment from china ’ s massive investment .
now , ethiopia is set to become an economic powerhouse in east africa .
but the urban youth unemployment rate has remained at 23.3 % : if unchecked , this is likely to lead to ethnic conflict and political instability .
another related challenge concerns resource mobilization : countries need to invest in infrastructure , human resources , and trade and digital linkages that are needed to invest in africa and beyond .
the african development bank report estimates that infrastructure investment alone will require about $ 170 billion annually in the continent , which is roughly $ 100 billion per year .
currently , africa receives a total of about $ 60 billion in foreign direct investment in foreign direct investment .
african governments must attract more funding to bridge this gap .
the challenge , at least , is daunting .
but african countries can learn from one another .
for example , ghana ’ s smooth transfer of power after the december 2016 election set a positive example of democratic institutions .
nigeria ’ s lagos state and tanzania are doing very well to mobilize internal resources for development .
add to that the rise of the indigenous intelligentsia , such as the african development bank , which seems to be in the offing .
africa ’ s schooling 失教
accra – as september begins , the news has received good news from nearly a half-million students attending high school : · 总统 fulfilled his promise to deliver free secondary education to children in the country .
he swore not only to withdraw fees , but also provide free textbooks and meals – both of which have historically been a barrier to the poorest students .
ghana began free compulsory education in primary and secondary school in 1995 , but it was poorly implemented – and students ’ educational dreams ended up before high school .
even in 2014 , only 37 % of the country ’ s students were enrolled in secondary school .
the president ’ s move is an inspiring example that should follow .
unfortunately , despite these incremental reforms , students in africa still face serious obstacles to achieving genuine universal education .
even in ghana , poor and rural children are still struggling to benefit from new secondary education policies .
things may be worse in the rest of the continent .
the problem is not just that there is a lack of access to schools , but also a lack of good schools .
a startling report by the unesco institute for statistics shows that six of the world ’ s ten children and adolescents – six million people – have not learned basic skills in math and reading .
in sub-saharan africa , 88 % of children and adolescents enter adulthood without basic literacy .
this constitutes a moral and development crisis that would require immediate action .
the department of education , the department of education in ghana , which serves as the director of education university , has learned from my experience that one of the main issues is education ’ s lack of education and absenteeism .
the world bank has also made a “ return to schooling ” in a new report , which also confirms my view .
addressing this will require investing more in the world , promoting teaching as the professional honor of the country ’ s builders , while encouraging the best students to take the lead .
we can not expect a small , poorly educated teacher to learn from a weak education .
we must also invest more resources – including from scholarships for poor students to new libraries and classrooms – to improve schools and learning .
because many african governments are unable to provide citizens with equal access to quality education , this is not a challenge that they can afford to assume .
as the continent ’ s population grows – half the world ’ s population growth between 2017 and 2050 – africa ’ s heads of state must work closely with major allies and multilateral organizations to finance and share core educational skills .
fortunately , as unesco reports , several partners have already stepped up .
french president emmanuel macron is perhaps the most prominent among the heads of state promising to invest africa ’ s education investment as a priority .
as the un ’ s main education and cultural organization , unesco itself will play a critical role in pushing for free , high-quality schooling in the continent .
the new director-general who took office next month will also have an opportunity to develop the right agenda to address this challenge .
notably , france ’ s candidate , former minister of culture of culture , will put unesco ’ s internal crisis and education at the top of the agenda .
she presented the fiscal dilemma as the biggest threat to unesco , and has emphasized more dialogue with member states , such as the united states , than the united states .
in his previous administration ’ s role , azoulay helped launch a program of global cultural diversity and a plan to protect cultural heritage in conflict zones .
she also called for unesco to treat education as a catalyst for development and gender equality , and is the best way to help combat “ ideological radicalization . ”
she promised that , if elected , the sdgs will be sustainable – quality education for the 普适性 – as a core mission for unesco , and especially in africa .
in part , the preamble to the preamble of the unesco charter points out : “ because war begins with people ’ s hearts , it is time for the preservation of peace . ”
unfortunately , in africa , we all know what will happen when efforts to build peace eventually fail .
islamist militants continue to impose threats on mali , and in 2013 they burned down a library of thousands of valuable historical manuscripts in the cultural center of timbuktu .
this is not only a serious blow to the world ’ s cultural heritage ; it also reminded people that africa was a center of cultural exchange , literature , and education , and it needs to act .
africa faces high risks .
our children are not only threatened by a lack of access to schools , but also a lack of opportunities to learn from their own histories .
we really want more national governments to follow ghana ’ s example , more like france ’ s allies like france , and the new director-general will be more important in africa than ever before , all of which will be more important than ever .
africa ’ s year of opportunity
geneva – we have just entered the beginning of 2018 , and we already feel that tensions and disorder will be the defining feature of this year .
from anti-immigration policies in the united states to the region ’ s remarkable geopolitical hotspots , disruption , instability , and uncertainty seems to be in place today .
but at least one metric has reasons for cautious optimism : economic development .
the imf estimates that this year ’ s global economic growth will reach 3.7 % this year , up from 3.6 % in 2017 .
as christine lagarde , the imf managing director , put it in a speech in december , “ sunshine is penetrating clouds and helping most economies achieve the strongest development since the financial crisis . ”
lagarde made such an outcome in addis ababa , because the rays of prosperity are most impressive in africa .
indeed , as eight key areas grow , i predict that 2018 will be a year in many – though not all – african economies .
first , africa is about to achieve a slow economic recovery even if it is 断断续续 .
after three years of weak economic performance , overall growth is expected to accelerate from 2.9 % in 2017 to 3.5 % today .
this year ’ s expected growth rate stems mainly from global environmental improvement , increased oil production , and the ease of drought in the east .
to be sure , growth is not balanced .
while almost one-third of africa ’ s economies will grow by about 5 % , economic growth in more than a dozen african countries could slow .
this is especially true of nearly half of sub-saharan africa ’ s public debt , which has risen to 50 % of gdp .
but , overall , africa will have a positive year .
second , africa ’ s political landscape is liberalizing .
some of africa ’ s longest-serving presidents , including robert mugabe in zimbabwe , angola ’ s josé eduardo eduardo 和 , and the gambia ’ s yahya 叶海亚 , have dropped in 2017 .
in january , libyans witnessed the transfer of power for the first time since 1944 , when former soccer star george weah was sworn into office .
all of this progress will be tested as voters in 18 countries come to vote this year .
several african countries continue to be politically vulnerable , including the central african republic , burundi , nigeria , south sudan , and somalia .
the third source of optimism is africa ’ s agricultural sector , where farmers are finally realizing their potential , most of which are women .
agricultural yields in africa are expected to reach $ 1 trillion by 2030 .
it is precisely the best time to emerge ; almost two-thirds of africans depend on agriculture to sustain their livelihoods .
large chunks of 未开垦 land , young labor , and the emergence of a “ agriculture entrepreneur ” are increasing output and reforming the entire economy .
fourth , africans are benefiting from technological disruption .
with more than 995 million mobile subscribers , africa ’ s growing information interconnection is helping to accelerate innovation .
key sectors such as agriculture , health care , education , banks , and insurance have already begun to transform the region ’ s business landscape .
fifth , african leaders are serious about curbing illicit funding from corrupt practices , with the corrupt majority occurring in the oil and gas sector , which is about $ 50 billion per year .
although us legislators are pushing for the repeal of the dodd-frank financial reform act of 2010 – which includes the requirement that oil gas and mining companies disclose the regulations to government payments – they will not be able to increase transparency and establish a responsible and responsible trend .
for example , the panama papers and paradise papers have revealed in underground systems such as tax havens and shell companies , and billions of dollars out of the world ’ s poorest countries , including many african countries .
with the g-20 and the oecd working hard to fight tax evasion , africa could soon benefit from global efforts to end the curve .
sixth , africa ’ s energy sector is set to flourish .
while tractor million africans still lack reliable access to electricity , innovations like renewable energy , mini-grids , and smart metering are benefiting more people from energy facilitation .
in south africa , renewable energy has taken off ; the price of wind power is now competitive with coal prices .
ethiopia , kenya , morocco , and rwanda also attract substantial investment in renewable energy .
the seventh area showing signs of progress is education .
to be sure , africa ’ s educational products remain low ; in sub-saharan africa , more than 30 million children are out of school , even if those children do not have enough knowledge .
but many african leaders and citizens have recognized these shortcomings ; in some countries , including ghana , education has even become a decisive issue for voters .
as the education commission highlights , some countries are increasing investment in education .
this creates an opportunity to align learning outcomes with future employment needs .
but , with more than one billion young people living in africa by 2050 , investment in education is urgently needed .
finally , it is increasingly focused on building 泛非 identities , and african fashions , films , and food are moving toward new markets .
as cultural connections continue to grow , africa ’ s soft power will continue to grow and powerful radiation outside the continent .
in many corners of the world , 2018 is becoming a disappointing year , as inequality and poverty continue to fuel anger and populism .
africa will not be immune to such developments .
nonetheless , the continent ’ s residents have at least eight compelling reasons for optimism , and most of the rest of the continent has no such luck .
johannesburg – in october , the european union announced a plan to invest $ 40 billion in investment in africa , an african “ marshall plan ” that would boost african economic growth , create jobs , and eventually reduce african youth to europe .
“ it ’ s impossible to say that immigrants will stay home , ” the european parliament president 塔 雅尼 said , “ we have a chance to live with a decent life . ”
tajani is right .
unfortunately , his approach is wrong .
for almost six decades , well-meaning foreign governments – many of them from europe – have invested heavily in africa , but have little impact .
the ongoing solution to africa ’ s development challenges will certainly require funding , but it also requires important adjustments to foreign partners .
africa ’ s relationship with europe is most needed .
the problem is much deeper than money ; it may even be a philosophical issue .
africa and europe have a long history of relationship , with complexity and pain .
europe will impose its governance system , values , and then impose its trade approach on africa , which has been saying that africans need to be trained to modernize , need to be modernized .
this 庇护 partnership is no longer tenable , and it is crucial to change this dynamic .
the fifth african union summit , in abidjan , côte d ’ ivoire , concluded last week in abidjan , côte d ’ ivoire .
at the african union summit , “ investment in youth ” has become the focus of the focus , and it has also made the complex connection between the two sides .
one conclusion is clear : the eu ’ s current solution to migration in africa is outdated .
if europe ’ s strategy to address the migration challenge relies solely on money , it is doomed to fail .
the 倾斜 relationship between the colonial era is long gone .
today , europe needs africa more than africa needs europe , especially in human capital .
over the next 15 years , some 440 million africans will enter the labor market , and europe is only 200 million .
african job seekers will need work , and europe has jobs .
aging populations have already begun to influence european growth , and , as labor has declined , vacancies are expected to rise .
even if it is possible , the care of europe ’ s pensioners will be paid to the african youth .
these demographic differences imply a significant potential for rethinking economic and political ties .
without migration , the redistribution policies dependent on the european welfare state will not withstand the current rate of aging .
not only is it more difficult to take care of an aging population ; obtaining sufficient revenue to fund social security systems will become increasingly difficult as the dependency ratio rises .
migration policies that emphasize mobility are essential to support european industry , household consumption , and ultimately social-welfare financing .
strategic competitors like china and india have already recognized the human capital potential of young africans , and europe must move quickly to attract and retain – rather than resist – african professionals .
many of africa ’ s students are studying abroad each year , many of which will find their place in a globalized economy .
the us , canada , china , the middle east , and africa themselves are increasingly competing for these highly educated and highly educated students .
just as europe in the sixteenth century required the continent ’ s gold , there was no african diaspora , and europe ’ s twenty-first-century europe will be elusive .
so , for europe , europe must not succumb to political calculation , but in this regard other economies .
instead , europe should work to achieve mutually beneficial employment schemes , thereby maximizing both peoples and cultures , most notably through skills transfer .
europe ’ s recognition of its need for africa is a necessary paradigm shift , and that we hope to bring about rational cooperation .
in an increasingly uncertain world , africa and europe can lay the groundwork for smarter partnerships by changing their foundations .
if it does not , it will be high .
but much of the price will be borne by europe .
the rest of the world has already embarked on talent , and the biggest impact is not africa .
gender equality for african scientists
kigali – a ethiopian girl can grow up as long as it is able to find a proper mentor to a new approach to crop yields .
a young woman in malawi has a new idea of cancer for cancer , but if she is forced to stay out of school forever .
a girl in rwanda has all the skills to create mathematical models to mitigate droughts ; she needs just a research grant to help her .
there are global gender imbalances in science , technology , engineering , and mathematics – the so-called stem disciplines .
but in africa , not only is the future being threatened by such imbalances .
it also deprives the continent of talent and contributions needed to advance development and progress .
according to a 2011 african development bank report , “ bringing women to science and technology ultimately benefits society . ”
while gender equality in science , technology , engineering , and mathematics can be achieved , many african scholars are showing how they will lead the world .
but they need help , and programs that provide scholarships and support are the best way to achieve scientific equity .
the reasons for africa ’ s scientific , technological , engineering , and mathematical imbalances are often compared to a leaky cocktail : girls are full interest and talent when they are beginning , but they are forced to quit in the education stages .
early data from the mastercard foundation ’ s aim of reversing these trends show that a comprehensive approach to plugging the leaks will change the entire picture .
it is successful to acknowledge that gender equality in science , technology , engineering , and mathematics has begun .
the “ science needs us ” is the words of 阿曼 库瓦希 , a former mastercard foundation scholar and industrial engineer .
“ different ideas and perspectives can lead to better solutions and thinking , which drives scientific innovation forward and benefits across africa . ”
the right thing is true .
africa can not afford to squander its young female talent .
sub-saharan africa faces shortages of 2.5 million engineers , technologists , mathematicians , and scientists .
this lack of expertise could threaten several sustainable development goals , such as food security , health care , clean water , sanitation , and energy and infrastructure .
eliminating gender barriers in science , technology , engineering , and mathematics will require african governments to prioritize scientific equity issues .
most successful in rwanda , our collective experience has helped more than 250 girls and young women have done well in these disciplines .
the african institute for mathematical sciences in kigali , rwanda , is one of the drivers of this change .
innovative approaches to mathematical science in africa include helping governments to train teachers , ensure that a number of girls in classrooms , support for the classroom , and work with industry leaders to help graduates achieve success .
to attract more female students , 30 % of the school ’ s scholarships are reserved for female applicants , and schools want to reach 50 % in the near future .
likewise , carnegie mellon university in kigali is promoting change by allocating 30 % of its scholarships to young women .
such a move would have a positive impact on the entire educational system , because the african carnegie academy of carnegie university is actively taking steps to increase enrollment rates for women .
finally , the forum for education in africa has funded the education of 1,200 students in the country ’ s excellent high school , technology , engineering , and mathematics .
in these students , an estimated 70 % of the population is expected to learn the science of science .
despite these positive developments , quotas alone can not achieve parity .
opportunities outside the classroom will require lasting gains .
at the african women forum for education , rwanda , a 项目 project called “ making us publicly express ” through play , 歌唱 , and creative art training , and taught them with a speech , negotiation , and decision-making technology .
rwanda ’ s education professionals forum also collaborated with teachers to develop pedagogical methods .
likewise , the african carnegie academy of carnegie university was invited to participate in a school symposium on the minds of schools , the annual global gathering of undergraduates , at the meeting of undergraduates , students , government officials , and industry representatives to demonstrate their achievements .
moreover , according to the 精选 project of the african institute for mathematical science , the world ’ s highest youth scientist and the technical workforce – 40 % of whom are women – provide the opportunity to lead their own research , while encouraging the next generation of scientific thinkers .
inequalities in girls and young women in africa can not be eliminated overnight .
as 丽贝卡 丽贝卡 , a mastercard foundation scholar at uganda , has said , “ my classroom once called us ‘ 假小子 , because if you were a woman and a university , you are 假小子 . ”
but , 丽贝卡 added , “ the science of science is cool . ”
africa needs more women like 丽贝卡 , technology , engineering , and mathematics .
to ensure that science is attractive to women , schools , governments , and industry must work together to educate teachers and teachers , while funding the gender gap .
as the other mastercard foundation scholar 米兰达 米兰达 recently noted , “ when we want to find new creation and inventions to promote economic development , i believe that mathematics and science are at the forefront of progress .
as professionals who do best to improve african education , my view is that i am not .
liberal democracy in africa can wait
yaoundé – african policymakers understand that strong economic and political leadership is essential to growth and stability .
for years , africa ’ s economic performance has been better than expected , which is a commitment to improving governance .
the question now is how to sustain this momentum .
the current strategy does not provide sufficient answers .
at the recent african economic conference in addis ababa , ethiopia , leaders pledged to keep governance reform at the top of africa ’ s agenda , but they did not offer a roadmap .
from my perspective , this gap is an opportunity to think about new governance paradigms , including the “ washington consensus ” and the paradigm of “ beijing . ”
development practitioners have long debated that model is the best framework for reform .
simply put , “ governance ” refers to a dynamic rule of law , structure , and process to help governments manage the economy , politics , and 行政事务 .
but there is a different approach to the principles that governments should focus on .
since trump ’ s presidency , the united states , which has remained africa ’ s primary donor , has begun to focus more on the principles favored by china – such as political stability , trade , and counterterrorism – than human rights .
the reason is that the beijing model is better for africa in the short and medium term .
while acknowledging that this may not be popular , trump has a point .
simply put , food , shelter , health , and good sanitation are more important for most africans than to voting rights .
moreover , only when the population is richer and creates a healthy middle class can the rights of democracy be fully demanded .
ironically , the best way to build a strong middle class in africa is to adopt the principles pursued by china ’ s model at all levels .
for africa , the governing approach , the adoption of washington consensus , requires its leaders to work toward improving institutional effectiveness and economic management .
the first set of reforms should include establishing clear borders with international partners .
africa ’ s relationship with western donors , for example , has historically placed individual rights above national rights .
but in my view , individual rights should not go beyond sovereignty .
punishing the country for the laws that affect the minority would backfire .
one example of this collective punishment occurred in uganda in 2014 , when the world bank froze roughly $ 90 million in loans .
at the time , uganda ’ s government spokesperson said that the world bank “ should not capture its members ” to accept western values .
but , when the governance model is judged solely by the standards of the washington consensus , there is little choice .
at the same time , the second set of reforms concerns economic rights rather than political rights .
politicians who manage the economy , for example , should not have term limits .
neither singapore nor china is democratic ; but both leaders have used their political power to improve living standards .
forcing leaders to step down in the medium term could prove counterproductive .
none of this seems far-fetched .
today , in rwanda , one of africa ’ s success stories , leaders have improved stability by abandoning the governance approach of the washington consensus .
politically , rwanda is strong , organized , and disciplined , but not free .
the landslide re-election of president paul kagame last year has not stemmed from democracy .
although kagame remains popular , his government was criticized for stifling free speech and oppression of human rights .
my conclusion is not that human rights are important , but the political discipline and imperfect forms of democracy that are acceptable to the ongoing improvements in economic and institutional governance .
we should be intellectually honest and spade a spade a spade .
the people of rwanda need not be ashamed that they are more ashamed than their fair economic and administrative strength .
so the question facing other african countries seeking to reform the governance model is to emulate rwanda ’ s approach .
neither the washington consensus nor the beijing model is all the answer .
but , as rwanda shows , if discipline and strong leadership can improve lives and provide public goods , perhaps liberal democracy should be a long-term priority .
dar es salaam – my grandmother is 76 , and my grandfather is 83 .
they live in a remote village in the southwest of the southwest of uganda , raising crop grazing crops .
but whenever i think of them , i am more in awe of their health than their hard work .
because of the remote region ’ s remoteness , each of my grandparents needs to travel to the nearest hospital in a hospital that is known to be known as boda 前往 .
then , because they had recently been forced to withdraw from medicare , they had to cough up more money to pay for their bills .
in other words , for my grandparents – and for many of africa ’ s elderly people – the doctor is not only troubling , expensive , and rare .
access to health care has become 强迫症 强迫症 .
in may , at the who ’ s annual world health assembly , officials from dozens of countries discussed how to achieve universal health coverage through the united nations sustainable development goals .
but maternal and child attracts vast swaths of the attention ; the discussion of elderly people in developing countries is largely ignored .
without this omission of omission , a growing number of people in africa will lack access to affordable health care .
according to the world bank , life expectancy in sub-saharan africa has been rising steadily in recent decades , from only 40 years in 1960 to 60 today .
if this trend continues , the number of africans aged 60 years old will double by 2050 .
this is certainly good news ; longevity is a key indicator of human development .
but africa ’ s aging population will have devastating consequences if longevity means that the disease suffers from inadequate health care .
in uganda , many rural health-care centers are inadequate to meet older patients ’ needs , supplies , and infrastructure .
it is often a few miles away , too , that the most elderly patients typically turn to the most senior hospital .
riding a motorcycle on a bumpy terrain could worsen health conditions ; but , because there is no other option , the vulnerable must choose between a bumpy ride and abandoning treatment .
no wonder some chose the latter .
according to a 2010 survey by doctors at the national referral hospital in kampala , surgeons are the main causes of uganda ’ s road damage .
during the survey , motorcycle passengers accounted for 41 % of the city ’ s 1,500 trauma cases , compared to 62.5 % of the 该院 budget .
given the dangers that may arise , it is no wonder that my grandparents are reluctant to seek medical services .
of course , like elsewhere , money is the biggest 障碍因素 of health care in uganda .
in 2015 , researchers at the university of 雷雷 found that household income was the primary determinant of elderly people ’ s access and access to health care .
the situation is similar in the us , where the average annual health-care costs have been increasing in recent decades .
but while older patients in the us can use medicare ( 15 % of federal spending in 2017 ) , the elderly in most african countries lack the government ’ s support .
nonetheless , the lack of resources does not mean that african leaders must ignore older voters ’ needs .
by combining care services with existing programs , health benefits can be extended to underserved populations .
for example , initiatives like the hiv/aids treatment programs , such as the hiv/aids treatment program , can be incorporated into the health care of elderly people .
health-care workers in the service of pregnant women and mothers could also be trained to provide 上门 medical services for elderly families in generations .
developing countries have made significant progress in improving health care for young people .
now we must provide the same services to the elderly .
in uganda , a strengthening of the elderly ’ s health-care strategy could easily be achieved by adding the elderly to the list of so-called vulnerable .
other means of expanding access to health care are the existing health-care framework , such as ethiopia ’ s health extension program , tanzania ’ s community-based health program , and the rural health teams of my country .
finally , to prevent the exclusion of poor older patients , there must be radical reform of the community ’ s health insurance programs .
to ensure health care for the elderly and protect the elderly from financial bankruptcy , we need to reform programs that are financially sound and broadening their base base .
everyone is hungry for longevity , health , and productive life , like my grandparents .
but without a decent quality health care , longevity can be achieved without science .
the extent of how to treat the most young and oldest members can determine the extent of society .
the same reasoning applies to governments .
africa ’ s last decade
vienna – since 2000 , africa ’ s economy has grown impressive , owing largely to the long-term prosperity of development aid and commodity .
although the continent has shown great diversity in socioeconomic development , growth rates often mask the absence of structural transformation .
many african countries still have not experienced the kind of transformation needed to achieve long-term social inclusion and environmental sustainability : industrialization .
wherever industrialization is occurring , it certainly fosters economic diversification , helping to nurture , strengthen , and maintain the conditions needed for competitive development and growth .
in recent decades , some developing countries – mainly in asia – have managed to industrialize .
but , despite repeated attempts , african countries have failed to industrialize .
in 2014 , the region ’ s share of global manufacturing value added was 44.6 % , compared to just 1.6 % in africa .
with only one industrialized country in south africa , sub-saharan africa is the least industrialized region in the world .
to achieve sustainable development , african countries must increase the share of industry – especially manufacturing – in areas like national investment , production , and trade .
to be sure , most african countries have already recognized that such a transformation will be needed to address the range of interconnected challenges that they currently face .
one challenge is population growth .
more than half of the continent ’ s 1.2 billion people are under the age of 19 , and almost one in five are between 15 and 24 .
every year , 12 million new entrants are added to the workforce , and they need the tools and skills to ensure future living standards .
industrialization is essential to helping africa ’ s fast-growing population achieve a demographic dividend .
the related challenge is immigration .
many of africa ’ s most ambitious and entrepreneurial young people are joining others with the rest of the population .
but no country , especially in africa , can afford to lose so much talent and potential .
industrialization alone can not solve the migration crisis , but it can be addressed by creating jobs in the countries of origin .
to meet this challenge , africa needs to develop and apply green technologies while attracting more investment in resource efficiency and clean energy .
if there is plenty of investment , african countries can reduce the cost of transmission to rural areas and contribute to global efforts to reduce the impact of climate change and mitigate climate change .
in short , africa must industrialize , and it must do so in a way that ensures social inclusion and environmental sustainability .
given that sustainable development efforts in africa have largely failed , it is clear that a new approach is needed : sustainable development must take care of a broad basis , and to take advantage of financial and non-financial resources , promoting regional integration , and foster partnerships between africa ’ s development partners .
indeed , the un general assembly has declared that the 2016 period is the third of africa ’ s industrial development .
during the third decade of industrial development , the united nations industrial development organization ( unido ) , which i lead , will spearhead the new approach to sustainable development .
the united nations industry development organization supports partnerships with partners to mobilize resources , while providing a 验证 model for african countries .
the pcp in the united nations industrial development organization provides technical assistance , policy consultation , and investment to countries that help them design and implement industrialization strategies .
the program was launched in 2014 , and has been successfully implemented in two african countries , such as ethiopia and senegal .
the national partnership provides a model of 以多 partnerships that can be implemented after the national development agenda adjusted .
it aims to coordinate cooperation with government governments and its partners , while providing additional funding and investment to the sectors that have high growth potential and key sectors of the government ’ s industrial development agenda .
people often choose to create jobs , attract investment , and export their export potential as a priority , and one condition is that raw materials must be easily accessible .
the national partnership initiative aims to maximize the impact of all partner projects and programs associated with industrial development .
to achieve this , strategic partnerships with financial institutions and the corporate sector are particularly important .
with these , african countries can raise more resources for infrastructure , innovation , expertise , and new technologies .
unido ’ s goal is to make the pcp model the mainstream model adopted by all african countries .
we are ready to support africa ’ s progress toward inclusive and sustainable industrial development – or after the third decade of african industrial development .
africa ’ s decade of industrialization
vienna – in today ’ s interdependent global economy , africa remains weak .
to achieve the sdgs , the united nations 2030 agenda for sustainable development will have to be achieved by promoting rapid and responsible industrialization .
africa is hardly a drag on the world economy .
rather , it is promising to become the engine of the world economy – and the next decade .
but , to realize its economic potential , africa must industrialize .
the importance of this has been repeated in the recent international forum , including the sixth international conference on development in tokyo last august and the g20 summit in hangzhou in september .
the g-20 , for the first time , will have the industrialization of africa – and all of the least developed countries .
the african union ’ s agenda 2063 also supports industrialization in africa .
the recent united nations general assembly resolution will be a third decade in africa ’ s industrial development , which is the latest decade of this .
the organization i represent , the united nations industrial development organization ( unido ) , took the task of executing and leading a multi-pronged program , including mobilizing the resources needed .
all of these declarations and commitments are important first steps .
the question is how .
the short answer is money and action .
we must urge the international community and the development partners to fulfill real cash promises .
we must build partnerships with partnerships that enable africa to become the world ’ s next major engine of economic growth .
these programs must acknowledge and address the acute challenges facing africa .
economic growth in recent decades has not been structurally driven , unsustainable , and fully inclusive .
indeed , africa ’ s growth rate is very different , and not all countries are benefiting .
while africa ’ s middle class has expanded rapidly in recent years , creating a consumer boom has also boosted domestic investment , but many are still 艰难度日 .
unemployment is high , especially among young people and women – a reality that many africans have moved to north .
to retain these people , african economies can not simply produce raw materials , but also build a dynamic and competitive manufacturing sector that is more valuable .
here , africa must seize the opportunity to participate in global and regional value chains .
new and innovative industrial development strategies must be introduced , and a careful effort to attract foreign direct investment .
of course , developing such strategies and effective engagement in industrial value chains requires knowledge .
investment in education and skills training is key to successful and sustained industrialization .
by understanding and deploying effective innovations from around the world , africa can technologically catch up with more advanced countries , building the capacity to produce more sophisticated , higher-value goods .
understanding other countries ’ experience also helps africa avoid the pitfalls of laissez-faire industrialization – particularly environmental damage .
africa must ensure that its industrial development strategy includes effective environmental safeguards .
africa is well placed to industrialize .
beyond the rich natural resource endowments , africa has favorable demographics ( rapidly growing population means that it will soon have the world ’ s largest labor force ) and high urbanization rates .
africa also benefits from an educated diaspora .
but industrialization is not automatic .
governments must step in to address market failures , while planning , implementing , and implementing industrial policies that address the shortcomings of previous ineffective solutions .
they must also institutionalize these countries ’ national and regional development strategies .
to succeed , governments must have sufficient energy , capacity , and legitimacy to mobilize stakeholders and interact with them , thereby creating attractive investment climate .
implementing the necessary reforms will open the doors for public-private partnerships , while public-private partnerships provide infrastructure development and maintenance .
governments will also facilitate cooperation with international organizations and development institutions , which can provide more funds , and help african countries upgrade their capacity .
the g20 ’ s report in hangzhou , hangzhou , offers africa many recommendations .
the report proposes support for agricultural and agribusiness development , enabling them to connect with other sectors and take steps to strengthen resilience to price shocks .
moreover , the report emphasizes the need to deepen , broaden , and update local knowledge reserves , invest in increased energy and raw materials , and promote green technologies and industries .
i have met with africa ’ s leaders countless meetings and visited dozens of african countries , which have led me to believe that africa is committed to industrialization .
indeed , industrialization has already begun in many countries , including ethiopia , ghana , rwanda , and senegal .
by providing our commitments and support , we can enable these countries to achieve inclusive and sustainable development , benefiting everyone .
a roadmap for african industrialization
abidjan – africa is at a crossroads .
today , six of the world ’ s ten fastest-growing economies are in africa , with annual gdp growth forecast for 4.1 % in africa , compared to 3.6 % in 2017 .
but africa ’ s economic growth has not led to a commensurate job creation , especially for women and young people .
indeed , today ’ s jobless growth may even reverse the progress of poverty reduction in recent years .
the problem is that africa ’ s growth , while impressive , is unstable , because it is driven mainly by commodity prices in commodity prices .
the economic impact of this imbalance should not be underestimated .
it , together with other factors , led to the world ’ s 75 % of the world ’ s cocoa , but only 5 % of the chocolate market of chocolate markets per year .
despite the vast amount of natural resources , africa still needs to be at the mercy of commodity prices and trade flows unless it achieves deep structural shifts .
as soon as it is time for africa to unlock the transition from agriculture to manufacturing , the continent should unlock its real economic potential .
in africa ’ s integration into the global economy , manufacturing is the weakest link .
today , primary products ( raw materials ) account for 62 % of africa ’ s total exports , the highest in the world .
at the same time , the total per capita export exports of 2014 amounted to just $ 128 , with the lowest among the world ’ s lowest , well below other developing regions , such as the us dollar and the latin american dollar .
clearly , africa must begin to catch up .
fortunately , globalization is important for global consensus , and it is in everyone ’ s interest to make africa the global manufacturing force that it should be .
the african development bank ( afdb ) has identified the “ five priorities , ” which made industrialization the most important work .
likewise , industrialization is an important component of the 盟 agenda .
in 2016 , the united nations general assembly announced the 2016 “ third decade of industrial development in africa . ”
without concrete action , however , these pronouncements are meaningless .
to change africa ’ s economic trajectory , african policymakers must focus on three key areas : industrial policy , manufacturing financing , and leadership .
we now know that industrial policy is effective in spurring growth .
the question is whether countries have the capacity to implement their policies .
if they are , they can channel resources toward industry , using technologies that can be used to tap agriculture and manufacturing .
many african countries are already moving in this direction .
ethiopia , for example , has created special economic zones to reduce production costs by investing in infrastructure .
as a result , ethiopia has become africa ’ s largest hub of textile manufacturing , attracting major players like h & m and 普利马 .
but industrialization can not thrive without electricity , roads , and railways , so infrastructure must be critical .
at the moment , the afdb believes that africa ’ s infrastructure gap is $ 170 billion a year .
closing this gap requires not just more financing , but also innovative thinking , particularly in the innovative thinking of public-private partnerships .
here , the afdb has expanded loans for new infrastructure projects in several countries .
as part of our “ new energy deal in africa , ” we increased investment in renewable energy , and to generate $ 20 billion to develop two solar power plants in mexico .
in côte d ’ ivoire , energy demand soared at an annual rate of 8-9 % , and we invested $ 60 million in upstream building hydroelectric power .
african countries should do so , in order to achieve the demographic dividend of africa ’ s population bulge in the years ahead .
as manufacturing activities expand , the need for stronger knowledge and skills underpinned the economy ’ s investment , which requires boosting investment in education and boosting technical and vocational skills and training .
no country can modernize without industry .
but , more broadly , there will be no functioning industrial sector without strong leadership .
consider mauritius , where it was a low-income single economy in the 1970s , with per capita gdp of just $ 250 .
it is now in a high-income country , with economic diversification and per capita gdp of $ 9,600 .
it is often seen as a model for economic success in africa .
how can this be made ?
as former prime minister and president 格纳特 格纳特 put it : “ no miracle .
it is simply efforts to work , discipline , and will .
leaders who want to develop a strong manufacturing base must have the political will to allocate resources fairly and to the private sector .
mauritius also confronts a wide range of challenges when moving from low-end manufacturing to technology-intensive goods and services .
but now it has become an example of what committed leadership can accomplish .
other african countries are pursuing their own economic transformation when energy efficiency is available .
in short , africa will be well positioned to seize the many opportunities that the global economy offers emerging markets .
it has resources and labor ; now it needs a firm leader like 贾 to implement the right policies .
africa ’ s other development path
washington , dc – several recent projections suggest that several sub-saharan african countries will achieve strong economic growth in the next five years .
from 2000 to 2023 , roughly one-third of the region ’ s economies will grow at an annual rate of 5 % or higher .
but , as the economist observed last year , africa ’ s development model “ puzzles economists . ”
after all , only four of the continent ’ s high-growth countries are resource dependent .
and overall development is not driven largely by industrialization , as the traditional development model predicts .
what explains this strong economic performance ?
according to the forthcoming book industries 无烟工业 : rethinking africa ’ s industrialization , there is evidence that sub-saharan africa is undergoing a deeper structural transformation than we think .
africa ’ s structural transformation is not the result of traditional industries , but new developments in tradable services and agricultural sectors that resemble traditional industrialization .
beyond horticulture and agricultural operations , these new industries include services and communications technology and communications technology .
this is the opposite of the historical norm .
traditionally , as harvard university economist dani rodrik points out , economies that have sustained strong growth rates without relying on high prices of natural resources are “ typically achieved through export-oriented industrialization . ”
but in africa , manufacturing accounts for about 10 % of total economic activity , and economic activity moved from agriculture to services .
because productivity growth in services is only about half that of manufacturing , the overall productivity gains needed for sustained growth are relatively small .
this process of premature deindustrialization is not unique to africa .
but , given the scale of the development challenges that africa faces , this process makes sense for the continent .
because its labor force is young and growing rapidly , africa now needs to create more than 11 million jobs in the formal economy each year .
but , as the nobel laureate economist joseph e. stiglitz has warned , africa can not replicate east asia ’ s manufacturing-led model , so the question is whether it can achieve economic development through modern services .
according to the brookings institution ’ s “ forward african forward : the priorities of the 2018 priority ” report – the report ’ s conclusions , the report ’ s conclusions – that africa ’ s services export grew sixfold between 1998 and 2015 .
in kenya , rwanda , senegal , and south africa are thriving , based on information and communications technology .
in rwanda , tourism has become the single largest export activity , accounting for nearly 30 % of the country ’ s total exports .
ethiopia , ghana , kenya , and senegal are all integrated into global horticultural value chains , and ethiopia has become a major player in global 花卉 exports .
as these industries grow , they generate new models of structural change unlike the manufacturing-led transformation in east asia .
if properly restarted , these industries can play a role in africa ’ s development as well as east asian manufacturing .
manufacturing boosts growth in east asia , for three reasons : first , productivity in manufacturing is more productive than agriculture , which can absorb a large number of low-skill workers from the agricultural sector ; and , third , east asia ’ s manufacturing sector is in the opposite direction .
as john page , one of john page ’ s 编者 编者 , has said , africa ’ s growing service sector has the same characteristics .
beyond tradable , they have high productivity and can absorb a large number of middle-skill workers .
as in manufacturing , they also benefit from technological change and the size of the economy .
moreover , africa ’ s smokestack-less service sectors have the advantage of being vulnerable to automation .
while automation has many benefits , it poses challenges to the top priority of the country ’ s top priority job creation .
while economists are increasingly convinced that africa ’ s development model will be different from east asia , they are uncertain about this model .
an 模式 model provides a potential answer .
from a policy perspective , african leaders should explore more support by targeted reforms or incorporating them into national industrialization strategies and broader development agendas .
the development of industry industries can go hand in hand with efforts to develop industry , thereby providing a multifaceted approach to africa ’ s structural transformation .
hoping for african infrastructure
johannesburg – as the us federal reserve moves to “ reverse ” the stimulus package that began nearly a decade ago , emerging economies increasingly fear that the dollar will have a negative impact on the solvency of dollar-denominated debt .
