but if the fed ’ s continued withdrawal from stimulus has provoked african nerves , it is also recognized that a more sensible approach to development finance is more sensible than borrowing in dollars .
in the existing proposal , one specific asset class stands out : infrastructure .
africa is expected to reach 26 billion people by 2050 , so it is urgent to build and maintain infrastructure , ports , and grids .
according to the world bank , africa must spend an astounding $ 93 billion annually to upgrade its existing infrastructure ; most of these funds – roughly 87 % – will be used to improve basic services such as energy , water , health , and transportation .
but if there is any experience in the past , it is that the money needed is not easy .
between 2004 and 2013 , africa ’ s countries did just about the financing transactions of infrastructure or industrial projects , valued at $ 5.9 billion – just 5 % of the total required .
given these past experiences , it is difficult for africa to fund even a small fraction of the world bank ’ s projected requirements .
the most obvious funding is institutional and foreign investment .
but , so far , many factors , including poorly predicted earnings projections and political instability , constitute a serious constraint on financing for infrastructure projects across the continent .
investing in infrastructure projects in africa is viewed as a high-risk option .
fortunately , as some investors – such as the african development bank , the southern african development bank , and the trade & trade bank – have shown , such negative perceptions can be overcome .
companies from the private sector are also profitable in financing infrastructure projects across the continent .
for example , the black rhino funds established by blackstone are one of the world ’ s largest multinational private-equity companies , with the development and procurement of energy projects such as fuel storage , pipelines , and delivery networks .
but these are the exceptions , not the rule .
adequate funding to address africa ’ s infrastructure shortfall requires a rapid appeal to more investors .
to succeed , africa must develop a more concerted approach to pandering to capital , while working hard to control investors ’ risk exposure .
public-private partnerships provide a possibility .
in energy , for example , independent electricity producers are working with governments to provide electricity to 620 million africans who have yet to access the grid .
these producers of electricity production are financed by private donors and accepted government regulations , by purchasing agreements to operate , and the public health sector and regulatory agencies agreed to purchase electricity in advance of their own prices .
there are roughly 130 such electricity producers in sub-saharan africa , valued at more than $ 8 billion .
south africa alone is in the middle of 47 projects , with a total of 7,000 megawatts of additional power capacity .
similar private-public partnerships are emerging in other sectors , such as transportation .
the most promising is toll toll roads built by private investment in south africa .
projects emerging in the rest of the continent are more profitable than most financial markets ; and they are actually paving the way for future economic growth .
clearly , africa needs more such ventures to meet the challenges posed by infrastructure .
as a result , my business leaders and policymakers in africa are calling for an african institution to invest 5 % of its funds to invest in local infrastructure .
we believe that infrastructure can be an attractive and attractive asset class as long as incentives are appropriate .
one sector that can lead this goal is the continent ’ s pension funds , which have roughly $ 3 trillion in balance sheets .
the 5 % agenda that was launched in new york last month highlights the belief that a collaborative public-private approach can change africa ’ s infrastructure shortfall .
but in 2012 , the african union adopted the african infrastructure program , launching more than 400 energy , transportation , water , and communications projects .
this is a very good start – one that is based on the 5 % agenda .
but some key areas of reform must be reformed .
the key objective of the 5 % agenda is to help upgrade national and regional regulatory frameworks , thereby channeling investment in african institutions .
similarly , new financial products must be developed so that asset owners can allocate funds directly to infrastructure projects .
unlocking new funding flows would help create jobs , encourage regional integration , and ensure that africa has infrastructure projects that meet future generations ’ needs .
but all of this depends on persuading investors to put their money in africa ’ s projects .
as business leaders and policymakers , we must ensure that the conditions for profit and social impact are mutually exclusive .
if development goals are aligned with profits , everyone wins .
unlocking africa ’ s internet
washington , dc – what the government of addis ababa surprised is that “ the ninth zone ” has become a household name in ethiopia .
since 2012 , this group of small journalists has used social media to demand that countries achieve political freedom and civil liberties .
its success – such as the number of likes and comments that can be measured on its facebook page – is the result of the government ’ s attempt to silence the writers , including the arrest of six members in 2014 .
ethiopia ’ s government is not the only government attempting to consolidate political power by restricting citizens ’ online rhetoric .
across africa , many governments have implemented laws restricting internet access and criminalizing criticism of elected officials .
digital campaigners face myriad censorship techniques , such as “ border 网关 protocols , ” “ http 限流 , ” and “ deep 封包 tests . ”
the irony , of course , is that censorship rarely enables discontent .
instead of repressing dissent , the government has stimulated more people in WhatApp , facebook , twitter , and other social media platforms , and africans are exposed to increasingly challenging governments , revealing rigged elections , and demanding their voice .
at the moment , however , few african leaders are listening .
in the 18 african countries that held elections in 2016 , nine of the world ’ s nine countries had managed to restrict dissent to contain dissent .
four days before uganda ’ s presidential election in february , president yoweri museveni cut off mobile payment services and social media websites .
in august and september , gabon ’ s president , 班戈 班戈 , wanted to build an atmosphere of calm in the face of the international community .
in december , officials in the democratic republic of congo ordered the internet to close the internet before president joseph kabila expires , in order to suppress the online dissent that he refused to step down .
internet blackouts violate human rights and undermine democratic processes .
last year , the united nations human rights council adopted a resolution affirming “ the rights of people online , online and offline , and especially free speech . ”
most african governments use their argument that internet embargoes are necessary to ensure public safety and security .
museveni , for example , claimed that cutting off internet access was the only way to protect visiting heads of state in his inauguration .
but he has offered no evidence that social media access and security in uganda or any other country have security .
according to the international community , which promotes digital rights “ soon , ” the internet has typically made it less safe , because people can not be exposed to information or with friends .
in zimbabwe , president robert mugabe of 93 % of the age of 93 is expected to be 履任 in his eighth term ( beginning in 2018 ) , and the government ’ s dominant crackdown appears necessary .
for decades , mugabe relied on intimidation and violence to stifle political dissent .
so it is not surprising that he has already been hostile to online activities .
last year , his government shut down the internet during political protests , and vowed to arrest anyone who has been attacking or sharing “ defamation or subversive material on social media . ”
but citizens are not hopeless .
while governments can command internet access , only telecommunications companies have the ability to hit the “ death switch . ”
as a result , african bloggers and online activists must work more closely with investors and shareholders in communications firms to persuade them to stand up for democracy and human rights , rejecting illiberal government directives .
moreover , civil-society groups , the african union , and the un should do more to condemn legislation aimed at limiting the internet ’ s policies .
in 2013 , the african union issued a model law for information contacts , which now should give countries a new guide to how to safeguard online collection and expression .
finally , new continent-wide measures are needed to ensure that africa ’ s online rights gain government and recognition and respect .
although the un human rights council resolution , which protects online freedom , is not binding , it provides a starting point for ensuring that governments allow citizens to use the internet as a tool for maximizing political participation .
these interventions are more needed than ever .
kenya , zimbabwe , and the ethiopian legislature are considering legislation that significantly expanded government control over internet access .
last year , tanzania implemented a legislation that was used to prosecute president john magufuli ’ s personal prosecution of president john magufuli on social media .
no matter how different the government is to bar citizens from gathering , signing petitions , or banning access to the internet and posting on social media .
all of these measures are meant to strip citizens of their rights .
ninth , the fight against freedom is as true as it is in the digital domain .
seizing africa ’ s high returns
washington , dc – since 2000 , at least half of the world ’ s fastest-growing economies have come from africa .
and , by 2030 , africa will have 1.7 billion people , with its total consumption and business spending amounting to $ 6.7 trillion .
seven years ago , harvard business review pointed out that africa was home to the world ’ s largest opportunity .
but , despite the huge commercial potential , africa has not been at the top of the western business leadership .
in fact , from 2014 to 2016 , america ’ s exports to africa plummeted by almost half , from $ 38 billion to $ 22 billion .
and while britain ’ s investment in the continent has doubled by more than doubled between 2005 and 2014 , to 亿英镑 billion ( $ 576 billion ) , exports to africa accounted for just 2.5 % .
the west ’ s challenge to china is rapidly losing its edge , from 2005 to 2015 , when china ’ s exports to africa increased by more than $ 103 billion – up to $ 103 billion .
if western firms want to keep up with china , they will have to take advantage of africa ’ s growing potential for growth .
by 2030 , more than half of africa ’ s population will reside in seven countries : nigeria , ethiopia , the democratic republic of congo , egypt , tanzania , kenya , and south africa .
but , more important , 43 % of africans will rise to the upper middle , compared to 39.6 % in 2013 , meaning that demand for goods and services would increase substantially .
by 2030 , household consumption is expected to reach $ 2.5 trillion , compared to just 1.1 trillion in 2015 .
but algeria , angola , ethiopia , ghana , kenya , morocco , sudan , and tunisia all have an opportunity to offer lucrative returns .
any of these countries can offer good opportunities for new markets .
by 2030 , food and beverages ( $ 40 billion ) , education transport ( $ 390 billion ) , and housing ( $ 90 billion ) will become the continent ’ s most valuable industries .
but , as with consumer goods ( $ 35 billion ) , hotels , and entertainment ( $ 600 billion ) , health care ( $ 175 billion ) , financial services ( $ 175 billion ) , financial services ( $ 85 billion ) , and telecommunications ( $ 6.5 billion ) will grow strong .
of course , whether growth will eventually be achieved will depend on the african union ’ s success in implementing its new frontier of the free trade area , which will create a single market for goods and services , providing a single market for businesses .
moreover , the cfta will increase the need for connectivity , thereby creating new opportunities for investment in sectors like infrastructure and transportation , energy , information , and communications technology ( ict ) .
to this end , the african development bank could help investors to find a prospective project through its african infrastructure development program .
africa ’ s corporate spending will be another major growth area between now and 2030 , which will amount to $ 4.2 trillion , compared to $ 1.6 trillion in 2015 .
the main sectors will include agricultural and agricultural processing ( $ 650 billion ) , manufacturing ( $ 650 billion ) , construction , architecture , public utilities , and transportation ( $ 84 billion ) , and the telecommunications and communications technology ( $ 650 billion ) , and telecommunications and communications technology ( $ 325 billion ) , and telecommunications and communications technology ( $ 49 billion ) .
the projected growth in agriculture and agricultural processing reflects the fact that food and beverages will account for the highest share of household spending in africa .
moreover , 60 % of the planet ’ s unused land is located in africa , even though africa still has a meager contribution to world agriculture .
this means that africa has enormous growth potential .
and , because severe hunger still affects many african countries , investors could even drive up the public good by investing in fertilizers , machinery , water , and irrigation .
by 2012 , africa ’ s highest growth rate in agricultural value-added countries included burkina faso , ethiopia , nigeria , mali , mozambique , rwanda , and tanzania .
moreover , angola , morocco , and south africa now have large markets , and are working to expand their agricultural sectors .
according to harvard business review , africa also has the potential to become “ the next big manufacturing center in the world . ”
by 2030 , china expected to lose over 15 million low-cost , labor-intensive jobs , and africa will take many of its jobs .
this helps to explain why manufacturing is second to business spending .
another reason is that many of africa ’ s manufacturing opportunities come from global competition areas like automobiles and transport equipment , refined petroleum , computers , office , and industrial machinery .
south africa , egypt , and nigeria have become the region ’ s emerging land .
investors can also find high returns and favorable business environments in ethiopia , morocco , and rwanda .
africa is the world ’ s last frontier market , and western businesses need to follow china , beginning to tap its considerable potential .
doing business in africa will also create sustainable job creation while pushing for sustainable development goals for the united nations to eliminate hunger and poverty .
and that , too , is a good thing .
as the business and sustainable development commission shows , achieving the sdgs ’ “ new market opportunities for all of the trillions of dollars will be open to a new market for all . ”
strengthening africa ’ s science
乌尔班 , illinois – in late march , africa ’ s distinguished scientists , innovators , and policymakers gathered in kigali , rwanda , to find solutions to an increasingly pressing problem : poor scientific quality in africa .
good leaders know that scientific discovery and innovation drive progress , promote development , and help address issues like food insecurity , water shortages , and climate change .
but most african governments have failed to provide sufficient funding for domestic research and development .
in the west , the share is close to 3 % .
this disparity underscores the development challenges africa faces .
africa accounts for 15 % of the world ’ s population , 5 % of gdp , but research spending accounts for only 1.3 % .
moreover , africa ’ s innovators have just 0.1 % of the world ’ s patents , meaning that , even when it comes to science , innovation , and research , results rarely translate into solutions to africa ’ s most pressing challenges .
to be sure , these trends are not universal ; some african governments are investing in technology-driven innovation .
in south africa , for example , authorities have promised to double r & d spending by 2020 , to 1.5 % of gdp .
until then , african heads of state have pledged to raise science and technology budgets by at least 1 % of gdp by 2025 .
a few countries – including kenya , rwanda , and senegal – are working to reach this funding threshold .
africa also benefits from generous research assistance and international support .
one of the largest donors and melinda gates foundation has invested more than $ 450 million in african science projects over the last decade .
these include a $ 3.06 million plan for crop yields and a $ 62.5 million improvement in health improvements .
these and other funding flows help african researchers develop drought-resistant crops , producing vaccines for infectious diseases like ebola , increasing opportunities for scientific and technological education .
unfortunately , many african governments lack the resources to fund programs that can build on these gains .
in short , african science urgently needs new and more cooperative solutions .
african leaders have pooled their scientific resources .
in 2003 , the african union and africa ’ s new partnership for cooperation began to implement an inter-continental strategy “ to develop and use science and technology to transform africa ’ s socioeconomic transformation and integrate its integration into the world economy . ”
this is a grand goal , and it has produced early results .
in 2005 , africa ’ s r & d spending grew , and research output in many countries doubled .
since then , however , progress has stalled .
the recent conference in rwanda , hosted by the organization of rwanda and the organization of one of einstein , aims to help the agenda back on track .
but the summit is only part of the solution ; governments must also work to improve the quality of research , which they can begin to focus on three key areas .
first , african leaders must work with ceos , philanthropists , and donors who understand the long-term value of scientific investment .
innovation is expensive , requiring seed funds to help strengthen african science ’ s capacity .
second , african universities and institutions should align their research agendas with national and regional goals .
africa ’ s most pressing challenge , for example , is to feed a growing population , focusing on schools in agriculture research that should ensure that their work can help them .
third , countries should encourage entrepreneurship within research organizations .
one way to do that is to establish commercialization offices , and the commercialization office helps scientists ’ research to work .
as national scientists turn their ideas into business projects , they need help to deal with bureaucracy , which is particularly challenging in the area of research and development .
increasing african science ’ s power will require african leaders not only to pose acute questions at summits ; they must also allocate more funds to build new partnerships .
the high cost of african food monopolies
lagos – in may , global food prices rose 1.2 % , reaching the highest level since october 2017 .
this surge is having a huge impact on africa , and the share of household spending on food is soaring .
to ensure food security , governments must act quickly to reverse these trends , and a starting point is to reduce the producers ’ producers .
according to the world economic forum ’ s data , four of the top five countries in the world are in africa .
nigeria ’ s list is the highest , with household income in 2015 , in 2015 , on food , followed by kenya ( % % ) , cameroon ( 45.6 % ) , and algeria ( 4.8 % ) .
by comparison , consumer spending in the us is a global minimum ( 6.4 % ) , far below emerging economies like brazil ( 16 % ) and india ( 30 % ) .
one reason for this distortion is food prices relative to income .
as africa becomes increasingly urbanized , people are buying more imported and 或全 foods , which are more expensive than locally produced foods .
and in most countries , wages keep pace with inflation .
but the main reason is poor public policy : african governments have failed to rein in the power of agribusiness and big food manufacturers , and lack oversight of local agricultural competitiveness .
most commodity prices , in turn , are 节节上涨 .
the absence of antitrust law , together with inadequate consumer protection , has led to a market for large companies in many countries controlling salt , sugar , flour , milk , oil , and tea .
the impact of african cities is most acute , and the prices of 白米 , frozen chicken , bread , butter , eggs , and even even 碳酸 drinks are 24 % higher than the rest of the world .
these prices directly affect consumers ( via input costs for food production and service providers ) .
the food and agriculture organization of the united nations ( fao ) has long emphasized that food security and equity prices depend on the market .
the oecd countries frequently require the authorities to address the “ anti-competitive mergers , abuse of dominance , cartels and price fixing , vertical constraints , and practices ” issues of the oecd .
but , in many african countries , this advice has rarely been heeded .
to be sure , this is not new .
for example , between 1997 and 2004 , the fao launched 122 “ anti-competitive activities ” in 23 sub-saharan african countries , which included “ vertical monopolies ” from malawi ’ s sugar industry , price fixed price fixed in the kenya industry , and “ buyer cartels ” in zimbabwe ’ s cotton industry .
and , despite the wide attention that these cases have received , its fundamental problems remain undiminished .
according to the world bank , more than 70 % of african countries are ranked in the rankings of “ market-based competition ” in global protection .
the 27 african countries and five regions already have antitrust laws , but there is little enforcement .
other countries simply do not have antitrust rules , and even drafted work in a few countries .
south africa is a notable exception .
since 1998 , south africa ’ s competition law has banned any company by excluding other firms or seeking to manipulate price controls , or more than 45 % of the price .
the fine of 10 % of the fine is fine , and some of south africa ’ s corporate giants , such as Brands brands , Pioneer foods , and 森达美 Darby , have been penalized .
特姆 博纳科勒 , the chairman of south africa ’ s competition commission , noted last year that the government “ is determined to prevent the exploitation of consumers in cartels , ” particularly in the food sector .
other countries should follow south africa ’ s example .
in countries like nigeria and ghana , where reforms are needed most , the share of food spending is high and food security is highest .
fortunately , a growing number of people are beginning to recognize these challenges .
the general 巴巴 吞德 , director of the nigerian consumer protection committee , recently suggested that , “ there is a tragic absence of broad competition in a large and loyal market like nigeria .
unregulated markets in competition environments have become the ‘ legal tender of financial and social extortion . ”
by dealing with anti-competitive practices in these sectors , or by reforming regulatory regulations to prevent competition , they would reduce the cost of 主粮 , even by 10 % ( far below the average premium demanded by the global cartel ) , which will enable more than 270,000 people , 200,000 people , and 20,000 in the world .
this policy would save households in these countries more than $ 700 million per year ( in 2015 ) , with poor households far more benefiting than wealthy households .
ultimately , it is political leaders ’ responsibility to protect consumers from collusion and prices .
no doubt , the cycle needs to be achieved through innovation , but their success must not be at the cost of some next meal .
the cancer threat to africa ’ s future
chicago – one of the most urgent public-health challenges in africa today is the coverage of the lowest : cancer , the leading cause of death worldwide .
every year , roughly 650,000 africans are diagnosed with cancer , and more than 500,000 people die from this disease .
over the next five years , africa could have more than one million cancer deaths every year , and mortality rates will cause cancer to become the continent ’ s leading killer of killer diseases .
throughout sub-saharan africa , tremendous progress has been made in combating deadly infectious diseases .
in recent decades , international and local cooperation has succeeded in reducing malaria deaths in africa by 60 % , nearly eradicated polio , and extending the lives of millions of africans infected with hiv/aids .
unfortunately , there has been no similar progress in the fight against non-communicable diseases , including cancer .
today , cancer kills more people in developing countries than aids , malaria , and tuberculosis combined .
but , because africa receives only 5 % of global cancer prevention and control of funding , efforts to contain cancer have little to do with this epidemic .
just as the world has helped to help africa contain epidemics , a similar approach must be taken to contain the cancer crisis .
the survival of cancer patients requires many things , but there is a time when experts , laboratories , and replacements are the most basic .
but , in most parts of africa , cheap medicines , trained doctors , and nurses , which mean that patients rarely receive the care they need .
on average , african countries have fewer than one trained 病理学家 , meaning that most people can ’ t receive accurate diagnostic services during the cancer .
according to Olopade Olopade , the university of chicago , cancer diagnosis in africa is “ almost always fatal . ”
building health-care systems that can manage infectious diseases , while also providing quality cancer care , will require significant investment in time , money , and expertise .
fortunately , africa has a good start .
past programs – such as the prevention of hiv/aids , tuberculosis , and malaria , the us president ’ s emergency relief program , and the world bank ’ s east african public health lab – have greatly expanded the continent ’ s health-care infrastructure .
african countries are also strengthening pharmaceutical supply chains , improving health-care training , and improving the quality of diagnostic networks .
but africans still face no such threat alone .
my organization ’ s clinical pathology in the united states is thus working with other global health-care innovations to contain the spread of cancer crises in africa .
we have worked with the us cancer association ( acs ) and pharmaceutical pharmaceutical novartis to support cancer treatment and detection efforts in four countries , including ethiopia , rwanda , tanzania , and uganda .
the american cancer association also training african professionals how to proceed and chemotherapy , to complement the technical work mentioned above .
the program funded by novartis was viewed as a kind of 试点工作 to the rest of the region .
finally , my organization is advocating guiding principles for cancer treatment in national health care programs , and we believe that such provisions are essential to improving the effects of health outcomes .
these provisions , combined with the american cancer association , are combining the availability of cancer to expand access to cancer treatment .
when the world recognized infectious diseases such as hiv/aids , polio , and malaria , we have developed an action plan and a positive action plan .
today , a similar global effort must be made to ensure that every african who is diagnosed with cancer receives the treatment that africans need .
now , as then , cooperation between african governments , health-care providers , drug companies , and non-governmental organizations has shaped the success of cancer .
none of the earth ’ s places on cancer diagnosis is fraught with fear ; and , wherever the patient gets it , catastrophic consequences for recipients and their families are catastrophic .
but geography should never be a decisive factor in the fight against cancer .
cancer has been africa ’ s silent killer for too long , and the global health community is no longer quiet .

if women are able to enter the job market , active business or political decisions can change , patriarchal dynamics will change , and women ’ s social standing is in place .
in other words , allowing more women to enter the workplace would lead to emancipation – whether for men or women .

networks exist .

capitalizing on africa ’ s youth dividend
toronto – in 2016 , south africa ’ s university students took part in the streets , a part of the campaign that “ must fall ” campaign , when “ the decolonization of the curriculum ” was one of the central preoccupations of the movement .
the movement is also a historical turning point in south africa , where young people are starting to demand high-quality education .
but the key question missing from the debate about tuition and curricula is that higher education has enabled young african youth to win power , driving the continent ’ s economic transformation ?
for africa , students are not “ right ” issues , but “ what ” questions are learned .
unfortunately , while access to education has improved significantly in recent decades , school curricula have not changed much more than the colonial era . in colonial times , secondary education was an elite privilege that was designed for a small minority of people .
education and vocational education ( tvet ) and training ( tvet ) are also lost .
today , these programs are outdated , learning methods that are not available to young people to accommodate the twenty-first-century employment market .
the problem is not just the traditional content of curricula , such as mathematics , science , and language , but also the lack of important “ soft ” skills , such as communication , teamwork , and problem-solving .
despite these skills , they can make young people resilient and lifelong learners .
there is a correlation between soft skills and improvements in school , work , and life outcomes .
but , until recently , training for soft skills remains in africa ’ s formal education system .
fortunately , things are changing .
across africa , secondary schools , secondary schools , and tvet systems are being transformed to equip africa ’ s young minds with the skills needed to make the transition to workers and participation more likely .
in particular , these changes imply more opportunities for young people to enter the job market when preparing to enter the job market .
but to succeed , young people must have the skills and education that modern economies require .
in the mastercard foundation , i oversee education and learning programs , and we have developed a blueprint – called the mass skills – to help african educators achieve their youth ’ economic potential more effectively .
now , one of the most successful projects that africa is implementing is the livelihood 计划 of the us international development agency ( edc ) , which is developed by boston ’ s education center .
akazi kanoze highlights how a small program can lead to large-scale education reform by emphasizing local employers that provide access to entry-level jobs , internships , and apprenticeships .
its focus on personal development , 人际沟通 , and leadership training ensured that students are fully prepared to enter the labor market .
rwanda ’ s ministry of education is poised to integrate the program ’ s drugs into national TVWT projects .
the government in rwanda recently incorporated akazi kanoze ’ s approach to the national 课程体系 initiative to enable secondary and tvet students to have the soft skills needed to succeed .
the 2018 academic year will also reflect a new 基于 curriculum .
since 2009 , akazi kanoze training has trained more than 13,000 young people , with 65 % of the initial training participants having found jobs after the graduation of the first six months .
based on the success of integrating soft skills into the curriculum in rwanda , the mastercard foundation and edc will launch a similar plan later this year .
examples of the massive skills study highlight six components of successful training programs .
they include a favorable policy environment ( supported by the government ’ s support for the independence of the country and set a clear goal for reforming the education sector ) , the broad participation of stakeholders , and the ability to measure the effects of change on youth employment and entrepreneurship .
change is not without challenges .
adapting models for skills training in africa will take time to adjust to african systems of education .
ensuring that intensive training patterns reach all young people , including those who are no longer in school , will be difficult .
as rwanda ’ s experience shows , curriculum redesign requires close cooperation with education and labor authorities , as well as government officials , teachers , and schools .
new 课程内容 also requires developing new teaching and learning materials .
achieving scale will also require a radically different approach to training teachers ’ current approaches to training teachers .
training must go beyond traditional , one-off approaches , and continuing to provide teacher support .
new 教学法 also requires monitoring and practice , especially in early stages .
the old “ cascade ” model of teacher training has been completely ineffective .
with the help of the international community , african governments can help students shift from school to jobs by emphasizing the importance of soft skills .
if so , these changes would ensure that young people drive africa ’ s future prosperity .
africans deserve a forward-looking education system , not one that is stuck in the past .
the country ’ s young students have demonstrated that only this will enable young africans to meet their lives last year .
the big bond in africa
lagos – the countries of sub-saharan africa have reached a critical juncture .
with the collapse of commodity prices and the slowdown in china , the region ’ s growth rate fell to 3.4 % in 2015 – nearly 50 % below the previous 15 years .
sustained economic growth is vital to sustain progress on reducing poverty , infant mortality , disease , and malnutrition .
maintaining economic growth is the only way to create enough good jobs for ballooning young populations – the world ’ s youngest population growth rate .
as the german minister of development general , general stuart mill , pointed out at a recent press conference , “ if young people in africa fail to find jobs and future in their country , millions of people , not tens of thousands or hundreds of thousands , will find out to be in europe . ”
one way to maintain growth , create jobs , is to project and implement large-scale investment in infrastructure across africa .
public infrastructure is particularly important .
they include highways , bridges , and railways , connecting landlocked farmers to african urban consumers and the external market ; including massive transport and internet infrastructure , including mass transportation and internet access , which would include private financing plants and electricity grids .
many of sub-saharan africa ’ s small economies also need to connect with large regional projects .
this is the only way to create economies of scale , with the economy improving the potential for agricultural and industrial exports in africa , as well as the need to reduce domestic prices for food and manufactured goods .
while african governments are spending on their own public infrastructure spending , they still need external financing , especially for regional projects that are rarely top of national governments .
but the traditional generous donors , including the us and europe , are now prepared to curtail aid by political and economic constraints .
but perhaps there is a way to help restore growth in africa , and the west ’ s leaders and their constituents accepted .
we call it “ big bonds ” – using foreign aid funds as international capital markets to raise financing for large-scale infrastructure investment .
specifically , donors can borrow in capital markets , according to future aid flows .
thus , they can use the current low interest rates to raise revenue .
the 30-year us treasury interest rate is about 3 % , and donors need only about $ 5 billion , which could raise $ 100 billion .
this money could come from a total of 3.5 billion official development assistance ( oda , roughly $ 50 billion ) per year .
donors can put interest costs on african countries to reduce their own fiscal burdens .
for african countries , conditions are better than the conditions provided by eurobonds .
indeed , while this may sound risky , passing on the cost of interest to recipient countries could actually strengthen their debt sustainability .
according to a study by the african development bank ’ s policy innovation lab , a 3 % interest rate would be lower than the marginal cost of commercial lending in some african countries over the last five years .
moreover , long maturities and grace periods relative to market finance will ease pressure on foreign-exchange reserves .
frontloading aid in this form is not new .
in the early 2000s , vaccines to finance this approach saved millions of lives in the developing world .
under management of the african development bank , the largest bond resources are available to finance large regional infrastructure projects that can not be ignored for long , such as connecting tanzania , rwanda , and burundi , and from nigeria to côte d ’ ivoire .
such projects can also work with private investors to finance them .
moreover , large bonds help to revive the relationship between donors and african countries .
moreover , because it supports investments that would yield important benefits at the national level , it could be an incentive for african countries to implement reforms that increase their absorptive capacity – such as the choice and implementation of public infrastructure investment .
the big bond approach represents a much-needed escalation of the oda framework – one that supports higher and more sustainable growth in recipient countries , while reducing the burden of donor countries .
now that aid is under political pressure , it may be a bold approach to maximizing efficiency in the world .
paris – in much of africa , transition from fossil fuels to cleaner forms of energy is viewed as an environmental imperative .
with fossil fuels accounting for most of the world ’ s energy – up to 70 % – africa ’ s situation is truly ecological .
but , economically , africa desperately needs energy transition .
africa ’ s oil subsidies are around $ 50 billion per year , amounting to about 1.5 % of gdp .
that money is enough to provide solar power to 300 million people .
if africa can rebalance its energy mix , phasing out hydrocarbons gradually , these subsidies will be available to other uses , producing environmental and economic benefits .
today , neither oil exporters nor importers are immune to shocks .
in 2015 , for example , oil prices fell rapidly , and oil spending in africa declined , while exporters suffered economically .
when the results rebounded , the relationship is the opposite , with energy exporters rising , while importing countries are struggling to sustain consumption .
this is a needless cycle .
integrating cleaner power into national energy systems would not only raise local capacity ; it would also unleash more hydrocarbons for exports .
the resulting revenue can be invested in new green power .
this transformation will require cooperation by the oil sector , which is likely to boost social progress .
the electrification of some of the greatest gains is the electrification of some of these areas , which , in the current distribution system , can be said to be alive .
today , only 30 % of africa has reliable electricity .
but an estimated ten terawatts , producing solar capacity in africa , could expand significantly .
indeed , according to some estimates , solar power generation can increase 15 gigawatts by 2030 .
fossil fuels can not be phased out anytime soon , but if solar energy ’ s share in the energy mix increased significantly , the huge economic advantages that africa will bring , especially in agriculture , are the most important economic sectors .
the electrification of agricultural areas can facilitate the storage and transport of crops , improve food security , and boost farmers ’ income capacity .
in the process of rebalancing the energy mix , africa has an important advantage relative to the advanced economies : africa is a clean slate .
the relatively small legacy of history is a major reason why green power has become africa ’ s best energy option .
while each country must balance its own energy needs , relying on renewable sources ( especially solar power ) , it is the most cost-effective strategy for promoting rapid economic development across africa .
the potential for this potential is the few photovoltaic power plants that are already operating in africa .
senegal ’ s Senergy solar power plant , for example , sells electricity for the electricity grid in senegal by 50 % .
similar solar solutions are being applied to telecommunications towers in africa .
the best way to accelerate the transition from hydrocarbons to greener energy is to use some of the country ’ s oil subsidies to renewables .
this would create stronger incentives to reduce fossil-fuel consumption while encouraging investment and growth in green-energy production .
moreover , for rural africa , such policies would help to lift communities out of darkness and build essential infrastructure needed to build other economic growth .
but while renewables are the key to africa ’ s long-term prosperity , africa ’ s transition to clean power should not be instantly rejected , either .
africa needs the oil industry ’ s experience to complete its energy transformation .
and , because fossil fuels remain part of africa ’ s energy mix , the oil industry must be encouraged to move toward cleaner .
this sounds like an impossible alliance .
but , as policymakers across the continent seek to ensure adequate supply of clean energy to ensure rapid , inclusive economic growth , and environmental sustainability , they may find that there is no alternative .
cooperation between new and new energy industries may be the only engine that can drive africa forward .
africa ’ s vaccination test
boston – in february in addis ababa , african health ministers signed a popular declaration that promises to treat immunization as the centerpiece of efforts to save african children from death and disease .
fulfilling this promise will not be easy .
immunization is not only a health issue , but also an economic challenge .
the case for vaccination is strong .
globally , some 2-3 million children die each year from vaccine-preventable and 600,000 adult deaths .
moreover , immunization is considered to be the most cost-effective public-health interventions for reducing child disease , death , and disability .
a recent study estimates that every dollar spent on vaccination could save $ 16 in preventive prevention costs .
given the importance of individuals to longer lives and healthier lives , the net return on investment in immunization is at 44 times higher than the cost .
and net returns exceed the cost of all vaccines .
progress has been made .
in 2014 , 86 % of children were immunized against diphtheria , tetanus , and pertussis , compared to less than 5 % in 1974 .
there is also a major breakthrough in the number and types of available vaccines .
but , globally , about 18.7 million infants still do not have routine immunization .
the problem , of course , is access .
detailed analysis of immunization in africa shows that there are significant differences between countries and countries .
more than 60 % of infants live in the ten countries : the drc ( drc ) , ethiopia , india , indonesia , iraq , nigeria , nigeria , pakistan , the philippines , uganda , and south africa .
routine immunization coverage in africa remains remarkably low ; indeed , it has remained stagnant in the last three years , owing to weak health systems and inadequate resources .
as a result , one in five children in africa still lack access to life-saving vaccines .
in 2014 , some 42 % of the world ’ s measles deaths occurred in africa .
most of africa ’ s poor children live in nigeria , ethiopia , the drc , south africa , ethiopia , and guinea .
poor people , rural populations , and low levels of education comprise much of the country ’ s lack of immunization coverage .
clearly , money is the primary factor shaping immunization outcomes .
beyond funding constraints , weak and inefficient health systems ( especially in rural areas ) , african countries face the challenge of becoming more expensive new vaccines .
but médecins sans frontières estimates that the introduction of new vaccines caused most african countries to vaccinate a child in 2014 , and 68 times higher than in 2001 .
another study showed that the total cost of less than one dollar in 2001 was less than $ 1 .
in 2014 , the number of vaccines recommended by the who increased to 11 – and cost about $ 21 per boys , about $ 35 for girls .
today , the additional costs of fighting vaccines – roughly $ 25 per child – have cost a child with a total of $ 50-60 per child .
the same study showed that , in many low- and middle-income countries , immunization budgets are currently inadequate to sustain vaccination programs , not to mention the new expensive vaccines .
in some countries , health ministers in addis ababa argued that high vaccine prices force poor governments to make difficult choices about what deadly diseases they need to prevent .
for some countries , the situation is likely to worsen further , and gavi , the international organization for the massive global expansion that supports new vaccines , has gradually withdrawn support from countries that believe that they have “ graduated ” from aid .
many countries that lost the prices of gavi may not be able to take the new vaccine .
in response to this challenge , african political leaders have pledged to invest in developing africa ’ s capacity to develop and produce their own vaccines .
this long-term strategy requires coordinated regional investment planning , market development , and stronger regulatory capabilities .
in the short and medium term , african countries would best look to collective bargaining power to secure better contracts for the required vaccines .
africa can and should do more to improve vaccines , but the global community also has a responsibility to work together to reduce the cost of vaccines .
the recent announcement of lower prices for pneumococcal vaccines is a step in the right direction , but it is not enough .
without collective action , equality , equality , and continued access to africa will remain a major problem – and children ’ s lives will continue to lose .

africa ’ s unsustainable economy
dakar – the world ’ s economic downturn and financial-market tremors have strained national budgets in africa .
in addition to ghana and a few other countries , the most african countries in 2009 have deteriorated .
but , thanks to prudent management of public finances for public finances prior to previous periods of robust growth , a substantial number of african countries have been in the midst of crises in the past .
in 2009 , africa ’ s total gdp growth averaged 1.6 % , compared to 5.7 % from 2002 to 2008 , but still growth .
and , despite the serious challenges facing the financial crisis , some african countries continue to advance long-term reforms that improve the environment for business and investment .
current international trade and global industrial production are gradually improving , and sub-saharan africa ’ s sub-saharan african countries seem to grow stronger as demand for oil and other minerals rebounded and prices rebound .
but the continent ’ s most intractable structural imbalance is the two-tier nature of its economic and financial structure .
frankly , two africa is rising : an african economy that is modern , and is based on cash .
in african countries , almost every government will be able to modernize the economy as the bedrock of prosperity and its effectiveness in power efficiency , which many countries boast of their own financial infrastructure , underpinned by a set of laws , regulations , accounting , accounting , payments , payments , and settlement systems .
national payment systems have introduced a series of electronic payment products and services .
a 极高 system of interbank money is conducted in real time to settle the credit risks , risk credit between institutional participants , and accelerate the implementation of monetary policy .
the system provides the tools for banks to implement regulatory positions , thereby encouraging them to make investment decisions that would meet cost-benefit principles .
so far , only a few registered financial institutions , such as commercial banks in the west , have access to such facilities .
non-bank financial institutions , such as 外汇局 , post post offices , and microcredit institutions , have not entered even financially sound , sustainable development capacity .
the exclusive agreement that banks and remittance companies , such as the western union and western union , signed with most african countries exacerbates the country ’ s national payment system , as well as the effects of modern economic services .
such agreements exclude non-bank institutions from the lucrative market for migrant remittances in africa , which has been an important engine of economic growth in africa .
but rapid urbanization across africa has created a dynamic informal sector that is unrelated to modern economies .
while african officials are marginalized , this cash-based economy remains a major contributor to the continent ’ s productive productivity .
this sector employs more than 90 % of the labor and 75 % of the retailers .
but , despite the critical economic role that the informal sector plays , it still lacks access to traditional bank loans .
micro-finance institutions provide the only credit lines open to informal operators .
a collective guarantee loan is the 惯用 business model , which translates into a network of networks and support mechanisms that mitigate credit risk and encourage precautionary discipline .
management of high-quality microfinance institutions ’ credit repayments is at around 95 % , and all the studies involved show that women are not just the most active entrepreneurs of the informal economy , but also their promises .
african countries must now recognize that modernizing the informal sector and integrating the modern economy into an important development tool can be an important development tool .
nigeria has refused to obtain exclusive agreements with western union and other businesses , and the country ’ s newly consolidated banking sector has been progressing rapidly in the region .
rwanda has already adopted regulations that eliminate exclusive agreements , opening doors to microfinance institutions , and join them in the ranks of service providers .
south africa ’ s reserve bank has created a special platform for microfinance and non-banks within the country ’ s national payment system .
malawi ’ s national payment system is directly open to non-bank participants , including third-party service providers .
allowing micro-finance institutions to use national and regional payments systems and electronic retail facilities will help to meet the needs of the retail and business sectors .
this would also help the poor to use financial services , thereby reducing the proportion of the population that does not use it .
all of this will always promote the development and integration of national financial systems and intra-regional trade .
such developments are welcome , because a large proportion of intra-regional trade comes from informal operators and small and medium-size enterprises that do not have access to banking systems .
moreover , economic integration and increased regional trade are the best entry points for all countries in global markets .
when it comes to analyzing africa ’ s problems , people are accustomed to 历数 the continent ’ s traumatic past .
but the pains of africa ’ s colonial era to spend huge sums on the country ’ s most advanced settlements , and then ban their own citizens from exploiting them , seem to be beyond people ’ s imagination .
the economic corollary is that prosperity can come only from an economically functioning economy .
africa ’ s hard landing
lagos – in the developed world , there is no infrastructure service that is more widely accessible and more widely understood .
for consumers in the industrialized world , unchecked electricity supply is a no-brainer .
but this is not the case in africa , where a few parts of the world are the world ’ s electricity , with only 20 % of the population supplying electricity .
according to the international monetary fund ’ s recent economic outlook for sub-saharan africa , only two-thirds of the region ’ s countries were experiencing extreme energy crises in 2007 , and have shown a persistent energy boom .
there is no shortage of hydropower plants in africa .
many of these plants , however , are unable to keep up with rapid population growth and the resulting increase in demand .
moreover , these power plants are affected by frequent drought , which reduces electricity production dramatically , making many power plants a 点缀 .
growing populations in countries like nigeria and ghana mean more water use for electricity generation .
agricultural activity has been expanding rapidly , with higher demand for water across the continent .
other resources , such as fuel , diesel , light crude , solar , and gas , can also be used for electricity generation , but their costs are too high to supply .
these factors make it possible to use coal as an alternative source of cheap power in africa .
coal has historically played a key role in the world ’ s energy resources , and there are several important advantages to other fossil fuels .
for starters , the availability of proven coal reserves worldwide is roughly 850 billion tons .
africa has roughly 500 billion tons .
coal is more widely distributed than any other fossil fuel .
since 1980 , global energy demand has increased by more than 50 % , and is expected to increase by 1.6 % between now and 2030 .
more than 70 % of this new demand will come from developing countries , which are projected to account for about 80 % of total energy demand at the end of this period .
coal is the world ’ s fastest-growing fossil fuel , with annual production increasing by 6.4 % since 2004 .
in some important energy countries , coal has become a source of power .
strategically important developing countries such as china and india will be a major country in future coal generation .
in 2006 alone , china added roughly a million megawatts of coal production , and this trend is expected to continue with china ’ s efforts to meet its huge energy needs .
even in many advanced countries , coal still accounts for a large share of electricity generation .
more than half of america ’ s electricity supply comes from coal-fired power plants .
denmark has some of the world ’ s most efficient coal-fired power plants , and its coal generation accounts for 半壁河山 .
the same is true of germany , which has some of europe ’ s most efficient coal plants .
poland uses coal for 98 % of electricity production , while south africa is about half .
this is why , in this context , especially given that modern technology can help clean up in clean fashion , it is difficult to expect developing countries to develop their abundant 煤炭资源 to provide electricity to their own development .
with coal reserves , gas prices are volatile and gas prices are volatile , and long-term trends are uncertain .
by comparison , coal prices are more stable and likely for a long time .
beyond electricity generation , coal is also widely used for several other industries .
it is a key component of steel and cement production .
moreover , africa ’ s growing use of timber is causing rapid deforestation in many countries .
the potential demand for 煤饼 is huge , replacing wood for cooking , home , and industrial heating .
as a result , the demand outlook for the coal industry has been expected to create huge investment opportunities .
it is clear that the use of coal as a energy source would have environmental degradation , and it can not be ignored .
despite massive storage , coal remains a finite resource .
it is therefore essential to extract coal more efficiently and take care of the environmental impact .
fortunately , today ’ s by-products of the use of coal and coal is more concerned .
with acid rain and other public health hazards linked to coal combustion , more technologies are emerging to reduce harmful emissions from power plants .
in the last few years , it has been driven by a growing cleaner , more efficient coal-fired power plant , and , especially in advanced countries , the technology is disappearing .
developing countries lag behind this process , but , as global warming threatens , the pressure to adopt policy policies is now increasing .
africa ’ s resource-rich countries must use their abundant natural resources .
they must use coal to advance economic development .
today , african countries must use all available resources to escape poverty , or they will lose .

remittances have long spurred inflation in many parts of africa .
a ugandan doctor working in norway , for example , cares little about the price of a beer in kampala .
compared to a local doctor , he is willing and able to pay more for services – and , of course , a home in uganda .
fewer remittances flowing into uganda mean fewer economic activity , or lower prices .
the financial collapse of the global financial meltdown is not controlled , but risk becoming a new generation of more lethal collapses . a new round of collapse will not destroy the virtual economy of the us trading business and 经纪 , but also the real economy of goods and services .
president barack obama ’ s current style is like that of the latter scenario , and he bet that massive government spending will support the real economy .
if his policy succeeds , the chances that africa will remain intact will grow .
even if obama fails , however , africa should escape the worst of the global crisis , and for good reason .
good reason is for africa ’ s self-reliance , and scholars and policymakers are increasingly aware of the region ’ s trade , especially in africa , where the region ’ s urban-rural trade will eventually yield significant benefits .
another factor in africa ’ s favor is that private companies and consumers rarely rely on borrowed money .
people tend to pay cash to pay goods and services , wherever they are .
in the united states , loans to buy cars ( those who are now damned ) are the main factor behind the financial crisis .
and only a tiny minority in africa borrows to buy these things .
in the past , africa ’ s cash-based economy has impeded development .
after all , by allowing people to spend more than they can , borrowed money can fuel the economy .
but today , africa ’ s pay-as-you-go practices are a powerful guarantee against financial contagion .
as africa ’ s paradoxical economic situation is observed , another approach is to acknowledge that the region ’ s history has been marginalized by the global financial system , and that , at the time of the world ’ s richest countries , it has become a surprise .
lagos – the rise of africa is dangerous .
after years of annual economic growth , global uncertainty , low commodity prices , and unfavorable external conditions threaten to undermine decades of much-needed progress .
ensuring the wealth and wellbeing of africa ’ s residents will not be easy ; but policymakers can do much to help africa to return to an upward trajectory .
first and foremost , policymakers must ensure that the funding needed to pursue sustainable development in an uncertain global environment is uncertain .
the world bank estimates that africa needs at least $ 93 billion per year in infrastructure funding alone .
the cost of climate-friendly sustainable infrastructure is higher .
but , as long as global growth continues to slow , africans can not count on developed countries to fulfill their commitments to help achieve the sdgs .
africa must rapidly develop its own resources , which will almost double the tax revenue .
across sub-saharan africa , tax revenues are less than one-fifth of gdp , compared to more than one-third in oecd countries .
this means that there is plenty of room for improvement .
from 1999 to 2004 , for example , ghana reformed its tax system , with tax revenues increased from 11 % to 22 % .
to be sure , such progress is difficult ; in nigeria , we have seen an opportunity to raise non-oil tax revenues , but it is difficult to grasp it .
another domestic resource is the roughly $ 380 billion held by the ten african countries .
policymakers should use this considerable amount of funding .
meanwhile , african countries must find ways to diversify their economies .
diversification requires investing in future investments , such as education and well-developed infrastructure ( communications , electricity , roads , rail , and waterways ) .
a model that can be emulated is many : dubai , singapore , thailand , malaysia , mexico , indonesia , and south korea all are admired by africa ’ s people .
dubai , for example , began to prepare for a future without oil .
the government has implemented a gradual transformation , transforming the economy into a service economy , providing the necessary infrastructure and incentives for financial services , tourism , health care , real estate , media , arts , and culture .
while neither south korea nor singapore can rely on natural resources , their example is also encouraging .
behind these countries ’ success is a relentless leader , both secular and moderate , or democratically elected politicians with a shared vision of a broad-based economy .
sub-saharan africa has the diverse growth paths that many of its pioneers lack : value-added agriculture and agriculture , mineral resources , petrochemical , durable , and consumer goods , tourism and entertainment , and emerging information technology .
with the necessary diversity of measures , policymakers must ensure that the economic growth they pursue creates jobs .
sadly , this is not necessarily the case .
much of the recent growth has benefited only a few people , excluding most people – especially young people and women .
from 2006 to 2013 , many of africa ’ s most important economies , including south africa , nigeria , ghana , tanzania , and rwanda , have increased .
as nigeria ’ s finance minister , i was already addressing some challenges .
we know that we need not only ensure that growth is needed , but also the quality of growth .
to this end , policymakers must ensure that growth is channeled toward sectors that create jobs , such as agriculture , manufacturing , and services .
matching skills to job opportunities is crucial .
roughly 70 % of africa ’ s population is less than 30 years old , and africa ’ s out-of-school children account for half of the world ’ s children .
bringing africa ’ s children to a basic reading , writing , and technical skills is a top priority .
poor health-care systems must also be strengthened in order to address endemic diseases that limit productivity , such as malaria , and to improve preparedness for infectious diseases .
the stakes are high .
the world bank estimates that the outbreak of the ebola epidemic has reduced the economies of sierra leone , guinea , and liberia by 16 % .
as the world economy is weak , african countries must develop trade in one another .
in 2013 , african goods and services accounted for just 16 % of intra-african trade or more than 3 % of world trade .
one problem is that most african countries produce a single commodity , with very little value-added .
policymakers must encourage greater specialization ; diversified goods and services can be added to the value of trade .
logistics is another obstacle to intra-african trade .
policymakers must improve the linkages between the state and reduce bureaucratic barriers and administrative costs , thereby facilitating cross-border transit .
for example , road transport tariffs in africa are estimated to be $ 0.13 per cubic meter , compared to the average of $ 0.05 for all developing countries .
the railway railway project , which ultimately connects mombasa in mombasa in mombasa , in kenya and kampala , provides a good illustration of the benefits that investment in transportation can provide .
the afdb estimates that it would double the volume of trade between the two countries , while lowering marginal costs by 30 % .
and , while these investments can not be made , policymakers must not forget that most of africa ’ s growth is due to good macroeconomic policies and sound economic management .
extending africa ’ s rise requires strengthening african economic fundamentals .
this means ensuring that prices in the economy are correct , beginning with the exchange rate .
some countries may need temporary controls to curb the outflow of destructive capital , but policymakers should aim for the market exchange rate and a sound plan to govern inflation , debt , foreign-exchange reserves , current accounts , and fiscal balance .
africa ’ s potential is enormous .
africa is well placed to build diversified economies based on low-carbon , sustainable infrastructure .
but policymakers can not assume that africa will continue to rise .
they must take the right steps to ensure that .
africa ’ s urban farmers
nairobi – when i recently met in nairobi , kenya ’ s capital , nairobi , i was surprised by the content of her phone call , and she was constantly asking her mother ’ s own home with a few hours from the capital .
as a nurse , you will hope to use farm farming to buy more land – and then get more .
while living in kenya ’ s capital is living in kenya ’ s capital , wangari is able to profit from cash crops in relatives every year .
the start was her nurse ’ s monthly wage of around $ 350 per month – but it was long before .
wangari is one of thousands of lives in kenya ’ s “ urban peasant ” – and hundreds of thousands of people in the continent – are raising their incomes by “ telemedicine ” farming .
a remote farm has thus strengthened national pride , while boosting pride in traditional diets by raising attention to some regions ’ vegetables .
“ the food of imported food and western-style food has been proliferating for too long in our country , ” wangari says , “ we are now fighting back and planting our own food . ”
after a long period of neglect of rural areas , leaders across the continent have become more important than farming , recognizing that educated people , even in the major cities , can play a role in agriculture .
in nigeria , former president olusegun obasanjo has a huge , 农场 farm , pursuing a series of policies to help absentee farmers succeed .
in uganda , vice president 吉尔伯特 坎尼 has routinely visited the country as well , promoting more valuable agricultural operations , such as milk production .
the most explicit political support for remote agriculture is in liberia , where agriculture in the small west suffered a major blow to the country ’ s population , which still depends on imported food to feed the population .
when president johnson-sirleaf realized that a well-educated people could contribute much to the agricultural revival , she launched the “ return of the ground ” activity in june 2008 , especially to encourage city dwellers to become agriculture .
one thing is certain : the long-range agriculture created by the elites and educated cities can not solve all of africa ’ s immediate food problems .
moreover , these telemedicine workers face unexpected problems .
because they are unable to check the ground , they are largely dependent on their own friends to care for the state of emergency , which , when i grew up in villages that grew up in the countryside this spring , my mother agreed to help me regularly , 浇水 , and administer .

while i grew up around wheat fields , my knowledge of farming is thin .
fertilizer and pesticides are more expensive than i think .

the key tool is mobile phones .
my hopes for success are my hopes , because i call my mother a call to her farm , and that i would not .
we even decided to use which pesticides and to hire a company to hire .
because these cities ’ appetite for urban dwellers and rural conditions is familiar , many have succeeded .
in fact , some urbanites do not need to worry about buying land or acquiring remote assistance , because some of the varieties of crops are available in their own homes .
james 麦姆锡 , a accountants , grows at home as a spare bedroom , and sold it to nearby hotels and supermarkets .
but most people living in african cities have a way to get land in rural areas , which is why liberia ’ s government has so clearly emphasized the expansion of agriculture .
in a new campaign initiated this summer , the official was the case : “ land is the only bank , invest in the bank . ”
in liberia , the main driver is to reduce imports of staples like rice and tomatoes .
and in a more affluent country , africa ’ s elites are driven by complex reasons that are intertwined with national pride and concerns about food shortages .
consider , for example , the 一系列 班达 banda 20 years ago in zambia , leading a fashion in a real local 菜 .
now , ordinary 卢萨卡 want to cook a similar bus in their own home , which requires a growing number of farmers to produce more precision , such as 南瓜 , “ 黑杰克 , ” and fresh 秋葵 .
similarly , in nairobi , a woman entrepreneur 名叫 金亚 is producing more nutritious 粗磨 and 小麦粉 小麦粉 .
