these activities are closely related to the expansion of agriculture , because these sellers tend to prefer nearby growers , even though they are increasingly 城里人 .
cultivating africa ’ s scientific talent
toronto – ten years ago , south african physicist neil turok made a bold prediction : the next einstein will come from africa .
it is a decade late , and it is time to think about whether the continent is closer to the next global genius .
that is certainly true .
by 2050 , 40 % of the world ’ s young people will be africans .
in terms of demographics alone , africa is set to produce 神童 in science and technology .
africans once led the world in science .
indeed , some of humanity ’ s greatest innovations – from vaccines to brain surgery – are pioneered by africans .
one of the oldest measurements of the most ancient measure of equipment so far has been devoted to people who lived in modern-day 瓦蒂尼 ( swaziland ) .
in other words , mathematics itself is an african invention .
for decades , many scientific and policy hubs – for example , the global champion of sustainable development , 卡莱斯 , and the environment activists and nobel laureates – supported the african scientific agenda .
as these visionaries are gone , africa needs a new set of think tanks to inspire a study of the ethical and common spirit of the future .
but how can we ensure that africa , for its part , supports , support , and nurtured innovative scientists that change the rules of the game ?
the missing factor is an african education system that supports research innovation – and , in the case of africa ’ s local – offers the training and support needed to provide the training and support that he or she needs .
across the continent , governments have become increasingly common in recognizing that science , technology , engineering , and mathematics are critical to economic growth and development .
yet many of africa ’ s young researchers have no choice but to go abroad and work abroad .
this can be changed , but only through concrete investments in homegrown talent .
this means rethinking the entire african education system .
three priorities must be addressed
first , african countries need to fix the knowledge pipeline .
this means investing in teacher training , improving learning outcomes , retention of girls in scientific engineering disciplines , providing support for universities in research and development , and in the 私营部门 实验室 实验室 .
second , africa needs indigenous knowledge creation .
this requires simultaneously promoting both basic and applied research and creating the necessary infrastructure for the spread of research .
this would include providing more funding to researchers and research institutions and to promote open-source knowledge sharing .
a third priority is to move knowledge into practice .
this may involve providing scientific information to the public and innovators , and to support public-private partnerships to experiment , demonstrate , and apply research , thereby creating jobs tailored to public problems .
the company is a good example , and it uses drones to deliver blood to remote areas of rwanda .
it is now being introduced in ghana after successfully deploying ghana .
it has saved hundreds of lives and demonstrated the potential of technology transfer that has massive influence .
the next einstein forum , spearheaded by the institute for mathematical sciences in africa , has been organized – and the idea of the tad foundation is partly supported by the mastercard foundation – showing that africa produces high scientific talent .
the forum is working to highlight africa ’ s innovators to highlight breakthrough discoveries and promote scientific cooperation on human development .
since selecting the first fellows in 2015 , the forum has promoted many young african researchers working to address the world ’ s toughest technological challenges .
at the forum ’ s current research team , 阿布迪 迪里 , a 平台 加尼 in kenya , has created a 贷款 loan platform that has recently been met with a 评为 of 非洲 传感器 , one of the country ’ s most recent innovators ; and , in the case of 南非 讷 , south africa ’ s 文 性健康 , he has been a patent device for detecting 再生能源 性健康 .
in many complex problems today , africa needs an innovative education and research model .
but , as long as the next einstein forum and a similar program continue to build and address systemic problems such as the continent ’ s brightest young scientists , the academic head of the solution is likely to emerge in the next einstein prediction .
improving african women ’ s health through financial inclusion
accra – last october , the world health organization ’ s office in africa signed an agreement with the united nations international telecommunication union ( itu ) .
the goal of this seemingly impossible partnership is to encourage the use of digital services to “ save lives , improve people ’ s health . ”
but perhaps the agreement ’ s most innovative part is that it promises to integrate financial inclusion strategies with modern health services .
financial inclusion is an effective way to verify the health of people ’ s health , especially for women in developing countries .
women who can easily access bank accounts or cash payment options tend to invest more in their businesses and households .
in turn , they live healthier , more satisfying .
but , as is often the case , initiatives like the agreement signed in october tend to focus on one – electronic health ( such as 保险 ) or financial products like insurance .
the ability of africans to make money and save more than they would have had a good health care or no chance of dying , so it is an opportunity to help patients and build more resilient societies .
the stakes for africa ’ s women are particularly high .
in nigeria , for example , 400,000 women are suffering from 产瘘 , a disabling condition of childbirth .
in tanzania , around 8,000 women die each year from pregnancy or childbirth ; most are avoidable .
and , for all africa , life expectancy for women is only 58 years , compared to more than 80 years in developed countries .
people are working hard to link women ’ s health solutions with financial inclusion and are making progress .
at a recent conference in dar es salaam , experts from technology and financial-services industries joined investors , philanthropists , and development experts to develop ways to work for african women .
by a similar program , development experts can promote digital solutions as a means of social and financial empowerment .
unfortunately , the cooperation plan , signed in october , is the exception , not the exception .
banks , regulators , the financial sector , and telecommunications companies are all frequently discussed in general , but they have not included local and global health professionals .
this must change if we are to build more inclusive platforms for african patients and customers .
the first step is to recognize missed opportunities .
one big opportunity is to adopt a different approach to extending financial services and digitization to rural areas in africa .
meanwhile , community health workers ( chws ) are taking these areas to prevent , treat , and triage jobs .
combining these measures makes sense , because both programs rely heavily on trust .
through 网络 networks , chws can use financial products , such as mobile cash payment systems , to expand their access to electronic health services .
broadening digital disease management and access to health information to include financial wellbeing produces natural synergies .
some fear that increasing the burden of chws would drag down health-care quality , but a fragmented view of prosperity is worse .
in recognizing the opportunity to expand the opportunity , the rest of the world needs to be addressed before women ’ s health and financial inclusion programs are expanded .
first , the lack of a gender distinction makes it difficult to formulate policies based on health quality and financial needs .
although countries like burundi and senegal are working to improve the collection of specific gender data , broader , more coordinated initiatives are needed .
increased regional financial literacy is another challenge .
the ability to understand and execute personal financial affairs is the weakest link in transforming women ’ s opportunities through financial inclusion .
moreover , financial literacy is a prerequisite for the launch of financing programs – such as the support of small and 小微 enterprises – for women .
if it can increase the level of financial literacy , women receive resources like land and credit , which are crucial to business development , social mobility , and personal growth .
progress has been made in building a level playing field , but it must be sustained .
the agreement by the who and the itu would help to foster wealth creation in africa , which lacks access to health care and financial services .
to sustain this momentum , deeper commitments are needed , especially from the global health community .
but , regardless of how african governments advance their health and financial services , women need to be at the heart of their proposals .
closing the youth apathy gap
nairobi – when united nations member states adopted the sustainable development goals two years ago ( sdgs ) , they committed themselves to reducing “ the proportion of young people who are excluded from employment , education , and training . ”
unless the political participation of the young can grow significantly , that commitment is almost impossible .
young people are the key to progress .
as us president barack obama noted in his 2015 speech in nairobi , “ unless one country can rely on the talents of all people , it can not fulfill its full potential . ”
today , young people comprise a large share of these people – and , precisely , the 18 % of the world ’ s population .
in most developing countries , this ratio is even higher .
the median age of africa ’ s population is 19.5 .
from these data – not to mention rising educational attainment and literacy – young people can change the world , affecting political processes and electoral outcomes .
but that will require them to engage and be active .
in the united kingdom , most young people want to remain in the eu .
a lord Ashcroft survey showed that 73 % of those aged 18-24 , and 62 % of those aged 16-24 , voted for remain in the last year .
but most young british people have actually failed to exercise their voting rights , making the british older – mostly backed by brexit – winning victory .
in kenya ’ s presidential election last month , 51 % of registered voters were below the age of 35 .
despite the supreme court ’ s ouster of the results of the election and the removal of the results , a large number of young people may be tempted to vote again .
unfortunately , kenya is an exception to the rules .
political apathy among young people – as in the brexit referendum – remains pervasive worldwide .
in much of africa , for example , young people have become disillusioned with politics , believing that the winner will always be rich , they have driven their interests to sacrifice the interests of younger generations .
this sense of cosmopolitanism ( disempowerment ) may turn the youth bulge in the developing world into a youth curse – and potentially potentially serious consequences .
the arab spring uprisings led to violence and instability in most affected countries , driven largely by desperate young people demanding rights and opportunities .
to avoid such an outcome , young people must become part of national politics , enabling their own vision of the future .
as young kenyans repeatedly emphasized during the recent election campaign , “ the tables are not on the table . ”
so how can the political consciousness and participation of young people be raised ?
in kenya , government measures are focused on creating three institutions : the ministry of public services , youth , and gender affairs , youth entrepreneurship funds , and the national youth council .
although these institutions are not necessarily perfect , they can help to empower kenyan youth , contributing to high voter turnout last month .
but the most effective approach to closing the apathy gap is centered on projects led by young people themselves .
in nigeria , young people led the way to a “ beginning to run a ” campaign that drove nigeria to revise its constitution and reduce the minimum age of candidates .
their success inspired a global movement to support young people ’ s rights .
in kenya , the youth-led Jiactivate – the name and english , the name of “ activating you ” – aims to increase youth political participation by emphasizing the main issues affecting young people .
as the national 理事长 ’ s identity , our goal is to act as a platform to amplify young kenyans ’ voices and make it easier for them to act .
to inspire more such initiatives , efforts must be taken deliberately to support genuine political engagement with young people , rather than at the 表面文章 and 空喊 .
to this end , africa ’ s youth organization , which i am coordinator , is not only collaborating with local youth groups and community networks ; it also learned from a GeoPoll survey of 2,000 kenyan towns and rural youth .
the survey showed that 27 % of respondents never participated in politics , but 26 % attended political events and 34 % posted social media .
moreover , 68 % of respondents said that they would participate in political activity only if access to safe and trusted platforms can be secured .
from these data , we can conclude that , while social media have been contained during elections in many countries , it remains a powerful tool for facilitating youth participation in politics .
for example , by creatively using social media to collect , 整理 , and amplify young people ’ s priorities in the kenyan elections , it has raised their interest in politics .
nonetheless , many kenyans who were popular on social media have not had much impact on the election results .
translating social media ’ s energy into effective action in the real world remains a daunting challenge .
higher political participation in youth will require sustained efforts and hard work .
but this should not be a resistance , and it should be a powerful incentive to start action .
young people are the most affected by past , present , and future policies .
they must be at the table , not waiting for handouts .
toronto – a few years ago , when young people spoke with young people in some of senegal ’ s poorest communities , the two social entrepreneurs told me that they were projects that they were engaged in success .
one young man said that he plans to deliver more computers to primary schools ; another , in the city ’ s capital crunch , created a network of rural job seekers .
after having finished their plan , i told them that their parents were sure to be proud .
but instead of accepting praise , they are silent .
“ my parents object to me , ” they almost unanimously said , and then they explained to me that young people face a government job or use their english skills as a guide – rather than becoming entrepreneurs of risk .
for ambitious young africans , many obstacles will be needed to succeed .
with formal or informal work , the journey to work often is full of solitude .
many young people lack skills training , or even a favorable social environment to try new things .
this day ’ s experience in senegal reminds me of helping young people to find valuable jobs that can help africa ’ s development .
africa has the world ’ s largest population .
for the next 25 years , these young people will become the world ’ s labor force , with more than 1.1 billion working-age people .
some predict that ten million people will enter the african labor market every year over the next ten years , most of which are first-time job seekers .
if african countries promote employment growth and equip young people with skills skills , this youth bulge could bring rapid , inclusive , and sustainable economic growth to the continent .
in turn , millions of people may have an opportunity to escape poverty .
but africa can not achieve this future alone .
in the mastercard foundation , we believe that if africa is to reach its full potential , the gap between two key areas must be closed .
the first area is access to financial products and services .
according to the world bank , some two billion people around the world currently lack access to financial products and services .
in sub-saharan africa , only 34 % of adults have 银行户头 , making it difficult for people to save money money for a rainy weekend , for example , with crop failures or the need to save the school .
this must change , and africans should not only have better financial systems , but should also improve financial literacy .
the second key issue that must be addressed is exclusion from secondary and higher education .
although progress has been made in some regions , it has only about one-third of young people graduate from high school .
girls are particularly disadvantaged ; according to unesco , in sub-saharan africa , nine million girls under the age of 11 have never been subjected to school education , while only six million boys have never attended .
to address these problems , the mastercard foundation has established partnerships with local organizations aimed at designing education and financing programs that help young people find and retain jobs .
by building a more trained workforce , the mastercard foundation projects are helping to empower community members and leaders in the next generation , so that they can help their families , communities , and countries achieve a brighter and prosperous future .
as i have encountered in senegal , a new generation of educated and ethical entrepreneurs is emerging , reflecting the far-reaching goal of building a stronger africa .
for example , when i asked the young people who participated in our academic plan to do something , they almost invariably reply that , after finding new jobs , they want to help others , such as the return of secondary education to a young student .
some of our curriculum graduates have already established a community plan for hiv/aids in their villages , and others have been housed in orphans and children .
every smart african youth – the example of “ transformational leadership ” – is likely to drive change in their own countries and communities .
if we succeed , africa ’ s dreamers today will be a catalyst for positive change tomorrow .
africa ’ s defining challenge
addis ababa – africa has the youngest population in the world , and is growing fast .
by 2055 , the continent ’ s youth population ( 15-24 from 24 to 24 ) is expected to be more than quadrupling in 2015 .
but young people still face unfriendly political , economic , and social conditions across the continent .
whether african governments can address this problem will be the single most important determinant of prosperity or bust in the continent over the next few decades .
if it continues to pursue business as usual , africa will need to face not only economic weakness and brain drain , but also the rampant , political , and social turmoil that can erupt into conflict .
but if african governments act immediately to inspire the energy and dynamism of a new generation of young people , the continent will prosper .
we need a comprehensive policy agenda to take into account the relevant demographic factors , which address the exclusion and plight of young people in politics , culture , and economics .
achieving this will not be easy , especially given the huge age of youth and national leaders in africa , where the average age of the african presidency is 62 , while the median age of africa ’ s youth is 19.5 years .
this creates the biggest age of age between world rulers and the establishment , and has raised concerns about whether policymakers can understand the expectations and demand of young people .
many countries have traditionally made the difference in traditional , 老人 politics , which means that young people ’ s political participation and influence are subject to cultural factors .
to overcome this hurdle , african governments should address generational inequality by addressing the urgency of other unequal issues , accelerating the efforts of young people to implement quotas for young people , parliaments , and other policymaking bodies .
there is also much to be done about the economy .
according to the african development bank , 12 million young people joined african workers in 2015 , but only 3.1 million jobs were created .
this means that millions of young people are deprived of the economic benefits .
in the short term , it is almost impossible to create jobs to meet job demand and the employment needs of the vulnerable .
africa does not have large labor-intensive manufacturing sectors with large populations of young people .
but some initiatives can help .
for example , the YouthConnekt initiative , launched by the united nations development programme and the government of rwanda , encourages 政策 policies , such as the opportunity to finance them , to finance market needs in their countries .
but , given the dearth of opportunities at home , many young africans rely on immigration to secure social mobility .
but the ceo of a major business firm in sub-saharan africa recently complained that the working visa for africans is extremely difficult .
indeed , british citizens may be making work visas more easily than a ghanaian with equal skills .
without labor-market policies to expand vocational paths to young africans , the prospects for african economic integration planning for the african union ’ s agenda will be difficult to achieve .
so many africans prefer to risk drowning in the mediterranean , living in appalling detention centers in north africa , or 露宿 in europe , or to remain in africa ’ s case .
but , contrary to widespread recognition , young people are not alone in choosing migrants for economic reasons .
instead , they want opportunities for genuine self-improvement and freedom of self and lifestyle .
young people , i have been young , leave africa to europe .
in fact , the desire to achieve self-improvement through migration is a key component of human experience – no desert , sea , or artificial barrier .
as a result , any strategy that can not truly resolve the environment in which the environment is not being resolved is simply not working .
so far , africa seems to be sleepwalking into a future of lost opportunity and potentially extreme instability .
and africa ’ s international partners seem to focus on limiting migration from the continent , rather than focusing on the underlying causes of migration .
but there is reason for hope .
the european union summit , scheduled later this year , will focus on the continent ’ s young people .
likewise , the african union ’ s work theme in 2017 is “ through investment young people ” to “ drain africa ’ s demographic dividend . ”
one hopes that a growing awareness of the need for young people to create opportunities for young people can foster an effective and effective effort to eradicate the continent ’ s youth employment obstacles , and to replace the actions of young people simply through barriers to prevent young people from leaving .
to borrow martin luther king , africa is now facing an acute emergency .
too late , too late .
listening to africa ’ s future farmers
nairobi – africa is in a youth employment crisis .
by 2035 , africa needs about 3.5 billion new jobs , and its largest industrial sector could provide much of it .
but , so far , africa ’ s young people are leaving the farm to work in cities .
to fill africa ’ s unemployment gap , agricultural firms must find ways to recruit younger people .
the challenge is my research focus , which is part of a program working with young people , 研究 youth think tank , and the mastercard foundation .
in the latest report , we examined the experience of africa ’ s young agricultural experts .
we found that the best way to attract young people back to farms is to enable them to access and exploit emerging technologies .
many young people with whom we communicate say that their biggest barrier to farming is to learn the digital and technological skills needed to succeed in today ’ s agricultural market .
cloud computing , land sensors , and weather drones are changing food production , packaging , and distribution methods , as is the case with arable land and high-quality seeds .
so , if more young people are able to master digital skills , more people will find their uses in the field .
to understand the importance of technology to africa ’ s young farmers , consider the following land competition .
most farmland is acquired through legacy or communal distribution , and new distribution of farmland is often small , with less than a small amount of farmland .
to remain profitable , young farmers must produce more crops in less land , which requires innovation .
our research found that , in many cases , the best way for young farmers is already being developed among young people .
in kenya , for example , a 菜农 garden transformed her garden into a vertical farm to increase output .
today , she runs her own businesses to design , produce , and install similar structures .
another 受访者 developed a mobile app to help farmers connect with local seed and fertilizer suppliers .
unfortunately , these young people ’ s innovations rarely receive the necessary political and financial support to achieve survival and expansion .
many young agricultural innovators have great ideas , but they lack support .
our research suggests some strategies to achieve this outcome .
first , young people need places that communicate with innovative innovators .
recognizing this , policymakers and the private sector should work together to create incubation centers and creative hubs to help young people build , discuss , and engage with farms related to farms .
moreover , those pushing for new farm technologies should experience a place where young people gather , providing an opportunity to train their own experiences and tailor to audiences .
if the latest farm technologies and tools are to be sold to social media ( often in the same way ) , rural areas ’ absorption of these technologies and tools can not be increased .
then there is the need for financial products and services to help them convert their ideas into marketable businesses .
finally , countries must find ways to engage young people in the early stages of technological development .
as the experience of the kenyan 菜农 shows , young people are often the best way to deliver long-term tangible results .
last year , i was fortunate to show these findings at the global youth economic opportunity summit in washington , dc .
i spoke about the role young people play in africa ’ s economy , and to collect their views about the future of african agriculture .
this is an important first step toward putting young people on the table .
but much work is needed .
according to the united nations food and agriculture organization , the average age of african farmers is now around 60 , compared to less than 24 % in the age of 24 .
to breathe new blood into africa ’ s farms , the entire agricultural sector must innovate .
our research shows that the best way to achieve innovation is to cooperate more closely with those who benefit most from progress .
after assimilation
human migration is as old as our history , even if immigrants migrate to distant and unfamiliar places .
in the nineteenth century , millions of europeans traveled to the americas , especially the united states , for freedom and prosperity .
but today ’ s migration scale is unprecedented , and migration often crosses the massive cultural barrier – without a specific target .
africa ’ s 船民 african region is often unaware of what it wants : italy , germany , or britain .
even as immigrants in spain and france , like north africa and france , are aware of their own destination , their primary goal is to escape the desperation of domestic despair , rather than as a whole .
this modern form of migration creates many problems for host countries , even as europe ’ s most serious social problems , because no one knows how to deal with the resulting cultural clash .
once upon a time , north america , especially the united states , became a model of problem-solving .
they propose `` melting pot '' : different american culture made their own contributions , but most importantly , they do their best to accept reality .

part of the melting pot is fragmented .

israel and the us still have mechanisms to integrate new immigrants .
language is an important underlying factor , as well as the military , and the values embedded in the us constitution still represent a common social belief .
but such mechanisms are gradually weakening worldwide , and are almost non-existent in european countries .
the problem has become the greatest crisis in modern societies .
it is no longer possible to feel an implicit link , as felt by the past , which has led them to cling to other more primitive identities .
they reject assimilation , fear that the integration of culture is not only a new sense of belonging , but also the old identity .
what else is the alternative to assimilation ?
the so-called 沙拉 `` 沙拉 '' is not really a matter of choice , because it provides the glue that binds groups together .
all are separate from the start .

people in the public sphere are diverse , but they are consistent with shared values and even the same language , while people ’ s private life – a word to describe a bad thing – is a different phenomenon .
in theory , this is a second-best solution to the problem of migration , but , in practical terms , it is our best approach .
but that is no easy feat .
even if the common minimum of a common language is to be met , let alone establish a specific code of conduct for behavior .
as london ’ s residents , the london people ’ s acceptance of public transport in the shops and western indians , which have never asked me why the region is bangladesh or the chinese .

such a phenomenon is certainly more common in cities like london and new york than in smaller towns and even in english .

if this happens , there is an explosive picture of separatism , not an ancient group of groups , but rather a new immigration and the natives .
if we are forced to abandon the hope of assimilation , we must concentrate on creating the public environment that all will give and enjoy .
ideally , this public environment should continue to grow , because , after all , the cohesion of modern societies is the ultimate guarantee of civil liberties .

immunization independence
washington , dc – the first years of this century are the golden age of global health .
international donors – whether national governments , such as the national government , or new international financing programs , such as the global effort to fight aids , tuberculosis , and malaria – have invested billions of dollars in national control plans and health systems , saving millions of lives .
but today , some countries that have benefited from these programs face a new challenge : the gains that continue after external support is lost .
ultimately , donors ’ programs – and health assistance as a whole – are judged by this shift .
consider gavi , a vaccine alliance .
the gavi establishment was founded in 2000 by a major donors , international institutions , and the industry ’ s leaders , aimed at helping the world ’ s poorest countries to introduce new lifesaving vaccines and strengthen their immunization programs .
a country that per capita per capita income is at a certain level – currently $ 1,580 – can not afford gavi support .
of course , gavi does not cut off immediately .
support will be phased over for years .
in this transition period , the country will have to increase immunization programs dramatically and prepare for full self-reliance .
this approach has been implemented since 2000 , enabling gavi to concentrate resources on countries that need the most .
but now it faces a serious test : one-third of the countries that have been supporting the support of gavi , where gavi has expanded support , or have just completed the transition .
these countries , such as armenia , bhutan , honduras , vietnam , and vietnam , have the highest birth rates , such as india and nigeria .
the gavi model is being observed under the microscope .
can these countries continue to buy and expand the vaccines adopted by gavi support ?
equally important , will this work stick ?
should the government be cut off , will immunization be protected with other essential health services ?
can countries introduce them when new lifesaving vaccines are available ?
can they sustain and strengthen disease surveillance so that outbreaks of disease are detected and quickly controlled ?
or will fiscal pressures lead to vaccine shortages in some countries , declining vaccination coverage , and even worse , and , in the worst case , the vaccine has been discredited by the country ’ s hard-won progress in recent years ?
the answers to these problems are important not only for these countries themselves , but also for their neighbors , where their neighbors may be immune to backsliding .
after all , infectious diseases do not respect national boundaries .
the recent yellow fever epidemic in angola , for example , spread to a far poorer neighbor than its poorer neighbor , the democratic republic of congo .
the experience of countries with “ graduated ” from gavi aid also provides important lessons for other international health programs and their beneficiaries .
the stakes are high , and international institutions must do whatever they can to prepare for the “ life of gavi . ”
while immunization programs require only a relatively small share of health budgets , and with high economic returns , ensuring that the money needed is still required .
new resources can help countries overcome this challenge .
the “ 融资 : 者 , policymakers , and programs , ” provided the resources for estimating the cost of vaccination , assess the benefits of different financing resources , and develop procurement strategies , through information processes .
instead of specifying a practice , it provides relevant information and expert analysis .
countries can respond accordingly to their own environmental assessments , and to promote the right questions .
with gavi support , close to 580 million children have been vaccinated since 2000 , more than eight million future deaths .
this is impressive achievements that are worth celebrating .
but only when countries successfully navigated the transition from gavi support will they have confidence that future generations will receive the same health protection .

after the mdgs
cambridge – in 2000 , 189 countries accepted the united nations millennium declaration , which included a series of concrete initiatives called the millennium development goals ( mdgs ) .
these ambitious initiatives – from halving poverty and reducing maternal mortality to three-quarters of all children – should be completed by the end of 2015 .
as the deadline approaches , development experts are debating new issues : what happens next ?
almost certainly , the mdgs will not be realized until the end of 2015 , but there were significant successes in several areas .
for example , the goal of reducing extreme poverty by half ( measured by the number of people living on less than $ 1.25 per day ) is likely to be achieved ahead of schedule , with china ’ s significant growth contributing .
at the same time , there is no evidence that these successes are the result of the mdgs themselves .
china ’ s history of greatest poverty reduction has been followed by domestic policy , which was preceded by the millennium declaration and the mdgs .
needless to say , however , the mdgs were a public-relations victory , not to diminish their role .
like all worthwhile pr efforts , the mdgs helped raise awareness , attract attention , and mobilize action .
they have expanded global dialogue on development issues and determine the themes of dialogue .
indeed , the most obvious implication of the mdgs may be the flow of aid to poor countries .
charles 肯尼 and andy 萨姆纳 of the washington center for global development have shown that the mdgs not only stimulate aid flows , but also targeted aid flows to smaller , poorer countries , and more specific areas like education and public health .
aid , however , is not directly related to performance and effectiveness , and it is far more difficult to understand whether aid is achieved .
the mdgs include eight goals , 21 targets , and 60 indicators .
many critics pointed to these 数量化 targets and indicators to doubt that their direction and measures are wrong , leading to a shift away from other equally important areas .
but these complaints do not capture the point .
any specific and enforceable goal requires detecting the results , while setting clear targets is the best way to test the results .
but there is a core paradox that plagues the mdgs .
the millennium declaration was a compact between developed and poor countries .
poor countries pledged to rebalance their development efforts , and developed countries pledged to support them , technology , and market channels .
but , oddly , only the last one in eight goals is about “ global cooperation , ” whereby developed countries can and should do what they should .
even here , the mdgs have failed to set targets for financial aid or other advanced countries ’ assistance , which contrasts sharply with specific poverty-related targets for developing countries .
what is clear is that the internet ’ s use of the development program – institutions that report on the progress of the mdgs – is the internet ’ s use .

these considerations clearly provide the direction of the next mdgs .

the list goes on .
on immigration , we are all in the same boat , and that boat is leaky .

an agenda for resolving us-china conflict
new haven – there is a pressing question to address the conflict between the united states and china , where president donald trump ’ s upcoming presidential summit with president donald trump and president xi jinping will be at the top of the upcoming summit in buenos aires .
the alternative poses serious risks for both sides : escalating trade wars , cold war , and even a real war .
these risks can be avoided , but only if both leaders are willing to make a principled compromise .
there is no doubt that a serious conflict has existed .
contrary to the claims of the us , the problem is not the excessive bilateral trade deficit between the world ’ s two largest economies .
the main concern is the macroeconomic imbalances afflicting both countries : china saves too much , while the us saves too little .
in 2017 , the us had merchandise trade deficits with 102 countries , while china has trade surpluses with 169 countries in 2016 .
if only a portion of the multilateral imbalance between the deficit countries or surplus countries ’ multilateral imbalances is a part of the multilateral imbalance , the trade imbalance would be the only outcome .
for the us , this will lead to higher imports – similar to the role that it plays to consumers .
for china , this means increasing export penetration for other markets .
focusing attention on bilateral trade imbalances ignores the possibility of a classic struggle for codependency .
to be sure , china has long relied on the us as a major source of external demand for its export-oriented economy .
but the us also needs to import low-cost goods from china to keep its income limited ; the us also relies on china as the largest foreign purchasers of us treasuries to help balance its long-standing government budget deficit .
and , as the third-largest and fastest-growing export market in the us , china has become an increasingly important source of demand for us firms .
the codependency framework is important because it emphasizes joint resolution and compromise .
as in human relationships , economic dependence can undermine stability and lead to devastating consequences .
when one partner changes course , another sense of response to a 伙伴 partner is likely to be powerful .
at this stage , china has played a role in transforming its growth model from manufacturing to services , shifting from exports to internal consumption , and shifting from imported technology to indigenous innovation .
at the same time , china has shifted from surplus saving to saving absorption , which has left it less likely to lend to the us deficit partner .
unsettling americans feel threatened by their partners , because this partner is changing the relationship .
while trump ’ s actions on these threats are far more radical than his predecessors , there is no doubt that america ’ s bipartisan sentiment on china is now reaching a high degree .
according to a 爱 survey conducted in september 2018 , an 80 % of republicans – who have long been the largest proponent of free trade – believe that raising tariffs would be good for the us .
the most influential republicans , such as vice president mike pence and former treasury secretary henry paulson , have warned that a new cold war with china is possible , and the most influential democrats agree that china has abandoned its responsibilities as a global stakeholder .
in an era of ever-escalating threats and counter-threats , the need for compromise must not be ignored .
trump and xi ’ s upcoming meeting offer an opportunity to redefine the us-china conflict and become an opportunity for the world ’ s two major economies to confront .
four possible avenues are needed .
market access : a decade of tortuous negotiations , the us-china bilateral investment agreement ( bit ) is now facing a breakthrough .
both sides need concessions .
the bilateral investment agreement in the us would increase the ownership of foreign direct investment by multinational corporations by both countries , eliminating controversial joint-venture mechanisms in china , and the us has long insisted that such joint arrangements have become a mechanism for forced technology transfer .
the bilateral investment agreement will also expand ownership of china ’ s ownership of us assets – and thus to challenge anti-china regulations recently adopted by the us commission on foreign investment .
saving : both countries need to commit to responsible macroeconomic adjustments .
the us needs to save more , reversing the reckless and reversible trajectory of last year ’ s huge tax cuts .
rebuilding saving and non-tariff is the most effective strategy to reduce trade deficits with china or any other trading partner .
at the same time , china needs to save less , using the huge amounts of money it accumulated to build the country ’ s social safety net , which is essential to a consumer-led rebalancing .
cyber security : the digital area is a battleground for the information age , and us president barack obama and xi have clearly failed to mitigate the ongoing tensions between cyber espionage , hacking , and disruption in september 2015 .
dialogue : the two presidents met again after the earlier and at mar-a-lago mar-a-lago meeting , with no doubt being fortunate .
those gatherings follow more formal arrangements , such as strategic and economic dialogue .
but all of these efforts are not in the dark , but they lack substance .
a permanent secretariat working on key policy issues ( including data sharing , joint research , and public-private consultation ) will be a more productive step .
given the recent contentious developments between the us and china , it is difficult to see a meaningful breakthrough on both sides .
a substantial list of substance points to test any deal that trump and xi could achieve .
the world is watching .
the age of 不确定性
berlin – 2017 marks the 40th anniversary of the publication of john kenneth galbraith ’ s age of uncertainty .
forty years later , it is worth looking back and reminding us that our readers have much to do with uncertainty and his readers .
in 1977 , while galbraith was writing the book , the world was still reeling from the first opec oil-price shock , and no one knows that there will be no second shock ( later ) .
the us is facing a growth slowdown , accelerating inflation , and stagflation , which has raised questions about policymakers ’ competence and the adequacy of their models of economic models .
at the same time , efforts to rebuild the bretton woods international monetary system have failed , with a shadow over international trade and global growth prospects .
for all of these reasons , the global age of stability and predictability that is consistent with the third quarter of the twentieth century seemed to be sudden , with a period of heightened uncertainty .
in 1977 , that was the case .
but , judging from the 2017 perspective , the uncertainty of 1977 is almost enviable .
in 1977 , there was no president donald trump .
jimmy carter may not be the best president in american history , but he does not threaten to take action that makes the entire global system dangerous .
he did not turn his back on international responsibilities like nato and the world trade organization .
nor did carter declare war on the fed , or the fed board , which is sympathetic to his re-election , wants to sacrifice his re-election .
instead , he appointed paul volcker , a central pillar of monetary stability , for the fed board .
and while carter failed to balance the federal budget successfully , he did not have a mess .
it remains to be seen whether trump would levy tariffs on chinese goods , repeal the north american free trade agreement , and put the fed board on its own board .
it is possible to be confident that the bad catastrophe is possible .
who knows what will happen ?
by today ’ s standards , carter is the embodiment of predictability .
in 1977 , moreover , the prospects for european integration were rosy .
denmark , ireland , and the most prominent british european community have just joined the european community .
the european community attracts new members , not lose them .
moreover , in order to support the common market , the european community has just established the regional monetary system , and was named as a “ tunnel . ”
although this is far from perfect monetary system , there is a very positive character : countries can leave in difficult economic times and rejoin when the outlook revives .
by contrast , in 2017 , negotiations over brexit will continue to be a dark cloud over the european union .
how these talks will proceed , how long they will be , we can only speculate .
moreover , the main problems of brexit ’ s decision – whether other countries will follow suit and , indeed , the eu itself – are far from resolved .
at the same time , the european monetary edifice is still on ice .
the eurozone is neither enough to attract more members , nor is it flexible enough to give temporary concessions to distressed members ( that is , floating ) .
in 1977 , uncertainties stemming from the uncertainty of emerging markets were not in the air .
developing countries in latin america and east asia are growing , and they are increasingly dependent on the currency center ’ s foreign-currency loans .
china remains largely isolated from the debate .
and , even in the third world , developing countries are very small enough to drag down the global economy .
today ’ s situation is very different .
the situation in china , brazil , or turkey is not confined to china , brazil , or turkey .
on the contrary , these countries ’ circumstances will have the most significant impact on the world economy , as emerging markets have contributed to the bulk of global growth in recent years .
china has a corporate-debt problem , and the government ’ s commitment to adjusting its economic structure is uncertain .
turkey has a large current-account deficit , one erratic president , and an unstable geopolitical neighborhood .
and if political scandals can be exported , brazil will have a clear comparative advantage .
while the era of uncertainty is about how much it is in 1977 , it captured the thrust of the age .
but if galbraith wrote that book in 2017 , he might call the 1970s the era of certainty .
europe ’ s europe ?
/ – europe ’ s europe in the euro crisis is europe ’ s europe ?
during the euro crisis , the european union ’ s power seemed to be shifting to the national capitals , particularly berlin .
but , while germany ’ s 转内 , france , and the united kingdom ’ s 独立 , the great story of the united kingdom ’ s foreign policy is , in the great narrative of europe ’ s foreign policy .
in europe , this important step is not only in berlin , paris , or london , but also in stockholm or warsaw .
major foreign-policy issues on the european threshold - whether in egypt , belarus , or now syria – are welcome european initiatives , regardless of where they originate .
germany , whether in foreign policy or economically , can play a decisive leadership role in the eu .
for example , it joined poland , leading the eu to try to build a coordinated relationship with russia and extend to serbia .
but , on other issues , such as libya , germany has failed to use room for maneuver in the face of other eu member states .
so the answer today to henry kissinger ’ s famous question of who wants to talk to the european dialogue should not be german chancellor angela merkel .
moreover , germany seems to be a “ geo-economic power ” driven by demand for its export sector .
with its economic means , germany is gradually pursuing its european partners .
at the same time , france has suffered from the loss of power on economic issues in germany , which still plays a decisive role in foreign policy .
france has guided libya and tried to impose tougher sanctions on iran , just as it provides support for the un in côte d ’ ivoire .
but france ’ s unilateral approach often makes it hostile to its european partners .
in september , for example , french president nicolas sarkozy seized a common european position on the palestinian statehood vote .
in other words , even if france leads , it does not always use such constructive ways .
in addition to playing a decisive role in libya , the uk has become increasingly marginal in european foreign policymaking .
even before the european union summit in december 2011 , it vetoed the creation of a “ fiscal union ” proposed by eurozone countries , whose influence on key foreign policy in europe is gradually diminishing .
britain has supported the eu ’ s eastern enlargement , with closer ties with turkey and the development of africa , but has not launched any creative initiatives to support or change the eu debate .
on other issues , such as “ strategic partners ” – particularly for china and russia – the united kingdom is often a supporter .
the “ big three ” is increasingly pursuing their narrow national interests , and other eu member states are becoming leaders in important foreign-policy areas .
for example , sweden – the country ’ s 14th largest population among its member states , with 8 % of gdp – is far more influential under prime minister 赖因 bildt and foreign secretary carl bildt .
last year , its annual support for north africa increased by a million ( 欧元 million ) , a week after the revolution in tunisia , which suggested a european delegation to support democratic will , and the un ’ s early and strong supporters in supporting the libyan uprising .
poland , too , has become a foreign-policy leader .
prime minister donald tusk and foreign minister radek sikorski , in particular , have taken a proactive approach to russia ’ s strategy for russia , which has largely overcome disagreements with germany and is now working to develop a genuinely broad approach .
poland also led europe ’ s defense ( though it refuses to participate in military intervention in libya ) .
this reflects the strength of poland ’ s economy , which is expected to grow by more than 3 % in 2012 – faster than most of the eu .
germany may be paying more attention at times of crisis , but last year ’ s situation confirmed that the eu would have the greatest impact and influence when small countries joined the great powers .
for example , for iran ( except for greece ) , europe has a clear policy and coherent stance , such as the oil embargo .
thus , poland and sweden : europe needs your leadership .
but it is not enough for a more than 500 million citizens .
the rest of the eu needs to make a real and influential case for europe ’ s foreign policy and influence .
a german glimmer in the global boom
in 2004 , the world economy grew at 5.1 % , the fastest in the last 28 years .
while this indicator has deteriorated slightly in the first three quarters of 2005 , it has increased again in the final quarter .
in 2005 , growth is expected to grow by about 4.3 % , and it is expected to grow in 2006 , which would be a period of rapid growth in the global economy unseen since the 1970 ’ s .
but this boom is not balanced .
in the united states , the number of experts on the status quo has declined . indeed , most people believe that the economic situation will worsen after six months .
the same is true of eastern europe , the ex-soviet states , and latin america .
surprisingly , europe , unlike in 2004 , looks like the rest of the world in the first half of 2004 .
growth in the 15 “ old ” eu members of the eu-15 in 2005 , though only 1.5 % , is expected to accelerate to 2.1 % in 2006 .
indeed , the economic performance of eu member states is huge .
italy is left behind , just 1.1 % , and irish rockets will not fall , and its real gdp will grow by about 4.8 % , on average , compared to smaller eu countries .
this is not surprising , because eu institutions have largely helped to overcome small vulnerabilities by giving small countries a large economic advantage , and these large economic advantages have been dominated by major powers .
but even germany , the eu ’ s largest economy , is rising .
according to monthly surveys by 70 companies , ifo ’ s german economic climate indicator jumped in the second half of 2005 , reaching the highest level since the year 2000 , the business community ’ s assessment of the current situation and expectations .
after five years of stagnation , the german economy has finally begun to recover .
it is a drive for economic recovery , which , as the world ’ s second-largest exporter , has benefited enormously from global prosperity .
exports grew by 6.2 % in 2005 , and are expected to reach 7.4 % in 2006 .
but , as we saw in 2004 and 2005 , exports will not be enough to create sustainable growth if domestic demand fails .
the good news for germany is that investment demand is growing .
the second half of 2005 was already good , and ifo expects investment in equipment to grow by 6 % in 2006 .
with years of contraction , investment in construction will grow slightly .
overall investment growth is expected to reach 2.9 % , which is weak in terms of past standards , but promising relief for the wounded german mood .
and , for germany , any investment growth is essential , according to the oecd ’ s latest statistics , which account for the world ’ s lowest share of national income .
even if germany lags behind the global economy , such investment demand will contribute to gdp growth .
that figure pales in comparison to most other countries .
indeed , all eu countries , except italy and the netherlands , will grow faster .
but everything is relative : germany ’ s trend growth rate is just 1.1 % , and has been the slowest growth in the eu since 1995 .
even germany , with its disappointing past , is now experiencing an economic boom .
germany ’ s unemployment rate has risen since 1970 , even as unemployment has declined slightly in 2006 , from 4.8 million to 4.7 million .
good economic data will underpin the good impressions of the new government , the volcker government , which helped to reach a compromise between the eu and the eu in 2007 ( which would add two billion to germany ’ s annual budget ) .
in fact , the government , by announcing strong measures to consolidate germany ’ s own public finances , may well contribute to good economic data , a prerequisite for investor confidence .
according to the government , a substantial tax increase would put the fiscal deficit below 3 % of gdp in europe ’ s stability and growth pact in 2007 , when germany has exceeded that limit .
the real test for the german government is the labor market .
most observers now believe that germany needs a similar tax deductible like the us .
in germany , this is called “ activating social aid ” or “ composite wages , ” but the principle is the same : the state should pay less money for the people who work .
in his inaugural address in the german bundestag , her government announced that her government would implement this system in 2006 .
if they act , and she really will have to reform the incentive structure of germany ’ s welfare state , the result would be higher employment and structural economic growth .
in the long run , this will be more promising for the eu and the global economy than in germany , which is currently driven by demand-driven growth .
will the old age be the norm ?
milan – the right-wing populism that has emerged in many western democracies in recent years may not just be a blip in the political landscape .
beyond the great recession and immigration crises that create fertile ground for populist parties , the aging of the west will continue to guide political power toward populists .
older voters have proved to be sympathetic to nationalist movements .
older britons who voted for brexit are higher than their share of the population , while older americans took the presidency to trump .
poland ’ s law and justice party , as well as fidesz fidesz in hungary , will not be in power without enthusiastic support from the elderly .
in italy , the league has largely succeeded in exploiting the discontent of northern italy ’ s elderly population .
among today ’ s populists , only marine le pen , the national front ( formerly the national front ) , is likely to rely on younger voters .
by next spring , this 年龄 voting model could affect the outcome of the european parliament .
a recent study points out that older europeans – especially those with less education – are more skeptical about europe ’ s same process than the younger generation .
this is surprising , given that memories of world war ii and its legacy are more well known for the older generations .
yet their suspicion of the eu ’ s democratic institutions may explain their embrace of authoritarian leaders .
most likely , growing insecurity is pushing the elderly into the arms of populists .
and , in addition to promises of each country ’ s respective features , nationalist parties have committed to containing global forces that have disproportionately affected the elderly .
older voters , for example , tend to have more fear of immigration , because they often rely more on traditional values and 自给自足 communities .
likewise , globalization and technological progress regularly hit traditional or legacy industries , which are more likely to employ older people .
the digital economy , dominated by the 人群 population , is pushing older workers into the margins .
but , unlike in the past , crumbling pension systems can no longer absorb such labor-market shocks , with older workers losing into long-term unemployment once they lose jobs .
moreover , pensioners now have reason to worry about their retirement benefits for their children .
young people are frustrated with the socioeconomic systems that are clearly biased toward retirees and increasingly demanding fairer intergenerational redistribution .
for example , the five star movement ( m5s ) , which governs italy ’ s league party , recently proposed a “ citizen ’ s income ” – regardless of age – to all unemployed .
and yet , while right-wing populists have attracted older voters , left-wing populists won their followers .
by supporting right-wing populists , older voters want to return to the time of the country ’ s internal affairs , and that national borders are not so easily crossed .
at the heart of the current nationalist politics is the promise to maintain the status quo – and even return to the mythical past .
so nationalist politicians often resort to nostalgic rhetoric to encourage their older supporters .
trump , for example , has promised to bring jobs back to the 地区 rust belt in the us .
and his attack on illegal immigration , and the travel ban against citizens of major muslim countries , marks his commitment to a “ pure ” american country .
similarly , in continental europe , right-wing populists hope to return to the euro and most of the schengen era before the euro and most of the schengen system .
they often appeal to older voters by lowering their retirement ages and expanding pension benefits ( both of which are the main policy of the league ) .
in the united kingdom , the “ leave ” campaign promises to take charge of those who have been left behind by the age of globalization .
but it also boasted about a free and independent “ global britain . ”
the brexiteers are not new .
in any case , because the current wave of populism is driven by demographics , this trend is unlikely to reach a head anytime soon .
in an increasingly aging society , the political influence of the elderly will grow steadily , but their resilience will decline in rapidly changing economies .
so older voters will seek a growing number of social security , while irresponsible populists are ready to appease them .
how do we respond ?
in order to stem the nationalist tide , mainstream parties urgently need to devise a new social contract that mitigates the growing sense of insecurity among older voters .
they need to strike better balance between openness and protection , innovation , and regulation ; and they need to do so without a populist retreat .
the answer is not to kill global forces , but to make them more acceptable .
citizens of all ages need to be able to cope with current and future shocks .
in this sense , rather than protecting the elderly , it is better to give them power , because most advanced economies can not afford a new interest in such a very large interest group .
moreover , a policy that makes people dependent on some form of external support is morally problematic .
instead , governments should focus on boosting the skills of older workers , creating more opportunities for older and younger generations to work together , and allow disruptors to take on the socioeconomic consequences of their own .
subsidies for the most vulnerable should be the last thing .
in many ways , older voters ’ infatuation with populists is a call for help .
enlightened politicians should respond constructively .

the global perfect storm
new york – in any direction , finance and economic growth are both 阴云密布 : the eurozone , the us , and china .
indeed , by 2013 , the global economy could be very difficult to find .
first , the eurozone crisis is worsening , owing to the euro ’ s strong fiscal consolidation , which will deepen the recession in many member states , while credit crunch and high oil prices in the periphery are impeding prospects for recovery .
with the contraction of cross-border and interbank credit and the possibility of a disorderly exit from the eurozone in the coming months , the eurozone banking system is falling apart .
moreover , as interest-rate spreads in spain and italy return to an unsustainable peak level , fiscal and sovereign-debt tensions are deteriorating .
in fact , the eurozone is likely to be more than just international aid for banks ( now spain ’ s banks ) , but in the eurozone and the international firewall that is inadequate to withstand full sovereignty in spain and italy .
farther afield in the west , the us economy has performed as well , with a first-quarter growth rate of 1.9 % , far below potential growth .
moreover , in april and may ’ s job growth , the us may be stuck in stagnation by the end of the year .
making matters worse , the risk of a double-dip recession next year is increasing : even if it seems that the 美国 us fiscal cliff is ultimately a secondary drag , the increase in taxes and transfers would weaken growth in disposable income and consumption .
moreover , whether obama or romney won november ’ s presidential election , political gridlock about fiscal adjustment could persist .
thus , the risk of a new fight against the debt ceiling , the risk of government bankruptcy , and downgrades in credit rating will likely depress consumption and business confidence further , dragging back spending and boosting funding to safe assets ( thereby hastening the stock market ) .
in the east , china ’ s growth model is unsustainable , and it could be pushed into recession in 2013 if investment is weak and reforms that are unlikely to boost consumption .
china ’ s new leaders must speed up structural reforms , reduce national saving , and increase consumption as a share of gdp ; but the pace of change among leaders is likely to be insufficient , and the transition to political power may not be smooth .
the economic slowdown in the us , the eurozone , and china has had a major impact on other emerging markets , which are determined by trade and financial linkages with the us and the eu ( that is , “ decoupling ” does not occur ) .
at the same time , the lack of structural reforms in emerging markets and the evolution of state capitalism are hampering their growth and eroding their resilience .
finally , in the middle east , tensions between israel and the us over iran ’ s nuclear proliferation could erupt in 2013 .
the current negotiations may fail , even if tightening sanctions may not stop iran from acquiring nuclear weapons .
these risks have contributed to a slowdown in the economy : countries ’ stock markets are falling , leading to a negative wealth effect on consumption and capital spending .
borrowing costs in heavily indebted countries , credit quotas are crowding out small and medium-size enterprises , and commodity prices are holding back exporters ’ incomes .
the rise in risk aversion is leading economic agents to take a wait-and-see stance , which creates some self-fulfilling effects .
compared to 2008-2009 – when policymakers had ample room for action – the monetary and fiscal authorities ’ approaches to monetary and fiscal authorities are about to run out ( or , more ironic , to get out of hand ) .
monetary policy has hit the wall with zero interest rates and another round of quantitative easing .
indeed , the problems facing the economy and markets are no longer liquid , but credit and solvency crises .
meanwhile , unsustainable budget deficits and high levels of public debt in most developed countries have severely limited room for further fiscal stimulus .
replacing exports with exchange rates when private and public deleveraging erodes the structural problems of the current-account deficit is a zero-sum game .
after all , a country ’ s currency devaluation and improved trade balance will necessarily mean that other countries ’ currencies and the deterioration of the trade balance are deteriorating .
at the same time , the ability to backstop , ring-fence , and bail out banks and other financial institutions is constrained by politics and the inability to absorb more debt in the banking system .
as a result , sovereign risk is becoming a bank risk .
indeed , many countries , especially the eurozone , are shifting more public debt to banks ’ balance sheets .
to avoid a disorderly outcome in the eurozone , fiscal austerity today should be slowing considerably , with the new eu fiscal compact should be accompanied by a growth pact that should be accompanied by debt mutualization ( eurobonds ) , and , even if greece leaves the eurozone , and consider further political integration .
unfortunately , germany is blocking all of these key policy measures , because further economic , fiscal , and banking integration will expose its taxpayers to credit risk .
as a result , the probability of a eurozone disaster is rising .
although the cloud of the eurozone is the largest , this is not the only threat to the global economy .
the hatches is still in check .
a global solution network
new york – there is a great deal of profound change in society .

to increase the global community ’ s energy , ban has launched an ambitious new global plan that i am delighted to take .
the united nations sustainable development solutions network is a powerful effort to mobilize global knowledge to save the planet .

该网 will cooperate and support the government , un agencies , civil-society groups , and the private sector .
humans need to learn new ways to produce and use low-carbon energy , sustainably grow food , build livable cities , governance globally , biodiversity , and the atmosphere .
but time is running out .
today ’ s metropolises , for example , have faced dangerous heat waves , rising sea levels , rising levels of extreme storms , dire congested , and air and water pollution .

today , we need universities worldwide to help their societies address poverty , clean energy , and sustainable food supplies .
by connecting the course and keeping curricula online , universities worldwide can become more effective in finding and promoting science-based solutions based on science-based complex problems .
the global corporate sector also has an important role to play in sustainable development .
today , the corporate sector has two faces .
it is the vanguard of cutting-edge sustainable technologies , pioneering research and development , world-class management of world-class management , environmental sustainability .
at the same time , however , the corporate sector has lobbied aggressively to loosen environmental regulations , reduce corporate tax rates , and avoid the ecological destruction they face .
sometimes the same company operates on both sides .
we urgently need far-sighted companies to join sustainable development solutions .
these companies have a unique role to play in translating new ideas and technologies into early-stage demonstration projects , thereby accelerating global learning cycles .
equally important , we need more critical , respected corporate leaders to put pressure on their peers to stop the environment that could lead to the kind of environmental lobbying and campaign contributions that the government does not make .
sustainable development is the challenge that generations will face , not a new priority .
a reinvention of energy , food , transport , and other systems will take decades , not years .
but the long-term nature of the challenge is not a reason for inaction .
it is precisely because change needs for a long time , and environmental risks are imminent , and we must begin to rebuild our production systems now .
after 2015 , the world will fight against poverty and protecting the environment .
the secretary-general ban ki-moon has launched several global initiatives to help set the new goals set in the post-2015 new goals for the new post-2015 goals .
so it is time for the secretary general to initiate a sustainable network of sustainable development solutions .
not only will the world accept new sustainable development goals , but will also have new global expertise to achieve these vital goals .

cambridge – while i subscribe to exchange rates to explain or understand that it is clear , there is still a mystery about the value of today ’ s euro relative to the euro .

in my view , the euro must fall in a very good reason , and six less compelling reasons for the euro ’ s stability and even appreciation .
let us start with why the euro must fall .
in the absence of a clear path to a closer fiscal and political union – which can be achieved only through constitutional amendments – the current euro system is only a half-baked project , and is becoming increasingly unsustainable .
clearly , the european central bank will be forced to purchase a very expensive eurozone sovereign ( junk ) bond .
doing so may be effective in the short term , but if the risk of a sovereign default becomes a reality – and , according to my research and carmen reinhart , it is likely to be a capital restructuring .
moreover , if more robust northern european countries are unwilling to take on the transfer costs – political resistance is considerable – the ecb may be forced to recapitalize its own capital .
in any case , the risk of a deep financial crisis is high .
so what are the arguments to support the euro ’ s current level even appreciate ?
for starters , investors might tell themselves that , under the worst-case scenario , the northern european countries would abandon weaker countries and create new 欧元 .
but , while this scenario can not be said entirely impossible , the eurozone ’ s disintegration will be highly disastrous , and the euro will be able to recover .
second , investors may remember that in the financial panic of 2008 , the dollar at the epicenter of the 2008 financial panic was in the midst of a panic .
although it is difficult to link the dollar to today ’ s euro , the huge euro crisis is perfectly possible in the us and elsewhere .
perhaps the transmission mechanism would be us banks – many of whom remain fragile , because their capital adequacy is low , and the mortgage portfolios accounting for the value of their mortgages far exceed market value .
third , foreign central banks and sovereign wealth funds may be happy to continue purchasing the euro to hedge the risks of dollar and their own economies .
government investors , unlike private investors , do not necessarily invest in the highest returns .
if foreign official demand is the real reason behind the euro ’ s strong strength , the risks facing the euro are the eventual exit from foreign sovereign buyers , who are more focused on private investors than on them .
fourth , investors may assume that , ultimately , the risks are less severe in the us than in europe .
indeed , the us political system has been stymied in reaching a stable medium-term budget deficit .
while the us congress , which heads the “ super committee ” for fiscal consolidation , may be able to offer a case , the republicans and democrats are willing to be willing to compromise in an election year .
moreover , investors may worry that the fed will consider introducing a third round of “ quantitative easing , ” which would further depress the dollar .
fifth , the value of the euro ’ s current value has not been far too far off the terms of purchasing power , and the euro ’ s exchange rate is cheap for german exporters at $ 1.4 , even if the euro appreciates significantly , even if the euro appreciates .
for the eurozone ’ s southern periphery , however , the euro ’ s exchange rate is unsustainable .
some german companies have persuaded employees to accept wage cuts to help weather the financial crisis , but wages in southern europe have been rising steadily , even when productivity stagnates .
but , because the euro ’ s overall value must balance southern europe and northern europe , it is possible to say that 1.4 is in a reasonable range .
finally , investors may think that , although previous programs have failed , eurozone leaders ’ latest plans will work .
abraham lincoln famously said , “ you can always fool some people , but you can be deceiving everyone , but you can not always be deceiving everyone . ”
the complete euro recovery program will occur at some point in some countries , but it is unlikely to happen in any country .
thus , one can identify the great argument why the euro , despite its protracted crisis , has so far remained strong .
but , looking ahead next year , don ’ t count on the euro-dollar exchange rate to remain stable , and that the euro is stronger .
