as a co-author of a new european growth path , a report commissioned by germany ’ s government , i am now sorry for adding a voice to the positive outlook for green growth .
the european climate foundation has already published its roadmap 2050 , a practical guide to a prosperous europe .
since then , the un environment program has released its green economy report ; mckinsey wrote the resource revolution ; and the international trade union committee published a report called “ increasing green and decent jobs . ”
all of these reports have taken a different approach and proposed various recommendations , making it hard for policymakers to see forest .
the implication is that the economics of economics is not fully explained by economics and innovation , which makes it a whole .
in a period of smooth and incremental progress , macroeconomic models are a reliable tool for policymakers , but green growth is not the only way forward .
for example , the eu ’ s goal of achieving greenhouse-gas emissions by 80 % by 2050 will necessarily mean a comprehensive upgrading of infrastructure within the next few decades .
even if economists can not create models for such rapid and radical change , they should not be condemned , because it merely reflects our current level of knowledge , and the fact that economics really is very complex .
we simply have not yet had enough insights to understand how all of the factors in a faraway transition – whether a financial crisis or an explosion of growth – interact .
but all research on green growth seems to offer such explanations .
so what do they tell us ?
in practice , however , each study is limited to one or two dimensions of the economy , and explains how they interact .
the increase in the relationship between green and decent jobs has been studied .
the new growth path in europe explains the impact of expectations and the effects of 边干边学 .
the roadmap 2050 focuses on greening the energy system .
the authors then report a bold conclusion on the economy as a whole .
but when the value of these studies is reflected in the explanation for the part of the explanation , it was always central to the whole , and the whole is measured in gdp and employment .
every study explains a piece of the green economy , not one that covers the whole – not because of the shortcomings of these studies , but because it is beyond our capacity .
this suggests that , while there is no definitive demonstration that green growth is effective , it does not mean that we should abandon it .
we can not prove that a wave of environmental innovation would have a similar effect , but studies of different parts make such an outcome more compelling .
as humans , we all have unique capacity to make decisions about ambiguous information – in fact , we all do .
when we choose a career or spouse , or a politician who captured an opportunity from a plethora of possibilities , it is often based on incomplete information that can trigger cascading consequences .
a major pile of 叠 reports demonstrates the persuasive path of this shift from a historic economic crisis .
and it is time to turn our potential into reality .
green growth offers a realistic alternative to the austerity response to the current economic crisis .
policymakers should also merge this idea into the “ transcending austerity ” narrative that is now taking shape among major eu member states .
ethics and agriculture
melbourne – should developed countries ( or investors there ) buy agricultural land in developing countries ?
this is the questions raised by the south asian institute for land sales , the land matrix partnership , a land for european research organization and nongovernmental organizations .
the report shows that , since 2000 , investors in advanced or emerging countries have bought more than 300 million hectares of farmland in less developed countries ( more than 200 million acres ) .
this amounts to 1.7 % of the world ’ s agricultural land .
most of the world ’ s agricultural land bought in africa , two-thirds of which occur in countries where hunger is spreading and lack formal ownership of land ownership .
africa ’ s agricultural land is equivalent to the total amount of agricultural land in kenya .
foreign investors claim that they buy idle land , so , by making them produce output , the land buy up food supply .
but the land matrix partnership report found that this is not the case : some 45 % of the land of land is already available , and almost one-third of the trading land is the land of forest land , which suggests that development could threaten biodiversity .
this type of investment is both private and public-sector ( as in state-owned entities ) , the main buyers are three categories : china , india , brazil , south africa , malaysia , and south korea .
on average , per capita income in countries in origin is four times higher than the investment target .
the purpose of most of the investment is to produce food and other crops for land acquisition countries , which are obvious – more so than in the advanced countries that the price of land is higher .
more than 40 % of the investment purpose is to export food to countries in origin – a point that suggests that food security is the primary reason for buying land .
oxfam calls part of the deal “ 抢地 . ”
the report ’ s “ our land , our life , ” shows that the social community , affected by world bank programs , has been responsible for undermining the official complaints of its land since 2008 .
in order to attract attention to large-scale land acquisition of direct rights violations , oxfam called for the world bank to freeze investment in land purchases until the local society is assured and chooses to choose .
oxfam also calls for the world bank to ensure that these land deals do not undermine local and national food security .
in response , the world bank agreed to take misconduct in the land acquisition process , particularly in developing countries with weak governance and indicating that it supports more transparent and inclusive engagement .
at the same time , the world bank has pointed out that increasing food production to feed up to two billion people in 2050 is necessary , and suggests that it will need to increase agricultural investment in developing countries .
the world bank refused to suspend its cooperation with investors in agriculture , suggesting that such cooperation is set to be based on those who are most likely to turn things around .
might you ask that transparency and the requirement that local landholders are willing to sell is enough to protect people living in poverty ?
advocates of free markets would say that if local landholders want to sell their land , that is their choice .
after all , poor people can not be allowed to sell kidneys to the highest bidder .
of course , single-minded free-market supporters would say that we should be allowed .
but , in any case , people must explain why people should be barred from selling kidneys and selling land for food .
most people can live without a kidney .
but no one can live without food .
why buy the body of human organs , while buying agricultural land does not – even if the latter includes the expulsion of local landholders and the production of the rich rather than local consumers for export ?
indeed , compared to other foreign investors , the world bank may be able to care more about local landholders .
in that case , the 21 complaints about the world bank ’ s program most likely will most likely be the tip of a large iceberg of violations of land rights in foreign investors in agricultural projects in the developing world , where there are many cases of infringement .
one such case has finally led to the attention of the united nations human rights council .
in november , the committee concluded that germany had failed to use the 依曼 coffee to force the establishment of a large coffee card on a few villages in uganda .
but , in 2001 , the 村民 ’ s villagers were still living in extreme poverty , with no compensation compensation , whether in uganda or germany .
their land rights have been protected by the international covenant on civil and political rights , and germany is a signatory .
can we expect local landholders to receive better compensation from chinese or saudi investors ?
the rise of the food barons
berlin – industrial agriculture has long been criticized for intensifying climate change , environmental degradation , and rural poverty .

this is not surprising , more than $ 5.7 billion of farmers and seven billion consumers worldwide , but the value chain in the global industrial sector is controlled by a handful of companies .

moreover , agricultural concentration in agriculture is rising , owing to the growing demand for agricultural raw materials in food , feed , and energy production .
as the middle class of southern countries rises , their consumption and nutrition habits have changed , boosting demand for processed foods , and a war on cross-border agriculture , chemicals , and food companies .
for years , the biggest players in these sectors have been buying their smaller competitors .
but now they are buying , and financing often comes from investors in completely different industries .

how to feed the world
prague – hunger has plagued humanity from time to time .
almost every major society is affected by famine ; it is estimated that , from bc to 1911 , there were at least one province in china or at least one province of droughts or floods .
but the fight against hunger is a battle that humanity can finally win .
in the last quarter of the twentieth century , production of grains in the last quarter of the twentieth century was higher than in any previous period , and this year ’ s grain production is higher than ever .
since 1992 , the number of hungry people worldwide has declined by more than 200 million , though the population has increased by nearly two billion .
affordable nutritional food is a top priority for all human beings , and one in nine people still can not get enough food to keep healthy .
today ’ s population of 7.3 billion is expected to become 8.5 billion by 2030 , and will grow to a total of 9.7 billion by 2050 .
with more mouths , stresses on food supply will come from conflict , economic instability , extreme weather events , and climate change .
thanks to improved seeds , new fertilizers , and pesticides , credit channels , and technological breakthroughs , agricultural productivity has increased substantially , as the main driver of reducing hunger .
from 1930 to 2000 , us agricultural output quadrupled , with productivity growth in agriculture more rapidly than in manufacturing .
developing countries also share these benefits : in 1960 , their fertilizer consumption was negligible , and in 2000 they used more than industrialized countries .
the world bank has found that productivity growth in agriculture is more than four times higher than in other sectors ’ productivity growth .
so how can we sustain this momentum ?
research and development investments are crucial .
according to the copenhagen consensus center , which i lead , an increase $ 88 billion in investment in agricultural research and development over the next 15 years could increase output by 0.4 percentage points annually , leaving 79 million people out of poverty , leaving five million children out of poverty .
achieving these goals would amount to $ 3 trillion of social good , implying a huge return on $ 34 per dollar spent .
scientific breakthroughs have also played a critical role in defeating specific nutritional challenges , such as vitamin a deficiency , which is the main cause of preventable child blindness .
robert 万加 has been awarded the world food prize for the inspiring work of 乌干达 ( vitamin a content ) in uganda with a large number of people who replace the rural poor in a variety of 品种 varieties .
another way to increase agricultural productivity is through labor .
copenhagen consensus centers are finding that increasing agricultural labor productivity “ is the only way to strengthen bangladesh ’ s resilience to climate change and achieve long-term development goals . ”
over two decades , investing around $ 9,000 per worker would boost agricultural productivity by 10 % .
the case in bangladesh is instructive , because it is vulnerable to flooding and climate change , while its agricultural productivity lags behind other developing and middle-income countries .
unsurprisingly , the bangladeshi prime minister ’ s office is working to lead global innovation , creating an agricultural innovation lab that shares best practices and ideas .
the copenhagen consensus center and the world ’ s largest ngo , brac , work together to understand what the country ’ s rural areas – the “ extreme poverty ” that brac engages with the “ extreme poverty ” that brac is working closely with .
these workers , the housewife , and others live on less than $ 0.6 per day , and their voices rarely have a place in policy discussions .
at the nine forums in remote parts of bangladesh , participants overwhelmingly spoke of a single policy priority : raising agricultural productivity .
“ it is well known , ” according to a local 孟加 ( 孟加 ) of the “ 地区 region , ” is that “ 孟加 ” is the bengali , referring to the natural hunger phenomenon of year .
“ our people are 饭 – we need to increase agricultural productivity . ”
as one 木吉玛 村民 put it in the same way : “ we need crops and seeds for 盐碱 and floods , so we do not die from food shortages . ”
humanity can win a war with hunger .
the world has made great strides , but the world needs more agricultural r & d and higher productivity .
a farmer near the 偏远地区 霍拉 in northern bangladesh , 附近 指出 , pointed out starkly , “ our survival depends on it . ”
we would do better .
the arab marshall plan
but , despite the revolution ’ s overthrow of dictators and changed society , these core objectives remain as distant as ever .
indeed , the economic challenges facing the arab spring countries have become even more urgent , severely affecting these countries ’ political prospects .
unemployment in tunisia and egypt nearly doubled , and foreign direct investment in the arab world has dried up .
tourism revenues , while strong , are falling , and fiscal challenges are still high .
but economic urgency does not reflect a policy response to slow ( if not impossible ) .
for example , the fiscal deficit in egypt this year will exceed 11 % of gdp .
but the country ’ s leaders are struggling to calm the conditions for imf loans .
the government cut fuel subsidies last year , but it did not increase further , and president mohamed morsi delayed the effort immediately after announcing the necessary tax increases .
almost all political stakeholders in egypt ( other arab transition countries ) know the need for economic reform .
but neither people nor policymakers want to assume the social and political costs of reform .
in the context of sensitive and uncertain political climate – a new crisis – economic reform has repeatedly been postponed and is not surprising .
politicians understand that macroeconomic stability and social cohesion are irreconcilable in the short term .
cutting food and energy subsidies to reduce the fiscal burden can not be counted on to win the support of you , because more than 40 % of egypt ’ s per capita income is allocated to food .
thus , politics has become a constraint on fiscal health .
at the same time , narrow imf prescriptions have the potential to amplify political instability , and people are no longer afraid to take on the streets to express their grievances .
the recent stalemate over economic reforms has highlighted a larger problem : the desire to reform and tax systems , which first put the social contract in exchange for political obedience .
but , during periods of economic uncertainty and high unemployment , such a movement would be too high for politicians to be even as large as individual countries .
in order to create the political space needed for economic reform , arab leaders must offer a regional growth pact – similar to the marshall plan – to stimulate investment aimed at reviving economic activity .
when the economy expands , the reform subsidy will be much easier .
moreover , building competitive markets is essential to ensure sustainable gdp growth .
to this end , regional trade barriers – the problem in the arab world even more generally than in sub-saharan africa – must be broken .
by agreeing to this pact , arab countries will be able to commit to reforming the subsidy system and reducing cross-border restrictions .
the regional dimension of prosperity is long ignored in the arab world .
but weak regional linkages limited small businesses ’ growth potential , forcing them to rely on national support .
though arab leaders often regard turkey as a beacon of hope , they rarely recognize that turkey ’ s current transition from “ sick man ” to the world is unlikely to be realized if regional synergies is not pursued .
this link is particularly important in egypt and tunisia , unless the country ’ s labor market – which has traditionally absorbed immigrants from north africa ’ s neighbors – is unlikely to reduce unemployment .
and , while tunisia ’ s situation seems to be the most optimistic , a crippling investment shortfall could derail reform .
with europe suffering from crisis , capital inflows from the resource-rich arab neighbors are the biggest hope in tunisia .
beyond that , arab countries must gradually increase development spending .
the new investment entity , such as sovereign wealth funds and islamic finance , can also help firms with 饥渴 financing .
at the same time , arab countries must streamline current aid efforts .
arab governments have long wasted money on the issue , with rich gulf states effectively subsidizing their troubled neighbors .
over the last two years , saudi arabia has provided more than $ 3 billion to yemen .
qatar has provided $ 5 billion to egypt since 2011 , and has pledged $ 3 billion .
and the united arab emirates recently pledged $ 2.5 billion to bahrain .
but unconditional aid can only delay 干戈 , because it weakens budgetary constraints , thereby reducing pressure on policymakers and creating moral hazard .

helping neighboring countries ’ economic revival , the political transition to spur political transition , is the region ’ s interests – including countries that are not facing an imminent threat of revolutionary threats .
the ahistorical federal reserve
berkeley – the past 20 years have taught – or should have taught – the fed ’ s four lessons .
but the fed ’ s current policy posture has raised questions about whether they have internalized any of them .
the first lesson is that , at least in the face of current interest-rate adjustments , the fed ’ s sensible target inflation should be 4 % per year , not 2 % .
higher inflation is essential to raise inflation targeting in order to reduce the short-term safety nominal interest rate of five or more .
the fed objected that changing the inflation target , even once , would undermine the credibility of its commitment to ensuring price stability .
but the fed can pay now and then pay the price .
after all , if today ’ s credibility means sticking to policies that limit you ’ ability to do the job tomorrow , what is certain ?
the second lesson is that the phillips curve ’ s two regressive arrows have occurred in the 1970 ’ s or even 1980 ’ s , when the phillips curve described the relationship between expectations and inflation .
in the 1990s , then-fed chair alan greenspan discovered this phenomenon .
he rightly judged that pushing for faster growth and lower unemployment would not bring excessive risk , but rather low-hanging fruit .
the current fed seems to hold different views .
the third lesson is that the bond market ’ s inversion curve is not just a sign that the market is too tight ; it is a sign that monetary policy is too tight .
those who thought that the fed ’ s overshooting would lead to lower interest rates led to a spike in us treasury securities , which now fret about when the recession would quickly lead to excess capacity .
today , the fed has a “ habitat theory ” explaining why this time is different – that is , why investors ’ preferences for a maturity duration mean that the yield curve is contrary to the meaning of the past .
but in 2006 , before the financial crisis erupted , people thought it was different .
( there was also the thought that this time was different . )
history suggests that this time is unlikely to be different – if the fed continues to do so again .
in the 1980 ’ s , there was good reason to believe that the next big shock to the us macroeconomy could be inflationary .
today ’ s judgment is no longer tenable .
in the past , the major shocks have not triggered inflation , such as the 1973 and 1979 oil crisis , on which they triggered deflation , such as the us savings and loan crisis of the 1980 ’ s , the asian financial crisis in 1997 , the dot-com bubble , and the september 11 , 2001 , terrorist attacks in the united states , and the european debt crisis in september 2010 .
former fed chair janet yellen told me in the 1990 ’ s that , in the case of the fed , the debate within the fed ’ s framework of interest rates has facilitated a rough consensus on the appropriate policy of the right policies about the economic structure and the state of the state .
but , at least in my view , the fed ’ s shift from a realistic view of the economy to the right monetary policy is a bad thing .
perhaps the fed should discuss internal discussions within a more clearly defined framework .
consider , for example , the fed ’ s “ optimized control ” approach , which is based on the creation of multiple macroeconomic models , which use different interest rates and balance-sheet tools to predict future inflation and unemployment .
the problem with optimizing control methods is that the real world is a closed system , with economic relations never changing , or in an entirely predictable way .
the most effective – and thus most credible – monetary policy must reflect not only the lessons of history , but also the willingness to reflect on the long-held assumptions .
a history lesson for koizumi
once again , china and south korea protested against the annual demonstrations against japanese prime minister junichiro koizumi ’ s annual pilgrimage to the yasukuni shrine .

yet koizumi was bent on clinging .
and , most likely , prime minister shinzo abe , who will succeed him , has publicly declared that he will continue to visit the yasukuni shrine .
another may succeed koizumi , foreign minister aso , calling for the japanese emperor to visit yasukuni .
despite this seeming pessimism , the deadlock in yasukuni appears to be deepening .
but history can not only bring us to the present .
even on the issue of yasukuni , there are positive lessons for us to learn .
consider nakasone , koizumi ’ s predecessor in the 1980 ’ s .
both are savvy politicians who have long been popular and took office .
both are conservative , nationalistic , and promoted more political and military roles abroad .
finally , both are pro-american , with nakasone announced that japan was the united states ’ “ unsinkable aircraft carrier ” in east asia , and koizumi has sent to iraq to support the us-led war campaign .
but one important difference between nakasone and koizumi is often overlooked : their handling of the yasukuni controversy and its approach to relations .
nakasone broke the taboo as the first prime minister who visited the yasukuni shrine on august 15 , 1985 , after the four decades of the end of world war ii .
the decision triggered a strong response from china , where students marched to protest his visits .
but , instead of taking advantage of his domestic disapproval of china , nakasone decided to visit yasukuni .
he chose to repair relations with china , focusing on positive aspects of bilateral ties .
in 1986 , nakasone visited beijing ’ s general secretary of the communist party , hu yaobang , the architect of the chinese communist market ’ s founding activities , and pledged to cultivate friendly relations with china .
this genuine embrace of reconciliation offers a much-needed support for china ’ s leaders , who are eager to control anti-japanese sentiments .
hu praised nakasone ’ s courage and warned of chinese youth that if they “ consider only the interests of their country , they are not 头脑冷静 patriots . ”
nakasone managed to escape the crisis , as a politician who was considered good at dealing with japan ’ s diplomatic relations with china .
no one accused nakasone of “ selling the nation ” to beijing .
nor is his conservative , nationalist , and pro-american credentials damaged .
this episode suggests that koizumi ’ s hardline stance is not the only option .
japan ’ s prime minister can be a strong prime minister without exploiting domestic discontent with its neighbors ; it can maintain a functioning , patriotic , and pro-american stance while fostering a functioning , patriotic , and pro-american stance .
indeed , ending the yasukuni shrine will most likely open the door to the long-overdue sino-japanese meeting , which will strengthen the voices of moderate chinese and chinese , seeking to develop a future-oriented relationship with japan .
unfortunately , koizumi and their allies are not prepared to go further on the yasukuni issue .
as foreign minister aso recently pointed out : “ the more the chinese object , the more [ japan feels to be going to visit it . ”
as if someone told you ‘ don ’ t smoke cigarettes , it actually makes you want to smoke . ”
no one expects the japanese and chinese leaders to embrace each other , as nakasone and hu did two decades ago , but the leaders of neighboring powers pretend to be a sad one at the international conference .
if koizumi had now answered the yasukuni shrine to answer the yasukuni shrine , he could simply play the analogy : 继续 koizumi ’ s smoke smoke not in japan ’ s national interest .

lies , damned lies , and ai
cambridge – algorithms and algorithms are as biased as the data they have relied on .
and all data are biased .
even “ official ” statistics can not be considered objective “ facts . ”
the figures issued by the government represent the current state of social affairs , where those who are collecting data represent both importance and relevance .
the scope and classifications used to understand the data are not neutral .
just as algorithmic decision-making spreads to broader decision-making areas , it is revealing harsh social biases that used to be collected in the shadows of our data .
by incorporating existing structures and processes into their logical plates , artificial intelligence ( ai ) is forcing us to confront the communities we create .
the problem is not just that i have made the math of computers , as i have done in cambridge university ’ s 同事 詹妮 , but that computers think , but computers emulate economists .
after all , ai is an economy where humans can not be considered wrong .
it is an agent capable of calculating , logically coherent , and targeting goals , which can use limited 计算资源 to achieve the desired situation .
if “ maximizing utility ” is “ utility , ” they are more effective than anyone .
“ utility ” is like “ phlogiston ” that once seemed to be “ phlogiston . ”
early chemists assumes that the 可燃物质 contained a hidden element – phlogiston – that could explain why substances change in the form of burning .
but , despite their efforts , this assumption can never be borne out by scientists .
the chemist can not justify phlogiston , and economists today can not measure the actual utility .
economists use the concept of utility to explain the causes of people ’ s choices – buying , investing , and working hard work : everyone is trying to maximize utility of utility according to their preferences and beliefs around the world , and to the limits of income and resource scarcity .
while there is no shortage , utility is a powerful construct .
naturally , everyone seems to think that everyone is doing their own good .
moreover , economists ’ notion of genius stems from classical utilitarianism , which is the goal of classical utilitarianism .
as modern economists follow in the footsteps of john stuart mill , most of the algorithms are 功利主义者 , believing that they can maximize the benefits if they know “ good . ”
but this assumption may be unsettling .
consider , for example , the use of algorithms to determine whether prisoners deserve parole .
an important study in 2017 found that algorithms have been far more effective in predicting recidivism rates than humans , and they can be used to reduce “ incarceration rates ” by more than 40 % , while “ not raising the rate of crime . ”
as a result , in the us , artificial intelligence can be used to change a disproportionately black prison population .
but what if ai takes over the parole process , and the proportion of african-americans ’ incarceration is still higher than white ?
effective algorithmic decision-making leaves these problems out of reach and forced us to decide precisely what outcomes should be maximized .
should we simply want to reduce the overall prison population , or should we care about fairness ?
while politics can be allowed to fudge and compromise to hide this tradeoff , computer code must be clear .
this demand for clarity makes it harder to ignore structural sources of social injustice .
in the age of ai , algorithms will force us to recognize how the results of past social and political conflicts can be sustained through our use of data .
thanks to groups such as the ai ethics initiative and the ai partnership , the broader debate about the ethics of ai has begun .
but ai algorithms are , of course , simply working on code .
the real problem is not just the use of algorithmic decision-making , but also on the moral foundations of our societies .
and , while we need to debate the practical and philosophical tradeoffs of maximizing the practice of utility by artificial intelligence , we need to rethink ourselves .
we must now decide whether we really want to integrate existing social arrangements into our decision-making mechanisms into the future .
given the political fragmentation currently occurring around the world , this seems to be the best time to start a new chapter .
a better global framework to end aids
stockholm , geneva – this week , we celebrate progress toward fighting aids .
in many countries with strong health systems , aids is no longer the death penalty , but a chronic condition .
africa has reached a critical point : the number of africans who are starting to treat aids every year has surpassed the number of infected africans .
but , while we celebrate , we still have to lose 1.1 million people who died this year for aids .
every day , 6,000 people are infected with hiv , and aids remains a major cause of death for children , adolescents , and women in africa .
the fight against aids spurs us all to help those who are left behind , and work to eliminate aids once and for all .
fortunately , we already have the knowledge , resources , and the most important political impetus to do so ; at this year ’ s high-profile meeting of aids , the un ’ s member states have made ambitious commitments that will enable us to take the fast path .
moreover , in september , canada hosted a successful conference on the global fund for aids , tuberculosis , and malaria , $ 1.3 billion in funding , and a sufficient global fund for the 2018-2019 period .
at the same time , individual countries have increased domestic investment , while international partners – both small and small – have maintained the $ 26 billion needed to support global aids responses .
but financing the global health system is not enough .
the international community must adopt a more comprehensive perspective , strengthening global responses , and that arrangement must make clear division of labor and close cooperation .
ultimately , the goal of this arrangement must be to support countries ’ own health systems , in order to channel public and private actors at every level of the public and private actors in order to make all facilities – from public hospitals to clinics – ready .
sweden has been proud of the global fund ; at a meeting in september , it pledged 25 million ( $ 2.71 billion ) .
the global fund is the largest multilateral financing source for aids , tuberculosis , and malaria ; but , as the global vaccine and gavi union ( now known as gavi , or vaccine alliance ) , it is part of a larger global arrangement .
as a result , it is difficult to sustain progress on the level of progress on hiv/aids if countries support other global health organizations , such as unaids , the world health organization , and the united nations development programme .
providing the necessary support requires donors to work together to enable the current arrangements of global health problems to be plentiful .
this , in turn , will ensure that all countries – and all of the people – receive the support they need .
unaids has set a powerful example for international cooperation , and it has worked hard to bring together the common purpose of the 2016 战略 strategy .
this unique partnership of innovation brings together 11 un agencies , together with specialized experience with diverse sectors , and mobilize major global stakeholders .
partners include business , community , and religious leaders , including teachers , judges , law enforcement officials , parliamentarians , and many of the health departments that affect health outcomes .
one of unaids ’ mission is to encourage national governments to prioritize aids as a public-health agenda , and to invest in ending the disease .
it is the only organization with the power to establish the norms of global aids response , which means that it plays a key role in the current international arrangements .
unaids maintains close cooperation with the global fund .
it has a offices in more than 80 countries , and its regional teams can provide technical support and strategic information , thereby helping the global fund to channel adequate funds to the right projects , regions , and populations .
moreover , it can help to create social , legal , and political conditions for people to use health services , including not only to promote gender equality and ensure that the people who are at risk of contracting hiv do not face discrimination .
by using international aids responses to promote equality , dignity , and human rights worldwide , unaids is working with citizens at every level .
but , while unaids ’ authority is widely shared , it lacks sufficient resources , which threatens previous achievements and future projects , with the people and countries that rely on the organization to facilitate their life-saving support .
sweden and unaids will work together to ensure that international aids responses continue to change – and save – lives .
we will protect and empower women and girls , and to ensure that vulnerable populations are heard .
at the same time , however , the international community must strengthen the existing framework for managing global health problems .
as swedish prime minister 洛夫 洛夫 said in montreal in september , “ today we focus on the global fund , let us hope that we don ’ t forget the whole global health arrangement . ”
the international community should face the challenge , pledging to support our global health infrastructure , all of which – and all countries and individuals – must be involved .

likewise , there is a link between working on poverty , gender , and nutrition – all factors that contribute to the aids crisis .
the causes of ncds are not isolated , but also require a multidimensional approach to prevention .
engagement – E – gave the aids movement enormous influence .
proponents of the aids movement have taken the approach of the movement ’ s rights movement , leading the slogan “ our thing , we all engage in ” the slogan to address the problem of disease .
for example , unaids remains the only united nations agency , composed of representatives of civil society , from civil-society representatives .
this paradigm has been incorporated into a powerful group of aids movements , which are almost unthinkable in the aids conference .
the disease prevention campaign must also develop a persuasive narrative , while robert f. kennedy – defined ( frame ) – is the key to winning political leaders in the aids community .
in particular , access to aids treatment is defined as a matter of economic justice .
this narrative has reduced the price of drug prices sharply , with more than half of the people living in low- and middle-income countries receiving treatment .
an equally important question about the aids movement – which is also true of the ncd movement – is responsibility .
the aids community has worked hard to deflect attention from the choice of individual life choices to demand health care and elimination of legal discrimination .
in the aids debate , gender – the g-20 in our movement – is an important focus .
hiv was initially viewed as “ gay disease , ” and gender identity was marked by the dna of the aids movement .
gender issues for ncds are equally important ; consider the marketing of alcohol and tobacco .
gender should therefore be a priority for ncds prevention .
finally , H – human rights – is the cornerstone of the aids response mechanism .
aids activists have launched campaigns against discrimination , schools , and hospitals .
strategic litigation helps to ensure equality for the law .
the aids movement refused to hold conferences on countries with punitive laws to carry hiv .
the ncd movement should also adopt a similar strategy , such as the refusal of countries to fight for junk food advertising against children .
the lessons of the aids movement can be traced to the entire alphabet , but they are right to end in comparison , because human rights drove the aids response and should promote the response to ncds .
poverty , exclusion , and social and economic marginalization make it easier to infect hiv .
the same is true of ncds .
the early mainstream reaction to the aids epidemic was to ask “ why those who do not make a better choice ? ”
the aids movement proved that this is a mistake .
today , 70 % of the planet ’ s people face the risk of premature death for premature deaths from preventable diseases .
when we join this force , we have created a stronger movement .
the views expressed here do not represent unaids .
aid works
new york – critics of foreign aid are wrong .
a growing number of people in the data show that death rates for poor people in many countries are declining rapidly , and the aid for health assistance is crucial .
aid works , and it saves lives .
according to recent research by the 德莫姆 and 特罗 穆勒 , kenya ’ s infant mortality rate has fallen sharply in recent years , owing partly to the massive use of malaria .
this finding is consistent with murray ’ s important study of malaria mortality , which has found that , since 2004 , malaria mortality rates in sub-saharan africa have experienced significant and rapidly declining mortality rates , owing to the support of malaria control efforts supported by external aid .
let us begin a dozen years ago .
in 2000 , africa was devastated by three epidemics .
aids kills more than two million lives every year , and is spreading rapidly .
malaria has surged , owing to the parasite ’ s growing resistance to traditional drugs .
tb is also raging , partly because of the aids epidemic , partly owing to the emergence of drug-resistant tb .
moreover , hundreds of thousands of women die each year during childbirth , because they can not produce in safe clinics and hospitals , nor do they need the emergency relief needed .
these crises spurred action .
the un ’ s member states adopted the millennium development goals in september 2000 .
three of the eight mdgs are directly focused on health , reducing child mortality , deaths of maternal deaths , and infectious diseases .
likewise , the world health organization has vigorously called for increased aid for health assistance .
african leaders , led by nigeria ’ s president , olusegun obasanjo , have accepted the burden of fighting epidemics with the continent .
nigeria hosted two landmark summits , namely the malaria summit in 2000 and the aids summit in 2001 , which played a major role in facilitating action .
in the second summit , then-un secretary-general kofi annan called for a global fund to fight aids , tuberculosis , and malaria .
the global fund works in 2002 to finance the prevention , treatment , and care of these three diseases .
high-income countries , too , are eventually reaching agreements , agreeing to remove debts from heavily indebted poor countries , reduce their debt-service burdens , and spend more on health programs .
the us has taken action , with two major projects , one of aids , and another against malaria .
in 2005 , the united nations millennium project offered a practical approach to how to increase primary health care in the poorest countries , with high-income countries helping the poorest countries to assume the costs of their failure .
the un general assembly adopted many of the project ’ s recommendations , and began to implement many low-income countries .
aided by these efforts , donor aid is booming .
in 1995 , total aid for health aid was about $ 79 billion .
this inadequate level of aid has increased slowly , to $ 10.5 billion in 2000 .
the abundance of funding has enabled programs to fight aids , tuberculosis , and malaria to launch , safe childbirth , and increase vaccine coverage , and polio is largely eliminated .
many innovative health-care technologies are developed and used .
with roughly one billion people living in high-income countries , aid in 2010 meant that they accounted for $ 27 per capita – a small fraction of what they are , but for the poorest .
public health is now visible in many ways .
in 1990 , 12 million children died under the age of five .
by 2010 , the number fell to around 7.6 million – still high , but certainly historic .
the number of malaria deaths in africa has fallen from the peak of one million in 2004 to around 700,000 in 2010 , while the number of pregnant women worldwide fell by almost half from 1990 to 2010 , from 145 to 287 ( estimates ) .
if annual health aid increases $ 100- $ 150 billion ( with residents of high-income countries claiming $ 10-15 per person ) , the next few years will be more progressive .
the mdgs , even in the world ’ s poorest countries , are achievable .
unfortunately , each of the steps that have been taken in the last decade ( and now no exception ) , a group of skeptics of aid is needed to intervene .
they have repeatedly claimed that aid has little effect ; aid funds were lost ; and the case for malaria can not be used for the poor , because the poor do not have the right use ; and so on .
their attacks were relentless ( including for me ) .
the opponents of aid are not just wrong .
they are unanimous in opposing the financing needed to make progress – reducing infant deaths in order to enable the poorest countries to complete their basic health services in 2015 and then to ensure that all people have access to essential health services .
a decade of progress in health outcomes has shown that skeptics are wrong .
aid for health is useful in saving lives and improving lives and improving lives .
let us continue to support these lives , raising the dignity and wellbeing of all people .
the aiib and global governance
hong kong – despite official opposition from the united states and japan , 57 countries have chosen to become founding members of the china-led asian infrastructure investment bank ( aiib ) .
regardless of the skeptics ’ views , this remarkable turnaround has helped to improve global economic governance .
as former us treasury secretary larry summers has pointed out , the aiib ’ s establishment “ may be remembered as a moment of us loss of its global economic system . ”
on the contrary , the adb president , 中尾 Nakao , argues that the aiib ’ s establishment will not lead to “ major changes in development finance , ” though he acknowledged that “ there is a range of interpretations of its symbolic significance . ”
who is right will depend largely on the decisions that the aiib ’ s major shareholders have made to their operations .
so far , the aiib has not sought to change the principle that the largest contributor to multilateral organizations is the largest contributors to multilateral organizations .
as the us dominates the world bank , european leadership , and the international monetary fund , china will dominate the aiib .
this means that china will assume more global leadership , including the traditional powers , which should welcome this change .
after all , leading the world is not just a matter of power , but also a global provision of public goods .
in the end of world war ii , the us was not only the world ’ s most powerful military and economic power , but also the largest supplier of global public goods , which supported the marshall plan for reconstruction in europe , supported the united nations , and provided its power to the bretton woods institutions .
but today , large debt constraints have undermined the ability of the us – not to mention the constraints of europe and japan – to continue doing so .
indeed , china could have filled the void within the bretton woods institutions , but the voting rights within these institutions are too skewed in the advanced countries , which still enjoy veto power .
for example , china has only 3.8 % voting shares in the imf and world bank , even though its share of global gdp is more than 12 % .
britain and france – only one-third of china ’ s economy – have a 4.3 % share of the vote .
the current advanced-country rulers are reluctant to give china the voting power commensurate with its economic power , and china has no choice but to establish its own institutions .
but the aiib has its own objectives , such as the world bank , to target it .
specifically , the aiib is a key component of china ’ s economic development through the “ one belt , one road ” strategy , which includes two major projects : the overland silk road belt linking china and europe to the twenty-first century , and the twenty-first century maritime silk road connecting china and southeast asia , the middle east , and europe .
while the “ pivot ” to the east is underway , china is west westward , and it has spread its development experience to its trading partners in eurasia and beyond .
perhaps most important in these experience is the crucial role of connectivity to economic growth .
over the last three decades , china ’ s roads , railways , airports , and communications systems have facilitated trade , attracting regional disparities , and reducing regional disparities by linking the country ’ s inland western and southern provinces to more prosperous eastern coast cities .
china ’ s silk road project aims to boost china ’ s trade partners largely through infrastructure investment , which is the next step in china ’ s development .
in addition to investing $ 50 billion in investment in the aiib , china has also lent $ 40 billion to its silk road fund , $ 32 billion to new capital flows to the country ’ s development bank .
according to estimates by hsbc , the “ one belt , one road ” initiative could eventually cost $ 320 billion – almost two-thirds of the world bank ’ s balance sheet in 2014 .
the $ 100 billion aiib will play a central role here .
according to the adb ’ s estimates , global infrastructure financing needs to be buoyant , and the aiib alone will need $ 8 trillion in the next decade alone , so the aiib should not be viewed as a threat to the world bank , the adb , and other multilateral lenders .
despite this , the bank will compete with other institutions , because its approach to loans differs from it .
indeed , the aiib ’ s operations would be more similar to the world bank in the 1960 ’ s , with engineers who have the experience of development experience to design the appropriate loan conditions for borrowers .
in the late 1980 ’ s , the world bank began to implement the washington consensus , pursuing economic and political liberalization that no longer fully account for local political or economic realities .
the result is conditional lending , which is often formulated by academic policy experts , leading many developing-country borrowers to meet their claims without hiring international organizations to adjust their official reporting .
the test of the aiib ’ s effectiveness will be its governance model .
one of the failures of the bretton woods institutions was that it has a full-time shareholder board to represent the will of the donor , which has always undermined the effectiveness of projects , often requiring contradictory lending conditions .
the world bank has wasted too much time being carried out by the new governor , without recognizing the fundamental problems of its governance structure .
even if the aiib fails to deliver the results of its commitments , its establishment could be an important reminder that , in a rapidly changing world , economic governance can not be stagnant .
if western leaders truly believe in innovation , competition , and meritocracy , they should welcome the aiib .

the dawn of climate-friendly air travel
montreal – as the world becomes increasingly interconnected , the demand for air travel is growing , with more than 30,000 new aircraft expected to take place in the coming years .
but if it is to maintain the growth of air travel without aggravating global warming , it will have to reduce co2 emissions from air dioxide emissions , and the paris climate agreement , which has not been reached in more than 190 countries last december , has been agreed .
fortunately , it is time to decouple aviation emissions from the growth of aviation travel .
this week , representatives from 191 countries gathered in montreal to attend the 11th united nations international civil aviation organization ( icao ) conference ; after decades of debate , they agreed on a 气候 climate agreement .
the goal of this new icao framework is the “ carbon neutral growth growth ” that began in 2020 , which is at the heart of the global market ( GMBM ) , helping airlines to limit net emissions to the level of the 2020 level .
the initiative would be the first global industry to emit a cap on the cost of a global industry that does not cost consumers significantly .
airlines will purchase emissions reductions from other economic sectors , thereby channeling billions of dollars into low-carbon development worldwide .
in the first six years of the year , the new framework would apply only to flights of a country that voluntarily accepted the framework of voluntary acceptance that the icao must encourage adequate participation in the program .
this autonomous approach has been criticized for some criticism , but it is not irrelevant to “ voluntary ” or “ coercive ” issues , because international agreements generally apply only to sovereign states that decide to join them .
with 64 countries already willing to sign up on the icao agreement , they collectively account for more than 80 % of co2 emissions by 2020 .
while 100 % of that is not true , it is a good start , and we expect more countries to join the benefits of achieving low-carbon development .
the airlines themselves would welcome a global framework that establishes clear and predictable compliance standards , rather than facing regulatory frameworks that are complicated by countries ’ fragmented and confusing international operations .
to minimize compliance costs – and because environmental sustainability is now a key competitive market for customers and investors – airlines may encourage the country to join the icao program .
the new agreement provides important opportunities to prevent the first 15 billion tons of co2 from the first 15 years – equivalent to an annual reduction of around 350 million cars .
the agreement will also spur cleaner technologies like boeing , airbus , bombardier , and brazil ’ s air , thereby reducing the purchase of emission deductions , which have already begun to invest in more quiet , fuel-efficient aircraft , and improve existing ones .
but the framework identified in montreal is incomplete , and it must be accelerated to develop key details that enable airlines to begin planning how to achieve new environmental goals .
developed countries have already proposed solutions that help to implement the GMBM , and hope that it can pave the way for investments in emerging economies that are increasingly in the new air power .
if one can leapfrog over old technologies , it can become a new leader in a new , smart airplane .
they should take advantage of the opportunity to join the icao framework so that producers are clear and predictable .
at last year ’ s paris climate talks , we saw the power of global cooperation to address climate change .
many of the 187 countries – small , developed , and small – announced their emissions-reduction targets for months before meeting , creating a landmark agreement .
with the paris climate agreement coming into force a few months later – faster than anyone expected – we remain in this momentum .
the icao agreement is a new wave of international war against climate change .
together , these two agreements will increase opportunities for environmentally sustainable economic growth .
by starting to clear our carbon footprint from now , future air travelers , whether from any country , can learn from a healthy planet .
europe ’ s airpocalypse
asia , especially china , is the favorite target .
indeed , sometimes , it is incomplete to say that any major environmental conference is in short supply in europe ’ s so-called “ best practices ” to emulate europe .
but , when it comes to air pollution , europe is still doing more talking .
air pollution is becoming a major concern for europe .
the world health organization called it “ the continent ’ s biggest environmental health risk , ” an estimated 90 % of european citizens are exposed to outdoor pollution that exceeds the who ’ s air-quality compass .
in 2010 , about 600,000 european citizens died prematurely because of outdoor and indoor air pollution , while economic costs were $ 1.6 trillion , equivalent to about 9 % of the eu ’ s gdp .
london and paris suffer from severe air-quality problems .
二氧化氮 levels in some parts of london have sometimes reached 2-3 times the recommended limit .
in the united kingdom , air pollution kills more than 11,000 people every year , after the second premature death of smoking .
the situation in paris is even worse than in london ; in march , the level of air pollution in paris was more than shanghai ’ s , and it had to implement a partial and free bus .
sadly , european policymakers do not seem to face up to the challenge .
chancellor of the exchequer george osborne opposed britain ’ s leadership in the fight against climate change .
“ we won ’ t stop our 轧钢厂 , 炼 , and paper paper , ” he said in 2011 .
osborne is not alone .
it is no surprise that european politicians believe that introducing environmental protection mechanisms will affect the eu economy , which is not surprising , so it is not surprising that measures to contain air pollution are far from demanding .
according to the green peace organization ’ s report , it is not even china ’ s strict standards for limiting emissions from coal-fired power plants .
but many european politicians have also demanded a further cut in the country , and hungary argues that it should abandon it altogether .
to be sure , air pollution levels in asia are indeed worrisome .
according to yale university ’ s 2014 air quality ranking , nine of the world ’ s ten most polluted countries are in asia .
new delhi is ranked at the top of the earth ’ s urban pollution , and air pollution exceeds 60 times the level of security .
because of the health of beijing ’ s air , foreign companies must pay a “ hardship fee ” to employees in beijing .
but at least policymakers in asia recognize the problem and take action to address it .
china , for example , has declared a “ war on pollution . ”
by 2017 , beijing , once hailed by the international media as “ 霾 , ” would spend €700 billion ( $ 121 billion ) on air pollution .
at the heart of china ’ s efforts is to improve public transportation , green trade , and change the energy structure .
the government has set up every 500 meters of the city ’ s center in the city city , bringing down tariffs on 54 environmental products to 5 % or less .
the share of primary fuels in primary fuel consumption will rise to 20 % by 2030 .
these goals are likely to be implemented rigorously , because they receive strong political support at the top .
meanwhile , in gujarat , maharashtra , and tamil nadu , states such as gujarat , maharashtra , and tamil nadu are prepared to implement the world ’ s first cap-and-trade system .
other asian countries are taking steps to improve air quality .
vietnam aims to build a 八条 urban rail network in the coming years .

japan , too , has introduced subsidies for hydrogen cars and opened new 步行 areas .
europe , one of the world ’ s richest regions , should be at the forefront of promoting environmental sustainability .
but , on air pollution , european policymakers should stop preaching and focus on solving their problems .
japan ’ s transformation ?
osaka – yesterday ’ s landslide victory in the democratic party of japan ( dpj ) , the democratic party of japan ( dpj ) , ended the ldp ’ s all-powerful one-party system , from 1955 to control over the ldp .
over the past decade , the dpj has been considered an alternative party for the ldp , despite the size of the 伪两党 system .
twenty years after the end of the cold war , japan is finally on the verge of establishing a 体系 system of government .
even now , the japanese public remains skeptical about the dpj ’ s ability to govern power and the attractiveness of a wealth redistribution that lacks funding .
it is also clear that the public ’ s ideological blinders are not realistic , coherent diplomacy , and security policies .
but the public ’ s aversion to the ldp has brought the dpj to the next government .
for four years , the ldp has utterly ignored the critical issues of public attention , unemployment , and the deterioration of the social safety net .
moreover , the ldp has been plagued by a series of scandals , and has always shown poor governance capacity .
the ldp ’ s replacement of three prime ministers for more than a year has said that the party ’ s core power is breaking down .
after assuming power , the dpj will immediately face a large bureaucracy and entrenched mandarins , which will willfully undermine any administrative reform that threatens its power and vested interests .
indeed , the election is just over , and the next fiscal year will have to be submitted .
the budget numbers require a cumbersome process , which will require the bureaucracy to speak closely with the ldp .
so , without the cyclically adjusted budget cycle , the dpj will be forced to impose a supplementary budget plan for the ldp , and it must accept the next annual budget , which reflects the democratic party ’ s 政策 policies .
thus , the dpj has announced plans to abolish the ldp ’ s rules , eliminating caps on budget applications , so that it would be able to set its own budget on its own budget .
but time is short , and few democratic lawmakers have the legislative experience and budgetary expertise needed to achieve the goal .
in order to control the bureaucracy , the democrats plan for 100 lawmakers to fill the ministries ’ top leadership , and appoint three dozen political appointees to work on the office of the prime minister ’ s office .
unfortunately , democrats rejected a 公务员 civil-service reform act , which could have allowed the democrats to replace mandarins with political appointees .
the democrats , however , seem unprepared to tame the bureaucracy , and thus may eventually have to accept them .
the superiority of the mandarins goes back to the unique historical development of japan ’ s modern history .
unlike in europe , japan has established a state in a strong civil society .
in fact , the full range of “ social ” construction began only after the 1868 meiji restoration began , leading to the balance of power to the state .
the mandarins survived world war ii with the postwar us occupation , and they also survived the democratic government ’ s term .
the liberal democratic party ( ldp ) and the mandarins created a regular process , with the mandarins responsible for the cabinet ’ s bill , legislation to review , and then submit to the final draft resolution , and then submit to the parliamentary vote .
since the ldp ’ s recent alliance with coalition partners to control the parliament , the legislative process became the interaction between the liberal democratic party ’ s headquarters and the mandarins ’ mandarins .
parliament played a mere role .
indeed , under the ldp ’ s one-party system , the constitutional mechanism has become an integral part of the japanese government ’ s polity .
the dpj government will collide directly with the bureaucracy , partly because the democrats are unable to recruit enough qualified policymakers .
the mandarins have maintained their privileged position in these areas , thanks partly to the tax system ’ s resistance to the emergence of non-profit institutions , especially think tanks , and independent policy knowledge is needed .
moreover , perhaps anticipating changes in power , the mandarins have pushed the annual personnel change in the main ministries ’ top ministries .
so what will the ldp do ?
after losing power , it will control the redistribution of government money .
failure to deliver on the benefits of their supporters could lead to a breakup of the break-up , because the ldp has never been able to support the manipulation of power and machines through the connectivity of local communities , occupations , and indigenous communities .
only by absorbing new blood and rebuilding a strong ideology will the ldp be able to regain power .
the dpj ’ s grassroots support is even weaker , so the mandarins are most likely to use their standard of divide-and-rule tactics , 诱骗 the democrats , like the ldp , to use state funds and government contracts to give back major supporters of trade unions and other interests .
the birth of the dpj government could still be a turning point .
a transition to “ social ” power has occurred .
if the democrats were to escape the control of the mandarins by concentrating on policy decisions , as they wish to do , japan can become a more dynamic democracy , with a better two-party system , and more willing to play the role of international leadership .
a jobless recovery ?
cambridge – who will suffer the most from the wall street storm and the ensuing global recession in 2008-2009 ?
not the bankers and financiers who created this disaster .
some financiers , like bernard madoff , have tried to jail .
but , while madoff ’ s scandal is the tip of an iceberg of rampant financial penalties , most of the usual financiers didn ’ t need to worry about arrest , because their actions are often the only marginal edges of law , or because they are often more subtle than outright fraud .
some bank bosses would be left behind , but it would be massively compensated to relieve their pain – for example , the $ 50 million “ golden 降落伞 ” of the bank of america ’ s bank of america , as fred 歌德 , the royal bank of scotland ’ s bank of scotland , receives $ 25 million .
yet , after receiving emergency funding , guarantees , and low interest rates , many banks have been paying huge bonuses for top managers , while vigorously opposing reforms aimed at limiting their risk-taking and compensation .
the big losers from this economic disaster are workers in those developed countries that favor laissez-faire capitalism .
from 2007 to october 2009 , the us lost nearly eight million jobs , and employment rates fell from 63 % to 17.3 % .
the unemployment rate at the end of 2009 was more than 10 % , the longest duration of the unemployment rate since the great depression , and millions of people have worked shorter hours , and millions of people have lost their jobs in their jobs .
europe ’ s advanced countries , canada , and japan have also suffered serious unemployment , and they will continue to take a long time .
spain ’ s unemployment rate , which allows temporary contracts to exist widely , is the largest , because the spanish workers were fired as fast as us workers .
some countries – for example , germany , sweden , and south korea – pay for companies , allowing them to retain official workers , “ hide ” unemployment .
this may be effective in the short term , but it can not be sustained over time .
in the united states , where the economic recovery under president bill clinton has been jobless , there was a jobless recovery in the latter part of the 1990 ’ s .
in the early 1990 ’ s , sweden suffered a massive recession from a housing bubble and banking crisis , rising from 1.8 % in 1990 to 9.6 % in 1994 , to 5 % in 2001 .
after 16 years of crisis , the unemployment rate reached 6.2 % – more than triple the level in 1990 .
in 1997 , south korea was hit not only by the asian financial crisis , but also by insisting that the us and the international monetary fund continue to raise interest rates and implement reforms similar to the washington consensus .
employment has recovered , but mainly because of the limited benefits of welfare , low wages , and little job security .
south korea ’ s gap between rich and poor rises from moderate moderate to the second high ( after the us ) among advanced countries .
weakness in the job market has severely harmed the economy ’ s health and individual wellbeing .
the economic losses that young people and workers who are seeking a first job in a weak job market are affected by the economic loss of their lives .
studies of happiness show that unemployment is a blow to happiness as much as loss of a 至亲 .
the us is hard to achieve full employment anytime soon .
from 1993 to 1998 , the us created millions of jobs , and the employment rate rose by 5.4 percentage points .
if employment begins to rise at this rate in 2010 , it will be reached before 2015 .
the slow recovery in the us economy will drag down other developed countries , reducing their employment .
a long and painful high unemployment rate is the opposite of what most experts believe in flexible american economic models .
from the early 1990 ’ s , many analysts viewed america ’ s lax trade unions , any hiring relationship , limited legal protections for work , and frequent job rotation as a major factor in the unemployment rate of most eu countries .
many oecd countries have launched various kinds of reform reforms to improve their economies .
viewing flexibility as a key factor in employment is no longer tenable .
the oecd took a careful look at their preferred policy reforms in 2009 , finding that such reforms are inadequate to help countries adapt to a recession caused by the financial sector .
according to the oecd , “ there is no strong reason to believe that recent structural reforms will effectively reduce the oecd ’ s labor-market sensitivity to severe economic contraction . ”
the lesson of the recession is clear .
the weakness of capitalism is not the labor market , but the financial markets .
in the worst case , the recession in the labor market would be only modest , but capital markets ’ decline would hurt society considerably , while workers , not the financial disaster , are responsible for the worst .
moreover , globalization means that us capital markets will have a significant impact on global capital markets .
we owe the workers who are harmed by the recession , and the need for financial systems to transform real economic development , rather than enriching the financiers .
this means changing the incentives and rules of the financial sector .
other countries ’ economic and jobs are also at stake , so they must also push for meaningful financial reform in the us .

truth and consequences
new york – the recent re-election of colombia ’ s president , juan manuel santos , has brought hope to an end to the country ’ s decades-long conflict .
but , like many other peace processes , finding a balance between the stability pact and the terrible injustices that it recognizes in conflict may be difficult to achieve .
many countries and groups from nepal to northern ireland have been struggling to address the legacy of ethnic , ideological , religious divisions , and violence , but successful precedents are rare .
after all , a mechanism for dealing with post-conflict reconciliation , truth , and justice has not been enough .
but the victims complain that its procedures are slow ; many bosnian serbs believe that courts are selective and politically motivated .
the government ’ s agreement to establish a truth commission between nepal ’ s government and maoist guerrillas was delayed for seven years .
when legislators finally enacted the authorizing act of may 2013 , the victim found the commission ’ s right to recommend amnesty for crimes against humanity , violated international principles and un guidance .
the good friday agreement , which northern ireland ’ s termination of the bloodshed and initiated reconciliation , deserves to be praised for the victims ’ frustration – a mechanism to establish a mechanism to investigate past crimes – with a strong political backlash .
peace talks are right to fear that criminal liability for past crimes would threaten the security of their leaders and supporters .
many are based on a misinterpretation of south africa ’ s experience that truth commissions are more “ soft ” than justice justice .
they are thus willing to put these mechanisms in peace agreements ( conveniently ignoring the victims ’ forced choice between justice and truth ) .
one should expect that , as the truth commissions become part of a transitional justice , former armed militants have become increasingly worried about their reputations and political credibility .
understanding the truth is fraught with unease and anguish , but it will have serious consequences for those who have reason to fear sanctions .
in fact , the truth about the truth and transitional justice of the truth commissions is not because it is punished for the worst crimes ; on the contrary , they have enacted a comprehensive , comprehensive law and policy based on rights .
the recent symposium , hosted by the kofi annan foundation and the international transitional justice center , concluded that the truth commissions are contributing the most to peace by restoring the rule of law , recognizing victims ’ rights , and supporting institutional reforms .
but the truth is that effective , independent , and legal .
half-measures is unlikely .
so it is never like nepal to turn the truth into a symbolic institution that alleviates local or international public opinion .
even if the broader task and functions of the task were established entirely through well-intentioned intentions , the truth commissions often lack the necessary resources , leading to further frustration and disillusion .
moreover , the commission should not be allowed to lead or participate in people with questionable rights , or risk undermining the process .
in short , the truth commissions must be adapted to the country ’ s circumstances .
we are already seeing the nature and resolution of conflicts in bosnia , colombia , nepal , northern ireland , and elsewhere ; so the commission should be given the principle of leverage .
“ one-size-fits-all ” solutions are unfit for any country .
it is important to understand and implement the details of each case of transitional justice .
it is political leaders ’ best mistake to ignore victims or conceal the truth when trying to sign peace agreements .
but achieving a lasting condition for lasting peace is to recognize the rights of victims .
no one ’ s political agreement is at the expense of human suffering and the dignity of victims .
finally , we must recognize the lessons of the past : justice is not just an ideal ; it is also investment in a better future .

interest rates are high enough to curb stock market speculation , and would contain construction and other forms of investment , boost unemployment , and bring the economy into recession .
