the albanian miracle
tirana – five years ago , albania faced an ominous situation .
as greece and italy suffer from the euro crisis , the country ’ s remittances and capital inflows have both fallen and the economy slowed .
the fiscal deficit soared to more than 7 % of gdp , and to the extent that external financial markets have collapsed and domestic interest rates soared , with fiscal deficits largely limited to credit .
moreover , the country ’ s distribution firms are in the midst of a financial crisis and financial crisis , because it can not afford to pay for electricity from producers of electricity generation .
the arrears of governments and utilities have led to a sharp increase in non-performing loans in the banking system .
it is there that all the ingredients of a disaster are there .
fast-forward to the current : in agriculture , mining , manufacturing , energy , tourism , and business services , respectively , the economy is growing at a brisk 4.2 % pace .
at a time when emerging-market economies like argentina , turkey , nigeria , and south africa face sharp declines in their exchange rates and rising interest rates , albania ’ s interest rate is at its lowest level and a persistent appreciation of the currency .
the country ’ s current sovereign interest-rate spreads are among the lowest in the same ratings hierarchy , suggesting that markets believe that rating agencies are too careless .
as a european north korea ruled by communist dictator 霍查 霍查 , albania ’ s per capita income level is now 25 % in germany .
as it stands , it will reach germany ’ s current income level by 32 years .
while economists are blamed for a variety of frustrating events , multilateral institutions such as the international monetary fund and the world bank have been criticized for failing to provide the appropriate advice to countries , and that albania is surprisingly convinced that it is .
what is the secret of albania ’ s turnaround ?
for starters , when many countries delay the clock so long as they delay the timing , prime minister 拉玛 拉玛 called the international monetary fund in september 2013 .
his government then negotiated a program that enabled albania to finance its fiscal order while achieving fiscal support .
the three-year plan was about two years ago , and the debt-to-gdp ratio continued to fall .
this year , the value fell by 2.5 % , even as the country is expanding its public investment budget significantly .
to achieve growth in the process of fiscal consolidation , it will require taking advantage of other factors – especially exports – to pull the economy .
the experience of albania ’ s research program , which has led harvard ’ s international development research center since 2013 , is not due to luck , but because people have worked tirelessly to eliminate bottlenecks and take advantage of the bottlenecks .
in this process , albania eschewed the temptation to focus on the db indicators that are focused on certain indicators of doing business , which assumes that randomly selected and following some international best practices can reap some results .
instead , the authorities adopted a diagnostic approach to determine its policies ’ priorities .
this approach has led to plenty of ideas that proved highly effective .
in agriculture , the development of a firm ’ s development helps farmers acquire advanced technologies and more lucrative markets , creating a boom in vegetable exports .
in the power sector , the government has used an unconventional strategy to change people ’ s electricity theft and liability , leaving the distribution company cash flow to nearly 2 % of gdp in 2015 .
likewise , the consultative group in manufacturing and tourism has identified areas needed to improve .
albania is investing in repairing its old cities , and it is now targeting 100 villages with strong agricultural tourism potential but just as it is in poor regions .
no wonder tourism has risen double-digit growth .
moreover , the country ’ s foreign ambassadors are now taking a concerted strategy to promote foreign investment through direct engagement .
policymakers are now leading albania ’ s diaspora to play an important role – because they are an important source of talent , investment , market opportunities , and business ingenuity .
these innovations are not just the national level .
市长 维 , the mayor of tirana , has tripled municipal income since taking office in 2015 and used the benefits to become one of the most pleasant cities in the region .
albania ’ s capital has won several european awards for its high-quality development of high-quality urban spaces and to address human mobility and environmental problems .
the lesson for other countries is clear .
to succeed in difficult circumstances , the government realized that its dilemma and weakness are clear and set to define and develop their own goals and seek ways to achieve their aspirations .
in the process , each country is not in the cards .
international financial assistance , spearheaded by the imf and the development financial institutions , can help .
but countries must figure out when and how best to use them .
they can enhance governments ’ capacity , but they can not substitute for government commitments .
the lesson is clear in the eu : when considering the absorption of albania and other western balkan countries , it is important not only to focus on these countries ’ circumstances but also to focus on the enthusiasm of their own ideals .
for most of its history , albania looked hopeless .
but despair itself can not survive forever .
now albania ’ s transformation has become a source of hope for the rest of us .
toward a more reflective planet
cambridge – the last time the atmosphere contains the same amount of co2 with the same amount of co2 today , the same is true of three million years ago , when sea levels are higher than ten meters today .
climate models have long worked hard to replicate the dramatic fluctuations in sea levels – until now .
indeed , for the first time in history , a high-quality antarctic ice and climate model can mimic these large swings .
this is 智能科学 , but it is disastrous .
the new model suggests that melting in antarctica alone can increase global sea levels by one meter – well above previous estimates .
making matters worse , models suggest that even if the extraordinary success of cutting emissions is successful , it can not save the west antarctic ice sheet , which would eventually increase the rise in sea levels .
a mere one meter of sea-level rise would be able to risk the risk that a city from miami to mumbai will face the city , leading to massive economic disruption .
to this end , albedo modification – a kind of geological project aimed at increasing the earth ’ s atmosphere – has a great deal .
for example , injecting synthetic aerosols that reflect sunlight into the stratosphere can help contain the warming of greenhouse gases .
the mechanism is similar to that of the summer : white reflect sunlight and makes the appearance of something more cooler ; and 深色 absorb sunlight and heat up .
to be sure , even in the best scenario , solar geoengineering alone can not stabilize the world ’ s climate .
we must stop pumping carbon pollution into the atmosphere , and learn how to remove carbon emissions in the atmosphere .
this is why most resources should be used to combat climate change .
but , as recent research shows , emissions cuts alone can not save the west antarctic ice sheet and prevent catastrophic sea-level rise .
if , however , albedo modification is a modest change in albedo modification , there is an opportunity to stop rising temperatures , help to keep the world within 1.5°c of pre-industrial levels , and the more radical goal reached in paris last december .
( it should be noted , given the 碳循环 thaw , that , even today , the world ’ s temperature increases could reach 1.5° celsius . )
today , most of the world ’ s climate models have explored albedo modification , and both find that the process does have the potential to mitigate climate change .
beyond limiting aggregate warming , it can help to contain rising peak temperatures and reduce the risk of destructive heat waves .
and it seems particularly effective in reducing extreme rainfall , which is unlikely to be minimized .
albedo modification remains uncertain and risky , partly because organized research is too few .
and , in fact , albedo modification will undoubtedly make something worse .
but no climate model suggests that a modest intervention would make any region worse off .
moreover , the huge potential benefits ( $ 1.5 million ) compared to low direct costs – all of which require only billions of dollars – compare sharply .
in fact , albedo modification is very cheap , and direct costs will not be decisive .
rather , it is a risk trade-off – and more research is needed to assess .
given the lack of knowledge , smart people will not deploy albedo modification today .
but it should not be ignored .
after all , no one would argue that we should abandon a promising cancer drug without confirmation .
the us national academy of sciences first focused on the issue in a 1983 report , as the “ climate change . ”
in 1992 and 2015 , the us academy of sciences recommended careful research .
the main environmental organization , such as the environmental protection fund and the natural-resource defense council , supports a careful range of studies .
but these programs are not .
one reason is that the resources to worry about other approaches are dispersed .
of course , there are trade-offs .
but the us , for example , has a climate science budget of around $ 3 billion per year .
a solar geoengineering project for solar geoengineering will cost only tens of millions of dollars annually .
perhaps , but if you had a pleasant effect on the mice simply because you had a therapeutic cancer cure , you must be mad .
and , indeed , one can imagine that a concerted effort to change albedo modification can spur action to reduce emissions , as evidenced by photos of the effects of chemotherapy .
whichever response , the moral imperative to explore the technology that will protect the poorest and most vulnerable communities in this century seems to outweigh the piecemeal concerns that doing so could weaken the incentive to pursue solutions that would yield significant benefits to future generations .
china has launched a limited study of albedo modification .
the us has not .
given that albedo modification is an essential study of open , transparent , and international research – which is what the us is doing – it is a grave failure .
as it stands , the us government should lead albedo modification .
even if albedo modification does not , the dividends generated by these studies will be enormous , because it would bring more pressure on emissions reduction .
and , if successful , its social , environmental , and economic returns will be sweeping .

securing mutual dependence
london – during the cold war , the certainty of “ mutually assured destruction ” of the “ mutually assured destruction ” of the nuclear arms race has brought the arms race away from disaster : 人若犯 , and the fate of both sides .
today , a very different race is underway – a contest that is crucial to the earth ’ s key resources , which could destabilize the stability of the world ’ s critical regions .
countries increasingly rely on other countries ’ food , water , and energy , which requires a global response to sustainability .
unlike the nuclear arms race in the twentieth century , the resource security agenda is not linear .
mutually assured destruction was written in both sides of the cold war .
in a race to the resources of the twenty-first century , no actors directly or indirectly threaten other actors to reduce food and energy exports , but all have systemic risks .
countries inevitably become interdependent , and the decline in climate change , water stress , and ecological resilience has increased this volatility .
the world ’ s resources are limited and scarce , and countries and companies will be forced to make decisions that affect each other .
to guide this interdependence , the planet ’ s security index , the planet ’ s security project , shows that countries are vulnerable to increasing risk exposure to governments and companies , unless we have a more strategic approach and sustainable investment .
the esi identifies four areas of mutual dependence that may affect global security over the next few decades :
· 梗阻 points .
national energy , water , food , and land demand can not be met without a tradeoff between limited available resources .
when the resources are not sufficient to meet demand , they reached 梗阻 points .
in china and india , for example , this means that some regions will not be able to develop enough water in the short term to produce coal and irrigate large tracts of crops .
in china , 60 % of planned coal-fired power plants will be built in water-stressed regions .
· food .
many countries ’ dependence on food , water , and energy imports has created new opportunities for trade and investment , but it also exposes the country to key weaknesses .
australia , for example , is a big coal exporter , but most of the refined fuel relies on imports , with fuel reserves worth only three days .
the challenges of mutual dependence are particularly acute in food terms .
the esi shows that some countries – including egypt , peru , and the united arab emirates – are heavily dependent on grain imports from a few suppliers .
moreover , grain suppliers are vulnerable to extreme weather shocks , which could constrain their continued supply of supplies , which would allow imports to suffer .
in 2010 , for example , russia imposed a ban on wheat exports for a severe drought .
the resulting increase in food prices is believed to have played an important role in egypt ’ s revolution .
· teleconnections .
predicting systemic ecological risks will become increasingly important for sectors like reinsurance and infrastructure investment .
“ teleconnections ” refer to weather events that are geographically linked to one another .
for example , tropical rainforests play a critical role in maintaining stable weather and rainfall , helping to play a “ pump ” for water transmission across regions .
deforestation is thus destabilizing weather patterns , exacerbating the frequency and severity of extreme events like floods and droughts .
the resulting responsibility for the resulting industrial and financial sectors is clear .
in brazil , for example , deforestation in the amazon has slowed markedly over the past five years , but brazil has lost 100 hectares of tropical forests , and the extreme weather in brazil has been rising steadily in 2011 alone .
· 瓶颈 bottlenecks : agricultural systems are reaching resource limits , continuing governance gaps that limit their ability to ensure food security , dignity , and ecological stewardship .
companies , investors , governments , and society are facing key barriers to the availability of food that is urgently needed around the world , where land ownership is not guaranteed ; and the loss of 重要 ( for example , fertilizer and pesticides ) has reduced the resilience of food production ; and the loss of key ecosystems , such as fertilizer and pesticides , has eroded the resilience of food production .
in some parts of india , for example , these problems exist .
insecure land ownership has left smallholder farmers unable to make improvements in productive investments ; allowing the 的 of 政策 to produce excessive water extraction ; and , despite rapid economic growth , millions of people remain unprotected .
countries and companies will increasingly need to invest in sustainable land to circumvent these resource risks .
the 2015 global framework will be agreed to address climate change , coordinate responses to natural disasters , and guide the global development agenda .
some of the multilateral processes – particularly ambitious global climate agreements – have been slow , with no geopolitical interest .
in the past , the demand for high-level nuclear governance is urgent and clear , but it needs to create a common understanding of the risks of risk and opportunity .
successful multilateral responses , such as the nuclear non-proliferation treaty , remain supported by more flexible global platforms such as the nuclear threat initiative , based on relationships and trust outside of formal multilateralism .
this year , world leaders will discuss the next generation of sustainability , development , and climate frameworks , and , in the process , they need to put security and mutual dependence at the heart of the response .
here , too , the world needs to create informal platforms to supplement traditional multilateralism .
in particular , the old divisions between rich and poor countries and their responsibilities must be redefined .
china , brazil , india , and other g-20 economies and other g-20 economies have proposed reform of the global governance system , and their vulnerability to resource security should be encouraging .
only then will the world go to improve the security of all .

living big data
cambridge – big data comes from the digital traces that we have used to use credit cards , mobile phones , or networks .
but theoretical effectiveness does not mean that in the real world , complex human interactions are not always fully captured , even if you use the most cash .
big data requires a massive experiment .
for example , my own lab is building a web site based on the google map , which uses digital traces of digital traces , infant mortality , crime rates , changes in gdp , and other social indicators , and shows daily updates .
this new capability allows viewers to understand whether , say , a local government plan is a failure or a failure .
but , while these remarkable visualization tools can significantly increase transparency and public knowledge , their role remains limited when it comes to solving social problems .
one reason is that such abundant data flows have generated unreliable correlations .
even if using conventional scientific methods no longer works ; in measuring the potential relationship between measurement and measurement , our standard statistical tools can not produce meaningful results .
without knowing all possible alternatives , we can not reach a limited , testable conclusion .
and if we can no longer rely on laboratory experiments to test causality , it must be tested in real , real-time data .
this will require transcending the closed , 以 , and 提问 lab process , which uses us to use our ideas more frequently than ever before .
in order to understand what is going on in reality , we must build a living lab – a community that is willing to try to try a new approach – that is , to act as a mice .
one example of a living lab is the “ open data cities , ” which i co-authored with the italian telecommunications ( telecoms ) , the spanish telecommunications institute , research universities , Bruno , data-driven design , and local companies .
what matters is that the life of the living lab has been informed and approved by all participants ; they know that they are involved in a huge experiment , aimed at creating better lifestyles .
a major challenge for living laboratories is to protect individual privacy without undermining the potential of a better government .
for example , the pilot experiment will experiment with the “ new deal of data ” that i propose , and users will pass a greater control of their personal data through trust – such as our new PDS ( personal data store ) systems – to their personal data .
one hopes that the ability to share data in safe sharing data while protecting privacy can encourage individuals , companies , and governments to communicate their ideas , thereby boosting productivity and creativity throughout the city .
but the biggest difficulty of using big data to create a better society is the intuitive understanding of social physics .
while it is extremely dense , data and modern computing can give us a lot of details about how the details of society are made , and that the original mathematical mathematical models have too many variables and complex relationships that are difficult to understand .
what is needed is a dialogue between some form of human intuition and a compelling reality of big data – a dialogue that is currently lacking in the current management and government system .
to deploy big data effectively , people must be able to understand and interpret the statistics .
this requires new understanding of human behavior and social dynamics that transcend traditional economic and political models .
only by developing the science and language of social physics can we make big data the world we are willing to live in .
peril and promise in algeria
madrid – five years after the start of the so-called arab spring , these revolutions were initially characterized by great economic expectations , which are largely dashed .
in many countries , revolution has evolved into a brutal long-term conflict , with no solution .
in all of these conflicts , the international community has paid little attention to countries like algeria , where the revolutionary spirit of the revolution has not yet been fully recognized .
but algeria ’ s fate is now on the international community ’ s radar – and it is far too late .
on february 7 , algeria ’ s parliament approved a constitutional reform package that stipulates that the president will serve only two ( the leader of the 总统 war of independence ) , and recognized some basic freedoms .
these steps , starting in 2011 , aimed at strengthening algeria ’ s democracy ; but many criticize algeria not enough .
indeed , the “ consensus ” of algerian politics has been paralyzed for years to come .
the disease ’ s 缠身 bouteflika has not experienced a year of public discourse , and the results of the 2019 presidential election are problematic .
the effort to cut security and intelligence authority over the last three years – as mohamed Mediene , who has been chief of intelligence since 1990 – was forced to retire – a problem that highlights domestic political tensions .
major external challenges have exacerbated algeria ’ s situation .
in particular , oil and gas industries account for 97 % of algeria ’ s export revenues , and the price collapse since june 2014 has left the algerian economic model untenable .
the decline in oil revenues means that algeria ’ s government can not maintain a variety of subsidies that traditionally serve as social 稳定剂 , help to prevent unrest .
the government has already had to raise taxes , while raising prices for fuel , power , and gas .
if oil prices are not falling quickly , and algeria ’ s leaders are forced to take more drastic steps , social stability could collapse .
of course , some factors help to contain social unrest – the people ’ s memories of the brutal civil war in the 1990s , with more than 150,000 people killed in the war .
but memories fade over time , and the new generation of young people lacks the fear of social conflict over social conflict .
in this social context , the protests , if not violent , are not a distant matter .
to avoid this outcome , algeria ’ s government must diversify its economy quickly .
but such concerted action is difficult in the current political environment , especially given that governments focus increasingly on security challenges in algeria ’ s neighborhood .
tunisia ’ s revolution , the war in libya , the 阿雷格 of the malian diaspora , and the most important of algeria ’ s 因阿迈 gas plant , the terrorist attacks in algeria in 2013 , brought algeria ’ s leaders increasingly to regional security .
although the constitution explicitly prohibits other countries from interfering in other countries , algeria is clearly keen to ensure that its neighbors are stable and capable of preventing extreme forces – witness its foreign policy .
in libya , for example , algeria is supporting an inclusive process of reconciling all parties , in order to support the un ’ s efforts to stabilize libya .
the us and europe have recognized algeria ’ s leadership and cooperation in anti-terror operations around the neighborhood .
for the eu , further ties to algeria are particularly important , because the stability of the region ’ s neighbors in north africa and the sahel is in the interest of both sides , and algeria has helped to improve the eu ’ s energy security .
a key way algeria can help improve regional security cooperation is to rebuild diplomatic relations with morocco .
to be sure , the two countries have been wrestling over four decades of dispute over the sovereignty of western sahara .
but the economic , business , and security-related dividends that reset cooperation should be sufficient to persuade them to reconsider their positions .
if the two north african giants are willing to recognize the common interest , rebuilding relations , restoring relations with the maghreb would be possible .
algeria ’ s influence across africa will also increase .
as it stands , algeria ’ s influence in africa is set to grow .
some argue that the algerian candidate may become chair of the african union ’ s commission after the end of next july ’ s term .
to this end , algeria ’ s consistent support for the au and its contribution to regional security – exemplified in the role of the mali peace agreement and the host of libya ’ s negotiations – is good for it .
if successful , algeria will become the first north african country to lead the au .
the severe challenges posed by falling oil prices and severe regional conditions suggest that algeria desperately needs change .
but if algeria ’ s government acts to unleash the political system , achieving economic diversification , and strengthening diplomatic efforts , algeria could become stronger and more influential than ever .
washington , dc – in the tenth century bc , china ’ s steel system has produced thousands of thousands of people to use thousands of people to use their lives and 祭祀 .
in the case of this early production , the process of building a process requires coordination and coordination among workers across a wide range of workers , which , in precise sequencing , perform separate tasks .
a thousand years later , a similar complex process was used to produce famous 秦始皇 兵马俑 .
according to the asian art museum in san francisco , these statues “ make up assembly systems for production production and commercial base . ”
some scholars speculated that these early forms of regulation have played an important role in shaping chinese society .
together with other factors , people have embraced the social philosophy that emphasizes the hierarchy of hierarchy in hierarchy and convince people that they are right to do so .
when industrial factories were born in europe in the nineteenth century , even staunch critics of capitalism like engel acknowledged that greater production was necessary , regardless of whether economic institutions were capitalist or socialist .
in the twentieth century , theorists such as · winner extended this thinking to technology .
he thought , for example , that the bomb should be considered “ a political product , ” because its “ lethal nature requires it to be controlled by centralized and rigid orders . ”
now we can extend this thinking to far further .
consider machine-learning algorithms , the most important general-purpose technology used today .
these algorithms are using real-world examples to mimic human cognition , which is now ubiquitous .
but to make full use of these technologies , organizations must redefine the task of human tasks to forecast tasks , which are better suited to the advantages of the new african government .
a key feature of machine-learning algorithms is that their performance improves as data increase .
thus , using these algorithms creates a technological drive that would inform people ’ s information about information and availability .
as in the big production system , they have “ inherently political ” ( inherently political ) , because their core functions require some social behavior and blocking other social behavior .
in particular , machine-learning algorithms are directly related to individual privacy aspirations .
a system based on open and accessible information about individual members ’ information seems to fit the communitarians , such as 社会学家 奇奥 , who believe that restrictions on privacy are the means to enforce social norms .
but , unlike communitarians , algorithms don ’ t care about social norms .
they are focused on making predictions better , and that can be achieved by transforming a growing number of human lives into 集来 data .
moreover , while technological coercion will translate individualist westerners into accidental communitarians , it also allows them to accept a culture of meritocracy based on algorithmic assessment .
whether in the workplace or in school , we are accustomed to using impersonal tools to assess our eligibility and then distribute our place at a level level .
to be sure , algorithmic assessment is not new .
a generation ago , scholars such as oscar h. h. H warned that we are turning into a society that is documenting and ranked , and requires more accountability and redress .
but , unlike modern machine-learning algorithms , old assessment tools are well understood .
they make decisions based on relevant normative and empirical factors .
for example , it is no secret that many credit-card debts have hurt one ’ s creditworthiness .
on the contrary , new machine-learning technologies 深挖 the big data sets to find correlations that are predictive but poorly understood .
在职 , algorithms can track employees ’ conversations , and how much time they spend on where they spend lunch , telephone , or meetings .
in a system of algorithmic elites , what is required is a good standard .
still , technology is not destiny .
we have decided before our technological decisions .
business leaders and policymakers can develop and deploy technologies according to their institutions .
we have the ability to assemble privacy nets around the human lives of humans , protect people from the effects of harmful data , and demand that algorithms balance the values of accuracy and fairness , accountability , and transparency .
but , before we follow the natural flow of algorithmic logic , more meritocratic and communitarian culture is inevitable .
this gradual change will have far-reaching implications for our democratic institutions and political structures .
the chinese scholar daniel bell and jang 维维 argue that the main political alternative to liberal democracy in the west is in china ’ s evolving socialist system .
in china , collective decisions do not require citizens to make explicit decisions to legitimize them , generally in the case of the government , especially when it comes to monitoring .
ordinary chinese are largely limited to participating in local elections .
at the same time , national leaders are selected through a meritocratic process , as guardians of people ’ s wellbeing .
liberal democracy is unlikely to be a political system entirely .
but if today ’ s business and consumer culture continues , we will soon have more of a meritocratic and communitarian tradition in china than in our own individualist and liberal traditions .
if we are to change course , we must put our own political imperatives ahead of technology .
the sunni-shia divide
baghdad – in the first parliamentary election of 2011 , iraq has been holding the first parliamentary election since the us military withdrawal in 2011 , which was held in the context of escalating violence .
can the new government reestablish order and address the many pressing challenges that iraq faces ?
the challenge is truly daunting .
the authorities must address the fundamental constitutional issue , such as iraq , as a confederation , rebuild civil society , reforming state institutions , reviving the economy , and eradicate waste and corruption in the oil sector .
but perhaps the most difficult challenge is bridging the sectarian divide between the iraqi shia and sunni citizens .
this split is also evident in other arab countries , such as syria , lebanon , the gulf states , and yemen , with the momentum sweeping the muslim world ( including pakistan , malaysia , and indonesia ) .
is this a historical parenthesis , or is islam ’ s two largest sects in perpetual tension ?
there is no doubt that there have been periods of peace in the two communities .
but the most important thing today is that shia and sunnis have emphasized different differences in the past , and historical memory can be distorted – and even fabricated – to create mistrust and loathing .
the first muslim dynasty of the shia dynasty – 倭 王朝 ( grand food staple ) – was ousted in the first 75 years of the prophet mohammed 叔父 , who was the prophet of the prophet muhammad 叔父 .
this has led to a brief sunni-shia settlement that has many of the most valuable incidents that later accompany each other .
in particular , much has been learned from the different legacies of the 哈里发 caliphate , 1180 , and the last caliphate of abbas ’ s successor , jabhat al .

iraq ’ s current political leaders need to draw lessons from these historical lessons and ensure that all of iraq ’ s factions are not marginalized or discriminated against , which is derived from the entire islamic world .
in pakistan , for example , sectarian killing is almost daily ; in malaysia , few shia have been seen as existential threats ; and , in saudi arabia and many other countries , wahhabi forces tend to declare hunting against a hostile faction .
politics and power struggles explain much of this violence and mistrust .
the gulf states ’ leaders , for example , believe that hegemonic hegemony in iran is the basis for its shia population ’ s loyalty .
malaysia ’ s political parties , for their part , appealed to shia targets for their purpose , thereby attracting votes and consolidating power .
after the us-led invasion of iraq , syria and its regional allies were determined to defend the new regional balance of power that is good for its favorable directions .
but political calculation can not explain everything .
the fall of saddam hussein in 2003 provided a good example of how the same political event is different from different sectarian interpretations .
the us ’ s destruction of iraq ’ s states has led to a new and unstable order that seeks to correct the sunni dominance of many years .
but , as the sudden loss of power in the sunni world has triggered a backlash against muslims in the muslim world , the conclusion is that the shia and us collusion in iraq have been strengthened by events in syria .
according to this view , the shia have merely recovered the “ history ” of its perpetrators and fifth columnists .
historically , the shi ’ ism was in the midst of a 勾结 勾结 that led to baghdad ’ s fall , killing the last caliphate of the monarchy , killing the muslim world ’ s “ grand unified ” – abbas ’ s demise .
some medieval muslim historians point out that the shia 宰相 ibn al- ‘ alqami , ‘ Alqami , had collaborated with the 蒙古人 .
恰米 ’ s story was the preserve of some scholars , and now it is the central part of the sunni-shia dispute .
indeed , “ ‘ alqami ” is “ ‘ ‘ alqami ” – “ ‘ alqami , ” which is now applied to the shia as apostates .
social media forums are riddled with the struggle between shia and american invaders .
many even call the iraqi shia ‘ alqami ’ s offspring , and put iraqi prime minister nouri al-maliki as the modern-day 恰米 .
these diatribes reflect the polarization of iraqis ’ historical memory .
while full historical evidence suggests that the two sides were once peaceful , many – whether for ignorance of history , or the need to maintain a certain version of a certain version of the truth – are more willing to believe that the 变节 of hatred and betrayal will be the order of the day .
more important , the current situation reflects the lack of wisdom , accountability , and basic respect for political and religious leaders , who prefer to fuel rather than 消弭 the conflict .
sadly , intolerance has become a general phenomenon .
it is too late for the faith and history of other factions , and some of the remaining understandings are overwhelmed by sectarian anger and 恶意中伤 .
as long as sunnis and shia refuse to think about their past , it is difficult to foresee the future of peaceful coexistence .
and if political and religious leaders are unable or unwilling to seek compromise , they must rely on like-minded individuals , organizations , and civil-society institutions to rebuild mutual respect and find ways to cooperate .
and that requires knowledge , patience , and , above all , open thinking and mentality .

america ’ s roads pick up
beijing – today , the “ green shoots ” of recovery have withered , and the debate over fiscal stimulus is being scaled up .
in the united states , those who advocate a stimulus package believe that the $ 787 billion stimulus package to offset private-sector spending is really wishful thinking .
the unemployment rate soared , beyond expectations .
combine this with the continuing decline in house prices , and it is understandable that consumption remains low .
while banks have been recapitalized , they had little to do with their continued business balance .
贷之风 continues to limit investment .
if there is a new stimulus package in february , that need is more urgent .
yet the case against the introduction of new stimulus programs is strong .
the us federal deficit has reached 12 % of gdp , and it is alarming ; public debt is expected to double , to 80 % .
it seems unrealistic to think that the us can repay its debt growth , as it did in finland and sweden in the 1990 ’ s , when the financial crisis hit the financial crisis .
given this , greater deficit spending will only stoke fears of future high taxes and high inflation .
this would prompt a renewed global imbalance .
and that prospect will not reassure consumers and investors .
economics can be hedged , and politics all points to it .
the us congress has no stomach for new stimulus programs .
there are already fierce criticisms of congress ’ s fiscal cliff .
the first stimulus is slow , and it will take a long time to be fully demonstrated , giving ammunition to politicians in parliament who favor the electorate .
the effectiveness of the 计划 program has been disappointing , leaving people and parliaments no longer supporting more public funds to recapitalize them .
so , even if some believe that , according to the logic of economics , active fiscal policy is imperative , and they must acknowledge that such policies are politically supportive .
the second stimulus is far from guaranteed .
if , say , aggregate demand in the global economy expands , it will come from a place .
not europe , but also japan , whose liabilities are higher than the us , the demographic outlook is worse than the us .
that is only the emerging-market economies – for example , china .
the problem is that china has done much to stimulate domestic demand , expanding government spending , and guiding bank lending .
as a result , china ’ s stock market and housing prices have begun to bite .
in may , real-estate prices rose 18 % year on year .
china ’ s official starting to worry about bubbles is understandable .
the most obvious response is to expand import spending .
china can buy more industrial machinery , transport equipment , 炼钢 materials , all of which china imports from the us .
by increasing spending on capital flows , not only can china ’ s domestic market overheat , boosting productivity ( and thus the future growth potential ) , but also support demand for us , european , and japanese products .
this strategy is not without risk .
allowing the renminbi to appreciate in order to encourage imports also depresses exports , while exports are the traditional engine of the chinese economy .
reducing the administrative barriers to imports would channel more spending to foreign goods , perhaps not in the case of the government .
however , if china is serious about taking the role of a global leader , these risks are worth taking .
the question is what china can expect ?
china ’ s $ 1 trillion in us treasury bonds is worried about the safety of the assets .
it wants america to ensure that it does not , so it wants the us to offer a viable solution to a balanced budget after a recession .
instead , the obama administration has failed to offer a credible roadmap for consolidating fiscal consolidation .
if it gets it , it would reassure us taxpayers and reassure chinese policymakers .
we live in a multipolar world , and neither the us nor china is enough to lead the global economy alone .
for china , responsible leadership implies many risks .
to allay china ’ s concerns , the us will want to help china circumvent some existing risks .
only by working together can the two countries lead the world economy out of the current depression .
the rise of china ’ s rise
beijing – us vice president joe biden ’ s recent four-day visit to china ended on a final note .

are we preparing to war with each other ?

so , for china and its neighbors , the key question for the us , and for the rest of the world , is not what china will deploy for decades to come , but how china will use its newly acquired economic and military power to achieve its own domestic and foreign policies – and how the world ’ s powers are mutually destructive .
if the challenges are to be met , the only way is to achieve positive , consistent , and frank 相互了解 in china and other countries .
china ’ s economy will continue to grow ; china ’ s military will continue to move toward modernization ; and the chinese people will continue to unite the great powers .

only one patient , creative , and consistent communication strategy can remove fears of both sides .
china ’ s rise is the fact ; in the long run , a lasting peace is bound to be the first priority in china , its neighbors , and especially the us .

testing times for alzheimer ’ s
london – alzheimer ’ s disease is the most common cause of dementia , and the world ’ s most frightening neurological disease .
by 2050 , there will be 135 million alzheimer ’ s sufferers , with more than three-quarters of the current population , three-quarters of which occur in low- and middle-income countries .
predicting the onset of alzheimer ’ s – not to mention prevention and treatment – remains a huge challenge .
alzheimer ’ s disease was discovered more than a century ago by the results of the autopsy , characterized by brain lesions known as “ 淀粉 plaques . ”
the disease is more difficult to diagnose in life .
doctors rely on observation of memory loss and other 缺陷 failures ( such as reasoning and language ) – signs that the brain is already suffering from injury .
but it will take a few years before the plaques create them , and a few years before the onset of dementia .
if scientists have time and resources to engage in deep longitudinal studies , alzheimer ’ s alzheimer ’ s could be expected to increase .
these studies would best include blood , images , memory , and medical tests for thousands of young people and middle-aged people , and detailed lifestyle questionnaires .
the research participants will be subjected to decades of tracking to observe who develops alzheimer ’ s , which can be observed before alzheimer ’ s disease was diagnosed .
indeed , two famous longitudinal studies – the framingham heart study in massachusetts and the 国王 project in sweden – have made important progress in predicting alzheimer ’ s disease .
these studies have found that a short-term memory would damage short-term memory , given the diagnosis of alzheimer ’ s disease .
since then , brain imaging , biochemical analysis , and – perhaps the most important – genetic test have made significant progress .
in fact , the risk of alzheimer ’ s will double if a parent or sibling is suffering from alzheimer ’ s , probably because of the presence of the ApoE gene .
the probability of a 欧洲人 of a particular kind of ApoE ( ε4 ) would double the probability of alzheimer ’ s ; genetic 双份 will make it roughly ten times higher .
but genetic testing alone can not be a precise metric , because about half of alzheimer ’ s sufferers do not carry ε4 , and perhaps half of ε4 will not occur with alzheimer ’ s .
moreover , while international studies of more than 70,000 people have shown that more than 20 genes relate to alzheimer ’ s , they are small .
nonetheless , a 2012 study published in the new england journal thomas 医学期刊 analyzed a rare genetic mutation that occurred only in the world ’ s 500 families , which would lead to alzheimer ’ s disease .
research shows that testing can be predicted in the decades before the symptoms of symptoms .
studies found that beta ’ s proteins ( such as 物质 斑块 ) will vanish around the brain in 25 years before the onset of dementia .
fifteen years before the onset of dementia , 正电子 scans ( pet ) scans showed that 乙型 proteins are accumulating in plaques in the brain itself .
according to the framingham and king studies , the ten years prior to onset of dementia , a decade before the onset of dementia , short-term memory tests will be abnormal .
these tests are now becoming part of clinical practice , and are using commercial applications .
memory and other cognitive tests can reveal whether you have minor problems in some aspects of thinking – so-called “ mild cognitive impairment , ” often before alzheimer ’ s alzheimer ’ s .
the problem is that these tests must be carried out by trained 心理学家 , which will take more than hours to complete ; and many of those with mild cognitive impairment do not follow dementia .
the 取样 survey of 脑脊液 ( or “ spinal water ” ) can predict whether people with mild cognitive impairment will experience dementia , at more than 80 % accuracy , but still means a misdiagnosis of one in five .
pet scans are slightly less accurate , while routine mri brain scans can reveal only about 70 % of the accuracy of mild cognitive impairment .
as a result , scientists continue to find accurate predictions that are cheaper , quicker , and less painful than pet scans or 腰椎 穿刺 .
whatever the predictive approach that doctors use in the next few years , they may be able to inform them that patients with mild cognitive impairment are likely to develop alzheimer ’ s in the short term .
the more difficult question is whether we can accurately predict alzheimer ’ s alzheimer ’ s , or predict the disease five years ago .
even with early accurate predictions of alzheimer ’ s disease , there is no drug currently able to prevent or cure alzheimer ’ s before the amyloid plaques are removed .
this will be the next big challenge .
africa ’ s data revolution
washington , dc – ever since the word “ data revolution ” has emerged , there has been plenty of movement to define , develop , and implement the agenda to change the collection , use , and distribution of development statistics .
that makes sense .
to assess the international community ’ s next development agenda , regardless of its details , there is no definitive data .
but , in sub-saharan africa – with the coming sustainable development goals – the region has the greatest potential to make progress , with very little accurate data .
from 1990 to 2009 , only one sub-saharan country had data on the 12 indicators developed by the millennium development goals of 2000 .
indeed , none of the 60 countries that are fully available in key statistics is african .
although most african countries have experienced economic growth over the past decade , the accuracy of the data that underlie growth estimates remains the basis , not to mention data on inflation , food production , education , and vaccination rates .
inaccurate data can have serious consequences .
consider nigeria , which earlier this year , when gdp 重估 showed that the economy is more than 90 % larger than previously thought .
the distortions in nigeria ’ s economy before the previous data could lead to decisions about decisions regarding private investment , credit ratings , and taxation .
moreover , this means that nigeria has received more international aid than it should be – aid that could have been used for countries that need more .
contrary to popular belief , the constraints on basic data production and use are not the result of technical competence and knowledge , but from underlying political and institutional challenges .
first , national statistical offices often fail to ensure that they are independent , leading to the emergence of political forces and special interests .
poorly designed policies also undermine the accuracy of the data .
for example , governments and donors sometimes tie money to self-reported measures , which creates incentives for recipients to exaggerate key data , such as vaccination rates and school enrollment .
without effective oversight , these well-intentioned rewards are likely to backfire .
despite these failings , national governments and international donors are being used to ensure that enough data are collected .
only 2 % of official development assistance has been used to improve the quality of data – a figure that is inadequate to assess the effects of other 98 % of aid .
and the government ’ s reliance on donors to fund and collect the core statistics is unsustainable .
indeed , stronger national statistical systems are the first step toward improving the accuracy , timeliness , and availability of data , which are essential to calculating the accuracy , timeliness , and accessibility of virtually every important economic and social welfare indicator .
these include birth and death data , growth , and poverty data , taxes , and trade data , health , education , and security data , health , education , and environmental data .
developing such institutions is an ambitious but achievable goal .
what is needed is the willingness to experiment with new approaches to collecting , using , and sharing data .
the public can play a role here .
bypassing the government , hoping for simple , evidence-based solutions may be tempting , but it is difficult to produce sustained and credible progress without public-sector involvement .
governments and external donors recognize that the need to increase the size and efficiency of funds ( especially the national statistical system ) would benefit this shift .
a stronger incentive to provide a stronger incentive for the authorities to produce good data ( that is , data that are more accurate , timely , relevant , and readily available ) would be useful , but identifying “ good ” metrics .
in fact , measuring progress and adopting a performance-based agreement could improve development outcomes considerably .
a specific strategy for achieving these goals is to establish a 国家 compact on the data .
this compact would enable governments and donors to establish a common set of national statistical systems for years to come , with well-defined and verifiable milestones .
it would also provide a country-specific framework for innovation in country-specific financing frameworks and the engagement of civil society and the private sector , while mobilizing new technologies for data collection and dissemination .
in short , the data contract helps to mobilize and focus domestic and donor funding to achieve national statistics .
data are the currency of global economic performance , accountability , and credibility , improving data and improving governance and increasing private investment .
what africa needs to support a new decade of growth and development requires improving data .

given that there are some uncertainties in the best assessment methods , we recommend a doctor using standardized , validated methods .

ambivalent arabia
a democratic wave is sweeping the arab world .
even the traditional arab monarchies and emirates have something to change .
kuwait has now allowed women to vote , with qatar accepting a difficult reform program , bahrain ’ s massive tolerance of popular protests , and the united arab emirates is allowing a free press .
but saudi arabia continues to be wary of any kind of change , and thus a huge and seemingly immovable obstacle to reform in the arab world .
although saudi arabia ’ s ruling family , the al-saud , has endured enormous pressure on their neighbors ’ models , opposition forces remain strong .
as a result , the al-saud have become a double game : on the one hand , the royal family encourages democratic reform to be bold , while the royal family has brought them to prison .
on may 15 , three reform leaders – famous journalists and poet al qaeda al qaeda ’ s al thani – were sentenced to a criminal sentence for nine years .
their crime was to call for a constitutional monarchy .
according to official rulings , they use “ foreign ” – “ the west ” – “ the west , ” threatening national unity , challenging national sovereignty , and stoking popular opposition to the state .
soon after the terrorist attacks in the united states in september 2001 , these liberal reformers joined 160 other experts in a petition submitted to crown prince abdullah ( abdullah abdullah ) , a petition calling for reform .
the petition called for the monarchy to work within constitutionally mandated limits and called for an independent judiciary .
reformers believe that such reforms are the only way to enable saudi arabia to survive violent threats , instability , and state fragmentation .
only the constitution , they argue , can restore the legitimacy needed for a political system that is widely perceived as inept and inept .
crown prince abdullah , the true ruler of the kingdom ’ s 碌碌无能 half-brother , and saudi arabia ’ s true ruler , king abdullah , wants to be seen as a winning winner .
in january 2003 , he accepted these proposals with a passionate reception .
crown prince abdullah has failed to ask for a dissenting opposition , and his reform program is in political limbo .
in order to maintain absolute power and minimize public outrage , saudi princes , led by prince naif , demanded a deal to ensure that they are never asking for reform .
prince naif banned the use of “ reform ” in public discourse , because the term implied the problem of the system ; he prefers “ development . ”
ten of the reformers who have been arrested in 13 have submitted to this request , but the remaining three were explicitly rejected and paid .
they remained in jail in jail , before they failed to discuss any legitimate debate .
those who succumbed to their passports were detained and lost their jobs and were denied the right to speak to the news media .
under local and international pressure , saudi arabia ’ s ruling family has built a reform of a reformed version of the country , while taking over absolute control over all political developments .
at the beginning of this year , they held a tightly controlled local election , without allowing any independent view of opinion to be and how to hold an election .
all women are excluded from voting , and only one-quarter of men have a vote .
there is no doubt that the wahhabi islamists will do the best .
the family is now facing two threats : a violent islamist , another from liberal reformers .
clearly , they fear the reformers .
nor is it much easier to say that the “ terrorist ” criminals are more likely than repression to demand social justice .
indeed , the eradication of violent islamists and al qaeda groups will be recognized as a victory for the war on terror , especially the us .
but , as they seek and go beyond domestic extremists , they have been quietly tightening the noose around those who want moderate reforms .
this crackdown on liberal reform is particularly pronounced in the us , with the silence of the world standing quietly .
this silence is critical to the princes , because the al-saud care about the most .
in saudi arabia ’ s current scenario , the us government has no other trusted alliance with the current regime .
so , unlike ukraine , georgia , kyrgizstan , and lebanon , the us supported a strong opposition .
as long as saudi arabia is able to meet us oil needs and fight islamist radicals , it will continue to receive american support and silence – and its tacit acquiescence .
but the blind alley of the us and saudi arabia is not a durable solution .
those who use the possibility of a peaceful revolution will make violent revolutions inevitable .
liberal reformers who are imprisoned may have paved the way for a peaceful transition to a new saudi arabia .
by jailing these people , the authorities have made clear that violence is the only available route to change .
algeria ’ s dying dictatorship
algiers – despite poor health , algeria ’ s president , abdelaziz bouteflika , is still re-elected this month , with 81 % of the vote – at least in the case of his administration .
indeed , the false victory of the 岁 incumbent president is not a sign of political stability , but rather a reflection of algerians ’ inability to influence changes in the regime .
under bouteflika ’ s leadership , algeria ’ s government can not address the country ’ s most pressing economic and social challenges .
there is no sign of change .
as a result , his regime is increasingly finding it difficult to declare that bouteflika ’ s leadership is civilian , not 武治 .
as a result , the regime has adopted a new strategy aimed at creating a climate of transformation : a revision of the constitution and a vice president ’ s legitimate successor .
the real purpose of this move , of course , is to rally the military around the next compliant “ civilian leader . ”
the regime will also propose a “ national contract , ” pretending to start dialogue with the opposition .
but , faced with bouteflika ’ s bogus victory , the opposition can not continue to accept the role of the regime in the regime ’ s reform program .
indeed , the announcement of bouteflika ’ s plan to secede has been enough to rally the islamists and leftists – even those chosen by the regime – to resist the vote .
after the election results , they quickly rejected the new government ’ s legitimacy .
but , to gain credibility , opposition parties must extend their criticism from bouteflika to the system .
this is a matter of survival for them , because younger opposition groups are seeking new ways of building political change beyond national control .
one important development is the growing influence of non-partisan dissidents .
non-violent movements are not only opposed to bouteflika ’ s re-election , but also against the army and intelligence agencies ’ pervasive presence in civil society .
these movements , such as the “ sufficiently open ” movement , have encouraged algerians to shift from anger and negative abstention to positive resistance .
the underground unions – which organized protests and strikes to protect workers ’ rights , and refuse to cooperate with the regime ’ s official unions – also criticize elections .
moreover , young people have played a leading role in opposition – including by disrupting bouteflika ’ s campaign .
unemployed young people hold protests in southern algeria ’ s southern oil industry , arguing that high unemployment is linked to the military ’ s control of the algerian natural resources .
by organizing peaceful protests to demand accountability for public spending , these movements have raised problems during the campaign .
they have since challenged the government ’ s ban on street demonstrations – a legacy of the state that lasted until 1992 .
with the civil war in 1990 , security officials have been unable to account for the arrest of algerians demanding jobs .
of course , repression will continue to threaten many algerians .
but it is becoming increasingly easy for a twitter , youtube , and facebook to inspire their fellow citizens .
they have been able to spread their discontent by galvanizing daily debate about local human-rights violations , more effectively spreading discontent , and the previous traditional political party did not .
what algerians demanded is a better state service , not a “ arab spring , ” which is highly ingenious and highlights the regime ’ s inability to deliver on the security and economic prosperity of the people .
thus , even without explicitly talking about politics , a growing number of ordinary algerians are mobilizing against the government .
the street demonstrations have occurred mainly in areas where rights are violated , most overlooked in the most neglected areas , and the need for better work is economic : better jobs , housing , health care , and infrastructure .
for some , the right to earn a living in the informal market is enough .
the protesters are very large – sometimes destructive – with a stark voice , setting up barriers , occupying factories and government buildings , and destroying water supplies and electricity bases .
more than 150 algerians have not even tried to square their own houses since 2011 – where they are spent on government buildings .
against this background , the facile approach that governments make to buy off opponents is not surprising .
in 2011 , the government feared that the situation in tunisia and egypt – which had been brought down to algeria in the long term – was reflected in increased public protests by public-sector workers by 100 % , in 2008 .
to be sure , street protests have had a profound impact on algeria ’ s authoritarian politics , and officials fear that large-scale unrest affects public budgets and political appointments .
but the decision to prolong bouteflika ’ s presidency does not provide the strong transformational leadership that algeria needs to stabilize its regime .
the algerian authorities face significant challenges , because they reject a pluralistic system that makes it difficult to find a negotiating partner .
the more the regime tries to buy its opponents , the more it becomes its ego – the more outrage the people become .
in particular , angry younger people are not particularly afraid of the poor benefits that the status quo poses to them .
