america at stall speed ?
newport beach – judging by the vagaries of markets and “ consensus expectations , ” the outlook for the us economy remains fraught .
the us is now seeing the next double-dip recession of a double-dip recession ; after the next , the next one is at last , and the us has finally begun to use its massive cash reserves , seemingly as fast as possible .
this is understandable , but it also exacerbated the unease in the us and the global economy .
this reflects the fundamental consequences of fundamental ( and historic ) economic and fiscal union , inadequate policy responses , and systemic rigidities that allow structural change to stall .
as a result , there is a legitimate question of the underlying functioning of the us economy and for years to come .
one way to understand the current situation – and how to improve – is to reflect on two events that trigger the world ’ s major attention : the release of boeing ’ s 梦幻 jet , and the death of apple ’ s steve jobs .
let us start with a simple 航空 dynamic , with a metaphor made by my pimco colleague bill gross to describe the economic risks facing the us economy .
a bright airplane wants to take off , ascend , and sustain stability , and move forward alone .
it must move fast enough , more than a physical threshold threshold – far more than most of boeing ’ s other aircraft ( smaller ) aircraft .
failure would mean a mid-air buildup , a slow pace , and a high rate of 突降 .
unless we are convinced that the new 梦幻 is capable of avoiding stall speed , the idea of how to improve the travel experience of millions of passengers around the world is just as good .
the us economy is now at stall risk .
specifically , the problem is not whether growth is growing , but whether growth is sufficiently rapid enough to drive a large economy facing “ balance-sheet deleveraging , credit constraints , and households and businesses ’ perceptions of economic prospects . ”
and , remember that , just a year ago , some us officials were committed to declaring that the us economy had entered a “ summer of recovery , ” which was supported by the belief that the us is “ escape velocity . ”
stall speed is highly risky for economies like the us desperately needed to grow robustly .
without rapid growth without rapid growth , there is no way to reverse the trend toward structural deleveraging , which will not be able to achieve excessive debt deleveraging , but can not prevent an already rising income and wealth inequality .
the private sector can not and will not withstand the risk of stall speed alone .
what is urgently needed is better policymaking .
specifically , policymakers should be open and willing to clarify the unconventional challenges facing the us economy , making the corresponding response , and with sufficient effective policy tools .
unfortunately , it is far from clear that the us ( and europe , where the situation is worse than the us ) , is far from being so .
moreover , in recent weeks , us policymakers have been more interested in pointing out to europe and china than to identify and respond to paradigm shifts , while paradigm shifts are a source of growing us economic problems and social challenges .
this is what is happening in the insights of steve jobs , the world ’ s best innovators and entrepreneurs .
jobs do not only guide paradigm shifts ; they , in fact , create norms .
he is a master of the 化繁为简 ; not only does he not get out of complexity , but he found the way to rebuild and overcome the complexities of complexity .
teamwork is an obligation , not a choice .
instead of seeking a single “ big bang , ” he is aiming for multiple goals .
in the end , this will come from the willingness of evolutionary – a drive to move gradually toward the perfect .
moreover , he is good at selling to believers around the world and realizing his strategy .
so far , us economic policymakers have lagged in this regard .
instead of promising to deliver a much-needed 强化措施 , they are obsessed with a vain quest for “ big ammunition ” to solve all of the economic problems in the us .
the result was nothing .
as it stands , we have not even created the complexity of the complexity of our efforts , let alone to win the public ’ s support for a medium-term vision , a credible implementation strategy , and a package of measures that will suffice at hand .
the persistence of the stalemate , the us economy – already mired in an unemployment crisis , massive fiscal deficits , and massive underwater mortgages , while policy interest rates have fallen to zero – is exacerbating the risk .
in this context , unhealthy balance sheets will suffer even greater pressure , while healthy investors refuse to ride them .
what follows is that the risk of a recession will continue to temper , with the unemployment crisis continuing to deepen , while inequality will continue to grow as a result of a further deterioration in net social safety nets .
america , china , and the productivity paradox
new haven – in the late 1980 ’ s , a fierce debate about the so-called productivity paradox – the massive investment in information technology – did not produce measurable productivity improvements .
now that paradox is back , posing a problem for the us and china , a problem that will emerge in the annual strategic and economic dialogue .
let us return to 1987 , the nobel laureate economist robert solow , who famously quipped that “ the era of computers is not found in productivity statistics . ”
the productivity paradox appears to have been resolved in the 1990s , when the us experienced a spectacular productivity renaissance .
annual productivity growth in the us business sector grew by 2.5 % annually from 1991 to 2007 , compared to 1.5 % in the previous 15 years .
the benefits of the internet age were finally realized .
concern about the paradox of productivity vanished .
but it seems to be premature .
despite another technological revolution , productivity growth has fallen again .
this time , falling productivity is the global trend , affecting the world ’ s two largest economies – the united states and china .
in the last five years ( from 2010 to 2014 ) , average annual growth in us productivity has fallen to 0.9 % .
indeed , in the last two quarters ( 2014 and early 2015 ) , productivity fell at a 2.6 % annual rate .
unless there is a major data revision , america ’ s productivity renaissance is in serious trouble .
china has undergone a similar process .
despite the government ’ s disclosure of productivity statistics , the problem is clear : total employment growth in the town has been stable , and it has been 万人 million per year – far from the government ’ s target growth rate of 10 million .
in early 2015 , hiring seemed to continue to be sustained .
meanwhile , output growth has fallen from a trend of 10 % in 33 years to 7 % today .
this decline occurred in the context of sustained rapid job creation , suggesting that productivity is surely slowing .
therein lies the latest paradox .
revolutionary technologies are creating new markets ( digital media and computerized wearable devices ) , services ( energy management , and dna sequencing ) , products ( smartphones and robotics ) , and high-tech companies ( alibaba and apple ) , no doubt .
the modern-day solow might say , “ the internet of everything is everywhere , ” and it can not be found in productivity statistics .
but is this a paradox ?
northwestern university ’ s robert gordon has argued that information technology and the internet , like automated high-speed data processing and e-commerce , pale in comparison to the industrial revolution , including the steam engine , electricity , and piped water .
he believes that , while these innovations have made huge changes in the major advanced economies – for example , higher female labor-force participation , improved transport rates , urbanization and standardized temperature – these changes are difficult to replicate .
if america ’ s productivity data do indeed come as a result – a trend that would break up in a prolonged period of 16 years , this trend has disappeared – it is possible that all of the achievements that the us has achieved are the interim efficiency improvements that information technology has driven to shift from one technological platform to another .
optimists believe that official figures do not reflect a significant improvement in quality of life , and perhaps so , especially when it comes to major breakthroughs such as biotechnology and online learning .
but this ignores another important aspect of the critique of productivity measures : the undercounting of work time for the availability of portable information equipment .
in the united states , the bureau of labor statistics estimates that the average workweek has been at around 34 hours since the internet began two decades ago .
but this is far from reality : knowledge workers are increasingly outside the traditional office , checking email , updating their reports , writing reports , engaging in collective storms .
indeed , white-collar knowledge workers – that is , most workers in the advanced economies – now need 24 hours per day , seven days per week , without reflecting official numbers .
productivity is not working longer ; it is about more output per unit of labor input .
the undervaluation of output pales in comparison with a small underestimate of the work that information technology has caused .
china ’ s productivity slowdown may be worse than the us .
it is a byproduct of china ’ s nascent structural transformation from capital-intensive manufacturing to labor-intensive services .
in fact , it was only in 2013 that services exceeded the construction and construction industry , and became the economy ’ s largest sector .
today , the gap is widening , and this trend may continue .
given that china ’ s services sector is more than 30 % more workers per unit of output than manufacturing and construction combined , the structural rebalancing of china ’ s economy is shifting growth to less productive services .
until this shift is the problem , china has plenty of time .
gordon argues that urbanization will produce long-term productivity dividends – a dividend that is at least a decade in china .
but there is a stop , and china will begin to look at the so-called frontier of advanced economies .
in that case , china will face the same productivity challenges that the us and others face .
chinese policymakers ’ 重点 growth as a new priority suggests that they recognize the risk .
without strong innovation , sustaining productivity growth will be difficult .
china ’ s recent decline in productivity has been a signal that one of china ’ s most daunting economic challenges will be one of china ’ s most daunting economic challenges .
productivity growth is no escaping the decisive factor in a country ’ s economic performance .
for advanced economies , however , sustained rapid productivity growth has become the exception .
the recent rise in productivity growth in the us and china highlights this reality .
this is disturbing news for a world in which secular stagnation is in the doldrums .
a new blueprint for us-china relations
new york – in the coming decades , how the united states and china respond to changing powers will be the most important factor shaping global peace , prosperity , and governance .
in the long run , other pressing challenges – including russia ’ s relations with the west and the various events in the tumultuous middle east – are inferior .
what makes sino-american relations dangerous is that powerful forces in both countries seem determined to a collision course .
under xi ’ s strong leadership , the government is no longer following deng xiaoping ’ s dictum in international affairs that “ time will never be repeated . ”
the chinese are widely believed to be isolating , containing , and undermining china .
what is disagreeable is that many evidence in the us has fueled this sentiment .
regardless of what us policymakers say in private , they almost invariably say that they are almost invariably the world ’ s dominant power – especially in asia .
the most confrontational manifestation of this stance has been the council on foreign relations in the united states , which argues that the central objective of america ’ s grand strategy must be to “ keep america ’ s primacy in the global system , ” and urge the us government to adopt a series of aggressive economic , political , and military means to “ balance china . ”
this is , they say , not “ containment ” strategy , but the extent to which it is not contained is far from complete .
is there another way to deal with the reality that the forces and mindsets of both sides can not be turned into dangerous conflicts ?
in a new report by harvard university ’ s institution , belfort , the center for international relations , kevin rudd , a former australian prime minister , has proposed a strategy that he called “ constructive realism . ”
this is an unwieldy subject , but his analysis and policy advice are compelling .
the “ realist ” dimension of rudd ’ s argument acknowledges that some aspects of divergence – including taiwan , territorial disputes in the south china sea , and territorial disputes in china , america ’ s asian allies , china ’ s military modernization , and the legitimacy of china ’ s political system – remain uncertain in the foreseeable future .
this means that there is no easy solution – and thus a very cautious management .
the “ constructive ” part of rudd ’ s report , “ constructive ” part of the story , is to address a host of other difficult issues at the bilateral , regional , and global levels – the more that the us should treat china as an equal rival .
in the case of a bilateral scenario , such cooperation could include investment treaties , joint counter-terrorism intelligence groups , cyber security agreements , a consistent approach to managing the military accidents , and mutual ratification of the comprehensive nuclear-test-ban treaty .
at the regional level , rudd argues that the us and china can work to develop a joint strategy to promote denuclearization on the korean peninsula , and to end the 战争史 , long-standing japanese war , and align the region ’ s prospects with a more comprehensive and enduring war in the region .
at the level of the global level , rudd argues that the us-china agenda should focus on combating climate change , bolstering the g-20 , the renminbi ’ s internationalization , giving china a greater role in the imf and the world bank , and reform other important international institutions within the un system .
some in the west – including david shambaugh , the veteran chinese observer david shambaugh – still believe that such collaborative adaptation is not necessary , because the failure of economic and political management will allow china to collapse from within .
rudd argues that these people are wrong , and xi will not use his authoritarian measures to reduce growth sharply .
china will continue to rise , and the world – including the us – must find a principled approach to peace and adaptation .
rudd ’ s recommendations are undoubtedly ambitious .
but , given his qualifications – his mastery of the study of mandarin and his constructive policy thinker , with a long-term personal relationship with the us and china – his argument must be taken seriously .
indeed , while rudd ’ s australian prime minister is not quite flat , his own intelligence is one of the top public figures that i have dealt with in the last 30 years .
( this does not necessarily help him to become the next secretary-general ’ s willingness to become the next un secretary-general : the major powers will always prefer modest and moderate secretaries , rather than 有创造力 commander-in-chief . )
the us presidential candidates are unlikely to speak complacent about the us anymore .
but , in the coming years , one can hope that we can hear less “ 超然 , ” “ dominion , ” and much more of cooperation and coordination .
only such a us policy toward china could make the world confident that the twenty-first century will not repeat the mistake of the twentieth century .
a bilateral foil for america ’ s multilateral dilemma
new haven – it is good news that the united states and china seem to have withdrawn from the precipice of a trade war .
while the details are not too many , the agreement reached on may 19 to defuse tensions and promise further negotiations .
the bad news is that the framework of these negotiations is flawed : to address the underlying economic imbalances that the us has generated in a interconnected world , it would be impossible to deal with any agreement .
there is a longstanding disconnect between bilateral and multilateral solutions to international economic issues .
hoover ignored the suggestion , and the global trade war that followed resulted in a small “ big ” depression .
today , president donald trump ’ s interpretation of how to “ make america great again ” is comparable to the former .
politicians have long favored bilateral views , because it could be a contradiction in contradiction : you “ solve ” issues by targeting a particular country .
by contrast , the multilateral approach was endorsed by most economists , because it highlights the balance-of-payments distortions caused by saving and investment .
the contrast between this simple and complicated nature is precisely what economists have often lost in public debate .
the dismal science has never been known for clarity .
the same is true of us-china debate .
china is easily locked into a political goal .
after all , it accounted for 46 % of america ’ s $ 800 billion huge merchandise trade deficit in 2017 .

and , in such an atmosphere , the opposition from multilateralism , like me , is mixed .

similarly , when we emphasize that china is only one of a larger segment of a larger multilateral problem : the us has a bilateral trade deficit with 102 countries in 2017 .

while there may be fallacies , the debate about bilateral politics resonates in the us , because the country ’ s struggling middle class is eager to present its own anxieties .
the argument is that trade deficits lead to unemployment and wage compression .
and , because the merchandise trade gap is already about 4.2 % of gdp in 2017 , such pressure will only intensify in the current economic recovery .
so there is considerable political appeal to china .
so what could be done on may 19 ?
there is little real benefit from the suspension of tit-for-tat tariffs .
all of the attention of us negotiators focused on the goal of reducing bilateral trade imbalances around $ 200 billion within two years .
and , given the extent of america ’ s multilateral problems , this goal is largely meaningless , especially in the last six months , when the us has enacted massive and outdated tax cuts and federal spending growth .
indeed , because the budget deficit may continue to widen , america ’ s saving shortfall will only deepen in the coming years .
this means that both balance-of-payments and multilateral trade deficits will increase , and these deficits can not be addressed by targeted bilateral actions to a single country .
china , for its part , is more cautious about resisting any deficit target , while promising to achieve a common goal of “ effective reduction ” of bilateral imbalances in the us .
china ’ s vague commitment to purchasing more us agricultural and energy products has followed the “ shopping list ” approach of its former trade delegation to the us .
even if china and the us were to break out of america ’ s saving constraints , the us sought a formulaic bilateral solution to its own multilateral problems .
the largest annual contraction in us-china merchandise trade imbalances since 2000 is $ 4.1 billion , but that reduction was the worst in 2009 .
the goal of achieving more than twice that amount for two years is wishful thinking .
finally , any effort to impose a bilateral solution on multilateral issues would backfire , with adverse consequences for american consumers .
without addressing the shortfall in domestic saving , bilateral solutions are simply shifting the deficit from one economy to another .
this is the toughest problem .
china is a low-cost provider of imported consumer goods .
trump ’ s deal would shift the country ’ s share of us multilateral imbalance into higher costs elsewhere – the functional equivalent of raising taxes on american families .

america ’ s baby bust
london – as the united states ’ fertility rate fell to 1.75 in 2017 , the news is surprisingly worrying .
by the end of the 1990 ’ s and early 2000 ’ s , the us economy was booming , fertility rates were 2.00 per woman , and 1.8 in the 1980 ’ s .
but in the last five years , economic recovery has been growing stronger , with fertility rates falling .
this may portend a long-term shortage of workers relative to retirees , with pension funds and health-care provision facing heavy financial stress .
but there is no evidence that stronger growth and economic information must produce higher fertility rates – a trend that reflects expectations about the future .
moreover , the fertility rate in the us today will not pose a serious problem – and some benefits .
in all major advanced economies , fertility fell in 1960 and 1970 , with the replacement rate falling below the replacement rate of 2.05 children per woman .
the united states reached 1.77 in the late 1970 ’ s , compared to 1.8 in northern europe and 1.65 in western europe .
while we can not be sure , the shift in the fertility rate is likely to remain in the way of the replacement rate , which would have been sustained by one-off one-off factors .
some argue that america ’ s recovery in the 1990 ’ s was due to economic dynamism and increased confidence , which contrasts sharply with “ old europe . ”
but , over the past 30 years , the average fertility rate for white and black americans is far lower than the replacement rate , owing largely to the higher fertility rate in spain , reflected in higher fertility rates in spain , reflecting a typical phenomenon that is often associated with poorer countries .
but today , latin america ’ s fertility rate has fallen sharply – from 2.9 % in 2000 to 2.1 today , brazil from 2.5 to 1.7 % today , and the us is returning to the typical fertility rate in rich countries .
excluding temporary immigration , the fertility rate in all major advanced economies has become a 演变 2.0 , with most of them falling to 1.9 .
some evidence suggests that sudden deep recessions cause temporary fertility rates to fall , and subsequent rebound , but cross-country comparisons have not shown correlation between the long-term fertility rate and the specific fertility rate within the range of economies – whether positive or negative .
canada ’ s fertility rate is lower , but its economy is as successful and confident as the us .
the strong german growth rate over the last two decades has produced a fertility rate of 1-1.5 , well below the less successful france .
south korea has maintained its economy ’ s economic expansion by 1.3 per year .
latin america ’ s most prosperous economies , chile ’ s most prosperous economy , are experiencing only 1.76 , far less than a successful birth rate in argentina .
so the recent decline in us fertility rates should not be surprising ; if it does not fall to a significantly lower level , there is no need for concern .
of course , in the long run , lower fertility rates , together with the extension of life expectancy , will lead to the ratio of older people over the old age of 65 .
but , because people live longer and healthier lives , retirement ages can and should be raised .
in a world of huge potential for automation , it is likely that wage growth is low , rising inequality , and rapidly rising working-age population , which would be both unnecessary and undesirable , and a slight supply of workers may be able to boost productivity and support real wages .
remarkably , fears that robots will take jobs are far less widespread in japan and china than in western countries with higher fertility rates .
so , in rich societies with modern attitudes toward women ’ s role , fertility rates tend to be below replacement rates , and are generally welcome .
but the degree is important , with low fertility rates , such as japan ’ s 1.4 , which would pose a major problem if long .
the median forecast of the united nations suggests that , from now to 2050 , north and south america ’ s total population will increase by 15-20 % , and will remain stable until the late 2000s .
by contrast , japan ’ s population is expected to decline from 125 million today to around 80 million .
demographic contraction will severely constrain japan ’ s ability to support aging populations .
thus , sensible policies should identify and eliminate the barriers that needlessly curb the birth rate , such as labor-market discrimination , limited parental leave , or inadequate childcare facilities , which are difficult to pursue .
scandinavian countries are exemplary in this regard , though their fertility rates are not restored to replacement rates , but only by 1.75 .
with similar policies in the us , it may be possible to raise fertility rates slightly on the basis of today ’ s 1.75 , creating a favorable net outcome .
but the main response to the recent decline in the us fertility rate should be to accept its inevitability and stop worrying about it .
the us , exporting obesity
cambridge – when us president donald trump ’ s administration runs sharp 上窜下跳 in trade negotiations and plans to repeal the rules introduced by president barack obama , one casualty is likely to be the fight against obesity worldwide .
without control , rapid increases in obesity could slow or reverse the dramatic progress in health care in much of the world over the past few decades and life expectancy .
and by imposing it on countries like mexico and canada , the us is making the problem worse .
one of the paradoxes of modern global capitalism is that more than 800 million people in the world do not have to go to eat , but roughly 700 million people ( including 100 million children ) are obese .
of course , these are not necessarily directly related , because the world has a substantial share of hunger in countries suffering from civil strife or severe government dysfunction .
at the same time , obesity prevalence is broader , with advanced economies and most emerging markets .
although there is some connection between obesity and poverty within some countries , it is noteworthy that obesity rates in wealthy countries like the united states , the united kingdom , and canada are among the highest in the world .
according to the united states ’ disease control and prevention centers , the average weight of american women today is larger than americans ’ average weight in 1960 ( 166 pounds ) .
the average weight of american women in 1960 was 140 pounds , and the average weight of american males today is 195 pounds ( compared to an average height of just one inch in the us over the same period ) .
the same dynamic is in the world , and obesity rates in europe , latin america , and even china are rising .
while it is difficult to measure long-term health outcomes , there is ample evidence that obesity has a high impact on the incidence of II diabetes , heart disease , and certain types of cancer .
the cost of health care is staggering , estimated at nearly $ 200 billion per year .
as childhood obesity rates continue to rise worldwide , the health costs of health care are significantly higher , as the health costs of the future adult population rise .
the causes of obesity are manifold and complex .
yet there is a growing body of evidence that a culture focused on processed food and universal lifestyles is at the heart of the problem .
rapid urbanization in emerging markets is another important factor , with the desire to emulate western lifestyles .
many governments have already launched measures to improve nutrition education .
unfortunately , industrial advertising often leads to such efforts , as the us trade lobbies have done to other parts of the world .
the fact that mexico ’ s adult obesity rate has soared since the signing of the north american free trade agreement in 1993 is a reality that is difficult to ignore .
the direct foreign investment of the processed food industry and the surge in advertising is an important factor in this .
mexico ’ s consumption of sugary drinks almost tripled between 1993 and 2014 , while a new tax on sugary drinks has only fallen only slightly .
the other north american free trade agreement – canada – also experienced an increase in obesity rates , partly because exports from the us led to a sharp decline in the price of fructose .
unfortunately , government regulators are trying to reverse these trends , for example , at the pace of spreading nutrition to the public .
and , for a long time , most governments ’ focus on obese education has focused on rigid regulation of calorie intake , without considering the obvious differences between the precise differences in food prices ( as david ludwig , professor david ludwig , and david ludwig ) .
the skeptics might point out that nutrition guidelines seem to be changing , and last year ’ s sin foods often turned into 超级 food this year .
this is true , but the fact is that nutrition research has made significant progress in recent decades .
beyond education , governments can use other tools to influence people ’ s eating habits .
they can and should , as in the united kingdom , impose restrictions on advertising on child advertising , as in the united kingdom , france , and several other countries ; obesity in early years will cause a lifelong problem .
beyond that , david ludwig , 达瑞许 莫扎法 of tufts university , and i also proposed taxing processed foods , just like tobacco taxes .
and money is available to subsidize healthier alternatives .
it is a fantasy to expect that the current administration , struggling to phase out the current administration ’ s policies , is probably a fantasy .
that is why countries with a new trade deal with the us ( for example , post-brexit britain , or by dismantling the north american free trade agreement ) need to be wary of any provisions that the us has made to reduce obesity .

tackling america ’ s economic policy shocks
new york – the united states will consider a series of tax and trade moves this year , and emerging-market economies might face depreciation pressures and volatility .
three major us economic uncertainties , in particular , will affect emerging markets in 2017 .
the first is a border adjustment tax , which would allow us exporters to obtain tax credits , but taxing us imports – or eliminating deductions , as well as eliminating deductions .
both president donald trump and the republican-controlled congress have expressed support for this proposal , and it is likely to become a reality .
this tax , even the expected expectation of its implementation , would push up the dollar ’ s exchange rate ( ironically , at least partly to offset the improvement in the us trade imbalance that the trump administration expects ) .
the second uncertainty is that the us may respond more aggressively to china ’ s exports to the us .
the trump administration has repeatedly said that it will confront china with china on unfair trade practices .
trump has openly mused about imposing a 45 % tariff on chinese imports .
implementing any similar measures would lead china to export demand , causing downward pressure on the renminbi .
but the move will also lead to many other currencies .
my research with 王志 , muhammad 音译 , and 朱坤福 发现 found that about half of china ’ s exports to the us are value-added products , and components from south korea , japan , taiwan , singapore , and other economies .
because products from china are often part of a globally integrated global or regional value chain , the us has reduced imports of china indirectly ( but rapid ) to the decline in exports of other asian economies .
this transmission mechanism is likely to offset the direct increase in these economies ’ exports , at least in the short and medium term , because 组织 production chains are no easy feat .
the third move that the us may destabilize emerging markets is the fed ’ s tightening of monetary policy faster than expected .
a sharp interest-rate hike would translate into a weaker dollar and currency depreciation in developing economies .
commodity exporters may be the exception .
higher us infrastructure spending could trigger an increase in demand for commodities , triggering higher prices , leading to a currency appreciation .
but , even in these countries , some commodity exporters – such as brazil and russia – are not necessarily able to see exchange-rate improvement , because their weaker economies have other powers to drag down .
the challenge that us policy changes pose to emerging-market currencies involves not only devaluation pressures , but also volatility .
so how should emerging-market countries strengthen their resilience to the shockwaves ?
one option is to optimize the structure of capital inflows .
then there is the increase in exchange-rate flexibility .
for the former , my research and 童辉 show that countries with severe reliance on foreign banks or international capital markets are more vulnerable to capital flight than countries that rely mainly on foreign direct investment ( fdi ) .
so , to counter exchange-rate volatility or the changes in the us exchange rate , emerging markets should work to improve the business environment to attract fdi , thereby reducing their reliance on short-term “ hot money ” – thereby reducing the impact of sudden capital-flow reversals on them .
this adjustment is particularly important for countries with rigid labor markets .
one risk of a fixed exchange rate is that the currency is overvalued or undervalued , both against economic stability .
when the forces affecting the equilibrium exchange rate intensify , the likelihood of an overvalued or undervalued currency would be substantially higher .
the face and timing of america ’ s future policy are uncertain , but it is clear that capital-flow management and nominal exchange-rate flexibility are well prepared .
in benjamin franklin ’ s words , if developing countries were not ready , they must do the job .
why millennials will reject trump
new york – the key political divide in the united states is not between parties , but between generations .
the millennial generation ( aged 18-35 ) largely opposed trump , and will become the backbone of trump ’ s policies .
older americans are divided , but trump ’ s base is above 45 .
after issue on issue , younger voters will reject trump , viewing him as a politician over the future .
of course , this is an average of average , not absolute .

according to a export poll , trump won 53 % of the 65 and older voters , 42 % of the electorate , and 42 % of voters in 18 .

the message is not that today ’ s young liberals will become tomorrow ’ s older conservatives .
the millennial generation is far more liberal than baby boomers and silent generation of young people .
their party is also far less partisan , who will support the politicians who address their values and those who need them , including the third parties .

in fact , young people need the opposite policy : higher taxes on the older generation , for higher education , job training , renewable-energy infrastructure , and other investments in the us ’ s future .
third , compared to their parents and grandparents , young people are more aware of climate change and its threats .
trump , with its last 狂欢 狂欢 , paralyzed the elderly generation , while young people have only failed .
a generational divide on global warming owes part to many of the older americans , including trump , ignoring climate change and its causes .
older americans didn ’ t learn about climate change .
they never received basic scientific knowledge about greenhouse gases .
thus , they want to put their short-term financial interests above the deadly threat of their grandchildren .
in a 2015 survey , 60 % of those aged 18-24 said that human activity was causing global warming , compared to 31 % of those 65 and older .
a survey released in january found that 38 % of the us survey respondents aged 65 and above have supported fossil fuels , not renewable energy expansion , with only 19 % of those aged 18-25 .
trump ’ s economic policies are geared toward this older , 肤色 , native-born us .

one might attribute trump ’ s backward-looking mindset to his age .
the trump era of 70 is the oldest new president in american history ( ronald reagan was a slightly younger one ) .
but age is hardly the only reason for the day .
bernie sanders is undoubtedly the most audacious of the ideas of the 2016 presidential candidate , and the hero of the millennial generation is 75 .
young people are encouraged by pope francis , who is 80 years old , because he will worry about their concerns – whether poverty , job distress , or vulnerability to global warming – and , rather than as 粗鲁 , as trump and his ilk do .

what makes america great
cambridge – presidential inauguration and commencement ceremonies are usually emotional events .
these ceremonies mark an end to the end of a country or an individual .
though the commencement ceremonies are so common for me , i have been excited when i see a student ’ s journey and start thinking about them .
in our ceremony , a highlights is that several professors and public figures 逐字逐句 john f. kennedy ’ s inaugural address .
it was a text written 56 years ago , representing a different world , a world in which the cold war , the threat of nuclear armageddon , and the challenges faced by a large number of independent poor countries account for policymakers ’ attention .
but , in less than 14 minutes , this inaugural address can move and encourage every person on the table , including half of the graduates and their families .
to understand why , it is worth recalling that .
at first , kennedy vowed to defend friends of freedom , against the enemies of freedom : “ to make every country aware that , whatever it wants or bad , we will be able to take all of our costs , take all of our costs , and keep our friends , ” to ensure freedom of life and success . ”
he has also promised to fight poverty : “ living in the countryside , hungry half of the planet , and half of the planet : we are committed to helping them to fend for themselves , regardless of how long it takes to help them . ”
if a free society can not help many people in poverty , it can not save the few rich . ”
and that commitment is the cornerstone of the western hemisphere ’ s solidarity : “ we have a special commitment to our brethren in the south of our borders , and we make a special good thing – a good thing to make our good good . ”
finally , there is the ethic of service for the public good : “ there ’ s also my fellow americans : don ’ t ask the country what you can do for you – ask what you can do to your country .
my fellow citizens of the world : don ’ t ask the us what you do to do you , ask what we can do for our people . ”
these words have lasting emotional appeal because they refer to a potentially difficult approach to action , driven by their commitment to the common values of american and world citizens .
this approach – based on rules-based rules , rather than building on individual transactions – enables the us to create and sustain a national coalition that can ensure peace and peace .
fast-forward to now .
president-elect donald trump ’ s campaign rhetoric is based on such recognition : the us has fallen from its former greatness .
employment went to mexico and china because weak leaders negotiated a bad deal .

america ’ s turn from 教师爷
cambridge – when america ’ s large financial crisis continues to unfold , one can only hope that us policymakers will be able to hear about half of advice from developing countries as they hear advice from developing countries .
the us does not seem to recognize that their “ sub-prime ” mortgage bust is in common with many banks that have swept the global banking crisis since 1945 .
the good news is that many of the world ’ s leading policymakers , especially from emerging markets , have seen this situation .
if us policymakers were to listen , they know how to handle them from the experts who have survived the financial crisis .
unfortunately , the parallels between today ’ s us crisis and the past financial crisis are not mere hyperbole .
in essence , it is clear that banks use off-balance loans to finance highly risky projects , exotic financial instruments , and excessive excitement about the new market .
but there is also a strong parallel in common .
professor reinhart and i systematically compared the us sub-prime crisis to the worst of the 19 worst financial crises in the last 60 years .
these include the massive crises in scandinavia , spain , and japan , and lesser events , such as the us saving and loan crises in the 1980 ’ s .
almost all of the major indicators , including asset and housing prices , a rising trade balance , a surge in government and resident debt , and the growth trajectory before the crisis have sent red flags to the us .
simply put , capital flowing to the us artificially drives down interest rates and inflated asset prices , leading to lax banking and regulatory standards and ultimately causing disintegration .
at the beginning of the 1990 ’ s and the beginning of the asian financial crisis in latin america and latin america , they have heard advice not only from the imf , but also among prominent representatives of diverse backgrounds and experiences .
the us should do so .
the imf ’ s president , 思 卡恩 , could easily start with any prior crisis countries , including mexico , brazil , south korea , turkey , japan , japan , and sweden , not to mention argentina , russia , chile , and many others .
it should be acknowledged that the imf ’ s panel would be spared the current hypocrisy .
in the 1990 ’ s , the us treasury strongly encouraged asian tightening to tighten fiscal policy .
but today , the us congress and the president are committed to adopting a massive , reckless fiscal stimulus package that is primarily aimed at limiting the next president ’ s scope for simplifying the us tax code and eliminating the budget deficit .
the americans firmly told japan that the only way to clean up japan ’ s economic woes is to remove debt losses and rehabilitate the financial system through schumpeter ’ s “ creative destruction . ”
the us authorities now seem willing to consider any measures to ensure that their main banks and investment companies fail to fail , regardless of how much inflation is inflationary .
for years , foreign governments have complained that america ’ s hedge funds are not transparent about stability .
now , many american politicians are complaining about the transparency of swf ’ s ( that is , large government investors in asia and the middle east ) , which are taking us pride in 花旗银行 assets like citibank and 美林公司 .
indeed , it is not a bad thing to invest more in the economic well-being of countries like russia and china .
yes , the imf should establish a voluntary code of conduct for sovereign wealth funds , but it should not be used for weapons of financial protectionism .
for years , i and many others complain that emerging markets need a larger share of representation in global financial governance .
today , the problem goes far beyond symbolism .
the us economy is in trouble , and its problems are unlikely to be limited to the us .
experts from emerging markets and elsewhere have much to say about dealing with the financial crisis .
obamacare and effective government
berkeley – if historians look back at the 2010 obama administration ’ s controversial health-care reform – american patients protection and affordable care act – we predict that they will not spend their attention on its rules , its troubles , and its web sites .
on the contrary , we believe that historians will focus on how “ obamacare ” encouraged an increase in the costs of an increasingly dysfunctional system , even if it left millions of previously excluded americans .
innovation is perhaps the least discussed issue in health-care reform .
but it is the key to “ bending ” the curve curve in health-care costs , because it provides high-quality health care .
obamacare provides a powerful new incentive for such innovation .
in the 1980 ’ s , us health-care spending was almost twice as rapid as economic growth , from 9.2 % to 17.4 % of gdp .
many factors contributed to this increase , but most experts agree that the most important reason for this is the 计费 system , which encourages health-care providers to provide expenses as many as possible , rather than maintaining health and effective treatment of diseases .
the aca has changed all of this by building new incentives to boost health-care delivery – for example , by reducing expensive and unnecessary hospital infections and 住院 ( readmissions ) , adopting electronic medical records .
most important , the aca provides incentives for the creation of “ affordable care organizations , ” “ 捆绑 systems , ” and other health-care services , thereby encouraging better treatments , especially for patients with many chronic diseases .
these patients account for about 10 % , but they paid about 64 % of total health-care costs .
across the us , providers , insurers , non-profits , and local governments are responding to the aca ’ s incentives .
the federal medicare and medicaid programs for medicare and medicaid have just announced the second round of appropriations – $ 6.65 billion in 28 states , three territories , and the district of columbia – to boost health-care delivery .
of course , it is too early to declare victory , but obamacare seems to be working .
according to the recent analysis by the council of economic advisers ( cea ) , about 10 million people in 2014 were receiving health insurance from the aca – the largest year in four decades .
but the real surprise is that growth in health-care spending slowed sharply in 2012-2013 , with gdp growing at a similar pace .
this contrasts sharply with the previous half-century ; indeed , it created the slowest growth in real per capita health-care spending .
to be sure , the aca is only one factor in this promising trend ; growth in health-care spending is often slowing as the economy slows .
but medicare spending , which is not affected by recession , has slowed with private health spending .
in recent research , the cea calculated that the aca ’ s medicare reforms contributed a large share of the slowdown in health-care spending .
the aca is a good example of how governments can be able to promote innovation by providing goals , direction , and incentives , rather than by pursuing solutions .
the role of government is like venture capitalists , providing seed money and financial support to promote innovation .
in this scenario , different actors – medicare and federal medicaid , state and local governments , private insurers , doctors and social entrepreneurs – collaborate to forge effective solutions that account for a portion of government revenue .
for example , responding to the aca ’ s incentives and flexibility , arkansas and oregon launched bold experimental measures to revamp medicaid – one that rewards better outcomes , healthier health-care providers , and health providers .
in camden , new jersey , jeffrey brenner , the family doctor , has pioneered strategies to reduce hospital hospitalization through “ 使用者 ” ( super ) , a small federal medicaid patient who often uses expensive emergency treatment .
brenner synthesized “ hot spots ” around camden , and sought to figure out why some in the region will be so large .
the problem is not fraud , but rather a lack of cooperation , particularly basic primary care and lack of attention to basic risk factors .
the most expensive 1 % patient is often a disease , which accounts for 30 % of 坎 public health spending .
brenner ’ s 联盟 alliance , founded in 2003 , was founded in 2003 by a philanthropy , robert wood , and private insurers , to united health care .
the government is now providing more support , with similar programs in maryland , colorado , pennsylvania , and north carolina .
oregon is “ pay-for-success ” negotiations with the federal government .
the state will gain $ 1.9 billion over five years to revamp the federal service service for camden ’ s approach .
oregon receives that money only if the cost per capita is significantly lower than in the other states .
now , oregon is on the way .
arkansas , which provides 20 different medical services to “ program ” ( including hip and 膝盖 , pregnancy , 结肠镜 , asthma , and 充血性 heart failure ) , has turned from a fee-for-service model to a quality outcome .
so far , the effect has been good – not only to reduce costs , but also to link services with best practices .
governments can stimulate innovation by providing incentives that pool multiple actors ’ strengths .
in health care , this means taking advantage of the purchasing power of medicare and medicaid , the risk of social entrepreneurs and charities , and the dynamism of markets and private firms .
and health-care reform is just one example of what governments can do by setting targets , encouraging innovation , and providing the public with the resources to expand useful solutions .
one hopes that a quarter-century later , historians will look back at the aca as the start of a new era , in which public and private communities develop innovative solutions to complex social problems – and thereby restore trust in the government itself .
america ’ s hidden debt
washington , dc – former us treasury secretary lawrence summers recently quipped that , “ fiscal stimulus is like a drug with tolerance of tolerance ; to sustain sustained growth , the deficit must grow . ”
people like summers worry about the deficit because they suspect that the government ’ s borrowing is ultimately being used to boost gdp growth over the longer term .
unless the portfolio changes , the debt-to-gdp ratio will continue to grow , until disaster strikes .
others disagree .
for example , paul krugman , the leftist nobel laureate economist paul krugman , believes that a “ debt crisis can not happen in countries like the united states . ”
john 塔姆 , the economic political-economic editor of the right , also felt that “ the endless 危言耸听 of the budget deficit is irrelevant . ”
but , despite disagreement about the sustainability of us government debt , they are all accepted by the accuracy of the standard approach to measuring it .
this is a mistake , and perhaps disastrous .
the us congress ’ s budget office recently reported that the federal budget deficit in the first ten months of the fiscal year was $ 1160 billion higher than it was year before .
the cbo is now expected to reach $ 1 trillion by 2020 .
this is worrying , but it does not reflect the harsh fact that last year ’ s annual deficit almost certainly exceeded $ 1 trillion .
to understand this , the us could imagine the us as a house of smallpox .
if you want to sell home to the buyer of a mortgage , the federal reserve would demand that you assess the home , and evaluate the results would be required to repair the roof .
in this case , you can not delay maintenance .
the law requires that you disclose and pay for the hidden costs of repairing the roof , or you are stealing the buyer ’ s interests .
indeed , unlike mortgage mortgages on balance sheets , you may not regard roof maintenance as a current liability .
but postponing that spending does not make the problem disappear .
and the federal government has some of the outstanding debt that people do not hear .
the debt that has already been accounted for is the $ 305 trillion held by public debt in the form of us treasury bonds ; and , without 85 % of the debt , water systems , water systems , and 54560 have the potential to extend the costs of a low-carbon , low-carbon energy system .
but these are only two broad examples .
so how much hidden debt is america ’ s debt ?
we rely on rough estimates .
for example , according to a 2016 report by the american society of civil engineers , upgrading the country ’ s crumbling infrastructure will cost $ 5.2 trillion .
according to the international energy agency ’ s 2014 report and our calculations of the share of us carbon-dioxide emissions , the shift to clean-energy systems would cost $ 6.6 trillion .
combined , $ 11.8 trillion is contained in unaccounted-for non-inflation-adjusted liabilities .
to be sure , these debts are not just federal debt .
state and local governments are responsible for most infrastructure and climate costs .
yet more than $ 3 trillion of municipal governments have been overwhelmed by their massive spending facilities and the recent ease of mitigating climate change .
but , because climate change and infrastructure security are national rather than local , this $ 11.8 trillion in infrastructure and environmental 相关 will ultimately be borne by the federal government .
they are the country ’ s “ leaky roof . ”
this figure increases year , because , as bridges continue to crumble , the costs of repairing their costs will only be higher ; with rising sea levels and rising temperatures , the cost of deforestation will increase .
in fact , between 2012 and 2016 , the american society of civil engineers raised the annual gap in annual infrastructure investment in the united states – an increase of around $ 55 billion per year .
and from 2012 to 2014 , the international energy agency ’ s estimate of the cost of a transition to a clean-energy system is roughly $ 270 billion annually .
combined , the inflation-adjusted deficit amounted to $ 2 billion – just because the delayed spending on infrastructure and climate cuts is delayed .
the us federal deficit in 2017 , which is $ 6650 billion , reflects the amount of debt that is actually accounted for .
but if the infrastructure and climate debts that are not included are included , the entire deficit in 2017 will exceed $ 1 trillion .
this is a rough calculation , but they point to a pressing question : why does the us not calculate its hidden debt ?
the short answer is that law does not require that .
the federal “ debt ceiling ” has never been a fixed construct , and it has become a soft “ smallpox card ” that has made it possible for governments to borrow as much as possible .
at the same time , a congressional decision aimed at increasing the deficit by running a deficit over a decade would have been an accounting trick for avoiding responsibility for the 11 and subsequent years of responsibility for the government .
but , just as withholding and delay repairing a leaky roof from home buyers , we are stealing from the future americans when we ignore the government ’ s liabilities in all areas .
unless all debt is counted , we can not even know whether fiscal policy will have positive or negative effects on future growth .
america and india ’ s second chance
new york – indian prime minister narendra modi ’ s visit to washington , dc , in june , is largely absent from india .
but asian diplomats and military professionals are clearly watching closely .
for good reason : the relationship between the world ’ s two most populous democracies can determine the future of the world .
the official joint statement issued by the two governments portrays india as a “ major defense partner ” in the us , entitled access to military advanced technologies .
in a generation , the relationship between the indian and indian relations has been a strategic proximity to strategic proximity – and , in terms of geopolitics , the development of development is fast .
the impetus behind this shift is noteworthy , because many of them are likely to make the two countries more tightly .
the end of the cold war was an important part of the détente relationship , because india no longer needs to deal with the soviet union , and the rationale for non-alignment was no longer .
the second factor is pakistan .
the us has long adopted an even-handed policy toward two strategically important south asian countries .
nonetheless , for most of the cold war , pakistan was seen as a friendly country , and its great rival , india , was viewed as a difficult one .
this view was reinforced by pakistan ’ s importance as an important conduit for weapons to afghanistan ’ s invasion of soviet aggression .
but , since the soviet army withdrew from afghanistan in 1989 , us-pakistan relations have weakened .
pakistan ’ s development of nuclear weapons , providing sanctuary and support to the taliban , and the willingness of the world ’ s most dangerous terrorists , including osama bin laden , will further influence us-pakistan relations .
as a result , america ’ s relationship with india is no longer constrained by concerns about pakistan .
china is also pushing for improved ties .
the motivation is far more fundamental than that of china ’ s border with china .
china ’ s rise has helped to strengthen the country ’ s interests with the us and one another , in order to ensure that it can withstand china ’ s political and economic forces .
domestic politics also has a serious impact on the development of india ’ s relationship – a case for both .
the decline of india ’ s congress has diminished the influence of the political forces that support the us from keeping its distance from the us .
at the same time , the us now has three million citizens , and , like many other immigrant groups , they become more important and powerful .
support for stronger ties in india has become a rare bipartisan foreign policy in the us , and it can be expected that this will continue , regardless of this november ’ s party .
the breakthrough in the bilateral relationship began ten years ago , when the us canceled sanctions imposed by india ’ s nuclear weapons program , and subsequently signed a deal to pave the way for the us to participate in india ’ s civilian nuclear program .
unlike in pakistan and north korea , india is viewed as a responsible nuclear power , with the us now supporting organizations that india ’ s entry into its various efforts to prevent nuclear materials and weapons further .
as india ’ s economy grows , india ’ s economic relationship is strengthening .
bilateral trade has increased to more than $ 100 billion per year .
high-level visits are already commonplace .
closer economic ties and large-scale cooperation in clean energy are the top priority .
cooperation between the two countries ’ military and intelligence agencies would also increase .
indeed , efforts to maintain open and secure action in the indian ocean have been a fait accompli .
the formal alliance between the us and india can influence china ’ s strategic designs .
of course , challenges remain .
bureaucracy , corruption , and poor infrastructure remain constraining india ’ s economy .
they must also ensure that close ties with the us are not just a prime minister or a 党的政策 .
this means making congress fully involved , and to overcome the resistance to new ideas and actions .
it is hard to see some of the irony .
more than a half-century ago , in the early days of the cold war , many people in washington regarded india as a model of apolitical politics and economic development .
for many reasons , things did not evolve in this direction , and india ’ s economic evolution became statist , with politics becoming closer to the soviet union , and more closely than us officials expected .
today , however , india is emerging as a successful example of democratic democracy in close ties with the us .
there is little chance of life in life , and india and the us are likely to reap this opportunity .
america keeping haiti down
as the world ’ s largest regional development bank , the inter-american development bank ’ s work in latin america and the caribbean allegedly “ contribute to accelerating economic and social development . ”
but it has severely damaged these goals in haiti ’ s behavior .
the inter-american development bank , to improve haiti ’ s drinking infrastructure – which is not , say , the worst of the world ’ s worst water conditions – provides an estimated $ 10 million to help prevent a deadly 水致 of drinking water .
in 2001 , us officials threatened that unless haiti ’ s main political party accepts the special political requirements of the seats in haiti ’ s electoral observation , they will use their influence to stop funding for the idb in advance .
soon after the us demands , the inter-american development bank and its members did not lend to the plan , but instead adopted the measures that were never taken , suggesting that the conditions for additional political action in haiti were increased .
these actions violate the idb ’ s own charter , which strictly prohibits banks and their members from intervening in internal political affairs .
some internal emails show that a us attorney of the inter-american development bank ( iadb ) told the us treasury that , though these loans lack legal barriers to legitimacy , the us can effectively prevent the lending process by “ slowing ” the lending process .
indeed , by requiring further scrutiny of lending , haiti will have to pay regular payments before lending .
“ while this is not the ‘ perfect approach to stopping idb lending , ” the lawyer wrote , “ but , however , it is bound to give more of the same amount of funds . ”
in 2001 , the us ambassador to haiti , 迪安 科兰 , famously made the case for the idb ’ s seizure of bank lending and the demand for a compromise that haiti ’ s political party wanted .
these strategies worked .
haiti has no money to pay for repayment borrowing because it has been denied and expected , which would enable the idb to launch bank policies that prevent bank lending .
in a few years later , the us used other delayed tactics , such as the inter-american development bank ’ s goal of changing the target ’ s target .
the consequences of these strategies are devastating .
the city of chemistry , with its miserable drinking water , managed to track the inter-american development bank as the first project a decade ago , but it has not yet seen the implementation of any water program .
research conducted by healthy partners , robert f. kennedy ’ s human-rights memorial center , and new york university ’ s human rights and global center for justice found that there is no available public water in the city of chemistry .
researchers found that three-quarters of the city ’ s water sources contain high levels of 大肠 bacteria , an important indicator of water contamination .
moreover , a staggering 15 % of households report symptoms associated with typhoid .
if the us and other member states join the idb , assuming responsibility for improving state conditions in the americas , they can not only promote their own political agenda , but to use its membership to undermine the right of people who claim to serve services .
the inter-american development bank and the us government must take responsibility for their actions , and implement the necessary transparency mechanisms to ensure that the rights of such rights are no longer occurring . the us congress is asking and government responsibility for an annual review of the inter-american development bank and its funding .
in order to ensure that their commitment to development and human rights in the us and the inter-american development bank is to be made to ensure their commitment to development and human rights , the people of haiti and the us should have a public system in which the inter-american development bank and the united states are open to the public .
new haven – it is too easy to predict .
with the us stock market recovering from a sharp correction in early february , the spell of the great bull market began to return .
today , the recent correction has been defined as a fleeting aberration – a volatility shock that is still highly appropriate .
after all , the view that economic fundamentals – not just the us , but also the world – has been so good for a long time .
but is the fundamentals really that sound ?
for a saving-short us economy , there is no further truth than the 这离 .
in the third quarter of 2017 , america ’ s net national saving rate – the saving of businesses , households , and government governments – is just 2.1 % of national income , just one-third of the 6.3 % average of the 6.3 % average over the twentieth century .
it is important to see savings in “ net ” thinking , which means that , in assessing how much money is left for the expansion of productive capacity , the depreciation of the inevitable or abandoned capacity will be removed .
net savings represent today ’ s investment in the future , and america ’ s calculations are saving close to zero .
alas , the story is not over .
to finance consumption and growth , the us borrows surplus saving abroad to compensate for domestic shortages .
all of these borrowing amounts to a massive balance-of-payments deficit , with a large trade deficit .
president donald trump ’ s administration does not need to be responsible for this sad state of affairs , but its policies will exacerbate the dilemma .
last year , trump signed legislation that would lift the us federal budget deficit by $ 1.5 billion over the next decade .
and now the us has its great wisdom , and it will raise the number of $ 300 billion by the latest deal in order to avoid a government shutdown .
at the time of the economy ’ s proximity to full employment , deficit spending simply makes no sense : such a large increase in the federal budget would be enough to move toward zero net national saving rates .
in december 2017 , the personal savings rate fell to 2.4 % of disposable ( after-tax ) income , the lowest in 12 years , only about one-quarter of the 9.3 % average in the last three decades of the twentieth century .
with domestic saving collapsing , the us has two options – reducing investment and the economic growth that it supports , or increase borrowing from abroad .
over the last 35 years , the us has chosen the latter , with a balance-of-payments deficit of almost every year since 1982 ( only a small exception in 1991 , owing to the gulf war ’ s foreign aid during the gulf war ) .
of course , the same is true of the us trade deficit with these deficits , which are deeply entrenched .
in 2017 , the us ran trade deficits with 102 countries .
the multilateral external trade deficit in a saving-short us economy is probably the most egregious policy blunder made by the trump administration – a shift to protectionism .
further compression of domestic saving positions , which are already weakened , means that current-account and trade deficits continue to rise – a basic focus of macroeconomics that the us has consistently appreciated .
in january , the trump administration ’ s imposition of tariffs on china ’ s solar panels and washing machines to resolve multilateral imbalances will not be helpful in addressing multilateral imbalances .
moreover , because emerging trade barriers are likely to increase – for example , the us department of commerce recently proposed imposing high tariffs on aluminum and steel – the combination of protectionism and expanding trade imbalances is more problematic for the us economy , which is increasingly dependent on foreign capital .
the fundamentals of a saving-short us economy are hardly reliable , but they are more precarious than ever .
lacking a cushion of credible support from income creation , the lack of savings also makes the us more vulnerable to fickle asset prices .
this is especially true for american consumers who rely on the rise in equity and housing prices to support a living way of income inequality .
the same is true for the fed , which relies on unconventional monetary policies to support the real economy through the so-called wealth effects .
fueled momentum in the momentum of the trends in employment , industrial output , consumer sentiment , and corporate earnings , the argument for sound fundamentals is a record that is broken in times of financial-market volatility .
but momentum and fundamentals are two very different things .
momentum is all but invisible , especially for the saving-short us economy .
with policies that are counterproductive in the years ahead , the myth of sound us fundamentals is like a horror story .
