alliances for peace
washington , dc – i grew up in the shadow of world war ii and the dawn of the cold war .
my father was a 事务处 officer who had an opportunity to watch history closely closely closely : i would never forget and keep him on the beach in normandy .
likewise , i would never forget the strange sense of the bicycle passage from 西柏林 to east berlin , and saw the contrast between liberals and those trapped in the iron curtain .
many years later , what i have shocked is that a generation of leaders won not only war , but also peace .
they worked together .
the us and our partners worked hard to create alliances that provide prosperity and stability to western europe , japan , and south korea .
the old enemy became a new ally , together with a leading global economic system that led to a more prosperous global economy .
even when the cold war raged , leaders found ways to cooperate on arms control and to prevent nuclear armageddon .
in short , by building effective and indispensable international institutions and strategic partnerships , we have not only avoided another devastating world war , but we ended up ending the cold war , raising living standards for hundreds of millions of people around the world .
this is the remarkable story of the twentieth century .
the question now is how the story of the twenty-first century unfolds .
today , the world order faces new challenges .
extremists who engage in religious jihad threaten governments and people everywhere .
technology is accelerating the balance of power between 治国者 and 被治者 , providing opportunities for democratic accountability , and creates obstacles to inclusive politics .
we have come from a world where power is distributed hierarchies to the distribution of power .
statecraft has yet to adapt .
the international institutions and partnerships that emerged during the post-war period need to be sustained and required modernization .
faced with all of these turmoil , some argue that the us should turn inward .
this is a cliché .
some suggested that .
they were wrong after the fall of the berlin wall 25 years ago , when they were wrong .
they are now wrong .
the need for leadership has never been so large , and the us has never been more engaged in the world .
the role of democracy in our first peace in afghanistan ’ s history reminds us that all of the world ’ s blood and money cost the country the same amount of blood and money to help afghans win the war .
we know that 100 % of the chemical weapons that would destroy syria ’ s claim that the chemical weapons that are not being delivered are impossible , just as there is no such effort , just as syria ’ s appalling civil war is not over .
the same is true of asia , where president barack obama and chinese president xi jinping has just pledged to address climate change , and we can see what really leadership is , and how countries can do what it takes to achieve a successful climate agreement , which will also require a successful climate agreement in paris next year .
the world has changed , and we have changed .
the map on the map no longer contains the gravest threats , and the players are no longer divided into two camps .
in the twenty-first century , the back door is everywhere .
thus , the world needs coalition diplomacy .
no country can defeat terrorism alone .
no country can solve the existential crisis on its own .
no country can eradicate extreme poverty , combat potential pandemics , or improve nuclear security .
if i don ’ t face up to the world , we all can not afford a safer , wealthier life .
we must forge new alliances with allies , civil society – yes , and , yes , with the general public – to forge new coalitions .
a good example is the international effort against the islamic state ’ s brutality in iraq and syria .
political , humanitarian , and intelligence tools from more than 60 countries are used to support joint military action .
success does not depend on what a country or even a few countries can do alone , but depends on what we all can achieve by acting together .
in another , equally important front , the us is working with the un to inspire the global response to the threat of ebola .
my personal dealings with more than 50 foreign leaders have been discussed , and we agree that only by coordinating action can we stop west africa ’ s disaster and ebola .
we have made progress on both issues , but much work remains to be done .
this requires a lot of diplomacy , mobilization for decades , and a coalition of alliances with the new partners .
but by overcoming differences , working together to defeat the islamic state , conquer ebola , we are strengthening support for a world order based on collective solutions to shared problems .
cooperation is equally important to consolidate the economic principles that underpin the post-war prosperity of the us and others .
in any country , frustration will not be faster than opportunity .
for example , the trans-pacific partnership ( tpp ) has shown that obama ’ s resolve with a third of global trade , 40 % of global gdp , and 40 % of global gdp .
both the us and our partners are big .
it is estimated that , in the us alone , the tpp could increase $ 77 per year of real income and support 650,000 new jobs .
the transatlantic trade and investment partnership ( ttip ) , which is negotiating with the eu , provides another big step forward .
genuine partnerships are not built overnight , either for mutual security or shared prosperity .
patient diplomacy and collective will are necessary to advance common goals , as the us has done for decades – peace , prosperity , and stability in the us and our global partners .
closing the investment gap
berkeley – private investment in the united states and other advanced economies has been weak in the wake of the 2008 global financial crisis , and it is puzzling .
indeed , according to the international monetary fund , private investment fell by 25 % from pre-crisis pre-crisis trends in 2014 .
the depth and breadth of investment are large , affecting not only residential investment , but also investment in equipment and structures .
business investment is significantly lower than anticipated in 2008 , when business investment in the united states collapsed in the last year , owing to plummeting investment in the energy sector .
interestingly , america ’ s investment shortfall and the sharp rebound in returns on capital are occurring .
private capital returns , in some ways , are now higher than at any time in recent decades .
but much empirical research confirms that , at the macro level , business investment depends largely on expectations and output growth , rather than on current rates of return or retained earnings .
according to the imf , the “ accelerator ” theory of this investment explains much of the weakness in business investment in advanced economies since the 2008 crisis .
in this interpretation , us investment growth is consistent with the normal historical relationship with output growth .
in short , private investment is weak primarily because of weak recovery .
firms have reduced their pre-crisis investment plans to adapt to the “ new normal ” of growth in demand for output , more uncertain , and more uncertain .
in the context of weak aggregate demand , stronger public investment encourages more private business investment .
but public investment has also fallen short of pre-crisis expectations , exacerbating , rather than mitigating , private investment .
the accelerator explanation for us business investment is consistent with evidence that the projected demand growth , for example , is relatively strong – for example , in an cable , communication , digital platform , social networking , and until recently – investment growth is relatively strong .
indeed , communications and cable companies account for the largest share of business capital spending in the last three years , followed by energy production and minerals .
differences in innovation opportunities among industries are also consistent with the changing share of business investment .
from 2009 to 2015 , the us equipment investment slowdown slowed , but intellectual property products , including research and development , software , and so-called original works ( the output of artists , studios , and publishers ) .
in cyclical expansions , investment in r & d is typically faster than gdp , and recent trends have been consistent with historical trends .
the accelerator theory of investment suggests that a large number of r & d investment occurs in technology-intensive sectors that are currently projected to be strong in both current and future expectations .
there is also evidence that the distribution of returns on capital is becoming increasingly skewed toward these sectors .
according to the latest mckinsey global institute , the most digitized sectors – ranked by 18 metrics , such as digital assets , digital use , and digital labor – are significantly higher than traditional sectors .
in a letter to the s & p 500 & p 500 company , ceo larry fink , ceo of the world ’ s largest investment management company , has expressed concern about many global companies ’ opportunity to waste the value of their own companies with dividends and buybacks .
in the us non-financial corporations , the share of investable funds used for dividends and share buybacks since the 1980s has increased ( despite ups and downs ) .
during the recession of 2008-2009 , that share was significantly higher , but now it has recovered to around 50 % , with a high historical average .
the macro evidence suggests that the main reason why business investment in the us and other advanced countries has been disappointing since the global financial crisis is weak demand , not excessive funding for shareholders .
but , in the long run , the increase in dividends and share buybacks as a percentage of investment in corporate investment is a symptom of rising shareholder pressure on companies to focus on short-term returns rather than long-term investments .
the mckinsey survey recently investigated 1,000 名高管 and corporate directors , with 63 % indicating that shareholder pressure to achieve short-term returns has increased over the last few years .
indeed , 79 % said they were under pressure to get large financial returns in two years or less .
shareholder pressure is often larger for established firms , and over the last few decades , the us has risen as a result of the decline in corporate startup rates .
moreover , fink and others have warned that linking executives ’ pay to short-term successes , such as quarterly earnings per share or annual stock performance , have encouraged the “ short-termism ” of corporate investment decisions .
diminishing capital gains – that is , the increase in the return to investment – would reduce incentives for short-termism in investors .
larry fink , the center for american progress , and hillary clinton have all proposed this approach .
in its latest ceo , fink also called for major companies to create annual “ strategic frameworks ” for long-term value creation , using quantitative 财务指标 and linking long-term executives ’ compensation to such metrics .
these frameworks , fink notes , should cover environmental , social , and governance ( esg ) factors that are central to long-term values .
companies can use the new evidence-based criteria developed by the sustainability accounting accounting standards board board to disclose information about esg performance .
the strategic framework for esg disclosures encourages companies and their shareholders to focus more on long-term values than on short-term financial performance .
at the macro level , however , expectations of demand and corresponding innovation will remain the main driver of business investment .
inequality and american children
new york – children are a special group .
they can not choose parents , let alone the broader circumstances of birth .
they did not protect or care like adults .
thus , the international league adopted the geneva declaration on child rights in 1924 , and the international community adopted the convention on child rights in 1989 .
sadly , the us has failed to meet its obligations .
indeed , it has not even ratified the convention on the rights of children .
the us has always prided itself on a land of opportunity , and should be a model for justice and enlightened treatment .
instead , it has become a symbol of failure – “ contributions ” to the global weakening of children ’ s rights in the international economy .
the average american child may not be the worst in the world , but the contrast between american wealth and child conditions is unparalleled .
in the developed world , only romania has a higher rate of child poverty .
the rate of child poverty in the us is two-thirds higher than in the united kingdom , and three times higher than in the nordic countries .
some groups are far worse off : 38 % of black children and 30 % of hispanic children are poor .
none of this is because the us cares about its children .
rather , the policy agenda that the us adopted in recent decades has made its economy widely unequal , leaving the most vulnerable segments of society increasingly behind .
the increasingly concentrated concentration of wealth – and a significant reduction in wealth taxes – implies fewer spending on public goods such as education and child protection .
as a result , american children are worse off .
their fate is a painful lesson to show that inequality is not only undermining economic growth and stability – and economists and organizations like the international monetary fund are beginning to admit that it is the concept of our most cherished society .
income inequality is correlated with inequalities in health , inequality of education , and environmental hazards , and all of this affects children more than others .
indeed , nearly one-fifth of america ’ s poor children are diagnosed with asthma , 60 % higher than poor children .
child learning is nearly double the percentage of children earning less than $ 35,000 per year , and almost twice as many children as a result of their annual income .
some members of the us congress also want to cut food stamps – about 23 million american households depend on food stamps – which would pose a danger to poor children .
inequality in these outcomes is tied to inequality .
in countries where childhood nutrition is inadequate , inadequate access to health care and education , environmental risks are inevitably higher , and poor children ’ s life prospects are far worse .
moreover , part of the country ’ s current opportunity for equality of opportunity is less equal to any other advanced country , owing to the fact that children in the us are more dependent on their children ’ s income and education .
for example , in america ’ s elite universities , only 9 % of students come from the bottom half of the population , with 74 % come from the top quarter .
most societies believe that the standard of living that helped ensure that young people fulfill their potential is a moral obligation .
some countries have even constitutionally mandated educational opportunities .
in the united states , however , the education of rich students is higher than it is for the poor .
as a result , the us is wasting one of its most valuable assets , with some young people unable to acquire skills and engage in dysfunctional activities .
the prisons of states in california , texas , and higher spending on higher education are sometimes higher .
without compensating measures – including pre-school education , which begins at a young age – unequal opportunities for education will translate into unequal outcomes when children reach five years of age .
this should be a spur to policy action .
indeed , while the effects of inequality are overwhelming , they are largely avoidable .
the extreme inequality observed by some countries is not the inexorable result of economic power and laws .
the right policies – strengthening social safety nets , progressive taxation , and better regulation ( especially in the financial sector ) – can reverse these negative trends .
to create the political will needed to meet these reforms , we must make policymakers ’ inertia and inaction with the grim reality of inequality and the negative impact on children .
we can reduce the disenfranchisement , increase equality of opportunity , and thus provide a foundation for more just , prosperous future – a future that reflects the values we have publicly pursued .
why do we not act ?
with adults , he is responsible – perhaps not enough – to be responsible – and not enough to make good decisions – but children ’ s circumstances have no choice but to impose them on them .
perhaps children are more entitled to protection than anyone else – and the us should serve as a model for the former world .

new york – in 1831 , france ’ s liberal aristocracy , alexis de tocqueville , visited the united states in order to write a study of the “ enlightened ” prison system in the united states , which has been held in a 单间 , like remorse .
as a result , the us tour made de tocqueville ’ s masterpiece , america ’ s democracy , in which he preached the world ’ s first genuine liberal democracy , compared to the old world ’ s institutions .
tocqueville also had serious reservations .
the greatest danger to american democracy , he argued , is that the tyranny of the us is the tyranny of most people , and america ’ s suffocating , suffocating , minority views , and dissent .
he believes that any unlimited power , whether personal or political , is bound to end in a mess .
in most cases , democracy requires restraint , just as the government of all other institutions is .
thus , the uk has mixed the power and the prerogatives of the monarchy .
as a result , americans still cherish the constitution ’ s separation of government power .
on the contrary , in france ’ s republican system , the state represents the will of the so-called people .
as a result , its authority is less constrained , which may explain the frequency of street protests and even mass violence in france .
indeed , these upheavals are informal checks on formal power .
tocqueville noted another source of restraint in the us system : the power of religion .
human greed , as well as the temptation of radicalization , was tempered by a common christian faith .
in the us , freedom and religion are inextricably linked .
the spectacle of american politics today seems to have cast doubt on tocqueville ’ s observation .
or , rather , the rhetoric of many republicans aspiring to fill the presidency is in the opposite of what tocqueville saw in 1831 .
religion and freedom are frequently mentioned as talk , but often to promote extreme views .
religious minorities are oppressed .
apocalyptic fears are stoked .
intolerance is promoted .
all of this is in the name of god .
of course , the us is not the only country where fringe demagogues are being poisoned .
in western europe , religious language is less heard than ever , but in parts of eastern europe , turkey , and israel .
the meaning of populism is much more about democracy : liberal elites are responsible for all of our problems and anxieties , whether the refugee crisis in europe or the rise of the global economy , whether “ multiculturalism ” or the rise of radical islam .
populism is causing alarm , because mainstream politicians are becoming increasingly unable to find a convincing way to prevent it .
those who rightly worry about fear of politics like to assume that populism is a threat to democracy itself .
distrust of elites leads to distrust of the system , and hopes that great leaders will allow us to escape the selfishness of our professional politicians leads to a new form of tyranny .
that may be true .
but , indeed , it is not democracy that is under siege .
the phenomenon of donald trump ’ s phenomenon is that old parties can be overthrown by popular outsiders .
social media also make it possible to circumvent traditional authority , such as serious newspapers or magazines , as possible , issuing any perspective .
the power of private wealth to sway public opinion is also disrupting the traditional order , especially in the us .
elitism can be fanned by vast personal wealth , because the elites are defined by education rather than the ability to define them .
angry people who are enraged by populist beliefs , clever bankers , or cynical journalists are more angry than their anger about billionaires .
( the combination of president barack obama ’ s elite and his skin – or , rather , the combination of both – offers so much anger . )
at the same time , people are more empowered than ever before to vote for power .
like the barbaric view of the internet , these figures are no longer subject to traditional political parties .
it is not democracy that has steadily receded , but that de tocqueville thought it was essential to the functioning of liberal politics .
populist leaders increasingly choose to choose their majority as a license to crush all political and cultural dissent .
de tocqueville ’ s nightmare was not in america ’ s reality , but the situation in russia , turkey , hungary ( perhaps poland , and perhaps poland ) is far from the same .
even israel – despite its obvious problems , has been a strong democracy – has also been heading toward this direction , with government ministers demanding that the writer , artists , and journalists demonstrate their “ national loyalty . ”
it is hard to know how traditional elites will retain any authority .
but i think tocqueville was right .
without editors , there is no serious press .
without a party led by experienced politicians , the line of entertainment and politics disappears .
without limits on the preferences and prejudices of most people , intolerance becomes a rule .
this is not nostalgia or 势利 .
this is not a plea to trust anyone with the authority to “ 气场 . ”
anger over elites is not always unjust .
globalization , immigration , and cosmopolitanism are in the interest of a highly educated minority , but sometimes the interests of those who are at times sacrificed .
but the problems that tocqueville discovered in the 1830s are more relevant today than ever .
liberal democracy can not be reduced to populism .
constraints on most rule are necessary to protect minorities , whether ethnic minorities , religious minorities , or the knowledge minorities .
when that protection disappears , we will ultimately lose the freedom that it deserves .

america ’ s foreign policy after iraq
what next after iraq ?
if president george w. bush ’ s troop “ surge ” fails to deliver a “ victory , ” what lessons can the us learn from its future foreign policy ?
will it turn inward , as it did after its defeat in vietnam 30 years ago ?
will it move from promoting democracy to a narrow realist view of its interests ?
even in discussions in washington , dc , some thoughtful foreign observers have begun to argue that these longer-term problems have been raised .
analysts and pundits are often mistaken about america ’ s standing in the world .
for example , 20 years ago , the general public thought was in decline .
ten years later , as the cold war ended , the new public view was that the world was a superpower .
some neo-conservative pundits believe that the us is so strong that it can decide on its own will , and others have to follow .
charles Krauthammer famously described this view as a “ new unilateralism , ” which had had an important impact on the bush administration before the attacks of september 11 , 2001 .
but the new unilateralism is based on a profound misunderstanding of the nature of world politics .
power is the ability to achieve what needs to be desired .
whether the resources with which they have it depends on the environment .
for example , if the war is carried out in the desert , a large 现代化 is a powerful resource , but if it is in the midst of the swamp – as in vietnam – the us has discovered in vietnam .
in the past , there was general thought that military power dominated most issues , but in today ’ s world , the great context of power varies .
i have likened today ’ s political power to a three-dimensional chess game .
the world is indeed unipolar , and it is likely to persist for decades .
but in the middle of the middle of economic relations , the world is already multi-polar , and the us is unlikely to be able to work with europe , japan , china , and other countries without the help of its own .
transnational issues beyond the control of governments – including from climate change to pandemics to transnational terrorism – are messy , and thus pointless in this context .
but it is on this bottom board that we are seeing the biggest challenges we face today .
the only way to deal with these problems is through cooperation with others , which will require the attraction of “ soft ” power and hard power and hard power with a simple military solution that keeps us going .
the new unilateralist who dominates bush ’ s first administration mistakenly thought that a unipolar distribution of power in the military context is enough to guide foreign policy .
like a young child with a hammer , they believe that all issues are like nail .
their approach to thinking is now obvious .
in playing a three-dimensional chess game , one is focusing only on a board that is doomed to fail in the long run .
fortunately , this pendulum is now slipping toward cooperation .
in bush ’ s second term , some of the most extreme unilateralism left the government , while the president himself adopted a more multilateral approach than it was in dealing with north korea or iran .
similarly , all complaints about the un , the united states and other countries , have been used to clean up the legacy of the last summer war in lebanon .
americans now view cooperative action on global climate change more favorably .
similarly , the threat of pandemics means that americans may finally recognize the importance of a stronger world health organization , just as the problem of nuclear proliferation makes it more clear that the international atomic energy agency is more important .
the nature of these problems means that the us has not returned to the luxury of inward , whatever the outcome of iraq .
this is not a question you can leave abroad .
they follow suit and go back home .
america ’ s foreign policy is also unlikely to return to a narrow realism , which emphasizes democracy and human rights .
while the iraq war has discredited the idea of coercive democratization , republicans and democrats remain strong in their foreign policy orientation .
the problem facing whoever elected president in 2008 will be to seek the right pragmatic way to advance democratic values and adjust official rhetoric accordingly .
when official rhetoric trumps reality , others think it is hypocritical .
americans need to find their commitment to democracy , freedom , and rights in a way that respects diversity and others ’ views .
the lesson that iraq offers is to develop civil society and the importance of civil society , before trying to hold broad elections .
democracy is not just elections , because it requires significant investment in education , institutions , and promoting non-governmental development .
it must be rooted in local society and bear its characteristics , not imposed abroad .
the more likely the us response to the war in iraq is unlikely .
the paradox of american power is that the world ’ s only military superpower can not protect its citizens by acting alone .

american hegemony or america ’ s primacy ?
cambridge – in modern history , no country has a strong global military power like the united states .
but some analysts now believe that the us is on the verge of losing a global hegemonic power – the following .
this history , though increasingly popular , is misleading .
it is true that it has a navy equal to the size and third of third and third , and the “ 日不落 empire ” covers a quarter of humanity .
but the relative power sources of britain ’ s imperial empire were different .
in the outbreak of world war i , the number of military personnel in britain was fourth only among the great powers , and gdp was fourth and fourth in terms of military spending .
the british empire took advantage of local fighters to rule .
in the 8.6 million british forces in wwi , nearly one-third came from abroad .
this makes it increasingly difficult for the london government to declare war on the entire empire when nationalist sentiment began to rise .
by world war ii , protecting empire became a liability rather than a asset .
the fact that britain ’ s power with germany and russia is close to it makes it even more urgent .
the fact is that the us does not have the colonies that it must manage , so it has greater freedom of maneuver than the uk .
moreover , the us is not threatened by its neighbors and two oceans , which are much easier to protect themselves .
this brings us to another problem with global hegemony : the confusion about what “ hegemony ” really means .
some observers portray hegemony as a synonym for imperialism ; but the us is a clear example of the need for a formal empire .
others define hegemony as a capable set of rules for international institutions ; but the hegemon must have many more influence in relative terms .
still others believe that hegemony means that the most powerful resource resources are under control .
but , accordingly , in the nineteenth century , britain – whose gdp was the world ’ s third-largest ( below ) peak of its gdp – was not supposed to be a hegemon , despite its maritime dominance .
likewise , those who claim that america had hegemony after 1945 failed to note that the soviet union has been checks on us military power for more than four decades .
although the us has unmatched economic power , its room for political and military maneuver was constrained by soviet power .
some analysts refer to the post-1945 period as the us-led hierarchical order , characterized by liberty , with the us providing public goods and establishing a loose multilateral rules and institutions that are also likely to win in weak countries .
they argue that , for many countries , the institutional framework for preserving this institutional framework is rational , even if american power sources decline .
in this sense , the us-led international order has a greater role to play than america ’ s dominant source of power , even though many others argue that the rise of new powers portends the collapse of the order .
but , in the era of so-called american hegemony , there has always been a lot of mixed links to the facts .
it is less a global order than a group of like-minded countries ( mainly in the americas and western europe , less than half of the world ’ s ) .
its impact on non-member countries – including china , india , indonesia , and the soviet bloc – is not always positive .
as a result , america ’ s position in the world should be called a “ 半 . ”
of course , the us did maintain economic dominance after 1945 : world war ii , which led many countries to become melting , meant that the us contributed nearly half of global gdp .
but , from a political or military perspective , the world is bipolar , and the soviet union checks and balances .
in fact , the us was often unable to defend its interests in the interim : the soviet union had nuclear weapons ; the communist party established the regime in china , cuba , and vietnam ; the war ended ; the hungarian and czechoslovakia insurgents were crushed .
against this background , it may be more accurate to describe a country ’ s disproportionate share of power in three major power areas : military , economic , and soft power .
the question now is whether the era of american primacy is coming to an end .
the rise of transnational forces and non-state actors – not to mention emerging powers like china – implies significant changes in the global situation .
but there is still reason to believe that , at least in the first half of this century , the us will retain its dominant power resources and continues to play a central role in the global balance of power .
in short , while the era of american dominance is not over , it is bound to change important .
whether these changes will increase global security and prosperity remains to be seen .
i tell my friends outside the us
cambridge – i frequently travel abroad , and my foreign friends ask each other with varying degrees of confusion : what happened to your country ?
here ’ s my answer .
first , don ’ t misinterpret the 2016 election .
contrary to what some commentary claims , the us political system has not been eliminated by a wave of populism .
to be sure , we have a long history of rebelling against elites .
it is donald trump ’ s use of the tradition of andrew jackson and william wallace and george wallace in the nineteenth century and , as george wallace and george wallace did in the twentieth century .
and trump lost nearly three million votes .
he won the election by appealing to populist anger in three rust belt states , michigan , pennsylvania , and wisconsin – three states that previously had the democratic base .
if those states had ten million votes , then trump will lose the electoral college and the presidency .
that is , trump ’ s victory reflects the real problem of growing social and regional inequality in the us .
万斯 , 万斯 ’ s recent bestseller , describes the huge difference between california and 阿巴拉契亚 .
research by princeton university economist anne casper and angus deaton shows that low-income whites who do not have a college degree are worse than african-americans , and african-americans have historically experienced the least unequal inequality in history .
in 1999 , white death rates without a college degree were around 30 % lower than in african-americans ; by 2015 , the data became 30 % .
moreover , manufacturing jobs , which were once a major source of working-class whites , have fallen sharply in the past generation , with only 12 % of the total workforce .
these previous democratic voters were attracted by trump ’ s commitment to change and 创造 manufacturing jobs .
ironically , trump ’ s efforts to repeal president barack obama ’ s health-care bill will exacerbate their lives .
the second thing i tell foreign friends is not to underestimate trump ’ s communication skills .
many are offended by his tweet storms and his twitter storms .
but trump is a veteran of television reality-tv , and he knows that a monopoly on a monopoly is essential to success , and that it can be done by extreme rhetoric , rather than caution .
twitter helps him to set the agenda and distract his critics .
the content that offends the media and academics does not matter for his supporters .
but , as he begins to move from campaigning to a 自我中心 campaign , twitter has also played a two-edged sword that prevents the needed allies .
third , i tell my friends not to count on trump ’ s performance .
normally , a president who loses the popular vote will turn to the political center to attract more supporters .
trump , by contrast , has claimed that he won the popular vote , and , as he really did , he would have called for a base of voters .
while trump has energetically nominated the ranks of the centrist , secretary of state , secretary of state , and department of homeland security , he appoints republican extremists to the environmental protection agency and the ministry of health and public services .
the white house staff , which he has arranged for pragmatism , also had ideologues , and he can deal with both .
fourth , one should not underestimate american institutions .
sometimes my friend says that it is like the lower sky , asking whether trump is as dangerous a narcissist as mussolini .
i tell them not to panic .
despite all the problems the us has , it was not italy in 1922 .
our national political elites are often polarized ; but america ’ s founders were the same .
when it comes to designing the us constitution , the founders ’ goal was not to ensure a harmonious government , but to regulate the regime ’ s entire system of checks and balances and increase the exercise of power .
some joke that the founders created a political system that prevents george gyanendra – or any dictator – from taking office .
they would prefer to achieve liberty at the cost of inefficiency .
in the early days of trump ’ s presidency , we can not determine what might happen after a major terrorist attack .
but , so far , the courts , congress , and state governments have been constrained and balanced by madison ’ s intent .
the permanent civil servants of the executive branch have also played a stabilizing role .
finally , my friend asked what this means for us foreign policy and the us-led liberal international order .
frankly , i don ’ t know , but i worry less about china ’ s rise than that of trump .
while us leaders , including obama , have been complaining about free riders , the us has played a leading role in providing key global public services such as safe , stable international reserve currencies , relatively open markets , and global public resources .
despite problems in the us-led international order , the world has prospered , and poverty is gradually reduced .
but we can not be sure that the current system will continue .
the us needs to work with china , europe , japan , and others to manage transnational issues .
during the 2016 campaign , trump was the first major party candidate to question the us alliance system in seven decades .
since taking office in january , statements from trump and his appointees suggest that this suspicion may not be eliminated .
after all , america ’ s hard and soft power is largely sixty allies in the us ( and only a few ) .
but it is much more uncertain whether to help manage the multilateral institutions of the world economy and global people .
trump ’ s budget director speaks to hard power budgets , cutting funds from the state department and the un system .
other officials advocate replacing multilateral trade deals with “ fair and balanced ” bilateral arrangements .
and trump has refused to acknowledge obama ’ s efforts to address climate change .
i told my friends that i hope to give them to them .
but i did not .
denver – if you focus on the debate about the united states ’ news media , the “ america first ” may seem to be america ’ s interventionism : it is frequently rumored that it is frequently coming to war with the united states and its exceptional military power .
but interventionism is different from internationalism .
it is impossible to confuse the quick use of force with deliberate use of force and thoughtful engagement of the world and its problems .
in the us “ 摆平 ” transactional worldview , international disputes are often viewed as military challenges to political issues .
in fact , the opposite is often the opposite , which is why the world ’ s most complex conflict has rarely been solved by intervention .
geopolitical conflict has a long and ugly history , and violence is often not an intrinsic feature , but a symptom of its difficulty .
they are often linked to identity , and they claim that ownership of a land with a “ national ” ” is common .
the basis for political membership is often ethnic , not civic , that is contrary to americans ’ understanding of state .
at the same time , some contemporary problems may be the product of flawed arrangements for decades or centuries .
two examples of this can be easily thought of the sykes-picot agreement of 1916 between france and france in 1916 , and the 1919 treaty of versailles , which had divided borders in the balkans .
in both cases , the creation of a new state might seem like a straightforward solution , but doing so would only lead to more wars .
for the us , international conflicts are often the opportunity to demonstrate “ toughness ” and “ resolve . ”
america ’ s airstrikes in bosnia were intended to promote a political process that has been backed by the eu and russia .
air strikes are the last resort , to punish those who do not support the peace process .
so , for many american pundits and politicians , the lesson from bosnia is simply that the bad guys should be bombed sooner rather than later .
few opportunity to study the region ’ s complex history in order to distinguish between smart and sensible boundaries across each entity .
if they do , they may end up focusing more on protecting external borders and nurturing a constitutional structure that enables new states to integrate into the european map .
the same is true of kosovo , where history is more complex than many are willing to explore .
a diplomatic approach that seeks to achieve kosovo ’ s sovereignty while respecting serbs ’ emotional attachment to serbs is derided .
this means that military means are the primary – and not last – option to ensure kosovo ’ s independence .
many european countries , to be sure , oppose creating an independent state and calling for a multilateral diplomacy before discussing any air strikes .
interventionism in the century after the turn of the century continues to exist , and it is on the broader stage .
after the attacks on september 11 , 2001 , the us led the invasion and then occupied afghanistan to root out al-qaeda .
but the us lost its patience after 17 years of military deployments , and many accepted us president donald trump ’ s “ america first ” isolationism .
in iraq , with a much weaker connection with terrorism , the us spends enormous military effort to achieve confusing and 飘摇不定 goals , and it seems that they are not clearly expressed .
american interventionism tends to be accompanied by criticism of friends and allies , accusing them of weak and vacillating when confronted with global challenges such as russian president vladimir putin or china ’ s growing assertiveness in the south china sea .
when the problems arise in afghanistan and iraq , the us blames these countries ’ political leaders , denouncing their corruption and human rights .
europeans , too , are decried , not least because of incompetence , but also because they enjoy their lives without taking proper responsibility .
given that these narratives are deeply etched into the american public ’ s consciousness , it is no wonder that trump ’ s dystopian vision will overwhelm internationalism , because the latter has become an endless use of force and a mockery of allies .
but those who claim to support it can accelerate its revival by acting according to its original meaning .
traditional internationalists show respect for the views of others , and demonstrate – and even support – multilateral structures .
what internationalism needs now is america ’ s commitment to engage in cooperation , even when other governments need more time to obtain a mandate from their respective systems .
after all , america ’ s international leadership must be embedded in america ’ s values and broadly adhere to the 原则 principles behind liberal democracy .
in other words , the us must lead the way .
and its recent dysfunction – particularly on refugees – has undermined the influence that its power ultimately rests .
renewing america ’ s leadership
madrid – december is always an opportunity to stop thinking and what future will be .
this year , one conclusion of this year ’ s thinking is that the us remains the centerpiece of the liberal world order , a position that is strong .
another is that the us needs to do more to meet its international standing .
over the years , doubts about whether the us can maintain global leadership have been raging .
but , while a widely focused multipolar world order may be doomed , the reality is that , for now , efforts to address global challenges – from climate change to conflict in the middle east – require us engagement .
unfortunately , the narrative of america ’ s decline has been a major market in recent years , and even us officials seem to have started believing that it is , pushing for weak piecemeal policies ( or even inaction ) .
president barack obama ’ s restrained foreign-policy approach is fueling , rather than containing , global instability .
the reasons for a strong act are disputed .
some blame obama for fear of repeating the past ; others blame the hostile congress .
indeed , perhaps both are working .
obama would rather act prudently – even when people call for decisive action – rather than urge more damage .
but the negative impact of a highly partisan us congress on the objective of creating obstacles can not be underestimated .
congress , for example , has blocked the international monetary fund ’ s governance reforms in 2010 , which could damage the legitimacy and importance of the bretton woods institutions .

american pie in the sky
new york – the risk of a disorderly crisis in the eurozone has been recognized , but optimism about the us remains optimistic .

of course , a drag on tax increases would be reduced substantially if tax increases were modest .

american power in the twenty-first century
cambridge – the united states government ’ s national intelligence council predicts that america ’ s advantage in 2025 will “ drastically weaken , ” and the key area in which the us has maintained its strength – military power – will be less important in the world in which it will compete .
the leader of the canadian opposition freedom party , michael ignatieff , believes that america ’ s power is over .
how can we know whether these predictions are correct ?
one should beware of misleading metaphors of a full-blown recession .
countries , after all , are not the individual individuals who can predict their lives .
for example , when the united kingdom lost its americas in the late eighteenth century , 勒斯 沃波尔 lamented that britain had become “ like denmark or 撒丁岛 . ”
but he failed to predict that the industrial revolution will make britain more secure in the coming century .
the roman empire lasted three centuries after the apogee of the roman empire .
even in the end , rome did not succumb to another country , but the road to death after being ravaged by a brutal tribe .
indeed , while china , india , or brazil will outperform america ’ s predictions over the next decade , a shift to traditional power shifts among major powers may be less than the rise of modern 蛮族 ( non-state actors ) .
in a world where information is based on information , the threat of decentralization may be greater than the transfer of power .
what , then , will wield power in the global information age ?
which resources can bring power ?
in the sixteenth century , the control of colonies and gold bars gave spain a competitive edge , in the seventeenth-century netherlands from trade and finance , in eighteenth-century france and france in the eighteenth century , and nineteenth-century british power came from its unique industrial status and navy .
conventional wisdom has always assumed that the army ’ s largest country will win , but it may be a state that is 最会 in the information age ( or state ) .
today , there is no clear way to measure the balance of power , much less how to develop successful survival strategies .
in his inaugural address in 2009 , president barack obama proposed “ our power from prudent use of power ; our security from the cause of justice , the power of models , and humility and restraint . ”
soon after , secretary of state hillary clinton said that “ america alone can not solve the most pressing problems , without america ’ s involvement in the world . ”
we must take advantage of what we call ‘ smart power , using all tools that can be used for us .
smart power means combining hard power and the soft power of attraction .
power always depends on the environment .
the children who play in the game are likely to become a laggard .
in the middle of the twentieth century , joseph stalin aptly asked the division of divisions , and four decades later , the pope remained intact , while stalin ’ s empire had collapsed .
in today ’ s world , as the environment differs , the distribution of power is changing .
the distribution of power resembles a three-dimensional chess game .
in the game of the game , military power will remain unipolar , and the us is likely to remain the only superpower for some time .
in the middle of the game , however , economic power has remained hierarchical for more than a decade , with the us , europe , japan , and the four major powers , and the importance of others growing .
the bottom chessboard is the realm of cross-border transactions that governments can not control .
participating non-state actors like electronic remittances are more than a majority of bankers in most countries , and the terrorists or threats of cyber security are in the other extreme .
it also includes new challenges like pandemics and climate change .
even after the financial crisis , the dizzying pace of technological development may continue to drive globalization and transnational challenges .
even the strongest countries have an increasing array of problems to control the problem of american power in the twenty-first century .
while the us has accomplished its achievements militarily , there are many military areas that can not be covered .
in the wake of the information revolution and the impact of globalization , the way the world ’ s political change has changed is to impede america ’ s unilateral pursuit of all international goals .
for example , international financial stability is vital to america ’ s prosperity , but the us needs other countries ’ cooperation to ensure international financial stability .
global climate change will also affect americans ’ quality of life , but the us can not rely on its own power to manage global climate .
in a world where borders are porous to drugs , infectious diseases , and terrorism , the us must help establish a league of nations and institutions to confront the challenges and threats that shared it .
in this sense , power has become a positive game .
it is not enough to consider the terms of the power of others , and we must consider the power of our goals .
on many transnational issues , empowering others can help to achieve their own goals .
in this world , networks and linkages have become important sources of relative power .
the problem facing america ’ s power in the twenty-first century is not a gradual decline , but rather a recognition that even the most powerful countries can not achieve their own goals .
