trump ’ s deplorables
new york – hillary clinton , the democratic party of the democratic party of the democratic party of the united states , recently called the support of her opponent , donald trump , “ a group of deplorables . ”
the wording was 不得体 and elegant , and she apologized for her remark .
but she was right .
trump has attracted many supporters , and some of their ideas are deplorable , such as ethnic ideas .
the problem is that many of these deplorable voters are relatively uneducated , making clinton ’ s assessment seem 势利 .
alas , the us has too many relatively uneducated people .
in developed countries , the us ranks low in terms of literacy , common sense , and science .
japan , south korea , the netherlands , and russia score much more than the us .
this is at least partly because education is too dependent on markets : the people with money are better educated , and without being educated .
so far , it is clear that clinton attracted more educated urban voters , while trump has mostly attracted less education , whose forebears were often supported by the democratic coal industry or industrial workers .
does this mean the connection between education ( or lack thereof ) and the appeal of dangerous demagogue ?
one of the most notable features of trump is his own ignorance , despite his high education , and the fact that he has benefited from flaunting his ignorance .
perhaps a 大嗓门 无知者 makes a lot easier for the world ’ s knowledge and people to believe themselves .
but this would be a mistake to assume in the rhetoric of a populist agitator .
emotions are more important , and , in the us and elsewhere , the main emotions dominating the demagogues are fear , resentment , and distrust .
the same was true of hitler in germany .
but the nazi party ’ s early supporters were largely not the least educated .
on average , germany ’ s higher education population is more populous than other countries , and some of the most enthusiastic nazi teachers , engineers , and doctors , and local businessmen , white-collar workers , and peasants .
overall , urban factory workers and conservative catholics are less sensitive to hitler ’ s rhetoric than many more educated protestants .
low education does not explain hitler ’ s rise .
fear , resentment , and distrust are high in weimar germany , when the failure of world war i and the disastrous economic depression gave germans a sense of humiliation .
but the racial prejudices inspired by nazi propaganda are different from that of trump ’ s supporters today .
jews were perceived as a sinister force , dominating elite professions : bankers , professors , lawyers , news media , and entertainment .
they are behind the so-called 搞鬼 , making germany a great one again .
trump ’ s supporters also display a similar hatred of the elite , such as wall street bankers , “ mainstream ” media , and washington insiders .
but their resentment was directed toward poor mexican immigrants , blacks , or middle east refugees , who are treated as freeloaders , who are 抢走了 ( white ) in the social hierarchy .
this is a problem of a group that is less vulnerable in a globalized world than those who are more vulnerable to globalization .
today , the us , like the weimar republic , has lacked trust in mainstream political and economic institutions , so that leaders following the promise of maximum disruption are following the lead .
they want to recover the old glory through a radical “ clean house . ”
in hitler ’ s germany , this hope existed among all classes , both elite and grassroots .
in trump ’ s america , this hope is mostly mostly thrives .
in the united states and europe , more affluent , highly educated voters believe that today ’ s world is not so frightening , benefiting from a combination of open borders , cheap migration , information technology , and cultural influences .
likewise , migrants and minorities who seek to improve their lives have no interest in joining the revolt against them , which is why they voted for clinton .
so trump must rely on the disaffected white americans who feel left behind .
the fact that people feel sufficiently strong to support a president like trump ’ s unqualified presidential candidate suggests that american society is dying .
this does have some relation to education – because well-educated , educated , and poorly educated systems have left too many vulnerable people .
in the past , there are enough industrial jobs to be left to less educated voters , leaving them decent lives .
today , these jobs are gradually disappearing in post-industrial societies , and too many people feel that they have nothing to lose .
this is true in many countries , but in the us , it is too high for a paranoid demagogue to lead not only to america , but also to a country that seeks to protect its freedoms in an increasingly dangerous world .
america ’ s double trade policy
cambridge – the high-profile american trade delegation has returned quietly from china to the united states .
this outcome is not surprising , because america ’ s demand is entirely and one-sided .
americans urge china to change its industrial policies and intellectual property rules , and demand that the chinese government do anything to do anything about trump ’ s unilateral tariffs on chinese exports .
a generation of global trade agreements – beginning with the world trade organization ’ s establishment in 1995 – was based on a premise that the global rules of law will converge .
china ’ s approach to economic management , in particular , will become more “ western . ”
on the contrary , the ongoing divergence in economic institutions has become fertile ground for trade frictions .
china and other economies have good reason to reject the pressure on us trade lobbies to impose pressure on them .
after all , china has achieved a massive globalization of globalization , and its creative unorthodox industrial policy is as creative as economic liberalization .
selective protection , credit subsidies , state-owned enterprises , domestic production rules , and technological transfers all play a role in china ’ s role as a manufacturing powerhouse .
china ’ s current strategy , “ made in china 2025 ” plan , aims to build on these achievements , allowing china to join the advanced economies .
the fact that many of china ’ s policies violate wto rules is obvious .
but a mockery of china ’ s “ trade con ” people should reflect on the need to diversify economic diversification and growth if it became a member of the wto before 2001 , or if it had applied carefully to wto rules since then .
ironically , the same commentators have many people who do not hesitate to believe that china is a model of globalization ’ s benefits – conveniently forgetting china ’ s contempt for the contemporary rules of the global economy .
china played a globalization game with what we call bretton woods rules , and before the postwar governance of the world economy was more relaxed .
as one chinese official once explained to me , china ’ s strategy was to open the window , with a 屏风 .
in doing so , they obtained fresh air ( foreign investment ) , and blocked harmful elements ( volatile capital flows and disruptive imports ) .
indeed , china ’ s behavior is not very different from what all advanced countries have done in history .
one of america ’ s biggest complaints about china is that china systematically violates intellectual property rights to steal technical secrets .
but in the nineteenth century , the united states ’ relationship with the united kingdom at the time was just as linked to china ’ s relations with the us today .
the us ’ s trade secrets for british industrialists are just as concerned with china ’ s ip concerns today .
the nascent textile mills in new england was eager to acquire technology , to steal britain ’ s designs , and smuggle skilled british craftsmen .
the us does have patent laws , but it protects american citizens .
as one historian of the us business historian put it , the us “ is also an piracy . ”
the starting point of a sensible international trade regime would be to acknowledge that policy space for countries to design their own economic and social models is neither feasible nor desirable .
countries ’ levels of development , values , and historical trajectories vary widely , and can not be reconfigured smoothly .
sometimes domestic policies backfire , allowing foreign investors to flee , and the domestic economy is impoverished .
sometimes , domestic policies drive economic transformation and poverty reduction , as china has achieved , not only to benefit the economy , but also to consumers worldwide .
international trade rules are a variety of interests – most notably , the interests of companies and their lobby groups – that can not be expected to be reliable in both settings .
countries that take harmful policies to stifle development prospects have hurt them .
when domestic strategy goes wrong , other countries may be hit , but their own economy is at the expense of the country ’ s economy – which is sufficiently incentive to do so .
in turn , the fear of a critical transfer of technological knowledge to foreigners will impose a ban on business investment in foreign or foreign firms ’ domestic acquisitions .
many liberal commentators in the us believe that trump is right to take on china .
but , in fact , trump ’ s trade agenda is behind narrow mercantilism , and corporate interests in the us are strictly higher than those of other stakeholders .
trump has no interest in improving global trade in general .
these policies should start from the trade regime ’ s golden rule : don ’ t save others .
america ’ s ongoing civil war
new york – the united states continues to be in civil war .
this is not just a civil war , but a civil war .
back in the first round of the 1860s , the confederacy lost .
but now the confederacy is temporarily leading .
the us remains torn apart by two cultures .
from the start , the us has had two visions of competing .
america ’ s founding credo was “ equal . ”
but the status quo was that white males were more equal than others .
whites have a slave , deprived women of their voting rights , and denied the land and livelihoods of native americans .
during the 内战 civil war , the confederacy of 13 divided states was defeated by 19 northern states , and then occupied by the federal government for a dozen years .
but in the aftermath of the “ reconstruction ” that ended in 1877 , the south was fully committed to systemic discrimination in a century , until the us congress , backed by the northern democrats , passed the civil rights act and 1965 rights act .
since then , southern white voters deserted the democrats .
the republicans adhere to the so-called southern strategy , based on resistance to the rise of african-americans and other minorities , and oppose legislation to transfer any funding to them , status , or power .
the republicans , too , became the party in the south , the democratic party of the northeast and pacific west , and the midwestern and western mountains became volatile zones .
the industrial great lakes region tended to be the democratic party , and the republicans are more prone to the midwestern farm and mountain states .
the midwestern and mountain states have also prevailed in the frontier culture of white settlers , who advocate repression for native-born immigrants and hispanic immigrants .
gun ownership marks another divide between democracy and republicans .
the republican party ’ s gun culture is a reflection of the same cultural power that determines its minority views .
the historian Roxanne Roxanne reminded us that the “ militias militias , ” referring to the second amendment to the second amendment in the united states , are in possession of the gun , with the right to carry out the gun , with the white group of the americas attacking native villages in the americas and hunting the boat .
just as Acharya Acharya , matthew blake , and matthew sen cite the deep roots of the recent book : how slavery shapes the south ’ s politics , the current political culture in the south is rooted in slavery and the apartheid insurgency .
according to their argument , “ the most likely to be 反对 in the region , where slavery has been used , is the most likely objection to the democratic party , opposition to affirmative action , and the possibility of being interpreted as racial hatred . ”
before the civil war , poor southern whites accepted their humble status , because they value their superiority over a more desperate african-american .
ethnic politics thus impedes the rise of class politics , while class politics could have led to poor whites and black blacks to raise taxes to the white elite .
in today ’ s 26 senators , representing 13 former confederate states , 21 are republicans , and only five from the democrats .
and , in the 19 northern states representing the 1861 in 1861 , 27 people come from democrats , and only nine ( and two are independent 无党派人士 , 伯 , · and angus 金 , who are often aligned with democrats ) .
trump embraces the white male culture of white males , leaving his own hometown of his hometown helpless to avoid , by september 2018 , 59 % of the vote .
he is not like manhattan , more mississippi .
this cultural divide has been amply demonstrated during the recent us supreme court nominee , judge brett kavanaugh .
kavanaugh ’ s senate supporters were mainly white in the south and midwest , who were fighting for him when confronted with criticism of kavanaugh ’ s advocacy of white males ’ drinking and 寻欢作乐 privilege .
mitch mcconnell of kentucky , a former slave state , successfully orchestrated kavanaugh ’ s nomination .
蓄奴 graham , the state of south carolina , was first declared in 1860 , and 林赛 graham , the state from the state of the state , was the strongest supporter of the senate judiciary committee , describing sexual assaults against kavanaugh as “ the most unethical fraud since his own politics . ”
john f. kennedy was born with another former confederate state , describing the hearings with “ 银河系 秀 . ”
democracy and the republicans are not only parties of different cultures and regions , but also different economies .
the northeast and pacific states have been leading us high-tech , innovative , tertiary , well-paying jobs , and per capita income .
the south is far from comparable .
working-class whites in the south and midwest not only defended their status and race ; they are also fighting for their jobs , owing to the steady erosion of jobs , automation , and foreign trade in their industries .
working-class whites from the working-class south would have much to gain from abandoning the racial politics of the republican party .
after all , it is white corporate elites , not poor african-americans , hispanics , and other minorities who deprive working-class whites of quality public education , affordable health care , and environmental safety .
southern white senator senators are part of a culture war aimed at protecting the republicans ’ super-rich , who enjoy the party ’ s tax cuts and the ease of relaxing environmental regulations , while republicans all blame african-americans and hispanics .
the declining dominance of non-hispanic whites in the total population is likely to widen america ’ s cultural divide over the last two decades .
with non-hispanic whites expected to become a minority of the total population by around 2045 , the ongoing civil war in the us is likely to intensify .
the war will not end unless all the working-class americans , ethnic , and ethnic americans united , demanding that wealthy corporate elites pay more taxes and more responsibility .
america ’ s exploding deficit
cambridge – two recent pieces of budget news are a serious warning to america ’ s fiscal policy crisis .
president barack obama ’ s administration ’ s executive management and budget office announced that the federal government ’ s deficit of about $ 600 billion in fiscal year was $ 600 billion , and annual growth is more than $ 345 billion on year .
and the cbo ’ s annual budget projections predict that , with fiscal policy unchanged , the federal government ’ s debt will rise from 75 % of gdp a decade later to 86 % , to 86 % , with a record record of ％ % , with italy , portugal , and greece .
while us debt has doubled over the past decade , the obama administration and congress willfully ignored the problem , instead focusing on the gradual decline in annual deficits and the relative stability of the deficit relative to gdp .
but this short-term success is due to economic recovery and limits on the us congress ’ s spending on defense and non-defense discretionary programs .
but the long-term increase in the annual deficit – owing to an aging population , rising health-care technology , and rising interest rates – and thus a rising debt-to-gdp ratio , which is clearly predicted by the congressional budget office and other institutions .
a large number of older americans who qualify for social security benefits will increase spending from 4.9 % of gdp in the next 30 years to 6.3 % of gdp .
the cost of the major federal health-care programs has risen from GDP5.5 % now to 8.9 % in 1910 , to 8.9 % of the recipients ’ longevity and the number of additional health-care technologies that have been produced by the population .
despite the increase in the volume of debt , the fed ’ s unconventional monetary policy has driven down the cost of a net federal debt , which amounts to 1.4 % of gdp .
but as interest rates normalize and the volume of debt grows , the cost of servicing the national debt is expected to rise to 5.8 % of gdp .
if the rest of the deficit and debt forecasts are proved correct , interest costs may be far less likely to be expected .
but us treasury investors may demand much higher interest rates as a return on the share of government bonds in their portfolios .
in that case , interest costs and debt will be much higher .
the fact that more than half of us public debt is publicly issued by foreign investors may make interest rates more sensitive to the size of the debt .
foreign investors may worry that governments will adopt policies that reduce their real holdings .
although the us government would not explicitly default , it can pursue policies ( such as the earned-income income tax ) to do so , which will hurt foreign holders and reduce the value of bonds .
moreover , foreign investors may worry that excessive debt levels could lead to inflationary monetary policy , which will lead to a weaker dollar and lower the real value of bonds .
here is why the cbo ’ s projections are surprising .
by 2049 , the projected spending on “ mandatory ” entitlement programs ( social security and major health programs ) , together with interest payments on debt , would be higher than the income of the government today .
even spending on “ discretionary ” programs , such as defense , would save a small deficit , with a small deficit of 1.6 % of gdp .
we can not offset the growth of mandatory programs by slowing defense and other discretionary programs .
total defense spending amounts to just 3.2 % of current gdp , and is expected to decline to 2.6 % over the next decade and to remain at the same level in 20 years .
this would be the lowest level of defense spending since world war ii .
it is estimated that all non-defense discretionary programs would be similarly reduced , with the lowest percentage of gdp ratios .
the bright spot of this bleak picture is that it does not need too much of the annual deficit to prevent the rise in the debt ratio , or even allow the latter to move back to its level a decade ago .
if any combination of policies that began to reduce spending and raise income by 2017 , the deficit could be averted by 1.7 % of gdp , avoiding the current rate of relative gdp growth .
at the same time , reducing the deficit by 3 % per year will reverse the trajectory of debt growth and return it to the decades before the recession .
no presidential candidate has announced plans or will to reverse expectations of rising national debt .
but this should be a top priority for the white house ’ s occupant next year .
there is no excuse to delay waiting quickly , and to avoid the worst .
america ’ s anti-environmentalists
as americans , i am appalled , ashamed , and embarrassing in dealing with global warming .
the scientific evidence of the risks of warming is growing , and the stern report of the british authority has been documented .
but , while the us accounts for about 25 % of all man-made carbon emissions , americans have no willingness or inclination to change their consumption .
despite the wrong reasons , the bush administration was right to refuse to sign the so-called kyoto protocol .
the kyoto protocol is problematic , one that redistributing carbon emissions to developing countries .
but why can ’ t the us raise taxes on gasoline and other sources of carbon emissions such as coal power plants ?
despite the economy ’ s booming growth , the us government has a huge deficit , as if it does not need them .
many believe that bush is the problem .
what can you expect from a texas oil businessman and his friends who took power , and what is to be expected ?
american citizens ’ resistance to the global environment to reduce energy consumption is more deeply entrenched .
for example , former us vice president al gore ’ s film film , the global warming film , has been commended for winning praise for fossil fuel consumption , which has been lauded for fossil-fuel consumption .
the evidence of global warming is far more vague than gore ’ s film , but the underlying problem is real .
unfortunately , however , gore has failed to carry out the torch of warming during his political history .
there was no 恭维 .
no wonder the american public is strongly resistant to any aspect of the lifestyle that does force them to change their oil costs .
in this , not only politicians can provide leadership .
a respected new york times editor , the editor of the new york times , was until recently opposed to any energy tax , finally supporting the proposal .
like many liberals , the newspaper ’ s editors worried that higher energy taxes would make the poor too much worse off .
the typical argument that people hear is that there is no way to work in the poor in the 耗油 1980 ’ s .
this is true , but , as stern reports have pointed out , if sea levels begin to rise , many of our children will be swimming to work one day .
reducing poverty is not an excuse for inaction on global warming .
unfortunately , the new york times ’ s changing position does not herald a change in us voters ’ stance .
if any one of the candidates for a us president in 2008 could raise the energy tax , they will have to lose .
claiming that you care about environmental issues or , like bush , the magic technology will solve problems without much pain .
but any 2008 presidential candidate who dares to talk about a safer environment in the future is certainly risky .
before americans begin to address the global environmental problems that they have created , it is hard to see the support of the rest of the world being reached .
developing countries ask that if rich countries are not willing to limit their own emissions sharply , why should they focus on global warming ?
if rich countries were so profligate , why should poor countries worry about deforestation as a result of global warming ?
scientific evidence suggests that carbon emissions anywhere in the world have the same impact on global warming .
for this reason , many economists agree on a united ( coordinated ) global tax to tax all of the world ’ s places on carbon emissions , a tax on carbon emissions , whether coal , oil , or gas , regardless of consumers or consumers .
such taxes are the most flexible and pro-market way , and the impact on economic growth is minimal .
by contrast , the complex system of quotas that europe favors and embodied in the kyoto protocol threatens to lead to greater inefficiencies and costs .
for this reason , the uk ’ s stern report on reducing carbon emissions would cost only 1 % of the income of a year ’ s income by just 1 % .
but the stern report ’ s suggestion that the potential risks of continued inaction are far greater is the right thing to do .
one day , america ’ s unwillingness to assume leadership on environmental issues will be considered the country ’ s most profound political failures .
one hopes that the us will change course soon before we are forced to wear out to work .
the new low of china bashing
new haven – as america ’ s election season nears its end , the debate about elections seems unhinged .
both have highlighted the general election debate : the pain of america ’ s pain would be mitigated as long as the country ’ s tough strength is tough .
there is nothing going away from the truth , please think about the following charges :
currency manipulation .
since china launched its exchange-rate regime in july 2005 , the renminbi appreciated 32 % against the us , and has appreciated by about 30 % against a basket of currencies after the inflation rate .
this is not a trivial sum , and the renminbi ’ s exchange rate will continue to rise in the years ahead .
unlike japan , which was forced to undertake a sharp yen appreciation in the wake of western pressure in 1985 , the chinese chose more gradual and cautious action .
american officials view this as “ manipulation , ” arguing that the market ’ s power would have made the renminbi more significant than it is currently .
the chinese , by contrast , obsession with maintaining stability – an idea that us politicians and policymakers are unfamiliar with – and thus enjoy a more active role in managing their own currency .
i call this prudence – or even wisdom .
after 20 years of lost experience , japan ’ s guinea might know which approach is more appropriate .
outsourcing and intellectual property .
while america ’ s labor force has been in bad shape recently , america ’ s employment situation remains abysmal .
private-sector employment is still 4.1 million below its january 2008 peak .
but that is not enough to support the argument that the current crisis stems from the outsourcing of us manufacturing jobs to china .
while the share of manufacturing employment in the private sector fell from 11.9% % in january 2008 to 10.7 % in september 2012 , this is only a small part of the long-term trend in the long run , which accounted for more than 30 % .
in contrast to china , weak demand – especially consumer spending growth after the crisis – is more like the most recent culprit in hiring demand .
and china itself has become a major contributor to globalization – an assembly hub for production of production chains for more than a country , and an efficient offshore solution to the efficient offshore solution of western multinationals .
some 50 % of chinese exports were processed before other economies , and almost 60 % of all products were directed abroad by chinese subsidiaries of so-called “ foreign enterprises . ”
these trends benefit chinese workers while benefiting the us and other countries , because it helped to control inflation , while enabling firms to cope with harsh competitive pressures .
moreover , it did not prevent western innovators from putting intellectual property and new technologies on the production lines of china ’ s production base , such as apple .
trade deficits .
true , the us has a large trade deficit with china – about $ 2950 billion in 2011 , with roughly 40 % of total us merchandise trade in merchandise trade .
republican democrats have long believed that this is the key to america ’ s employment problem .
after all , trade deficits mean job losses .
because the largest part of the us trade gap stems from china ’ s 诽谤 作弊者 , the bilateral trade deficit has become a 诋毁 of the chinese .
this is precisely the reason behind the recent spat between the united states and china in the world trade organization and china ’ s 限制 wind power plant , which , in terms of trump ’ s assertions of currency manipulation and trade sanctions , is being fueled by romney .
but neither candidate acknowledges the bigger elephant .
the us ran trade deficits with 98 countries in 2011 .
other 97 deficits have not disappeared .
without saving , the us can afford to grow , and the us can afford to import other countries ’ excess savings with large current-account and multilateral trade deficits .
this misses the core of china ’ s folly .
no country in history has maintained a negative saving rate .
the trade deficit – from china or other countries – is one of the costs of america ’ s profligacy .
unless and until the us is directly confronted with its long-term deviation from saving – that is , by cutting massive federal budget spending and encouraging a 重建 household saving – multilateral trade deficits will continue .
simple arithmetic and basic economics tell us that you can not solve multilateral problems through a bilateral solution .
politicians have a penchant for simple and powerful information .
but those messages are often exaggerated .
many american households are hurting , and elected officials want to blame china , thereby diverting people ’ s attention from rebuilding saving , restoring competitiveness , and living beyond their means .
indeed , it is arguably the american public that has been manipulated by those targeted by china ’ s mistakes .
fortunately , the duration of the election is coming to an end .
the answer , however , is what happens next .
those who dismiss china generally will not change after the presidential election .
but the pressure on american households to continue on american families after november 6 will not disappear .
both obama and romney are confronting the risks that lie ahead with china .
this could push us all to a slippery slope .
before it is too late , us leaders must confess to their own people .
a social democracy in the us ?
almost all of the world ’ s developed countries have seen themselves as social democracies , pursuing mixed economic systems , with large governments and the allocation of the distribution of social benefits and livelihoods to most social wealth and the distribution of living goods .
the united states is something different , or is it ?
whatever the past , the us must decide whether to become a social democracy soon , and how much to accept social democracy ?
in the past , at least , there has been little “ 下流 ” in the us .
on the contrary , before the civil war in the united states , you could start with the 铁轨 track , and then quickly to the west , with victorious victories in the front of the white house – if you were called abraham lincoln .
in world war ii , one can maintain a blue-collar job in the union ’ s trade unions , or to climb to the top of the authorities , enjoy good professional security , relatively generous pay , and long-term stability .
but at least half of the myth is 神化 .
it is expensive to pay a high price for the country ’ s entry into the top .
even in the post-wwii period , only a small fraction of americans – mostly white men – can produce firms in a union of large capital 集约型 , such as gm , ge , or at & t .
but if that claim is half to boast , half is always true .

governments then return to their policy horizons , beginning with a permanent military program on expenses and development , and will continue to advance the program ’ s work and program programs , with the support of the federal highway program , financed to federal housing authority .

america ’ s constrained choice
newport beach – the conventional wisdom about the november presidential election in the united states is only partly correct .
yes , economic issues will play a large role in determining outcomes .
but the next phase – whether the party that wins in an increasingly ugly race – is much more uncertain than the uncertainty that its rivals have pursued .
with the new president ’ s term starting in january 2013 , contrary to what is now described by obama and romney ’ s penchant for competition , those who came to power will find that there is little room for adjustment .
in fact , there is no shortage of potential differences in the us .
they focus on social policies that are accompanied by a wide range of similar economic policies ; here , the differences between candidates will have significant consequences .
whoever wins will face economic growth only 2 % next year , with a full risk of stagnation .
unemployment is still high , and about half of the unemployed are struggling to find a long-term unemployed unemployed – a share that should be even higher if we were to leave the labor force in the us .
economic considerations are also worrisome .
the fiscal deficit will continue to be stuck at 10 % of gdp , raising concerns about america ’ s medium-term debt dynamics .
and the household sector is suffering only half of the painful deleveraging phase .
the policy side is equally unsettling .
after hesitation and hesitation , the us congress will find it impossible to delay efforts to meet these challenges .
at the same time , the us federal reserve ’ s 翻唱 activism – including the list of ever-expanding “ 石头 ” measures – will be more effective , and the costs will become increasingly expensive .
the global environment in which the us operates is increasingly difficult .
in the coming months , europe ’ s debt crisis will most likely worsen .
given the slowdown in emerging markets ( including china ) , while a meaningful multilateral policy coordination has always been insufficient , major trade powers will compete to compete , so protectionist pressures will rise .
so , regardless of whether president barack obama wins in november , the new president will be constrained by a double constraint – a need for stability and long-term reform .
and , under the pressure of europe ’ s crisis and the world , the candidates have no choice but to adopt similar economic policies to restore job creation and financial stability , at least when the term began .
in seeking a balance between short-term economic stimulus and medium-term fiscal sustainability , the most important step is to address the fiscal cliff that is due to expire in temporary tax cuts and the fiscal cliff caused by deep and deep spending cuts .
failure to do so would significantly increase the risk of a full-blown recession .
a deep medium-term budget reform is essential to tackling the problem of repeated congressional inaction .
moreover , if the real numbers are learned , the next president will soon recognize that the right path to tax and spending reform is very narrow , far from today ’ s competitive political sloganeering .
this is certainly not an either/or proposition .
fiscal reform is best achieved in a dynamic economy .
to this end , obama and romney will have to do everything against growth and job creation .
in this area , as in real estate , labor markets , credit intermediation , and infrastructure , there is no way to do so .
but that doesn ’ t mean that it can not be done .
the space for change is that it reflects the fact that overall economic trends will be accompanied by dynamic dynamics .
according to the difference between skills and education , persistent differences in unemployment are persistent ; income and wealth inequality is hitting a historical record – a requirement that , in terms of distributional effects , will be accompanied by the need for social adjustment .
after the “ era ” of excessive leverage , debt creation , and excessive credit creation , the “ era ” that culminated in the global financial crisis of 2008 , the united states faces a daunting challenge – how to allocate the cumulative losses of investment , employment , and competitiveness .
so far , congress ’ s excessive political polarization has produced the effects of more adjustment on the weaker countries .
in an ideal world , the new us president should quickly implement a two-step approach to restore job dynamism and reinvigorate financial stability .
first , he should design a comprehensive and satisfactory package of economic policies – in this regard , to make significant difference .
second , for these economic policies , an explicit social policy mix – in which potential changes are significant – is needed to meet the need for fair burden-sharing .
indeed , the election is not a choice for outsourcing and tax increases or entitlement reform ; choosing the government to control production or unfettered private-sector activity ; and the choice of job creation or free riders .
the stakes in this election are the social justice , welfare , equality of personality , and a rich and civilized society .
this is an election in which social responsibility is a matter of social responsibility : social responsibility , community support for those who are not seeking jobs , and the obligation to find jobs and balance-of-payments pressures .
this election is about the most vulnerable communities in which they protect society .
in a variety of fairness and justice issues , it is the election ’ s focus that gives the rich a 制度 system to give them unimaginable wealth .
here , the differences between obama and romney are important .
the sooner the campaign will be , the more the american people are likely to make a more informed choice , thereby taking the necessary collective action to keep america out of control .
america ’ s crony capitalism
buenos aires – for 20 years , the united states has been openly attacking the third world in the world , especially in asia .
yet , at a time when the us has been touting its government and corporate governance – a groundbreaking decision that the hong kong court has just made bad for the local telecom giants – crony capitalism has taken root in a country that has long seen the world as a model of fair business competition .
the us treasury ’ s recently completed bank “ stress tests , ” a recent symbol of crony capitalism occupying washington , dc .
the us treasury secretary timothy geithner ’ s stress tests on big banks in the united states , and a few weeks before testing the results , were leaked , no wonder that the stock market would welcome the test of stress tests .
indeed , many professional investors , even because they benefited from rising stock prices , still believe that stress tests are dishonest .
even the most vocal 拉拉队长 wall street journal , the wall street journal , is openly suspicious of the integrity of the test , because the us government allowed bankers to “ negotiate ” the results of stress tests , like a student in the final exam negotiations .
the stress tests are the real thing to reflect on the fact that a large number of banks holding a large share of mortgage loans and financial derivatives are inadequately impaired , and the reasons behind the stress tests seem impeccable .
but is it ?
any experienced banker knows that managing good banks should take regular internal “ stress tests ” into a good business manager .
should the financial crisis have forced the banks to put themselves under constant stress tests , so that it is not .
the truth is that the test of us stress tests is not intended to find answers to the problem .
both wall street ’ s titans and the obama administration have known the truth .
they know that if the true truth of the us banks were to be made , many banks would immediately be declared bankruptcy , which would force the government ’ s bankruptcy authorities to prevent the resulting wave of bank runs .
while experts like former us federal reserve board chair paul volcker recommend nationalizing the us , the obama administration has been reluctant to nationalize it , because it does not want to be labeled “ socialism ” for nationalization .
and , if the us nationalized banks , there will necessarily be some wall street titans and their colleagues because of severe mismanagement .
wall street ’ s titans , however , have convinced obama and his administration that their continued work is critical to the world economy .
moreover , they succeeded in portraying themselves as victims of the economic crisis , not an act of economic crisis .
larry summers and barack obama ’ s chief economic adviser , larry summers , is a glorified 门徒 of the us treasury secretary , and robert rubin of citigroup , and robert rubin of goldman sachs ’ s board of directors , who believed that the culture of wall street was difficult .
the stress tests were meant to tell the public that the banks had no imminent bankruptcy threat .
the government hopes that such information can stabilize markets so that the price of “ toxic ” assets can rise to the point that bankers can feel less difficult to sell when selling them .
after all , senior bankers once said that the “ price tag ” of these banks ’ assets , pricing them at market level , would be unnecessarily penalized .
as it stands , geithner ’ s “ stress tests ” seem to have succeeded , because , indeed , the stock market is not just a stabilizing price , like the price of bank shares like citigroup and bank of america , and has increased by a fourfold rise .
the bankruptcy of wall street has been feared , and now seems to have been avoided .
but no one really believes that the us would allow citigroup and bank of america – which listed two banks – to fail .
in fact , the stock market bottomed out last winter .
what the world wants is precisely what the precise data about banks ’ value and the amount of “ market ” value that banks need to channel their investors ’ money .
the world also wants to see that the us can return to the path of stronger business ethics and good behavior – one that the last us administration lacks .
because taxpayers have invested heavily in rescuing failing banks and investing more in money , there is a need for transparency that suggests how these money is used .
the us , reportedly , has a large amount of public rescue funds , not to be transferred to foreign banks , goldman sachs , or a bonus of financial institutions ’ employees .
geithner ’ s stress tests have not revealed or debunked these circumstances .
on the contrary , the us government ’ s staff now seems to be on the streets of wall street , creating a false aura of profitability .
moreover , the value of toxic assets is as murky as ever .
in order to make the banks largely reporting their own devices , the us government has been revising its sacred accounting standards under wall street .
now that the us has unveiled the results of negotiations on the us government and banks , it is far healthier to “ prove ” america ’ s banks than people think .
while it may be too harsh to call this 骗局 scam , they are similar .
there is no financial profession to be fooled .
at the same time , wall street and their directors have little to worry about the us government , on the contrary , on the contrary , they are now a partner in the us government .
like swine flu , crony capitalism has shifted from corrupt third countries to the us , which once became a reliable place for government and corporate governance .
so , with the us being regarded as a reliable model for developing countries , and the us is now considered a symbol of hypocrisy and double marks , what is odd about us ?
america ’ s dangerous debt ceiling debate
newport beach – the us government ’ s debt ceiling has raised more than 70 times over the last 50 years , and there is little disagreement .
the us government must raise this ceiling again this summer if it wants to continue paying on its debt .
as a result , the line became the subject of private and emotional political pronouncements and urgent negotiations , and the outcome will clearly affect the rest of the world .
as part of the us system of checks and balances , congress has not only played a role in approving the federal budget , but also the us treasury ’ s debt ceiling .
once the ceiling exceeds that ceiling , the government would have spent money in the same way .
us treasury secretary timothy geithner recently informed the government that the government would have informed congress about the debt ceiling on august 2 .
with total borrowing already reaching a ceiling , the treasury is now using a variety of idle funds to pay off payment payments .
for several weeks , these “ liquidity ” will be depleted .
given that 40 cents of the us government ’ s current spending on $ 1 per dollar is at stake , a binding debt ceiling would force it to cut its spending sharply .
both politicians know that this will destabilize the us economy , which is already vulnerable , severely weakening the dollar , and triggering a highly dubious market that includes the us ’ s ability to pay for us debt .
but , in the current political environment of extreme polarization in washington , republicans and democrats are reluctant to compromise – or believe it is too early to compromise .
the republicans want to use a standoff to force the obama administration into massive spending cuts .
the democrats argue that the alternative to other factors would not only harm economic , but also social injustice .
at the same time , both sides risk disrupting transfer payments ( including the elderly ) and the provision of public services , even further threatening america ’ s global credit .
the recent example is that this year ’ s fiscal stimulus , which was not approved by congress , threatened the normal functioning of the government , and finally in compromise .
compromise on both sides would be mutually assured , offering government commitments to reduce spending and take a range of steps to make taxes more social justice .
but , like so many last-minute agreements , the agreement lacks long-term efficacy .
in fact , america ’ s political system will soon be repeated , and the hoped-for fiscal reforms are expected to be achieved only after the 2012 presidential election .
the time for a temporary compromise on both parties depends on a two-step or two-step approach , and it may be possible to see two scenarios in august 2 .
moreover , politicians need a two-step approach : the first is the failure of the agreement , which was followed by a rapid compromise in the aftermath of financial markets .
at the same time , the treasury will temporarily 重新安排 and slow payments .
this two-step process was somewhat similar to that of 2008 , when congress faced another dangerous condition : the bush administration demanded $ 700 billion to prevent financial markets from collapsing and economic downturns .
congress initially rejected this demand , but the stock market ’ s 急挫 points made politicians far more difficult to do , and then put the proposal back on the agenda .
but this approach would create many chronic risks for the us economy and its global standing , and the longer the us politicians address the debt ceiling , the greater the risk of an accident .
this could trigger a more worrying third scenario : the negotiations are long , and there is no longer , for the government ’ s fiscal payment , to fulfill other contractual obligations , as well as a greater disruption of public services .
those creditors who have already held us bonds will be able to express more serious concerns when they continue purchasing their purchases , so that america ’ s economy , already facing the crisis of unemployment and growth , is suffering more headwinds .
the next five weeks will take a lot of drama .
and our most basic expectation is that the democrats and republicans will be able to find ways to avoid damaging the fragile us economy in the face of risk , only to achieve meaningful medium-term fiscal reforms .
for the us private sector and countries that rely on the us to play a central role in the global economy , the us political system is uneasy about the paralysis that it faces when confronted with such critical economic issues .
this explains why so many firms are willing to hold cash without domestic investment , and explain why a growing number of countries are seeking to diversify their strategies gradually , and not to use us financial markets to manage their hard-earned savings .
the global economy is closely tied to the assumption of a strong us , and americans benefit from it .
but the more the us politicians debate on the debt ceiling , the more likely it is likely to break down .
america ’ s deepening moral crisis
new york – the political and economic crisis in the united states is set to worsen further after the midterm congressional elections in november .
obama , who has long been committed to helping the poor and environmental legislation , will lose his last hope .
indeed , all important legislation and reform will be stalled until the new presidential election in 2013 changed .
the sad situation that is fraught with stalemate and vitriol is likely to intensify , so the world should not expect much global leadership in a sharp and fragmented us .
most americans are now in an ugly mood , and the language of compassion and language has been abandoned .
both parties , though claiming to defend middle-class interests , are serving only for wealthy electoral donors .
the official statistics say that 15 % of the us population is poor , but the actual numbers are even larger if we are to see families like those who are in health care , housing , employment , etc .
the republican party recently issued a declaration called “ to america ’ s oath : the new republican agenda ” describes his belief and electoral promises .
but the declaration is replete with absurd statements like “ high taxes and over-regulation that led to high unemployment in the us . ”
moreover , the declaration deliberately misled the public , such as quotes from former us president john f. kennedy about “ high taxes that would suffocate the economy ” a half-century ago , while the top marginal tax rate was twice that of today .
the united states ’ internal disintegration in this rich country is because its core values have collapsed .
american productivity is among the highest in the world .
per capita national income amounts to $ 4.6 million – not only to feed itself , but also to live rich people .
but the country is being steered into a serious moral crisis .
income inequality has reached historic highs , and people claim that they are not responsible for other citizens .
they are reluctant to help the poor , and defend their tax cuts as much as possible .
all are complaining that everyone is defending their narrow short-term interests , and everyone will be left behind by the idea of a society ’ s long-term interests and aspirations .
in the current political debate in the united states , the most popular approach is to make a bigger political commitment to the middle class , and mainly to reduce government budgets and tax cuts , while the us fiscal deficit has exceeded 10 % of gdp .
americans seem to believe that they have a strong government service without paying taxes .
in the us political lexicon , “ taxes ” mean “ limiting liberty . ”
but , just a decade ago , americans were keen to address poverty at home and abroad .
in the middle of the 1960 ’ s , lyndon johnson ’ s “ war on poverty ” reflects the country ’ s euphoria , which was widely optimistic that the entire society must act in concert to address the problems of poverty , pollution , and health care , as well as programs to improve the air and water pollution .
but then , in the wake of the vietnam war and civil rights issues , the invasion of consumerism and advertising , together with the invasion of consumerism and advertising , ended up bringing the public to an end .
for 40 years , compassion has receded .
ronald reagan won support by reducing the social welfare of the poor ( who claimed that the poor had been able to gain extra benefits by being cheated by the poor ) .
bill clinton continued the 1990 ’ s .
today , not even politicians dare to make any poverty-reduction policy .
the election contributors to the rich are intended to ensure that their vested interests dominate the political debate .
this means that both parties are defending the interests of the rich , albeit a little less than the democrats .
even a modest tax hike on the rich is unlikely in the us .
all of this ends in the us ’ s long history of strength and prosperity , because americans are no longer collectively investing in their common future .
the us will remain a rich country for a long time , but it will gradually divide and instability .
fear and propaganda will lead the us to launch more international war , just as it did over the last decade .
and what happens in the us will happen in the rest of the world .
a highly polarized society has led to a profound social breakdown in the us .
and racism and anti-immigrant sentiment are an important part of the attacks on the poor , or at least the willingness to take on those who oppose the support of the poor .
as other societies diverge from their own societies , they follow the us .
swedish voters have recently cast enough votes on a right-wing anti-immigrant party , enough to make it a place in parliament , reflecting the growing resistance of swedish resistance to foreign migrants .
in france , sarkozy ’ s government has tried to win working-class support by expelling migrants from 移民 migrants , who have become perpetrators of ethnic hatred and attacks .
the lesson in the us is that economic development does not guarantee that people ’ s wellbeing and political stability are not guaranteed .
america ’ s social landscape is deteriorating , with the rich having been paying money for political power , while the poor are left to die .
in their private lives , americans have become trapped in consumerism , and consumerism swallowed americans ’ time , money , energy , and the tendency to commit to collective wellbeing .
the world must beware .
unless we get away with the vicious cycle of this kind of 权钱交易 and pathological consumerism , we will lose a little less .
america ’ s economic stalemate
cambridge – the united states seems trapped in a dangerous economic stagnation trap , both republicans and democrats reject the budget issue , leaving the us government unable to deal with massive fiscal deficits and rising national debt .
indeed , the congressional budget office estimates that the national debt will rise to 82 % of gdp over the next decade , double the level of the 2008 level .
moreover , this estimate is based on a very optimistic assumption on economic growth and low interest rates .
if growth is not so high , nominal interest rates are not so low , and the debt ratio will exceed 100 % in 2021 and surpass 150 % by 2030 .
one major reason for the acceleration in government debt is that the us population is aging rapidly , leading to an increase in the cost of universal pension and health-care programs – social welfare and medicare .
most experts believe that limiting debt growth must reduce the share of these “ welfare ” programs , while raising taxes as a share of gdp .
but president barack obama and congressional democrats oppose any reduction in entitlement programs , while republican presidential candidate candidates and congressional representatives oppose any additional tax increases .
the result is the current stalemate – not to cut the fiscal deficit , or to reverse the rising tide of national debt .
the republicans argue that national debt growth can be limited only by cutting government spending .
although some traditional spending cuts have been part of spending controls , this approach needs to be accompanied by cuts in “ tax expenditures ” – the tax code , mortgage loans , and local government taxes .
limiting tax expenditures could reduce annual deficits of 2 % of gdp , thereby lowering the debt-to-gdp ratio by more than 25 percentage points in 2021 .
republicans generally reject this form of spending cuts , because it would increase taxes .
this approach does make total tax revenue more expensive , but the economic effects of limiting tax expenditures are exactly the same as reducing those programs by other means .
but the republicans ’ opposition to any additional tax revenue means that the key to breaking the budget gridlock will never be implemented .
the budget costs of social welfare can be cut gradually by substituting for 部分 , based partly on investment-based personal retirement accounts , which currently rely on tax payments .
but even if such reforms can maintain income levels for retirees , democrats will also oppose , because it would reduce traditional government benefits .
so the stalemate will deepen .
both parties ’ positions are strong , which will affect congressional and presidential elections in 2012 .
in fact , the republican party ’ s message to voters will be “ we won ’ t raise taxes , but the democrats will . ”
and the democrats will be charged , setting up “ we will not cut pensions and health care , but the republicans will . ”
both sides will stand in stark positions before the election , so the immediate shift to tax expenditures and future social security pension changes is unlikely .
but , for the same reason , i am optimistic about the stalemate after the election .
at that point , both republicans and democrats could accept reforms that must be rejected .
official analysis underestimates the impact of lower marginal tax rates on taxable income , but experience suggests that marginal tax rates would make taxpayers work more for their own purposes , rather than receive compensation in the form of additional compensation , and thus lower taxable income , thereby boosting taxable income .
cutting tax expenditures and lowering marginal tax rates can go a long way toward raising revenues by increasing income levels .
the current economic stalemate is dangerous , because financial markets are likely to react negatively and delay addressing the fiscal deficit , which means that the national debt will continue to rise .
i may be overly optimistic , but i believe that there is good reason to believe that the current budget impasse is intended to give election campaigns , and that the us political system will be highly effective when the election results were settled .
america ’ s election and the global economy
stanford – the united states ’ election is approaching , with president barack obama narrowly ahead of the republican challenger , massachusetts governor mitt romney , who still believes that us president and senate elections are far from lost , and the house is likely to remain in republican hands .
the difference between candidates is clear , and the impact on us economic policy and the global economy is significant , despite the president ’ s economic policies .
the main difference between the two candidates can be summed up :
point out .
obama has dramatically increased spending .
he may continue to implement temporary measures ( as milton friedman once observed , “ there is nothing more durable than the government ’ s temporary policies . ” ) ; doubling the government ’ s spending on green energy and the losers ; and massive cuts in defense spending .
romney , by contrast , favors limiting federal spending , from 24 % of gdp to 20 % of gdp and keeping the deficit at 4 % of gdp .
he wants private markets , not government , to choose business and technology winners .
democrats oppose most nondefense spending cuts , arguing that cutting spending would lead to a recession .
this is the strongest effect when spending cuts occur unexpectedly in a weak economy .
if the process of economic recovery is achieved during the years of economic recovery , such as romney ’ s plan , it could be expansionary .
the share of us federal spending , for example , fell by five percentage points between the mid-1980 ’ s and the late 1990 ’ s , and in recent decades canada , for example , has fallen even more – both economically strong and economically .
taxation .
obama will raise the top marginal tax rate for wages , capital gains , dividends , interest , and real estate , especially for higher-income individuals and small businesses .
but , in terms of personal or corporate income taxes , he has no comprehensive plan for reform .
romney , by contrast , will reduce the rate of us corporate tax rates to 25 % , to 25 % , and transform the tax base for us mncs from around the world to increase taxes .
he will also reduce the personal tax rate by 20 % , and by limiting tax deductions ( especially the tax deduction for the very top , which could raise the amount of tax revenue that amounts to a high level of full employment ) to offset declining incomes .
obama , by contrast , will widen the deficit – his spending increase far more than the planned tax increase – implying a massive tax increase in the future .
moreover , obama ’ s tax rate will be far higher than romney ’ s , owing to the welfare benefits of debt .
welfare .
obama has remained silent on medicare and social security , and the long-term deficit is a several times the national debt .
vice president joe biden even said that the social security program “ will not change . ”
romney has supported gradual increases in retirement taxes , a model for medicare , and the elimination of medicaid ( for health care for the poor ) to the states by eliminating medicaid .
obama ’ s campaign approach is to attack romney ’ s medicare program , while romney ’ s strategy is to attack obama ’ s refusal to discuss the issue or even a draft solution .
some observers believe that obama ’ s unspoken plan is to pay for a growing welfare bill with european-style value-added taxes .
trade .
obama is the first us president to take the lead in global trade liberalization for a long time .
the doha round of world trade talks remains stalled , and has delayed three 自他 bilateral free-trade agreements that have been signed since the signing of the white house .
romney is a proponent of free trade , but it also expressed a tougher stance on china ’ s trade practices and monetary policy .
regulation .
obama wants to expand the federal mandate further ( though the courts have already suspended some of his extension of regulatory power ) .
romney ’ s approach is balanced by economic balance , and will reform obama ’ s main health , environmental , and financial services .
appointed .
every us president appoints thousands of officials , many of them empowered .

america ’ s exceptional fiscal conservatism
washington , dc – in most countries , the “ fiscal conservatives ” means that you worry about budget deficits and debt levels , and place such problems at the top of the policy agenda .
today , in many eurozone countries , “ fiscal conservatives ” are a powerful grouping , insisting that governments raise revenue , while controlling spending .
in the united kingdom , the ruling conservative party recently demonstrated a willingness to tax and limit future spending .
here , the us is very different .
in the united states , political leaders claiming to be “ fiscal conservatives ” – for example , the republican party ’ s vision of a common presidential candidate , mitt ryan , who challenges the november election – focus more on cutting taxes , regardless of the impact on the federal deficit and the debt level .

eisenhower rejected this advice , partly because he did not like and trust nixon , but mainly because he thought that he had a budget close to the successor .
after the collapse of the international monetary system in 1971 , the framework for us macroeconomic policy changed dramatically .
the us can no longer sustain the fixed exchange rate between the us dollar and gold , which was the cornerstone of the post-war bretton woods system .
the arrangement collapsed because the us is no longer willing to tighten monetary policy and adopt a tougher fiscal policy : it is understandable that , for president richard nixon , pleasing us voters is more important than maintaining a global exchange-rate system .
ironically , however , the end of the bretton woods system did not destabilize the dollar in international dominance , effectively increasing the use of the dollar in the world .
over the past four decades , talk and behavior about the dollar ’ s decline have been legion , but the fact is that dollar assets held by foreigners are now much larger than they were in 1971 .
this is a double-edged sword , because it has led the us to focus on fiscal accounts .
now that foreigners hold roughly half of the us federal government ’ s debt , they are willing to hold their holdings , even if the return on the dollar is low ( and the dollar ’ s depreciation ) .
in fact , whenever the world is less stable , investors will be willing to hold more dollars – even if they are the source of the united states .
when the big banks in the united states are in trouble or in america ’ s troubled public finances , global investors rush to buy us treasury securities .

america ’ s financial leviathan
berkeley – in 1950 , the united states ’ financial and insurance industry accounted for 2.8 % of gdp in 1950 .
in 1960 , that share had risen to 3.8 % , and reached 6 % in 1990 .
today , the figure is 8.4 % , and has not fallen .
the wall street journal ’ s · 报道 reports that , in 2010 , the share exceeded its 2006 peak .
lahart continues to point out that the increase in financial and insurance as a share of the economy is “ largely not a bad thing ... ” that enables capital flows to help the economy grow .
but , if the us is paying an extra $ 750 billion per year from the extra money that the us pays for finance and insurance – accounting for 5.6 % of gdp , it receives an estimated $ 7,500 per year from those who pay directly for useful goods and directly supplying useful services .
at the rate of real interest rates on venture cash flows , the share of resources that will take place in this year is taking place from directly available goods and services , which means that the resources would boost annual economic growth by 0.3 % – or by 25 % over a generation .
the past generations have experienced several shocks to the us economy , and many factors are added to economic growth .
but there is no obvious evidence that if the 系统 system maintains its level in 1950 , without explosive growth in the past 20 years , the us economy today is 6 % lower than it is now .
there are five ways to benefit from well-functioning finance-insurance systems .
one is that people stopped being hit by the fires , floods , diseases , unemployment , business closures , and the rise of the sector , owing to well-functioning financial - systems that would diffuse some of the risk , and those who are fearful of a risk .
to be sure , america ’ s current finance-insurance system is partly a better way to spread risk , but it is difficult to see whether it is actually true of stock and real-estate investors over the past two decades .
second , well-functioning financial systems match large-scale , liquid investment projects with the relatively small pools of money provided by individual savers who value liquidity .
over the past two generations , one important innovation has been made : businesses can now issue high-yield bonds .
but , given the costs of bankruptcy , firms like to issue high-yield bonds ( aside from the causes of the tax system ) , why investors like to buy high-yield bonds , and not yet have the means to buy and buy them , is not yet clear .
third , improved opportunities for borrowing allow people to spend more today ( more 穷时 ) in today ’ s ( 较富时 ) savings .
households have a clear increase in opportunities for borrowing , thanks to mortgage ownership , credit cards , and payday loans .
but what about them ?
many people are not buying more of their money and saving their ability to save , but instead buy temporary , without discussions with other family members .
and that is what you want to buy .
fourth , we have seen a dramatic improvement in the ease of transactions .
but , while electronic transactions have made a significant contribution to financial life , this should be accompanied by a decline in the share of gdp in finance , not rising , just as communications equipment should make phone calls reduced .
indeed , the operation of the financial system with the most progressive relationship has made a clear simplification , exemplified in the checks and balances of regional federal reserve banks .
finally , better finance means better corporate governance .
because shareholder democracy is not allowed to control its managers ’ obsolete 放任 , finance plays an important role in ensuring corporate managers ’ interests .
in general , however , however , we do not see obvious benefits , both in the medium and macro level , and the efficiency of the us economy has not increased to the extent that it can prove that it would be worth the equivalent of 5.6 % of gdp .
lahart cites the conclusion of thomas 菲力 of new york university that today ’ s us financial sector is too big to account for at least two percentage points of gdp .
and the estimate of the size of the us financial sector is likely to be underestimated .

can the answer to the growth of the financial industry come mainly from the professionals who are in the latter business or after the latter business ?

learning from the forgotten us default
los angeles – one of the most widespread myths about the united states is that the federal government has never defaulted on its debt .
with every congressional debate on debt , politicians and journalists stand to say that the us will not lose credibility to its creditors .
only one problem is not really .
a few decades ago , the us was once a “ banana republic ” rather than a advanced economy , and a unilateral and 性 restructuring of debt .
although few remember important times in economic history , it is valuable for today ’ s leaders .
in april 1933 , in order to help the us escape the great depression , president franklin roosevelt announced his intention to leave the us the gold standard and devalue the dollar .
but this is not as simple as fdr thought .
most debt contracts at the time included “ gold clauses , ” which stipulates that debtors must pay “ gold coins ” or “ gold equivalent . ”
these provisions were created during the civil war , in order to protect investors against possible inflation .
but for fdr , the gold clause was a barrier to the dollar ’ s depreciation .
to address this problem , congress adopted a joint resolution on june 5 , 1933 , to repeal all gold clauses in the past and the future .
the door to devaluation opened – and the door to political infighting opened .
republicans feel frustrated because america ’ s reputation is at risk , and the roosevelt administration believed that the resolution was not “ a denial of contracts . ”
on january 30 , 1934 , the dollar was officially devalued .
the price of gold rose from $ 20.67 a barrel – the price it entered into effect in 1834 – to $ 35 per ounce .
not surprisingly , holders of securities protected by the gold clause claim that this was unconstitutional .
this raises lawsuits , which eventually reached the supreme court ; in january 1935 , judges listened two cases related to private debt , two cases of government debt .
the underlying question in each case was the same : has congress changed its contracts retroactively and changed ?
on february 18 , 1935 , the supreme court announced its decision .
in each case , judges took the 投票 vote to vote for the government ’ s decisions against investors .
according to a majority of opinion , the roosevelt administration could be canceled by “ necessity , ” if that helped to lift the economy out of the great depression .
james 麦克 , a lawyer in the south in the us attorney general , as secretary of justice in president woodrow wilson ’ s first term , wrote a different opinion – all four different cases .
in a brief speech , he spoke about the inviolability of contracts , the government ’ s obligation , and the 赖账 of the law .
the united states has been a collective amnesia , given that most americans have forgotten this history , with a collective amnesia about the rule of law and contracts .
but a good lawyer still remembers ; today , a lawyer defending default countries , such as venezuela , would invoke 1935 .
as more governments face new debt crises – such as unfunded liabilities associated with pension and health-care obligations – we may be more likely to see this argument .
according to the latest estimates , the us government ’ s inability to pay amounts to more than 260 % of gdp – not a conventional federal debt and a state or state debt that is unable to pay .
this problem extends beyond the us ; many countries ’ pension and health-related liabilities are increasing , and the ability to cover these debts is diminishing .
the key question , therefore , is whether governments attempting to adjust contracts back on their contracts will again invoke “ necessity . ”
the 1933 abrogation of gold provides ample legal and economic grounds for considering this possibility .
the us supreme court has agreed to “ necessity . ”
it is not far-fetched to think that it will again do so again .
america ’ s 变疯
boston – in recent years , the relative global decline of the united states has become a common subject of debate .

but a fully focused focus on economic indicators has not noticed the geopolitical impact of a us domestic trend – a trend that is already high in the united states ( which has remained high for years ) , but the debate often is another expert .
the prevalence of severe mental illness has reached a level of “ pandemic disease , ” so we often hear that it is so .
but international politics , diagnosed with disorders suffering from bipolar depression , and schizophrenia , is extremely serious .
in fact , the most common among these diseases – a one-way depression from symptoms – is the most complex , but it is also the most lethal : 20 % of depressed patients are expected to commit suicide .
but both depressive disorder and schizophrenia are psychotic , characterized by the inability of patients to control their actions and ideas , and that patients can not be treated as agents of free will .
indulging in suicidal thinking and lack of motivation makes depression a psychotic illness .
these conditions are often accompanied by elaborate delusions – that is , confusing the reality of information from the information and the information provided by outsiders .
normally , the distinction between symbols and their 意象 will disappear , and patients are starting to view people as mere objects of thought .
to put it mildly , the judgment of such people is unacceptable .
a massive statistical study by the us national institute of mental health ( NIMH ) in 2001 estimated that the lifetime prevalence of severe depression in the united states ( 15-64 years old ) was more than 16 % .
lifetime prevalence for schizophrenia is about 1.7 % .
these chronic diseases do not have known treatments ; the first episode , before the age of 18 , is likely to continue until the end of the patient ’ s life .
surveys of the us university show that 20 % of respondents in 2010 were in depression and anxiety criteria , and 25 % in 2012 .
other studies also show that each generation ’ s rates are increasing , and some argue that if the old statistics are wrong , they are wrong to underestimate the prevalence of mental illness .
all of this suggests that as many as 20 % of american adults may be mentally ill .
from the debate on the importance of available data , we assume that only 10 % of american adults are mentally ill .
assuming that these symptoms are evenly distributed among populations , they are bound to suffer a large share of policymakers , corporate executives , 教育家 , and military personnel at all levels , with mental illness producing a delusion that can not be judged properly .
if this situation is called a scary sense , it would be a matter of a small proportion : a larger proportion of the population ( an estimated 50 % ) is affected by poorer disorders , which are only occasional disturbances .
epidemiologists have repeatedly noticed that these diseases have marked a marked feature : only western countries ( or , more accurately , a society with a 一神论 tradition ) , especially in the prosperous west , are so prevalent .
the national team in south asia is particularly immune to severe mental illness ; in other regions , poverty or underdevelopment may seem to be a protective barrier .
in my recent book thinking , modernity , and the gospel of modernity , the reason why i have serious mental illness is the west ’ s nature in the west .
the “ virus ” at the root of depression and schizophrenia ( including smaller forms ) is rooted in culture : these social alternatives are difficult to define and personal identities , so that many people have lost their way .
the us offers the most widely defined personal self-definition ; there is also the world ’ s biggest lack of choice .
unless the growing prevalence of severe mental illness is taken seriously and addressed effectively , it will be the only indicator of american leadership .
china ’ s rise is irrelevant .

paris – after a presidential term in the united states , assessing his foreign-policy performance is a challenge , because every us president faces complex diplomatic and strategic conditions and a severe domestic constraint .

after the vietnam war , jimmy carter hoped to make a breakthrough in established us policies .
but his administration ’ s actions – including major mistakes in iran and afghanistan – have made the us weak and indecisive .
obama ’ s policies , while failing to weaken america ’ s international standing , have failed to deliver anything that is comparable to nixon ’ s relations with china , largely owing to the pragmatic pragmatism underlying obama ’ s foreign policy – the emphasis on avoiding the worst outcomes .
moreover , obama faces major constraints , including the global economic crisis , domestic political polarization , hostile congress , and the need for the us to accept the rise of the us-led emerging powers .
as a result , obama has failed to reconcile strategic realities by , say , by , say , equating the united states with iran ’ s broader interests , pakistan ( and 敌亦友 ) , and israel ( key ally ) .
to be sure , obama ’ s diplomatic and strategic environment is more complicated than nixon in the 1970s .
the instability in iran ’ s internal coalition has shaped any meaningful negotiation between the us and iran , and pakistan ’ s political fragmentation has also impeded pakistan ’ s policy of pakistani policy .
the fragility of israel ’ s ruling coalition , together with strong support for prime minister binyamin netanyahu ’ s prime minister binyamin netanyahu , has made it difficult for the us to influence israel ’ s policies , despite its significant influence on america ’ s arab policy .
but obama has yet to offer the terms of a possible grand bargain .
any deal with iran would have to be agreed by israel and the gulf states , and both are different .
the us is unlikely to agree with pakistan without an agreement with pakistan , and whether india will agree is not in the us , especially if the us relies on india to counterbalance china ’ s influence in asia .
israel , for its part , seems to be simpler : as a exchange of security guarantees for the us , israel will accept the 1967 borders in the palestinian borders .

although obama ’ s first term is not a disappointment , his achievements – though not trivial – are very limited .
