other countries have already found such a path .
between the mid-1970 ’ s and the mid-1990 ’ s , australia witnessed mass shootings .
after the extraordinary killing of 1996 , the new prime minister , john howard , declared that enough was enough .
he has a serious crackdown on gun ownership , forcing would-be gun owners to take a rigorous application process , and must demonstrate the reason for a gun .
today , australia ’ s gun conditions are very strict , and the registration and approval processes are long for a year or more .
and howard ’ s government implemented a rigorous “ repo ” policy that allowed the government to purchase a gun that has been owned by the public .
this policy worked .
despite the failure of crime in australia , the murder has fallen , and , more important , the number of mass shootings that have not occurred since 1996 , or more than three or more of the number of deaths ( which were defined in many studies ) since 1996 .

what explains the high rates of homicide rates in the us and latin america ?
america ’ s violence has its roots .

citizens ’ militias have become obsolete , so gun ownership , which now bans the second amendment , is only personal gun ownership , as if it can provide protection against tyranny .
the reckless supreme court is on the side of the gun .
so gun ownership is closely linked to the american sub-culture , a large-scale gun gun .
but , rather than being protected by freedom , americans are now experiencing massive bloodshed and panic .
the claim that gun ownership ensures freedom is particularly absurd – and the world ’ s vibrant democracies have long since removed private gun ownership .
no tyrant has emerged in australia after howard ’ s gun-control reforms .
in short , freedom of the twenty-first century does not depend on unregulated gun ownership .
indeed , america ’ s gun culture is a threat to freedom – in recent decades , for the president , senator , and public leaders , and countless assassination officials .
but us gun culture remains pervasive and few reports .
with the us shooting a shooting disaster in one of the next , and in almost every shooting , politicians would vow to continue to fight unchecked gun support .

new york – the 2008 financial crisis heralded the end of our familiar global order .
in the run-up to the g-8 summit , we have not noticed the fact that , for the first time in 70 years , the us will not be able to implement the international agenda and the world ’ s most pressing problems .
indeed , america ’ s refusal to do so in saving the eurozone , intervening in syria , and using military force to address iran ’ s nuclear problem ( though israel strongly supports it ) has already signaled its role abroad .
president barack obama officially ended the war in iraq , and is withdrawing from afghanistan – an effort that can be saved only by controlling the pace of its withdrawal .
the us is handing over the leadership baton – though no country or country is willing or able to muster it .
in short , america ’ s foreign policy may be as positive as it once was , but it is also declining , and it is increasingly difficult to sustain its primacy .
as a result , many global challenges – climate change , trade , resource scarcity , international security , cyber-warfare , nuclear proliferation , and so forth – will be bound to intensify .
welcome to the g-zero world , a more volatile and uncertain environment , and the coordination of global policy issues has been thrown aside .
the irony , ironically , is that the new environment in which the us has turned into trouble has given the us a fresh opportunity to use its unique status .
the g-zero world is not a bad thing for the us – as long as the us has a good cards .
in such a world , many remaining powers will play a more important role , and the us remains the only real superpower and the largest economy , more than twice the size of china ’ s .
us defense spending has almost half the global total , and more than the subsequent 17 countries combined .
the dollar remains the world ’ s reserve currency , with investors flocking to us treasury bills in 2008 , suggesting that the us still has a safe haven ( though the us was the beginning of the crisis ) .
likewise , the us continues to lead in entrepreneurship , research and development , higher education , and technological innovation .
moreover , the us is now the world ’ s largest natural-gas exporter and exporter of heat , reducing the price shock or food shortages for the us .
no country can match the us in promoting the rule of law , liberal democracy , transparency , and free enterprise .
while other countries clearly support these values , only the us has been willing and strong enough to ensure that these values are pursued .
as a result , as america ’ s global leadership shrinks , it will find itself more popular .
consider asia ’ s economic strength , as well as its regional influence , with its neighbors seeking to pursue deep cooperation with the us .
japan , australia , indonesia , and 台湾地区 have both recently engaged closely with the us concerning trade and security issues .
even myanmar began to stumble toward the us , resuming diplomatic relations with the us and trying to escape china ’ s shadow .
in other words , in the g-zero world , an increasingly combustible international environment has made the us more appealing to countries that want to take bets on their own interests .
weakening the leadership role enabled the us to weigh opportunity before action , and to choose the best issues and the environment , in which the military intervention in libya and syria is far from certain .
the extent to which the us can capitalize on these opportunities remains to be seen .
in fact , america ’ s short-term advantages are the obstacles to its long-term prospects .
let ’ s call this the “ safe haven ” : as long as the us remains the safest safe haven for any storm , it has no incentive to fix its weaknesses soon .
for example , all references to the us national debt say that investors will continue to lend to the us .
in the long run , however , us policymakers must make real progress in restoring confidence in their national finances , by cutting spending on politically immovable programs like social security , health care , and defense .
officials must abandon short-sighted and political correctness , improve america ’ s aging infrastructure , reform its education and immigration system , and pursue long-term fiscal consolidation .
but it is this 超然 that eliminates the risks of creating disastrous consequences , thereby keeping the us happy .
america ’ s politicians should recognize the g-zero reality , and restore america ’ s powerful sources of strength , even if only gradual progress is gradually progressive .
america ’ s political system often works well in the crisis , but , because the us has some residual advantages in the absence of a leader , it does not need a crisis to stimulate action .
it needs only to seize the g-zero moment .
america ’ s housing crisis
sometimes it is time for some to prove that there is no pleasure .
for the last few years , i have long argued that the us economy was propped up by housing bubbles , which replaced the stock market bubble of the 1990 ’ s .
but no bubble can expand indefinitely .
with middle-class incomes in the us stagnating , americans can not afford increasingly expensive homes .
as president of the us council of economic advisers , one of my predecessors famously said , “ it won ’ t be sustained . ”
compared to those who live in the stock market , economists never claim to be able to predict when the day when the reckoning will arrive , let alone what the event will bring down the housing market .
but some signs are systemic , and the consequences are manifest over time .
there are macro and micro reasons .
the macro-story is simple but dramatic .
some observed that the sub-prime market collapses : “ don ’ t worry , this is the problem of the real estate sector . ”
but it ignores the role of housing markets in the us in recent years , when direct investment in real estate and investment in real estate flows from the housing market to three-quarters of the economy has grown to three-quarters .
the spike in housing prices gave americans confidence and money to spend more than they do .
america ’ s household saving rate has fallen at its lowest point since the great depression , not negative .
as higher interest rates hold down home prices , the game is over .
when america ’ s saving rate is 4 % ( which is still low in general ) , aggregate aggregate demand will weaken , with the economy weakening .
the micro-story is more dramatic .
record-low interest rates in 2001 , 2002 , 2003 did not lead americans to invest more in enthusiasm – excess capacity .
instead , the mentality of earning money induced households to refinance their mortgages and spend part of their capital in order to stimulate the us economy .
it is one thing to invest in investment , which strengthens our balance sheets ; but it is another thing to spend money on vacation and madness .
and that is precisely what alan greenspan encouraged americans to do .
when ordinary loans do not meet demand , he encouraged americans to engage in variable exchange rates – periods that keep pace with interest rates .
greedy lenders , then , have introduced negative amortization loans ( wages ) , so that borrowers ’ liabilities have gone back home .
at some point in the future , it will be higher , but borrowers will once again be told , not worried : rising house prices will rise faster , and so it is easy to borrow a negative amortization loan .
( in this view , only those who do not ) can not benefit .
the reality is grim : newspapers report a case in which borrowers ’ total income is not repaid .
globalization means that america ’ s lending problem has had a worldwide impact .
the first hit was the british mortgage bank northern rock .
the us has succeeded in throwing billions of dollars out of bad loans to investors worldwide ( including banks ) .
they buried these bad debts through sophisticated financial instruments , buried so deep so that no one knew exactly how bad these bad debts were , and that no one can quickly 定价 them .
in the face of such uncertainty , markets froze .
financiers who believe in free-market principles are temporarily leaving their beliefs behind .
they say that , for everyone ’ s greater wellbeing , of course , the government has saved it .
although the us treasury and the international monetary fund have warned of the risks of bailout bailouts in east asia , which had faced financial crises a decade ago and advised to do not raise interest rates , the us has bought massive ( bad ) loans , acquiring massive ( bad ) loans , and reduced interest rates .
but lower short-term interest rates have led to higher medium-term interest rates , which may be more relevant to the mortgage market , owing to fears about inflationary pressures .
central banks ’ purchases of mortgage-backed securities in order to increase market liquidity may have played a role , as central banks ( or the major us governments hold loans to the us federal mortgage service ) .
but those who share the securities should provide a guarantee that the public should not pay for their bad investment decisions .
the equity owners of banks should not be allowed to get a free ride .
securitization is in sharing risk , but there are three problems that make it unacceptable .
while this means that the us banks are not hit by the worst , america ’ s non-performing loans have already had a global impact .
moreover , securitization contributed to bad loans : in the past , banks with non-performing loans have gone awry ; but , in a new world of securitization , bad debts could be passed onto others .
( as economists do , the problem of asymmetric information is more severe . )
in the past , when borrowers discovered that they can not afford their repayment , mortgage lending will be from new combinations ; foreclosures are bad for both sides .
securitization made debt restructuring difficult ( if not impossible ) .
the victims of predatory lenders are those who need governments to help .
debt restructuring is less easy when mortgages reach 95 % or more of their homes .
individuals who need to give excessive debt , such as through a special bankruptcy provision , allowed them to regain 75 % of their assets in real estate , while lenders would incur the cost .
the us and the rest of the world should learn from many of the lessons ; above all , more stringent regulation of the financial sector , particularly better protection and greater transparency for predatory lenders .
america ’ s interest-rate puzzle
america ’ s long-term real interest rate has been low , and this is a major feature of the world economy today .
now , the us current account deficit has reached 7 % of gdp , and , as i have learned from traditional macroeconomists like me , would inevitably follow a large currency devaluation .
so we predict a significant decline in the premium on us interest rates .
if the dollar falls 20 % against the euro sometime over the next decade , long-term interest rates in the us will be 20 percentage points higher than the euro .
if the dollar falls 40 % against the yen sometime in the next decade , long-term us interest rates will be four percentage points higher than japan ’ s .
but there are no signs of this .
it is puzzling not only that long-term interest rates are too low internationally , but also in the us .
the bush administration did not have any plans to 割开 the blood vessels that the middle medieval economic policy 割开 , arguing that , as long as the government is bleeding , it can address all economic problems .
this means that , unless the us domestic deposit rate is rising sharply , and that , until 2010 , investment spending remains dysfunctional , with investment spending falling at a time when the current-account deficit is reduced to a sustainable level , and when prices are low , prices will rise , and prices will rise when demand falls .
in this case , the price of loanable funds is equal to real interest rates .
if interest rates are expected to rise at a higher rate sometime in the next decade , they would mean higher interest rates on long-term bonds .
but financial markets did not depreciate the dollar , and the corresponding us interest rate is rising .
when our fellow macroeconomists and wall street friends talk about it , they find it difficult to understand what they are not thinking .
on the contrary , they do not understand why , in our eyes , us long-term interest rates are worrisome .
they argue that the current high demand for dollar-denominated securities is easy to explain : central asia ’ s central banks are buying on their own currencies , and the us treasury is now investing in short-term bonds ( and thus not issuing a large amount of long-term bonds ) , and it will not lead to a large number of long-term bonds .
but every price of the market has gone away , generating lucrative opportunities : if long-term interest rates were indeed too low , the long-term bond price of long-term bonds will be invested somewhere in another , waiting for the bond price to be diverted to fundamentals .
thus , they can push prices close to fundamentals today .
on wall street ’ s friends , the opposite is said : if any financial institution is serious , and even borrowing to bet on a sharp decline in the dollar in the next five years , the iaea would face an existential crisis .
and trades do go wrong : remember the collapse of us companies in long-term capital management .
there are also big players in financial markets who are not concerned about maximizing their profits .
for example , if the bank of china and the us federal reserve decided to learn the lessons of speculators , driving up the dollar ’ s value relative to the renminbi , and keeping up the value of a month , they would be entirely likely to do so .
similarly , if any financial institution is serious , borrowing to bet on long-term interest rates in the next five years will be a high priority , and it is at risk of its own survival .
what are they to vote for ?
the real estate rents and the stock market are too low , and , if interest rates rise sharply , real estate and stock prices could fall , possibly equivalent to higher prices or higher prices .
only those who can afford long-term loans and lock up current real interest rates and invest in expanding their size can bet on domestic bets and bet on interest rates .
but us firms have seen future risks , and are constantly vigilant in keeping themselves at 套住 .
economists believe that market forces drive prices back to fundamentals .
but we tend not to be careful enough to distinguish between balance resilience and weak weakness .
only traders in wall street and elsewhere believe that , in the short run , holding dollars and long-term us treasury bonds will fall , and the us dollar will rise if long-term us interest rates rise .
in the long run , the future will be as high as it is now .
america ’ s islamist allies in convenience
new delhi – in just a decade , us military intervention has intervened in three muslim-majority countries and toppled their governments .
now , the coalition of american liberal interventionists and neoconservatives that launched these wars is pushing against punitive strikes against syria , and that they have largely strengthened the islamists and forged anti-americanism .
indeed , the last “ humanitarian intervention ” clearly backfired , turning syria into a bloody front of transnational forces .
by contrast , the desire to protect america ’ s “ credibility ” has become the last refuge of those seeking another war in the middle east .
if “ credibility ” is purged because of the debate and the real focus on america ’ s long-term interests , it is clear that a blow to syria will not produce even temporary geopolitical benefits .
looking beyond short-term perspective , this would have unintended consequences , potentially making syria a “ soft ” partition of iraq and a haven haven for extremists in northern syria and iraq , where the islamic state ’ s islamist forces are formed .
indeed , fighting syria is likely to make the us more dependent on the unpopular islamist rulers from saudi arabia to qatar and the united arab emirates .
some arab monarchs have pledged to fund us strikes – an investment that can easily be expected , because war rhetoric has already led to higher oil prices .
al qaeda has taken root in the middle east and north africa , creating the conditions for international terrorism in the coming years , which is an unintended consequence of us policy .
for example , america ’ s invasion and occupation of iraq opened doors to al qaeda , whose affiliates now represent a sunni and shia government .
likewise , regime change in libya has fueled a military presence with al qaeda , leading to the assassination of the american ambassador in benghazi .
a system based on islamic law has been established , and human-rights abuses are legion , weapons and armies have undermined the security of libya ’ s neighbors .
meanwhile , america ’ s support for the regime in yemen and saudi arabia has benefited al qaeda in the arabian peninsula .
in some parts of southern yemen , al Sharia , al-qaeda agencies , is de facto government .
in syria , a large number of territory is already under islamic law , and al qaeda ’ s al nusra front , the al nusra militia , has been in the grips of the us-backed free syrian army , which is feeling the consequences of the previous policy choices .
as it stands , airstrikes will undermine the fsa ’ s grassroots legitimacy and help islamist forces make matters worse .
in the east , the us wants to conclude a peace deal with the taliban , the main rival in afghanistan , to “ glorious ” out of the longest war in american history .
in the process of wooing the taliban , the taliban had already developed diplomatic relations with qatar – the legitimacy of the united states , which gave the us a sanctuary in the middle ages .
the us alliance with the islamic political forces and the government ’ s guiding doctrine is that islam ’ s garb helps to protect the credibility of leaders who might be seen as foreign warships .
this is a fundamental matter , even in the short term .
on the contrary , in egypt ’ s military , where the muslim brotherhood ’ s mohamed morsi came to power , many egyptians had long treated him as the architect of the us in cairo .
in the long run , the us is not , the risk is much – if it continues to support the oil sheikhs and from the philippines and india from the philippines and india to south africa and venezuela .
the united states , which supports islamic rulers , has moved toward the muslim killing of muslims from the maghreb and pakistan .
american policies are also fueling conflict between islamists and secular forces in muslim countries .
the best example is turkey , where obama has ignored prime minister recep tayyip erdoğan ’ s decision to destroy freedom of speech and make himself a reminder of the behavior of twenty-first-century sudan .
in turkey and other countries , the us , in a larger geopolitical goal of curbing shia iran and its regional allies , allowed sunni rulers to move toward religious and political extremes , even if they pose transnational threats to free and secular values .
moreover , conflicts within islam are likely to become regional instability , undermining the interests of the liberal world .
against this background , obama should follow powell ’ s ideas in 1991 .
powell thought that the us should use force only if key national interests were threatened , strategic objectives explicitly , and can be achieved more than costs , adverse effects , and access to broad domestic and international support , and a reliable exit strategy .
america ’ s record after this idea suggests that the main beneficiaries of military intervention are not america ’ s moral adversaries .
drone wars
brussels – in 1936 , the american poet carl sandburg wrote that “ they will someday go to war but no one .
instead , humans increasingly rely on drones – or unmanned aerial vehicles ( uavs ) – to kill them .
under president barack obama , the number of attacks on drone attacks in the us has soared , with the drone attacks on pakistan alone more than 300 .
in march 2011 , the us air force has trained more drones for the first time .
this raises serious ethical questions .
with no military personnel risking their lives , drones reduce the killing and the public ’ s legitimacy to justify war .
moreover , the lower the human tide ’ s fear of killing between the attackers and the target .
if drones are operating in nevada over yemen , the threshold for pulling the trigger would be dangerously low .
the killing is just part of the work , and then it might follow suit , and perhaps the entire evening .
moreover , the mere sound of drones can be heard for everyone , because it gives the enemy and the civilians a sign that they are being monitored and could be attacked – perhaps by terrorist recruiters .
in terms of legal and human rights , the us drone program is even more alarming .
after all , countries such as pakistan , yemen , and somalia are not recognized in a war zones .
in the context of war , it is only proof that the state should be killing its lives only if it proves absolutely necessary to save lives .
deterrence must be defended in a way that is under attack , or , in response to the possible threat of immediate threats , no time to discuss 致命 alternatives .
the us drone program has no longer been considered in the first category of reactive self-defense since september 11 , 2001 .
likewise , there is no evidence that the so-called terrorists who have been killed outside of the last few years have caused a direct threat to american citizens ’ lives , and that the threat must be addressed by prevention and premeditated killing .
unless us leaders prove otherwise , the us drone attacks in countries like pakistan and yemen should be reduced to the end of their execution .
the us state department legal adviser , 高洪柱 高洪柱 , disagrees , and suggested that the us is playing a world “ armed war with al qaeda and the taliban and related powers . ”
so the drone strikes claim that drone attacks are part of a global war in war zones and 战区 countries , so it is legitimate .
but even if we accept this adventurous assumption , there is still no legitimate explanation for human rights .
the war was allowed specifically to eliminate “ combatants ” who “ participate directly in hostilities . ”
and the killings must be controlled , strategically necessary , and acceptable to the public .
avoiding harm should be a top priority .
at the slightest sign of illegality , investigations have been investigated , prosecuted by the perpetrators , and compensation for victims .
but the us drone program ’ s legal basis is entirely unclear .
given the classified information classified in most drone activities , it is almost impossible to know whether all drone targets are directly involved in hostilities .
and , while the obama administration ’ s so-called civilian death numbers are officially defined as the official definition of what might be true , the premise is that any 参军 male who is killed in drone strikes is armed , unless subsequent intelligence proves otherwise .
according to a recent report by the law of stanford university and new york university , the number of civilian deaths in pakistan in real pakistan was probably 75 % in the real number of uav victims in 2011 .
other reports , while slightly less overvalued , have reached a staggering 30 % .
this clearly violates the legal obligations of proportionality .
the drone act is the cia , which all activities are secret .
and , unlike military personnel , cia agents enjoy extensive immunity , which has undermined the foundation of international law .
to declare that us drone operations are legitimate , however , they must be made more transparent in the context of war and armed conflict .
as long as the us does not allow the rest of the world to understand the truth , illegal offenses – including war crimes – could continue to elude impunity .
as citizens of the world have demanded to expand the scope of economic and fiscal accountability , we must also pressure further pressure on the us to demonstrate the need for drone operations , or that they immediately stop acting .
victims of drone attacks and their families and civil-society groups have begun to step up against america ’ s dubious drone activities , and have filed legal lawsuits .
others should be encouraged to do so .
at the same time , every drone attack would not only harm human rights and international humanitarian law , but will also create legal loopholes that other governments and armed groups will not hesitate to exploit .
instead of making the world safer , the us has created an environment of illegal killing at almost any time , in violation of basic human rights requirements that have been stripped of others ’ lives .
america ’ s locust years
berkeley – the writing on american political economy is hardly easy .
no one knows that the debt-ceiling 弦 will not survive ; how to survive ; and what happens if it is not .
if there were no consensus on the debt ceiling on august 3 , the interest rate on us treasury bonds could soar , but it could also maintain stability ( as investors assume that there are other more worrying things ) .
the fed and the people ’ s bank of china ( and other institutions ) could also support the market .
if the global economy is expected to weaken further , interest rates may rise , and if there is no inflation , investors will be more ( rather than less ) holding us treasuries .
frankly , no one knows what kind of solutions would be to raise the debt ceiling .
what we can know is that the proposal may include measures to reduce recent spending , which means that growth will slow further in the next 18 months , and unemployment will increase further .
we can also assume that such measures will end in january 2013 , when new initiatives are both likely to be reelected and a new republican president .
as a result , we are putting the us debt ceiling on side , and consider how the debt-ceiling standoff has been constrained by the us government over the last six months , let alone consider what useful policies are supposed to be discussed .
the threat of global warming , for example , is not eliminated .
the sooner this threat is , the better .
another six months should not be lost .
the employment-to-population ratio in the us remains stagnant , sustaining very low levels during the recession .
american households are working hard to restore their balance sheets , and capital investment is healthy , so that the only places that can boost production spending are exports , government purchases , and construction .
but we do not seize the opportunity to implement the necessary measures .
in this respect , another six months should not be lost .
similarly , the us has a reputation for its day-to-day responsibility for its international economic orchestra , but it did not , even the eu ’ s inability to deal with its slow debt crisis .
in northern europe , politicians in the north are running out of money and support policies that are far too high .
another six months later .
any of these three issues will be momentous progress toward resolving the long-term progress of the us ’ s long-term fiscal imbalances on long-term social security that the current tax rate and the us debt-ceiling debate want to address .
but the us government will not solve these problems , and it has wasted six months – to boost the us economy ’ s long-term potential and debt overhangs by investing in infrastructure investment , reforming education , and financing for health care .
during wwii ’ s war , winston churchill wore a “ disaster for the years ” – what he meant was a time when the great crisis that was supposed to be him ( the rise of fascism in the european continent ) was not done .
throughout the twentieth century – a remarkable exception – the us political system has always been able to predict a crisis long before the crisis , and when the crisis hit , at least , the us has dealt with it .
but , in the third millennium , the skills ( perhaps luck ) are gone from the us .
in my view , if only the republican party of dwight d. eisenhower could get back to life ( richard nixon and joseph mccarthy ) , the issue would automatically correct .
but it is becoming increasingly clear that the problem is not only in the us , but also elsewhere in the world .
since december 7 , 1941 , the world has been relying on a governance that is still a competent superpower .
such a us may be gone for good .
if so , the world needs another system to manage global affairs and soon .
america ’ s immigration debate
the us senate is engaged in a debate about immigration , which will discuss several proposals .
these include a hateful bill that stipulates that building a wall along the border with the united states and mexico , and putting illegal entry into the us , has approved the bill .
the us senate will also consider a bill led by senator john f. kennedy and senator john f. kennedy , who proposed strengthening border enforcement and instituting temporary work programs that can be redirected to residency and citizenship .
another is to demand that anyone who wants normal immigration in the us is returning to their homeland and wait for it .
last but not least , it is hard to imagine that no one has been willing to return to a new visa in the us to wait for a new visa .
almost five years ago , when president george w. bush promised to sign a immigration deal with mexico for president vicente fox , he has been spared the problem .
finally , perhaps the most important is the senate judiciary committee ’ s compromise proposal .
specter ’ s recommendations also apply to more border security , as well as six years of non-renewable work , which allows illegal immigrants to remain in the us for a new 移民 identity .
avoiding this question may be a tactical tactic for avoiding discussion of whether it is a form of grand amnesty , and , unfortunately , it is a form of grand amnesty .
what is missing from this debate is the latin american context .
in the old days , the flow of migrant flows in the western hemisphere was limited to mexico and the caribbean .
in the 1980 ’ s , when central america ’ s civil war brought hundreds of thousands of migrants to the us in mexico , the situation changed in the 1990 ’ s , when the people who escape the violence in colombia , venezuela , peru , and ecuador began looking for opportunities .
brazil has traditionally been a country of emigration , and it is now a country that exports migrants .
more importantly , these migrants are no longer confined to rural populations , and they are no longer confined to the traditional distribution of migrants in the us .
their remittances have benefited their families and communities as well as their economies .
in that case , the us , whatever its immigration policies , will have a major impact on regions outside of mexico .
and that is precisely what happened in latin america , where a return to anti-americanism and populism followed , first in 1999 , in venezuela , then last year , and perhaps mexico , peru , and nicaragua later this year .
if the us continues to feel hostile to latin america , it will harden irresponsible and demagogic left-wing tendencies .
the best way to exacerbate the region ’ s growing anti-american sentiment is to try to close the us-mexican border ( which would be futile ) .
instead , the us should establish a humanitarian , 安 , and legal mechanism for the us economy , and the people who want to enter the us for a permanent or permanent journey , and that the us should work with latin american governments , not against it .
five years ago , mexico ’ s president vicente fox tried to convince bush that to prevent a nativist backlash within the united states , it will have to take action to keep the us from its relationship with latin america in order to avoid a 强烈反应 backlash .
but the situation has become worse .
bush must start using his remaining political capital to support enlightened immigration reform .
without the support of the democrats , he will never have access to foreign workers , and the democrats will not be backed by democrats unless the white house supports a program that includes a permanent residence and citizenship .
mexico and the us must remain sensitive to domestic political concerns in their respective countries .
addressing the issue of security will not be able to deal with the migration issue in north korea , where immigration can not be imagined if immigration reform is ignored by the nearly five million illegal immigrants currently living in the us , and can not be expected to cooperate on border security and temporary workers programs .
mexico must act as a “ common responsibility ” on fox president .
the most viable agreement between the us and mexico , or the best possible us reforms , is not to eliminate migrants from mexico and south america overnight .
mexico must take responsibility for managing this flow of people , which means doing more than closing the southern border .
for example , the government could double down the welfare of male parents to stay home , threatening to eliminate land reform in the years after leaving rural communities , and establish checkpoints on highways in the 高速公路 hills .
fox has said that he is willing to break with the old mexican taboos , but the bush administration has never taken it seriously .
this is unfortunate , because fox will not be in power forever .
immigration is always a complex and delicate problem within the us , as is the case now for latin america .
the window of opportunity opened in bush ’ s first term was closed after the terrorist attacks of september 2001 .
now that window is opening up , and should be used before it is too late .
why iran won ’ t budge
tel aviv – no one really believes that a new round of international negotiations with iran will be possible .
so , while concessions from the p5+1 ( china , france , russia , the united kingdom , the united states , and , together with germany ) have been made at the meeting in kazakhstan , no progress has been made .
america ’ s belief that tough sanctions can induce iran to reach an agreement at least now appears unrealistic .
despite isolated and ostracized , iran has secured strategic breathing room with the help of the west , russia , india , syria , and venezuela .
more important , even the us-led sanctions regime is bound to be imperfect – and it will only strengthen iran ’ s resistance to “ american conspiracy . ”
iran ’ s strategic alliance is to be sure , and both staunch allies in syria and venezuela are likely to collapse outright .
the end of the chávez regime threatens to threaten iran ’ s enormous interests in venezuela , while iran ’ s collapse in the andes is likely to be undermined by the fall of the shah .
nonetheless , russia and china have been more lenient toward iran since the international atomic energy agency ’ s report in november 2011 detailing iran ’ s quest for nuclear weapons .
while the western powers imposed more sanctions than ever before , russia and china have made iran a global competition with the us .
china ’ s interests in iran are ultimately economic .
bilateral trade is about $ 40 billion a year , and china is not just iran ’ s largest customer of crude oil , but also a huge investor in energy transport ( $ 400 billion ) .
but china refused to recognize the west ’ s 单边制裁 measures , while supporting sanctions imposed by the un security council .
with bilateral trade worth only $ 5 billion , russia ’ s economic interests are minimal .
but russia worries that iran is making trouble , especially to whip up the muslim populace in russia .
moreover , the us has rejected the kremlin ’ s high prices – limiting congressional human-rights legislation , dismantling the cold war , and abandoning european ballistic missile defense programs , in exchange for russia ’ s support for us support in iran ( or in other volatile regions like syria ) .
the problem with america ’ s anti-iran crusade is that iran is playing an important role in areas where some countries are in play .
india is a case in point .
india is certainly wary of iran ’ s prospects for developing nuclear weapons , not to mention its concerns about the potential impact of iran ’ s islamic fundamentalism on kashmir .
but $ 14 billion in annual bilateral trade and dependence on iranian oil ( which india ’ s many refineries rely exclusively on iranian crude imports ) is a key strategic issue .
moreover , india needs iran to circumvent the country ’ s 替代 alternative to the country ’ s energy trade , and it needs iran to hedge its future uncertainty after the us withdrawal from afghanistan in 2014 .
as a result , india ’ s policy and china are like china : it is to agree to mandatory international sanctions , but the prohibition of voluntary western financial constraints .
the best guess is that india continues to brinkmanship – for example , in reducing dependence on iranian oil and expanding its oil imports from saudi arabia , the country ’ s largest supplier of crude oil .
the ambiguities in iran ’ s alliances is mixed .
there is certainly a good thing to be said of a country supporting tough sanctions , but it is likely that iran , with its back in the wall , could develop nuclear weapons .
after all , iraq is precisely the first point in the gulf war because of its nuclear program and without weapons of mass destruction .
similarly , libya ’ s muammar el-qaddafi became the target of nato ’ s assault on weapons of mass destruction .
on the contrary , north korea ’ s example suggests that the response is not a compromise but challenges .
as a result , iran has sought to develop its nuclear program with north korea ’ s assistance , which is likely to be destroyed by israel ’ s 2007 未公开 “ 行动 activities , ” which will be possible unless the comprehensive plan is set to address iran ’ s regional powers and ensure that the us does not act as a regional power .
albert einstein used “ doing the same thing , but expecting different results ” to define insanity , just as it applies to us policy toward iran .
diplomacy , exclusion , and brinkmanship have failed .
with iran ’ s uranium enrichment and other weapons r & d increasing , the us needs to change its old rules of engagement .
the wrong deficit complacency
cambridge – the united states still faces a dangerous budget deficit , but the deficit can not be known in the complacency that the washington budget debate has .
the previous federal deficit was seen as a pressing issue , but it is now a matter of us politics .
what triggered a change in opinion is the latest budget forecast for the congressional budget office ( cbo ) , an independent technical institution that is responsible for providing budget problems to the budget .
according to the cbo report , the us fiscal deficit will fall from 7 % of gdp in 2012 to 4 % in 2013 .
this reduction reflects spending cuts in defense and non-defense programs that came into effect last march , and the increase in taxes on income and payroll taxes that came into effect in late march 2012 .
even more remarkable is the cbo ’ s forecast that the deficit will continue to decline rapidly , cutting cuts to 2.1 % of gdp in 2015 , and then gradually rise , to 3.5 % in 2023 ( the end of the cbo officially forecast ) .
the budgetary changes imply that the government debt/gdp ratio will remain around 75 % over the next decade .
unfortunately , these headline-grabbing figures are unlikely to become reality ; indeed , even the cbo does not believe that they represent what happens in the future .
the cbo ’ s “ baseline budget ” assumes that all of the current law ’ s deficit cuts remain unchanged .
these include , for example , an old legislative requirement that the government ’ s medicare program will fall sharply in the years ahead , and that , in the case of this demand , a “ moratorium ” would be voted every year .
in order to provide better guidance , the cbo offered “ alternative fiscal scenarios , ” which , in this scenario , is not feasible .
the alternative suggests that the annual budget deficit will rise to 4.7 % of gdp , with the debt/gdp ratio at 83 % and rising .
and these estimates are based on optimistic assumptions that the economy will gradually recover full employment , with low inflation and low interest rates .
officials and others who support growth by increasing government spending ignore the cbo ’ s more realistic alternative scenario .
using long-term government debt – a ten-year treasury bond yield only 2 % , and the real interest rate on inflation protection ( tips ) is negative – the argument is not immediate .
but such low interest rates do not reflect normal market sentiment ; on the contrary , the reason for low interest rates is that the fed is buying more long-term securities , exceeding the volume of the government ’ s finances .
in the future , the cbo warns that a combination of rapidly aging populations and rising health-care costs will cause the deficit to rise rapidly , driven by increased benefits from retirement costs and benefits for middle-class retirees .
according to the cbo , without legislative changes , the annual fiscal deficit will be 1.7 % of gdp , while the national debt will rise to more than 195% % of gdp .
large and growing national debt is a serious threat to economic health .
rising debt-service costs require higher tax rates , which in turn weaken incentives and depress economic growth .
ten years later , the us needs to pay more than one-third of the revenue of personal income taxes to pay for interest on the national debt .
foreign investors now hold more than half of their debt .
paying interest to them would require sending goods and services to the rest of the world , with more than the number of other parts of the world going to the rest of the world .
this requires a weaker dollar to make us goods more attractive to foreign buyers , and that foreign goods are more expensive for us consumers .
a weaker dollar reduces us living standards .
a large national debt also limits governments ’ ability to respond to emergencies , including military threats and economic downturns .
it also makes the us vulnerable to changes in financial-market sentiment , as the european experience shows .
reducing future deficits and reversing the rise in the national debt will require higher tax revenue and lower growth in government pension and health-care programs .
tax revenues can be achieved without increasing marginal tax rates by limiting tax subsidies in the existing tax code .
these subsidies are implicit government spending , from family mortgages and health insurance to hybrid vehicles and household solar panels .
reducing the growth in spending on middle-class retirees and health-care programs is not an overnight task .
it must start with a decade of warning that people with a decade of warning are starting to start – and why need to begin now .
unfortunately , new complacency about the future deficits makes it difficult ( if not impossible ) to initiate the legislation needed to open the us budget deficit .
for policymakers and the public , it is important to understand the real fiscal outlook and the consequences of the deficit in the absence of immediate action .
simply throwing the problem on a minor footing will not prevent it .
facing america ’ s growth challenge
berkeley – the united states has been recovering from the great recession of the great depression , but the pace of recovery remains alarmingly low .
the recession or financial crisis in europe , or the slowdown in emerging markets , is a major source of external concern .
at home , the political struggle reflects two biggest risks : an agreement to achieve a higher debt ceiling and a new round of fiscal austerity that impede economic growth .
since 2010 , average annual gdp growth has averaged 2.1 % , meaning that job creation is weak .
in both cases , the rebound in employment growth was weaker than in gdp and lags behind gdp .
but the recent recession has fallen twice as much as the number of jobs in the latest recession , so slow recovery implies high unemployment for much longer .
weak aggregate demand is blamed for weak gdp and employment growth .
the 2008 recession was triggered by the financial crisis , which destroyed the housing market by inflating asset bubbles .
in the aftermath of such crises , private-sector demand fell sharply , and recovery will be slow .
the private sector ’ s volatility is the result of a deficit of 3.7 % of gdp in 2006 ( the height of the boom ) , which was about 6.8 % of gdp in 2010 , and now accounts for about 5 % of gdp .
this means that this is the sharpest recession and weakest recovery in private-sector demand since the end of world war ii .
the two components of private demand – residential investment and consumption , which account for more than 75 % of total spending in the us economy – are particularly slow .
both sources of demand are likely to increase in 2013 .
in terms of gdp , residential investment remains at a historic low , as the result of the excesses of the real-estate bubble of 2007-2008 and the tsunami of foreclosures .
but the headwinds in the housing market are dissipating .
last year , housing sales , prices , and construction rose , while foreclosures declined .
residential investment should be a source of output and employment growth this year .
the massive loss of household wealth , deleveraging at unsustainable debt levels , weak wage growth , and labor income ’ s share of national income , combined with a combination of income growth , has constrained consumption growth .
real median household income is still 7 % lower than its 2007 peak , and real median household wealth fell by 35 % from 2005 to 2010 ( and still significantly below pre-crisis peak ) , with 90 % of the income growth at the top of the top 1 % .
to be sure , balance-sheet headwinds for consumption have slowed .
household debt has been cut – often through painful foreclosure and insolvency – with the household debt/gdp ratio falling to levels in 2005 , significantly lower than in the 1980 ’ s .
but consumption will be affected by the expiration of the payroll tax plan , which will reduce household income by $ 25 billion this year .
another factor undermining recovery is weak growth in spending on goods and services in state and local governments , and recently the federal government has joined the ranks .
indeed , since the recession , state and local governments have eliminated 600,000 jobs and 20 % of infrastructure projects .
the fiscal trends of 2013 are still unclear , but negative .
state and local governments ’ spending cuts and layoffs in local and local governments are ending as recovery boosts tax revenues , and the fiscal drag on the federal level is increasing .
the us taxpayer bailout act – a tax agreement to avoid a “ fiscal cliff ” in early january – wiped out the $ 500 billion deficit in the coming decade , which would reduce the annual growth rate by 1 percentage points .
moreover , despite much less proponents of federal spending , the proposal has entered a phase of implementation , and may even intensify .
spending cuts and rising incomes for the law in 2011 are expected to reduce the deficit by $ 2.4 trillion over the next decade , with three-quarters coming from spending cuts and almost exclusively non-defense discretionary programs .
according to current economic assumptions , the us needs about $ 4 trillion in savings to stabilize the debt/gdp ratio over the next decade .
the so-called sequester ( across-the-board spending cuts that began in march ) will reduce $ 100 billion this year and $ 1.2 trillion in the next decade .
while this could stabilize the debt/gdp ratio , the sequester would be a mistake : it can not distinguish between spending priorities and undermines important projects , and that will lead to a severe weakening of growth this year .
moreover , despite warnings of deficit alarmists , the us has no immediate debt crisis .
recently , the public debt held by the public sector is just over 70 % of gdp , not seen since the early 1950 ’ s .
nonetheless , the government ’ s debt will increase by 86 % after a severe financial crisis , so that the federal debt increased by 70 % in 2008-2011 is not surprising .
there is little cause for concern .
the us economy is much higher after world war ii , but growth is growing much faster , and today ’ s ratio is lower than that of any other major industrial country ( roughly half of greece ’ s , and it is absurd ) .
over the last two years , washington has been obsessed with cutting the deficit and keeping the debt/gdp ratio “ sustainable ” path , despite global investors ’ scramble to push interest rates to historic lows .
significant progress has been ignored in the coming decade .
equally overlooked is the immediate challenge posed by low growth , weak investment , and unemployment .
it is time to refocus .
the us needs programs to boost growth , rather than deficit reduction .
the distinguished growth economist 多马尔 多马尔 ( one of my mit professors ) recommends that the problem of mitigating the debt burden is essentially the problem of national income growth .
we should heed his wisdom .
new progressive age in america ?
new york – in 1981 , us president ronald reagan came to the white house in a nutshell : “ the government is not a solution to the problem . ”
the government is the problem .
in the last three years , the obama administration ’ s recent inaugural address , which has now spoken out to support the most pressing challenges facing the government in the fight against america – and the world – will not seem to be taking the stage .
reagan ’ s dictum in 1981 was extraordinary .
it shows that the new us president is less interested in the government ’ s ability to address social problems than he did about the tax cuts ( mainly the rich ) .
more important , he started the “ revolution ” from the political right – a “ revolution ” for the poor , the environment , and technology – that , for three decades , has been “ revolution ” in favor of president george h. w. bush , clinton , george w. bush – and more or less in the first term .
the “ reagan revolution ” has four main components : tax cuts for the rich ; cut education , infrastructure , energy , climate change , and vocational training ; and the privatization of the defense budget ; and economic deregulation , including the privatization of military bases and prisons .
the revolution was called the “ free market ” revolution , because it is committed to reducing the role of government , in practice it is the beginning of the fight against the middle class and the poor .
these special interests include wall street , big oil , big insurers , and 军火商 .
they demand tax cuts ; they are required not to focus on environmental protection , which is met ; they demand and receive the right to hit trade unions ; they also have a strong government contract or even operation paramilitary activities .
for more than three decades , no one really challenged the consequences of ceding political power to the highest bidder .
meanwhile , the us has become increasingly divided from middle-class societies .
the ceo ’ s salary was 30 times higher than the average worker ’ s , now 230 times .
previously , the us was a world leader in the fight against environmental degradation , and then became the last great power to acknowledge the reality of climate change .
perhaps , perhaps , obama ’ s recent inaugural address marks the end of this destructive process and marked the beginning of a new era .
in fact , his inaugural address was devoted almost to the positive role of government in providing education , fighting climate change , rebuilding infrastructure , caring for the poor and the disabled , and generalized investment in the future .
this was the first inaugural address of the president since reagan made the us principle the first such thing .
if obama ’ s speech does become the start of the new progressive politics of the us , this would fit the path that great american historian arthur schlesinger sought to explore : the us presence in “ private interests ” and “ public goals ” and some 30 years .
at the end of the nineteenth century , the us moved to gilded age , creating a massive new industry in the era of a “ kleptocratic capitalism ” that produced massive inequality and corruption .
the subsequent progressive era was followed by a temporary return to plutocracy in the 1920 ’ s .
then came the great depression , franklin roosevelt ’ s new deal , and a new 30 years of progressive politics – in the 1930s .
the 1970s was the transition to the reagan era – 30 years of conservative politics held by powerful companies .
it is clear that it is time for public goals and governments to lead the recovery , to fight climate change , help the poor , promote sustainable technologies , and modernize the us infrastructure .
if the us were to achieve these major steps through a targeted public policy – which obama ’ s plan – the resulting innovative science , new technologies , and powerful demonstration effects will benefit all of the world ’ s countries .
it is certainly too early to declare that the us is entering a new era of progress .
vested interests remain powerful , especially in congress – and even in the white house .
these powerful groups and individuals offer billions of dollars in candidates for the recent campaign , and expect them to pay off .
moreover , 30 years of tax cuts have allowed the us government to lose its financial resources to implement key areas , such as the transition to low-carbon energy .
nonetheless , obama has wisely ordered the 战书 of the new government ’ s era of activism .
doing so is right , because many key challenges today – from our excessive behavior to saving the planet ; ensuring that technological progress benefits all members ; and the new infrastructure needed to build a national and global sustainable future – requires collective solutions .
for good governance , public policy is as important as implementing their vision .
the next task is to design smart , innovative , and cost-effective solutions to these challenges .
unfortunately , when bold innovative solutions are needed to meet vital human needs , the us tends to act as a bridge .
it is time for the us to begin a transition , and obama ’ s efforts to defend the vision of progress provide the us with the right direction .
america ’ s new trade hypocrisy
as the current round of “ development round ” enters the final stage , it is increasingly clear that the goal of promoting development can not be achieved , and the multilateral trading system will be hurt .
one clause has made it clear that the market ’ s market access would seem to be the least developed developed country .
a year ago , leaders in the world ’ s richest countries promised to ease the plight of the poorest countries .
in doha , in november 2001 , they pledged more valuable things to give the poor a chance to sell their products and earn their incomes out of poverty .
in a flurry of noisy 喧闹 , when the european union extended its “ all product ” programs ( eba ) , the advanced countries seem to have been able to achieve their promises at the time of the world ’ s poorest countries .
this openness is smaller than it seems .
the problem is that many developed countries found that the project ’ s complex rules of origin and the provision of supplier constraints mean that poor countries have little chance of exporting their products .
but the world ’ s richest country , the world ’ s richest country , has once again decided to demonstrate its hypocrisy .
developing countries have been disappointed by the results of open market projects in the eu , responding to the eu ’ s commitment to address at least some of the problems caused by rules of origin .
instead , the us intent on opening its markets to do nothing to do nothing , because , in the us , the us has chosen to select a different 3 % .
as a result , it was touted as a 项目 project : developing countries are permitted to export all products that they do not produce .
they can export 喷气机 engines , 超级计算机 , airplanes , and all computer chips , not their products , such as textiles , agricultural products , or processed foods .
consider bangladesh .
if we are using the most commonly used six-figure 六位数 code , bangladesh exported 409 tariff lines to the us in 2004 , with revenues of $ 2.3 billion .
but the top 12 tariff lines , which account for about 3 % of all tariff lines , account for the total value of us exports .
this means that the us can erect barriers to almost three-fifths of bangladeshi exports .
for cambodia , that figure is almost 62 % .
even if the us imposes a 3 % tariff code for imports from other parts of the world , the us would be able to exclude some 30 tariff lines from duty-free allowances .
for bangladesh , that means that 75 % of the tariff lines that account for the value of us exports could be excluded from duty-free treatment .
exclusion from duty-free treatment could spill over 100 % of cambodia ’ s exports , while the country exported only 277 tariff lines to the us in 2004 .
the formal justification for 3 % exclusion is that it affects “ sensitive products . ”
in other words , the us has preached the need to respond to the pain of rapid adjustment in the face of rapid adjustment of trade liberalization .
( indeed , the us has for 11 years to adjust to liberalization of textiles . )
but the real problem is even more serious , as 3 % of 排除法 policies are the specter of blatant divide-and-rule policies , which are being invited to compete with each other to ensure that america does not exclude them from 3 % .
the rule of law undermines the multilateral trading system .
indeed , even behind the 97 % proposal may be the more insidious purpose .
in the world trade organization ’ s 2003 summit in cancun , developing countries agreed to prevent the development of a trade deal that is just as unfair as the previous uruguay round .
the destruction of such unity is necessary .
the strategy for america ’ s bilateral trade agreement is precisely the goal of a few countries representing a fraction of global trade .
the 97 % rule could extend this split to the world trade organization itself .
the us has succeeded in making the poor poor .
preferential market access to african countries , according to the african 发胀 and the opportunity ( agoa ) and the recent initiative , is more likely to be a trade separation , and from some poor countries to other countries .
for example , bangladesh ’ s share in the us clothing market fell from 4.6 % in 2001 to 3.9 % in 2004 .
in the same period , agoa countries have risen from 1.6 % in us clothing to 2.6 % , and , when agoa countries started to take full advantage of duty-free market access , this share could be higher .
agoa includes a sunset clause , but , as it would be for less-developed countries in africa to keep duty-free access to africa ’ s less-developed countries , asia ’ s poor will continue to lose us market share .
the world trade organization is supposed to prevent such a trade deal , but so far it has failed to do so .
even if the us succeeds in dividing the developing world , it will inspire solidarity elsewhere .
the changing tide of growth
berkeley – the recent g-20 meeting in saint petersburg confirmed that the battle between growth and austerity is over – at least for now .
with europe ’ s long-term recession and emerging-economy slowdown , fears of budget deficits have given way to concern about growth .
in july , the imf revised its forecast for global growth this year .
japan and the united states have become bright spots for a bleak global outlook , but each has different reasons .
in japan , prime minister shinzo abe has launched a combination of aggressive monetary and fiscal expansion , and promised to reform the labor market , corporate governance , regulation , and trade .
with rapid and bold stimulus , japan ’ s economy is expected to grow by about 3 % this year – one of the highest in the advanced economies – and 80 % in the six months ending in may .
now abe has signaled his intention to pursue tough structural reforms .
as a result , his policies will make japan a 焕然一新 .
the situation in the us is that the recovery is continuing as growth headwinds diminish .
state and local governments ’ deficits are improving , and the housing market is strengthening , household deleveraging is deleveraging , and balance-sheet repair .
the perverse fiscal austerity at the federal level has dampened growth this year , but the private sector is more resilient than expected .
under current law , fiscal contraction will be loosened next year , and monetary policy will remain supportive , so most forecasters predict faster growth .
but the growth outlook may be undermined by a new political struggle that is deeply linked to the federal budget .
in view of the house republicans ’ tone , another round of fiscal austerity will be met .
earlier this year , the congressional budget office warned that the potential growth rate in the us was reduced by years of inadequate investment rates , population aging , and declining productivity growth .
every year that is lower than productive capacity implies a decline in future growth capacity , owing to the decline in investment , the loss of workers ’ skills and experience , and diminished risk-taking .
but , as some have often been overlooked , the future potential growth prospects of the us will be optimistic .
the latest mckinsey global institute has proposed five mutually reinforcing “ game-changing factors , ” which will dramatically affect gdp growth , productivity , and employment in the us , which are shale energy , big-data analytics , knowledge-intensive exports , infrastructure investment , and talent development .
the two – shale energy and big-data analytics – are building on ongoing technological breakthroughs , and technological breakthroughs depend largely on private-sector behavior , rather than on macroeconomic and structural policies , which are clearly leading the us .
over the last five years , annual growth in us shale oil and gas production has grown by more than 50 % .
owing to increased supply , us natural-gas prices have fallen by two-thirds since 2008 , and will remain significantly lower than the rest of the world ( at least ) in 2020 .
this price advantage strengthens the us as a manufacturing location , especially in energy-intensive activities .
the us has the world ’ s first recoverable shale-gas reserves and the second-largest recoverable shale-oil reserves .
the us and the us have a leading advantage in energy technologies , and have built a huge network of pipelines , refineries , and ports in the energy sector , which can be used directly to shale gas and oil ( though it also requires significant new investments ) .
growth in shale energy means more investment , output , and jobs in the energy sector itself .
lower gas prices will boost manufacturing production , especially in downstream industries such as petrochemicals and primary metals , which use natural gas to fuel fuel and inputs .
growth in energy and energy-intensive industries will fuel demand , output , and employment growth , including transportation , construction , and professional services .
overall , mckinsey estimates that growth in shale energy will increase annual gdp by 2-4 % in 2020 and create the most 1.7 million jobs .
it would also release co2 when shale gas is burned , despite the low coal prices of coal , and to reduce emissions to the mid-1990 ’ s .
not surprisingly , the president of the 环境 defense defense council recently remarked that “ fracking is the most complicated thing i have ever seen . ”
we need to go further on the environmental risks and benefits of shale energy , and develop new standards and regulations to control these risks .
big data and advanced analytics are a technology-driven change in us growth .
with more data , storage , and digital transmission , new data sets related to personal and business decisions are on the rise .
with greater computing power , the advent of cloud computing , and new software tools , more data sets can be analyzed quickly and are used by firms to reduce costs and boost productivity and services .
big data and advanced analytics also reduce health-care and government costs , increase their efficiency , and create value for consumers through greater product diversification and higher quality , better products , and better products for consumers .
mckinsey estimates that big-data analytics could increase the value of the retail and manufacturing sectors by by 2020 , or about 1 % of annual gdp in the retail and manufacturing sectors , while boosting productivity and cost savings for the health-care sector and the government .
potential savings in health-care costs would reduce government budgets and release resources to boost growth in other parts of the economy .
the factors that changed the potential growth rate of the us economy in the 1990s were new information and communications technologies .
according to mckinsey research , the benefits of shale energy and big data technologies will benefit the us economy as much as possible in the years ahead , and they are a new game changer .
america ’ s self-defeating future
i recently heard a 趣事 : america ’ s international financial economists and domestic macroeconomists are very different from the consequences of america ’ s current-account deficit , and even the opposite view .
international finance scholars believe that large deficits could lead to a financial crisis , followed by a long and painful recession .
rather than a crisis , macroeconomists believe that the dollar is about to depreciate rather than a crisis , or an opportunity to accelerate growth .
the domestic macroeconomists ’ views are roughly the same : at some point in the future , foreign central banks will continue to buy large quantities of dollar-denominated securities to maintain dollar value .
if they stop the large-scale dollar purchases , the value of the dollar falls – and it will fall far off .
but , according to this view , as the dollar ’ s value declines , us exports will become more attractive abroad , and employment in the us will grow , and labor will be redistributed to an export-led export sector .
the situation would be similar to that of abandoning a fixed exchange rate and allowing the pound to depreciate against the deutsche mark , or the us in the 1980 ’ s , when the dollar fell sharply against sterling , the deutschemark , and especially the yen .
international finance economists are far less sanguine about prospects .
they argue that a foreign central bank ’ s suspension of large-scale dollar purchases would not only lead to a fall in the dollar , but also the rise in long-term interest rates in the us , while the rise in long-term interest rates would bring consumption spending immediately and thus halt investment spending .
to be sure , international finance economists have also argued that the dollar would benefit from a weaker dollar , but demand lags for two years to delay growth in consumption and investment .
800 million people will have to shift from services and construction to exports of goods and goods , meaning that structural unemployment will inevitably happen .
moreover , the dollar ’ s depreciation may also lead to financial panics : a substantial increase in long-term interest rates in dollars would make large financial institutions with substantial short-term liabilities and long-term assets .
this disorder has caused financial crises and bankruptcies , as banks ’ local-currency assets and dollar liabilities have created in mexico and east asia in the 1990s , as well as the pressure and bankruptcy of argentina ’ s recent crisis .
international finance economists describe the picture , while domestically oriented macroeconomists think that more like a bad monetary policy .
why has the fed been allowed to increase long-term interest rates only because foreign central banks have stopped the dollar ’ s bond-buying program ?
can ’ t the fed step in , buy the long-term bonds issued by the us , thereby keeping long-term interest rates in favor of expanding employment ?
for this narrative , international finance economists believe that the fed does not have such a capacity .
as a result , because the dollar ’ s depreciation would raise import prices , negative effects on the supply of the economy will have a negative effect on the us federal reserve , which is selling rather than buying bonds .
the serious economist i respect in this debate stands starkly at the opposite of the debate .
i have no capacity to point out who is right , but i certainly know that i want one side ’ s views to be wrong .
america ’ s other 30 %
new haven – american consumers are now left with only a 影子 shadow .
in the second quarter of 2012 , personal consumption in the united states was only 1.5 % real per year – and hardly a disorderly performance .
unfortunately , this is a continuation of the weakness that has been evident since early 2008 .
compared to the 10 % growth trend that preceded the crisis , annual growth in real consumer demand has averaged only 0.7 % in the last 18 quarters .
the us has not yet had a long record of weakness .
the reasons are not secret .
consumers were 大注 in both bubbles and credit .
reckless monetary and regulatory policies have turned the sacred residence into an atm , allowing them to extract the dollar from bubbles and enjoy a life exceeding their economic capacity .
both bubbles have burst , with us households being forced to face the financial fallout of the bust , including underwater assets , record-high debt , and deep saving shortfalls .
at the same time , soaring unemployment and subpar income growth have also tightened the 绞索 of over-extended consumers .
as a result , american households have never been more conciliatory .
consumers spend meager income on debt and rebuilding savings , rather than spending .
the logic of logic – that is , not the fed ’ s reliance on unconventional monetary policy – would be offset .
america ’ s unprecedented retrenchment in us consumer attitudes has already raised projections of us economic growth .
consumption typically accounts for 70 % of gdp ( 71 % in the second quarter ) .
but it is almost 70 % growth , and the likelihood of strong growth in the foreseeable future is slim .
this led to significant pressure to propel economic recovery to the rest of the us economy .
indeed , the other 30 % are poor , especially given the headwinds generated by 70 % of consumption .
the other 30 % consists of four components : corporate capital spending , net exports ( exports minus imports ) , residential construction , and government procurement .
( it should also include the pace of inventory investment , but it is only a cyclical buffer between production and sales , not the source of final demand . )
given that a mere 0.7 % growth in real consumption in the last four and a half years , the us economy ’ s annualized recovery in the aftermath of the great depression was a miracle .
this is due largely to the remaining 30 % of consumption , especially with strong export and corporate capital spending .
instead , the government is moving in the opposite direction , because the state and local governments are implementing austerity , and federal purchases have reached its limit in the post-crisis deficit .
the housing sector has begun to recover in the last five quarters , but its current growth impact is negligible , owing to the previous conditions .
given the likelihood that consumption will remain weak in the coming years , the us economy ’ s growth agenda will need to focus on the remaining 30 % of its potential .
the prospects for these two sources of growth will not only affect the prospects for recovery , but also the determinants of a major shift in us growth patterns .
more than 70 % of the divide underscores the challenge : the us must confront a fundamental realignment of domestic demand , and to support more support for external demand .
capital spending and exports , which share roughly 24 % of gdp , constitute a key factor in this transformation .
the share of capital spending will exceed 10 % of gdp , well below the peak of nearly 13 % .
if us firms are to be equipped with advanced capacity , technology , and private infrastructure , they will have to take back market share at home and abroad , with capital spending exceeding its 2000 peak .
only then can export growth , impressive since 2009 , go further .
only then can the us stem the growth momentum of foreign production firms .
the other 30 % also highlight the deeper strategic issues facing the us – and also a deep competitive challenge .
the shift to external demand is not a red herring , with hard work , perseverance , and a long overdue competitive recovery .
here , too , the us has fallen behind .
according to the world economic forum ’ s global competitiveness index , the us slipped to fifth fifth from 2011 to 2012 , continuing a clear downward trend in 2005 .
the decline can be attributed to several factors , including deficiencies in primary and secondary education and macroeconomic management .
equally disturbing is the quality of infrastructure in the us ( 24 ) , technological effectiveness , and absorption rankings ( # 18 ) , and the breadth and depth of supply chains ( 14th ) .
improved improvement in the us ’ s competitiveness is essential .
but meeting these challenges will require the rest of the us – especially private capital spending – to remain strong .
as us consumption is likely to continue to slow , the same 30 % must continue to shoulder the burden of a sluggish economic recovery .
none of this can be achieved in a vacuum .
without a long-overdue recovery in us saving , the funds needed to restore competitiveness and sustain recovery simply can not be realized .
this may be the most serious challenge facing the us during a period of outsize government deficits and subpar household saving .
america ’ s other 87 deficits
new haven – the united states has a classic multilateral trade imbalance .
in addition to a large trade deficit with china , the us ran deficits with 87 other countries .
multilateral deficits can not be addressed by putting pressure on the bilateral partners .
but that is not the case with china ’ s hardline hardliners .
america ’ s massive trade deficit is a direct result of unprecedented domestic saving shortfalls .
the most meaningful measure of a country ’ s saving capacity is what economists call “ net national saving ” – the sum of personal , business , and government saving .
the measure measures “ net ” value to remove depreciation associated with aging or worn-out capacity .
the measure is available to measure the volume of savings that are available to grow in a country ’ s capital stock , thereby sustaining economic growth .
in the us , net savings have disappeared .
none of the world ’ s major economies has experienced such saving shortfalls in modern history .
but the us found a way to finesse this problem .
using the “ exorbitant privilege ” of the world ’ s reserve currency , the so-called “ exorbitant privilege ” of the world ’ s reserve currency , the us could borrow abroad to borrow abroad , running a large balance-of-payments deficit ( or current-account ) deficits to attract foreign capital .
the last balance in the us current-account balance was in 1991 , when the current account hit a record of $ 8010 billion ( 6 % of gdp ) in 2006 .
the deficit has declined in the last few years , but most of the improvement may have been the temporary effect of an unusually difficult business cycle .
america ’ s multilateral trade deficit has long accounted for a large share of the us balance-of-payments gap .
since 2000 , it has accounted for 96 % of cumulative current-account deficits .
this is the absurdity of china ’ s blame .
unless there is a problem at the root of the problem – namely , chronic saving shortfalls – it is ludicrous to believe that a bilateral solution can be addressed with a bilateral solution .
but that is precisely what us officials and many prominent economists believe the us needs .
the trade deficit has been widely viewed as a serious source of pressure for us jobs and real wages , which has been particularly focused on the us-china trade imbalance .
yes , china is the most prominent component of america ’ s multilateral trade deficit , accounting for 42 % of the 2010 trade gap .
proactive outsourcing and supply-chain management decisions by us mncs are one important reason why china ’ s share of the share has soared .
but that did not stop officials in washington , dc .
the long-standing charges of currency manipulation have provided us politicians – both republicans and democrats – with the explicit evidence that they should impose high tariffs on chinese exports to the us .
