that is the view behind the us senate ’ s recent overwhelming passage of the “ currency bill ” directed at china .
the problem with the us may be a stopgap scapegoat , but it is a bad game driven by bad calculation .
in an age of us government budget deficits and chronic shortfalls in personal saving , the us is bound to be in the midst of a saving-short period of saving and a large multilateral trade deficit .
cutting off trade with china would not only resolve the saving shortfall , but would also be self-defeating .
the chinese component of america ’ s multilateral trade deficit could simply transfer only another country , costing the country well above the cost of production .
the move would be a tax hike on beleaguered american families , not a solution that american politicians have promised .
this is not to ignore the us-china trade issues that must be addressed .
market access should be the top priority – especially for the us economy , which is weak and badly needed for exports .
china is now america ’ s third-largest and fastest-growing export market , so the us should work to expand china ’ s opportunities , especially at a time when china ’ s economy is increasingly oriented toward domestic demand .
china should be viewed as an opportunity , not a threat .
at the same time , the us government should clarify the american public ’ s ability to manipulate the exchange rate as unfair trade practices .
indeed , the renminbi has appreciated by 30 % against the dollar since 2005 .
from multilateral digital – a more meaningful indicator , because it measures the value of a country ’ s currency relative to all of its trading partners – the renminbi ’ s exchange rate , which has been “ real ” , is 8 % higher than in the past 12 years .
yes , china continues to stockpile vast foreign-exchange reserves .
blaming china reflects the deterioration of americans mentality .
this leaves americans ’ attention away from those who really should have made the biggest savings shortfall in history permanent .
the us has been seduced by the political economy of false prosperity .
it enabled americans to squander their lives for almost two decades .
now the game is over .
in any country , the ultimate test of its national character is whether or not a major challenge is to be developed .
and , in the wake of the twentieth century , others are the greatest tragedy .
ultimately , america ’ s 88 deficits are not a day .
the american consumer is not okay
new haven – 老手 are working hard to justify america ’ s subpar economic recovery .
all eyes are on family .
because the unemployment rate falls , the increase in household value , and the high stock market in which innovation is high , forecasters , market participants , and policymakers now agree on a new consensus that the us is finally returning .
they are 别信 .
for starters , the fact is that , in the 21 quarters since the beginning of 2008 , real ( inflation-adjusted ) personal consumption has grown at an average annual rate of just 0.9 % .
this is the longest period since the end of world war ii , which is well below the annual rate of 4 % real consumption growth in the pre-crisis pre-crisis period of 2007 .
given that household consumption accounts for about 70 % of the us economy , the gap between pre-crisis trends and the post-crisis trend is enough to reduce the post-crisis trend toward real gdp growth .
no wonder the us unemployment rate is unacceptably high .
in order to understand the unique features of the shortfall in consumer demand , trends in the last 21 quarters are divided into two different sets of 次级 .
the first is the 2.2 % annualized decline in annualized growth in the second quarter of 2008 from the first quarter of 2008 to the second quarter of 2009 .
as a result of the crisis , the peak was a 4.5 % annualized decline since 2008 .
then , after the six quarters of decline , the 15 quarters from 2009 to early 2013 , annualized consumption growth averaged just 2 % – a growth that would have been extremely anemic when based on past consumer-spending cycles .
the key point is that only the consumer recovery will be ignored .
in recent speeches with the current and former central bankers ’ discussions , i was focused on the 0.9% growth trend of the last 21 quarters , without focusing on the pace of recovery in the post-crisis period .
it is , they point out , at least a recovery , and a signal to health is that the fed ’ s bold unconventional approach is largely unconventional .
this brings us to the second reason against optimism : analytics .
one of the first concepts of economics in the basic macro curriculum is the “ repressed ” consumer demand .
discretionary consumption is typically delayed in recession , especially for durable durable goods such as automobiles , furniture , and appliances .
when the recession ends and recovery began , the “ inventory adjustment ” response occurs , with households compensating for previous alternatives and upgrading old durable goods .
for most of the post-war period , the pent-up consumer demand released after the crisis was a powerful blow to economic recovery .
by contrast , the release of the current cycle of pent-up demand brought about 3 % annualized growth ( in the five quarters from early 2010 to early 2011 ) .
moreover , the strongest quarterly growth was 4.1 % in the fourth quarter of 2010 .
this is a depressing outcome .
the worst consumer recession in modern history – a record of declining consumer spending in 2008-2009 – should trigger a full explosion of pent-up demand .
but nothing happened .
by contrast , the release of pent-up consumer demand is roughly half that of previous business cycles .
the third is the diagnosis : us consumer demand is so anemic that growth in the post-crisis period is due to deep balance-sheet recessions .
we learn from the hindsight that the 12 years of consumer spending that america experienced before the crisis was built on fragile assets and credit bubbles .
when these bubbles burst , consumers were left to consumers with too much debt and too little savings .
the post-bubble aversion to spending , together with the related focus on balance-sheet repair , reflects the powerful “ debt rejection ” syndrome economist richard koo .
the framework of japan ’ s first lost decade ( in the 1990 ’ s ) , japan ’ s first lost decade in the first half of the world ( in the 1990 ’ s ) , is also a part of the 危机 us consumer , which is still burdened by excessive debt burdens , mortgages , and massive personal savings .
the fed implemented unconventional monetary easing , trying to create a shortcut on household balance sheets .
here , the wealth effects of rising house prices and surging stock markets have been revealed .
but is this new wealth effect really what we want ?
yes , the stock market has now reached a record record – but it is now measured in dollars .
in real terms , the s & p 500 is still 20 % below its january 2000 peak .
likewise , while the 指数 us house price index was growing 10.2 % year on year in march 2013 , it is still 28 % below its 2006 peak .
wealth creation has worked , but it will not be able to address previous wealth destruction .
unfortunately , most us households ’ balance sheets are far from recovering .
moreover , while the us unemployment rate has declined , most of this reflects a declining labor-force participation rate , which has more than 6.5 million americans since 2006 .
at the same time , while consumer confidence is rebounding , it is far lower than it was before the crisis .
in short , the american consumer ’ s nightmare is far from over .
beyond market buoyancy , recovery has only just begun .

拜拜 , the middle east ?
paris – the idea that a strategy is beginning to be popular in the united states is becoming an energy independent , paving the way for its strategic “ pivot ” from the middle east to asia .
the us , eager for energy , has long depended on global markets to meet domestic demand .
in 2005 , the us consumed 60 % of the energy consumed by imports .
since then , however , the share of imports has fallen , and the future will continue to be sustained .
by 2020 , the us will be self-sufficient in energy self-sufficiency and became an oil exporter by 2030 .
this situation will give the us three advantages .
this would give us economic competitiveness , especially relative to europe , because the cost of extracting shale gas is lower .
this will also reduce the risk of america ’ s exposure to an increasingly unstable arab world .
finally , it will increase the relative vulnerability of china ’ s major strategic rival , china , which is increasingly dependent on the middle east ’ s energy supply .
these factors obviously deserve serious consideration , but their impact on us foreign policy in the middle east should not be ruled out prematurely .
in any case , though energy dependence is the main determinant of us policy in the region , it is not the only ingredient .
israel ’ s security and desire to contain iran are equally important .
and , given that the role of the middle east in global geopolitics will grow in the coming decades , it is hard to imagine that a superpower , like the us , will be able to do so .
over the next 15 years , opec countries will account for half of global oil production , and 42 % today .
moreover , a large source of growth is likely to come from iraq .
in the coming decade , could iraq be the world ’ s second-largest oil exporter , generating more than $ 200 billion per year in revenue , while a state that is increasingly dominated by an increasingly pro-israel shia regime ?
would the us have allowed its third regional allies – saudi arabia , turkey , and israel to confront a strategic threat from the region ?
as long as the iranian nuclear crisis is not resolved , the syrian crisis will continue to widen the middle east ’ s sunni-shia divide ( reflected in increasingly tense tensions in turkey and iran ) .
despite us president barack obama ’ s visit to asia in november – an effort to highlight america ’ s “ pivot ” to the us – he had to devote considerable time and effort to mediating the conflict between israel and hamas in gaza .
indeed , if oil is really america ’ s only important interests in the middle east , its special relationship with israel can not be overestimated , because it is bad for the us and the arab oil-exporting countries .
even if its dependence on middle east energy has peaked , the us will not change its policies to support israel .
it is also important to remember that , in 1973 , the opec oil embargo in the united states was much more expensive than europe , even though the us was the principal target of the embargo – israel ’ s support for israel in october ’ s war against egypt and syria .
ultimately , after egypt became america ’ s allies and a rapprochement with israel , the us has increased its position in the region .
china ’ s increasing interest in the middle east has also reduced the likelihood of american withdrawal .
the us will still consider ensuring security in asia ’ s allies , which , like china , increasingly relies on middle east oil exports .
nonetheless , while the us is unlikely to withdraw from the middle east , america ’ s exposure to the region will undoubtedly decline ; as this trend , the us is likely to play an increasingly cynical role in the middle east .
its interference in the israeli-palestinian conflict could be limited to the status quo , and it is no longer seeking a comprehensive settlement .
this stance – exemplified by the united states ’ opposition to the status of the palestinian observer in the united states at the united nations general assembly – is to acknowledge that abandoning the establishment of two countries in the middle east is just as emphatic .
this clearly satisfies israeli prime minister binyamin netanyahu and the palestinian fringe seeking to weaken the palestinian authority .
but it is also clear that obama is more a good man than a visionary .

america ’ s strategy vacuum
new haven – it is clear that policymakers in the united states federal reserve are beginning to start some hesitation with wise quantitative easing ( qe ) .
this is a reasonable hesitation .
this untested policy experiment failed not only to achieve qualified economic recovery , but also to another crisis .
at the united states federal open market committee ( fomc ) , which held its discontent on january 16-17 , “ many participants have expressed concerns about the potential costs and risks of further purchases of assets . ”
the participants worry about the possibility of an exit from quantitative easing , and fear that the fed ’ s portfolio of securities will rapidly increase capital losses ( the fed ’ s current portfolio of jgbs , and will reach $ 4 trillion by the end of the year ) .
regardless of how serious it is , they ignore the biggest weakness of the fed ’ s unprecedented strategy : emphasizing short-term tactics more than long-term strategies .
the fed , appalled by the crisis of 2007-2008 , has repeatedly added to the 注于 strategy , following two rounds of quantitative easing , following two rounds of open-ended quantitative easing , and thus deepening a misdiagnosis of the problem .
the federal open market committee found a false sense of security in the first round of quantitative easing ( when massive injections of liquidity were reached at the height of a crisis in fear of a crisis ) , mistakenly believing that the right model for follow-up action has been found .
this approach is likely to work if the us economy is to suffer from a cyclical malady of a short shortfall of aggregate demand .
in these circumstances , countercyclical policies like john maynard keynes , fiscal and monetary , and monetary policies can eventually compensate for insufficient demand and start the economy again .
but it is not just a temporary cyclical malady , but also a chronic malady : a protracted balance-sheet recession that continues to capture us households , which account for roughly 70 % of us gdp .
two bubbles in housing and credit that us households borrowed freely were long gone .
but the resulting impact did not end : in 2012 , the household debt burden still accounts for 113 % of personal disposable income ( which has been 75 % since the twentieth century ) , compared to just 3.9 % last year ( compared to 7.9 % in 1999 ) .
it is not hard to imagine that the us consumer , which focuses on balance-sheet repair , has not taken a 吞下 page .
instead , they have cut spending .
inflation-adjusted personal-consumption spending has grown by only 0.8 % in five years , the most severe and persistent slowdown in consumer demand since world war ii .
the brute force of massive monetary stimulus would do nothing to address the cyclical remedies .
on the contrary , in the process of healing monetary policy , the restoration of balance-sheet repair should take sufficient attention .
there should be a reduction in “ underwater ” mortgages ( i.e. , the loans that exceed the current market value of households ) and phasing out the foreclosure overhang of more than 15 million households .
what else can the rest of the us homeowners have to escape from the housing market ?
other measures also include strengthening savings incentives , and the financial safety of us households , which suffered huge losses in the great depression , were financial security .
the relevant measures should also include broadening individual retirement accounts and 401k pension plans , creating low-income families ( most of which are not retiring ) , and ending the financial repression of the fed ’ s zero-interest-rate policy .
to be sure , such policies are controversial .
debt relief brings us to the thorny ethical concerns of reckless and irresponsible behavior .
but addressing the problem of underwater mortgages could translate underwater mortgages into so-called “ 追索 debt , ” leaving unpaid liabilities to the threat of a debtor ’ s all assets , thereby giving the us a new sense of responsibility to deleverage .
timing is equally important when it comes to encouraging savings .
to avoid a surge in aggregate demand could lead to insufficient aggregate demand in 3-5 years .
the main advantage of the proposed proposal is to focus more on tactics than tactical , so it is better to address the balance-sheet problems that are actually afflicting the economy .
with a typical laissez-faire free-for-all , the us has always turned strategic issues to the invisible hand of the market .
over time , it is often misguided and often misguided for governments to deal with abrupt problems .
as a result , the fed seems more concerned about cleaning up , rather than avoiding a new crisis .
the same is true of america ’ s fiscal policy , which is increasingly pressing in the final deadline : fiscal expenditure on january 1 , spending on spending on march 1 , the continued march 27 budget , and a new debt ceiling on may 18 .
the 债券市场 bond market , which has been tested as the ultimate test of this shortsighted practice , is likely to have the next bubble .
the dangers of america ’ s strategy vacuum and short-termism have long been present .
harvard business school professor michael porter famously put this question in an article in a harvard business review .
he has focused on the short-term “ operational effectiveness ” of business decisions and misaligned incentives , and the worrisome dichotomy between the “ operational efficiency ” ( costs , outsourcing , and restructuring ) and the long-term vision of a successful strategy .
although corporate managers , porter ’ s remarks have a key impact on current us policy debates .
a successful long-term strategy can not be seen as a successful long-term strategy .
the internal debate within the federal open market committee implies that , for too long , central banks have finally begun to recognize the consequences of a policy that is misguided to the wrong problem .
there are similar controversies in fiscal policy .
can america finally face up to its strategic vacuum ?
america ’ s political class rivalry
new york – the united states is now in a fight against itself .
this month , president barack obama agreed to further tax cuts between the house of representatives and the house of representatives , which was supposed to be the beginning of a new bipartisan consensus , but in my view that it was a battle around the core values of american politics .

america ’ s annual budget deficit is $ 1 trillion , and that will worsen as the new tax deal is implemented .
but the problem is that corruption in the us is absent from corruption .

the democrats are politically motivated , including health care , education , training , and infrastructure .
but the democrats , like the republicans , are keen to provide tax cuts for their campaign sponsors – rich americans – for tax cuts .
the result is a dangerously dangerous mixture .

surprisingly , the richest 1 % of us households have more capital than the bottom 90 % of households .
the annual income of the richest 1.2 million households is higher than the poorest 24 million households .
the democrats ’ real intentions are to ensure that these income and wealth advantages persist .
so , of course , they also fear that everyone else will demand that the budget deficit be stopped by raising taxes on the rich .
after all , when the rest of the us is suffering , people living in rich people are getting better .

but that is where most republicans are reluctant to touch .
the way they cut spending is not to end the long-term war in afghanistan , but to eliminate unnecessary weapons , but reduce education , health , and other benefits for the poor and working-class sectors .
but i don ’ t think they will succeed .
most americans now agree that the republican language should be cut by cutting public spending , rather than raising taxes .
but when the draft budget is finally introduced , there will be growing resistance .
i predict that the old poor and working-class communities have started to fight for social justice .
that may take some time .

these large forces – many of which operate covertly under us law – are relentlessly maintaining the interests of those at the top of the distribution of the pyramid .
but what is certain is that both parties are implicated .

this money will certainly not come from the poor .

does the us really need to cut health-care security and retirement income ? in the us , it is reasonable to cut spending on education by cutting education spending ?

america ’ s problem goes beyond wall street
cambridge – with less than two months of america ’ s presidential election , attention is focused on the challenges that the us economy faces in the next president .
we are in the midst of a financial crisis that was caused by serious mispricing and the collapse of the housing bubble that the us generates during the last five years .
the initial subprime problem has now spread to the entire real-estate and other asset classes .
the housing problem has deepened the financial crisis , which is reducing the supply of credit needed to sustain economic activity .
indeed , the financial crisis has deteriorated in recent weeks , reflected in the fed ’ s takeover of a 半官方 mortgage company fannie mae and freddie mac that could cost the us billions of dollars – and the sale of lehman brothers ’ bankruptcy and merrill lynch securities .
ultimately , these financial failures reflect a downward spiral of housing prices and a growing share of households with negative assets ( that is , the stock market ’ s market capitalization ) .
the stakes are high because mortgages in the us are often “ no recourse ” loans .
if homeowners default , creditors can take on property , but they can not make up for other assets or incomes .
we can not be sure how much lower house prices will fall .
experts say that a 15 % decline will have to be returned to the bubble ’ s previous price path .
but even if home prices go back to that point , no one can stop it .
the widening gap between mortgage debt and house prices will continue to rise .
many homeowners who have the ability to repay mortgage payments would opt to default , and to rental their homes , until home prices continue to fall again .
as homeowners with negative equity defaults , the foreclosures of the foreclosures exacerbate the supply of prices further .
lower house prices lead to more negative assets , resulting in more defaults and foreclosures .
it is not clear what kind of power will prevent this self-reinforcing process .
falling house prices are critical to the financial crisis and economic prospects , because securities and other 衍生 securities based on mortgage-backed securities are a leading asset for financial institutions .
before home prices stabilize , markets do not have any confidence in the value of these securities .
and that means that financial institutions that hold these assets can not be confident about the ability and solvency of their counterparties ’ assets , or even their value for capital .
without such confidence , credit will not flow , and economic activity is depressed .
moreover , because financial institutions ’ assets are borrowed mainly , credit shortages exacerbate demand for their debt reduction .
because financing is difficult and costly , they reduce debt reduction by lending .
but america ’ s macroeconomic weakness extends far beyond the contraction of credit supply , which has reduced household wealth to reduce consumption spending .
declining employment has reduced wages .
high food and energy prices depress real incomes further .
the decline in the rest of the world and regional economic dynamism is also reducing demand for us exports .
i personally believe that the fed is right to respond to the federal funds rate and created a new set of credit initiatives .
low interest rates make the dollar more competitive , but , given the failure of real estate and the functioning of credit markets , monetary policy seems to have lost traction .
the us congress and the bush administration implemented a $ 100 billion tax cut to stimulate consumer spending .
those of us who support this policy understand that history and economic theory prove to be useless , but we believe that this time may be different .
the argument against our view is that “ a victory for experience is a triumph for experience . ”
ultimately , our hopes were frustrated .
official national income in the second quarter has been released , indicating that tax rebates have little effect on stimulating consumption .
80 % of all 退税款 are deposited into banks or their debts .
few have been added to existing spending .
so it is the us : in a financial crisis , the economy is headed for recession , with monetary policy having moved to the maximum , and fiscal transfers are weak .
at least this is an unenviable situation for any incoming president .
阿林顿 – the united states and myanmar have resumed diplomatic relations at a breakneck pace .
a year ago , both countries were not ambassadors .
in may , president thein sein became the first myanmar leader to visit the white house for almost a half-century .
but is the obama administration too quick to accept that last year ’ s most brutal regimes in the world ?
or , in turn , is decisive us support essential to myanmar ’ s fledgling reform process ?
in 1948 , myanmar was independent of the country , which had been ruled by secretive military blocs since 1962 .
in 2010 , myanmar ’ s military junta held a blatantly rigged election that the opposition refused to participate .
but , in 2011 , thein sein , who served as prime minister under the junta ’ s identity , began to take a great step forward as president before he took office .
unlike previous attempts to reform the previous rulers , sein ’ s actions are concrete and meaningful .
one important change is the release of hundreds of political prisoners , including aung san suu kyi , the most famous opponent of the system , who was almost 15 years since house arrest .
moreover , sein held talks with suu kyi , a nobel peace prize laureate and leader of the national league of democracy ( nld ) , to negotiate a transition to civilian rule .
the subsequent elections strengthened hope for myanmar ’ s democratic future .
in 1990 , the nld won 80 % of the seats in parliament , but the junta promptly announced that the results were ineffective and arrested suu kyi .
in 2012 , the nld won 43 of the 44 seats that it fought , while the junta accepted suu kyi as a legitimate leader in the reform movement .
moreover , sein has engaged with the 克伦 , kachin , and other ethnic minorities – groups that have suffered decades of official persecution and abuse .
transforming myanmar ’ s economy to international trade has transformed the country ’ s economic capital , rangoon , which is now at least opening up from six countries ’ capital secrets , with the streets now running with imported cars .
in some areas , however , reform has been slow .
indeed , in terms of human rights and minority protection , myanmar may even be regressing .
the emancipation process exposed myanmar ’ s long-standing religious divisions , leading to a series of sectarian violence against muslim minorities .
from the coastal coast to the island of 密铁拉 and 贡 , buddhists incited violence against muslims ( and sometimes , in turn ) , while local officials often drag on religious bloodletting .
when obama met in washington with sein , he condemned the violence against myanmar ’ s muslims and displaced many of them .
on the same day , the state department issued its annual report on religious freedom , and myanmar ranked among the world ’ s eight most repressive countries on religious intervention .
not always .
although myanmar is a buddhist country , dozens of religious and ethnic communities have long lived coexist .
in the heart of yangon , 金顶 金顶 , the 宝塔 金顶 and the construction of the bengali mosque , is gaining ground .
in order to consolidate the peace and stability needed to consolidate myanmar ’ s democratic transition , both sein and aung san suu kyi need to take the lead , making it all the more representative of all burma ’ s citizens .
muslims need to be assured of their security and full civil rights .
the obama administration has made significant political capital bets , betting on myanmar ’ s promise .
and , indeed , the pace of change in myanmar over the last two years has been a remarkable one .
how it handles these ( and not yet ) problems will determine whether the us supports the decision in myanmar .
the renminbi realist
new york – for seven years , the united states has held up the renminbi ’ s exchange rate , and thus will divert attention from other important issues of the relationship .
the upcoming strategic and economic dialogue between the us and china will be an opportunity to test ( and rethink ) america ’ s strategic priorities .
since 2005 , the us congress has repeatedly distanced itself from lawmakers , trying to save hard-pressed american workers from the threat of a presumed cheap renminbi .
bipartisan support for this approach began with the senator charles schumer , the liberal democratic democratic party ( liberal democratic party ) and lindsey graham , the first renminbi bill .
the case for legislative action is surprisingly simple : since 2005 , the us average merchandise trade deficit has reached 4.4 % of gdp , with china accounting for 35 % , and is believed to be the result of its manipulation of the renminbi ’ s exchange rate .
a large number of politicians , businessmen , and economists , insisting on the renminbi ’ s appreciation , should be imposing sanctions on china .
the american public resonates with it .
polls in 2011 , 61 % of americans believed that china was a serious economic threat .
thus , the currency debate looms as a major topic for the upcoming presidential election .
“ enough is enough . ”
the nine times will be obama ’ s republican candidate , mitt romney , who would soon announce china ’ s manipulation of the renminbi as illegal .
but , while this logic is appealing , it is wrong .
first , the us trade deficit is multilateral : the us ran deficits with 88 countries in 2010 .
multilateral imbalances – especially a multilateral imbalance that goes back to saving shortfalls – can not be addressed by pressuring bilateral exchange rates .
in fact , america ’ s main threat is domestic .
blaming china will merely delay the heavy lifting of the domestic burden – namely , by cutting budget deficits and encouraging households to save income rather than relying on asset bubbles .
second , since 2005 , the renminbi has appreciated by % % against the dollar , much more than the 27.5 % required by the original schumer-graham bill .
the chinese learned the lessons of japan – particularly japan ’ s disastrous contribution to the catastrophic effects of the yen ’ s sharp appreciation in the 1985 plaza accord – and opted for a gradual appreciation .
china ’ s recent efforts to internationalize the renminbi , open the capital account , and increase monetary transactions , undoubtedly indicate that its ultimate goal is market-based , fully convertible renminbi .
third , china ’ s external imbalances have been greatly improved .
the imf estimates that china ’ s current-account surplus as a share of gdp will shrink to 2.3 % in 2012 , at 10.1 % in 2007 .
us officials have long believed that china ’ s savings glut is an important reason for global instability .
but they need to do the same thing : america ’ s current-account deficit is expected to reach $ 510 billion this year , and is 2.8 times higher than china ’ s surplus .
finally , china has shifted from the world ’ s factory to its assembly line .
research shows that , in china ’ s exports to the us , only 20-30 % of chinese exports reflect added value in china .
roughly 60 % of china ’ s exports are just the 出货 of “ foreign investment companies , ” essentially china ’ s subsidies to global multinationals .
apple is a case in point .
china should not be allowed to face america ’ s first economic threat , and trade relations with china should be viewed as an opportunity .
the biggest component of us aggregate demand – consumers – is now very far off .
households are busy repairing severely damaged balance sheets , with an average annual growth rate of just 0.5 % over the last four years .
consumer deleveraging will likely continue for years to come , making the us desperate for new sources of growth .
exports are one of the most powerful candidates for growth .
china is now america ’ s third-largest and fastest-growing export market .
there is no doubt that china has the potential to fill the void left by us consumers .
the key to seizing this opportunity is the chinese market – and , in particular , by china ’ s upcoming support for consumer-led rebalancing .
historically , china has developed an open development model , which imports 28 % of gdp since 2002 , nearly three times as high as it was in the 1960 ’ s .
so , given the increment to domestic demand , china ’ s penchant for external resources is much stronger .
with the rise of chinese consumers , a wide range of us goods – from a new generation of information technology and biotechnology to auto components and aircraft – will be secured .
the same is true for services .
china ’ s service sector accounts for only 43 % of total gdp , relatively small .
america ’ s global business services are expanding indefinitely in china ’ s expanding prospects , particularly in the labor-intensive logistics sector – wholesale and retail trade , transport , and logistics – and 处理 market segments in financial , health-care , and data storage .
china needs to focus on the us-china trade agenda , focusing on expanding market access in the various areas – against china ’ s policy and government procurement priorities and indigenous innovation .
some progress has already been made , but it is not enough – for example , for china to join the world trade organization ’ s government procurement agreement .
at the same time , the us must rethink the antiquated cold war that limits chinese purchases of technology-intensive goods .
for a growth-starved us , the chances of entering the market extend far beyond the currency threat .
the 中国 chinese consumer is about to wake up .
this fits with one of america ’ s greatest strengths – its zeal to enter new markets .
it is a shame if the us squandered this rare opportunity in the upcoming strategic and economic dialogue .
america ’ s retreat from asia
on august 16 , president george w. bush announced that the us intends to withdraw its troops from asia , though the withdrawal of troops would not necessarily undermine the stability of the asia-pacific region , particularly north korea , but a close consultation between the us and its allies .
but until now , the us has done a bad job .
if the inevitable withdrawal is to succeed now , it is seriously considering the need for south korea and japan .
on the contrary , unilateral withdrawal of troops unilaterally would undermine the fundamental mission of the us military : to ensure that deterrence , stability , and nuclear non-proliferation in north korea and the region are deterrence .
the withdrawal plan raises many concerns .
many japanese fear that japan will become america ’ s stronghold in asia , which may well exceed the scope of the bilateral security agreement in the united states .
any increase in china ’ s military cooperation would cause alarm .
in june , the bush administration announced that it would withdraw from 37 million troops in south korea until 2005 , including the second 装甲旅 装甲旅 , including second 步兵师 , which has already been established to 派驻 iraq .
this change is part of the so-called `` us military buildup , '' which aims to bring the military to a more urgently needed area in the region .
but the unilateral nature of the announcement and the withdrawal of the military ’ s immediate agenda raised panic in south korea , and japan may , as is likely , to fear that the withdrawal will bring us troops to a serious crisis .
south korea ’ s genuine fear of a military withdrawal would make north korea a assertiveness , thereby weakening the effectiveness of the us military , while refusing to abandon its nuclear ambitions .
indeed , we should not forget that north korea retains 1.1 million troops .
moreover , the bush administration ’ s announcement of the withdrawal plan weakens the trust of the us-south korea alliance .
america ’ s unilateral announcement has raised domestic rumors that the withdrawal must be linked to a growing anti-american tide in south korea , particularly south korea ’ s reluctance and delay the deployment of 3,500 homegrown soldiers to iraq .
the bush administration tried to counter the rumor that withdrawal will not weaken the us military ’ s capacity to contain it , because the us will retain its dominant presence in the region .
moreover , the us plans to introduce some $ 11 billion in high-tech equipment in five years to strengthen south korea ’ s own forces .
militarily , this argument makes sense .
but , from a political and psychological perspective , this withdrawal , not to mention specific agendas and arrangements , raises questions about the future of the us-south korea security alliance , which appears to have a few problems , without common objectives , and no one .
and the bush administration emphasized : `` the us views the country as a strong and stable alliance , and we will strive to maintain south korea ’ s security and maintain alliances with seoul .
if the washington commitment is serious , it should be transformed into a long-term , comprehensive alliance that can survive the immediate crisis - even after reunification – with the bush administration ’ s chief of government , with the head of the south korean government .
to reduce concerns , restoring trust , the us and south korea need to reaffirm the mutual interests of both countries : the goal of pursuing containment , non-proliferation , stability , and democracy in asia and the korean peninsula .
once they are determined to continue the alliance for these purposes , officials risk establishing guidelines for concrete security cooperation .
whether us troops withdraw south korea , or from the demilitarized zone to the south of seoul , they must follow through on principles .
to achieve this , the us must put south korea on board as its partner , with the right to speak on its own security interests .
south korea is a 51 years of us partners , and east asia ’ s third largest economic power , the region ’ s third largest economy , has the right to say it fully .
despite anti-american sentiment in some south koreans , most people want us troops to remain in south korea .
on the korean peninsula , the interests of china , japan , russia , and the us are directly linked to peace and denuclearization , one of the world ’ s most important security goals .
as for this reason , the us and south korea must revisit the future .
america ’ s schizophrenic economy
the news that the us economy 渐行 in early march was once again depicted as a scenario that only a lunatic patient can draw .
real investment ( adjusted for the decline in the prices of high-tech and 信息 capital goods ) continues to grow sharply .
production and sales are consistent with the belief that real gdp growth is consistent with the putative 4 % annual gdp growth rate .
nonetheless , employment remains depressed : america ’ s net job creation remains stagnant .
this does not mean that employment in the us can not grow .
over the past year , the us employs roughly 300,000 people – an annual growth rate of 1.7 % – compared to the us .
more than 250,000 people are employed in business and professional services – an annual growth rate of 1.6 % .
this is easy to say .
total nominal spending in the us grows at 5.5 % annually , and annual inflation is 1.5 % .
overall productivity growth is 3.5 % per year .
so there is a simple equation : 5.5 % -1.5 % - 0.5 % .
employment growth is only about 0.5 % , because , despite strong growth in labor productivity , it needs to increase the employment rate .
it is clear from the growth of us labor productivity .
the small part of its growth was a simple acceleration : in the current economic situation , america ’ s jobless population is approaching the historic highs of world war ii .
the larger part of the increase in labor productivity stems from the revolution in computers and communications technology – making it much more effective for high-tech capital to be effective .
the drive for `` new economic '' growth is also difficult to fathom .
what is surprising is that new wealth does not go to dot shareholders , but to buyers and users who flow to high-tech capital , and the consumers they serve .
why is this surprising ?
at the end of the nineteenth century , the huge investment and technological advances received by the us railway system seemed to benefit everyone except the railway company ’ s shareholders and creditors .
still , some of the growth in us labor productivity stems from the fact that high-tech capital has enabled us companies to invest heavily in 改造 and networked processes to enable them to adapt to computerized and networked demands .
for the us , the annual growth rate of labor productivity growth , rather than in 1995 , is amazing .
this means that only one country has added $ 250 billion in annual value added to world income .
this is equivalent to increasing the productivity of the world equivalent to one-quarter of india ’ s .
yet the continued rise in us labor productivity has brought a huge political dimension to president george w. bush .
domestic demand for domestic demand , which has been 凯歌 in the last few decades , has suddenly become a serious problem , and the resulting slack in labor markets has brought bush to blame ( to some extent ) .
but it is an excellent opportunity for everyone to be unemployed for all of those who are unemployed with the lack of domestic demand .
as long as us policymakers resist the temptation , not from political interests to pursue `` safeguard output and employment , '' the policies that would undermine the economy ’ s growth and employment would ultimately lead to strong growth and strong growth in real profits .
as an economy leading the world , the us is notoriously difficult to ensure economic growth , because it must create – and not just – new technologies , better forms of capital , and more productive business organizations .
if the us economy is to develop at current rates , it is good news for other advanced economies , particularly in the world , where the world is more able to participate in the global division of labor in the united states , owing to the strong advances in computers and communications technology .
as a result , america ’ s economic paradox has shown that the world has entered an era of extraordinary opportunity - premise that we need to take the full and patient grasp of them .
america ’ s 焦土
the us economy shows signs of a perilous situation – from large fiscal and current-account deficits to falling home prices and falling prices for a weak dollar .
but something that has not been visible in any economic indicator is likely to drive many economic indicators : the deterioration in us management – which has weakened not only many large us corporations , but also the 书写 of american firms .
paradoxically , in the us , one indicator has been robust – productivity – that may be the clearest sign of this problem .
when it comes to productivity , managers either invest in employee training , more efficient manufacturing processes , and invest in the short term , or they seem to have done so in the short term .
productivity is a measure of output per hour hours .
of course , no company can do that , but many us companies are already shedding workers and middle managers – 19 % more than they were in january 2008 .
meanwhile , those who stay behind must work harder , often without increasing wages .
workers ’ wages adjusted after inflation adjusted in 2007 , and continue to trend in the decade .
this , too , is “ productive ” – until these people quit or become exhausted .
a sustainable company is not a collection of “ human resources , ” but a group of people .
its power is rooted in its people , its culture , and the goodwill created by its customers and suppliers .
so , when workers and middle managers leave them , they take them not just to many important information , but also to their company ’ s heart and soul , which has a profound impact on us competitiveness .
consider high-tech , where people think that the us should surpass other countries .
in november 2006 , the high-tech trade deficit extended to 2005 , according to the prospect of an american innovation group comprising prominent universities , think tanks , industrial trade associations , and businesses .
this is not clothing or cars , but the most renowned export sector in the us .
this deficit reflects a potential shortfall of research .
in the 25 of the 25 companies that the us patent was most likely in 2006 , only eight were american companies .
perhaps it helps explain why the institute of reputation in new york had more than six million surveys in 2007 , in order to “ most respected companies in the world , ” ranking the first us companies in the first place , ranking the first 25 us companies .
no one can determine how much of the recent increase in productivity in us productivity in recent years has been due to squeezing human capital , because it is not measured .
but it is clear that the us has much to do with this strategy , because it is not only because they must do so , but also because they do not have the financial expectations of wall street analysts .
managers ’ increased focus on maximizing shareholder value won many supporters in the 1980 ’ s , when the rules of financial markets that do not account for individual sentiments force companies to become more productive and innovative .
and , indeed , the us , in the 1980 ’ s and 1990 ’ s , is likely to owe significant investment in information communications technology to a large proportion of the investment .
but , when the marginal productivity gains from these investments began to fall , senior managers ’ survival and compensation continued to be tied to the stock market ’ s performance .
as a result , many senior managers have learned just how to manage their companies ’ short-term stock prices at the expense of their products and customers .
moreover , because maximizing shareholder value is not a good incentive for workers and middle managers , the company ’ s board of directors centers on power , and thus encourages a “ heroic ” form of leadership that and others leave .
indeed , in many cases , ceos – often the “ superstar ” 空降 in the wall street – are now the company , even though they know little about companies , customers , and competitors .
this shift to “ heroic ” leadership can be seen from ballooning ceo compensation .
according to a report from january 2008 , the top 50 corporate ceos in the 50 us companies are now almost three times more compensation than european workers – more than their own workers ’ compensation .
until recently , america ’ s asset bubble – first stock-market bubbles , followed by bubbles in the housing market – masked the potential decline of us companies .
but the bubble itself is caused by the same governance pathologies as those afflicting the real economy .
after all , mismanagement encourages mortgage lenders to provide artificially low “ 诱惑 ” interest rates to lure potential homeowners .
those who bought these mortgages never bothered to investigate their potential value – a serious responsibility for managing responsibility .
now that the bubble has burst , america ’ s current economic malaise may be much worse than it was before , because us firms have been slow and cautious to rebuild .
a sharp fall in the dollar could help the us to reduce its massive trade deficit , but it should not be expected that any sustained improvement should be sustained .
while american economists , politicians , and business leaders have been seeking to sell their management to foreign countries for years , many companies elsewhere have not been sold .
as a result , the economy is healthier than the us economy .
make no mistake : the problem is in the us , and only in the us .
america ’ s self-defeating hegemony
when i wrote the “ end of history ” 20 years ago , i didn ’ t expect us actions and misjudgments to make anti-americanism an important symbol of global politics .
but , especially after the terrorist attacks of september 11 , 2001 , that fact has taken place , owing to four mistakes in the bush administration .
first , a “ pre-emptive ” strategy devised in response to the 2001 attacks was inadequately expanded to include other so-called “ rogue ” states that threatened to develop weapons of mass destruction .
to be sure , a preemptive strategy to treat 恐怖分子 terrorists with weapons of mass destruction is reasonable .
but such a strategy can not be the core of all non-proliferation policies , guided by the guidance of us military intervention , aimed at preventing the development of nuclear weapons .
the costs of executing such policies are too costly ( in iraq ’ s hundreds of billions of dollars and tens of thousands of civilians , and the number is widening ) .
the bush administration has thus avoided military confrontation with north korea and iran , even though the us applauded israel ’ s osirak reactor in 1981 , given that it delayed saddam ’ s nuclear program for several years .
but , after all , the success of that attack itself meant that such a limited intervention would not be replicated , because the potential spread is learned to bury , covert , or duplicate their nascent weapons programs .
the second mistake is to judge the world ’ s behavior in terms of america ’ s exercise of hegemony .
many in the bush administration believed that even without approval by the united nations security council or nato , the success of the military ’ s success would be legitimized by us military force .
this was the pattern of many american actions during the cold war and the balkan balkans of the 1990 ’ s , when people called it “ leadership ” rather than “ unilateralism . ”
in the wake of the iraq war , however , conditions have changed : the united states has become so strong relative to the rest of the world that it is becoming angry at the expense of america ’ s closest allies .
the structural anti-americanism caused by the global distribution of power was starkly apparent before the war in iraq , compared to the 全球化 globalization of the united states .
but the “ 当面 ” of the bush administration has made anti-americanism even worse – a model that continues through the war in iraq .
america ’ s third mistake is to overestimate the role of conventional military power in a weak state of states and transnational organizations , at least in the middle east .
it is worth considering why a military more than any other country in human history , and that military money has been funded militarily by all other countries combined , is still not in a small country of 24 million people .
this is at least partly because the us is facing a social force that is not centralized , and thus can not be reined in by traditional military capabilities , forcing or manipulating them .
israel made a similar mistake when it considers that it could use a strong conventional military force in lebanon last summer to destroy hezbollah .
both israel and the us are nostalgic for the world of the twenty-first century , and they are so convinced that they have the most traditional power in the world .
but nostalgia has made both countries wrong to estimate the challenges they face , whether by al-qaeda ’ s iraq in iraq , or by hezbollah and syria .
this linkage is true in the case of hezbollah , but the various actors in the cyber community have their own social roots , rather than being manipulated by regional forces .
this explains why the use of conventional power has only frustrating results .
finally , the bush administration ’ s use of military power is not only a lack of coercive tactics or norms , but also less power .
in iraq alone , the bush administration has wrongly estimated the power of weapons of mass destruction , and failed to develop adequate occupation programs and then failed quickly to adapt quickly .
so far , the us has suspended all of its simple problems in iraq , such as raising money for democracy promotion .
the call for war in iraq , then a mess in iraq , is now stoking the battle against iran .
what is the rest of the world to believe in a better and more decisive fight against a more determined , more determined , and more determined fight against the fight ?
but the fundamental problem remains the distribution of power in the international system .
any country with equal status in the us , even in democracies , will be tempted to exercise its grip on power more recklessly .
the founding of america ’ s founding state also holds no limits on power , even if it is politically legitimate , and it is based on a constitutional system that has established internal devolution , so that it has a constitutional system to limit its leaders .
there is no such system for today ’ s global scale , which may explain why the us is in trouble .
a more balanced distribution of power , even under a global system of incomplete democracy , would reduce the temptation of cautious use of power .

america ’ s socialism against the rich
as people talk about a recovery in the financial crisis , the us banking sector is rethinking how to strengthen it .
in order to prevent another crisis from occurring , politicians are talking about how to reform regulatory norms , and we must focus on the areas where the banks are returning , and that they want to return to the glory of the past .
the past system is good for banks ( though it is good for shareholders ) , so why should they change ?

that is why they have been poorly run .
whenever they work , the government restructuring , providing deposit insurance , and holding banks ’ shares .

in the 1980 ’ s , when the savings crisis in the 1980 ’ s , the atm was not “ enough cash , ” and the government was forced to bail out it to avoid the outflow of funds .
in the usual financial restructuring , shareholders generally bear losses on all investments , and bondholders are often new shareholders .
governments may provide additional funds , and new investors must take over the failed banks .
yet the obama administration has introduced a new concept : too large a bank can not restructure .
so not only does it not have to play the bonds , or even the shareholders – all of which depend on government bailouts .
i believe that this line of thinking is wrong .
the obama administration may be a judgment of political pressure and misguided banking .
he has confused bailing out the banks and bailing out banks .
restructuring gives banks a new opportunity : new investors , whether asset collateral or bond restructuring , will be more confident , and other banks would be happy to lend money to them .
if the real value of banks ’ assets is higher than market prices , they will be compensated .
what is clear is that obama ’ s strategy will be very high in both the current and future costs – and , as it stands , he did not achieve a limited goal : restarting lending .
taxpayers have already taken tens of billions of dollars , and are likely to spend more than $ 80 billion in guarantees in the future .
rewriting the rules of the market economy is not just the loss of financial fire , but also those who have caused the financial crisis .
most americans believe that this is extremely unfair , especially when they see the bank ’ s acceptance of the billions of dollars and bonuses and dividends that they pay for themselves .
tearing up social contracts is not so facile .
if such a reform is adopted , it is also a matter of money to make money to individuals , and the losers are on the public side .
this is bound to fail .
if incentives fail , what is the rule of market game ?
banks that are large enough to be restructured know that they can gamble – because the fed provides near-zero interest rates , and money can be provided with money .
some have made this new economic form “ socialism of american socialism . ”
but socialism focuses on ordinary people ’ s interests .
by contrast , the us has offered no help for millions of ordinary americans who lost their homes .
unemployed workers have only 39 weeks of limited unemployment assistance , and they can only be left out .
when they lose their jobs , they also lost health insurance .
the us is quietly providing companies with security guarantees , from commercial banks to investment banks , then insurance companies , and now the auto industry , which is far from finished .
indeed , this is not socialism , but an extension of long-term corporate wealth .
rich people can help to turn their money into the government , while ordinary people do not have social protection .
we must break up these large and failing banks without evidence that such “ financial behemoths ” would benefit society when receiving relief .
if they are not broken up , we will have to limit their mandate considerably .
let them do nothing like the past – gambling after the gamble was borne by others .
for these financial behemoths , there is another issue worth noting : they have strong political forces .
they lobbied the college to work well : first regulations , then taxpayers , and then taxpayers to clean up them .

america ’ s perilous pivot

but the middle east may be as important as president barack obama ’ s explicit expectation if it is to solve and iranian disputes with iran .
the question is whether the us will have another war in the middle east as a result of declining dependence on middle east energy .
indeed , according to the international energy agency ’ s recent projections by the international energy agency , the revolution in hydrocarbons ( especially shale oil and gas ) in the united states will make the us the world ’ s largest oil producer by 2020 , and the global repercussions will be undeniable .
for the us , energy self-sufficiency is a perfect excuse for a phased withdrawal from the middle east ; once it comes out of dependence on energy , the us can concentrate on dealing with the pacific .
while the need to maintain stable global energy prices and the need for the alliance with israel mean that the us can not get out of the entire middle east , the shift to asia has begun to shift the focus of us strategic priorities before obama ’ s first term .

the basis for harmony in the international system will depend on the strategic trust of the twenty-first century powers .

because china ’ s oil imports by 2020 will come from the middle east , one important step will be to pursue china ’ s cooperation to address the region ’ s problems .

america ’ s suicidal statecraft
since winning the cold war , america ’ s global hegemony has depended on three pillars , namely economic power , military power , and a vast capacity to export popular culture .
the recent rise of a new power like the european union , china , india , and russia , which seeks to restore its lost status , has eroded the ability of the us to engage in unilateral affairs .
even so , the us remains the world ’ s most powerful country ; its decline and its use of power are more than the rise of competitors .
to paraphrase british historians , the us should blame america ’ s leaders for “ suicidal statecraft . ”
consider the middle east .
the us , in the first gulf war in 1991 , has used military force calmly , and the hubris and deceit of today ’ s iraq war are more understandable than the comparison of the two .
in 1991 , the united states formed the most powerful international force since world war ii , and it has led the force in a fully legal war to restore regional balance after saddam hussein ’ s invasion of kuwait .
in 2003 , the united states went to war without its trans-atlantic allies after manipulating false claims .
in doing so , the us has pursued a ludicrous macroeconomic strategy aimed at eliminating iraq ’ s authoritarian regimes , rebuilding the entire middle east , destroying al-qaeda , and helping democracy throughout the arab world .
the result was utter failure : military failure and a much lower moral position in the us .
not only has the us undermined extreme islamism , but it has legitimized it in iraq and beyond .
indeed , the region ’ s future is not democracy , but the violent divide between the shia and sunnis that the iraq war facilitated .
it is this muslim civil war that allows al-qaeda to recruit recruits .
in iraq , the arab countries that are likely to be the first shia muslim rule , and thereby integration into the expanding shia empire in iran , now see the us as unreliable .
indeed , the us is supposed to be a de facto complicit in the islamist revival of the shia revival .
the gospel of democracy is not very dear for america ’ s arab allies , because the call for democracy is merely encouraging the islamists to challenge the elite today .
there is no doubt that violent islamic fundamentalism has a deeper cause in the decline of arab nationalism .
but the result of america ’ s poor democratic assertion is that it alienated its conservative regional allies and islamist allies alike , alienated from conservative political islam , who can use the ballot box as a means to gain power .
america ’ s biggest strategic blunder in the region should be related to the emergence of iranian power .
the us has destroyed iraq as a 制约性 regional power , and thus a striking blow to its traditional gulf allies , as iraq ’ s ambitions are iran ’ s ambitions .
the us has ceded some strategic assets to iran . khomeini ’ s revolution , in the war with saddam hussein , and the region ’ s export revolution throughout the region , failed to make these strategic assets .
likewise , because iran feels that the notion of a “ pre-emptive war ” in the us has failed in iraq , its nuclear program has been similarly aggressive .
the disastrous us military operation in iraq has made it strategically depressed .
iraq has now become god ’ s playground , and the us can count on a modicum of stability there only by other regional powers .
but the us will remain the most influential external country in the middle east , owing to its failings , not actual power .
america ’ s role in the region can be restored only if the military fails to take the lead in the region , owing to its military failure , which can be restored only by avoiding arrogance and learning from others .
this requires engaging with revolutionary states like iran and syria , respect , and , rather than isolation , from jihadism to political participation , and to lead the international alliance to achieve an arab-israeli peace based on arab league initiative .
the palestinian question is not the source of all middle east troubles , but it can improve the united states ’ standing in the arab world .
more importantly , it will not allow iran to link the popular and arab cause with its own hegemonic ambitions .
america ’ s threat to trans-pacific trade
mumbai – it seems brazen enough that the world trade organization ’ s doha round of global free-trade negotiations is not excessive ( in geneva , the last ministerial conference in geneva ) , and the us continues to make foolish moves – a positive push for the trans-pacific partnership ( tpp ) .

countries can , in principle , join the agreement .

only a stronger country like japan can be given to “ leave and leave free ” negotiations .

and that will not be acceptable to brazil , the leading actor in the americas ’ free trade agreement , which focuses exclusively on trade issues .

america ’ s three deficits
berkeley – a series of reports at the start of the year show that economic recovery in the united states has been boosted .
job creation has increased , and indicators of manufacturing and services have improved , and consumer spending is stronger than expected .
but it is too early to celebrate .
us output growth remains subdued , with the us economy still facing three deficits : the jobs deficit , the investment deficit , and the chronic fiscal deficit , all of which are unlikely to be resolved in an election year .
although output is already higher than in the fourth quarter of 2007 , it is still much lower than in the labor and capacity of the labor force .
the gap – the difference between actual output and potential output – is about 7 % of gdp ( $ 1 trillion ) .
the output gap reflects more than two million jobs , even as employment levels peaked at the peak of the 2007 peak and to absorb the number of people who enter the labor market for every month .
even if the economy grows at 2.5 % in 2012 , as many expected , the employment deficit will not be eliminated , and could continue until 2024 .
the main concern for the us employment deficit is inadequate aggregate demand .
consumption , which accounts for 70 % of total us spending , is constrained by a combination of unemployment , low wages , and a sharp decline in housing prices and consumer wealth .
the rise in consumption in december 2011 was a boost to household saving and a surge in consumer credit .
neither trend is healthy nor sustainable .
as it stands , the unemployment rate is 8.5 % , and the labor-force participation rate is only 64 % and real wages have stagnated , leading to an all-time low of 44 % of national income .
labor income is the most important component of household income , and a major driver of consumer spending .
before the great recession , american workers and households were in trouble .
the annual growth rate fell by half for 30 years before the 2007 employment rate .
productivity growth is strong , but it goes far beyond wage growth , while workers ’ average real hourly compensation is declining , even as university graduates are not spared .
indeed , the period in 2000-2007 was only a rebound in the real income decline in median households .
moreover , job creation continues to play a polarizing role , with high incomes , technology , and management positions , as well as the number of food services in low wages , personal care , and protection .
on the contrary , white-collar and blue-collar jobs are shrinking , especially in manufacturing .
hard-pressed american households have had to cut their savings rates , borrow on home ownership , and keep their consumption at the cost of rising debt , leading to the housing and credit bubbles that burst in 2008 .
three factors have led to the toxic structural change in the us labor market :
· technological change is based on skill-biased technological change : the automation of traditional work and the increase in demand for skilled workers at least a college degree .
· global competition in competition and integration by trade and outsourcing has reduced jobs and reduced wages .
· declining competitiveness in the us , no longer the attractiveness of production and jobs .
but the decline in us competitiveness is the result of policy choices .
in particular , in terms of creating and maintaining high wages , the us has invested less in three areas : skills and training , infrastructure , and research and development .
the us government spends less than 10 % of its spending on these three fronts , and that share is declining .
today , the federal government can borrow at very low interest rates , while many projects have a high return on education , infrastructure , and research , with high returns and boosting the competitiveness of the us to attract high-wage jobs .
president barack obama has proposed numerous proposals to invest in us national competitiveness , but republicans in congress rejected these proposals , arguing that america ’ s immediate fiscal crisis is a fiscal crisis .
indeed , until 2030 , the federal deficit ’ s share of gdp will fall sharply in the years ahead , even without further deficit-reduction measures .
the us does face a chronic fiscal deficit , which is driven by rising health-care costs and aging populations .
but the current fiscal deficit is largely caused by low tax revenues , owing to low growth , high unemployment , and weak aggregate demand , and a new stimulus package is needed to take a new stimulus .
in any case , in order to ensure that the us economy will grow 2.5 % this year , the payroll tax and unemployment package proposed by obama should extend to the end of the year .
such measures can provide insurance to fragile recoveries , while no impact on long-term fiscal gaps .
so how can the us economy ’ s jobs deficit , investment deficit , and long-run fiscal deficits be addressed ?
policymakers should play a strong role in fiscal policy , eliminating jobs and investment deficits now , while proposing a multi-year plan to reduce long-run fiscal deficits gradually .
this long-term plan should increase spending on education , infrastructure , and research , while limiting further growth in health-care spending ( for example , the cost limits proposed by obamacare ) .
now , with a long-term deficit-reduction plan , it will prevent premature fiscal contraction by postponing the economy ’ s reach at full employment , which would prevent the economy from slipping into recession .
indeed , it would boost output and employment by enacting a package of investors ’ concerns about future deficits , boosting consumer and business confidence .
the painful choice of closing the long-run fiscal gap should be made , and it will be strong until the economy recovers .
but , in the coming years , the priorities for fiscal policy are jobs , investment , and growth .
america ’ s ungovernable budget
new york – any government is at the heart of the budget .
politicians can make endless promises , but if the budget is not kept behind , politics is simply empty .
this dilemma is already in the us .
in the just-released state of the state union , president barack obama painted a convincing picture of modern twenty-first-century government .
obama ’ s republican opponents complained that the proposal would make the government go bankrupt .
the truth is that both parties are incapable of recognizing the need for modernization without raising taxes .
obama wisely understood that today ’ s competitiveness in the world depends on modern labor and infrastructure .
this is no different for any country , but this is especially true for rich countries .
the us and europe must compete directly with brazil , china , india , and other emerging countries , and their wages are only one-quarter that of high-income countries ( or even less ) .
only by establishing competitiveness in advanced technologies , cutting-edge technologies , and modern infrastructure can the us and europe maintain their standard of living .
as a result , obama has called for the us to increase public investment in three areas : education , science and technology , and infrastructure ( including broadband internet , fast rail , and clean energy ) .
obama has good reason to emphasize these themes .
the us unemployment rate is currently hovering around 10 % , partly because emerging economies gain more jobs , while the number of jobs created by the us today is much higher than it was in the past .
unless the us increases its investment in education , science , technology , and infrastructure , such adverse trends will continue .
but when it comes to the budget deficit , obama ’ s statement starts with reality .
recognizing that recent fiscal policy has led to unsustainable public debt , obama has said that the budget balance is essential to achieving fiscal stability .
so he called for a five-year freeze on the us government ’ s so-called “ principled ” public spending .
the problem is that more than half of these spending is spent on education , technology , and infrastructure – and obama has just proposed more investment in these areas .
after telling americans how important they are to invest in modernization , he promised to freeze the spending in the next five years !
politicians often change different views in different speeches , but rarely so clearly contradictory propositions in the same speech .
this contradiction highlights the self-defeating nature of america ’ s budget policy for 25 years , and that is likely to continue .
on one hand , the us government must invest more in promoting economic competitiveness .
the us , on the other hand , is too low to support the necessary government investment .
two days after obama ’ s speech , the recent study published by the congressional budget office revealed that the budget deficit will reach $ 1.5 trillion this year , so large a deficit would be even more attractive than people ’ s imagination .
a large deficit of almost 10 % of gdp has led governments to debt , jeopardizing the us economy .
the congressional budget office study reports that the tax cuts agreed by obama and the republican opposition to the republican opposition have dramatically increased the fiscal deficit .
the tax cuts enacted by george w. bush were set to expire at the end of 2010 .
obama and republicans agreed to extend these tax cuts to at least two years ( the likelihood that they will continue to prolong two years later ) , thereby causing tax revenues to reduce tax revenue by $ 35 billion this year , and in 2012 .
tax cuts for the richest americans are also part of the solution .
the reality of american politics today is simple .
the leaders of both parties agreed on a policy of tax cuts , especially tax cuts for the rich .
both democrats and the white house would prefer tax cuts rather than spending on education , technology , and infrastructure .
the explanation is straightforward : the richest us households provide money for political campaigns .
so both parties have served to meet their wishes .
that is why the united states ’ 30 % of tax revenues are at the end of the country ’ s high income , while european countries account for less than 40 % of the country ’ s gdp .
one budget area can and should be cut : military spending .
still , even if america ’ s extreme military budget is slashed ( and bipartisan opposition to bipartisan opposition ) , new taxes are needed .
the economic and social consequences of a long tax cut are undeniable .
america ’ s international competitiveness is declining , while the poor are neglected – one-fifth of american children are trapped in poverty – and leaving a mountain of debt to young people .
despite obama ’ s lofty rhetoric , his fiscal-policy proposals are not hard to address these problems .
