cambridge – the united states ’ trade deficit is about $ 450 billion , or 2.5 % of gdp .
this means that us imports and services are more than $ 450 billion to the rest of the world .
how can americans ’ standard of living change if the us ran a huge deficit year after year ?
it is easy to blame large trade deficits against foreign governments that block us government sales in their own markets , hurting us firms and reducing their employees ’ standard of living .
it is also easy to blame the large trade deficit on foreign governments that subsidize exports to the us , which hurt us firms and employees , who lose access to foreign suppliers ( though in the us , as a whole ) .
but foreign import barriers and export subsidies are not the reason for the us trade deficit .
the real reason is that americans spend more than they earn .
the total trade deficit is the result of savings and investment decisions by households and businesses in the us .
foreign governments ’ policies can only influence how the deficit is distributed between us trading partners .
why america ’ s saving and investment decisions bring about a total trade deficit is simple : if a country saves more of its total output , rather than investing in equipment and structures , there is excess production to the rest of the world .
in other words , saving minus investment equals exports minus imports – a basic accounting identity that applies to each country in every year .
thus , reducing the us trade deficit requires americans to save more and invest less .
these policies would not change the overall trade balance by making markets open to us products , or allowing the us market to shut down foreign products .
the us has maintained its trade deficit for more than three decades , because foreigners are willing to lend their money to america ’ s net purchases of finance , in ways that buy us bonds and stocks or to invest in us real estate and other firms .
this is not to say that it will remain so in the coming decades ; but there is no reason to believe that it will end .
while foreign entities that lend to us borrowers some day will demand money , others will replace them as the next lenders .
but if foreigners as a whole reduced their demand for us financial assets , the price of these assets falls , causing interest rates to rise .
the rise in us interest rates would discourage domestic investment and increase domestic saving , causing the trade deficit to fall .
a declining trade deficit would help us exporters and businesses that now compete with imports .
but the decline in the trade deficit will also reduce americans ’ output of domestic consumption , or to invest in future consumption .
and that is only part of the story .
beyond reducing the remaining volume of goods and services available to us households and businesses , the trade deficit would also demand that us goods and services become more attractive to foreign buyers , while foreign goods and services are no longer attractive to us buyers .
this means that the us export price declines , import prices rise – and , through the dollar ’ s fall , the dollar is falling .
even if the size of the national output is the same , us output will decline at home , because the us must export more output to gain the same value as imports .
trade experts estimate that the us trade deficit has lowered its gdp by 10 % or 10 % of import prices by 10 % .
if these two changes are simultaneously simultaneously , they will reduce the current trade deficit by about 2 % of us gdp , making us trade a fundamental balance .
but , because us exports and imports account for 15 % of gdp and 12 % of gdp , lower export prices would reduce real incomes by about 1.5 % ( adjusted for inflation ) , while import prices would reduce real incomes by 1.2 % .
thus , eliminating the trade deficit will require a shift of 2.5 % of us real production to the rest of the world , and a change in import prices that would make real gdp more real 2.7 % .
in short , with national output unchanged , america ’ s real income will fall by about 5 % .
if trade deficits fall because of increased consumption , lower investment , and lower investment , the level of investment will cause growth to fall , further reducing long-term real income levels .
but if the trade deficit narrowed because households increase their savings and government deficits , there is a risk that investment will rise – and thus increase long-term incomes .
as a result , the americans ’ saving rate is the key to the trade balance , and it is crucial to its long-term real income level .
blaming other countries does not change this fact .
the state of america
new york – the united states ’ presidential election is not nearly half the corner , and it is impossible to know who will be nominated by the two major parties , let alone who will be the 45th occupant of the white house .
but it is not too soon to assess the mood of a country with 3.2 million inhabitants , and the meaning of the eventual winner of the world ’ s seemingly endless political soap opera .
today , mainstream sentiment in the united states is a source of anxiety and even outright anger .
the washington post recently published a series of articles , revealing popular anger against wall street , muslims , trade deals , washington , police shootings , president barack obama , immigration , and other goals .
today , the worst description of a person is “ professional politicians . ”
the beneficiaries of this thinking are anti-establishment candidates who stand in opposition to free trade and immigration reform , demanding a radical overhaul of current tax and spending policies .
the details of the specific details they advocate may be very different , but their platforms have committed to a radical departure from the status quo .
the basis behind this sentiment is not obvious , because the us economy is better than it was in the immediate aftermath of the 2007-2008 economic crisis .
over nine million jobs have been created during this period , with low interest rates ( making housing and car loans cheap ) , while the decline in gasoline prices amounts to $ 700 per household for households .
moreover , the stock market has risen by 200 % since its low seven years ago , with no health insurance now covered by insurance .
but this economic good news has been offset by anemic household income growth , which has grown in real ( inflation-adjusted ) terms for 15 years .
the percentage of americans who have full-time jobs still did not meet its level seven years ago .
more people fear that they will lose jobs , new technologies , or outsourcing .
many americans live longer , but they are anxious , because they have failed to put their money in order to ensure that they are kept out of old age .
for the reforms that obama has pursued , some would have to pay for the health insurance that they had previously saved .
there is also the issue of inequality .
this leads to real anger , but the problem is not that inequality , though bad , is not new , but the decline of opportunity .
the american dream is giving way to class consciousness – a profound change in the country ’ s ability to create an ideal effort to improve the lives of all .
but the reasons for anxiety and anger are not limited to economic reality and concerns .
there is also a sense of insecurity , whether because of crime or fear of terrorism .
in many communities , there is concern where culture and society are concerned .
modern media tend to make things worse .
our time is a time of “ 窄播 , ” not “ radio . ”
people are increasingly willing to see cable channels and websites strengthening their views and ideology .
national sentiment transcends the campaign , bringing real challenges to the new president and congress .
the divisions between democrats and republicans will create compromises and coalitions , and it is essential to govern it .
concerns about retirement and health-care affordability will significantly increase the difficulty of reforming equity , even if the expansion of these benefits would increase the national debt to record levels .
free trade is blamed for job losses , and is losing support , even if it is a new job and more consumer choice – and strengthens america ’ s strategic position around the world .
immigration has been part of the us , and it is a source of good talent , and it is now being subject to a lot of controversy .
american sentiment may also strengthen officials ’ domestic concerns .
the cost of intervention in iraq and afghanistan is far higher than the incomes of the income , and many americans have been disappointed by subsequent diplomatic engagement , with doubts about what the us can achieve abroad .
they are frustrated with their allies ’ failure to share a fair share of the fair share of their allies , and the us government is increasingly convinced that the us government should focus less on the world .
obviously , others in other countries are pleased ; but , overall , it is bad news for much of the world .
the united states , which is distracted by the division of attention , is less likely to be willing and able to lead the stability or response to stability in the middle east , europe , or asia .
without us leadership , these challenges could not be solved , or , worse , the problem .
america wakes up on climate change
after years of debate and the bush administration ’ s opposition to any action , the us is finally waking up to the realities of global climate change .
but this process is not the result of the president , but from the private sector .
the leaders of major us corporations believe that man-made global climate change is an indisputable reality , and it must be controlled , and the business community must play a constructive role in this process .
as a result , even the bush administration and some of the others who have proved the opposite of science are moving in the opposite direction , us corporate leaders are seeking concrete solutions .
the basic situation has been clear for years .
global use of fossil fuels is leading to a sharp rise in the amount of co2 in the atmosphere , which is causing warming to earth .
rainfall patterns are changing .
deserts and dry regions become drier .
extreme weather events like hurricanes and typhoons are also increasing .
flooding in europe may become even more severe , and the process could already be taken .
sea levels are rising , and if the ice sheets of green and antarctica are to be destabilized by global warming , this trend will rise further .
in short , there is a growing body of scientific evidence that the planet is already at risk . many bad effects are already visible , and that they are just the tip of the iceberg .
the right approach is also to be understood .
we must shift to a sustainable energy system that does not make a system of carbon in the atmosphere dramatically increased .
this will require us to shift to renewable energy sources , such as solar and nuclear energy , and to use new technologies that would enable the emissions of power plants to be used and deployed safely underground .
society must pay the necessary costs for the adoption of these new energy technologies , but we benefit from it .
the us is the world ’ s main country in the use of co2 emissions , but , in major countries , it is the least able to respond to the global climate challenge .
fortunately , the us has taken concrete action , owing to the consequences of other countries ’ leadership and the sense of awareness by major us companies .
first , the rest of the world ratified the kyoto protocol to control co2 emissions .
at the beginning of this year , europe introduced a new cap-and-trade system , using market incentives to control carbon emissions .
american companies operating in europe are part of the system because they are part of the system , and , even in the absence of their own government , us companies are integrated into a system of climate control .
moreover , america ’ s major investors , such as pension fund managers , are recognizing that companies that can not control emissions could suffer economic losses in the future .
they understood that the us would sooner or later join the process of global control .
at that point , electric power utilities using antiquated technologies face severe financial losses when they emit large amounts of greenhouse gases .
so investors are making today ’ s companies reporting carbon emissions to assess future liabilities .
likewise , many companies know that pretending that climate problems do not exist is bad for shareholders , because the truth prevails .
they know that today ’ s investments in clean ( energy ) technologies increase companies ’ long-term competitiveness .
as a result , many companies have taken steps to limit their emissions to avoid unnecessary economic responsibility and keep investors afloat .
when the world ’ s most important and innovative spirit , and one of the most respected companies , announced that it would be a “ green ” company by adopting new claims and commitments that benefit the environment , it is the one of the most important .
many us companies will follow the lead , guided by leadership that calls themselves “ ecological imagination ” ( combining ecology with imagination ) .
it is too early to say that the us has been able to step in to combat climate change .
the bush administration continues to delay and avoid effective 科学论证 .
the comparison , however , is a turning point .
as in other countries , reality is approaching the us .
as americans and companies continue to suffer from the adverse effects of climate change – heat waves , droughts , hurricanes , and floods – americans , including a growing number of business leaders , will urge american political leadership to take concrete steps .
the solution will not be easy , and it must continue for decades around the world .
but we must start acting now .
as in europe ’ s new trading trading system , global producers and consumers alike need to confront market incentives to slow ( and eventually stop ) the technologies and consumption patterns of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere .
when we are responsible for global climate change , we should be paying for a certain “ market price , ” which we can really take on economically motivated energy systems and new public investments – such as big 运量 public-transport systems – and thus preventing future climate disasters .
the right weights for mortgage risk
abu dhabi – ever since the start of a 狩猎 tribe began to build a habitat , homeownership became a mark of great social and economic stature .
today , the us has created a huge system of financial institutions to facilitate housing ownership , and economists , bankers , politicians , and , of course , homeowners themselves are keen to house prices .
but , as we have recently seen , unless mortgage risk is properly calculated , the dream of a house can easily become a bad economic nightmare .
mortgage debt has become the largest household debt in the developed world .
in the decade preceding the financial crisis , the us mortgage debt increased by almost three times , while the real economy grew by just one-third .
at the peak of 2007 , us mortgage debt amounted to $ 10.6 trillion – more than twice as much as gdp in china and india combined .
the collapse in real-estate prices was also the main cause of emerging-market crises , as occurred in asia in 1997-98 .
research shows that the output losses associated with the bust in housing bubbles are twice as high as they were in real estate prices .
moreover , the housing bubble burst by almost three years .
given that mortgage debt was subject to a collapsing housing price , a huge social and economic cost would be enormous , and that regulators should be engaged closely and closely .
unfortunately , not .
despite the 2008 global banking supervision committee ’ s main benchmark , the basel committee on banking supervision proposed implementing reforms aimed at strengthening the financial system , but the mortgage regulatory changes were little .
the key to mortgage regulation is the concept of “ risk weight , ” which increases with the probability of a borrower ’ s default .
for example , a loan to aaa-rated microsoft , a 0 % risk weight , means that it can be considered risk-free .
loans to india ’ s government , risk weight at 50 % , and riskier loans in argentina , will be 150 % .
as for mortgage lending , the standard risk weight is 35 % ( 50 % a decade ago ) .
but banks can use internal mathematical models to calculate their own risk weights .
this is akin to his own 考卷 rating ; it is not surprising that banks ’ risk rating tends to fall on the security side .
consider , for example , a $ 200,000 loan to buy a $ 235,000 house .
if the banks give the loans a 10 % risk weight , the risk is worth $ 20,000 .
if the bank ’ s share of the bank ’ s total capital shares is 10 % , the banks need only $ 2,000 worth of capital .
the loss of the bank ’ s own money would require a 16 % drop in house prices ( from $ 235,000 to below $ 198,000 ) .
by the s & poor national home price index , in june 2009 , the us declined by more than 30 % in march 2009 , while european countries , including spain , ireland , and the united kingdom , have experienced similar or larger declines .
the problem is that banks that have largely failed to “ contain them ” continue to make large amounts of mortgage lending .
the imf estimates that the average mortgage risk weight in europe and asia is 14 % and 15 % , respectively , with some of the risk weights that some banks use at less than 6 % .
recently , some regulators have begun to question the risk weights on banks ’ own profits .
in 2012 , the british authorities demanded a temporary risk weights for a 15 % of the bank ’ s mortgage portfolios , but the guidelines fell in july .
the swedish regulator suggested that mortgage lenders would raise the risk weight from 15 % to 25 % .
while these measures are welcome , they remain too small ; more important , they lack flexibility .
a better approach would be to implement pro-cyclical , pro-cyclical floors , forcing banks to hold more capital during housing booms .
moreover , a one-size-fits-all fixed floor could drive banks to lend more to riskier , more rewarding loans ; and a dynamic system allows the lower floor of mortgage lending to lower the minimum , while the lower bound on risky loans would require higher floors .
moreover , while risk weight is a huge macro-prudential lever , it must be used with other tools for regulators .
these include mortgage eligibility criteria ( such as 房屋 value ratios and 收入 ratios ) and dynamic ( in the case of a housing boom that raised banks ’ mandatory lending losses ) .
the impact of adjusting risk weight relative to the housing market is important , because excessive and 重复 intervention could lead to a vicious cycle .
modern banking regulation depends on the risk weight that is most apparent in the mortgage market .
this column represents the author ’ s personal , not representative of the national bank of abu dhabi .
hardening brazil ’ s soft power
brasilia – perhaps for brazilians , the country ’ s eternal peace is a tricky question .
after all , after negotiations to resolve the border dispute , brazil has nearly 150 years of conflict with ten neighbors .
the last war against the south atlantic in 1942 was the last war against the south atlantic .
brazil has signed the comprehensive nuclear safeguards agreement with argentina and the international atomic energy agency , pledging to abandon its nuclear weapons .
brazil is doing its part through mercosur and the alliance of south american countries ( unasur ) to contribute to the region ’ s political , economic , social , and cultural integration .
but can the world ’ s major emerging countries simply rely on soft power alone ?
to be sure , brazil ’ s peaceful foreign policy is doing well .
brazil has used its own status to advance peace cooperation in south america and beyond .
it is this constructive attitude that combines national pride with democracy , social justice , economic development , and environmental protection .
the key source of brazil ’ s soft power is its unique approach to promoting the ideal , exemplified in the support of brazil , which has more than the fao and the world trade organization .
but no country can defend its interests alone .
in fact , policymakers must not lose sight of the hard power of a new challenge in an old , 威胁 world .
the military has secured peace by curbing threats to national sovereignty , in brazil , for example , to prop up its constructive role in global stability .
that role is more necessary than ever .
over the past two decades , unilateral action undermined the un security council ’ s authority in international war and peace , leading to instability and uncertainty .
there has been little progress in nuclear disarmament on nuclear disarmament .
brazil ’ s abundance of energy , food , water , and biodiversity makes it even more important in the security environment for the fight against natural resources .
to meet the challenges of complex realities , brazil ’ s peaceful foreign policy must be underpinned by a strong defense policy .
brazil ’ s national defense strategy , updated in 2012 , made clear that the modernization of the armed forces is inherently correlated with the country ’ s development .
the report thus emphasizes the need to strengthen the domestic defense industry .
brazil is pursuing a more conventional deterrent capability in this strategy , including by building a 核潜艇 submarine to make the naval plan commensurate with brazil ’ s responsibility in the south atlantic .
brazil cooperated closely with its neighbors through bilateral and south america ’ s defense council , which aims to promote trust , transparency , joint regional defense industries , and most important – building a common defense identity .
south america ’ s defense college , a south american defense college , is a potential mechanism for advancing these goals .
the war is increasingly unthinkable in south america – the political scientist karl deutsch called the “ safe community . ”
i am convinced that the defense minister ’ s visit to hong kong was the most effective deterrent in the region .
meanwhile , brazil is seeking to strengthen bilateral defense cooperation with its african partners .
brazil is working closely with its neighbors on both sides of the atlantic to protect the construction of nuclear peace in the south atlantic , a construction of nuclear cooperation and nuclear weapons .
for example , brazil conducts regular trilateral naval exercises with south africa and india .
more broadly , we are exploring ways to cooperate in defense technologies .
brazil hopes to be able to contribute to a balance of power stemming from the importance of a hegemonic international order that focuses on the importance of mutually beneficial partnerships with developed countries .
even in brazil ’ s hardening of soft power , it remains committed to a dialogue to prevent conflict prevention and negotiation .
in countries such as haiti and lebanon , peacekeepers highlight brazil ’ s efforts to maintain world peace and security .
brazil also convinced the global order of genuine stability in the twenty-first century will depend on the ability to build a legitimate and effective un security council that is responsive to the emerging multipolar world .
the growth dividend grows
hong kong – for more than three decades , china has grown rapidly over 10 % of gdp growth .
yet , behind this remarkable economic growth , the resulting economic , social , environmental costs , and challenges , as former prime minister wen jiabao accurately described – “ unstable , unbalanced , uncoordinated , and unsustainable ” – has followed .
now , china must make choices : the old economic-growth model driven by export investment , or a sustainable economic growth order .
cheap credit and wrong incentives ( such as promoting officials such as gdp growth ) triggered massive repeat investments , resulting in excess capacity in manufacturing and infrastructure .
this model is not only inefficient , but also government resources to impede inefficient investments in chinese society .
given this , china ’ s leaders have decided to stop their gdp growth as the primary criterion for evaluating officials ’ performance .
in fact , the 12th five-year plan , which will end in 2015 , aims to transform china ’ s economy into a sustainable new growth model based on quality and innovation , and accepts the possibility of falling gdp during the transition period .
most discussions about growth patterns are based on the theory of the nobel laureate economist robert solow .
according to the solow , gdp growth is determined by inputs like land , labor , capital , and total factor productivity . factor productivity ( tfp ) refers to the changes in productivity , not because of changes in technology , but because of changes in output .
since 1978 , china has achieved three consecutive periods of rapid productivity growth ( 5-7 years per year ) by advancing major reforms .
the first phase was the introduction of the rural family responsibility system in the early 1980 ’ s , which boosted agricultural productivity and sent large segments of the unskilled workers into a more productive urban and industrial sector , and total factor productivity grew by 3-4 % .
the second rapid growth occurred after deng xiaoping , after deng xiaoping , stressed that china ’ s economy needs to open up to foreign direct investment , and establish a special economic zones that would enable a shift to a market-based state .
this time , partly because of the “ catch up ” of china ’ s adoption of advanced technologies and successful expertise , tfp soared to 5-6 % .
finally , after major reforms of state-owned enterprises and tax systems , china joined the world trade organization in 2001 , prompting china to integrate fully into global supply chains , with tfp growth reaching 4 % , and continued to be until 2007 .
since then , however , tfp growth has fallen by almost half .
indeed , china ’ s economic growth has slowed significantly since the global economic crisis began five years ago .
by 2012 , human capital contributed to china ’ s gdp to almost zero , while fixed capital accumulation accounted for about 60 % of total growth .
massive debt financing will increase china ’ s credit ratio to nearly 200 % of gdp , highlighting the fragility of the financial system – a point that the recent bank interest rate has soared .
to achieve a balanced , sustainable gdp growth , china ’ s leaders must implement a comprehensive set of structural reforms aimed at boosting total factor productivity .
reforms should be focused on promoting the transition to the chinese economy ’ s growth model , in order to expand the traditional supply-side growth model of infrastructure construction , which is clearly not adapted to the current economic situation .
in fact , slowing gdp growth may be precisely precisely because the current investment in manufacturing and infrastructure , dominated by local governments and state-owned enterprises , is not in domestic demand .
china , too , faces short-term excess capacity .
governments must emphasize their regulatory and enforcement functions , including by developing and overseeing standards , establishing effective property-rights infrastructure , and managing macroeconomic conditions , rather than direct investment .
at the same time , governments should raise the quality of education , health care , and social security , and minimize corruption and administrative abuses .
in short , china must shift its focus from achieving its target of gdp growth to creating a environment conducive to innovation and competition , thereby allowing markets to set prices and increase resource efficiency .
the government thus turned into an intermediary to facilitate the development of a sustainable economic order in exchange for more innovation opportunities .
needless to say , soes have played an important role in china ’ s past growth model , providing the essential infrastructure and services needed for global manufacturing supply chains .
but cheap credit by state-owned banks has encouraged soes to accumulate excess capacity , leading to systemic risks .
to address china ’ s excess-capacity problem , it will have to leave inefficient firms , whether soes or private firms .
china ’ s leaders need to implement major structural reforms to build a market-based economic growth model that enables china to avoid the “ middle-income trap ” – a trap that has led many developing economies to not access to advanced-country status .
china needs reform dividends , including market dynamism and overall economic stability , to offset the reform costs of slowing gdp growth .
tracking big pharma ’ s progress on amr

how to fight antimicrobial resistance
zurich – two weeks ago , g-20 leaders pledged to work together to address one of the world ’ s most pressing problems and one of the most troubling social threats – antimicrobial resistance ( amr ) – a sweeping and changing enemy , with routine treatment .
the threat is straightforward : bacteria and other microbes are resistant to existing drugs faster than the development rate of new drugs .
every year , resistant microbes kill 700,000 people worldwide – more than three times the number of deaths from armed conflict each year .
in 2016 , a special commission of the british government predicted that , by 2050 , as many as ten million people will die from drug-resistant microbes .
amr now poses a clear threat to everyone on the planet .
unless we face the problem , the world could return to the normal infections that kill people .
beyond the loss of human life , amr undermined the world economy .
in europe alone , the health-care costs and productivity losses associated with amr are estimated to be €150 billion .
the g20 has taken an important step forward .
g20 countries have committed themselves to implementing national plans to mitigate amr , and to increase new treatments for addressing resistant microbes .
here , g20 leaders have called for an international “ r & d partnership , ” to “ maximize the effectiveness of existing and new antibiotics and clinical research . ”
they also promise to explore how to use market incentives to advance new research .
beyond the g20 , innovative public-private partnerships are also providing new treatments for drug-resistant killers such as tuberculosis .
some governments have already begun to play a key role in curbing amr , gathering data that gather the data of drug-resistant strains in e. coli , salmonella , and other common pathogens .
now , political leaders will have to offer their promises .
given that new treatments for multidrug-resistant microbes are unlikely to yield a significant return on investment , governments have an incentive to make research on private companies more attractive to private companies , and to prevent the development of drug resistance .
when traditional market mechanisms fail , tools such as “ transferable market exclusivity ” can help , which allows pharmaceutical companies to transfer their intellectual property to another drug .
when private institutions join such partnerships , they must be prepared to work beyond traditional borders , accept the challenges posed by complex public programs , and are willing to offer their skills , ideas , and experience .
in dealing with amr , we can learn some important lessons from other global public-health initiatives .
malaria is a disease caused by a parasite , which is one of the most prominent causes of death in many parts of the world .
but many governments and private institutions have made it a high priority for the disease , which has halved the number of deaths in malaria over the past 15 years .
but the parasite ’ s parasite is developing artemisinin resistance , which is the most effective malaria treatment – based on artemisinin-based combinations .
artemisinin resistance first appeared in cambodia more than a decade ago , and then spread to thailand , laos , vietnam , myanmar , and china .
it is now approaching india , and experts determine that it will reach africa sooner or later .
according to a recent study , if artemisinin resistance is allowed to spread , malaria will kill at least 116,000 people every year .
unless new treatments exist , the tremendous progress that the world has made against malaria will be short-lived .
fortunately , those engaged in the global response to malaria recognize that we must adjust as parasites adjust .
new initiatives are underway to identify and minimize the spread of resistant malaria , while developing new 疗法 treatments .
for example , artemisinin resistance programs in the region are working to stem the spread of resistant malaria in the mekong delta region , monitoring and sharing drug resistance data , and promoting proper use of anti-malaria treatments .
so far , the program has received 1.10 million from the global fund for aids , tuberculosis , and malaria to fund the government .
moreover , novartis and the drug for malaria , aided by the bill & melinda gates foundation ( the help of the bill & melinda gates foundation ) , are likely to become new treatments for artemisinin resistant strains .
at the 2016 world economic forum in davos , switzerland , 100 companies , including novartis , signed the davos declaration on amr .
in this manifesto , we promised to work with governments to increase our investment in research and development , and enable the patients needed to develop high-quality antibiotics , thereby discouraging drug resistance .
one hopes that the g20 ’ s national plans can help us to meet these commitments .
but political leaders should also use action to prove words .
we urgently need more resources for drug resistance , stronger incentives for research and development , and innovative financing mechanisms to ensure access to precise diagnostic and quality health care .
the world can not afford to lose the fight against amr .
winning the war requires a large-scale public-private partnership , underpinned by a global leadership that puts global public health at a top priority .
murder in moscow

an agenda for growth in europe
as europe ’ s demographic population worsens , and if it continues to grow more slowly than elsewhere in the industrialized economies , this gap is likely to widen .
why did the european economy fail to catch up with us income levels ?
the gap is largely due to inadequate labor use , with women , the biggest and most young , employment hours below the us , and , more importantly , the unemployment rate .
some are consolation , arguing that europeans prefer leisure more than work .
but the lower labor force is largely due to higher taxes and higher taxes , owing to high levels of social welfare , which are built in the labor force ’ s rapid demand for labor , replacing the needs of unemployment with active unemployment , and more aggressive unemployment .
these measures should be revisited to increase the supply of labor and to make public finances more sustainable .
this process is already underway , especially in italy and france , where the process of reducing unemployment by reducing the conditions for low-wage workers , and imposing tax credits for the “ working poor , ” is already underway .
since the 1990 ’ s , relative employment in these countries has actually reversed .
but , as well as the causes of welfare , the low employment rates of the eurozone economies , which have contributed to lower minimum wages , as well as some features of employment protection laws , have slowed workers ’ mobility through the flow of jobs .
though first in germany , more cautiously in france , and in france , where france is beginning to deal with a long list of reforms , the public ’ s understanding of the need for reform is limited .
with the experience of every country and the eu ’ s small countries , labor-market reforms are inevitably more national .
since the 1997 “ lisbon agenda , ” the european employment strategy has been established for all of the eu ’ s countries , and , “ lisbon agenda ” has established a set of goals for boosting productivity in europe .
but , because the policy approach to achieving these goals focuses mainly on countries , and in many member states , the policy strategy has created unrealistic expectations .
the employment gap with the us is not the only problem in europe .
the growth rate of hourly output per hour is a major factor in per capita income growth , which began in most of europe in the mid-1990 ’ s , and the us , in turn , reversed the decade-long pattern .
between 2000 and 2004 , hourly labor productivity in the us grew by 2.8 % per year , and the eurozone economy was slightly more than 1 % .
so why can ’ t europe be able to maintain growth at the same time of growth and productivity , as well as on employment and productivity ?
this is possible not only in the united states , but in other advanced economies outside europe , such as australia , canada , new zealand , and surprisingly new eu members .
the cost of capital is typically linked to productivity , but it can not be explained .
this is where productivity can be explained only by 要素 elements .
the so-called total factor productivity is a composite factor of several key factors , including innovative activity , well-functioning financial systems , and willingness to take risks , and to facilitate organizational flexibility in new technologies .
europe ’ s tfp growth over the past decade has largely lagged behind services ( excluding information and communications technology ) .
so the eurozone ’ s total factor productivity would be essential if it is to improve , and that it is essential that most of the eu ’ s economies are , in this area , created two-thirds of total income .
while product markets are central to building a single european single market , services continue to be fragmented by countries ’ regulation and anti-competitive practices .
the main explanation is the diversity of services , as well as the mutual recognition , or the “ country-of-origin principle , ” which is crucial to the services market .
unfortunately , reform was derailed in 2005 .
in the run-up to the referendum on the european union ’ s draft constitution , the proposed directive on services was vilified as undermining the rights of workers , which were reflected in “ polish plumbers . ”
these attacks ignore the fact that the eu directive is subject to employment conditions for workers from the rest of the eu to the rules of the host country .
a revised version of the directive now gives the european parliament a number of compromises , in principle , to the european parliament .
although improving productivity is called the eu ’ s common goal , it is still unable to reach a consensus on a 法律 law that inevitably is a sad condition for the eu .
the eu ’ s new member states have a stake in mobilizing their interest in mobilizing european solidarity , but it is particularly disappointing for them .

avoiding america ’ s new recession
cambridge – the united states may be headed for a recession in 2013 .
even if it avoids the “ fiscal cliff , ” a poor political compromise that cuts the deficit too soon could have pushed an already weak economy into recession .
but a gradual cap on tax credits ( so-called tax expenditures ) can be combined with reform of entitlement spending that would constitute a fiscal consolidation that the us needs to avoid another recession .
last year , the us economy is headed at a lower rate than 2 % , and the outlook for 2013 is as bleak as it was in the absence of fiscal cliff .
president barack obama ’ s proposal to replace the fiscal cliff would raise tax rates for the top 2 % of earners substantially , limiting their tax credits , and now account for more than 45 % of the federal personal-income tax .
together , these changes would lower aggregate demand by about 2 % of gdp .
higher marginal tax rates would discourage incentives to work and invest , further weakening economic activity .
this is a fateful case for a economy that is still struggling to sustain a growth rate of less than 2 % .
the congressional budget office and the fed ’ s projected demise in the fiscal cliff will lead to recession in 2013 , and fed chairman ben bernanke recently declared that the fed can not sterilize the negative effects of the economy .
bernanke might also have said that to the fiscal drag caused by obama ’ s budget proposals .
although congressional republicans are right to respond to higher tax rates , they seem willing to raise revenues by tax reform , if that is part of the long-term cost of cutting the main welfare program – a long-term cost of medicare and social security .
although some republicans are willing only to see revenue increases caused by faster economic growth , this goal can not be achieved , if marginal tax rates are at the top of the tax reform that democrats can not accept .
raising revenue by tax reform would mean reducing a special tax cut , which currently stands in favor of tax revenues .
the potential recession of the budget package can be avoided by adopting a way to increase the revenue of the tax base gradually .
a reasonable way to broaden the tax base would be to limit the total amount of tax cuts that each taxpayer can receive through tax breaks .
total restrictions allow each taxpayer to continue to receive all existing deductions for tax credits , but limiting the scale of the tax burden that he can cut through this approach .
the total limit would also encourage a large number of individuals who currently use a reference point to the standard deduction – which implies a dramatic simplification of tax registration , and thus improved incentives .
tax cuts to tax expenditures that stem from tax expenditures ( 2 % of each individual adjusted for each individual ’ s adjusted 毛收入 ) would raise $ 200 billion in 2013 , if applied to the current tax deduction for the interest of all municipal bonds and employers .
even if the tax cuts for charity were preserved , i regard high high-value health insurance as a tax on taxes , and the extra income that the 2013 income will still reach $ 150 billion .
ten years later , the proposal meant that an additional $ 2 trillion in revenue would be added without current increases in the tax rate .
the $ 150 billion extra income in 2013 will amount to 1 % of gdp , and the us economy is not so large , especially if it is added to government spending cuts and payroll taxes .
but the same basic framework can be achieved by erecting higher starts and reducing it for years to come .
5 % of the benefits would be $ 75 billion in revenue in 2013 , about 1 % of gdp ; but that would be a much larger amount of revenue in the coming years , when the economy is stronger .
slowing the government ’ s spending on medicare and social security is necessary to avoid a long-term explosion of national debt and higher personal tax rates .
these changes should also be implemented gradually to protect beneficiaries and avoid economic downturns .
america ’ s national debt has doubled in the last five years , unless changes in spending and tax change are implemented , and will be set to exceed 100 % of gdp over the next decade .
a combination of well-designed tax expenditures and a gradual slowdown in spending on entitlement programs could reverse the trend toward rising debt and strengthen the us economy .
the current budget negotiations in the united states should focus on a credible reduction in a credible national debt , while protecting the short-term economic expansion .
the arab “ third way ”
amman – throughout the post-colonial period , arab countries have failed to establish effective – not to mention democratic – institutions .
now , after a half-century of competition between military or royal dictatorships and military islamism , many arabs are once again looking for a “ third way ” – a path toward a credible representative democracy .
but did their efforts fail today , as they have in the past ?
the middle east – whose name is rooted in the geography of europe and east asia – belonged to 400 years of ottoman rule , and then the ottoman empire was defeated by the ottoman empire in world war i , with the middle east under the sykes-picot agreement , and the middle east is divided by the sykes-picot agreement .
but , as the new divisions emerge , the arab awakening is rooted in the arab awakening .
but they have failed to deliver better lives to their citizens , with the left losing credibility because of the collapse of the soviet union , resulting in a rival movement – political islam .
the muslim brotherhood , founded in 1928 by the egyptian town of 1928 伊斯梅 , was the most established , best organized , and most widely influenced political islam , and it was ( still so ) despised by the secular arabs and arab monarchies .
indeed , the secular dictator has imposed repression on every turn – often violent repression , such as the brutal crackdown in 1982 , when assad ruthlessly crushed the muslim brotherhood ’ s 哈马 uprising .
being forced underground by a social agenda that aims to win the needs of the poor won support , and it has become a social network of social networks through coercive “ 天课 ” ( financial donations to religion ) .
the brotherhood is prepared to secure power at a time when its conservative society and mosque help .
another islamist movement , algeria ’ s islamist salvation front , has gained this opportunity in 1991 , when it won the first round of elections .
but the military canceled the second round , thereby preventing it , triggering an eight-year civil war that has killed roughly 200,000 people .
palestine ’ s hamas is also a branch of the muslim brotherhood , which succeeded in the 2006 election campaign , but it has since failed to cede a convincing track record .
then the arab spring erupted in 2011 , creating new opportunities for political renewal .
within a few months , the islamist parties that armed the idea of 以穆 armed forces toppled secular dictators in tunisia and egypt , and are prone to take over yemen and syria , largely because they are the only well-organized political movements .
moreover , the muslim brotherhood won the largest , most influential country in the arab spring , egypt .
but their exclusive rigidity is not suited to governing such a large and diverse country .
as a result , after only one year in power , the military ousted president mohamed morsi , while backing the military ’ s backing in 2011 .
but , unable to provide political alternatives , the protesters ’ rejection of islamist governments ultimately led to a return to power centers .
some argue that arab politics lacks a secular , liberal choice because of fear of political islam .
for decades , western powers have supported military rule in the arab world , intentionally ignoring their systematic repression of democratic movements and rights , to ensure that islam does not win power .
today , both the military leadership and the institutions leading the islamic leadership have been discredited , with a vacuum in arab politics .
but today ’ s arabs – most of which are less than 30 years old – are interested in a dominant political position , preferring effective representative government , which is more willing to implement policies aimed at creating jobs and boosting economic growth .
in short , they want governments to focus on improving their people ’ s lives .
indeed , the absence of ideology is the first time in the arab spring ’ s success in egypt and tunisia , because it enabled many young activists to form loose alliances .
but the mass movement will only push a country to this point , establishing a credible representative government that demands a political party organized around well-defined guidelines .
the muslim brotherhood has the organizing principle , but its internal rigidity – at least from morsi ’ s general morsi – determines it .
at the same time , infighting among egypt ’ s liberals has determined that they can not form a disciplined , reliable alternative to the principles of the brotherhood , based on principles such as diversity , support , and respect for women and freedom of expression .
as a result , when the islamic government ’ s credibility was discredited , the military became egypt ’ s only option .
in order to make progress , the leading movement led by the arab spring must translate their common principles into effective political structures , and elect leaders who are capable of looking for consensus over individual ambition .
if they succeed , the arab world may finally be able to identify alternatives to rule by generals or mullahs .
even if they fail to win power , the emergence of such an alternative is bound to affect the arab world ’ s agenda for years to come .
