the answer to russia ’ s challenges
berlin – for 19 years , the west ( the us and europe ) have been dragging on the answers to a key strategic question : what role should post-soviet russia play in the international , european order ?
should it be treated as a difficult partner , or is it a strategic adversary ?
even in the run-up to the brief war in georgia last summer , the west was not able to provide a definitive answer to the problem .
if you follow most eastern european countries , the uk , and the bush administration , the answer is “ strategic adversary . ”
but most west european countries tend to think that russia is a “ difficult partner . ”
these two ostensibly mutually exclusive options are common in one thing : there is no end to them .
while russia is no longer the superpower of the soviet era , it remains a great power , at least in europe and asia .
in response to many regional conflicts ( iran , the middle east , afghanistan , central asia , north korea ) , and those on the agenda in the west ( climate protection , disarmament , arms control , energy security , energy security ) , western and russian cooperation is necessary .
the strategic confrontation between the west and moscow , such as the new “ 冷战 cold war , ” undermines the agenda , or at least complicate its implementation .
so , the question for the west is whether the threat emanating from russia is serious to strategic reorientation in the west ?
i think the answer is no .
putin ’ s claim to power , and its great-power policies , is structurally vulnerable .
this is especially true when oil prices fall below $ 40 per barrel .
moreover , putin knows it .
from a demographic perspective , russia is in a sharp decline ; its economic and social sectors are backsliding ; its infrastructure is lagging , and so is investment in education and vocational training .
economically , it relies mainly on energy and commodity exports , and , in its modern efforts , it largely relies on the west , particularly europe .
but , given its geopolitical position and its potential , russia remains a permanent strategic factor in europe and asia .
so it is in the west ’ s interest to integrate russia into a strategic partnership .
but achieving this will require a western policy based on long-term considerations and a self-confident and powerful position , because the kremlin will view any disagreement and weakness as an encouragement to its return to great russia .
a few months ago , the russian government proposed a proposal to negotiate a new european order within the framework of the osce framework .
russia believes that the agreement signed in the 1990 ’ s was unjust , because these agreements were based on the weakness of russia , and wanted to change them .
russia ’ s main strategic objective is to weaken nato as a nato ally , or even step back , and to re-establish its influence in eastern europe and central asia .
putin , however , has taken a big mistake , because all of these objectives are unacceptable to the west , and the kremlin does not seem to understand that nato has the best and most effective foreign policy in the past .
as a mother of marxism-leninism , its leaders still seem not to understand dialectics .
after all , if russia ’ s government really wants to change the status quo in the post-soviet status quo , it should be pursuing a policy of reducing their concerns over its neighbors , rather than raising concerns .
but , if , in turn , this applies to the west : the principle of a new europe , established by the organization for security and cooperation in europe after 1989 , could not be allowed to veto the decisions of the coalition .
the same is true of free and secret elections , as well as the inviolability of borders .
on the other hand , the missile defense system in poland and the czech republic , and the potential for nato membership in georgia and ukraine , is responsible for the underlying unnecessary confrontations .
the west should not reject russia ’ s expectations of a new european security system .
instead , it should be viewed as an opportunity to answer the key question of russia ’ s position in europe .
here , nato must play a central role , because it is absolutely necessary for most european countries and for the us .
the west and russia may be able to deal with the rules and mechanisms that the post-soviet bloc , including nato , has been governed , and the principles and institutions that russia has embraced are greatly enhanced , including the possibility of nato ’ s full membership .
the peripheral of the nato-russia council is clearly not enough , and it does not work .
but why not consider transforming nato into a true european security system , including russia ?
if this is true , the rules of the game change , and a wide range of strategic objectives – europe ’ s security , conflict between neighboring states , energy security , and arms prevention – can be achieved .
but it has a greater impact on russia .
if the west is talking about these issues in russia , without illusions , and knowing its strategic interests , the worst of a partnership with russia is failing .
of course , such an approach would require two conditions that do not exist in current conditions : the transatlantic approach to russia , and a more consistent and consistent european union .
yet the challenge posed by russia does not allow for further procrastination .
addressing it is crucial .
the uses of nuclear ambitions
madrid – on november 24 , iran and the p5+1 ( the five permanent members of the united nations security council plus germany ) demonstrate an important question about iran ’ s nuclear program : sanctions worked .
the interim agreement is for the first time in a more than a decade , iran ’ s first compromise on its nuclear program , a diplomatic victory that has long overshadowed the specter of military intervention .
but some are happy .
aside from the ambiguities and limitations of the six-month agreement , the negotiations have clearly exposed iran ’ s nuclear weapons program , which is more broadly regarded as a geostrategic symbol .
this suggests that a comprehensive agreement is difficult to achieve , and the caveat that international efforts may only be a series of small deals that delay iran ’ s nuclear weapons program , without eliminating the nuclear threat to iran .
the headlines of a historic deal mask limited and ambiguous rules .
the joint statement of the eu ’ s high representative catherine ashton and iranian foreign minister javad zarif points out that the agreement was “ a plan for joint action ” that is “ clear long-term solutions . ”
while the first step toward “ delivering a comprehensive solution and the environment ” is a first step , the interim agreement is largely a measure of trust .
indeed , the obligations called “ voluntary measures ” refer to obligations .
at best , the agreement has maintained the current status quo , allowing iran to develop further its nuclear program in some respects .
in this sense , iran ’ s arak nuclear plant , which is forthcoming , is likely to be the most troubling project in the interim agreement .
while iran promised not to transfer its nuclear fuel or heavy water in the geneva agreement , it is not entrusted to the reactor ’ s construction , but its construction of reactor construction seemed to have no effective delay .
the international atomic energy agency concluded that the arak plant ’ s 控制室 equipment and several key reactors , including cooling pumps , remain in place .
thus , iran would be using the trust of six months to advance its plutonium program .
given this week ’ s french media coverage of shiraz , the facility could be used to separate plutonium and produce the fissile material needed to produce nuclear weapons .
there is no denying that iran ’ s drive to produce nuclear weapons is partly concerned with security concerns .
but nationalism is a more important factor .
not only does all of the great powers have nuclear weapons ; in iran ’ s eyes , the problem is a small number of small states – particularly neighboring pakistan and israel – that possess nuclear weapons .
the iranians regard themselves as the heirs to the great ancient civilization of the past , and that their ambitions reflect the process of achieving regional preeminence .
moreover , they believe that their country has been discriminated against and marginalized , with aggressive international condemnation .
nearly 70 years after the bombing of hiroshima and nagasaki , the world still regards nuclear weapons as a seat in geopolitics .
germany is the only exception , but it is not particularly important on geostrategic issues ; though japan is most aware of the horrors of nuclear war , it has important powers to call for change .
the nuclear non-proliferation regime , which has become a symbol of national power , as a symbol of national power , has consolidated the world into a nuclear non-proliferation regime .
as long as possessing nuclear weapons remains the clearest way to demonstrate its great-power status , the ability to develop nuclear weapons will be tempting for countries like iran , even perjury .
we need a worldwide shift away from nuclear weapons to geopolitical power .
efforts to cut off these linkages do not succeed , as the kremlin ’ s proposal to cut nuclear stockpiles from us president barack obama can attest .
moreover , with nuclear weapons states beyond the p5+1 , the country ’ s nuclear arsenal has been nearly three times larger than it was in the past decade .
iran ’ s interim agreement is an important juncture .
after all , the agreement shows that international sanctions can work , and diplomatic progress – albeit narrow – is possible .
we can be both realistic and realistic .
but a comprehensive agreement with iran – and the necessary elements of the future – will require broader reform : this requires that the world not only abolish nuclear weapons , but also recognizes that its deterrent deterrent is unsustainable .
insecure europe
madrid – over the last five years , europe has experienced financial and economic crises , and many citizens of europe have lost their lives .
the good news is that the european union ’ s economic and monetary system has finally made progress , which will help to return to the path of growth .
but eu leaders ’ attention has focused on the eu ’ s internal , particularly security policy , which ignores external policy .
as 2014 begins , fears of economic insecurity will give way to the eu ’ s strategic orientation .
the european council ’ s meeting in december is a sign of a return to a more outward-looking policy approach , particularly on security matters .
unfortunately , this hope was quickly dashed .
in fact , the meeting passed several distinct solutions , though it is interesting , but lacks the breadth and scope of the necessary , and to consolidate through outdated and weak strategic frameworks .
the flawed nature of the current european security strategy ( ess ) , drafted in 2003 and adopted in 2008 , reflects the context of its concept .
the ess was developed in the wake of the iraq war , which was developed by a hasty and passive process , and is being held hostage by those who are intent on defining europe as america ’ s counterweight or even hostile power .
worse still , since the ess drafted , the geopolitical environment has changed fundamentally , owing to the shift toward asia , the turmoil in the arab world , renewed russian assertiveness , and america ’ s growing isolationism .
as a result , the ess has not adapted to the realities of the current world , from its opening – “ europe never so prosperous . ”
to be sure , the ess ’ s three basic principles – development assistance , soft power , and effective multilateralism remain important .
but europe ’ s leaders must reconceive these concepts in the context of today ’ s challenges .
in terms of development , europe must escape the notion that its aid must be used to increase trade linkages , and recognize the importance of foreign investment .
indeed , globally , net private capital inflows in developing countries are nearly ten times larger than official development assistance .
as the world ’ s second-largest source of foreign direct investment , the eu has considerable influence , with european investors giving the project and the region credibility , thereby facilitating more investment .
for example , morocco ’ s 扎扎 太阳能 solar power plant and its program of potable water are supported by the eu ’ s €315 million ( $ 1.3 million ) investment fund , supported by the eu ’ s 周边 investment fund .
the ess ’ s emphasis on soft power is also urgently needed .
the wave of protests in the arab world has led some europeans to believe that these countries will somehow emulate the west , values , and norms .
but , while this did not materialize , the european principles certainly have not lost their appeal , exemplified by the recent decision by president viktor yanukovych in ukraine to make a break with europe .
as the rise of non-traditional threats grows , europe has increasingly ignored traditional security risks such as inter-state warfare , arguing that they are no longer relevant – a concept reflected in the ess .
but , as china ’ s increasingly assertive stance in the south and east china seas demonstrates , this perception is not only wrong , but probably dangerous .
this brings us to the ess ’ s third principle : advancing “ a stronger international community , well-functioning international institutions , and rules-based international order . ”
here , the problem is the lack of commitment , which the eu would prefer to choose with ad hoc informal arrangements , and unwilling to reform the institutions of effective multilateralism like the un , the international monetary fund , and the world bank .
indeed , the eu has been one of the most recent “ g ” clubs – the latest version of the g-20 .
moreover , while the embodiment of international law , the eu is obsessed with the 软法 approach , whether at the cop 气候变化 conference in warsaw or the “ geneva agreement ” on iran ’ s nuclear program , it is clear that the media have greatly exaggerated the results of this .
in the process of developing new security strategies , the eu must consider america ’ s role as a key part of a geopolitical environment , and the us is not a foil , but a subtle partner .
in addition to nato ( though it is at a low ebb , it remains important ) , and the transatlantic trade and investment partnership provides a good opportunity to create a rule-based international order .
the european union may have been declining , but the spectacular images of the maidan square of kyiv are powerful reminder that europe ’ s core values remain attractive .
what the eu needs now is an updated external policy that uses its attractiveness to build influence , security , and prosperity , thereby avoiding irrelevance .
russia and the silk road approach
madrid – ukraine ’ s collapse has brought the west to three major foreign-policy challenges : the danger of isolating russia , the puzzle of china ’ s indifference , and the widespread lack of new ideas .
overcoming these challenges will require a concerted effort by countries with different political systems and national interests to strengthen cooperation and build trust .
chinese president xi jinping ’ s silk road economic belt is instructive .
europe ’ s response to the crisis in ukraine and the us has failed in two ways .
first and foremost , the response is weak , which is a sign of weakness , undermining its ability to reverse russia ’ s annexation of crimea ( which is already accepted in tactics ) and its ability to contain its aggression towards eastern ukraine .
at the same time , targeted sanctions and diplomatic boycotts have intensified russia ’ s international isolation , undermining the long-term objective of building functional relationships .
it is vital for the west to stick to its principles , including by implementing harsh sanctions , but it is also vital .
after all , a weak , isolated russia is far more dangerous than a strong and internationally integrated russia .
moreover , there is no denying that relations with russia have now burst , with mutual trust falling to the lowest level since the soviet union ’ s collapse .
in this context , bringing russia back to the international stage will require china ’ s engagement .
but , for china , the problem is complex , because it is in china ’ s interest to build closer ties to russia , and , in some ways , the parallels between china ’ s actions in tibet and russia .
given this – and china ’ s long history of gaining global leadership – it is possible that china will participate in it only if targeted incentives for specific goals are motivated by targeted goals .
and the silk road economic belt is providing this , as i saw in recent visits to beijing .
in september , the goal was to improve links between asia and the european markets , including those along the lines of 18 central asian and european countries , including russia .
the plan – aimed at building shared prosperity through people-to-people exchanges , high trade flows , and increased currency transfers – is precisely the condition of the world to avoid a return to the cold war .
after all , the best way to build cooperation and trust is to ensure that it provides clear benefits to all parties .
although chinese officials talk about strengthening people-to-people exchanges , relaxing restrictions on foreign currency , and reducing trade barriers , reviving and modernizing the old silk road will require a well-functioning infrastructure that is central to both the functioning of and multilateral connectivity .
consolidation of a powerful transport network composed of roads , waterways , air , and oceans can produce a hierarchy effect , helping to optimize supply chains , thereby providing significant – and immediate – economic benefits .
today , freight freight from china to europe is less than half that of shipping .
but there is one danger : china may pursue a bilateral approach , using the program to serve its narrow foreign-policy interests .
although china may have a way to finance the large-scale infrastructure projects that it needs , such fragmented strategies will undermine integration and increase the perception that china ’ s rise will threaten the international order .
china ’ s leaders should recognize that if the silk road economic belt is to fulfill its potential , it must take a broader vision of a broader organization comprising financing diversification , 多边 multilateral , and multiple actors .
the world bank recently supported such a model by supporting such an open perspective , which will connect multilateral , regional , and national public actors , and the private sector to finance infrastructure development .
the g-20 , the fund ’ s de facto international priority , has endorsed the project .
applying this comprehensive model to the silk road project – especially by combining europe , china , russia , and multilateral institutions – would strengthen existing incentives .
for example , this would strengthen the region ’ s economic cooperation initiative , which is now operating under the auspices of the asian development bank , which now operates under the auspices of the asian development bank .
but , beyond joint financing , effective cooperation is the key to this project ’ s success .
here , europe ’ s experience of compromise and harmonization is essential .
in order to improve its fragmented transportation system , the eu design a core corridor – compatible with major transnational traffic flows and addressing the absence of links and gaps – to form the infrastructure of integration , 互容 , and harmonization .
this approach has been a catalyst for negotiating with different stakeholders .
europe ’ s railway traffic system has overcome the lack of consensus among member states ’ security and security standards , creating a unified system that is just one of many successes in this innovative strategy .
europe has shown that a sense of common ownership , together with concrete objectives , can encourage constructive dialogue , opening the doors of mutually beneficial cooperation .
the silk road provides not only economic opportunity ; it is in the long-term security interests of participants .
today , europe can not afford to miss this opportunity , despite the destruction of a large number of connections .
making iran less cold
madrid – rapprochement between iran and the west has long been a “ 白鲸 ” of global politics .
but an increasingly obvious trend is that the world may be on the verge of a new epoch , with a new feature of the country – especially between iran and the us – but , since iran ’ s islamic revolution in 1979 , has been unable to reconcile .
the need for such cooperation led to a joint 圆桌会议 round of 贝尔格 圆桌会议 , a joint organization for science and international security , together with the institute for international security .
i attended this conference , which , by 30 politicians , senior officials , and experts from europe , the united states , and iran , discussed the future of this relationship , producing important insights into future policymaking .
in the middle east , where countries have struggled , territorial sovereignty is difficult to sustain , and , in particular , the meeting will be premature .
to reverse the middle east ’ s slide into chaos , a strong stabilizing force is needed to underpin concerted action aimed at curbing sectarian conflict .
here , iran has a key role to play .
iran ’ s history and culture have made it a certain authority in the middle east , with iran having one of the region ’ s few governments capable of responding to geopolitical developments .
this is irrelevant to its vast oil reserves , though oil reserves ensure that it is crucial in a complex global energy situation , especially for europe , which is committed to reducing its dependence on russian energy imports .
the problem is that iran has always wasted its leadership potential , choosing the role of spoilers , especially the use of proxy armies .
this upset is more necessary for cooperation , underpinned by a strong incentive for iran to maintain its constructive and moderate foreign policy .
here , iran ’ s nuclear negotiations with the e3+3 ( france , germany , and the united kingdom plus china , russia , and the united kingdom ) are important first steps .
though the latest split and sectarian violence have become more urgent , the risks associated with iran ’ s emergence as a nuclear power should not be underestimated .
further increasing the importance of current negotiations is iran ’ s domestic political dynamic .
by next year ’ s parliamentary election , iran ’ s president hassan rouhani can not bring real economic returns to the iranian people – especially the easing of international sanctions – and hardliners will reassert their dominance over iran ’ s foreign policy .
as a result , the west finally sees rouhani and iranian foreign minister javad zarif as a very enthusiastic – and ostensibly inefficient – negotiator .
perhaps the most important motivation for the e3+3 negotiations lies in removing iran ’ s nuclear status as a prerequisite for the return of the international community .
a rogue state can not play a stabilizing role in the middle east .
this is not to say that negotiators should make the deal at all costs .
if a weak agreement is reached , the lack of adequate verification mechanisms , allowing iran to retain its enrichment capability for weapons development , would do more harm than good .
in addition to stoking israel ’ s security concerns and making it more resistant to the us congress , which has already held doubt , such a pact would strengthen the position of iran ’ s spoiler , making it more difficult to engage in future constructive engagement .
reaching a fair and effective agreement is undoubtedly difficult ; but there is reason to believe that it is possible .
the current round of talks has been one of the two major sticking points of this issue – the arak reactor .
the other key issue is centrifuges .
but alternative solutions , such as those that focus on aggregate control , rather than the number of centrifuges , plus robust monitoring guarantees can help the agreement .
by addressing nuclear issues , western leaders can advance cooperation with iran in other critical areas – starting with security and stability in the middle east .
of course , iran , despite its important importance , is not enough to stop the current carnage .
given the sectarian nature of regional conflicts – and the iranian authorities ’ considerable responsibility on this issue – the engagement with iran must be conducted within a broader framework for regional cooperation , particularly in the gulf states .
because the us and europe either lack interest or lack of money , there is no effect on upheaval in the middle east , so the solution will require at least some countries with strong influence .
but , in pursuit of cooperation with countries like iran , western leaders must remain vigilant and fail to lose sight of their concerns about the disruptive potential of these regimes .
by taking this precepts into mind , the potential benefits of the west ’ s cooperation with iran will be immense .
in the coming weeks , the us and the european union will have an opportunity to take a more stable and secure middle east – an outcome that would benefit the world .
america ’ s strategic blindness
madrid – the indictment of american spy behavior by former us intelligence contractor edward j. snowden has now reached a high level .
questions abound – president barack obama knows what , when , and when the 领导人 leaders talk ; the future of the transatlantic relationship ; and even the meaning of the term “ allies . ”
but the recent firestorm , like the current current diplomatic crisis in the us , reflects a more fundamental question : the lack of strategic vision for us foreign policy .
before the us can establish an overarching , results-oriented framework to connect with the world , it will inevitably take a reactive approach , and we will continue to be the norm this month .
for more than four decades , cold war policies that contain soviet influence have been a strategic framework for america .
while there has always been debate over tactics , and as governments change , the overall approach has not changed , because it is widely supported by republicans and democrats .
of course , the national security strategy does not guarantee the problem , or even to avoid the scourge of the us in vietnam and nicaragua .
nonetheless , in hindsight , containment of us foreign policy has created an order and organization that is now lacking .
the united states , which is complacent about victory , regarded the collapse of the soviet bloc as another manifestation of its exceptionalism , and was caught in a delusion : its cold war success was a strategy .
the subsequent decade was characterized by a decade of scandalous foreign policy , which is not a case in point of view , as well as a broader view of the broader view .
in a uni-polar era , the us can not afford to account for its strategic objectives .
in september 11 , 2001 , the us was shocked by the imposition of a new framework for the historical flood of thought that has remained open to freedom .
unfortunately , there was a serious flawed approach , because the us , with its declared “ war on terror , ” is a strategy , rather than an entity or an ideology .
under obama , the us has begun to move away from this approach .
the problem is that the us has yet to find a meaningful direction .
as in the 1990 ’ s , the us has no organized priority , and the results are similar : the combination of inaction and disharmony .
in the absence of political polarization in the united states , moreover , the absence of a global strategy has left the us a 聚焦点 of a democratic and republican party .
twenty years ago , geopolitical conditions constrained the 回力 of us foreign policy .
today , the us remains the world ’ s most important power , but it is no longer the only power .
america is no longer able to solve its problems directly , though american leadership remains indispensable .
it is better to think about the nature of the problem .
like the rest of us , the us can not escape climate change , pandemics , and terrorism – challenges that will require global cooperation .
but , for the us , the efficacy of multilateralism is purely situational .
ultimately , multilateralism will never be better than a “ good ” bilateral solution – a view that reinforces the ability to weaken , rather than strengthen , effective international action .
in fact , the us is always ready to negotiate the treaty , but few are willing to sign – even less – that has left the us out of the kyoto protocol , banning landmines , and the united nations ’ convention on the law of the sea .
the creativity and support of the training and support presented by formal institutions such as the united nations and the world bank give way to a preference for weak , informal , and ad hoc groups , such as “ g ” groups and “ willing alliances . ”
establishing effective multilateralism requires emphasizing rules and institutions that favor coordination .
the us recently decided to sign the arms trade treaty , which may be a good start – as long as congress gets the bipartisan support needed to ratify it .
but scattered moves in the right direction are not enough .
what really needs is a change in mindset and mentality – a strategy that no longer views multilateralism as a strategy , but as a strategic imperative .
the recent spying scandal is the result of a lack of a different us foreign policy , focused on narrow tactical objectives that focus on the concept of comprehensive and comprehensive thinking .
the result was a transatlantic relationship , with some europeans even asking for negotiations on the proposed transatlantic trade and investment partnership ( ttip ) .
suspending trade negotiations would be foolish , not only from a regional perspective , but also because the ttip should become a global norm .
the current diplomatic crisis is also an opportunity to use it to ensure that the transatlantic discussion of privacy and surveillance can be conducted on multilateral basis ; taking advantage of this opportunity would be a small development , but a small contribution to the very lack of strategic vision that the past quarter-century has been to be .
europe ’ s juncker revolution
madrid – before being appointed as president of the european commission , jean-claude juncker was denounced as an old-school federalist , who did not benefit from it .
but the new structure that he has brought to the european commission is a radical overhaul of the brussels .
but the importance of individual commissioners is far less important than that of the european commission to shift its focus from expansion and internal market transfers to the trend toward energy and monetary union .
one of the trends is that europeans are increasingly skeptical about integration , in may ’ s european parliament election .
with a new member state backsliding – romania ’ s rule of law , bulgaria ’ s corruption , and hungary ’ s democratic norms under viktor orbán – now focus on the existing member states .
reinforcing this change is turkey ’ s drift toward authoritarianism , which threatens its eu membership .
as for ukraine , the current unity of solidarity – such as the signing of an association agreement – is unlikely to have any significant progress in the foreseeable future .
the eu ’ s enlargement as a primary policy has gone , and the european commission is preparing other important steps .
the upheaval in europe ’ s southern and eastern neighborhood may lead to a long-overdue change in the eu ’ s neighborhood policy .
in addition , europe ’ s leaders should reinvigorate the european economic area , in search of alternative solutions to the wider eu .
another policy area that is less important is internal market – a notable decision , given that it has been the core of the european project since the creation of the eu in 1958 .
the four pillars of the internal market – free movement of goods , services , capital , and human capital – carry out the eu measures , such as foreign policy and judicial and internal affairs , and now will be in new policy areas , from economic and financial affairs to digital agendas .
the shift from internal market transfers to other places is partly due to member governments ’ aversion to more eu-level legislation .
although complaints about the eu ’ s “ bloated ” ( acquis ) are often unfounded , the eu ’ s legislative process is not without shortcomings , exemplified by recent efforts to coordinate efforts .
for example , the european parliament agreed to adopt a revised directive and a new regulation that should be applied to all 28 member states , for example .
but there are more than 20 member states that have been given discretion and interpretation .
the new european commission will try to change this by focusing on rules and supervision rather than creation .
this approach would be carried out by the newly established vice-presidential positions , spearheaded by the chief vice president , aimed at establishing a combination of “ better regulation . ”
to be sure , the liberating regulatory burden is the eu ’ s long-term leitmotif .
although the previous two commissions , led by josé manuel barroso , favor rationalizing , clarifying , and compiling rules , there is little action .
juncker ’ s change , however , may portend a genuine progress on this front and a move toward monetary and energy union .
indeed , the european commission ’ s structure suggests that juncker wants to strengthen its role in guiding european monetary union and related policies .
likewise , the european commission has introduced new vice president responsible for energy affairs , and has put energy in the energy union “ energy union . ”
the absence of progress in the past two commissions is largely due to germany ’ s modernization project , which has shaped its approach to energy security .
moreover , france has been reluctant to build an interconnected european grid , owing to heavy reliance on nuclear energy .
but , given russian behavior in ukraine , eu leaders have begun to rethink this approach .
in this context , the european commission ’ s new structure – not to mention the fact that the new european council president , former polish prime minister donald tusk has long sought the energy union – may well advance this approach .
while it is impossible to know fully the european commission ’ s new structure in early stages , some institutional structures have emerged .
apart from the european council , the commission ’ s departure from legislation will change the role of the european parliament ’ s active legislative agenda in the last five years .
the european parliament has no legislation to implement legislation , so it has no choice but to pivot to oversight .
all of this will determine whether the european project is progressive or stagnant in the coming months and years .
africa beyond ebola
madrid – in the world ’ s fear of death this summer , the spread of the ebola virus dominated discussion of sub-saharan africa ’ s problems and reinvigorated the old image of chaos and despair in africa ’ s new image .
indeed , there is still strong reason for optimism in africa .
the ebola outbreak overshadowed three important events in africa .
on july 1 , the world bank group implemented a major organizational restructuring .
two weeks later , the brics ( brazil , russia , india , china , and south africa ) announced the establishment of new development banks .
in early august , african governments and business leaders gathered in washington , dc , to advance a summit of private investment in africa .
today , this investment is crucial to private net capital flows , which are ten times official .
if this becomes a turning point for africa , rather than another false rebound , this summer must be a starting point in the effort to spur private-sector involvement .
the bank ’ s restructuring is part of a broader plan led by president jim yong kim , who has sought to reassert the world bank as a facilitator of the private sector , rather than primarily aid providers .
from 2009 to 2013 , the world bank ’ s private-sector lending arm , the international finance corporation , has increased 73 % of its investment commitments .
at the same time , the international investment guarantee agency , the world bank ’ s investment guarantee agency for investment in developing countries , has taken a two-pronged approach to expanding the range of activities – expanding the types of projects it supports , and has widened existing conditions to increase coverage .
july ’ s restructuring occurs in the context of these larger moves .
at the heart of the world bank group ’ s core component , the international bank for reconstruction and development , kim has adopted a model of management advisers with expert knowledge and regional coverage .
in order to keep regional experts isolated from one another ’ s bureaucratic “ strongholds , ” the establishment of 14 energy , water , and education organizations in areas such as 14 energy , water , and education has been used to capitalize on the world bank ’ s considerable knowledge and cooperation .
as the world bank has put it in itself , the brics agreed to establish their own banks .
there are many major problems about how the new development bank works , but early indications suggest that infrastructure will be central to the bank ’ s activities , and africa is a key priority .
the world bank estimates that inadequate infrastructure has reduced productivity in africa by about 40 % .
the entry of the new development bank , which has $ 100 billion in initial grant capital – and the world bank ’ s new global infrastructure facility , which has been funded by $ 260 billion since the beginning of last year ’ s launch – could dramatically reduce infrastructure financing .
but it remains to be seen whether the new development bank is still a political union that is still more than a political unity declaration .
even if it does start , the brics lack much more to do with the legitimacy and weight of the development bank ( especially the world bank ) and the weight of experts who have the world ’ s highest level of experts .
finally , the high-level meeting of the 美非 leaders ’ summit , with more than 40 heads of state and more than 40 % of the heads of president barack obama ’ s direct involvement in the summit , has become a popular topic .
american firms and investors clearly know better about africa ’ s potential and a deeper understanding of the diversity of investment climates across the continent .
but , despite the summit ’ s success , its long-term impact remains unclear , especially given uncertainty about the future .
at the moment , it seems impossible to institutionalize the summit .
moreover , the participation of so many heads of state obscures the situation of african business leaders .
the pragmatic relationship that us companies need in deciding whether to invest in investment should have made progress during the summit , but not .
the basis for a good future will require continued commitment and effort , and only by propaganda .
the same is true of the world bank .
even in seamless transition , the world bank faces a difficult internal struggle to overcome entrenched bureaucratic interests and pervasive 厌恶 risks , excessive adherence to processes , and 制度 institutions .
in recent years , africa has emerged as a land of opportunity .
if africa is to become a land of performance , it must aim to promote investment in domestic and foreign capitals .
this will require efforts and commitments ; because a stable international order is increasingly needed to thrive , it is an opportunity that the world can not afford to lose .
europe ’ s iranian mission

anatomy of a crisis
berkeley – getting out of our current financial mess requires understanding how we are caught in .
the fundamental reason , according to people like john mccain , is greed and corruption on wall street .
while i do not deny the existence of such a dynamic , i insist that the crisis is rooted in key policy decisions in the past few decades .
in the us , there are two key decisions .
the first is deregulation of payments to brokers in the 1970 ’ s ; the second is the repeal of glass-steagall in the 1990 ’ s , when the glass-steagall act was imposed on commercial banks and investment banks .
in the time of fixed commissions , investment banks can survive by recording stock transactions .
deregulation of fixed commissions means that competition and profits are reduced , while glass-steagall removed the other traditional business areas of commercial banks .
in response , investment banks have penetrated new business areas like creating and issuing complex derivative securities .
they borrow and run to keep their profitability at service .
this triggered the first cause of the crisis : the creation of securitization and the distribution of leverage .
it is important to note that these are unintended consequences of the fundamental policy decision .
at the same time , the removal of regulations in other ways allows small investors to transact stocks at lower cost , making their economies better off .
but the fact that the investment banks , which are driven by changes in these policies , particularly in the form of changes in these policies , is entirely outside the regulatory networks , is a recipe for disaster .
conglomerates enable financial institutions to diversify their operations , with commercial banks merging investment banks to finance their operations , rather than 变幻无常 money markets .
this pattern has proved its life in several centuries in europe , even if it is now buying merrill lynch in us banks .
but conglomeratization takes time .
in the short run , merrill lynch , like other investment banks , was allowed to be permitted .
it remains outside the purview of regulation .
as a stand-alone entity , it is vulnerable to market volatility .
a crisis that would threaten the entire financial system is needed to accelerate the inevitable conglomeratization .
another factor in the crisis is a series of policies that generate global imbalances .
the bush administration tax cuts , the fed cut interest rates to respond to the 2001 recession .
meanwhile , financial innovation makes credit cheaper and more accessible to people .
of course , this is the case for subprime mortgages in another guise .
the result of these policies is that the increase in us spending and the standard household saving rate is negative .
equally important , the rise of china after the 1997-1998 financial crisis and the decline in investment in asia .
with china ’ s saving rate reaching nearly 50 % of its gnp , all of this must be spent .
many of these money entered us treasury securities and bonds that became fannie mae ’ s bonds .
this has contributed to the us dollar ’ s borrowing costs and reduced borrowing costs for households in the us , encouraging them to live in a life that they can not achieve ; that creates a dynamic market for fannie mae and freddie mac .
again , these are not entirely policy mistakes .
lifting a billion chinese out of poverty may be the most important event in our lifetimes .
the fact is that the us federal reserve ’ s rapid response in 2001 prevented the deterioration of the recession .
but , with the consequences of the plan , the us regulators failed to tighten capital and lending standards , which ignited a massive credit boom .
china ’ s failure to act quickly to encourage more domestic spending commensurate with its higher income would fuel the boom .
now , bloated financial sectors are being forced to retrench .
some of these outcomes , like the marriage of us banks and merrill lynch , are happier than others , such as the bankruptcy of lehman brothers .
but , either way , the financial sector will shrink .
foreign central banks are suffering capital losses from their unthinking investments .
when they took over us treasury and agency securities , capital flows to the us would diminish .
the us current-account deficit and the asian surplus will be reduced .
american households will have to start saving again .
one anomaly is that the dollar has strengthened in recent weeks .
a stronger dollar reflects the knee-jerk response of investors rushing into us treasuries as a safe haven .
it is worth remembering that the same thing happened when the sub-prime crisis erupted in august 2007 .
but , once investors recognize the extent of the us financial problem , the inflow of funds into us treasuries reduces the dollar , and the dollar will continue to fall .
now , when investors recall the extent of america ’ s financial problems , we will see the dollar falling again .
emphasizing greed and corruption is the root cause of the crisis .
we will not change human nature .
we can not make investors less greedy .
but emphasizing policy decisions offers a more positive outlook .
the results are not always possible .
policy mistakes are not always avoidable .
the policy mistakes , however , are at least correct . but , above all , there is a deeper understanding of the underlying causes .
anatomy of the financial crisis
new york – the united states is currently experiencing a vicious circle , and may affect the global economy .
the severe credit crunch triggered by the us economic crisis has fueled a recession in the us , and a growing recession is triggering greater losses in financial markets , undermining the broader economy .
with huge credit and asset bubbles collapsing , us financial markets are facing serious systemic risks .
the question now is not simply sub-prime mortgages , but also a “ sub-prime ” financial system .
the decline in the housing market is the worst in history in america and continuing to deteriorate every day , leading to a decline in real estate prices over 20 % , leaving millions of americans losing their homes .
defaults on debt , default , and foreclosures are moving from sub-prime to 近优 and good mortgages .
the losses associated with 贷款 investment vehicles , such as collateralized credit derivatives ( cdos ) , would total more than $ 400 billion .
moreover , commercial real estate has begun to follow a persistent decline in residential real estate .
after all , who wants to build offices , shops , and shopping malls across the 空旷 cities of the american west ?
in addition to the decline in the real estate market , a larger bubble in consumer credit is bursting : as the us economy moves into recession , the phenomenon of credit cards , auto loans , and student loans is rising sharply .
given that private consumption accounts for more than 70 % of total us demand , cutbacks in real estate consumption will compound the recession .
in these financial risks , we can add the bonds that bond insurers provide to many of the risky securitization products that are risky for cdos .
the most likely decline in these insurers ’ credit ratings will likely force banks and financial institutions that hold these risky assets to be sterilized , and thus cost the financial system more than $ 150 billion in losses .
then there is the larger losses that banks and other financial institutions have suffered in financing reckless leveraged purchases .
as the recession continues to deteriorate , many of the outstanding debt , as well as the companies that have not purchased enough liquidity , can not repay their loans as much as profits or losses .
in these circumstances , the recession would lead to a sharp increase in the number of firms that do not live up to debt , which has been very low in the last two years , averaging 0.6 % per year , compared to an all-time low of 3.8 % .
in typical recessions , the ratio of firms that do not complied with debt could rise to 10-15 % , so that institutions that hold risky corporate bonds face huge losses .
if that happens , some companies that sell such insurance would most likely fail , so that the institutions that are buying them face further losses , because they have no capacity to pay .
in addition to all of this , the financial system of non-bank financial institutions faces a shadow , and , like banks , borrowed in short and illiquid assets , and to invest in long-term and illiquid assets .
such a shadow system includes structural investment vehicles ( SIVs ) , pipelines , and money-market funds for themselves , money markets , hedge funds , hedge funds , and investment banks .
like banks , all of these financial institutions face the risk of liquidity or rollover risk , and they will collapse if their creditors fail to rollover their short-term credit lines .
but , unlike banks , they have offered no safety net as a lender of last resort .
with the current recession deepening , stock markets in the us and around the world are beginning to fall : in a typical us recession , the standard & poor ’ s 500 index will decline by 28 % as corporate revenues and profits fall .
the stock market ’ s losses would have a double effect : they reduce household wealth , thereby reducing their consumption , while causing investors to borrow in stocks , causing margin calls and asset fire sales .
these are likely to lead to a broader risk of a broader asset market in many equity and credit markets that would be forced to sell illiquid assets in illiquid markets , thereby reducing asset prices to below their fundamental value .
the ensuing losses would exacerbate the financial crisis and economic contraction .
in fact , if all of the losses in financial markets were combined , the total would be $ 1 trillion .
tighter credit ratings will further impede the ability of households and companies to borrow , consume , invest , and sustain economic growth .
the risk that a systemic financial crisis will trigger a more pronounced us and global recession has become increasingly likely .
anatomy of the revolution

anatomy of thatcherism
london – thirty years ago this month , margaret thatcher ’ s revolution in the united kingdom was followed by a 革命 revolution , as was the case in the united kingdom .
the central attribute of this theory is to substitute for government intervention , which , three decades later , is in a depression , and some blame the global crisis for several reasons .
indeed , even if not the left , the anglo-american model of capitalism has failed .
that model should be held accountable for a full-blown financial meltdown .
after three decades of reflection , we should judge what should be preserved in the thatcher revolution , which should be revised to amend , so that the future economy recovers .
for the most part , the less efficient the market for market regulation and dynamism would be for the lack of excessive government intervention .
according to the 撒切尔 , the impact of the government ’ s mistakes was far more devastating than the consequences of market failure .
history will be bad .
the data show that , between 1950 and 1973 , the government ’ s intervention in a market economy was very successful , during which the global economy was not depressed , and the growth rate of global gdp ( per capita gdp ) was better than that of previous and subsequent history .
some might argue that , if the government ’ s intervention was less , the economy would be better off .
we can only compare different policies in the past .
the conclusion we draw is that market economies , together with government regulations , are better informed by market economies and less government regulation .
then , in the 1970 ’ s , the economy was in crisis , with the most obvious symptom of “ stagflation ” – inflation and high unemployment in parallel .
it is , therefore , problematic to use keynesian theory of economic growth .
moreover , the government ’ s spending is growing , and the union ’ s 势力 policies have begun to fail , and firms ’ expectations for profits began to decline .
many people have found that governments can no longer function effectively , and the solution is only two : either further regulation or the content of abandoning some regulation .
thatcherism was clearly an alternative to state socialism .
nigel lawson was thatcher ’ s second chancellor of the exchequer , or finance minister .
as a result , the policies adopted at the time were called “ lawson principles , ” a policy launched in 1984 , a policy that has been widely used by governments and central banks .
“ to fix inflation , ” lawson said , “ should be the scope of macroeconomic policy .
and the problem of economic growth and job creation is the scope of microeconomic policies . ”
the proposal overturned the prevailing orthodoxy that the aim of macroeconomic policy was to ensure full employment , and to control inflation .
despite the introduction of the “ supply side ” of the thatcher government at the time , the unemployment rate reached 7.4 % in the 1980 ’ s and is still above 1.6 % in the 1950s and 1960s .
what is the purpose of controlling inflation ?
the 1980 ’ s inflation rate had peaked , despite the deflationary pressure from low-wage competition from asia , which in 1980 and the 1980 ’ s from 1980 to 2007 , and the 1980 ’ s .
and , in view of this , controlling inflation did not prevent the emergence of subsequent asset bubbles , eventually leading to depression .
nor did the policies of thatcher address the main problem – how to reduce the share of government spending in national income .
at the time , the policy was to say that policies prevented further increases in government spending .
now that government spending has increased as much as 10 % of gdp , the fiscal deficit has reached record highs for peacetime .
in the world ’ s lower regulatory fashion , thatcher ’ s revolution led to a 铜臭味 revolution , with no increase in wealth – except for the wealthy .
if global gdp growth were to rise to the level of growth between 1950 and 2007 , global per capita gdp will be 20 % higher than it is now – and it is not excluded from china ’ s growth rate over the past 20 years .
thanks to the idea that thatcherism promoted , the morality of western societies began to fall .
in addition to these three shortcomings , thatcherism brought three benefits to us .
the first is privatization .
by privatizing most state-owned enterprises , thatcher ’ s revolution eliminated state socialism .
the former communist countries could also learn from the british privatization movement , which can be transformed from the ideas and tactics of the transition to a 计划 program of economic system .
the same idea could , of course , be used in the current fashion of “ nationalization . ”
thatcherism ’ s second great success was to weaken unions ’ power .
in the 1970 ’ s , labor unions , which serve as a defender of the vulnerable , became a resistance to economic development , with social conservatism .
finally , thatcherism ended fixing prices and the mandatory system of wages , ending the government ’ s tripartite games between governments , employers , and unions .
if this is allowed to happen , fascism and communism will emerge , and they will ultimately destroy not just economic , but political and freedom .
political pendulums sometimes overshoot .
in re-establishing the 形态 economy , we should be careful not to repeat the failed policies of the past .
as long as the central government is able to maintain a full and stable employment environment , keynes ’ s ideas , most of which should not be disrupted , should be left free .
building a proper dividing line between government intervention and free markets is the main task we face today .

nato ’ s new frontier
brussels – this week , an american ship sailed into a spanish naval base .
the new 母港 罗塔港 , the uss donald cook , arrived in the country ’ s new 母港 罗塔港 , a 母港 弹道导弹 defense defense system for the first time in the united states , where the us navy is in place .
唐纳德 cook , a 美舰 of 1,200 workers and sailors , will be one of four us navy destroyers that play a central role in nato ’ s missile-defense system .
there are also many other tasks , including maritime security operations , bilateral and multilateral training exercises , and deployment of nato operations ( including the permanent nato maritime organization ) .
the arrival of the uss donald cook marks a step forward in europe ’ s security and transatlantic cooperation .
since november 2010 , the united states and europe have steadily moved forward , with nato at the time of the lisbon summit on the lisbon summit to protect all nato citizens , territory , and military forces .
in april 2012 , nato announced its phased performance at the chicago summit , and was seen as a key step in the project ’ s implementation .
achieving full capability is expected in the coming years .
the purpose of nato ’ s missile-defense system is to defend europe in the event of real threats .
it is at least 30 times that the world has a ballistic missile or is trying to master the technology .
the knowledge needed to create a ballistic missile is increasingly being held by a growing number of countries , and the range of missiles in some parts of the euro-atlantic region is already in place .
the uss donald cook and the three other us destroyers have advanced 传感 and interceptors that can detect and shoot down ballistic missiles targeting europe .
other important components of the future missile defense system will include more radars , sensors , and interceptors – and more ships .
as it stands , thanks to the phased adaptive approach to missile defense in the us , nato can already rely on turkey ’ s powerful radar equipment .
already , romania has begun to build a land-based interceptor and radar site .
poland has announced its own air defense and missile-defense capabilities .
the netherlands is 为 four radar frigates , and has already contributed to the missile defense system .
germany has taken a similar step .
the netherlands , germany , and the us have already deployed patriot missiles in nato ’ s eastern border to help defend and protect turkey from possible missile attacks in syria .
at the same time , spain has allowed four us navy destroyers to be important not only for nato ’ s missile defense , but also to ensure that the entire mediterranean region is secure .
to connect all of these assets together , nato has built and is expanding a technologically advanced command-and-control system based on 德国 air base in germany .
the system already connects satellites , radars , and interceptors to defend against missile attacks , which will become more complex and flexible in the coming years .
this makes nato unique : it is the only multilateral organization capable of integrating the world ’ s most sophisticated countries into effective overall .
most important , such deployments have promoted transatlantic cooperation , because the ships represent far more than military capabilities .
each is a memo for america ’ s commitment to protecting europe ’ s security .
at the same time , nato ’ s missile defense shows that european allies ’ security commitments in the area of missile defense are in place .
i call for all allies to think hard about what can be done to secure defense systems that protect the entire european security .
missile defense heralds a new form of cooperation , one that responds to new threats .
once we build tanks along the border zone , we can now build a complex , complex , and 空 system that requires many allies to contribute a range of high-tech products .
nato ’ s missile-defense system embodies the transatlantic teamwork of the twenty-first century .
the antarctic point of return
potsdam – recent satellite observations confirm the discovery of two separate computer simulations : the west antarctic ice sheet ’ s ice sheet has become unstoppable .
the planet is now in a new era of irreversible consequences for climate change .
the only question now is whether we can prevent similar situations elsewhere .
the higher the global temperature , the greater the risk of antarctica ’ s rest , and the greater the risk that the antarctic basin is now at risk of a similar threat to the west ’ s surface , or even the 更胜一筹 basin .
we can not reasonably predict the impact of some human activities in advance , centuries , and even millennia .
the impact of nuclear waste is only one ; global warming caused by burning fossil fuels by burning greenhouse gases is another possible impact .
indeed , the recently released intergovernmental panel on climate change ( ipcc ) reports that the level of sea-level “ almost no doubt ” will continue to rise in the next couple or even centuries .
moreover , the more carbon emissions are emitted , the greater the sea-level rise .
but this is not in antarctica ’ s latest situation .
the west antarctic ice sheet suddenly “ crossed the tipping point ” into a new state of affairs , and it has not been able to anticipate incremental changes in global warming .
a small fraction of the 融冰 on the maritime sea has pushed the horizon to a 掩盖 hill , and now is in a state of “ decline . ”
simply put , a dramatic change in external temperatures will be sufficient to jump-start the internal stress mechanism , and that even if humans wanted to stop it , they will be difficult to stop .
whether the outcome of human activity is the result of human activity is not yet clear – but not a similar change in the new era of the planet ’ s energy balance .
but that is not the point .
what matters is that we must recognize that the earth ’ s climate system has a huge component – for example , west antarctica ’ s 三千万 ice sheet – that can break the balance .
this is not just theoretical risk .
the same conclusion has been observed and the computer simulations that the west ’ s vast 阿蒙森 sea ice sheet has already begun irreversibly melting , and any factor that has since failed to prevent the entire basin from melting is no longer possible .
the west antarctic ice sheet has been on the back burner .
so we must now focus on similar terrain elsewhere .
if the “ 冰塞 ” melting near the coast of vilks or the tip of the iceberg becomes iceberg , the basin ’ s huge 储水量 will eventually flow into the ocean .
while no one knows what would undermine the stability of vilks ’ basin , we can certainly increase the risk of global warming caused by greenhouse-gas emissions .
the fact that sea levels will continue to rise is clear .
but we can still determine how fast and speed the sea levels will rise by controlling our global warming .
climate change is humankind , so the good news is that humans can curb climate change by cutting greenhouse-gas emissions .
while west antarctica ’ s west ice sheet is bound to fail , we can still protect the marine ice sheet in antarctica .
that means deciding how to respond sooner rather than later .
the current response could further threaten the stability of the antarctic ice sheet ; it is our best and last hope that the world will embark on new energy sources .
reviving ukraine ’ s economy
washington , dc – ukraine has suddenly moved to democracy .
following former president viktor yanukovych ’ s massive bloodshed , many of his members ’ mps turned to the opposition , creating another majority .
in order to consolidate its regime , in order to consolidate its regime , they will have to act quickly – and accept some degree of international assistance – to restructure the country ’ s crisis-torn economy .
ukraine faces three economic problems .
last year , ukraine ’ s current-account deficit amounted to about 8.3 % of gdp , leading to a reduction in its foreign-exchange reserves and only two months of imports .
second , public finances are also unsustainable , with national fiscal deficits running at 8 % of gdp and higher interest rates on government bonds .
third , the country has experienced a recession of five consecutive quarters since 2012 .
these are precisely the consequences of yanukovych ’ s economic policies , which only one purpose : for the president and his family cronies .
over the last four years , ukraine ’ s leaders have been paying unprecedented sums of money , estimating that the yanukovych family has amassed $ 12 billion in wealth .
the new government will need international assistance if it is to close some of its hole .
with yanukovych ’ s ouster , the regime ’ s blackmail of ukrainian firms should be increased , allowing the economy to recover .
indeed , ukraine ’ s economy achieved 3.3 % growth in the fourth quarter of 2013 , owing to the protests of the president ’ s cronies .
but much can and must be done to act quickly , because ukraine ’ s coffers are running dry .
first , the new parliamentary majority needs to appoint a new government and launch a new economic-policy agenda .
at the same time , a new central banker should be appointed , and his top priority is to float the exchange rate .
this would trigger a 10 % devaluation of ukraine ’ s currency , the hryvnia , and thus contain a recent downward trend in exchange rates , eliminating the current-account deficit , and reducing ukraine ’ s high interest rates .
once the new government was created , the international monetary fund should send an immediate delegation to ukraine .
within two weeks , the delegation will be accompanied by a new , financial stabilization policy .
the imf should be able to make a first big disbursement in late march .
the imf could lend to ukraine $ 120 billion for a year of stability , and the eu would be able to make $ 3-5 billion to the imf ’ s share of its payments facility with the imf .
these two sources alone could pay a large share of the $ 35 billion of external financing that ukrainian proxy finance minister 尤里 柯 has proposed for two years .
moreover , the imf ’ s lending rate is lower than that of yanukovych ’ s government ( and is unlikely to continue ) , and maturities are longer .
and the conditions for the imf would help ukraine to remove yanukovych ’ s venal policies .
for starters , ukraine must drastically cut its fiscal deficit , while considering its large tax revenues , which can be combined with spending cuts and freezes .
massive industrial subsidies – for example , for the coal industry – must be canceled without and only enriching yanukovych ’ s supporters .
likewise , gas prices must be liberalized in order to keep those regulators from reaping the rewards .
what is being bailed out is poor consumers , not producers .
likewise , the imf will insist that the ukrainian government re-impose competitive tenders .
since 2010 , orderly public procurement has been stopped , with yanukovych ’ s direct government contracts to be twice as high as market prices and colleagues .
of course , sales of state-owned enterprises to loyalists – often at the lowest price – must end .
another source of corruption is a tax cut for export tax on exporters , where top tax officials receive fees .
stopping such behavior would stimulate exports .
moreover , ukraine should reintroduce the simplified tax code that yanukovych abolished .
ukraine also needs to work with the eu .
within a week , the new government will meet the conditions for a long-term association agreement with the eu , and that should be the eu ’ s agenda in march .
the parliament has arranged for a new election , and former prime minister yuliya tymoshenko has released from prison .
the eu ’ s last condition – legislation that reform prosecutor ’ s office – will soon be realized .
the eu ’ s association agreement with ukraine would greatly benefit ukraine .
it amounts to a comprehensive reform program for the ukrainian state apparatus , including its law-enforcement agencies .
sixty countries across the eu have already agreed on the necessary reforms with their ukrainian counterparts .
the agreement also includes a deep and comprehensive free-trade area that opened the vast european market to ukrainian exporters – and thus to ukraine to attract more foreign direct investment .
this would also help to protect the country from russia ’ s possible trade sanctions .
here , too , foreign policy will play an important role .
the us and the eu need to persuade russian president vladimir putin to reach an understanding of the new ukraine ’ s leader , vladimir putin , rather than by threatening to impose sanctions on him .
peaceful coexistence , not bilateral tension , can maximize two national interests .

running in place
santiago – a billionaire who owns harvard ’ s degree , chile ’ s president , has pledged to strengthen productivity and competitiveness , and win the election .
after taking office in 2010 , chile ’ s economy quickly recovered from the global financial crisis , job creation was created , and has been growing .
nor did the billionaire ever shy away from expressions of his accomplishments .
chile has shown that chile is a case of successful market reform , and he will leave the president on march 11 .
he is wrong .
worse , economic expansion proved unsustainable , and chileans will soon feel the consequences of piñera ’ s failure to deliver on their promises of growth .
during the 2008-2009 financial crisis , chile was hit hard : foreign loans disappeared , and the price of copper plummeted in major exports .
but this time , the chilean economy is well enough to withstand large-scale external shocks .
the government has been running surpluses , public debt is negligible , and banking supervision is very good .
as a result , president michelle bachelet , who has just been sworn in in 2010 and has just been sworn for the second term , could embrace a potent anti-crisis fiscal stimulus , financed by resources that had been stored in the previous copper boom .
the central bank , steered out of political pressure , 由广受 professionals , also intervened in a large interest rate .
in europe , the recession has lasted six years and continues ; in chile , the recession lasted ten months .
strict regulation and record-low interest rates allow firms and households to accumulate debt without having to accumulate debt .
in late 2009 , chile ’ s economy began growing again , with growth having been highly favorable to the external environment since then .
chile wants high commodity prices , rock-bottom dollar interest rates , and abundant international liquidity ; and , since 2010 , these have been met .
not surprisingly , chile ’ s rapid growth , until the us federal reserve began tapering qe at the end of last year , has caused economic activity to slow rapidly .
four years after the average annual gdp growth rate of more than 5 % , chile ’ s economy is expected to fall to 3.7 % or less in 2014 .
piñera blamed the incoming bachelet administration as a culprit for declining growth rates .
in that case , bachelet ’ s economists are so influential , because all latin american countries and emerging countries have experienced similar slowdowns .
the immediate cause of chile ’ s slowdown is the drop in investment , especially the drop in mining investment ; but the underlying problem is that there is no adequate economic diversification , which makes it difficult to understand which new investment and which new exports can be built .
exports of diversified countries such as thailand , malaysia , mexico , and ireland have changed a generation ago .
by contrast , chile ’ s exports basket remained unchanged .
in 1984 , chile exported copper and other raw materials , paper and pulp , fruits and wine , 鱼粉 , and 少量 manufactured goods .
three decades later , chile ’ s export basket remains such a thing .
energy investment may be able to start – but it will be possible to modernize chile ’ s institutions as possible .
this is another vestige of piñera ’ s legacy .
chile , with its neighbors , does not produce oil and gas .
today , chile ’ s electricity prices are the region ’ s 追高 , because generating electricity is less than growing .
a long saga could lead to the failure of the lights for years to come .
ensuring that cheap energy and clean environments are a huge challenge is a huge challenge .
experts agree that this requires national planning to deploy the country ’ s mountainous power plants , amend transmission mechanisms , and use natural gas , and the use of renewable energy , particularly wind and solar power .
unfortunately , piñera has done nothing in these areas .
employment policy is another shortcoming of the piñera administration .
while the recovery of the unemployment rate has fallen since 2009 , it has made little sense for governments to focus on the labor market , which leaves countless women and chilean youth excluded .
but these problems are politically sensitive , and small legal changes will lead to significant opposition .
piñera adopted a security approach – not attempting any change .
of course , the prospects for a job will be improved in chile , where they receive a first-rate education .
chile has done very well in terms of education , where enrollment is already comparable to that of developed countries ; but there is little success in ensuring that young people – especially children in low-income households – have achieved quality education .
piñera ’ s government , however , should pay a tension with student students who pay a college student .
this rivalry impedes other changes in education .
bachelet has promised to end this impasse and make education reform her government ’ s priority .
the goal is laudable , but achieving goals will not be easy .
every year , chile ’ s finance ministry will be independent of an independent group of experts to assess how high chile can achieve without inflation and other imbalances .
in the run-up to chile ’ s financial crisis in 2008 , the average answer provided by experts was 4.83 % .
in 2013 , three years after the center-right government took office , the answer is … % .
under piñera ’ s government , pro-growth rhetoric was abundant .
but rhetoric alone can not boost the economy ’ s growth trajectory .

not always .
not long ago , in latin america , life and freedom were seen as universal rights , and should be protected from national boundaries .
my father was a chilean lawyer and human-rights activist .
general augusto pinochet and our family removed him from our family , and my adolescence and the early days of the adult have been in exile and fear in exile , from exile in chile , argentina , brazil , and uruguay .

today , anyone accused of violence in venezuela is – in the words of president nicolás maduro – fascism , american imperialism .

so do venezuelan demonstrators .
in this context , the principle of autonomous principle of autonomy that foreign ministries have always heard is an empty slogan .

the federation , reminiscent of stalin ’ s tone in the 1950 ’ s , condemned the venezuelan students ’ “ to defend the old order ” and “ deviation from the path of the people ’ s chosen paths . ”
the problem with this argument ( if it can be called the point ) is that “ people ” do not speak out with a voice , nor do they make a full voice .
to figure out what really people want and respond accordingly , democracies have procedures , constitutional guarantees , and individual rights .
when these are trampled upon – as in venezuela – people simply can not speak freely and choose the path of the road freely .
the idea that maduro ’ s actions must be legitimate , because he was in power by elections , is equally mistaken .
democratically elected leaders have legitimacy only when they govern democratically .
georgetown university professor 夏米 夏米 recently recalled that portugal ’ s neo-nazis , paraguay ’ s 斯特 罗斯纳 , and indonesia ’ s suharto were all running out of power by running out of power , but not in history .

their struggle for democratic rights is a struggle for all .
latin american people know this , even if their leaders are not always willing to say loud .
