the next step in this ideological modernization is the inter-american development bank : the bank ’ s call for industrial policy in latin america .
this is a welcome development .
to be sure , the inter-american development bank , unlike the two institutions that emerged from the bretton woods system , is also the traditional international financial bureaucracy , with no industrial policy right ; it used the right phrase : “ productive development policies . ”
but the message is clear : in latin america , public policy should play a role in determining what to produce .
now it is common sense .
last week , economists from the inter-american development bank met in santiago , chile , for their proposal .
chile has been a model for economic management in latin america for decades , as well as the mirror of all latin american economies .
falling commodity prices , rising dollar interest rates , and a sharp rise in the dollar ’ s interest rate have slowed sharply .
productivity growth has barely grown in nearly 15 years , and its exports are as different as in the 1980s .
chile ’ s growth problem is the smallest in the region .
it is one of the region ’ s only four countries , which have shrunk per capita income relative to the us since 1960 ( another three are brazil , panama , and the dominican republic ) .
the inter-american development bank pointed out that productivity in most of latin america has been stagnant for a half-century of time .
what can be done ?
the conventional prescription includes improving education ( especially technical education ) , modernizing labor markets , reducing bureaucratic red tape , and promoting foreign investment and technology transfer .
the iadb has now joined or “ 横向 ” productive development policies on this standard list .
horizontal pdps provide the inputs that are needed for companies in different sectors to grow and grow .
a simple example involves transport infrastructure , trained engineers , and labor force proficient in english .
more sophisticated examples include systems for health and safety inspection , certification certification , or intellectual property protection .
the problem is that some of these public provision can be used only for specific sectors or products .
roads to remote and beautiful mountains boost eco-tourism , but do nothing to move goods to the nearest port .
the lab used to detect whether beef is contained is no useful for examining fruit and vegetable exports .
that is where vertical policies – policies that benefit the benefits of specific sectors – are coming .
horizontal pdps are relatively small , but vertical pdps may have severe criticism , and skeptics claim that they are “ picking winners . ”
but , as these examples suggest , the line between horizontal and vertical policies is inevitable .
in other words , when governments provide funds to train a particular type of engineers , build a particular road , or build a particular lab , they have no favors in some sectors , thereby picking the winners .
the iadb argues that the best , transparent implementation of this policy , and introducing appropriate checks and balances .
vertical policies can also be used to address the failures of cooperation .
consider tourism , where there is plenty of room for tourism .
but no private enterprise will build a hotel in so remote , sparsely populated regions without the lead .
by contrast , without hotels and 客栈 , there will be no government officials to think that they will build roads , because they do not make sense .
tourism can not take off without deliberate private-public partnerships .
the skeptics also point out that latin america has experienced a wave of industrial policy in the 1960s and 1960s , with only patchy effects .
the iadb report provides a balanced assessment of this history .
making matters worse , the government has helped to get away with the weak and powerful .
in asia , many firms that initially helped sooner or later grow into world-class competitors .
but , in latin america , where there is little market and policy discipline and chronically overvalued exchange rates , such a shift is seldom occurring .
to be sure , these problems need to be overcome .
but the inter-american development bank argues that latin american governments may go too far : “ today , policymakers and analysts are becoming increasingly aware of the possibility that industrial policy can be kept together with the bathwater . ”
it is increasingly evident that the problem is not whether to adopt productive development policies , but how to adopt it .
unlike the archaic industrial policy of the 1960 ’ s , modern pdps aim to address market failures , not to abolish market incentives .
market failures are not the only problem .
a new approach to pdps also fears national failure .
national institutions may be captured by interest groups , and aid can be used for private or political purposes .
to prevent this , the report again deviates from the orthodoxy that countries recognize and replicate the “ best practices ” of the country .
if these best practices require conditions that local governments can not provide , this approach will not succeed .
as a result , “ the core should not be in policy best practices , but it should be in the most institutional capacity . ”
latin america needs a lot of fresh thinking and policy innovations if it is to sustain growth during the commodity boom .
no policy can be saved .
but the approach proposed by the iadb report is the most promising approach .
dead cow walking ?
santiago – a statue of american independence hero , a country that wants to unite the continent as a whole , would be a recipe for the unraveling of today ’ s south american energy sector .
no doubt , he can easily see that no society can build on such a decentralized basis .
peru has gas and sold it to mexico .

while brazil discovered hydrocarbons across the atlantic deep years ago and started auctions , it began to produce more years .
chile has no oil and gas , and no single neighbor will sell it , so it has to buy from distant indonesia .
moreover , south america ’ s electricity grid is often inconsistent with the same , with electricity prices very different .
brazil and chile have the highest electricity prices in south america ( and are not so much in the world ) .
their industrial competitiveness and consumer budgets are thus affected .
optimists imagine that the production of productive , pipeline construction is fully , 互通 , and natural gas in bolivia , argentina , and elsewhere to boost growth across the continent and benefit everyone .
but this dream has always met with formidable obstacles : for decades , the national rivalries have repeatedly been able to block the energy integration agreement , which has been produced for centuries .
for example , ten years ago , chile and argentina signed contracts to supply gas to the former in order to supply gas to the former .
but , after a long period of price controls and underinvestment , domestic demand in argentina exceeded supply .
thus , then-president néstor kirchner ’ s government broke down the contract with chile , cutting off gas exports to chile , causing serious damage to chile ’ s economic growth , severely hurting the chilean people .
but now a new powerful factor may change this dismal political situation : shale gas has already had a significant impact on the us and its economy .
america ’ s natural and us prices have fallen to just over $ 4 per 百万 ( $ 13 years ago ) , even cautious analysts believe that the shale-energy revolution will boost america ’ s potential economic growth and increase the number of new jobs .
the impact of shale energy on south america is twofold .
for starters , the cost of imports from countries with no gas ( such as chile ) and local demand , such as those in brazil , could fall .
for countries like chile , large hydroelectric projects tend to lead to political controversy , with solar and wind power slowly and slow , and gas imports from the us will be a powerful boon .
in 2013 , the us department of energy approved the first large-scale gas export facilities ; despite the absence of stable gas flows , the gap between us and global gas prices meant its potential .
more recently , shale gas is development .
argentina reportedly has the world ’ s third-largest shale-gas reserves , after the us and china .
the vast death of the energy company ypf ( dead cow ) , with a 巨大 ( dead cow ) field , has begun exploration .
argentina ’ s government nationalized ypf from spain ’ s repsol in 2012 , resulting in lawsuits and lawsuits that delay potential investment in shale gas .
recently , however , argentina and repsol have reached a settlement , with interest in investment in shale gas being revived .
to be sure , there is a huge technological challenge for exploring the shale-gas reserves , with only a handful of companies worldwide having the skills to do so .
the financial challenge is even more severe : analysts predict a hundred hundred or even hundreds of billions of dollars .
but the potential for argentina and the region is enormous .
axel sturzenegger , the president of argentina ’ s economist , has estimates that the value of the gas field ( currently measured in argentina ’ s current gas imports ) is nine times the value of argentina ’ s gdp .
but , with global prices likely to fall rapidly as the us joined the exporting countries , argentina must act quickly to seize this potential .
sturzenegger ’ s decision on shale gas is the “ most important ” decision in argentina ’ s economic history .
argentina ’ s choice will affect not only the region ’ s economy , but also regional politics .
because the cow of the cow is far more expensive than argentina ’ s , exports will be inevitable , and neighboring brazil and chile are natural customers .
the shift in the balance of power in south america , in turn , could turn nationalists in bolivia , peru , and elsewhere into rethink their policies .
integration of oil , gas , and other energy industries , together with the interconnection of the national power grid , may occur .
the economic and political landscape in south america is changing permanently .
does this be too optimistic ?
perhaps .
in south america , it remains to be built to ensure that energy flows are safe and reliable .
as the region ’ s history shows , it is not a simple task .
but if the stakes are so high , the potential is so large , we should at least remain hopeful .

the third way ’ s second chance
santiago – remember tony blair and clinton ’ s third way ?
it is back .
the face and name , but the government can – and should – combine the idea of social democracy and modern liberal economics .
the third way that the third way , at the meeting of berlin ’ s leaders , hosted by german chancellor gerhard schröder in june 2000 , seemed to be the future .
the conference was tony blair ’ s handpicked product ( though he did not attend ) .
leaders in sweden and new zealand argue that you can make the country more hospitable and effective .
and south africa ’ s mbeki , fernando henrique cardoso , brazil ’ s fernando henrique cardoso , and chile ’ s lagos ( i am a member of lagos ’ s delegation ) , declared that the third way can go well to the so-called third world .
unfortunately , this does not last .
the sound argument for progressive governance has not easily become a permanent political philosophy .
al gore traded clintonomics for traditional populism , and was defeated by george w. bush .
social democrats and their allies lost power in several european countries .
the iraq war and the 2008-2009 global financial crisis led to serious criticism of the policies advocated by third way leaders .
fast to the status quo .
italy ’ s 39-year-old socialist prime minister , matteo renzi , is often called italy ’ s last hope .
he promised ( though not yet ) a deep labor market and fiscal reform .
after the election victory , renzi received praise from blair himself , and blair called “ matteo renzi ’ s dynamism , creativity , and toughness . ”
socialist prime minister manuel valls , france ’ s socialist prime minister , is betting on political capital on an ambitious tax and spending plan that is not supported by its own party .
critics from the orthodox left accuse him of “ taking a solution to blair and schroeder . ”
renzi and valls – and pedro sánchez of spain ’ s socialist party – are part of a broader trend .
as the world economy slows , many center-left politicians are trying to mobilize markets and stimulate growth while investing in jobs and skills .
the urgent need for a return to the third way is thus to return to the third way .
unsurprisingly , europe ’ s heavily indebted governments are moving in new social policies that are fiscal .
but the harsh austerity pursued by german conservatism is not the same as the gradual adjustment pursued by the new generation of southern european social democrats .
conservatives demand fiscal adjustment , regardless of the outcome .
the modern social democrats who read keynes know that some immediate adjustment is necessary to make the plan credible .
but they also know that increased spending on human capital and physical infrastructure is necessary to limit the impact of fiscal contraction on employment and wages , and to strengthen the economy ’ s growth potential .
another reason why the third way of thinking to regain the market is that it works .
schroeder ’ s effort to restructure germany ’ s labor market in the early 2000 ’ s was controversial at the time ; but , in hindsight , schröder ’ s efforts turned germany from the sick man of europe into a continental export champion .
the nordic countries are the pioneer of a new approach to experimenting with a new approach , while adopting “ flexicurity ” in the labor relationship .
as a result : they have achieved the trifecta of robust growth , high employment , and low public debt .
the effectiveness of this idea is not limited to the rich countries of the north .
the government of the concertación , garcía garcía garcía in peru , and fernando henrique cardoso in brazil , has taken inspiration from the 日程 agenda .
they have ( or led ) to their respective countries .
but they have no denying their country ’ s unprecedented democratic integration and economic modernization .
it is not surprising that aécio neves , a party in the same party as cardoso , did .
but the socialist silva is so remarkable that she has signed a new trade pact that transcends mercosur ( mercosur ) , to make the bcb independent .
blair , who gave the bank of england full independence in his first week in office , will be proud .
there are many differences between countries and time , but they include four shared ideas .
the first is policy pragmatism .
what matters is what works , not what is ideologically pure .
the debate about whether countries should be big or 小些 is both cumbersome and meaningless , and it is more effective to ask what kind of state intervention , where it is actually done .
the second idea is fiscal realism .
budget prudence is worth pursuing ( unsustainable deficits as a way to continue ) , and progressive ( when the poor and vulnerable suffer disproportionately ) .
the third idea is modern welfare states .
countries can and should redistribute income and wealth , but they can not undermine incentives to work and save .
governments can not simply engage in propaganda , but they should work to ensure good jobs and good income .
finally , the third way is defined by progressive liberalism .
liberty and equality are complementary , not contradictory , principles .
if the rules are properly formulated , the societies of people freely determine and act can be a society in which opportunities are distributed equitably .
conversely , without minimum equality , freedom can be a mirage .
these four ideas have given way to the third way , making it a second chance – though it should have been the first option for all .
the lawless sea
santiago – the rule of law is virtually non-existent , with little governance and policy .
illegal , unreported , and unregulated economic activity is rampant .
the powerful seize non-renewable resources .
environmental degradation is rising .
that sounds like a description of a failed state , a desperate poor country beset by civil war , or fictional 异邦 .
nor is it .
with a vast land of near anarchy ( 45 % of the earth ’ s surface ) , its name is the high seas .
how is this possible ?
after all , in 1982 , there was a legally binding un convention on the law of the sea ( unclos ) , and 166 countries and the eu signed the treaty .
at unclos , the high seas were protected , because they were hard to enter .
but technological advances have enabled resource exploration to be much deeper than ever before .
unclos has not kept pace with the development of the age .
industries and activities such as fisheries , shipping , and seabed mining are both independent .
there is no governance framework for emerging high-seas industries such as energy production .
transparency and accountability are weak , and there is no enforcement of law enforcement .
moreover , the authorities have limited power to intercept vessels suspected of illegal activity .
as a result , international cooperation against illegal fishing , weapons , and drug trafficking , population trafficking , and drug trafficking , and the international cooperation of vessels engaged in terrorist operations , has been severely strained .
the results are dire .
the ocean is the earth ’ s life-support system , and its health and productivity depend on the oceans .
but overfishing and pollution are causing serious damage .
the ocean waste will cause a million 海鸟 and 100,000 mammals ( seals , whales , and dolphins ) to die from drowning , asphyxiation , or starvation .
plastic pollution – including the fragmentation and the harmful plastics of the food chain – is becoming a growing problem .
likewise , rising temperatures are causing the ocean to decline .
the increase in carbon dioxide emissions is causing ocean acidification and unprecedented changes in chemical and 物理性质 , which in turn affects marine life and ecosystems .
every life in the global ocean is under threat .
today , we need to introduce the law of the sea , which is the aim of the global ocean commission .
the global ocean commission is an independent international institution comprising former heads of state , government ministers , and business leaders .
i am one of the commissioners .
last week , we proposed a package of remedies for improving governance and restoring ocean health efforts .
to strengthen high-seas governance , the global ocean commission calls for a new agreement based on unclos to protect biological diversity outside of national jurisdictions .
so far , less than 1 % of the high-seas ocean is protected , so the new deal includes provisions for establishing protected areas in the high seas .
we also propose an international agreement to assume responsibility and compensation for the economic losses and ecological damage caused by offshore oil and gas extraction and production . offshore oil and gas extraction should be subject to legally binding security agreements .
despite being in excess of overfishing , a handful of countries – including the united states , japan , and china , as well as the european union – are deliberately supporting industrial high-seas fishing .
without subsidies , high-seas fisheries would be unprofitable .
we propose immediate restrictions on high-seas fisheries and eliminate the subsidy within five years , and countries ’ fisheries subsidies should be transparent , and about 60 % to encourage sustainable fishing operations .
moreover , in order to eliminate the illegal fishing of the marine and marine life , we call for mandatory identification numbers , tracking all high-seas fishing vessels , and prohibit sea transit altogether .
by closing loopholes , we will ultimately leave fish caught with illegal fishing unable to grow and lose market .
the international ocean accountability board , which is accountable to an independent global ocean , is to monitor progress in all of these areas .
if the ocean worsens , and without adequate safeguards , the international community will have to consider that the international community will have to take the place of the high seas – in the region , where fisheries management is effective – as a ban on industrial fishing .
we can reverse the degradation of marine oceans , turning the cycle into a cycle of renewal .
bringing about change requires political will , and a concerted effort by governments , businesses , and civil society .
this can and must be done .
join us : //missionocean.me .
now it must take action .
unless we take strong governance , use the necessary means to enforce regulations , rampant 盗捕 will continue to lawlessness , without binding international security standards for deep sea oil and gas drilling , plastic pollution , and abandoned fishing tools .
the more the world ’ s ocean survives , the more our future generations will survive .
argentina ’ s use and abuse of keynes
buenos aires – us republican president richard nixon famously said in 1971 that “ we are all keynesians now . ”
axel kicillof , argentina ’ s peronist economy minister , is now in the same mood as nixon .
is he right ?
kicillof has gained the top value of argentina ’ s fight against so-called vulture funds , which , in several cents , bought the value of argentina ’ s argentine bonds , and tried to blackmail argentina ’ s full payment .
but , before president cristina fernández ’ s cabinet , kicillof was known in argentina ’ s intellectual best because a return to keynes was a return .
last week , when he spoke of a packed gold packed with the elite elite in argentina , kicillof explained the government ’ s policy as a real-world application of keynesian theory .
there are two key points to the speech .
first , kicillof attributed argentina ’ s rapid economic growth in 2001 to the 2008 global financial crisis , as a keynesian upturn in domestic aggregate demand .
keynes ’ s great contribution was to prove that the supply of a market economy does not necessarily create demand , and that the absence of an economic downturn could have been avoided .
can this logic apply in argentina ?
when argentina ’ s economy collapsed in 2001 , the people lost their jobs to their firms , causing domestic demand to shrink .
output fell sharply .
but when argentina abolished its currency and the dollar , the real exchange rate fell sharply .
this leads to the shift from imports to domestic products .
the price of food exports has risen sharply , in part , in argentina , where government revenues increased , with the accumulation of sufficient cash to increase spending .
because argentina almost isolated international financial markets , its central bank can reduce domestic interest rates without capital flight .
fiscal and monetary stimulus supported the rapid recovery in domestic economies .
at first glance , kicillof seems to be right ; this does resemble textbook keynesian reflation .
but keynes himself would not have favored the macroeconomic policies pursued by fernández and her predecessor , néstor kirchner , and the late néstor kirchner .
keynesian policies will first ensure that demand does not fall short of supply .
the kirchners have ensured that demand goes far beyond supply .
the fact that argentina ’ s annual inflation rate of 10 % for more than a decade has been at 20 % , and the fact that the price index has been rigged , is not really true .
he mentioned keynes ’ s self-fulfilling theory of expectations and warned people that if they were expected to go wrong , the expectation becomes reality .
keynes did say that capitalism ’ s economy is like a beauty contest , with judges choosing not to be the most beautiful players , but that their colleagues think the best .
expectations can change the outcome .
but argentines are not pessimistic about the economy for other argentines .
they are pessimistic because economic fundamentals are weak – and fundamentally different .
in 1991 , the nobel laureate economist paul krugman , arguably the world ’ s most respected keynesian , told people whether it is self-fulfilling , depending on underlying economic conditions .
if economic fundamentals are weak , the crisis will sooner or later inevitable ; if fundamentals are strong , the crisis will never happen ; but if the fundamentals of the crisis are too strong , the crisis will be expected .
a few years ago , the eurozone was in the latter .
ecb president mario draghi ’ s commitment to “ do whatever it takes ” to save the euro is immediately preventing the eurozone ’ s debt crisis .
( the development crisis , of course , remains unresolved . )
but argentina is not the eurozone .
whatever kicillof is to say , draghi ’ s commitment to the soothing effect that draghi has promised is impossible .
today ’ s argentines feel like dorothy – who has just begun to put in oz – they have moved away from the safe and familiar “ kansas . ”
but keynes should not take this responsibility , kicillof and kirchner .
monsieur piketty goes to latin america
santiago – there is no telling latin america ’ s left-wing intellectuals about inequality , as a frenchman wrote about inequality .
so , predictably , thomas piketty ’ s capital in the twenty-first century has been 洛阳纸贵 .
for two months , on the basis of the book published in english , the great work of the paris school of economics , a professor of economics in the paris school of economics , confirms the claims of inequality in latin america .
piketty 优美 the dynamics of capital accumulation in a market economy .
in his infamous formulation , if the return on capital is higher than the rate of economic growth , inherited wealth will rise faster than corporate income , and owners of capital will increase the share of national output .
no one can deny that income distribution in latin america is too large .
but the fact that piketty ’ s supporters ( many of whom have never read his book ) may be surprised , with his theory irrelevant to the 测得 dynamics of the region ’ s measured income distribution .
piketty ’ s theory is about what economists call the functional distribution of income : the distribution of labor providers and owners of capital .
but in latin america , an unequal distribution of inequality in latin america is about personal distribution of labor income – the distribution of the wage .
that is because the data on income distribution in latin america stem from surveys of households , which rarely provide real information about what piketty calls the rentiers ( their income is actually profitable , dividends , or interest ) .
for example , in 2009 , the 极广 household survey of chile showed that the distribution of capital income is more fair than labor income .
there is , of course , no belief in the right nature .
that outcome shows that owners of stocks and bonds tend to lie to government investigators .
this , in turn , reveals two points of information about income distribution in latin america .
second , even if the capital dynamics that are concerned are excluded , latin america ’ s income distribution will remain skewed .
the solution to the distribution of inequality is not the high wealth taxes that piketty produces alone .
why not ?
clearly , if labor income is distorted , redistributing capital income or assets to the poor would increase overall equality .
the imf economist ’ s latest paper uses a new set of data sets to cover new data sets in large countries , which are quite optimistic about increasing the chances of redistribution without undermining economic growth .
but the paper also reminds people of the limited income that the tax system can redistribute .
the authors compare the gini coefficient of government and transfer payments before the gini coefficient ( the gini coefficient is an index of inequality , and a zero point of 100 points ) .
as a result , only a handful of countries ’ redistribution has caused more than 10 % of the gini coefficient ’ s gini coefficient , and the gini coefficient ’ s gini coefficient , if more than 13 points , would have a negative impact on growth .
of course , real-life redistribution is much smaller , at least in latin america .
tax reform recently proposed by chilean president michelle bachelet ’ s administration has raised taxes by 3 % .
even if that money does not leaks out , and all went to the redistribution of chileans to the poverty of chileans , the reform would lower the gini coefficient of chile .
the problem is that chile ’ s after-tax gini coefficient is about 50 % ( as is brazil , colombia , and peru ) , and the gini coefficient in the advanced countries is mostly 30 or 20 .
bringing chile and some of its neighbors to the level of equality in oecd countries requires far more than tax reform .
in other words , if a society ’ s initial competition conditions are very unfair , the society is still in the midst of a sizeable fiscal redistribution .
thus , the policy focus must also be on what yale university political scientist jacob hacker calls “ pre-distribution ” ( pre ) , to change the market ’ s structure of wages .
there are three tools for improving the distribution of income .
for starters , education reform – a strong emphasis on teacher training – would enable low-income citizens to provide new skills that they can provide in the labor market .
second , targeted industrial policies create the demand for these workers and their newly acquired skills .
third , labor-market modernization can match workers ’ skills and firms more effectively in the context of increasingly divergent conditions .
these policies are not substitutes , but complementary : they must be implemented simultaneously .
doing so will not be easy .
in latin america , political leaders in the left worry about the economic and social justice issues that must be applied to their own countries .
there is no recipe for what they want in the french economist ’ s magnum opus .
the high cost of ocean degradation
santiago – the planet ’ s oceans are in trouble .
in the last nine months , the intergovernmental panel on climate change reported that the oceans are warming , seawater is melting , and oxygen concentrations are falling .
last week , another initiative on the international maritime state of the international ocean outlined these factors and other factors , such as destructive fishing and pollution , to the marine life .
marine degradation is not as visible as deforestation , but it is not in the same way .
the oxygen we breathe is at least half the oceans .
the damage to the ocean will have a serious impact on the planet .
environmental degradation is particularly acute in the vast seas of international governance .
these waters are outside of exclusive economic zones ; they comprise two-thirds of the oceans , covering fully 45 % of the earth ’ s surface .
the global ocean commission , an independent project that i joined earlier this year , is reviewing the situation of the high seas .
next year , the global ocean commission will offer a set of recommendations on how to restore the ocean to health and ecological productivity .
one of the first tasks is to quantify the economic losses caused by marine degradation .
in 1997 , the groundbreaking paper written by robert Costanza and his colleagues 推算 the total value of marine ecosystems to $ 21 trillion .
others estimate that illegal fishing costs the global economy $ 10-23.5 billion a year ; fisheries mismanagement costs $ 50 billion annually .
but these are ten years ago , and the global ocean commission will update these numbers and make them more precise .
it is not enough to prove that the losses are huge .
clearly , the next question is what should be done .
no official body is accountable to the high seas .
so , even if economic losses are far higher than previous estimates , there is no effective mechanism for change .
the main pillar of the ocean governance , the united nations convention on the law of the sea , is a product of 30 years ago .
for 30 years , technology has become fast-changing , and demand for resources has increased substantially .
so stopping and reversing the degradation of the global marine environment requires improving governance mechanisms , which must be enforced by improving the economic incentives and innovative solutions .
to this end , countries with a governance experience can help .
costa rica ’ s forest governance began in the early 1990s , with the country taxing fossil fuels in the early 1990 ’ s , using income to protect forests .
the net result is a reversal of deforestation .
costa rica ’ s economy also benefits from growing tourism , indirectly benefiting from ecosystem services , such as pollination .
the concept of payment for ecosystem services is currently receiving attention from governments around the world .
costa rica and colombia have both signed programs funded by donor governments .
brazil has introduced programs for protecting watercourses .
the program for redd+ ( cutting emissions from deforestation and forest degradation ) will be paid to the global ecosystem for ecosystem conservation , by rewarding forest conservation .
in the future , these ideas should be more noticed , because the supply of our non-renewable resources is drying up .
in the global ocean commission ’ s reform recommendations next year , economic analysis will be the centerpiece .
with more accurate data about the value of the ocean , we must decide how to use this information .
payment for ecosystem services is a solution , though it may be simpler .
but , whatever mechanisms they take , we must address governance issues : today ’ s institutional integrity will lead to sustained economic and ecological damage .
keeping the current laissez-faire regime afloat carries high costs .
one hopes that national leaders understand that the earth ’ s oceans – and the ecosystem services that it provides – are essential .
secular stagnation revisited
santiago – the return of commodity prices to people , the fed will gradually exit quantitative easing , driving up us interest rates , and latin america ’ s economies face challenges for sustainable growth .
in 2013 , growth in the region ’ s major economies slowed , and it is expected to be so .
today , it is clear that latin america ’ s rapid growth in the years following the 2008-2009 global economic crisis was not a revolutionary policy shift , but a highly favorable external environment .
as long as the price of soy , wheat , copper , oil , and other raw materials remains high , commodity-rich countries like brazil , chile , and peru have a strong boost ; and even argentina ’ s economic policies have grown fast .
but now , “ secular stagnation ” – ever since former us treasury secretary larry summers noted last november that the us ( and perhaps other advanced economies ) had been in a prolonged period of weak gdp growth – is likely to come to latin america .
the point is that the worsening of consumer debt , declining population growth , and worsening inequality have weakened consumer demand , stimulated savings , and slower growth in productivity and output itself .
thus , “ natural ” interest rates – which make investment demand equal to the supply of savings – have fallen , and even falling to negative levels .
but , because real interest rates can not be at a severe negative level ( unless inflation is high , the reality is that it is saving ) .
with consumption and investment , the us economy will be doomed to stall .
but this theory applies to latin america , where growth is stronger , higher interest rates , and stronger domestic demand than the us .
consider latin america ’ s history .
until the recent 繁荣 boom , growth in latin america was mediocre .
in the 1980 ’ s , with debt crises and massive recession , known as “ lost decades , ” the market reforms of the 1990 ’ s did not boost short-term growth .
from 1996 to 2007 , only four countries in latin america and the caribbean – brazil , chile , the dominican republic , and panama – grew faster than the us .
the decline in growth in the coming years is thus merely a return to latin america ’ s old path , not a historical trajectory .
this brings us to secular stagnation .
to be sure , latin american countries ’ average per capita gdp is only one-quarter that of the us , and thus should be faster than that of the north .
the question is how much faster .
against this background , stagnation means that growth is not enough for a long time to reach the level of living in the us .
unlike the us , latin american economies ’ actual output is at or near its potential , so boosting growth requires investment .
but investment has been disappointing .
the region ’ s problems are not too much domestic saving , but too little .
latin american countries account for 18 % of gdp , compared to 30 % in east asia .
as a result , whenever investment begins in latin america , it must borrow from abroad .
foreign investors are willing to accept the results of the current-account deficit , but there is a limit .
last may , us federal reserve chairman ben bernanke was only a bit bland – declaring that qe was finally over – and that the emerging economies that have been running out of current-account deficits have lost confidence in emerging economies that account for more than 4 % of gdp .
as a result , as in the past , so long as foreigners feel nervous , financing and investment will be curtailed , and growth will stall .
the scarcity of savings in latin america reflects poorly designed incentives for poorly designed tax and pension systems .
but savings performance also correlates with long-term fiscal problems .
to be sure , in 2007 , many latin american economies had improved their fiscal position , so countries like chile could implement strong anti-crisis fiscal measures .
but , as the iadb ’ s 2013 report makes clear , fiscal stimulus is not always in the timely future , so the fiscal position in latin america today is weaker than it was in 2007 .
the composition of government spending is also problematic .
according to the same iadb report , investment accounts for only 16 % of total fiscal spending , and less than half of the emerging asian population .
as a result , latin america has long suffered from technological infrastructure deficits , which have become a drag on growth .
even more than future domestic savings can not guarantee higher investment .
businesses ’ willingness to invest depends on how much output can be reaped from investment , and productivity growth in latin america ( and the us ) is disappointing .
the cause of productivity lags , but one of them is not the diversity of local economic structures .
the increase in productivity , or increases in efficiency , or the new sectors that are more productive – a process that can be seen by observing the extent of export diversification .
the sad fact is that most latin american countries today – mexico is a notable exception – export nothing more than two decades ago .
this is another significant difference in latin america and east asia .
so , can latin american economies sustain growth without the return of commodity prices and the world ’ s interest rates ?
as latin americans , the answer is yes .
but restoring stagnation is also possible – and only if policymakers acknowledge this and correctly adopt preventive measures that minimize this possibility .
the humanities crisis
new york – in the future of higher education , discussion of the future of higher education suggests an symmetry .
on one hand , a growing number of people worry that , in areas like the twenty-first century “ knowledge economy , ” such as engineering and information technology , the us and many european countries can not afford enough university graduates .
this concern led to the intolerance of education , which allows for the acquisition of practical skills .
on the other hand , some asian countries ’ concerns are that young people entering the labor force have experienced adequate technical training , but lack sufficient “ alternative ” experience .
this concern is growing in the context of an initial effort to expand access to education , integrate into the sense of imagination and imagination .
both directions are rooted in economic problems .
in the united states , most undergraduates are now saddled with the political pressure to pay credit for tuition credits and loan forgiveness ( so-called “ learning ” ) fees and loan forgiveness ( so-called “ learning ” ) .
cutting the traditional four-year four-year four-year meeting to reduce costs for “ 非 ” subjects like the two , thus reducing , and eliminating the literature , philosophy , and 美术 is also discussed .
at the same time , hong kong , singapore , and china , in hong kong , singapore , and china , have called for an extension of university education , enabling students to gain broad humanities education , in the hope of being more inclined to experiment and innovate .
hong kong university , for example , has extended its undergraduate programs from three years to four .
but this narrow view of the economy fails to account for the broader value of the global community .
but the other fact is that strengthening technical training does not provide sufficient foundation for addressing the more abstract but important questions that ultimately guide global policies and decision-making .
for example :
· how can the urgent task of economic development align with the need to limit climate change ?
· what does national sovereignty mean in a world where disease , pollution , and terrorists can cross borders at the same time ?
· are there universal human rights that transcend conflicting religious traditions ?
· how should the limited resources be allocated , thereby giving young people opportunities and hope , while enabling the elderly to get dignity and respect ?
· what is a country ’ s obligations to foreign refugees , whose persecution , poverty , and conflict come to mind ?
· how can we balance individual freedom and collective security ?
answering these questions , advances in science and technology ( for example , new approaches to energy products , surveillance , or online learning ) will be essential .
but ethical and ethical questions have never been fully technical ; they also need to be understood by the understanding of human society and cultural traditions .
science can help us get the life we want , but it can not teach us what kind of life we deserve .
in short , both sides of the current education debate are right to be wrong .
human affairs become increasingly complex , and the demands for ethics are increasingly harsh , so our future generations will need a combination of scientific and humanistic learning – more than ever .
fortunately , promising new models for making education more coherent and broader are emerging .
yale university and the national university of singapore are founded on yale , singapore ’ s liberal arts college .
the new 寄宿制 academy , led by liberal scholars and astronomers , aims to break the boundaries of discipline and enable students to learn from one another .
likewise , the university of canada has encouraged students to use scientific and humanistic knowledge to explore today ’ s most pressing problems .
a similar attempt has been underway for many years in the us .
for example , in north carolina , benjamin franklin , a university of the university of north carolina , has launched a partnership between the university of engineering and the humanities and social sciences to “ foster well educated professionals and make moral decisions , as well as moral decisions . ”
unfortunately , such programs have largely lacked the visibility and influence , unable to determine the education reform .
it is time to abandon the “ either/or ” mindset of science and humanities , and the british chemist and novelist edward snow recognized this as a barrier to human progress .
it is time to find ways to bridge this putative division and broaden .
in an important effort to adapt education institutions to the future , we must not forget the central task of education institutions that have been fully articulated in the past .
to this end , the best thing to do is benjamin franklin , who was both a 文学家 and a scientific innovator who defined education as a quest for “ real virtue . ”
“ the real virtue , ” writes that there is a combination of “ the ability to serve human , native , friend , and family members , and the aspirations of our people ; power ... can be achieved through real learning ; indeed , it should be the goal of all . ”
every generation should have such ambitions .
piketty with chinese characteristics
hong kong – according to thomas piketty ’ s book capital in the twenty-first century , the various mechanisms of capitalism have exacerbated inequality , which is based on the same notion – the approach ( the return on capital ) – that is more rapid than the g ( income gains ) .
while much of the debate about piketty ’ s book is concentrated in advanced economies , this fundamental concept applies to china ’ s experience in recent years , so it is worth exploring further examination .
a fixed capital investment that underpins china ’ s growth model has essentially benefited the entire economy ; for example , improved infrastructure has enabled the rural poor to boost productivity and incomes .
as the investment rate rises to about half of gdp , the share of consumption has fallen to nearly one-third .
recognizing the need to rebalance growth , the government began to increase the minimum wage in 2011 almost twice as fast as real gdp , ensuring that the average household receives more disposable income for consumption .
but real estate prices have grown faster than wages and real-estate profits , leading to higher returns on a small share of property owners ’ assets than china ’ s gdp .
they also benefit from the implicit leverage implied by strong credit growth .

indeed , while the rise of china and other emerging economies has reduced inequality among countries , inequality in the country is pervasive .

in particular , as the global economy moves to the creation of knowledge-based values , some brands have gained significant traction in high-tech creative ideas , as the global economy boomed .
the resulting concentration of income , wealth , and power created some of the “ too big to fail ” economies , thereby undermining systemic stability and undermining smaller players ’ competitiveness .
because real negative interest rates aggravate the financial repression of residential savings , the global financial system effectively strengthens the concentration of income , wealth , and power .
given banks ’ preferred lending to large firms and mortgage borrowers , smes lack access to credit and capital .

in many emerging economies ( outsourcing china ) , widespread fear of insufficient retirement income is fueling high household saving rates .
most economists believe that this trend is unsustainable , but disagreement about how to stop it .
the right is supposed to create wealth by more “ market-based ” reforms , while the left supports more government intervention .
in fact , both approaches can play a role , especially in china , where china ’ s government is pursuing a more market-oriented development strategy , but it retains considerable control over the economy .
china needs to strike a balance between policy stability and market-oriented development .
in particular , policies and institutional factors have led to too little pricing for resources , leading to major risks .
china ’ s labor force has driven down labor prices and prevents the economy from shifting to a high-income , 消费 growth model .

moreover , policies aimed at stabilizing the exchange rate and maintaining low interest rates have caused capital and risk to be underestimated .
local governments , by artificially selling land to investors through artificially low prices , spurred a large amount of investment to real-estate development , causing real-estate prices to grow at unsustainable rates .
because real estate is the main form of bank loans , financial risks rose sharply .
today , governments are trying to reduce the risks that investors and local governments are taking to reduce the risks that investors and local governments are taking .
but this transformation must be carefully promoted in order to ensure that real estate prices do not collapse , because the rate of non-performing loans would increase significantly , even triggering a massive financial crisis .
in order to ensure long-term social stability , china must promote inclusive wealth creation , such as establishing strong incentives for innovation .

financial assets can not pay a sufficient dividend or capital appreciation , leading investors to move toward real estate as a hedge against inflation .
