china ’ s subprime risks
hong kong – the recent global financial crisis is actually a balance-sheet crisis .
the prolonged period of negative interest rates in the us fueled an unsustainable boom in asset purchases , while high-risk mortgages undermine us national balance sheets .
when liquidity in key interbank markets dried up , vulnerabilities were exposed , and have devastating consequences .
today , the rapid expansion of china ’ s financial institutions – from 92 % of gdp in 2007 to 92 % from 2007 to 2011 – is putting a growing number of people predicting that china will soon experience its own subprime crisis .
is it plausible ?
the first step in assessing china ’ s economic vulnerability is to distinguish between solvency crises and liquidity crises that occur in the absence of sufficient capital to withstand asset-price crashes .
during the asian financial crisis of the 1990 ’ s , some countries experienced a foreign-exchange crisis , devaluation , and high interest rates that wiped out banks and businesses , owing to their lack of adequate reserves .
in the aftermath of japan ’ s asset price crisis in 1989 ( as in the united states in 2008 ) , bank recapitalization and central-bank liquidity support restored market confidence .
the recently released national academy of social sciences ’ s national balance sheet ( http : http : http ) shows that china is unlikely to experience a shortage of foreign-exchange shortages or a dysfunctional bankruptcy crisis .
at the end of 2011 , the central government ’ s net assets amounted to 87 trillion , which accounted for 192 % of gdp , 33 trillion in state-owned enterprises .
moreover , by last year , china ’ s net foreign-exchange position amounted to $ 2 trillion – 21 % of gdp – just below $ 4 trillion .
it is worth noting that china ’ s domestic debt is growing at 215 % of gdp .
since 2008 , soes and so-called local-government financing vehicles have been using loans to finance large fixed investments , while private-sector enterprises are typically borrowing through shadow banking – financing real-estate development .
excessive reliance on bank credit stems from the lack of sufficient access to other financing , particularly relative to underdevelopment , which accounts for only 37 % of gdp , compared to 104 % of gdp in the us .
the chinese nonfinancial corporate debt amounts to 113 % of gdp , compared to 72 % in the us and 99 % in japan .
but , because china ’ s large enterprises are skewed toward soes or local entities , their debt is actually domestic sovereign debt .
without soes and local debt , china ’ s total debt/gdp ratio is only 53 % , well below that of 80 % in the us and japan ’ s 226 % , so there are plenty of room for debt-equity swaps to address domestic debt .
of course , china ’ s leaders need to continue to pursue significant fiscal reforms , including improving the revenue of the central and local governments .
in the long run , the government must put more stringent regulation in order to ensure the sustainability of local-government infrastructure investment , and not entirely dependent on land sales .
during the transition , the burden of adjustment was on monetary policy , and the challenge is particularly challenging given the “ tightening ” of structural liquidity faced by the more productive sectors .
from 2007 to 2011 , china ’ s currency supply increased by 116 % , while its foreign-exchange reserves increased by 180 % .
the foreign exchange reserves have been recycled more than 20 % of the statutory reserve requirements on bank deposits .
as a result , large firms – most of them soes , who enjoy considerable financial subsidies and liquidity – received 43 % of total bank lending in 2011 ; and small and medium-size enterprises ( smes ) were given financial repression , including higher borrowing costs and tighter liquidity .
this highlights two fundamental structural issues .
first , large soes and local governments must be reined in , because they reduce the return on capital .
second , more capital must be channeled toward small and medium-size enterprises and regions where growth is faster and more likely to create jobs and innovation .
in other words , interest-rate reform must be pursued alongside capital-market reforms that would make it easier to obtain credit for more productive sectors .
only if the value created by innovation exceeds the value of the excess capacity of excess capacity , china will be able to move from an export-led economy to a 推动型 economy .
in short , despite a strong state balance sheet and ample central-bank liquidity , china faces a localized subprime problem , which would lead to a partial liquidity shortage for the sake of excessive lending .
one promising move is the central bank ’ s recent release of €1 trillion in liquidity by providing direct loans to the development bank , which has helped to connect the development bank to informal investment .
unlike the fed , china ’ s central bank has not purchased subprime mortgages directly .
the key to success will be to manage the sequence of liquidity injections and the sequence of interest rates , so that the move to address local subprime debts does not trigger asset-price depreciation .
if china is to complete structural reforms , it – and the rest of the world – will be able to avoid the consequences of a hard landing .
reforming china ’ s dual-track economy
hong kong – the chinese economy is growing again in discussions about the risks of a hard landing in the chinese economy .
the housing bubble , local government debt , and a struggling shadow banking are deemed the source of potential financial risk , making it difficult to challenge the challenge of rising labor costs , credit excessive credit , severe pollution , endemic corruption , and rising international competition and international competition .
each turning point of reform is accompanied by potential additional risks .
any strategy to address the risks of economic slowdown must account for the dual nature of china ’ s economy .
on one hand , some of china ’ s cities are increasingly modernizing and integrating the global economy .
china ’ s most dynamic 17 cities have entered the world bank ’ s high income , which accounts for 11 % of national population and 30 % of gdp .
on the other hand , half of china ’ s population remains in rural areas , with most of the income coming from agriculture .
according to mastercard , 25 % of consumer spending in china continues to use cash , suggesting that china ’ s informal economy is more informal than it is predicted .
this duality has positive implications for china ’ s economic prospects .
while the main driver of economic growth over the last few decades has been the region ’ s outward-looking manufacturing sector , the country ’ s rural and inward-looking cities will be a strong engine of growth as domestic consumption increases .
in other words , china ’ s economic fundamentals are larger and more diverse than many realize , which means that china ’ s potential growth momentum is difficult to restrain .
this feature of the chinese economy , as well as china ’ s $ 3.8 trillion foreign-exchange reserves and large ( though declining ) current-account surpluses , has left the chinese economy dependent on foreign saving and investment .
thus , local governments ’ debt and non-performing loans are just the problem of redistribution in domestic debt .
the only real international spillovers , stemming from tighter monetary and fiscal austerity policies , may reduce gdp growth , thereby depressing china ’ s demand for commodities .
this would hurt commodity-exporting emerging economies , and many of these economies are currently faced with a poor flight from the fed ’ s monetary-policy reversal .
in china ’ s dual-track economy , china must adjust its market-oriented reform strategy to ensure that the new systemic risks are not expected , while overcoming a major reform of the vested interests that the vested interests needed to create a level playing field .
to achieve this , china will need to address a two-track economy in the current economic development : a two-track credit system and a dual-track benchmark .
as a result , large soes and local governments have become the only borrowers capable of acquiring enough cheap credit to invest in large-scale infrastructure .
since the 2008 global financial crisis weakened china ’ s export growth , private firms have since moved to 导向 production and services , particularly the real-estate sector , which turned to the boom .
this shift , together with a current-account surplus and a massive infrastructure investment , has increased upward pressure on domestic interest rates .
while the authorities can control official interest rates , unofficial interest rates are beginning to rise inexorably , fueling rapid expansion of shadow banking .
the official credit of easy credit and cheap commercial banks has soared , and the average price of housing in 70 large and medium-size cities has risen from 每平米 in 2002 to 5791 , a decade after the decade ’ s 每平米 .
it should be noted that emerging industrial economies , such as japan , hong kong , taiwan , and south korea , have increased their economic growth in the early days of their economic development , with rising real productivity growth , based on credit booms , based on credit booms .
it is not surprising that the productivity of the first 17 cities in the 17 countries of the country ’ s best-performing 17 cities ( hong kong ’ s per capita gdp is three times higher than in hong kong ) , which is not surprising .
yet other 一线 and underperforming cities face labor and capital outflows , and their housing prices often become a glorified ghost ghost towns .
in pursuing interest-rate liberalization , china ’ s goal should be to isolate between formal and informal interest rates , which requires both macro-level and micro-level approaches .
specifically , china needs to reform the microfinance system to facilitate the market-driven process of creative adjustment , such as through institutionalized bankruptcy procedures that help to deal with ghost towns and failed real-estate projects , thereby minimizing the macroeconomic disruption .
relying on tightening credit to limit macro risk makes the problem more complicated .
a broad structural adjustment and deepening reform requires a robust monetary policy and stable inflation expectations , but , in good times , tighter monetary policy will affect the process of economic adjustment .
indeed , the rapid slowdown in the supply of money , from about 25 % in 2009 to around 14 % today , has been accompanied by rapid expansion of shadow banking .
at the end of 2012 , shadow banking accounted for 24 % of total credit , with interest rates reaching 10-15 % higher than official rates .
this unexpected increase in the cost of market orientation hurts the real economy .
unless inefficient borrowers exit markets or declare bankruptcy , they will continue to distort resource allocation , crowding out more productive firms .
thus , the key to the merger ’ s interest rate and credit system is reforming the credit allocation mechanism , providing more funds to well-performing projects and imposing various hard constraints on borrowers performing poorly performing borrowers .
this will inevitably trigger some defaults and shape the quality of banks ’ loan portfolios , but these efforts and costs are worth a more balanced , healthier economy .
harnessing china ’ s competitive streak
hong kong – china ’ s state council recently issued the 若干意见 reforms of capital markets in 2020 , with two key objectives : “ safeguard market order , fair and fair market order , and the legal protection of investor investors in particular . ”
to make these goals , policymakers will need to weigh their market autonomy against government regulation , innovation , and stability , and to accelerate the balance between reform and pragmatism , and to accelerate reform and pragmatism .
can china achieve these balance ?
from a policy perspective , the goal should be to strike a balance between competition ( spurring economic growth but also destabilizing reforms ) with cooperation ( which promises long-term social solidarity but also risk stagnation ) .
in the process , china ’ s leaders must consider three layers of competition : competition between firms , competition between sectors , and competition among citizens , businesses , and countries .
the implementation of the corporate competition framework has made progress .
in 2008 , the government enacted “ antitrust law , ” aimed at preventing companies from forming barriers that impede competition or “ monopoly ” contracts , minimizing market behavior , and discourage mergers and acquisitions that could discourage or overshoot competition .
but market competition in the market for three major players ( soes , private firms , and foreign firms ) is a complex task .
private firms are frustrated with the privileges that soes enjoy , and foreign-owned enterprises complain that they are at a disadvantage in competing with their local companies .
the onus of responsibility among regulators is more complex .
but , more than a decade after the accession of the world trade organization , foreign banks account for only 2 % of china ’ s market share – a point that suggests that china needs to improve access , openness , and level playing field .
this challenge is exacerbated by technological progress and regulatory arbitrage .
e-commerce platforms like alibaba have not only eroded banks ’ payment business ; they also started to provide wealth-management products .
regulatory arbitrage has spurred the shadow banking sector to compete actively with traditional financial institutions for wealth-management and lending business .
regulatory arbitrage stems from the absence of regulatory authority resulting from the difficulties of regulatory arbitrage , which often delays market development and institutional reforms , because coordination among regulators is not easy .
for example , the chinese bond market , at least for at least five agencies and the overlap , impedes its development .
the best example of china ’ s benign competition is in cities .
china has 287 , the median population of 3.7 million , and the median per capita gdp of $ 5,800 .
16 million cities have already crossed the world bank ’ s high threshold of income ( annual per capita income above $ 616 ) , and four cities – beijing , shanghai , guangzhou , and shenzhen – have become global metropolises .
these cities are key to china ’ s ability to cross the middle-income trap .
the secret of china ’ s economic success since 1979 is the easing of central planning , and the separation of powers to cities , markets , and private firms has sought , innovation , and growth .
because it is difficult to know which reforms will require reform or elimination of the old system , this process is benefiting from the central level of local mandates , which are more favorable to try and discovery through the creation of market rules .
at the same time , in order to stabilize and sound stability , the devolution of mandates has been accompanied by the central government ’ s supervisory and certain market watchdogs .
this balance of horizontal competition and vertical regulation of vertical regulation is crucial to boosting chinese cities ’ success and dynamism .
but this balance of governance is not perfect .
indeed , excessive competition among cities has led to disruptive imbalances , owing to the important impact of urban gdp growth on local officials .
local autonomy can help to implement bold measures to raise productivity , such as agricultural land transfer , financing infrastructure projects , and public-private partnerships with state-owned enterprises and manufacturing firms to compete for services and manufacturing .
but cities compete to imitate one another ’ s growth model , also causing severe environmental pollution , excessive local debt , excess infrastructure , rising inequality , depletion of farmland , depletion of farmland , and abuse of property rights and property rights .
increased competition has transformed china into the world ’ s second-largest economy .
but the current uneven growth model is unsustainable .
the task now is to rebalance the pattern of competition – namely , the negative externalities that address both governments and markets .
the central government ’ s recent push for some judicial justice in local governments reinforces property rights , which is an important step in the direction of reform .
but it is not enough .
let the market decide resource allocation and ensure that all participants play a fair level , requiring clear competition rules for governments , which may require a strong “ competition committee ” to provide support .
there is no good competition for fair , fair , and fair rules .
this is the real challenge facing china ’ s leaders today .
if they succeed in responding to this challenge , china ’ s access to high-income status will be only a matter of time .
the 政府职能 government
beijing – this year ’ s china development forum has made clear how china ’ s leaders are prepared to achieve “ china dream , ” as president xi jinping described as a “ national and national power , a national revival , and people ’ s happiness . ”
last november ’ s third plenum of the 18th central committee in the 18th central committee of the communist party of china ( ccp ) produced more than 330 major reforms in 60 areas by 2020 , reforming the breadth , depth , and complexity of the 60 areas .
achieving china ’ s shift from an economic model based on manufacturing and exports to a consumption model driven by consumption and services – inclusive , environmental sustainability , and more than 13 million jobs – is an extremely formidable task .
beyond that , the chinese government is facing the challenge of maintaining financial and social stability , and it is difficult to manage the world ’ s largest bureaucracy .
consider the government ’ s fiscal position last summer .
the national audit office needs to mobilize 55 employees to censor the government ’ s books , including the central government and 31 个省 and autonomous cities , five 直辖市 , 391 municipalities , 778 county , and 33 rural communities .
the entire survey covers 62 government agencies and institutions , 机构 institutions , and 68 public finances , 2 public corporations , 支持 public finance , and 其他 other institutions – a total of 73 billion ( $ 73 billion ) , combined with 债务 debt .
clearly , the governance of china ’ s public sector is very different from the west , whose structural model is the rule of law , democracy , and market .
while major reforms have led to a dramatic change in the country for 35 years , the private sector has become a leading contributor to job creation , but much of it remains to be improved – a notable example of the state-owned sector , especially local governments and state-owned enterprises ( soes ) .
one way to understand the complexity of china ’ s governance system is to examine the matrix of relationships between institutions and the so-called “ 条条块块 . ”
the “ legion of tiao ” is the vertical system of the central government and the bureaucracy through the state sector and the bureaucracy , including the national ndrc , the other key ministries , and the appointment and promotion of key ministries , and the macroeconomic tools , particularly fiscal , monetary , exchange-rate , and regulatory policies .
kuai kuai refers to the high level of competition between local entities and the central government in this regard .
to achieve genuine stability , china ’ s leaders must strike a delicate balance between tiao tiao control and kuai autonomy .
but this is a tall order that tends to ease not only the rapid growth of local economies and improvements in public services , but also the risks of rising imbalances and the risk of overheating , owing to the tendency of excessive fixed investment .
so the central government has to restart central control , and the emergency stops .
if china ’ s economy is a car , national leaders have been 交替 and brake .
the latest reforms suggest that the chinese government is finally trying to fine-tune its policies .
the reform program will concentrate some responsibilities on the central board , such as resistance to vested interests ; and expanding local autonomy in others , including licensing procedures and programs .
the government also established a free-trade zone ( low tariff , lower customs barriers , and less administrative intervention ) to strengthen the market ’ s decisive role in resource allocation .
this effort has eased unnecessary constraints on local institutions , with market and institutional innovations .
these innovations , together with increased transparency and adoption of cutting-edge technologies , are likely to curb rent-seeking and corruption , while boosting productivity and increasing employment .
the latest decision by governments to reform the household registration system will widen the results further , making workers and private proprietors an opportunity to choose where to live , work , and invest .
as china ’ s leaders made clear at the third plenum of the eighteenth century , removing arbitrary tiao control can enable cities and localities to develop more than their own comparative advantages .
china ’ s gradual openness will make it increasingly attractive for companies and individuals to pursue more attractive opportunities abroad , which will complicate china ’ s governance system further .
indeed , in response to markets , resources , talent , and global competition , china and the global governance system will need two-way interaction .
china ’ s leaders have shown that they know the need to implement modern management techniques , and understand that doing so requires updating and 调整 the central control tools that have long depended .
if the right adjustments are made , china ’ s governance system will effectively address issues like air and water pollution , food security , energy efficiency , and social inequality , and ensure that china ’ s long-term prosperity is .
this process is just beginning , but it is a good start .
great cities and ghost towns
hong kong – many observers like to associate the 无人居住 modern “ ghost towns ” as a sign of the impending collapse of china ’ s economy , often funded by risky local-government financing platforms .
in 2012 , the venture capitalist william 詹韦 argued that economic development is a tripartite game involving countries , innovative private entrepreneurs , and financial capitalism , which will inevitably produce overshooting , thereby creating conditions for the next wave of invention and output growth .
the us also experienced ghost towns following the emergence of railways in the mid-nineteenth century , mining , and industrialization .
but the us has not suffered from a systemic crisis that transcends national borders .
without large-scale infrastructure investment , especially investment in transport , it is unlikely to produce the productivity gains that make america the world ’ s industrial power .
while the process includes massive creative destruction , rapid economic growth offset the loss of overcapacity .
likewise , given the history of history , china ’ s ghost towns will simply be 坑洼 on the road to development .
major infrastructure investments financed mainly by local-government financing platforms are likely to be remembered as a key contribution to china ’ s economic modernization .
of course , infrastructure investment does not necessarily translate into economic development .
new infrastructure – and the on-the-job training that enabled chinese workers to manage these facilities effectively – must make china productive enough to offset the value of excess fixed assets , which can be offset by the destruction of excess fixed assets .
in this sense , china ’ s prospects are promising .
as it stands , china ’ s infrastructure investment amounts to only about 240 % of gdp , more than half of japan ’ s 551% – and a much younger population .
china ’ s per capita capital stock remains below $ 10,000 , compared to more than $ 90,000 in the us , with japan exceeding $ 200,000 ( in 2011 prices ) .
moreover , roughly 1 % of china ’ s population – the 120 million people – is moving to cities every year .
the innovative modern infrastructure needed to improve people ’ s lives , increase energy efficiency , and minimize pollution has huge needs – especially given the central role of urbanization in economic modernization and productivity gains .
although lgfvs have some intrinsic risks , owing to low transparency and government regulation , they have been integrated into china ’ s modernization process so far .
indeed , they have emerged in the early 1990s to enable shanghai and guangdong to upgrade their infrastructure and industrialize .
both cities were constrained by technical and institutional boundaries and the scarcity of foreign and domestic credit .
by working with the world bank and the development bank , shanghai and guangdong have created innovative institutional structures that provide a legal , accounting , and managerial partnership for stakeholders to enable specific infrastructure projects , particularly the legal and accounting tools of modern companies .
in other words , lgfvs are inherently modern platforms .
this institutional innovation enabled the reconstruction of hundreds of chinese cities , with the airport , highways , high-speed rail , and advanced communications connected to the advanced telecommunication system .
with the support of these structures and linkages , one-third of china ’ s cities are already in per capita gdp .
moreover , the initial local-government financing platform was not affected by maturity mismatches , because they were financed by long-term 国开行 loans , where local governments collect taxes from the completion of the completed infrastructure to cover the cost of their operations .
thus , lgfvs also helped to build networks linking local markets to global value chains .
but , as always , success has always led to excess .
the massive government stimulus in the aftermath of the global financial crisis prompted local governments to pursue infrastructure projects that are based on cheap bank loans and land , with remote cities seeking to imitate cities like shanghai , beijing , or shenzhen .
in a sense , this is a positive development .
after all , closing the infrastructure gap has expanded the scope of individual and corporate decisions where to live or build factories and offices .
but there is a key factor behind the infrastructure boom : the belief that local governments can easily access cheap credit , cheap land , and rising demand .
when the market tightened in 2011 , the outlook for many projects was no longer bright , spurring local-government financing platforms to seek credit opportunities for the shadow banking sector , leading to a new challenge to borrowing costs , as well as new challenges from the market .
at the end of 2011 , china ’ s outstanding local-government debt totaled $ 29 trillion , while its land and fixed assets totaled $ 90 trillion , implying that even if assets are worth less than half , local governments remain insolvent .
that leaves the debt burden and distribution .
to address this problem , china ’ s government has announced fiscal reform , aimed at further redrawing the central and local revenues , particularly in allowing local governments to issue long-term municipal bonds .
china ’ s ghost towns and local-government debt are not harbingers of doom , but a bumpy bumps on the road to advanced economies , and the excesses are bound to be corrected , or through the market .
in fact , overcoming these challenges in the long run will create a more resilient economy .
fighting for ?
hong kong – the eighteenth-century german military strategist carl von clausewitz defined war as a continuation of the country ’ s history , as was ancient chinese strategist sun tzu , who believed that ensuring peace means preparing for violent conflict .
as the world becomes increasingly unstable , such a deep understanding of the war ’ s resurgence , the ongoing chaos in the middle east , and escalating tensions in east asia , this understanding is important .
wars have traditionally been fought around territory .
but territorial definitions include five dimensions : land , air , ocean , space , and the latest networks .
this type of war reflects the threat that the world faces today .
but the most important question is the fact that the specific trigger for war , targeting , and conflict will be largely determined by five factors : faith , ethnicity , culture , climate , and currency .
indeed , these factors are dominating global conflicts .
first , faith and religion are one of the most common motives of history , and the twenty-first century is no exception .
consider the rise of jihadist groups , including the islamic state ( isis ) and the islamic state ( isis ) , which still lives in iraq and syria , and boko haram , which has carried out the barbaric , bombardment , and murder groups .
there are also violent clashes between buddhists and muslims in myanmar and southern thailand , and violent clashes between islamists and catholics in the philippines .
the second factor – race , representation , and growing ethnic tensions in europe , turkey , india , and elsewhere – is a second factor .
the causes of these tensions are immigration and employment competition , which , in africa , can not be sustained by the colonial powers , where tribal and ethnic groups try to carve out their own territorial space .
and ukraine ’ s conflict has fueled long-simmering frustration with russia ’ s long-suffering peoples after the soviet union ’ s collapse .
the third potential factor in conflict is the fundamental cultural divide created by different societies ’ unique histories and institutional systems .
although the us and europe account for only one-eighth of the world ’ s population , they have long dominated economic dominance – roughly half the world ’ s gdp – and have disproportionate international influence .
but , with the rise of new economic powers , they are increasingly challenging the west , whose goal is not just market share and resources ; they will also seek to inject them into the global order ( or soft power ) .
of course , resource competition will also be important , as is the fourth factor , with climate change linked to climate change .
many countries and regions face severe water stress stress , and , as climate change causes natural disasters and extreme weather events like drought , stress continues to worsen .
similarly , with forests and marine resources , food competition can lead to conflict .
these conflicts stand directly counter to the gospel of globalization , which is supposed to allow countries to access food and energy , thereby enabling countries to concentrate their comparative advantages .
if emerging conflicts and competitive pressures lead to economic sanctions or the obstruction of important trade routes , the resulting balkanization of global trade would significantly offset the benefits of globalization .
moreover , social unrest , which is often accompanied by economic strife , could lead to a country divided into smaller regions , and in terms of value or resources .
in some ways , this scenario is happening , and iraq and syria are split into sectarian or tribal areas .
since the global economic crisis , expansionary monetary policies pursued by central banks in advanced economies have led to massive , volatile flows of capital across emerging economies , causing severe instability in these countries , fueling a “ currency war . ”
the 超 use of regulatory and tax rights is reinforcing the view that money can be a weapon .
for example , the united states , with its extra advantage in issuing the world ’ s major reserve currency , is demanding subsidiaries ’ subsidiaries in the us , and the international banking system , which would require a dollar resolution account , is a total of the global banking sector .
us regulators impose a 重罚 on breaching the rules – a recent $ 8.9 billion settlement in bnp paribas – which has led european banks to rethink the costs and profitability of compliance .
meanwhile , us courts have forced argentina to default again .
but perhaps the strongest signal is that targeted sanctions against russia ’ s oil , finance , defense , and 科技产业 , and russian officials .
by doing so , the us and its allies sent clear signals to anyone who might oppose us policy : best not to use the dollar and the dollar bank account .
already , some financial activities have moved into the shadow banking system , which is reflected in the use of bitcoin and other currencies that are not subject to us regulation .
a recent example of the search for alternative us initiatives is that the brics ( brazil , russia , india , china , and south africa ) will establish the brics and the contingent reserve arrangements .
the problem in the us is that , in this case , the disaffected are the five major emerging economies , using resources that exceed the bretton woods institutions ’ existing resources .
the brics ’ transactions are virtually impossible to use in dollars .
us president barack obama recently declared that the problem is not whether the us will continue to lead , but how it continues to lead .
but , in the five factors that the faith , race , culture , climate , and currency , the real world has become increasingly estranged from the us-led international order , obama may be overly optimistic .
indeed , in the coming war , no one seems to be sure who should follow .
kermit ’ s bankers
hong kong – sesame street ’ s kermit , 科米 kermit , once lamented that “ the great bargain is easy . ”
today , this sentiment is also being used to describe the current global economy – and thus to the green economy – to the problem .
last september , the united nations intergovernmental panel on climate change warned that if the world does not change its growth model , global temperatures will rise by 4-6 celsius , far exceeding the 2º celsius threshold that was supposedly “ safe . ”
this prompted un secretary-general ban ki-moon to intensify its political , economic , and financial leaders in january to challenge a new global climate change agreement .
high-level agreements , though important , will have little impact if they fail to invest heavily in areas such as smart grids , energy storage , and renewable energy .
in fact , the international energy agency estimates that , from now to 2050 , $ 1 trillion will be needed to put the world economy on a sustainable path .
although this looks like a big sum , it amounts to just 1 % of global gdp and less than 0.3 % of global financial assets .
moreover , since 2007 , central banks ’ central banks have shown that they can spend more than $ 1 trillion a year on balance sheets without triggering inflation .
that is , the world can afford the transition to a green economy .
nonetheless , last year , green investment amounted to only $ 254 billion – a shortfall that implies nearly $ 750 billion per year .
to remedy this gap , advanced-country governments are using limited public funds to promote private-sector investment .
meanwhile , developing countries ’ contribution to green finance is rapidly increasing , and domestic clean-energy financing in non-oecd countries surpassed oecd countries in 2008 .
but the problem remains that the current market is the market ’ s ability to adjust to climate change .
what really needs to be done is not money , but the political will to address market failures , which will require fundamental shifts in investors ’ measurement of economic activity , institutions , and policies .
the return on private capital ( profits and losses ) plus the return on “ social ” capital must be positive .
current gdp measures ignore the negative external role based on fossil fuels , leading to massive wastage of pollution and non-renewable natural resources .
without full accounting costs , some of the worst economic activities will continue to perform very profitably .
successful transitions to the green economy require new metrics .
the good news is that some countries have begun to calculate the hidden costs of co2 emissions .
in the us , the “ social cost ” of carbon has increased from $ 99 per ton to $ 35 .
in china , releasing pm2.5 levels has played a critical role in mobilizing public support for addressing air pollution .
we now need a similar measure to measure other forms of natural capital destruction , such as deforestation , bleaching , wastewater , and soil degradation .
after establishing these indicators , they must be incorporated into international accounting standards for private and public financial statements .
some companies are already releasing annual reports on full detail of the full details of corporate social and environmental impact , and will eventually reach a full report .
but moral change is not enough to achieve real change .
to prevent inaction , policymakers must take advantage of all tools and tools , including legislation , reporting guidelines , taxation , incentives , and public education .
financial regulators in emerging economies like bangladesh and china have already moved toward the right direction , introducing rules that promote financial inclusion .
china ’ s green credit banking guidelines require financial institutions to consider the environmental risks of lending portfolios .
finally , we need to discuss the merits and limitations of the current monetary policy and financial regulation honestly .
central banks , such as quantitative easing and near-zero interest rates , should be subsidizing green projects for low-cost financing .
instead , they have increased the profits of a larger financial institution , and credit to small and medium-size enterprises is severely constrained .
ironically , regulations aimed at strengthening financial stability tend to reward short-termism ( higher liquidity ) , rather than increasing the risk weights and costs of long-term projects ( most green are long-term projects ) .
regulators must recognize that if the real economy is unsustainable , bank reforms will not protect people ’ s lives , let alone protect the financial system .
adding green investment to 0.5 % would be enough to cover the annual financing gap .
the reason for the global financial crisis is that we ignore externalities ( shadow prices and institutions ) , allowing instability and injustice to proliferate .
building a more stable , sustainable future will require the relationship between policies , prices , and incentives .
as comey put it , “ greening is not easy ” , but the problem is that if we do not , the outcome is the result .
the 煤王 climate challenge
washington , dc – in the united nations climate change talks , which are currently underway in warsaw , coal is a major topic for dialogue – and rightly so .
indeed , the world needs such a discussion .
the latest discoveries by the intergovernmental panel on climate change ( ipcc ) suggest that we are running out of rapidly running out of our carbon “ budget ” – a trend that can be emitted at a time when there will still be significant opportunities to keep global warming below 2º celsius .
according to the ipcc , reducing global temperatures on the basis of pre-industrial levels would mean that the world emits only about 1,000 liters of carbon ( GtC ) .
by 2011 , we had emitted more than half of all 碳量 .
when it comes to tolerable co2 emissions , coal is the budget buster .
just this week , a group of 27 prominent scientists published a joint statement to point out that all known fossil-fuel reserves will produce 800 carbon dioxide , or $ 1 billion , with coal accounting for more than half .
in short , if the world ’ s current technologies are known to be known as the current world ’ s technology , it will likely increase global temperatures far beyond 2ºc .
many governments and financial institutions acknowledge this .
in recent months , the bank , the european investment bank , and the united states have introduced new policies to limit new coal-fired power projects , unless they capture and store co2 emissions .
five nordic countries have joined the us treasury and stopped using public funds to support new coal-fired power plants , and other countries may soon follow suit .
this fall , the environmental protection agency has proposed emissions standards for new plants , with conventional coal-fired power plants no longer available – an important step toward reducing carbon pollution and stimulating innovation .
likewise , china has begun to focus on the high health costs associated with burning coal , and the three coastal provinces will cease to develop new coal-fired power plants , according to its latest governance plans .
the chinese authorities have also developed policies that reduce coal ’ s share of energy .
against this background , the world ’ s coal federation is meeting this week , and it is at the center of warsaw – and , indeed , the negotiations that are being negotiated at the end of the global climate agreement in warsaw .
the wca is calling for “ 高效能 , 低 coal combustion technology ” to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions from coal-fired power plants worldwide .
but this approach would still consume too much carbon dioxide .
even the most modern and advanced conventional coal-fired power plants emit more than twice as much carbon dioxide per unit of power per unit of electricity per unit of electricity and more than twice as efficient gas-fired power plants .
and coal plants remain strong globally .
the world resources institute estimates that around 1,200 coal-fired power projects around the world have been planned , with total building capacity totaling more than 1,400 gigawatts .
if it is built , the world ’ s remaining budget will put a large share of the world ’ s high-carbon infrastructure to high-carbon infrastructure for 40-50 years .
according to the international energy agency , according to the current world energy agency , the current trend toward coal will rise by an 升高 .
that will be an immensely irreversible change for life in the planet .
that is why the oecd secretary-general points to the need to stop building traditional coal-fired power plants .
the government can use more cost-effective technologies for electricity generation .
in many places , renewable energy ( such as solar and wind power ) has been competitive with fossil fuels , and can quickly expand .
moreover , most economic models lack the externalities associated with coal and carbon pollution .
according to a recent report by Trucost , for example , the damage caused by global coal power in areas like climate change and air pollution amounts to about $ 1 trillion .
many coal-fired power plants will be uncompetitive if they are required to internalize these costs .
of course , coal provides a reliable power for millions of people – a transition to low-carbon technologies overnight .
we need to expand access to these technologies quickly , while helping those who depend on the coal industry .
we need to maintain enthusiasm for climate change , but we must also adopt a pragmatic approach to addressing climate change .
but the coal industry must do so as well .
participants at the wca meeting this week should commit to more measures to help ensure that carbon emissions limit their security .
this would help to signal to the world that the coal industry really understands the scientific impact of current energy use , and is willing to assume greater responsibility in the fight against climate change .
we need to work on both sides of the world to build a fair , ambitious 2015 global climate agreement .
let us work together to create a safe and efficient low-carbon economy .
the chinese bureaucratic earthquake
beijing – the fallout from the big earthquake in sichuan has gone away , and it is time to look at the impact of the big earthquake on china ’ s political system .
has the earthquake fostered a new , positive political force that could accelerate reform ?
that happened before .
after all , a sharp political change in the country ’ s top leaders , such as the fall of “ four ” and deng xiaoping ’ s consolidation of power , was shortly after the 1976 earthquake in 1976 .
with prime minister wen jiabao ’ s efforts at disaster relief and president hu jintao ’ s lackluster political record , one might have been tempted to imagine that the earthquake may have changed the balance of the ccp ’ s highest balance , with the liberal forces that wen represented .
but the idea was naïve .
unlike 30 years ago , there is no strong demand for political reform in china ’ s large bureaucratic system .
at the time , mao ’ s cultural revolution forced a large number of his revolutionary comrades toward reform .
in today ’ s china , most bureaucrats like the status quo , and have enough resources to protect themselves .
although wen has won popular support for the earthquake victims , he remains isolated in official circles .
and , though hu is hard to hide his incompetence , the bureaucrats are not shy .
after all , they do not want someone who has both the capacity and the others to lead .
but the sichuan earthquake was not entirely irrelevant to china ’ s political process .
wen ’ s bureaucratic grip on the bureaucracy has long sought to deal with the media by expanding the media ’ s openness and transparency .
he tried to use the beijing olympics to give foreign media unprecedented freedom , but the bureaucrats managed to reverse his decision .
the earthquake gave wen an unexpected second chance .
he used television and his extraordinary performance to prove that modern media and information tools can limit china ’ s bureaucracy .
this precedent is difficult to reverse , and it will have a profound positive impact on china ’ s political process .
this earthquake , together with the media transparency that followed , makes bureaucrats more accountable .
thousands of people have died , including nearly 10,000 schoolchildren , and their parents are hard to mollify .
millions of people have been displaced and must be resettled for years .
bureaucrats must not spend an arbitrary spending on their largesse and national relief funds .
as a result , a new political culture conducive to accountability may have a realistic opportunity to grow .
but this is not to say that china will produce a kind of bold and capable political leadership .
indeed , i believe that china ’ s future leaders are more likely to come from china ’ s burgeoning , but still limited , civil society .
although the ccp uses different means to suppress their development , the sichuan earthquake shows that the ccp can not eliminate non-governmental organizations as a social force .
the earthquake gives them an opportunity to demonstrate that an unprecedented number of people have an opportunity to see this nascent civil society as a positive force in their interests .
there is also a more unknown force , which may produce a new generation of political leaders : the growing christian believers are now estimated to be 20 million .
in china , there is a growing number of people , with many people who believe that a growing number of people are in the communist party ’ s bureaucracy , in addition to the chinese communist party ’ s bureaucracy , and that it is becoming even missionary .
in most of today ’ s closed environment , they are largely unaware of their own political skills and vision .
more open and transparent public environments will help awaken their sense of political mission .
but we must ask : when will major political change arrive ?
wen ’ s recent book in sichuan , the sichuan museum of sichuan , was evidently convinced that the chinese will suffer more pain than they can achieve political progress .
this may be right , but i am convinced that a new generation of political leaders can grow in a more open information environment .
and we must hope that all leaders will refuse to use their people ’ s lives as bargaining chips in the coming showdown .
an economic agenda for italy
milan – at the end of the month , italian voters are approaching the next government , expecting the new government to provide more jobs and a more equitable platform of economic activity – and other european partners expect it to implement structural reforms and streamline fiscal consolidation .
so what should the new government ’ s economic-policy agenda be ?
in order to reduce current public debt and minimize painful adjustment processes , italy desperately needs economic growth – a problem that has eluded policymakers in recent years .
indeed , italy ’ s average gdp growth has been at an anemic 0.5 % since joining the european economic and monetary union in 1999 , well below the eurozone ’ s 1.5 % average .
since the global financial crisis erupted , growth has fallen to -1.2 % , and this year is expected to be negative , while the eurozone average growth rate is -0.2 % .
the biggest challenge facing the new government is to implement successful reforms – a reform that has kept the economy behind other neighbors after years of bad policy and paralysis .
this calls for increased investment in innovation and human capital .
from 1992 to 2011 , labor productivity in italy grew at an average annual rate of 0.9 % , the lowest in the oecd .
and since 2001 , unit labor costs have been higher than real gdp and employment growth , which has undermined their economies ’ competitiveness relative to developing countries .
as a result , italy ’ s share of global exports has fallen from 3.9 % to 2.9 % over the last decade .
persistently weak labor-productivity growth has led to such a situation – even if real wages are stagnant or falling , and unit labor costs have not fallen .
indeed , despite a 1.3 % drop in real wages in 2011 , unit labor costs have never changed .
to address these problems , italy ’ s new leaders must separate the labor force from contributing to productivity growth and total factor productivity .
according to the oecd ’ s forecast , lower regulatory costs and more effective public management – based on measures taken by mario monti ’ s last government – could increase the average annual growth rate of 意大利 % by 2020 .
likewise , labor-market reforms , educational attainment , and increased human capital will contribute to an additional 4 % growth in the coming decade .
moreover , italian policymakers should strive to boost female labor-force participation – which is now 49 % and the lowest in the oecd .
doing so would allow the national average to increase by 1 % by 2030 .
meanwhile , fiscal adjustment remains essential for italy ’ s short- and long-term stability .
italy ’ s new leadership must sustain this progress .
despite positive economic developments now , the road ahead remains bumpy .
to guide the future of the future requires italy to build trust between eu members and international investors .
the new prime minister will need to persuade germany , financial markets , and the european council that italy is a reliable partner .
the ability to refinance government debt and reduce spending is essential to strengthening public finances and promoting gdp growth .
moreover , attracting more direct investment is important , given that capital inflows are now below 70 % below pre-crisis levels ; capital outflows exceed capital inflows , and italy has become a net capital exporter .
“ selling ” italy in europe requires not only the leaders of other countries ’ leaders , or in london , but also in london ’ s financial institutions .
italy ’ s leaders should actively join business diplomacy , using the embassies and trade agencies to promote their own global advocacy , while establishing strong bilateral relations with other eu member states , particularly in southern spain .
at the same time , a new generation of leaders will need to “ sell ” europe in italy , with euroskepticism now spreading across europe .
according to the pew research center , just 30 % of italians are positively positive about the euro .
in northern italy , where per capita income is three million ( $ 4.5 million ) per capita ( $ 4.5 million ) , it is suspicious of eu membership .
they believe that they have paid a lot of costs , but did not benefit ?
moreover , fear of structural recession is pervasive throughout the country .
the crisis has lasted long , and people are tired .
the unemployment rate has risen to a record 11.2 % , which means that 35 % of young people are unemployed .
and the tax burden has been more than 40 % of gdp since 1990 , and now stands at about 43 % of gdp .
if public services do not fall below those of northern europe , the tax burden on this level of convergence is manageable .
sweden , denmark , and finland , for example , spend more than $ 300 per capita on public health spending , compared to just $ 175 in italy , implying that italy ’ s households must pay for 20 % of all health-care spending .
moreover , italy spends about 4.5 % of gdp on education , while the nordic countries spend more than 6 % of gdp .
as a result , italian students score significantly less on international student assessments than students in other oecd countries .
italy ’ s new government must demonstrate leadership and demonstrate a vision of a stable economy toward stable growth , avoiding the decline in the economy and reducing mounting social tensions .
most important , economic revitalization depends on the next government ’ s willingness and ability to respond to institutional weaknesses , which have made concerted action increasingly urgent .
europe ’ s energy tax
bush ’ s disastrous war in iraq has put europe in a pickle .
the us has long been europe ’ s protector .
now , given the war that europe does not want to be involved , europe has been weakened .
iraq ’ s chaos has emboldened iran , and iran is far more dangerous for europe than iraq .
and , because the us is bogged down in iraq , russian president vladimir putin has revived soviet-style bullying tactics .
would russia really dare to threaten its nuclear missiles if it does not ?
high oil prices make it easier for iran to build nuclear weapons and allow russia to use energy blackmail to threaten europe .
but europe can back back .
by imposing high taxes on energy consumption , europeans could reduce energy prices in energy consumption and international markets , thereby cutting off funds to russia and iran .
because crude oil is priced in dollars , the dollar has depreciated relative to the euro , and european consumers have been freed up relative to energy prices .
so the energy tax , roughly the same as the euro ’ s 33 % appreciation in recent years , is basically correct .
the idea that america ’ s military adventure in iraq raises the price of oil , and that it should be forgiven for oil prices to return to oil prices .
but the us is now a “ texas oil man ” in power that will not happen .
perhaps after 2008 , the change in american politics will benefit energy taxes , but it is now needed .
moreover , given the power of environmentalism in europe , the issue is specifically to make europeans work .
moreover , europeans do not narrowly equate national security with military spending .
they know that cutting off iran and russia would probably make the world safer than it is to build a submarine or aircraft carrier .
indeed , the energy tax would not only effectively counter the idea that europeans are “ 逃票 ” on defense ; it would also be tantamount to the role of defense .
yet , given that transfers to governments are already many , europeans may have increased discontent .
that is why energy taxes and payroll taxes must be implemented in the form of tax substitution , while income taxes and payroll taxes reduce the amount of actual transfers to governments .
this would strengthen national security while boosting economic growth .
critics worried that the cost of a energy tax does not account for tax substitutions .
they do not seem to recognize the far cheaper way to protect themselves from the threat posed by other means , such as the increase in the size of energy sources , such as the military expansion .
europe currently lacks military power , because it made its decision a half-century ago to protect the us , and to use the savings to build its own welfare state .
this strategy has been working for decades , but it is the risk that america ’ s resources are likely to be depleted elsewhere , leaving europe without effective protection .
this risk is becoming reality because of the iraq war .
but europeans are showing little interest in increasing defense spending , regardless of iraq ’ s war .
many believe that the new president , nicolas sarkozy , is a hawkish foreign policy hawk , but even he is pulling back from his campaign promises to keep his military spending from 2 % of gdp .
sarkozy conspicuously failed to repeat his promises in a recent speech to the french defense industry , instead warning that he might cut france ’ s defense budget immediately .
according to a respected defense industry publications , sarkozy ’ s victory in june ’ s parliamentary election was a little less than expected .
the reason europeans are reluctant to increase defense spending is expense .
spending on entitlements is costly , and that spending cuts will be painful .
the solemn promises that have been made for years have to be violated ( the social services that people can not afford to be paid for ) , and that they would reduce ( hospitals and 福利院 funding ) , while overall suffering increases .
even economic growth will not prevent a tradeoff between defense and welfare spending .
defense has been relying on the us for a half-century , creating a powerful “ peace industry ” in europe , and its main business is to fight defense spending .
the new migration from eastern europe may be a constraint on the “ peace of the people , ” which would not violate the promise of social services , but also work and wages .
but the new migrants ’ access to decisive political influence remains to be seen for some time , and europe ’ s iran and russia need immediate attention .
in short , europeans will not allow bush ’ s iraq war to become a war on their welfare state .
an energy tax that makes a tax substitution especially attractive is an attractive place for defense measures , while maintaining welfare states intact while making europe safer , greener , and rich .
so what is to wait ?

a new asian security constellation
new delhi – senior officials in india and south korea recently met in recent meetings with a new “ strategic partnership . ”
they are not alone , because , throughout asia , a new security architecture is being built , but is steadily building .
how asia ’ s geopolitical situation will evolve in the coming decades will be far from certain .
but it is clear that an increasingly assertive china is playing the role of america ’ s role in asia ’ s role as a guarantor of security and stability in the region .
four different asian security conditions are possible in the coming years or decades .
first , there is a sino-centric asia .
china seeks a multipolar world , but to dominate asia .
by contrast , the us tried to build a multipolar asia , but it wants to build a multipolar asia .
the second scenario is that the us remains the most dominant force in asia ’ s security , regardless of the third possibility : the emergence of a security chain based on shared interests , and ensuring that asia ’ s unipolar situation does not happen .
the last scenario is that asia will be defined as a 一连串 regional power , including japan , india , vietnam , indonesia , and a reunified korean peninsula .
in these four cases , the first has led to considerable unease .
china ’ s neighbors increasingly worry about its growing power and assertiveness .
when china ’ s rulers are intent on building a sino-centric asia , they can not become a reliable candidate for asia ’ s leaders .
after all , real leadership is not simply derived from power , but from other countries ’ consent or tacit consent .
if the leadership roles were created by military overreach , the 小混混 of schools can become presidents .
in any case , china ’ s power will be enormous and growing , but it lacks a coercive power .
in other words , china has no capacity to expel any of its military aggression , let alone to impose on it on asia .
this fact has not eased fears in the region .
with china ’ s military expenditures growing at more than twice as fast as gdp , the country has begun to drop the charade , and self-confidence has been able to act .
china , for example , currently views the south china sea as a “ core national interest ” with taiwan and tibet , in order to conduct military operations alone in the region .
according to india ’ s defense officials , china is increasing the military ’ s deployment of a 军队 border .
as china attempts to transform its economic influence into geopolitical advantages in asia , the country that once described itself as “ friends of friends ” finds that growing power might lead to a renewed concern , but its actual actions have boosted new concerns and fears .
which country will call china asia ’ s leaders ?
the brutal suppression of six decades of brutal repression is not even hard to identify with tibet and xinjiang , which could be known from the tibetan and uighur uighur figures of 2008 .
leadership requires not just a strong economy and military power , but a force that can inspire all sides .
this power is also often a moral veneer for the pursuit of a particular objective or interests .
for example , the us and its allies are not winning the cold war , but by sowing ideas and market economies to other regions .
as the strategic analyst stanley a. 崴 put it , “ it ’ s eating the new blood of communism , leaving it out of global appeal , ” and it will eventually fail to satisfy the aspirations of a better and more open life .
while it has already shown confidence in its own national interests and the classic geopolitical balance , china can not simply pursue its own interests or contain potential rivals if it is to replace the us and lead its rivals .
more fundamentally , china represents what values and ideas are .
in the absence of an answer to this question , china ’ s excessive assertiveness spurs the us to strengthen america ’ s security cooperation in asia .
south korea has already strengthened its military alliance with the us , japan ’ s previous demand that the us military base withdraw from okinawa , and , in the asian countries , india , vietnam , indonesia , and the philippines all have closer to the us .
in terms of military power , and the distribution of military bases and the number of asian security allies in asia , no single force or alliance will be comparable to the us in the next 25 years .
but , while the us continues to ensure its central role in asia , its security treaty will need to be defended by security guarantees for allies and partners .
america ’ s determination to do so with allies when things are going sour will determine its ability and scope for future asian security alliances .
the third and fourth scenarios may be possible in the united states , where the us remains the bedrock of its asian security .
asian countries are also starting to build multilateral security nets , laying the groundwork for a strategic partnership with the future .
indeed , asia , linked by strategic cooperation , is crucial to achieving regional stability .
a new deal for un reform
the united nations is deeply troubled .
the controversy over the creation of a united nations human rights council has just been resolved , and the new dispute has begun .
the us is pressing for administrative reforms and threatening to cut funding without reform .
the secretary-general has submitted a sensible reform plan , but most countries in the un , the united nations member states , are sharply opposed .
this is because they believe that it is a step toward weakening the un general assembly , serving as yet another step in the security council , and , in particular , the proposal to give the secretary-general more power and responsibilities , and the security council ’ s five permanent members , which have veto power , actually decided .
many un member states believe that the un ’ s internal power is shifting from the un general assembly , thereby refusing to abandon what they perceive as the last authority , by controlling the budget by the convention ’ s fifth committee .
in practice , the fifth committee imposed the kind of 宏观管理 that should be imposed by the secretary general and the management of the secretary general , which can ensure that the un works effectively and with the challenges that it can face .
this is the basis for america ’ s insistence on administrative reforms .
there is a urgently needed way to find out that dilemma .
the current proposal , if failing , would mean that all un reform efforts will end the disaster , with devastating consequences for the provision of assistance provided by the united nations development program , the un ’ s myriad peacekeeping missions , and the myriad other services provided by un agencies .
the way to a satisfactory end is clear : giving the general assembly a greater role to the general assembly ’ s selection problem is that the member states will be empowered to empower their own authority .
this approach would not only implement much-needed administrative reforms , but also clarify the need for improved progress and transparency .
after all , the un charter stipulates that the un general assembly appointed the secretary-general under the auspices of the security council .
originally conceived , these two institutions will agree on a candidate .
in practice , however , the five permanent members agreed on candidates to agree on the security council , the subsequent un general assembly , and then by the un general assembly .
the substantive discussion of the new secretary-general is being carried out by secret members of the five permanent members , adding to other member states , including those seeking to expand the size of the security council .
the united states , for its part , should reform the budget process in order to persuade the other permanent members of the security council to play a larger role in the process .
there are several ways to do that .
the security council can agree to recommend several candidates , and the un general assembly has chosen .
likewise , the un general assembly could recommend several candidates for the security council , and the security council has chosen one of the next to be ratified by the assembly .
either way , the selection process will benefit from greater transparency .
for example , the general assembly should hold public hearings to press candidates for candidates , thereby dramatically increasing the candidate ’ s standing .
such proposals would help resolve the current dispute if they are accepted , and all parties are satisfied .
indeed , these proposals will make the un stronger than ever .
new dawn for chinese journalism
a major incident inspired chinese journalists .
earlier this year , the government banned newspaper bing , the newspaper bing dian weekly , fueling public protest .
even more surprising , the government has allowed bing to keep bing on the hook .
the editor-in-chief of the bing and the editor-in-chief were sacked , but public questioning of the legitimacy of the government ’ s authority to regulate journalism is bound to have a profound impact .
foreign observers like to associate the bing dian incident with other recent crackdowns on china ’ s mass media , and concluded that , under current bureaucratic control , china ’ s press freedom has no hope of any hope .
there is no denying that , since the chinese government launched its opening of reform 30 years ago , governments have no significant change in the system ’ s regulatory system .
on the contrary , the system has become more rigorous and covert .
but i am also convinced that subtle changes are emerging .
one prerequisite for effective control of the media is the accepted acceptance of the controller ’ s ideology .
after 1949 , the chinese communist party cultivated a pile of “ theoretical experts ” and other ideological servants to write a lengthy article to promote “ marxism . ”
now , however , it is difficult to see how such writers are involved , and their creations will be ridiculed by readers .
indeed , it is widely derided that china ’ s ideological grip on ideology can be maintained only through internal notices and telephone calls .
more important , even regulators themselves have no longer embraced rigid dogma .
i recently met with a official who was in office , and i had impressed me with a bold and bold commentary on the immediate present .
for news producers , they have long believed that news is propaganda .
my career began in 1979 , and i joined daily youth daily , experiencing the entire process of china ’ s reform and opening up .
by the mid-1980 ’ s , the chinese news workers of our generation passed a broad reading of the traditional communist idea of journalism .
younger journalists have thus been able to reach western news ideas from the start .
indeed , in china ’ s universities , western works are taught as “ models for writing ” to journalism students .
this is a crucial change , one of the most fundamental reasons for the growing number of chinese journalism and the number of real comments today .
market pressure is also important in pushing china ’ s media to embrace change .
contrary to what foreign countries recognize , only a handful of chinese media – such as the people ’ s daily , the 光明日报 , and the 经济日报 – are dependent on government money .
central television relies mainly on its advertising revenue , and the government pays only a fraction of its large budget .
whether most local broadcasting or tv stations survive will survive in the market .
political information remains subject to tight control , which has contributed to the development of “ harmless ” recreational , entertainment , and sports information – a story that is basically free .
in the short run , this is a recipe for low journalistic standards .
but , in recent years , many of the products that have thrived on 红火 红火 have begun to decline .
sooner or later , readers will begin to buy the newspapers that they can provide , expressing their views .
indeed , it is precisely these tabloids who have started to take responsibility for market pressure to respond to market pressure .
in recent years , they have repeatedly been sensitive to sensitive news .
as a result , mainstream media are marginalized , and previously marginalized media have become the main media .
so , even if the current system does not change any changes , the pursuit of disaster , judicial abuses , and citizens ’ pursuit of their own legal equity , and the broad coverage of policies from public perspective , is now common .
in the south , for example , reports of the south korean ocean have led to the kind of abortions that the state department publishes .
the 连续 report on sars made the chinese public aware of the truth about the epidemic .
the bing shimbun daily published the taiwanese writer 龙应台 龙应台 on taiwan ’ s democratic development .
these gains are slow and frustrated , reflecting the gradual evolution of the system .
nevertheless , this progress is real progress , suggesting that the chinese media ’ s growing influence , and that china is becoming a “ free expression ” country .
as the old saying goes , a “ 得道多助 , a little more than a little more . ”
the “ 道 ” resides in people ’ s hearts .
without the hearts and minds of producers of news producers – or , rather , the people who gradually lose their journalistic censors – this seems to be as formidable as the collapse of the berlin wall .
a new deal for fragile states
paris – around a quarter of the world ’ s population is now living in fragile and conflict-affected countries .
despite the vast amount of money invested in these countries over the last 50 years , armed conflict and violence are continuing to take millions of lives .
i experienced firsthand the need for a new approach in 2004 .
in december , sri lanka struck a devastating tsunami , with foreign ministers visiting the island in nearly 50 months .
every minister brings the country ’ s own initiative , its own civil-society organizations , and its own television media .
almost no one has a deep understanding of the dynamics of political conflict between tamils and sri lanka ’ s state .
the result is a great mistake , fueling further violence .
one of our major challenges today is to change the old model of partner , policy , and financing by donor countries and partners .
conflict-affected countries need to be able to decide their own destinies .
we should establish a post-conflict transition model , proposed by the g7+ , a group of fragile states .
this model is simple : countries themselves assess their own situation , using tools that they develop , thereby planning to plan for peace , prosperity , and plan for prosperity .
that sounds like the sky in the sky , but we have already tried in africa , where the 2013 繁荣 agenda ( Agenda ) and liberia ’ s vision 2030 demonstrate the potential for such planning .
progress is being monitored by countries that meet the urgent need to consolidate peace , expand access to justice , and increase security .
the truth suggests that using local institutions and capabilities strengthens progress .
the “ new deal for a fragile state ” was established in a series of international commitments on aid and development , and the fourth assistance summit in south korea in 2011 is highly welcome .
the plan proposes a similar pattern , arguing that the most important elements of building a peaceful state and society : a commitment to improving aid to the region and the region ’ s fragile regions – peace and development goals .
the new deal suggests that the history of peaceful construction teaches us that the country ’ s national leadership and all are essential to achieving clear and sustainable results .
as the south sudan finance minister 诺盖 Ngai put it , “ we don ’ t engage in what we do . ”
in several conversations with south sudan ’ s president , Salva Kiir , we discussed a clear list of priorities for the new country .
but these goals can be meaningful only if partners in fragile countries are willing to accept what they do , rather than their own headquarters .
more than 40 countries and institutions support the new deal ’ s approach , promising to build better partnerships and the resources and political capital needed to invest .
this is the new deal ’ s innovation story ; it creates political support around the issues needed to achieve a country from conflict and fragility toward peace and stability .
supporting inclusive political dialogue , ensuring conflict through peaceful means , is the most urgent task , as well as the private sector ’ s dynamic problems with security , justice , and the creation of full employment opportunities .
moreover , many fragile countries are rich in natural resources , and must build transparent resource management – aimed at curbing corruption , controlling the illegal flow of money , and the illegal flow of goods and goods .
focusing on these processes would ensure that fragile states become leaders and those responsible .
as partners , we must accept the country ’ s leadership .
after haiti ’ s earthquake in 2010 , the country became a “ 共和国 republic . ”
external partners can not create conditions for the haitian people themselves to dominate their grip on their own territory , undermining the establishment of well-functioning internal governance systems .
how , then , will we translate our commitment and priorities to improving the lives of people who are affected by conflict and fragility ?
oecd countries need a model to guide their commitments .
our partners must continue to demand changes in policies and measures by groupings like the g7+ .
with the 2015 deadline for the millennium development goals , progress toward peace , security , and non-violent conflict resolution continued to be critical , and must be fully integrated into the future development agenda .
recently , with international peace building and national construction dialogue ( the high-level political forum on the new deal ) meeting in washington , dc , member states met in washington to assess progress toward changing work and implement new deals .
they have passed the washington declaration , which urged partners , the brics , and civil-society organizations to win further progress according to the new deal , and call for a development agenda for peace and state-building in the post-2015 period .
ultimately , our progress depends on the determination of all people to make living in the face of violence , conflict , and insecurity .

what went wrong with the eu ’ s lisbon treaty ?
