but none of this is as isolated as the euro has been .
in many countries , “ power ” was politically neutral .
after all , there is no linkage between national power and power in europe .
if we want europe to become more legitimate , we must show how to link these two areas .
aside from the public ’ s lack of understanding of the lisbon strategy and the inability of member states to do nothing in the long term , another problem is that people lack the knowledge - competition , innovation , and low interest rates – to ensure quality , innovation , and low prices .
competition also reduces rent-seeking problems , eliminating protection of traditional corporate interests .
similarly , while competition improves the quality of research and education , it does not necessarily need to cut public investment , base basic research , or eliminate research funds .
competition can force policymakers to ensure transparency and fairness , and that the effective means of restoring democracy and modernizing political institutions will probably be the most important .
the so-called centrists must give up their privileges , and adjustment companies must limit collusion between managers , civil servants , or politicians .
we must explain to people that europe is upholding the democratic virtues of public faith , in economic , political , and social life .
the main objective of how to organize research and higher education is the lisbon strategy .
fundamental changes to the appointment of academics and researchers in most member states , or to overhaul the standards of teaching and experiment , are impossible , but the eu can become a catalyst for quality and reform in the country , which has become a catalyst for national quality and reform .
emulation with good excellence will be the essence of competition .
the french socialist party ’ s leader , dominique strauss-kahn , was a good start , arguing that 0.25 % of europe ’ s gdp is dedicated to research and development .
moreover , europe must develop tools to analyze strategic analysis , assess , and forecast the public debate .
these across europe must remain free and independent , and leaders need to listen to their advice and integrate their advice into crafting decision-making .
in many areas of the lisbon strategy , the eu can not avoid member states ’ concerns .
but , because all countries can not do it alone , they will not reject political control , and we must combine the eu ’ s policies with policies that are well connected to member states .
otherwise , the lisbon strategy could merely create an inefficient bureaucracy , rather than catalyzing the eu ’ s democracy .
in short , the lisbon strategy would have expected europe to become a true giant for decades to come , or to promote further euroskepticism .
a new democratic agenda for russia
moscow – when russian president dmitri medvedev ’ s statement on the federal assembly , his speech seemed to be directed at an advanced , prosperous country , rather than today ’ s russia , which is all the more true .
russia will hold a presidential election in 2012 .
in my view , the events of 2011 will exceed the 2012 election campaign .
indeed , while domestic opposition has refused to change , some are irresponsible to draw russia into an “ incorrigibly authoritarian state , ” but society ’ s development is likely to change russia ’ s politics completely .
but to achieve this , new initiatives must be developed this year .
a decade ago , defending the territorial integrity and restoring the rule of law was a priority for russia .
the people supported president vladimir putin , who is committed to stabilizing the russian order .
the precise approach and the results of the results , while debatable , have been overcome by the fact that the “ existential challenge ” has been overcome .
but progress on stabilization further highlights russia ’ s unresolved problems , even though it was not the global financial crisis , but these problems have become more serious in the global financial crisis .
after all , russians have opted for this , 资源 , and 依赖 economy .
the same can not be blamed on the onset of the global financial crisis , which has undermined official corruption at all levels .
we russians continue to rely on oil and gas , and forget that these resources are not a permanent solution to the problem .
but even under favorable world markets , we failed to address the poverty problem facing millions of russians .
i believe that all of russia ’ s troubles come from politics .
only in such circumstances can a solution be difficult to find .
but , starting in 2005-2006 , government measures have almost shut down the likelihood of immediate problems .
by appointing an election to the region ’ s provincial provincial governors , political parties rank on the list of electoral lists , driving up the electoral threshold to the duma , and the elimination of a minimum standard of voting – all of which are accompanied by a political system in which all of the elections and public media manipulate them .
in this case , political elites become self-absorbed , and only their own narrow interests .
this summer , with wildfires raging outside moscow , the political elite increasingly became more dangerous .
but there are other factors at work : the public ’ s demands are growing , and they know how to express their own interests while knowing how to express their claims .
while the traditional russian society is neither deep nor strong , real progress toward this goal can be seen .
public activists , journalists , ecologists , businessmen , and ordinary people who have experienced the tyranny of public officials have begun to participate .
this is partly the case with the government .
medvedev ’ s construction of a highway building near moscow ’ s highway near the massive public protests is a meaningful step .
for a few months , moscow and the federal government have abandoned their opponents of highways , so medvedev ’ s decision sent a signal to people that they are not allowed to ignore their demands .
but , soon after that decision , the bureaucracy tried to turn public hearings into an inferior form , and the hearings were intended to give public and civil institutions a voice in addressing similar issues .
so the struggle between democracy and the anti-democratic side is growing .
if the opposite triumph prevails , the results that we have made in previous years – including the stability itself – have been made .
it is not secret that medvedev is publicly said in november that he wrote in his blog : “ there is a sign of stagnant political life at a time when political life is stagnant , and the threat of stability has become a threat . ”
the president ’ s statement is surprising .
medvedev ’ s view has reinforced his understanding of russia ’ s problems from politics – the ruling by the ruling party , the absence of opposition forces , and the lack of a few political players .
i welcome medvedev ’ s focus on social concerns and his anti-bureaucratic rhetoric .
but his statement is a first step in formulating russia ’ s new agenda , beginning with the need to restore and accelerate the pace of progress toward truly effective democracy .
it is important to convince russians that medvedev ’ s statement reflects his voice , and he believes that he is willing to fight for the people .
among these priorities , education is certainly the most important project .
we are close to the dangerous edges , and the provision of provisions for universal free education is likely to become hollow .
people ask : why did world war ii provide free education for free education after world war ii ?
social citizens also demand effective mechanisms for fighting corruption , which is becoming a growing political problem , owing to the growing gap between the government and the people .
indeed , today ’ s elites can not and will not solve it .
only a serious presidential plan supported by civil society and brave new political forces will be able to address this problem .
the new plan must also include strong economic factors .
patching up the budget deficit and a specific plan is not enough to ensure economic renewal .
russia needs a breakthrough , building a modern , knowledge-based , and ecologically sustainable economy .
i am sure that medvedev will be a leader in formulating russia ’ s new agenda , and he must take action in the coming year .
he will support the social community .
de-risking revisited
new york – before the latest bout of financial-market turbulence , a large number of risky assets ( including stocks , government bonds , and commodities ) have been rebounding since last summer .
but economic growth worldwide remains stagnant , despite the risk aversion and volatility that the risk aversion is declining .
today , the global economy is coming home to roost .
japan had to resort to two decades of stagnation and struggle for abenomics to avoid a recession .
in the united kingdom , the debate since last summer has focused on a triple-dip recession .
most eurozone countries remain mired in a severe recession , and now spread to the periphery .
even in the us , economic performance has been lackluster , with growth hovering hovering around 1.5 % over the last few quarters .
today , the darlings of the world economy is not immune to its own spin .
according to the imf , china ’ s annual gdp growth has slowed from 10 % in 2010 to 8 % in 2010 ; at the same time , india ’ s growth rate fell from 11.2% to 5.7 % .
russia , brazil , and south africa are growing at around 3 % , and other emerging markets are not .
the differences between finance and livelihoods ( rising asset prices and economic underperformance ) can be explained by three factors .
first , the tail risks of the global economy ( low-probability , high-impact shocks ) – the eurozone ’ s collapse , the collapse of the fiscal cliff in the united states , the chinese economy ’ s hard landing , israel ’ s economic hard landing , and the war on nuclear proliferation – would be lower a year ago .
second , despite disappointing growth in both advanced and emerging markets , financial markets still want better economic data in the second half of 2013 and 2014 , especially in the united states and japan , where most emerging markets will return to their knees .
optimists repeatedly reiterated “ this year ’ s different ” : after a prolonged period of painful deleveraging , the global economy should have been on the cusp of stronger growth .
third , in response to low growth and low inflation ( partly owing to lower commodity prices ) , the world ’ s major central banks have implemented a new round of unconventional monetary easing : lower policy rates , forward guidance , quantitative easing ( qe ) , and credit easing .
similarly , many emerging-market central banks have used lower policy rates to deal with low growth and low inflation .
that liquidity search for yield has fueled the rebound in global asset prices .
but there are two risks to 反弹 asset reflation .
first , if growth does not recover , it can not be expected ( and thus the validity of asset prices ) , which will eventually overwhelm the 浮力 of liquidity , forcing asset prices to fall as weak economic fundamentals fall .
second , some central banks – that is , the fed – would pull back ( or plumbers ) , exit from qe and zero policy rates .
this brings us to the recent financial-market turbulence .
in the first half of this year , growth in china and other emerging markets is slowing .
this explains the underperformance of commodity prices and emerging-market equities before the recent turmoil .
but the fed ’ s recent signs of tapering of qe – a stronger evidence with china ’ s slowdown and china , japan , and the european central bank – have made emerging markets worse off .
these countries find themselves in the 接收端 – not just the correction in commodity prices and equities , but also a brutal 货币 of currency 重新 and fixed-income assets .
brazil and other countries have complained that “ hot money ” inflows and “ currency wars ” are now being brought to what they want : the possibility of an early withdrawal from qe .
whether the correction in risky assets is temporary or the beginning of a bear market depends on several factors .
the first is whether the fed will be out of qe as soon as it signaled .
a weak us economy and lower inflation will force the fed to slow down the pace of liquidity support .
another variable is how monetary policy in other developed countries will be more accommodative .
the bank of japan , the european central bank , the bank of england , and the swiss national bank all have eased monetary policy without the economic lag .
how they will follow will depend largely on domestic conditions , and how china ’ s growth slowdown will threaten asia ’ s economy , commodity exporters , and the us and the eurozone .
the further slowdown in china and other emerging markets is another risk to financial markets .
how can emerging-market policymakers respond to instability : they will raise interest rates to prevent inflationary depreciation and capital outflows or reduce interest rates or lower interest rates , thereby increasing the risk of inflation and capital flows ?
finally , there are two factors : the rapid fall of the eurozone economy ( which recently signaled some signs of stability , but the monetary union ’ s chronic malaise has not resolved ) ; and tensions in the middle east and the threat of nuclear proliferation – and the threat posed by the us and israel – will escalate or succeed .
the new era of uncertainty and volatility is already underway , and it is likely to lead to a surge in economic and market drift .
in fact , a broader cycle of risk for financial markets is likely to come .
a new era for islamic science ?
for centuries , when science and mathematics are undergoing a period of great invention , one region in the world stood out .
the masters of these disciplines were revered there , medicine developed quickly , and ordinary people were curious about the nature of nature .
this region , too , has received little global respect .
in the other half of the planet ’ s known known , scientists are punished , even killed .
mathematics has been banned as a 异端 异端 , and thus became subservient to religion .
living standards are low .
the prosperous middle east was the middle east , and , by contrast , was ignorant europe in reverse .
while both regions are governed by religious rule ( historians ’ views and views of religion in this context differ ) , science flourished only in one of them .
of course , today ’ s roles in the middle east and the west have reversed .
since world war ii , the us has been the world ’ s undisputed leader in science .
throughout this period , the brightest students in the world were attracted to their country ’ s superior research universities and opportunities .
until recently , more than half of all mathematics , science , and engineering professionals were foreign-born .
many of these people stayed after graduation in the us , and the industry and government in the us have benefited from it .
at the same time , the islamic culture has entered a historical phase : science is being equated with western influence .
even in countries where oil revenues can support a substantial number of countries , arab rulers do not encourage such investment .
more recently , a more politically respected desire for greater political respect prompted the islamic state to invest in technology , most notably in pakistan and iran .
but , while nuclear weapons have some political heft , it is ordinary and old .
imagine the impact of a pakistani institution that is in the world lead in cancer research .
if researchers in oman find a way to suppress hiv , what will happen to the country ’ s political voice ?
this is an opportunity .
but another opportunity exists not just for islamic societies .
the us has lately been wrong .
as a whole , the “ right to faith ” has replaced science with the president .
when facts and official beliefs clash with official beliefs , the report ’ s reports have changed in political terms .
encouraged by a religiously influenced government , the school system will focus on shifting its focus from “ science ” to “ values . ”
since the terrorist attacks of 2001 , entry visas in the us have been reduced , and it has become more difficult for the flow of young people to us universities .
major scientific organizations have protested , but they do not help .
at the same time , changing the tax code makes investors richer in the short term , thereby discouraging long-term spending on research .
the iraq war has received $ 500 billion worth of funding – a amount that almost equals the amount of funding that has been given for the last 1,000 years .
even if the us avoids a fundamentalist dark age , it is clearly facing the risk of losing global scientific dominance .
in the 1980 ’ s , japan recognized the link between political influence and science .
japan ’ s chief industrialist , jim yong ishihara , the chairman of sony , and right-wing politician shintaro ishihara , published a series of speeches in 1986 , with the publication of “ japan could be said to be the book . ”
they outlined a national strategy that produced world influence in science .
the key idea is that military power is obsolete if the “ food chain ” of military technology is controlled by other countries .
the book ’ s title refers to japan ’ s “ no ” military influence on us military influence after japan is in possession of key military technologies .
it is possible to build a knowledge-based economy with oil wealth .
for example , texas , like most southern us states , was once economically poor and deteriorating .
it has a revenues from oil , but it is not as much a boon for prosperity as it is for the economy .
so texas decided to devote its oil funds to an education fund .
the fund is now comparable to that of harvard university , and is shared by 15 universities .
the effect is amazing : aerospace manufacturing has almost disappeared from california , but in texas .
telecom research centers and consortia have , and even canada ’ s telecommunications giant 电信 , texas .
while manufacturing in the us is in crisis , texas is among the strongest in the world .
the same outcome can not be found in the middle east .
nevertheless , the islamic world must rediscover and inherit its proud tradition .
a new agenda for growth in europe
growth and employment need to be two-pronged .
the eu ’ s leaders have now recognized this , which will be a limited agenda for the european commission meeting in january 2012 .
but there is still a big question : how can growth revive growth ?
clearly , we need urgent action .
the eurozone contracted in the last quarter of 2011 , and even germany was not immune .
the new year looks grim .
france and britain are crumbling .
italy and spain are already in deep recession .
greece will be in a fifth year .
unemployment in the eurozone has reached all-time highs , with one in two young people jobless in spain and greece .
the difficulties facing the economy are large : fiscal austerity , higher interest rates in countries below the 级别 level , retrenchment in bank credit , weak private sector deleveraging , weak private sector investment , and a declining demand for the global slowdown .
unless growth picks up , any temporary fiscal stabilization is fragile .
recession will hit banks and governments ’ already-weak balance sheets , exacerbating pressure to deleverage .
but , while gradual adjustment is crucial , deep and deep cuts are likely to backfire : a massive reduction in private credit and government spending would lead to a sharper slowdown , causing a vicious cycle of recession .
new big growth is therefore essential .
so far , the growth agenda has been composed largely of structural reform , which is needed to boost productivity and productivity flexibility in the future .
the crisis does provide a political opportunity for many countries to do great things in this direction ; but , overall , structural reforms do not immediately generate growth and job opportunities ( except for allowing shops to prolong their purchases ) .
by contrast , measures like phasing out low-productivity jobs start up with unemployment , increasing government spending , and reducing private spending .
moreover , because demand is depressed , credit supply is deficient , and barriers to entrepreneurship are often higher , businesses will need more productive jobs than usual .
in short , structural reforms alone can not be relied upon to stimulate growth in 2012 .
indeed , it is time to focus on boosting investment and exports in surplus countries , such as france , italy , and spain ( as well as the united kingdom ) ; and boosting consumption of surplus countries like germany and the netherlands .
the ecb has taken decisive action to boost european banks ; now it should support the real economy simultaneously .
although official interest rates are only 1 % , countries like spain , which have no solvency problem , have a ten-year debt rate of 5 % , while in italy the creditworthy firm had to borrow at extremely high interest rates ( if it is financed ) .
as a result , the ecb should help to bypass the transmission mechanism of monetary policy ; the european banking authority should organize excessive deleveraging , different banks should have different capital requirements , and , when necessary , national governments should guarantee the loans to small and medium-size enterprises .
while improving access to finance is crucial , governments need to do more to boost investment .
they need to take steps as soon as possible , making it easier for startups to become more vulnerable , leaving risky capital to be limited by barriers to a wide range of barriers , to boost investment .
at the eu level , just as eu president josé manuel barroso proposed last september ’ s eu union address , the european investment bank ’ s ( 赎回 ) capital should increase substantially in order to provide financing to a large pan-european investment program , particularly infrastructure projects .
boosting growth also matters .
deficit countries need to increase their competitiveness , increase productivity , and cut costs .
a weaker devaluation – a lower payroll tax , and a higher tax on revenue – would also help .
the surplus countries should also do their part , in their own interest .
as china needs to allow the renminbi to appreciate , germany needs to increase its real exchange rate – both in absolute quantities and from its share of gdp , which exceeds china ’ s .
this means that germany should raise wages and allow wages to be tied to their rising productivity , thereby enabling the german people and spaniards to enjoy vacation .
if businesses do not want to do so , they can adopt a reduction in income taxes .
this requires fiscal policy .
governments that can not borrow from the market at low interest rates have no choice but to tighten their belts .
but they should pursue smart fiscal consolidation , not new austerity .
so they should maintain investment in skills and infrastructure , while cutting subsidies and transfer payments .
they should also legislate for future reform legislation , especially to encourage people to work longer .
finally , governments that can borrow at unprecedentedly low interest rates ( for example , germany , for example , can issue ten-year treasury bonds for more than a 0 % real interest rate ) should bear the responsibility to support demand .
is it really so difficult to see the vat drop before germany ’ s general election next year ?
a new holy alliance ?
london – saudi arabia ’ s king abdullah and pope benedict xvi , who recently met with the vatican ’ s “ custodian of the holy land , ” have been particularly consequential , especially as radical muslims are citing the role of “ jihadists ” in the middle east .
this is the clearest sign of the “ holy alliance ” that is being made in the world ’ s conservative leaders .
the main audience for the muslim king and roman catholic 教宗 was not their followers , but another conservative leader , president george w. bush .
the first “ holy alliance ” was the creation of the austrian prince metternich in the aftermath of the napoleonic war .
it aims to maintain peace ( and the security of the relatively vulnerable austrian empire ) by upholding a coalition of shared values .
metternich ’ s “ holy alliance ” was a creative political argument rooted in napoleon ’ s defeat .
after its lofty 名分 , it is an innovative innovation that has had a significant diplomatic significance : the introduction of a calculated 限制 factor .
its members , austria , prussia , and russia , have a vested interest in the survival of their own regimes , and thus to seek to avoid conflict .
metternich ’ s system worked in much of the nineteenth century , because it protected a genuine balance of power between countries with shared values .
but what about the saudi king , the pope , and the us president ?
that meeting itself suggests that both pope and king believe that they should make a difference .
indeed , king abdullah believes that he is the top leader of the muslim world , the first saudi king to meet the christian leader .
the two met ostensibly , not expressing shared conservatism , but confirming and promoting the authority of its traditional values .
both agreed that reforms must be slow and cautious , and they must not undermine the inherent institutions , especially religious and patriarchal families .
abdullah wants to meet because he believes that the world has divided the conservative party since 2001 .
until then , he and bush shared a shared worldview , emphasizing the importance of religion , traditional family ( as the two countries understood ) , social discipline , and the state ’ s role in supporting these mechanisms .
but america ’ s extremism has created tensions between the middle east ’ s religious communities and the rise of extremism in the region .
since 2001 , christian minorities throughout the region have called the target targets , including even lebanon ’ s maronite community .
in iraq , sunni muslims feel besieged by the majority of the country ’ s ruling majority .
against this background , the holy alliance of moral restraint has emerged .
abdullah may well understand that some restrictions are needed to prevent the entire middle east from becoming a bitter war .
moreover , abdullah understands that his crumbling regime would be able to withstand the radical winds of extremism if it can build a stable alliance that metternich created .
king abdullah and the austrian emperor , like the austrian emperor , understood tocqueville ’ s theory : the most dangerous moment of regime change is its beginning .
the king is careful to start politically open , and he knows that he needs regional peace and a reduction in islamic holy rage .
the problem is that abdullah can not rely on his domestic conservative allies to give him the time he needs .
the wahhabi religious establishment is the saudi state ’ s behind-the-scenes ruler , and it is likely to undermine attempts at regional religious reconciliation .
religious police members insist that the country ’ s christian guests must continue to abide by strict wahhabi rules .
the wahhabis could also be bribed by the oil dollar , a group of judges who eagerly await the next beheading , stoning , or 鞭击 in public square .
in doing so , the united states now is the only viable diplomatic strategy for saudi arabia , even if some of these conservatives are christian .
conservative rulers fall when the conservative rulers failed to control their own weaknesses , and , especially , the revolutionary challenge .
after all , few political systems can withstand these , like saudi arabia ’ s islamic extremists , who claim that they can maintain that system more effectively than their current rule .
abdullah believes that only conservative leaders and powers ( including the us retreat from diplomatic radicalism ) can restore some stability in the middle east .
a glimmer of hope for iran
berlin – hassan rowhani ’ s victory in iran ’ s presidential election is predictable .
even supreme leader ayatollah ali khamenei may be surprised by his first victory in rowhani ’ s first-round victory .
as a result , a new dynamic is possible with iran ’ s nuclear program and the syrian civil war .
but the situation is in the middle east : you never know what happens next .
this year marks the tenth anniversary of the launch of iran ’ s nuclear program , launched by iran and germany , france , and britain .
i was at the time representing germany , and rowhani led the iranian delegation .
the expansion of the talks between germany and the five permanent members of the united nations security council , the two permanent members of the united nations security council , remains until today , without any tangible results .
now rowhani has returned to iran ’ s risky nuclear program , though it is the president .
we – and what he should expect ?
according to individual experience , rowhani ’ s 性格特点 is civility and openness .
unlike outgoing president mahmoud ahmadinejad , he is not surrounded by skillful and experienced diplomats .
but he should have no doubt about the government ’ s relationship with the government , which is real and moderate , rather than the opposition representative .
to succeed in his presidency , rouhani must deliver on improving the iranians ’ commitment to improving living standards without endangering the islamic republic .
doing so will not be easy , and it is an impossible task .
the economic improvements that voters demanded when rouhani was elected are almost certain to be realized only if the west and international sanctions were removed .
but the premise of an end to international sanctions is a breakthrough in the nuclear negotiations .
economic development requires at least a temporary resolution of the major regional conflicts .
the region has changed dramatically over the past decade .
withdrawal from iraq and the withdrawal of afghanistan from afghanistan have weakened the us .
at the same time , we are witnessing the disintegration of the middle east in the middle east of england and britain , when the two imperial powers in europe , including today ’ s lebanon , have created territorial claims beyond the palestinians , the jordan river , and iraq .
the new regional order has not yet materialized , with a future of danger and chaos .
as iran seeks to maintain its influence and its shia allies , its nuclear dispute with the security council is linked to its regional ambitions .
after all , iran ’ s nuclear prospects will most likely exacerbate the regional nuclear arms race and violent conflict .
the two issues , therefore , must be addressed successfully before the sanctions were removed .
iran and its international interlocutors should take past lessons , and rightly anticipate the possible gains .
dialogue can not be reached quickly , given the diametrically opposed interests of all parties , and both domestic and coalition resistance , and a deep lack of trust in all sides .
moreover , in addition to negotiating with the p5+1 , direct and american negotiations are a good option for iran .
to achieve positive results , iran is likely to improve relations with saudi arabia and the gulf states and change its attitude toward israel .
likewise , the west must understand that the islamic republic is not homogeneous .
the iranian government has the power of many of its power centers to influence each other in the decision-making process .
the office of the president is only one of them .
the same is true of the supreme leader , who , despite its seeming title , is not in his hands .
the last decade has attempted two political paths : president mohammad khatami ’ s reformist model , and hardline radicalism under ahmadinejad .
this is a failure .
the reformers can not defeat the conservative opposition , while the radicals can not overcome the domestic economic realities of their foreign and nuclear policy .
rouhani must fight for a majority of power centers , while completing the task that voters give .
in iran , the pervasive loss of trust will complicate the difficult task that has become even more complicated .
many in the us and the west view rouhani as the islamic republic ’ s moderates , because ahmadinejad is more aggressive and perceived as the iranians .
in turn , many iranians regard obama as an american moderates attempting to overturn iran ’ s regime , and he views george w. bush as america ’ s most honest and radical representative .
both perceptions distort reality , but both contain practical factors .
while these perceptions are not accurate – perhaps precisely because they are inaccurate , rouhani ’ s government offers an unexpected opportunity for the nuclear negotiations and political settlement in syria .
during the afghanistan conference in bonn in 2001 , iran took a pragmatic and pragmatic approach , while iran did nothing in return .
as for nuclear negotiations , the p5+1 needs to focus on the objective of blocking all of iran ’ s military use by objective .
iran ’ s focus should be on upholding the right to peaceful nuclear energy by adhering to the non-proliferation pact and its provisions .
both problems sound more straightforward than simple : a failure to succeed , and there is plenty of room to negotiate , regulation , and enforcement .
it is important to highlight the need for realistic expectations .
the task of achieving a nuclear deal with nuclear negotiations , or even controlling major regional conflicts , is difficult .
but it would be a high degree of irresponsible irresponsibility not to seize the unexpected opportunity of rouhani ’ s election .
a second chance for european reform
munich – the european central bank ’ s commitment to stabilize eurozone government bonds has stabilized markets , because this promise is essentially assured creditors , and taxpayers and pensioners in countries where the eurozone is still strong still bear the burden of repayment .
despite the ecb ’ s failure to mention the implementation of its bond-buying program , its commitment has been enough to stimulate investors ’ appetite , reducing interest-rate spreads within the eurozone , and making it possible to reduce the financial burden of the crisis by printing ( target credit ) .
a temporary respite offers an ideal opportunity to reform reforms .
greek prime minister antonis samaras must convince the greek people that he is serious about implementing reforms .
spanish prime minister mariano rajoy and portuguese finance minister 加斯帕 加斯帕 deserve greater support .
we should also hope that italy ’ s caretaker prime minister , mario monti , is participating in the next election .
these leaders know what must be done .
instead , france has not noticed the writing on the wall .
president françois hollande wants to address france ’ s problems with growth programs .
but when politicians say “ growth , ” they actually mean “ money . ”
and that is what france needs most .
france ’ s debt/gdp ratio is already around 90 % , even though its budget deficit in 2013 is no more than 3.5 % , and its debt/gdp ratio will rise to 93 % by the end of the year .
the government ’ s gdp share is at 56 % of the highest in the eurozone , ranking second among all developed countries .
not only movie actors like 德帕迪 are missing out to avoid high taxes ; industry has the feeling .
france ’ s 的 carmakers are struggling to survive .
indeed , france ’ s manufacturing share of gdp has fallen to 9 % , below the united kingdom ( 10 % ) , and less than half of germany ’ s ( 20 % ) .
france ’ s current account is slipping into a deeper deficit hole .
unemployment is also creating a record .
france ’ s fundamental problem is that the euro ’ s underlying problem is that the cheap credit that the euro has brought to the fore is fueling inflationary bubbles and thus undermining its competitiveness .
goldman sachs calculated that france must maintain 20 % cheaper to sustain its debt sustainably .
the same is true of spain , which needs 10-15 % of the price of prices , and domestic prices in greece and portugal need to fall 30 % and 35 % , respectively .
so far , however , there has been virtually no progress on this front .
worse still , some troubled economies ’ inflation rates are still higher than their trading partners .
eurozone politicians tend to believe that it will regain competitiveness by implementing reforms , infrastructure projects , and improving productivity , and reducing domestic prices .
this is wrong , because these measures improve competitiveness only because they reduce domestic prices relative to eurozone competitors .
as long as these countries remain in the eurozone , they can not reduce their relative domestic prices : either they are deflationary or their trading partners will inflate faster .
there is no easy or socially comfortable way to achieve this .
in some cases , the risk is significant , and it may even be impossible .
the gap between the ability to restore competitiveness and what citizens can endure is too big to be found .
for an orderly devaluation , a country ’ s inflation rate must be below its competitors , but that can be achieved only through a recession .
the more trade unions struggle to maintain existing wage structures , the lower the productivity growth and the longer the recession becomes .
spain and france will need a decade of recession , in which they are less than 2 % below their competitors in the year preceding year .
for italy , the path to competitiveness is shorter , but the roads of portugal and greece are much longer – probably too long .
italy , france , and spain should be able to regain competitiveness within the eurozone for the foreseeable period .
after all , from 1995 ( a year when the euro was explicitly announced ) to 2008 ( the year of the global financial crisis ) , germany fell by 22 % relative to its eurozone trading partners .
a decade ago , germany , like france today , is europe ’ s sick .
it has experienced rising unemployment and inadequate investment .
most of the savings are invested abroad , the lowest in the oecd countries .
under pressure , schröder ’ s social-democratic government decided in 2003 to eliminate millions of germans ’ unemployment benefits , paving the way for a low-wage sector , which in turn reduced the inflation rate .
unfortunately , so far , the crisis countries – led by france – have yet to show ready for the bullet .
the longer they feel disillusioned with magic , the longer the euro crisis will be .
a new science
this summer , an unusual scientist at the conference in paris brought together scientists from around the world to discuss the need to create new science , and the new science that they discussed may be revolutionary , as einstein ’ s discovery a century ago discovered .
most scientists believe that basic science is known for humans .
the conventional wisdom , however , is that little has been found for what we have yet to discover .
the only question can be divided into three groups : “ important scientific challenges , ” such as the united states , which is at a very high level and 电学 , will require not only massive investment , but also first-rate research , as well as the actual work of “ scientific information . ”
beyond that , many believe that how to use existing laws to benefit humans from new technologies is the only hard work .
who can argue differently ?
after all , today ’ s model is successful .
but some scientists have begun to point out that existing theories can not fully explain some phenomena .
this missing scientific rule is to describe processes , and how the system evolves .
we have a very deep understanding of the single discipline .
physics , at least in the physics of our ordinary people , has built a comprehensive structure .
chemistry and biochemistry are similarly solid – though the body is unknown , but widespread perception is that we have a basic method of responding to cells and molecules .
a little more than a little more , the new social sciences , people , and societies are research fields .
in any area where physics , biochemistry , and social science are mature , the theoretical structure has been mature and there are too many 疑义 .
each discipline has its own language and mechanics .
few scientists have a variety of areas , because they are very different from both areas .
this means that we can not answer the interdisciplinary question .
the brain , for example , is composed of molecules that interact with the laws of physics , and the delivery of information follows from the laws of 电学 .
there is also a system of specialized cells , with the kind of 化学物质 chemicals taking place .
the interaction between the brain adds a new field : here , information is spread through language , symbolism , and ideas .
we have an abundance of information at every level , with a reasonably well informed interpretation of each level .
but information is being exchanged at different levels .
even in the most fundamental areas , there is no scientific explanation .
to address this problem , some scientists have tried to restructure a level at some level and apply them to other areas .
the “ language ” of the cell ’ s “ language ” and the “ energy ” of organized societies emerged .
some of this transplant can succeed , but do not solve the core problem : what features the information that can be transmitted across different levels , and how is it delivered ?
indeed , almost every system in the world has a different level .
in any case , there is a lack of understanding of how the system works .
the interdisciplinary scientist in paris is loosely affiliated with the “ foundations of information science . ”
they have been working together for eight years , from a range of countries and different specialties .
like relevant professional scientists , art theorists , psychiatrists , languages , and philosophers are beginning to join the discussion .
most groups sent great hopes to “ transplant ” strategies : the basic science of one at one level , while adjusting or supplementing , so that they can function .
others consider a new approach .
they believe that many scientific conventions are a coincidence of history , and new abstractions can be devised .
if the foundations of science are more fortunate , there will be no new idea that thinkers with first-rate research devices will be available .
independent thinking is often underestimated .
almost all of the activities that have reached the “ science ” of the “ science ” are associated with institutional convergence .
many people who believe in science are undergoing a revolution , and many of these ideas , sometimes revolutionary , are never linked to laboratories and research centers .
for almost two decades , the most advanced ideas of mathematical algorithms have come from a soviet empire with no computing power .
the wisdom of nearly two generations of the most intelligent and influential physical thinking is not that it is today , but budapest ’ s research .
iran has a tradition of architectural design , with major insights from cognitive scientists .
even today , the latest ideas of artificial intelligence ( so-called “ autonomous agents ” ) are 孵化 in prague .
the most creative breakthroughs are often 一举成名 .
when einstein was integrating new ideas into the physical discipline , the notion of time of time has changed dramatically .
the foundations of the information science in july are the beginning of this way of restoring the universe in this way .
scientists find the gaps that need to be explained , and they will absorb more thinkers , including scientists from the need to innovate .
following that , they will determine what new science might solve , with new discoveries .

a new start for non-proliferation
vienna – us president barack obama has injected new momentum into his efforts to halt nuclear disarmament for a decade .
he has made a promise of a world without nuclear weapons and acknowledges the link between nuclear non-proliferation and disarmament .
obama has said that he would restore the restoration of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty ( npt ) , which was restored in 1970 , aimed at preventing proliferation of nuclear weapons .
the nuclear non-proliferation regime , based on the nuclear non-proliferation treaty ( npt ) , is in disarray , with the main problem .
one problem is that the five main nuclear weapons have not taken seriously the npt ’ s obligations on nuclear disarmament .
instead , they insist that nuclear weapons are vital to their security , and are still modernizing their nuclear arsenals .
this naturally lost the moral authority to convince others not to acquire nuclear weapons , while nuclear weapons are still viewed as a source of power and influence , and a insurance policy that prevents attacks .
second , as we have seen in the case of north korea , there is no way to retreat from the npt ’ s signatories when they declared that the “ very big event ” has already threatened its high interests .
third , the international atomic energy agency , which is perceived as supportive of non-proliferation , is being underfunded .
when the international atomic energy agency is in secret in determining whether a country is engaged in secret nuclear weapons , the iaea inspectors often felt powerless , or because they lack the legal authority to enter into place in which they are deemed to have had to be examined , or because the agency can not acquire an adequate satellite image .
fourth , export controls have failed to stop the spread of sensitive nuclear technologies , particularly the complex and seasoned efforts taken by the secret nuclear networks , one of which is a case in point .
nine countries have a nuclear weapon , and , assuming that other countries , especially those in conflict zones , are not 非分之想 , are naive .
moreover , countries with nuclear energy projects have the capacity to do so : when their security is changing , they can produce nuclear weapons in just months , because they have a critical technology – uranium enrichment and reprocessing of plutonium .
if more countries follow suit , this will prove to be the achilles ’ heel of the non-proliferation regime .
the problem is that the international community , led by the united nations security council , is paralyzed by the challenges of international security , not responding effectively to suspected nuclear proliferation cases .
these problems can not be resolved overnight , but many work relatively quickly .
the us and russia are beginning to negotiate a massive reduction in the amount of nuclear warheads that both countries account for 95 % of the global nuclear warhead .
other key steps include the comprehensive nuclear-test-ban treaty into force ; by negotiating a verifiable treaty , the production of fissile materials used to stop weapons purposes ; and to improve the physical safety of the nuclear energy agency , while strengthening the international atomic energy agency .
last month , i presented advice on the international atomic energy agency ’ s board of governors of the international atomic energy agency ( iaea ) – the creation of an international atomic energy agency ( 浓缩铀 ) – to ensure that the supply of countries that are needed for nuclear fuel is needed to maintain its nuclear power reactor .
leu can not be used to create weapons .
this type of mechanism will play a key role in the coming decades , as more countries introduce nuclear energy .
this would give countries confidence that they can rely on reliable supplies of fuel to maintain their nuclear power plants , thus no longer need to develop their own uranium-enrichment or reprocessing capacity .
this would help to avoid iran ’ s experience after the 1979 revolution , when the nuclear energy program in the country ’ s planned nuclear energy program was not honored .
thirty years later , we still feel part of the consequences .
leu will open up to countries that exist in the basic , non-discriminatory criteria .
all countries that abide by the nuclear safeguards obligations can gain these materials at market prices .
countries will not be required to abandon the right to develop their own fuel cycles .
the launch of the new 启动资金 bank has been put in place , thanks largely to non-governmental organizations – the “ nuclear threat initiative , ” and initial funding from warren buffett .
but this is only the first step , and the next agreement should be signed , leaving all new enrichment and reprocessing activities to be taken seriously over many countries , and the regulation of all existing facilities will be transferred to the hands of a country .
this is a bold idea , but today we need bold ideas more than ever .
60 years ago , given the cold war ’ s relationship , the opportunity to place the nuclear fuel cycle under many countries under control ; today , the spread of nuclear technology is fueling the growing risk of it in this time .
a new palestinian state for israel and palestine
princeton – consider the two-state solution to the israeli-palestinian issue : the palestinians have the right to return to their homes , and israelis can settle anywhere in the west bank , and jerusalem does not need to be divided .
this is not an ideal solution , but it is creative , a twenty-first-century model of statehood .
us president barack obama ’ s just-completed trip to israel offers an opportunity to explore real new thinking .
with bill clinton almost successful in 2000 , supporters of the israeli-palestinian peace process have been gripped by a mantra : despite solutions , israeli and palestinian leaders who are willing to move toward this direction have never succeeded .
the solution is precisely the deal that clinton pursued : two sovereign states based on the 1967 borders , with the negotiated response to the existing reconciliation model .
this arrangement includes a land corridor in gaza and the west bank ; separating jerusalem in jerusalem and ensuring that everyone can go to religious places ; the palestinians are willing to withdraw their borders ; and the middle east admits of a settlement of the two countries .
but , considering that the palestinians and israelis are willing to agree on such a proposal , the reason is that the solution itself is not supported by both sides .
consider that , as long as a version of the solution is the only solution , the growing encroachment of the israeli state on land and the arab 人口 population will continue to undermine its base .
the window for the two-state solution is rapidly closing ( and , after all , close ) , because the proposal is a problem .
princeton , in 2008 , a philosophical graduate student named russell , a philosophy student for russell ’ s life , was a widely praised speech that was so widely praised for his extension of content in the american journal .
the “ two-state solution to permanent israeli-palestinian peace – a two-state solution research , ” which is supposed to serve as a means for “ the creative thinking of the jews and arabs , ” is to stimulate “ the creative thinking of the jews and arabs . ”
“ two-state condominialism ” is 雅 , but it is quite visionary .
its core view is that israelis and palestinians will be citizens of two independent states , and thus are two separate political regimes .
palestine will be the palestinian people , and israel will be jewish .
but , with “ condominialism , ” palestinians and jews “ will be granted the right to settle the rights of either land on either land , which will constitute a single twin national settlement society . ”
it takes time to think about this .
as 尼利 describes , palestinians “ have the right to settle anywhere within israel , just as jews have the right to settle anywhere within a palestinian state . ”
regardless of where they live , all palestinians are citizens of the palestinian state , all jews are israeli citizens .
these are the rights and responsibilities of national borders , just as the us , for example , meets the needs of foreign personnel ( for example , civilian families in foreign bases ) .
to make this work work , first and foremost , the boundaries of each country ’ s borders – and perhaps on the basis of the 1967 borders .
israeli arabs will be asked to convert their citizenship , national identity , and voting rights – but not to rival sites – to a new palestinian state .
they will have the right to live in israel ’ s right to live with israel ’ s current citizenship , but they will vote in palestinian citizenship .
other palestinians living in israel will receive only the rights and benefits enshrined in palestinian law .
condominialism recognizes the reality of a deep link between israeli settlers in the west bank and other israeli israelis – including roads , water supplies , electricity grids , government structures , and economic relations ( as in israel ’ s israel zone and the palestinian district in jerusalem ) .
in contrast to the isolation and restoration of all of these structures and relationships , it is more effective in building ways that benefit both peoples and economies .
moreover , in many citizens , criminalizing condoms has actually occurred in a world of growing time .
in the 1950 ’ s , the idea that europe had suffered after 40 years of war was forged by the european union , and member states ’ citizens can be free to work freely , while retaining political allegiance and cultural identity , as well as political allegiances and cultural identities .
( in fact , the name of the political process created by the eu , the “ new 功能主义 ” ) , and the cumbersome and 繁琐 “ two-state condominialism ” are in fact .
but french and german politicians began with vision and determination to open up a bold experiment , a single experiment that includes 500 million renminbi .
why shouldn ’ t another ancient divide be a source of statehood ?
interestingly , many young people in the 1950 ’ s , like my belgian mother , enthusiastically supported the vision of a new europe .
today ’ s young israelis and palestinians pride themselves on their entrepreneurialism , despite the various new risks that create new risks .
it would be a landmark act of this generation to support and contribute to innovation politics .
a new american agenda for latin america
mexico city – for the next us president , dealing with the international mess inherited from the bush administration is not a simple task .
while latin america ’ s government is not a priority for obama ’ s administration , the us government continues to ignore the neglect of latin america over the last seven years .
in latin america , there are two obvious political challenges : cuba ’ s impending transformation or a crisis of succession , the region ’ s “ two left ” forces , one of the left , represented by a president of venezuela ’ s hugo chávez .
if the next us administration is hearing latin america with a moment of time to combine its history and the worst in its history : the fastest pace of economic growth since the 1970s , poverty and inequality have become more democratic , and it is politically more politically polarized .
in cuba , fidel castro ’ s eventual disappearance from the scene represents a huge challenge .
the us can no longer continue to fail in the past half-century .
america ’ s demand for a complete shift in democracy as a prerequisite for normalizing relations between the us and cuba is both unrealistic and unpopular .
yet , when it awaits his brother ’ s brother , raúl , who continues to rule , the us is unlikely to ignore cuba ’ s democracy and human rights .

but the us should not be allowed to budge on this temptation .
the us , canada , europe , and latin america have established a regional legal system to protect the hemisphere ’ s democratic rule and human rights , which should not be abandoned .
cuba needs to return to a circle of regional powers , but it must accept the rules of the circle .
elections and fair elections may not be the main problem , but they should not be put aside in order to stabilize and self-interest .
while cuba ’ s transformation should begin with the us to lift its trade embargo , all other things should also be conditional on cuba ’ s beginning to address all outstanding issues .
but cuba is just part of what could be called the “ left ” problem in latin america .
indeed , there has been a lot of recent articles about strengthening the latin american left in the last decade .
in fact , there are two lefts in the region : one in chile , brazil , uruguay , central america , and , to some extent , peru ’ s modern , democratic , globalized , and 阿根廷 political spectrum ; and , in the case of mexico , el salvador , nicaragua , cuba , bolivia , and the 左派 left .
some of these “ left ” are in power ; some , like mexico ’ s last controversial presidential election , have just failed to be elected , but they will still be in office .
in the last two years , it is increasingly evident that “ modern ” or “ moderate ” left will govern the country well .
another left has become more extreme and unpredictable than many expected .
the former has no incentive to “ export ” its “ model ” of “ export , ” which has the means and means to do so .
the left is now in retreat from che guevara ’ s dream : not “ one , many vietnamese , ” but “ one , two , venezuelans , ” and the establishment of power through the ballot box and the establishment of an armed self-defense force and a full-fledged political party .
it can obtain all of this funding from venezuela ’ s state-owned oil company , which is needed to implement all of the funds that are misguided in the long run , especially when such policies are carried out by cuban doctors , teachers , and professionals .
for the us president ’ s next president , there is a dilemma : how to improve relations between the us and latin america , and to strengthen the left ’ s way of 干涉主义 interventionist policies , to counter the apparent distinction between the left and the old left .
the best focus on latin america ’ s efforts is self-evident , even if they are not easy to succeed .

for the us , turning back from such challenges is no longer a viable option .
beyond its special concerns ( oil , arms , the trafficking of drugs ) , the us now needs latin america , because resistance to its resistance has existed , and that these resistance has become more malicious since world war ii .

the year of global conflict
davos – in today ’ s world , identifying and managing hot spots , looking for a map , shows that 火点 diplomats are not enough to send to the fire .
to understand today ’ s major conflicts and confrontations , we must recognize the global political environment that leads to them .
the conflict is most likely to produce or continue to be a way of stopping or ending those who can not or will do so .
unfortunately , this will be a defining feature of 2013 .
in the united states , president barack obama ’ s administration will spend most of the time , energy , and politics in order to reduce debt and other domestic affairs unless a foreign policy crisis is directly threatened .
in europe , officials will continue to struggle to restore confidence in the eurozone .
and , in china , though the demand for economic growth and job creation will force new leaders to develop ties with other regions , they will not be much more preoccupied with the complexity of economic reform than in asia .
that is why the world ’ s fires will be 更旺 this year .
this does not mean that the world ’ s powers will not inflict trouble on themselves .
today , governments are more likely to use drones and special forces to deal with their enemies .
the world has become accustomed to us drone attacks on afghanistan , pakistan , and yemen , but recent reports suggest that china and japan are also investing in drones – in part , in the first place .
these technological innovations have reduced the cost and risks of attacks , thereby increasing the likelihood of military action .
that is why large and well-funded governments – and some of the resources that are not so strong – are investing in technology and skills .
this form of warfare is more worrying for two reasons .
first , unlike the cold war era ’ s “ mutually assured destruction ” structure , cyber weapons provide an opportunity to provide anonymous attacks on users .
second , technological change ensures that no government can know how much damage its cyber weapons can cause and how much deterrent deterrence is possible , and that only then can it be known .
as a result , countries now publish the risk of a defensive defense force that increases the risk of accidental hostilities .
if john kerry and chuck hagel were confirmed as us secretary of state and secretary of defense , the obama administration raised the question of military intervention by the two .
but the level of investment in the us drone , the network , and other unconventional weaponry will most likely not be reduced .
these technological advances have created the backdrop of competition and hostility in two of the most important geopolitical hotspots .
in the middle east , us and european officials will continue to reject the regional turmoil this year , leaving local powers – turkey , iran , and saudi arabia – competing for regional influence .
the antagonism between moderates and radicals , together with the sunni-shia schism , will occur in several north africa and the middle east .
us officials have reason to believe that , over time , they can reduce their concerns about the region and its problems .
according to current projections , technological innovation in non-traditional energy areas will enable the us to meet more than 80 % of its energy needs by 2020 .
china , on the other hand , will increasingly depend on middle east oil output .
east asia , meanwhile , will remain the potential trouble spot in 2013 .
many of china ’ s neighbors worry that their economic and military expansion will pose a growing threat to their interests and independence , and to the diversity of us security partners and to protect china ’ s poor intentions .
and the us can hope to boost its long-term economic prospects by developing new trading partners in the world ’ s fastest-growing regions , so it is also moving toward asia – even though the us ( and europe ) has been smart about the transatlantic free-trade agreement .
a growing risk is that the new chinese leadership will mean america ’ s deep engagement in the region as a means to contain china ’ s rise and impede chinese growth .
in the region , we have seen a series of worrisome rivalries , such as the 中越 rivalry in the south china sea and the philippines , as well as sino-japanese tensions in the east china sea .
these disputes will not lead to military confrontation this year , but the use of drones and cyber weapons remains real .
the biggest risk in 2013 is that asia ’ s massive economic conflict , which would not only hurt countries directly involved , would also impede global recovery .
the first war on this front has been fired .
last summer , disputes over a series of islands in the east china sea led to the world ’ s second-largest and third-largest economies – china and japan .
the two sides are too far off the war , but chinese officials allowed nationalist protests to erupt , boycotts of japanese goods , and destruction of japanese products .
japan ’ s automobile exports to china fell by nearly 10 % , while china ’ s imports from japan have fallen by nearly 10 % – all of which occurred within a month .
this is a serious blow to the struggling japanese economy .
it is a clear warning for those of us who believe that not the military , tanks , and rockets can cause a heavy price .
the new year ’ s resolutions
new year ’ s resolutions are determined , and this year is particularly pronounced .
at the start of the millennium , world leaders pledged to seek a peaceful solution to the problem of poverty , poverty , and a cleaner environment .
in 2005 , we were prepared to adjust .
a variety of new perceptions , scientific advances , tourism , and global diffusion give us more options to address the world ’ s major problems .
last year , a new disease called sars attack china , the world health organization coordinating national government action , and quickly control dangerous situations , at least for now .
when bill gates donated a $ 1 billion vaccine to poor children , he protected thousands of young people from infectious diseases .
when an agricultural survey called the world ’ s 农林 center found that a tree can help african farmers expand food production , they introduced a new , valuable approach to overcoming food crises in africa .
unfortunately , such examples of global cooperation are rare enough to impress people .
the living conditions of the world ’ s poorest people can be significantly enhanced by our existing knowledge and science level , and millions of people are suffering from malaria , aids , hunger , and living slums .
the problem is not that we lack a solution , but rather our failure to cooperate globally to put them into practice .
un secretary general kofi annan ’ s special adviser to the millennium development goals , which led me to lead a team of scholars and development experts , to identify substantial steps , made me a great privilege .
at the same time , we set the report on the un millennium project , which annan issued on january 17 , 2005 .
and the world ’ s people will be able to see our research “ investment development : complete steps toward completing the millennium development goals . ”
our research results are simple for what we know about what we know .
for each major problem , such as famine , illiteracy , malnutrition , malaria , aids , drought , drought , and so on , there is also a proven solution to the solution .
in turn , these investments could strengthen private industries and boost economic growth .
but that requires a partnership between rich and poor countries around the world .
most important , the richest countries should help the poorest countries take advantage of modern science and technology to solve these major problems .
for example , in recent years , the us spends $ 450 billion in annual military expenditures , while governments spend less than $ 15 billion to help fight disease , educate children , and protect the environment .
this is a mistake , because military hardware alone is not enough to ensure us security .
only shared prosperity can truly bring the planet safe .
the us should invest more in peaceful economic development .
germany , japan , and the rest of the developed world do not have enough to do so , much less than they have promised for poor countries .
in 2002 , all donor countries committed to `` substantive efforts '' to provide 0.7 % of national income to help poor countries develop .
germany , japan , and the us , however , have done so far more than they promised .
citizens around the world have many opportunities in 2005 to insist that their governments keep their promises and complete the millennium project .
our report will be completed in january , when secretary-general kofi annan issued a report in the spring to confirm the concrete steps taken in the new year .
at the same time , an important african commission will present a report to british prime minister tony blair .
later , britain will host the annual g-8 summit in july .
prime minister tony blair has promised that it will work to address poverty and long-term climate change , which is the focus of the summit .
in september , heads of state will meet at the united nations and discuss action plans over the next decade .
the us claims that it helped the world fight poverty , but it spends much money on weapons .
germany and japan say they want a permanent seat in the un security council , but none of them insisted on committing to helping the world ’ s poorest people .
the poorest countries will ask : if germany and japan can not keep their promises , why should they vote to support their members ’ seats ?
so , for the world ’ s richest countries , the smartest alternative is to keep up with the promise of a poor , hungry , and afflicted people .
the road to peace is at hand .
the year 2005 was a year of promises , and the world will fulfill our hopes for the new millennium , we need to recognize that we want to share peace and prosperity .
let us pledge that the rich world can take concrete action to help impoverished , disadvantaged , and painful people .
farewell to it
london – she was dubbed the queen of europe , and it is the leader of the liberal world after us president donald trump ’ s election .
as the eu has gone from crisis to crisis over the past decade , german chancellor angela merkel ’ s steady hand helped to preserve the eu ’ s unity .
the conventional wisdom is that when she leaves the prime minister in the next federal election in 2021 – if her grand coalition collapses – she would be sorely missed .
that is not the case .
in merkel ’ s 13 years , domestic drift and european recession have been domestic .
she has been complacent and failed to address germany ’ s growing economic and security challenges , thereby allowing many crises in europe to fester .
a small country with a long time ago can tolerate her husband , the idea of the management of inaction ; and , for a european dominant state in turbulent times , her behavior was disastrous .
unlike many european countries , germany has enjoyed robust economic growth in the past decade .
but it is hardly merkel ’ s credit .
her four governments never enacted any significant pro-growth reforms .
in their obsession with the budget surplus , they failed to invest in the country ’ s crumbling infrastructure and education system .
merkel has done nothing to convince germany to deal with the threat of its manufacturing core – particularly the automobile industry ’ s digital disruption , which apple ’ s iphone has influenced nokia ’ s impact .
germany will regret that it will not repair its roof when the sun remains shining .
the eurozone crisis has greatly strengthened germany ’ s financial clout within the monetary union .
this gave merkel considerable political power , and she could have used it .
instead , she put germany ’ s narrow near-term interest in a creditor , which led her to make decisions that exacerbate the eurozone crisis , transferring costs to other countries , and obstruct any long-term solution .
merkel is finally responsible for the eu ’ s refusal to restructure greece ’ s debt in 2010 .
she favors lending to european taxpayers to distressed governments to bail out german banks .
her government has demanded that debtor countries respond to financial panics through extreme austerity and painful adjustment , even though germany ’ s current-account surplus is growing .
by finally agreeing to ecb president mario draghi ’ s “ doing everything ” to protect the euro , merkel has done just to save the common currency , while doing nothing to reform a dysfunctional , incomplete monetary union .
to be sure , with trump destroying the liberal international order and the united kingdom , hungary , poland , italy , and other countries , merkel deserves credit for a quiet , reassuring , reassuring voice .
and , while british prime minister theresa may has humiliated himself by kowtowing to trump , merkel has been the liberal liberal values .
likewise , unlike many senior politicians in germany , she has resisted russian president vladimir putin ’ s bullying and aggression .
nonetheless , merkel ’ s tepid leadership makes germany vulnerable to today ’ s nationalist backlash .
the country ’ s economic , political , and geopolitical security is based on three pillars that nationalists want to destroy : the dynamic open market for german exports ; and the united states , which guarantees germany ’ s defense of europe and the world , and the us ’ s nuclear umbrella .
germany is not a trade cheat , as the trump administration claims .
but , under merkel , it has undoubtedly adopted a beggar-thy-neighbor mercantilist policy that suppresses wages and boosts exports at all costs .
true , protectionism is a mistake ; but mercantilism encourages it .
if germany can take more steps to stimulate domestic demand , it is in germany , europe , and the global interest .
likewise , merkel should not be blamed for brexit or many of italy ’ s travails , which are self-inflicted .
but her eurozone policy is a major factor in italy ’ s current populist government , which has vowed to block future eu trade agreements , incite the refugee crisis , and threaten another eurozone panic .
unless germany and italy are happy to share a monetary union , the eurozone will not be safe .
the truth may eventually prove impossible .
but if there is a viable solution , it will require major reforms , as french president emmanuel macron proposed last year .
merkel ’ s spurning of macron ’ s reform , therefore , represents another opportunity to be left behind by germany .
in terms of security , even if merkel recognizes that germany can no longer rely solely on the us to its defense , she has done little to strengthen german or european military capabilities .
german defense spending remains inadequate , which gives trump a pretext to undermine nato .
germany ’ s crumbling military has 坦克车 , 潜 , and 飞机 planes .
there is little discussion on the need for nuclear deterrence , whether in germany or in europe .
so , instead of tragedy , merkel ’ s departure has provided european reformers .
macron and his european allies will be right about the threat posed by the european parliament election in may to the threat posed by populist populists .
but , because macron does not want to offend strong partners , he has so far failed to challenge merkel ’ s flawed european leadership .
as merkel is about to die , he and other reformers have a new chance to promote a different europe for all .
if they do not use her exit , the charlatans of the far right will certainly not let this opportunity slip .

angela merkel , angela merkel
angela merkel is finally germany ’ s new – and first woman – chancellor .
while continuity will remain the key to foreign policy , germany ’ s performance in international affairs and the leadership of schroeder will differ under merkel ’ s leadership .
schröder ’ s representative of the new generation of germans was in power seven years ago , not a “ cold war , ” european integration , not a transatlantic friendship , but a restoration of german unity and national sovereignty .
for him and the team who inherited power from 16 years in office , germany has become a normal country , unlike other countries like france or the united kingdom .
the lesson that schroeder learned is that germany can no longer be despised , and it needs to play a role commensurate with its power .
self-assertion became the watchword of german foreign policy .
as a result , when schröder announced that germany had failed to comply with the budget ceiling set by the eu ’ s stability and growth pact , he seems to be arguing that such restrictions should be applied only to small countries , not large countries .
when he openly opposed us troops in iraq , the pride of the world ’ s only superpower protests is palpable .
when he established close personal and political ties with russian president vladimir putin , his message to the world – and the eu ’ s sensitive new member states - is that germany ’ s foreign policy will no longer be constrained by the past .
in fairness , it should be acknowledged that germany , under schroeder ’ s leadership , eliminated concerns about sending troops overseas .
his support for international peacekeeping operations in kosovo or in afghanistan will require significant political courage , while making germany a major international force for peacekeeping .
one of schroeder ’ s great achievements in his tenure is to remove this issue from domestic ideological battles .
but another message is that germany has grown into a truly international power .
with merkel ’ s leadership , there will be little substantive change in german foreign policy , but the assertive style will be muted .
america ’ s leaders will welcome her election as proof that the bilateral relationship is the norm .
