angela merkel ’ s vision problem
cambridge – as europe struggles to save the euro , complaints about the lack of strong leadership from the world ’ s major economies abound .
many have pointed to german chancellor angela merkel , who believes that she has failed to set a long-term vision for europe as his predecessor and mentor , helmut kohl .
is it right ?
as a good leader , part of the work is to communicate a vision that gives meaning to the relevant policies , and to launch people ’ s support for such policies ( and their advocates ) to support them .
this is also one of the ways to build a common goal among leaders , with one of the means to inject collective action into collective action .
this vision usually identifies the future of change , but it sometimes portrays the status quo – or a glorious past – to resist change .
once a vision is lacking , neither of these approaches will lead .
as ceo 弗里德里克 斯密斯 , ceo of ma , said , “ the top priority is to communicate a vision and values . ”
but the vision must be cautious .
sometimes leaders thought that a vision would solve the most of the problems they face , but the wrong vision – or an ambitious ambition – is that they suffer .
george h.w , george h. w. bush , lost his 大亏 , and even threatened himself .
when confronted with his staff ’ s priorities , he replied , he replied , “ that ’ s not my style . ”
after the terrorist attacks of september 11 , 2001 , his son was building a more ambitious vision .
as one former white house adviser pointed out , george w. bush “ obsession with the ambitious ideals of bringing democracy to the middle east , a very different departure from his father ’ s prudent style . ”
but , relative to that , we will find bush ’ s foreign policy better .
some aspiring leaders believe that they must build a vision that can combine their followers with their followers , but in practice we have found that a successful vision usually arises from collective needs , and that leaders are only time to cultivate them and clarify .
for example , martin luther king , king luther king , said that his vision of the “ i have a dream ” not only begins with the mainstream values of equality and inclusion in the united states , but also the bitter experiences of african americans being enslaved and excluded .
moreover , it will be difficult to articulate the pressure of a vision .
as one university president put it , “ everyone asks ‘ what your vision is . ”
the first step is to tell you about your vision . ”
a successful vision must be able to attract many followers and stakeholders .
in a group of popular people , it is not possible to do so in another group .
a successful vision for success must be based on a deep understanding of the situation facing the group .
leaders must get the issue accurately before the answer .
they need to listen not only to their followers , but also to understand the context in which people choose to shape their choices , in order to choose goals and articulate them in a vision .
in short , leaders must assess reality accurately .
the boldness of the vision varies with leadership .
the leaders of social movements are more ambitious than public servants .
a society ’ s leaders can promote a vision far beyond their followers ’ imagined vision , and a prime minister who bears a variety of responsibilities and various responsibilities will have to communicate with the public , so that the vision will not remain in public forever .
former us vice president al gore became a leader who became a leader in the fight against global warming after the 2000 presidential election , and his leadership style has turned from pragmatism to the type of the prophet .
analysts are able to judge whether his vision will be successful in terms of whether the movement ’ s leaders can realistically balance the risks with risk .
there are a lot of options , but effective visions are the product of forward-looking and feasibility .
critics of former british prime minister tony blair have acknowledged that , while the details of a vision lack concern , blair ’ s ability to articulate a vision is one of the great strengths of his leader .
similarly , the two american presidents of the twentieth century – woodrow wilson and george w. bush – were good at articulating a grand foreign policy vision , but they are not good at redefining and modifying the vision when they are blocked .
both want to promote democracy , but they are in a manner that can easily provoke resistance .
of course , prudence is not enough .
sometimes leaders need a break with reality to encourage followers and inspire additional effects , like winston churchill in 1940 .
but without a degree of caution based on this understanding , vision can easily be turned from grandiose to grandiose , harming the values that it seeks .
just as franklin d. roosevelt spoke carefully in the 1930 ’ s to abandon isolationism , merkel is now cautiously saving the euro .
she stood up to the public ’ s skepticism about using german funds to save the greek economy .
her political allies have divided on this issue , and their party lost state elections .
if more radical action is taken , merkel might lose more support , and she will not be able to let the market regain confidence .
in this year , however , she has finally articulated a vision for europe ’ s future , and to persuade the bundestag to agree to save the euro package .
but whether that vision is too late – and whether it is feasible – will be determined in the coming months .

washington , dc – in the wake of the turmoil in ukraine , the united states and russia seem to be watching each other ’ s every move , with the world seemingly sliding into a long-term conflict similar to the cold war .
is it ?
russia accuses the west of supporting a coup in kyiv with “ the terrorists ” and “ terrorists ” in kyiv , with an inter-continental ballistic missile testing , an intercontinental ballistic missile test , and retaining the right to military intervention in eastern ukraine .
but the us also calls for cooperation to resolve the status quo peacefully and declare that ukraine should pursue constructive relations with russia and the west .
so far , russia has dismissed its attitude toward the us .
but this is not the beginning of cold war ii , and russia is not america ’ s rivals .
but it is not an ally .
the two sides disagree on many issues .
but progress on many key international issues – such as syria and iran – can not be made without cooperation .
the challenge is not to try to “ reset ” bilateral relations again , but ( in the aftermath of the crisis in ukraine ) , to find a foundation that allows both sides to collaborate on their interests .
but we must recognize reality .
since 1992 , every us president has sought to redesign the us-russian relationship , beyond the ideological and military competition of the cold war .
but every effort , though possible , ended in disappointment .
one key reason is that there is a fundamental difference between the us and russia in improving the relationship ’ s relationship .
when it comes to assessing these efforts , one thing is true : the us has made the most progress in the region where it is russia that respects its interests .
the first diplomatic reset occurred in the late days of president george w. bush ’ s presidency , making significant progress in reducing the nuclear threat caused by the collapse of the soviet union .
as a result , russia became the only nuclear power nuclear power in the former soviet union , and the us senator richard lugar and richard lugar have helped to ensure that nuclear facilities , scientists , and materials are safe .
the second reset was even more important during clinton ’ s administration : building a comprehensive partnership that promotes broad us involvement in russia ’ s economy and changing political institutions .
it was also easier to persuade russia to support nato intervention in the balkans .
but the second war in kosovo in 1999 led to the reset .
the third reset came from russian president vladimir putin , who helped the us in afghanistan after the terrorist attacks of september 11 , 2001 .
but the bush administration ’ s expectations were very different from putin ’ s .
russia seeks “ equal partnerships between the two sides , ” especially the us recognition of russia ’ s sphere of influence in its neighborhood .
and russia must deal with the iraq war , nato enlargement to the baltic states , and the pro-western revolutions in ukraine , ukraine , and georgia that the bush administration aims to democratize .
the kremlin is deeply concerned about the specter of institutional evolution , especially in its neighborhood .
the reset ended in the 2008 战争 war , when the us regarded russia as a global spoiler .
the obama administration ’ s reset – the fourth since the soviet union ’ s collapse – was the most successful , at least in its first term .
the hope is more realistic and some have achieved results : new start weapons control treaty , tighter sanctions on iran , cooperation on transportation and transportation , and russia ’ s accession to the world trade organization .
but the reset was essentially driven by the personal relationship between obama and medvedev , who , in 2012 , was president dmitri medvedev , who was president in his third term .
the us and russia began to deteriorate when they condemn the us as a protest against his return to the presidency .
the reset ended last august , when the kremlin decided to grant temporary asylum to the us intelligence contractor edward snowden .
the ideological antagonism of the cold war may be , but russia now sees itself as a different civilizational and social model .
the kremlin also views the us as the source of instability in the former soviet space , and blames the west for the turmoil in ukraine .
nonetheless , the us-russian relationship is always divided between the us and russia , with many pressing multilateral issues confronting russia , particularly syria , iran , and afghanistan ( the us will withdraw its troops this year ) .
while the us and russia differ over how to end the syrian civil war , they are working together to bring together syria ’ s chemical weapons .
similarly , neither side wants to see iran develop its nuclear-weapons capability .
over the last two decades , there have been several strong hopes for the two sides , which demonstrated that , after the crisis in ukraine , the us will be more moderate and realistic toward russia .
unless both countries go beyond the cold war , the 1990s , and today ’ s crises , it will be more effectively managed to manage the relationship ’ s relationship with the kremlin or the kremlin .
for the us , this means recognizing russia ’ s status : it is a highly important country , with political systems mixed , with serious domestic economic , demographic , and political challenges .
russia ’ s post-soviet evolution was a multi-decade process , and it is unlikely to be linear .
its worldview is very different from the us , and it will be in the foreseeable future .
but a cold peace is better than the cold war .
pisa ’ s success
paris – the oecd ’ s program for international student assessment ( pisa ) assesses students of students in the best and most educated education systems , providing valuable reform options for how to achieve this .
pisa has focused global policymakers , educators , and researchers , discussing what kind of knowledge and responsible citizens in the world today will require , and how to develop more efficient and inclusive education systems .
some argue that pisa ’ s results are based on too broad a combination of factors , and others lack the connections , others argue that students in different languages and cultural backgrounds are inherently irrational .
of course , comparing education across countries is not easy , but pisa remains the most useful tool for policymakers attempting to improve national education systems .
before pisa , many governments claimed that they had the world ’ s most successful education system , and believed that they had taken the necessary steps to correct all flaws .
pisa assessments have exposed weaknesses in a country ’ s system , thereby helping to ensure that policymakers recognize – and want them to improve – their flaws .
the government ’ s accountability for government and education ministers has helped to spur them to act .
they increasingly learn how to apply innovations in their curricula , teaching , and digital resources ; how to provide personalized learning experiences to maximize students ’ chances of success ; and how to cope with the diversity of teaching .
the oecd will be a global assessment , because in today ’ s globalized world , students must be able to work with people from various backgrounds to accept different ideas , perspectives , and values .
to give students the greatest chance of success , education must be prepared to deal with problems beyond national borders .
but pisa ’ s most important outcome is also at the national level , because it inspires innovation and broadens the country ’ s internal education prospects .
diverse educational systems such as finland , japan , china , and canada – previously rarely policymakers – have become a global reference point for educational performance , helping other countries to design effective reforms .
in the first pisa assessment of the 2000 ’ s , the country ’ s education system was the worst , and many rightly questioned whether it is fair to compare the emerging markets to developed countries like finland and japan .
but brazil rose to the challenge , making significant investments in improving the quality of teaching .
brazil is now the world ’ s most rapidly improving education system .
germany , too , is pisa ’ s 突出者 , whose performance is less than average , and a huge society of educational injustice , which has shocked germans and launched a series of months of public debate .
spurred by stimulus , the government has pursued measures to support weak and immigrant students , and make early education a driver of german education policy .
today , pisa reports confirm that the quality and fairness of germany ’ s education system have made significant progress .
for example , pisa assessments suggest that , while japanese students are reproducing the 复述 knowledge , they often struggle when asked about the need to apply knowledge creatively .
in the last year , the creation of more innovative learning environments was found in the northeast asian schools that had been struck by the 2011 tsunami .
this experience offers another lesson : even if social and cultural factors are the main force shaping a country ’ s trading style , improved space remains .
countries like japan do not need to change their culture to correct education ; they need only adjust policies and practices .
since pisa ’ s initiative in the late 1990 ’ s , global platforms that create education research and innovation have been their intent .
since then , policymakers , researchers , and experts have established the world ’ s largest commitment to the development of robust , reliable , and reliable information about students ’ learning outcomes .
at the same time , pisa measures their students ’ social and emotional skills , as well as educational equity and parental support – all of which are indispensable for understanding scores of global assessments .
of course , assessments do not cover all important skills or attitudes .
but convincing evidence suggests that the knowledge and skills that the pisa system assesses are critical to students ’ future success , and the oecd has been working to expand the range of cognitive and social skills that pisa measures .
pisa has already played a role in promoting global education .
the oecd will continue to work with 80 participating countries , further developing the program , so that it can continue to help policymakers and educators design and implement better education policies – the tools needed to enable citizens to fulfill their lives .
the zero-emissions imperative
davos – the planet is alert .
the 2013 report by the intergovernmental panel on climate change makes it clear that we have emitted the co2 emitted over the last half-century .
we need a more robust approach to global warming to avoid catastrophe .
unlike the recent financial crisis , there is no bailout option for the planet ’ s climate .
three years ago , at the united nations ’ cop 16 climate-change climate change in cancún , countries agreed to reduce their emissions to 2º celsius above pre-industrial levels by 2020 .
but , according to the un estimates , current trends can only enable the world to do just about 25-30 % of the world .
that is why i call for all governments to raise their commitment to fossil fuels in the second half of this century by raising their commitment to fossil fuels .
this goal is impossible without a comprehensive change in the energy economy .
this week , the european commission unveiled the 2030 energy and climate targets – a 40 % reduction in the european union ’ s greenhouse-gas emissions by 2030 , with 27 % of energy coming from renewable sources .
this is an extremely important step , and other countries should follow suit .
to be sure , we will face significant obstacles .
two-thirds of electricity generation and nearly 95 % of energy are spent on transport systems , and from fossil fuels .
our energy security is increasingly tied to the exploitation of unconventional fossil fuels such as shale gas , which is especially true in the us .
in many areas , carbon-intensive technologies are still more profitable than low-carbon alternatives .
cash-strapped governments continue to encourage oil and gas exploration , partly because they enable them to gain rents and amount to large amounts of revenue .
but change may still be .
there is a yawning gap between the promises of climate change and the policy arrows that are often inconsistent ( not to mention contradictory ) .
i believe that we can achieve great and rapid progress if it is clear on three issues .
putting a price on carbon .
by pricing carbon costs , we can manage its use ( or prohibit ) .
more than 40 countries have already implemented some form of carbon tax or emissions-trading schemes .
trading mechanisms are often more politically attractive , because they can be flexible ( though their design and implementation can be improved in many ways ) .
but we can do more .
some governments have managed to introduce carbon taxes without adversely affecting growth , and we should encourage more countries to go along .
cutting fossil-fuel subsidies .
the oecd estimates that , between 2005 and 2011 , fossil-fuel subsidies from member countries amounted to $ 55-90 billion per year .
the international energy agency estimates that fossil-fuel subsidies worldwide grew by $ 544 billion in 2012 .
most of these subsidies should be canceled ; the energy industry does not need more state aid to burn fossil fuels ( and in developing and emerging economies , subsidies are mostly inefficient , and may not help the poor ) .
clear policies are clear .
governments must address inconsistencies in energy strategies , consider the links between energy strategies and broader economic policies , and stop sending contradictory signals to consumers , producers , and investors .
in particular , governments must assess whether to implement the right regulatory arrangements to enable clean-energy investments to compete on the risk-return risk-return basis .
this is essential to enabling investors to gravitate toward climate-friendly alternatives .
the oecd will play its part .
to understand and compare the performance of different countries , oecd economic surveys now include data on climate policy and analysis .
by 2015 , we expected a clear picture of the challenges that are being achieved and the oecd and all major emerging economies still need to confront , and to offer these countries the advice and cost-effectiveness of how they can actually enhance their policies .
these steps will signal a significant increase in the price of emissions to achieve net emissions .
the transformation is not costless , and governments must be honest about their social and economic impact .
but a low-carbon , climate-resilient world must provide new economic opportunities .
more important , the alternative – inaction , or inaction – is much more costly in the long run .
hurricane sandy , for example , has caused the us to lose 0.5 % of its gdp .
by 2050 , global coastal cities could increase to more than $ 50 billion per year .
the situation in developing countries is even more difficult : typhoon haiyan in the philippines in 2013 was a terrible lesson to remind us that poor countries are vulnerable to climate change .
if the world is to avoid a collision between nature and nature – one that is unlikely to win in the fight – we must act decisively on every front , especially in terms of carbon pricing and the coherence of economic and energy policies .
and we must act now .
anger in the us
hong kong – many people attribute current populist revolts in the west to the far right on the far right , with far-right promises to win votes by stoking fear and encouraging extreme tendencies .
two recent studies strike at the heart of the current problem , especially in the us , but also in the rest of the world .
in the new book the fall of the book , steven brzezinski , a journalist ’ s author , pointed out that liberal democracy in the united states is disconnected from the social goals that it advocates , because they protect only a small minority , allowing other vulnerable groups to be exploited by free markets .
in brzezinski ’ s view , this is the result of america ’ s meritocratic system : the best and brightest have the opportunity to climb to the top , but then remove the 登天 , so that they can be rolled out in order to hold democratic institutions and take advantage of their privileges .
according to matthew stewart , he argues , “ the meritocratic class has mastered the old tactics of consolidating wealth , and that the meritocratic class will privilege the privileges of their offspring . ”
in the mid-1980 ’ s , the share of wealth held by the bottom 90 % in the us at the bottom of the mid-1980 ’ s was reached at the bottom of the twentieth century , and the share of their wealth has fallen to 20 % over the next three decades , and the wealth that they lost is almost just 0.1 % .
the 9.9 % – what stewart calls the “ new american aristocracy ” – constitutes a former middle class .
in 1963 , the 90 % of the population needed to increase its wealth sixfold to reach 9.9 % of the middle class ; but , by 2010 , they needed to increase their wealth by 25 % .
as a result , most americans have worked harder than they once did , but living standards are still falling , and , worse , they still have a high level of insurance , and many have not yet insured .
the top 10 % can easily get higher education , giving their children the same privileges as they are ; and 90 % must redouble their efforts to cover high tuition fees , often at a high cost .
the top 10 % will receive first-rate medical services ; the bottom 90 % often do not , or at high cost .
taxation should be a tool for promoting equality .
but the us republican party has been seeking to reduce taxes on the rich , arguing that lowering marginal tax rates would boost investment , employment , and economic growth , thereby enabling the wealth to “ trickle down ” to the rest of society .
in fact , tax cuts for the rich merely entrench their privileges , exacerbating inequality .
making matters worse , the poor actually pay more indirect tax ( including land , real estate , and the consumption tax ) , and the bottom 20 % of americans pay more than twice the state in state taxes .
add to that the challenges of automation and robotics , not to mention the frequent and intense natural disasters that result from climate change , and it is difficult to see why so many people feel so angry .
according to stewart , the middle east ’ s elite “ dominion over the social machine that combines resources from the bottom 90 % to the top 0.1 % , ” happily accepting the “ spoils of the spoils . ”
but the inequality created by this social machine could have serious consequences , for example , by stimulating social discontent and the inability of us to see what it is now seeing in the us .
as the austrian historian walter 沙伊 points out , inequality has historically been eliminated by war , revolution , national collapse , or natural disaster .
if we want to avoid such catastrophic events , the top 10 % will need to be better at promoting the interests of the bottom 90 % , including income , wealth , welfare , and opportunity .
but economic myopia , together with political polarization , has led many to try to divert popular anger in the us into foreign migrants , china , and international trade ( including trade with allies ) .
this leaves the entire world in the midst of an escalating protectionist struggle with no winners .
historically , internal contradictions and imbalances have often led to international conflict .
but this is not inevitable .
instead , the outcome depends on the quality of leadership .
in the united states , for example , both washington , abraham lincoln , and franklin d. roosevelt managed to deal with crises and make the us stronger , because they can recognize that resolving internal divisions must be rooted in national core values , national standing , and long-term development goals .
us president donald trump has skillfully exploited popular anger to advance his own interests and agenda .
but creating anger is not trump , but america ’ s elites , who have created the conditions for the rise of trump for decades .
now that trump is in charge , the situation in the bottom 90 % is likely to worsen further .
his trade protection policy , in particular , would not only fail to help the mass people he deserves ; it would also undermine the sense of fairness and commitment that has historically been shared with leaders .
but the only way to “ make america great again ” is to address internal injustices , not import tariffs and border walls .
rethinking animal agriculture
tasmania – in mid-july , a severe drought decimated crops , some european dairy and dairy farmers were forced to 宰杀 their livestock to reduce the number of animals needed to feed .
in a growing heat wave , a growing number of people are increasingly engaged , and increasingly frequent , desperate decisions will become the norm .
so it is time to start serious discussion about animal agriculture .
animal agriculture is not only vulnerable to the existing and predicted effects of climate change ; it is also one of the main causes of the problem .
in fact , 肉用 and 奶用 animal agriculture accounted for 16.5 % of global greenhouse-gas emissions .
moreover , if we treat climate change as a state of emergency , the impact of serious mitigation in the next 20 years will be even greater .
this is because animal agriculture has produced a third of man-made methane and two-thirds of nitrous oxide emissions – both potent greenhouse gases that are more powerful than carbon dioxide .
beyond climate pollution , as much as 60 % of biodiversity losses are attributable to land-use changes , 80 % of farmland is used to feed animals or grow feed .
the fact that we eat too many animals is also alarming .
we do not need to make great sacrifices .
for example , according to recent research by the british royal institute for international affairs , developed countries are willing to reduce their meat consumption if they are convenient and convenient substitutes for a similar price .
to be clear , i am not suggesting that everyone should be a universal or narrow vegetarian ( though there is no dispute about the environment , which is better for mitigating climate change , and healthier ) .
nor do i think the government should enforce limits on meat consumption .
but if policymakers believe that , for most people in developed countries , reducing the risk of meat is less risky , the benefits are high , and so many cost-effective solutions fuel us .
first , governments can and should stop subsidizing factory farms and the crops that feed factory farming for slaughter .
supporting these polluting and inhumane acts is really like paying companies to undermine emissions targets set by the 2015 paris climate agreement .
instead , governments can and should subsidize subsidies that encourage climate-friendly , 作物 crops such as 豆科植物 .
growing more soybeans , peas , and 扁豆 can help reduce greenhouse-gas emissions , thereby reducing climate change , and farmers can benefit from more resilient crops .
the government can also move from factory meat farms to developing a 开发 “ meat ” and other meat alternative .
“ clean meat ” is nascent , but growth is growing rapidly , and the public reaction was overwhelmingly popular .
nonetheless , as with the fossil-fuel industry , meat industry lobbyists push policymakers to block the 化 of alternatives .
in many countries , lobbyists have managed to ban plants from using 肉基 products .
france , for example , recently banned terms like 素 “ hamburg ” and “ steak ” for only animal meat .
these policies are obviously a barrier to reducing meat consumption , and they contradict the country ’ s commitment to the paris climate goals .
the meat industry ’ s support for these policies gives them and the fossil-fuel industry the same in the same way that only their own profits are .
can producers be a positive force in the transition away from meat ?
for climate policy , food and agriculture should be treated as energy and transport , with clear guidelines for climate change and mitigation .
we have two years from the first major report to track progress in the paris agreement .
countries will have to do what they have done and what to do to reduce emissions .
but if they do not address the production and consumption of meat and dairy , they can not reach a major part of the problem .
meanwhile , european farmers will experience more droughts like this summer , as will food producers in the rest of the world .
farm meat and dairy production will become increasingly difficult , and early 宰杀 will become the new normal .
like fossil fuels , our only choice is to overcome the industry ’ s resistance , changing our food systems , make diets healthier , and more 美味 .
the imf we love ?
cambridge – what does the impact of this crisis have on the international monetary fund ?
just a few months ago , this important but not 爱 institution ( the landmark of post-war global economic arrangements ) seemed destined to fail .
the international monetary fund has long been a scapegoat for the left and the right – for the former , because the organization will focus on fiscal rectitude and economic orthodoxy ; and , for the latter , the fund ’ s role is to bail out heavily indebted countries .
developing countries grudgingly accepted the organization , and developed countries that don ’ t need funds do not need it .
when the world ’ s private capital flows impede the organization ’ s treatment of various resources , the imf seems to be a bad one .
moreover , when some of the group ’ s biggest debtors ( brazil and argentina ) began to return to their debts a few years ago without new borrowers , all seemed to be struck on the last one .
the imf seems to be in addition to losing its raison d ’ être , and has been condemned by the absence of income .
the group would reduce its budget and reduce its size , while the new responsibility ( especially surveillance of “ currency manipulation ” ) has given the fund a greater indication of its ability to prove highly competent .
but this time the crisis is encouraging it .
under the leadership of dominique strauss-kahn , a capable managing director , the imf is one of the world ’ s few official institutions , not behind the curve .
it has responded quickly to countries with “ 合情 ” policies , and it was eager to provide 迅捷 credit to the world ’ s gdp – a gesture that , given the imf ’ s previous conservative attitudes on all fiscal issues , is extraordinary .
and , in the run-up to the g-20 summit in london , the fund thoroughly overhauled its lending policy , emphasizing the consistent conditionality that allowed countries to access their loans .
more significant , the imf has emerged at a meeting in london that has brought more resources , as well as to its new responsibilities .
the g-20 has pledged to double the fund ’ s lending capacity by more than $ 250 billion ( from $ 250 billion to $ 750 billion ) , issuing a new special drawing reserve of $ 250 billion ( a reserve reserve asset ) , and allowed the imf to borrow in the capital market .
the imf is also designated as one of two agencies ( another expanded financial stability forum , now renamed the financial stability board ) , and its responsibility is to provide warning of macroeconomic and fiscal risks , and to publish the policies needed to implement them .
the other good news is that europe has now abandoned their declaration of 任命 the fund ’ s managing director , as americans have said about the world bank ’ s president .
in the future , these senior officials are selected to be selected “ through a process of public , transparent , and superior quality . ”
this would make it better to manage ( though strauss-kahn ’ s leadership is a model ) and will raise the legitimacy of two ministries in the eyes of the developing world .
as a result , the imf now finds itself in the context of the economic universe .
how will it deploy its newfound power ?
the biggest danger that it faces is that it will once again power its power with its capacity .
this was what happened in 1995 , when the imf began to advocate the liberalization of the 资本性 account , and the fiscal rescue package implemented by excessive austerity in asia during the asian financial crisis was tried to reverse asia ’ s economy .
but it remains to be seen whether it has fully internalized these lessons within the organization , and that we need a more market-friendly , 性情 imf to replace the previous hard-line and 教条化 organizations .
one encouraging fact is that developing countries will almost certainly have a larger say in how the imf operates .
this would ensure that the view of poor countries ’ poor countries will receive more votes in the future .
but if the imf ’ s organizational culture fails to change , little will be useful for developing countries ’ greater power alone .
the fund ’ s staff is composed of a small number of smart economists who lack what they lack to understand and correctly evaluate the institutions that they have studied .
their professional qualities are based on their 高等学历 , not by their achievements in actual policy decisions .
this breeds arrogance and a sense of smug superiority that transcends its colleagues – those who must weigh in multiple complex agendas .
to address these problems requires active action among the imf ’ s top leadership , such as recruiting talent , management of employees , and promotion of job promotion .
one solution could be to increase the number of middle-skill workers who have practical experience in developing countries .
in theory , the imf ’ s staff would be more cognizant of the fund ’ s staff .
another strategy would be to relocate the entire workforce to the “ regional work ” of the field , including those working in the ministry .
for employees who are accustomed to 趾高气昂 in washington , dc , such a move would be a substantial amount of resistance .
but there is no better way to appreciate the right place to appreciate .
the world bank , which recently conducted a similar division of power , was finally in the service of better service customers ( without difficulties recruiting on the 高级人才 ) .
this is an important moment for the imf .
the international community is ready to wait for the imf ’ s decisions and performance .
to trust fully , the imf will need to organize internal reforms .
leveling up afghanistan
new york – afghanistan ’ s security and political landscape remains plagued by uncertainty , stemming from the withdrawal of us and nato combat forces , the upcoming presidential election , and the stalled peace talks with the taliban .
recognizing that sustained economic insecurity will exacerbate this dangerous situation , the afghan government announced a new initiative aimed at attracting foreign direct investment ( fdi ) .
the plan includes a land of land that is at very low prices , a tax for the largest seven years of the factory , and low-interest loans for the longest decade for farmers .
these incentives are aimed at foreign investors and local elites , seeking to prevent or even reverse capital flight .
but the new measures will eventually go to the same thing : a divided policy approach will not be enough to address afghanistan ’ s fundamental economic problems .
at the early stages of the post-war transition , fdi rose rapidly , from 1.2 % of gdp in 2002 to 4.3 % in 2005 .
most of these inflows have entered the construction and services sectors – the main engine of gdp growth – aimed at meeting international civilian and military needs .
but , in 2007-2008 , fdi levels began to fall , owing to deteriorating security conditions , inadequate electricity and infrastructure , and inadequate legal and regulatory systems , inadequate legal and regulatory systems , and an updated system of firms every year .
land grabs , stubborn corruption , impunity , enforcement of contracts , and a decentralized and inefficient approach to the implementation of contracts , as well as the spread and ineffectiveness of foreign and domestic investment , fell to 0.5 % of gdp in 2011-2012 .
moreover , in the process of developing one of the world ’ s largest mines , investors ’ greed prevailed over safety and business climate concerns .
in 2007 , the 中冶 group won the extraction permits of a copper copper mine .
but , despite all of the billions of dollars in prices , high hopes , investment , and little progress , there is little progress on security .
making matters worse , the displacement of residents , 克扣 , and environmental damage has already raised resistance to local communities , and may even increase further .
after all , putting mineral resources to foreigners hurts , or even eliminated , their benefits to locals .
as it stands , afghanistan ’ s economy is like a house of cards .
aid levels are comparable to gdp , which covers roughly two-thirds of government spending and a current-account deficit ( 40 % of gdp ) .
but aid is shrinking , and it is expected to shrink sharply after 2014 .
instead of continuing to pursue piecemeal measures ( such as those recently approved ) , governments need to implement comprehensive , targeted strategies that revitalize investment , employment , and trade .
indeed , a major shift in policy is necessary to avoid economic collapse .
to reduce the risks of investing in afghanistan , governments must build institutions that favor local communities and foreign investors .
this could be achieved through a strategy based on two different but mutually beneficial “ reconstruction zones ” : export-oriented zones and 生产区 zones .
export-oriented zones focus only on producing exports , which should provide tax incentives , basic infrastructure , and services , security , and stable legal frameworks .
in exchange , investors should have promised to train local workers , create jobs by purchasing local inputs and services , improve corporate behavior and local suppliers , and establish links with local 技术学校 and universities .
the 生产区 region should make local people better off through agricultural production , providing efficient services , and light manufacturing .
this mechanism should also boost gender equality by providing an equitable share of all afghans providing security , social services , infrastructure , credit , and inputs ( such as seeds , fertilizers , and agricultural machinery ) .
moreover , it should boost food supply and reduce its exorbitant dependence on imports .
afghanistan , which focuses exclusively on foreigners and local elites , lost its potential for small firms in stabilizing gdp growth .
achieving long-overdue peace and stability can not be achieved .
an inconvenient peace prize
this year ’ s nobel peace prize gave the thousands of scientists the un intergovernmental panel on climate change ( ipcc ) .
these scientists are working hard to determine the precise impact of climate change on the world .
another winner , former us president al gore , spent many time telling us that we should worry about the issues that should be feared .
the ipcc ’ s forecast and conclusions are based on serious research , and gore seems not to be subject to similar constraints .
gore told the world in his film , the film that recently considered the world ’ s sea-level rise by 20 feet .
he has clearly missed the findings of the united nations intergovernmental panel on climate change ( ipcc ) , which he has received , concluded that the sea-level rise of the sea-level rise will only be around two feet in the near future , and they are expected to be around the same foot .
this is similar to what the world has experienced over the past 150 years .
similarly , al gore ’ s ice sheet , the melting of greenland ’ s ice and the consequences that it will inflict on the planet , ignores the conclusion that intergovernmental panel on climate change will rise by the end of the century .
gore also failed to note that the research showing greenland ’ s temperatures in 1941 is higher than today .
gore also frets about the future of polar bears .
he claims they are drowning because of the disappearance of habitat .
the man who has emerged as a film for the production of the film is expected to lose sleep because of the number of people expected to die .
the flip side of this story makes sense : rising temperatures will reduce the heat of a cold weather , which is a much bigger killer than heat .
reliable research shows that , by 2050 , heat will kill more than 400,000 lives , but the number of people dying in cold times is less than 180 million .
indeed , according to the first comprehensive survey of economic impact on climate change , global warming will actually save lives .
the ipcc has convincingly said that if gore had received the nobel peace prize alone , he would be happy .
i am pleased that he was not , and the un intergovernmental panel on climate change has been given fair acceptance .
gore has helped the world .
unfortunately , our attention has been distracted by what really matters .
climate change is not the only challenge facing the world today .
our myopic focus on the problem is little attention to the other challenges facing the planet , which will be exacerbated by gore ’ s nobel peace prize .
gore has appealed to world leaders ’ reductions in co2 emissions , but other policies can do more to the planet .
in the coming century , developing countries will increasingly depend on food imports from developed countries .
this is not the result of global warming , but the consequences of developing countries ’ populations and less arable land .
the number of hungry people is more of a population and income than a climate-related phenomenon .
a huge effort to reduce carbon emissions is likely to lead to more malnourished people .
if our goal is to fight malnutrition , it would be more effective to deliver nutrition to those who need it to save more than $ 50 trillion in carbon emissions .
similarly , global warming may increase the incidence of malaria slightly , but reducing co2 emissions is far less effective in fighting the disease than by bed nets and drugs , which can cost 85 million lives a year .
the kyoto protocol would have to prevent only 1,400 people from malaria every year .
when we worry about the impact of climate change on the future , we will not solve the problems facing the planet today .
this year , some four million people die from malnutrition , 1.3 million died from aids , and 2.5 million people die from indoor air pollution , and 25 million people die from indoor air pollution , with no micronutrients and clean drinking water .
given that attention and money are limited , what we should do is to use the best solutions to solve the problem , and to do the most good in the century .
if we focus on solving today ’ s problems , we will make society more resilient , economically dynamic , and more developed .
that would make these industries better equipped to cope with future problems , including global warming .
focusing on massive reductions in carbon emissions will only make our descendants poorer and lack the capacity to adapt to challenges .
gore is adamant that climate change is the biggest challenge facing the world .
to be fair , he deserves some form of certainty for his resolute passion .
yet the contrast between this year ’ s nobel winners is stronger .
the united nations intergovernmental panel on climate change is convinced that it is meticulous research .
gore ’ s approach is entirely different .

the burden of imbalances
economic prosperity in china and india helps to mitigate global imbalances .
over the past two decades , indians and chinese have narrowed their gap with the rich countries .
but , at the same time , many of the world ’ s truly poor countries have become far poorer ( especially in africa , where development is often described as disaster ) , and inequality within most countries has become more serious .
widening inequality has been recorded in the us ( beginning with the reagan administration ) , the united kingdom ( which began with margaret thatcher ’ s government ) , and , more recently , in russia and india .
these developments seem to have exacerbated global imbalances .
as a result , global imbalances seem to have remained relatively stable over the past 20 years .
should we act accordingly ?
many believe that global action to respond to economic imbalances is unnecessary .
they argue that only poverty reduction matters .
according to anne krueger , the deputy managing director of the international monetary fund , “ the poor are eager to improve their material … rather than leap forward on the income distribution . ”
so , even if the gap in per capita income in the us and africa is widening , what is worried ?
after all , this view would say that ordinary africans have improved poverty .
but this assumption assumes that we are not irrelevant to the relative incomes of others .
on the contrary , psychological research invariably shows that people do not just value their absolute income , but also their place in social pyramid and whether this position is fair .
in the past , a poor africans may look at their fellow citizens ’ wealth in their eyes ; now he and his wealthy compatriots look at the income gap between their rich and rich worlds .
with people working on different nationalities , just as in many multinational companies , such a gap is even more pronounced .
a “ foreign worker ” is likely to be a factor of ten times the same local employees working in the same jobs .
a wage premium based solely on nationality is objectionable .
but , even if people do not work together , the world brought the world to everyone ’ s 起居室 ( or 茅舍 ) , enabling them to compare their living standards even more widely .
this brings us to the relatively safe 茧 of the rich world .
now , the income gap is clear .
that is why international action is needed to address global poverty and global imbalances .
the idea that a global redistribution through taxation through tax revenues seems to be a chimera seems fanciful today , but the logic of development that we have witnessed – especially the erosion of the nation-state as a sovereign vehicle – implies that this ideal is likely to materialize .
we missed one such opportunity in the early 1990 ’ s .
when russia faced its worst crisis , economic aid was given corrupt yeltsin .
a international organization could have been able to distribute cash grants to those with a country of 20 million pensioners – money that would have been better targeted by the russian state than it was to the government .
if that were done at the time , russians could have made cash aid from the international community , rather than blaming the latter for corrupt leaders .
but similar measures could be implemented in many countries , from angola to zimbabwe .
such a move would be simple and powerful .
it includes three steps : raise money from the global rich , not to deal with governments , and directly transfer funds to the poor in cash .
those who advocate globalization only in the private sector may resent the idea of a global institution that will give a global institution .
but they are unlikely to notice that the process that they support undermines their own interests , making the difference in the distribution of wealth more obvious , and that the distribution of real global ( wealth ) distribution is more dubious .
they will eventually realize that their interests lie in supporting some form of action against global poverty and inequality .
the inflation check
cambridge – as inflation rises around the world , it may be a wake-up call for countries ’ central bankers to awaken themselves to complacency .
is it possible to place them at the 超级 zimbabwe meeting for every two months ?
this may not be comfortable , but it is educational .
according to the official estimate of zimbabwe ’ s official statistical agency , the country ’ s inflation rate was 66000 % in 2007 , and , rather than today , it is a weimar country .
although no one knows exactly how the government is expected to estimate prices , most indicators suggest that zimbabwe is very likely to break the world record of inflation .
of course , while heads of state are somewhat curious , they can be considered too inconvenient and politically unpalatable in zambia .
fortunately , there are many other good , albeit less spectacular , inflation places .
inflation is double-digit in russia , vietnam , argentina , and venezuela alone .
indeed , in addition to being plagued by deflation , the state ’ s presidents can meet with a high degree of inflation at a high level .
the chinese authorities are so worried about the country ’ s 7 % inflation , following india ’ s control of food prices .
even if the us reached 4 % inflation last year , the fed was somehow convinced that most people will not notice .
many presidents and economists argue that the rise in global inflation today is simply a temporary aberration , with the surge in food , fuel , and other commodity prices fueling this phenomenon .
indeed , the prices of many major commodities have increased by 25 % since the beginning of the year .
but if the governor believes that today ’ s inflation is just the result of short-term resource flows , not loose monetary policy , they are wrong .
the fact is that , in most parts of the world , inflation is expected to rise , unless central banks start tightening their monetary policies .
the us is now central to global inflation .
the fed faces the twin pressure of a collapsing house price crash and implosion of credit markets , and has been aggressively cutting interest rates to avoid a recession .
but even if the fed does not recognize it in its forecast , the price of this “ insurance policy ” will almost certainly be higher inflation in the coming years .
if so many other countries , from the middle east to asia , actually peg their currencies to the dollar , inflation in the us may be manageable .
other countries , such as russia and argentina , do not actually tie their currencies to the dollar , but try to smooth the currency fluctuations .
america ’ s lax monetary policy has thus broadly set the pace of global economic inflation , and could reach 60 % .
but the economies of much of the middle east and asia are healthier than the us , and inflation in most emerging-market economies has risen sharply , with aggressive monetary stimulus being the last thing they need .
the ecb is now stable , but it may even suppress higher interest rates , partly owing to the fear that it is already in a record-high euro .
and the ecb worries that if america ’ s recession hit his country , it may have to transform its policies and start cutting interest rates .
so what happens next ?
if america ’ s recession becomes a deep recession , the global deflationary impact will offset some of the inflationary pressures that the world faces .
global commodity prices will collapse , and many commodity and services prices will stop so rapidly as unemployment and excess capacity grow .
of course , the us recession will also bring further fed interest-rate cuts , which would then increase the problem .
but if america ’ s recession continues and global growth remains strong , inflationary pressures will be even worse .
in this case , inflation would be easily reached in the 1980 ’ s if it were not to reach the world ’ s 1970 ’ s .
until now , most investors believe that they would rather risk a few years of inflation than they would have been in a few years .
but they also conveniently forget the costs of high inflation and the difficulty of pushing inflation out of the system .
perhaps they should be holding a conference in zimbabwe for a meeting .
a 情报战 情报战
terrorism is an existential threat .
in our `` european security strategy , '' terrorism is seen as one of the key strategic threats facing the eu , and we are using all available methods , particularly in intelligence services .
the first objective of intelligence is to find terrorists , prevent them from acting , and track them after their attacks .
this is the intelligence of military action , and it is better at the national level .
many of the terrorists in europe , and many of the terrorists who have thwarted terrorist operations , are the result of eu member states ’ intelligence services .
the recent journalists ask me whether cooperation between institutions is enough , and whether europe should build a mechanism for sharing military intelligence .
as a result , five european countries arrested more than a dozen terrorists in a joint effort .
the success of this operation is no accident .
last year , the eu signed two europol deals , as well as an extradition and mutual jurisdiction .
europe ’ s security services are working closely together in counter-terrorist organizations , and europol ’ s counter-terrorist task group has been re-established .
a high-level organization for border and transport is working , and links between member states ’ police chiefs are strengthening .
but widespread sharing is not always necessary or appropriate .
member states also need intelligence from ongoing cases , not to provide information to the design of policies , at least not directly , but to undermine and eliminate terrorist attacks .
these intelligence is more sensitive in many ways , and ministries should share the foundations of `` knowledge , '' rather than to promote cooperation .
i also found the other role of intelligence : providing information to political action .
we have only learned the right policies to develop appropriate policies .
to this end , we need good strategic assessments of intelligence .
the eu ’ s member states have a mechanism for this , through their support and input , and we are building a europe-wide mechanism for eu policymakers .
europol has the material to work from the police , and we need to work hard to ensure that these efforts are coordinated .
this is a different level of intelligence , more analytical , and closer cooperation .
after the madrid bombings , the eu focused on combating terrorism at home .
but this does not mean that the eu has become introverted .
instead , the eu believes that international cooperation is the basis for fighting terrorism .
overall , counter-terrorism is in our international priority , and is becoming increasingly integrated into political dialogue between the eu and other countries .
we are putting foreign aid and building programs on a more appropriate place , and we are ready to use our trade and economic forces when necessary , in bilateral agreements , in bilateral agreements .
transatlantic cooperation between the eu and the us has also changed dramatically .
with respect to deeds , and in the us and europe , there has been a rapid and decisive event – for example , joint efforts aimed at eliminating the funding of terrorists - even as we disagree over events in iraq .
still , i am not complacent .
to facilitate the radical complexity of the eu ’ s counter-terrorism policy , we now have an act of action , with the approval of the council of the european council approved by the council of the european council , which clearly defined their responsibilities and the timing .
the program will also help countries understand the eu ’ s objectives , promoting the pace of legislation .
i recently appointed a counter-terrorism coordinator to help me monitor the program ’ s implementation .
in terms of judicial and home affairs , there is a lot of new ways .

argentina ’ s sovereign bondage
washington , dc – sovereign debt has lately been front-page news , and this time , the united states supreme court ’ s decision on argentina ’ s debt was a decision .
after that decision , the 事件 event will become more complicated .
sovereign debt has been an important feature of the international financial system for centuries .
the king borrowed to other countries to pay for wars elsewhere .
but when they can not pay , sovereign default occurs .
today , sovereigns are often elected democratically elected governments , but they still borrow .
at the same time , there is no shortage of resources to continue to pay for their repayment obligations .
when private firms ( or regional governments ) are unable to repay , they normally enter the legal bankruptcy process .
without such procedures , market economies can not function .
to some extent , this is because creditors are bound to stop lending and demand repayment when the problem is the problem .
this is because the first creditors would often be able to recoup their total payments , while others have only partially withdrawn – which has created incentives for all creditors to rush off , even if they have not lost their capacity for repayment .
moreover , in many cases , the value of assets that affected the real entity will be higher than it was after the separation of assets .
in these circumstances , the best interest in all creditors is to reduce debt rather than collapse .
bankruptcy law thus prevents creditors from persecuting each other by preventing all of them from inflicting harm .
but on the issue of sovereign debt , there is no binding international law that can approve bankruptcy .
while some conventional practices are emerging as international capital markets grow , they remain temporary .
given the uncertainties involved , and sovereign 借债人 can be repaid by printing money to pay for debt issued by the printing press , creditors would normally demand interest on the bonds that are not issued under the law , often in the united states or in the united kingdom , where they are often the united states or the united kingdom .
when a sovereign decides that its foreign debt is no longer sustainable , governments and their creditors will have to negotiate with any of them .
the paris club , established by creditor countries , has developed procedures for dealing with this debt , with sovereign debt held by other sovereigns .
how private creditors hold sovereign debt , and how to organize these creditors , have led to the challenge .
when debt can not be repaid , there are several possible negotiating outcomes .
while it may sometimes be restored to repayment , it could be extended to longer years , so it would allow debtor countries to regain their repayment capacity .
sometimes debtor countries would agree to exchange the old debt with a lower face value or lower interest rates .
few governments would simply refuse to borrow in any form .
argentina defaulted on debt in 2001 .
after a few years , the country was able to use its heavy value to swap bonds with a very low set of bonds .
after 2005 , argentina began paying for new bonds .
but some creditors do not accept this , and sued argentina in new york ( because these claims were issued according to new york law ) .
the opposition ’ s appeal is that if the new bonds were paid in full ( as they once did ) , the same treatment would mean that opponents should withdraw all of their money ( not only interest , but also principal ) .
the second circuit appeals court in the us court ruled that argentina had to pay the same percentage of repayment obligations on its opponents , 100 % in full , as well .
the us supreme court recently upheld this ruling .
under the court ’ s judgment , argentina paid only its opponents to pay for holders of new bonds , while without us financial institutions as a broker for payment for argentina .
so argentina must either repay its opponents in full or merely announce a new bond default .
regardless of the current predicament , the decision raises many questions for issuers and holders of sovereign bonds .
if holders are now convinced that they are resisting the possibility that they would make themselves full of debt at a later date , it is harder to restructure sovereign debt and restore the debtor economies to normal .
in the aftermath of the argentine crisis , most new debt is issued under collective-action clauses , and all bondholders agree to agree on a debt restructuring , as holders of a particular proportion ( about 70 % ) agree .
as time passes , there will be fewer unpaid bonds without cacs .
but the clause does not solve all problems , because every bond is included in a single bond , if it is to buy a sufficient share of its position .
there is also a risk that the future bond issue will be required to replace the pari passu clause , but it would also provide adequate safeguards for bondholders to keep the market operating as they do now .
before the euro crisis , it was believed that problems associated with sovereign debt would only arise in emerging-market countries or least-developed countries .
the united states supreme court ’ s decision to make a difference has been added to the united states supreme court ’ s decision to raise the risks associated with holding sovereign debt – and the cost of issuing them .

xi ’ s recipe
washington , dc – china ’ s government is cracking down on western journalists by cracking down on western journalists and reporting stories about corruption in the new york times and bloomberg journalists , which are threatening to renew visas for them .
times columnist thomas friedman recently wrote an open letter to the chinese government , arguing that , because “ greed is the primary cause of the history of the chinese regime ’ s demise , ” the press is more helpful than harming the chinese government .
anyone who believes that free press and free speech is all too universal would agree with friedman ’ s position .
but chinese politics – including the politics of rights – is always intertwined with economic factors .
last month , xi announced a complete set of reforms on the central committee ’ s third plenum , proposing a “ great revival of the chinese nation . ”
his 60 plans include fiscal policy and financial-sector reforms that implement interest rates on deposits , allowing private investors to participate in state-owned enterprises , active smes , relax labor restrictions , and increase local government revenues .
the policy of this renewed investment is reminiscent of deng xiaoping ’ s initial shift to capitalism in 1979 , when the policy left china ’ s deeply entrenched corporate and government elites .
if xi ’ s administration manages to succeed – a significant uncertainty – its reforms may help china to complete the transition from export-led economic and government investment to a sustainable growth model based on domestic consumption .
the stakes are high .
the country that has lifted hundreds of millions of people out of poverty over the past two decades must now find ways to protect and gradually expand these gains , while creating the same miracle for the hundreds of millions of people who remain impoverished .
china ’ s reform program will have a successful economic and moral impact on the world .
against this background , it is important to know that xi ’ s economic reforms are only one ingredient of a carefully scripted cocktail .
the rest of the formula includes two popular social reforms – ending the one-child policy of many chinese parents , dismantling the “ transfer of labor ” system , and a political crackdown .
strengthening censorship and intimidation of foreign journalists , as well as imprisonment and stricter restrictions on dissidents , are intended to ensure that economic chaos does not lead to the political insurgency .
to implement ambitious reforms , xi has taken several steps to consolidate his personal and bureaucratic power .
he has reduced the politburo ’ s members from nine to seven , thereby reducing the difficulty of achieving consensus under the institutionalized leadership .
he has also expanded the power of the central committee , led by his own leadership , and established a new national security council .
understanding how the national security council will meet xi ’ s statist needs is a case in point .
without national security council and domestic policy committees , the us president has no routine way to control the various bureaucracy .
the white house staff working in the national security council convened the state department , department of defense , the department of finance , the justice department , and other important institutions to comment on specific policies .
but it is president barack obama ’ s staff who directed the outcome toward the next steps .
since the third plenum ended xi ’ s reform agenda , many chinese observers have hailed him as the most transformative leader since deng xiaoping .
time will tell the answer , but the key difference between 2014 and 1979 is that the chinese cocktail is now intertwined with fear .
埃文 snowden once wrote two years ago in the arab uprisings , when a senior official said at a meeting in beijing that “ the country will fall into the abyss ” when the chinese government ’ s global movement was “ shaken ” in the social media .
as snow recently reported in a chinese diplomat explaining the dangers of the government ’ s threats to expel the new york times and the release of bloomberg journalists , it should not allow them to continue doing so . ”
that fear is an important force driving xi ’ s reform agenda .
the communist party must maintain china ’ s economic growth ( even if growth relatively slow ) , while fighting rampant corruption , responding to the needs of people .
china ’ s citizens can not vote , but they are able to express their grievances , making the chinese bureaucracy “ stability . ”
geert 多布森 , the author of the dictator ’ s learning curve , describes the government ’ s substance as an expert , based on effective problem-solving .
“ when the regime ’ s legitimacy is linked to its performance , he suggested , “ any crisis – and the political parties ’ response – can turn into question its right to govern . ”
china ’ s leaders apparently fear that western-style investigative journalism in china could trigger such a crisis .
in any case , they will not risk doing so .
they believe that they can handle the scandal , and the top-down drive for economic , social , and political reform .
they are increasingly reluctant to adhere to western rules .
germany stands up
washington , dc – since the first term , us president barack obama has been repeating the mantra of other countries : “ responsibility versus power . ”
france has repeatedly demonstrated that it understands and bears this responsibility ; it may now be in germany .
a couple of weeks ago , german president gauck gauck looked back at the fifth munich security conference , which has shaped the history of the federal republic in the last half-century , a period that has emerged as a “ good germany , ” which was known to be known .
moreover , germany has benefited more from the current open , value-based international order than most other countries , and thus has greater responsibility for defending and expanding the order .
gauck ’ s speech reflects an important new report , based on political and scientific foundations , and the united states ’ marshall fund , entitled the new great powers , new responsibility ( new power power ) .
the report arises within seven months of internal discussions within germany ’ s foreign policy and security establishment , arguing that germany ’ s current values and interests are committed to “ human dignity , liberty , democracy , the rule of law , and the international order based on universal norms . ”
as 高克所 points out , germany ’ s “ overriding strategic objective ” must be the order of “ preservation and lasting adjustment . ”
in order to achieve this , germany must become a “ great power power , ” a country capable of addressing the problems of conflict and addressing the conflict with all of the international community .
while the traditional dimension of a country ’ s power relative to others – geography , demography , economic power , and military power – remains important , it is often insufficient to wield actual influence in international politics .
a powerful power power builds relationships , investment institutions , and thus allows it to work with other countries and build and mobilize “ coalitions and networks of like-minded countries . ”
germany has a special responsibility to help the global new powers finance the system as a powerful power in which to protect and extend the openness of the international system .
therein lies the essence of this .
germany has long sought permanent seats on the un security council , as well as japan , brazil , and india .
but the new great powers , the new responsibility point out a different path , put forward a new security council reform package that would merge the united kingdom and france into permanent european seats , thereby ensuring that the number of non-permanent members in europe is “ small and permanent . ”
in this scenario , germany will play a global role in peace and security through european seats , while as a non-permanent member .
this new commitment to “ strong and united europe ” is the second pillar of the twenty-first century german foreign policy .
the new great powers , new responsibility proposes “ deepening ” the european union through a series of measures , including the direct involvement of national parliaments , and europe ’ s fiscal constraints on the european union ’ s government , in exchange for the democratization of european banking , the eurozone budget , and eurobonds .
in terms of foreign and security policy , the new powers , new responsibility proposes strengthening the role of senior representative representatives in the eu and the role of the european action service .
the current eu high representative catherine ashton continues to demonstrate the value of the eu ’ s foreign policy agency , such as , say , brokering an important peace agreement between serbia and kosovo , which also played a key role in negotiations on iran .
the third surprise comes from the use of force .
it is clear that germans , who must be prepared to use force , will use force at least as a final option , and accuse some of germany ’ s fellow citizens from using their “ past crimes , ” as opposed to the “ 愿望 of the past . ”
more controversially , gauck ’ s request for any military action would require security council authorization , but he also hinted that kosovo could serve as a precedent for military intervention in syria .
as he points out , when the international community faces an obvious situation , it needs to use force to protect people from their own government , but the un security council can not agree on a united front , “ the relationship between legitimacy and legitimacy becomes a hindrance . ”
in the deliberations of the new great powers , the new responsibility , there is disagreement .
some argue that the security council authorization is necessary , and some believe that , without authorization , humanitarian interventions can be “ the exception of a strictly defined exception . ”
us secretary of state john kerry spoke at the munich security conference .
but , given that he did not mention gauck ’ s statement , he missed an opportunity to highlight obama ’ s key foreign-policy principle : as the us no longer acts as a policeman , more attention to diplomacy , other countries must stand up .
more important , kerry and obama can reflect on a key lesson embedded in gauck ’ s speech and the report .
countries that want to retain power in an ever-changing global order must learn to share it , which requires accepting and embracing a new world landscape .
the obama administration should think carefully about reform of the security council .
it must send a real signal that it is willing to replace the order of the world in 1945 to replace the world of 1945 .
this means supporting a larger role for all countries that understand and accept the real responsibility for maintaining global peace and stability .
stopping syria ’ s contagion
washington , dc – syria ’ s civil war has become a very complex issue .
with the parties coming to a second round of peace negotiations in geneva , the government has launched a vicious bomb attack on cities like aleppo ; both militant islamist groups , including the syrian free army , are fighting alongside al qaeda affiliates ; and al qaeda agencies have clashed .
moreover , the war is becoming more influential in others .
the fighting has exacerbated instability in the region ; the us and european citizens are flooding into syria ; and the idea of a post-war middle east border is increasingly being accepted .
indeed , many armed groups backed by outside powers are threatening the survival of the country ’ s multi-ethnic nation-states – iran , saudi arabia , qatar , russia , the us , turkey , france , france , and many private donors .
there are three ways to simplify the situation , allowing participants in geneva ii to agree not only on a third geneva conference .

the un must reaffirm its doctrine of “ responsibility to protect , ” which is not an excuse for military intervention , but rather a fundamental principle that the government has emphasized the need for the government to protect its citizens .
second , the international community must lay the groundwork for engagement .
the conflict in syria was also an internal matter , with the un playing only a humanitarian and refugee rescue .
but now the conflict has spread to the entire middle east , causing instability in lebanon and threatening to fracture iraq .
the united nations security council has a responsibility to punish default and remove threats to international peace , which are now clearly met .
so russia ’ s permanent security council has an obligation to act ; it ( and china ) can not use the un to act as an excuse to justify its internal affairs .

finally , the most important step that us president barack obama can take is to restore credible threats of force .
during the three years of escalating conflict , assad believed that the only diplomatic success was achieved when the us missile strikes .
he suddenly recognized the benefits of destroying the chemical weapons .
but most experts believe that military strikes are impossible .
the american public has adamantly rejected obama ’ s attack on assad ’ s repeated attack on assad ’ s repeated use of chemical weapons , and a recent pew poll showed that the majority of americans believe that “ america should exercise its own affairs in international affairs , and what can do the rest of the world . ”
in particular , obama will have to do more than polls .
the us military has withdrawn from afghanistan and iraq , but the victory that has paid off is waning .
al qaeda is 趁虚而入 and is forming their own government in western iraq and the eastern part of syria , where al-qaeda is far from europe and the united states .
perhaps obama believes that he and his successor can deal with such threats later .
if al qaeda starts to threaten the us in the case of islamic states like iraq and syria , the us could eliminate them by drones , as in afghanistan , pakistan , and yemen .
but if he is willing to consider the use of force against al qaeda without international authorization , why should we now not use drones to support moderate syrian opposition , forcing assad to negotiate seriously ?
the threat of cruise missiles last september was enough to bring al qaeda members out of the dock .
actions aimed at destroying assad ’ s air force and blocking him from dropping bombs to the people might concentrate his attention on diplomatic negotiations .
obama should declare that the us is committed to political solutions to syria , and his government will do whatever it can to find such a solution in the next year and subsequently .
but if a ceasefire is not fulfilled in the next three months , the us should be able to empower the regional organizations and the syrian people to attack the attacks on civilians and the assad regime against civilians .
the obama administration should explain to the american public that this directly matters to america ’ s security interests .
after all , if geneva ii fails , the third geneva conference will not only involve syria .
people may need to consider how to end the wars in the middle east .
