a no-fly zone for syria
brussels – in an interpretation of international relations , the enemy ’ s enemy is my friend ’ s enemy .
sometimes it is right , often wrong .
thirty years ago , afghanistan ’ s jihadist friends were wrong with friends of the west when they fought with soviet invaders .
the deepening of the syrian crisis , together with the crime of chemical weapons , created a similar dynamic and dilemma .
but the west does not need to offend the same false and equally mistaken choices .
let us start with the first principles .
the recent chemical-weapons attack in syria must be a game changer .
although these weapons of mass destruction are technically not illegal , most countries joined the 1993 chemical weapons convention , which syria refused to sign .
so , “ what will happen next ? ” can not be “ won ’ t happen . ”
the principle of international law – particularly the emerging “ responsibility to protect ” and the use of chemical weapons globally – means that some form of military intervention must be carried out in order to deter other countries that might use weapons of mass destruction , especially for civilians , to use weapons of mass destruction .
but what is the right move , and does it really work ?
what measures are more favorable to strengthening western security , and what can be done to undermine the west ’ s security ?
i believe that the most fair and simple response is a no-fly zone in syria .
the proposal is particularly appropriate in the absence of a solution to the united nations charter ( “ action to threaten peace threats ” ) , because russia and china ( almost certainly ) will vote on the security council .
of course , since the appalling chemical-weapons attack on damascus , which erupted in damascus , and in the aftermath of the rebel control , it has been tense .
but , given the brutality of president bashar al-assad ’ s regime , no one doubts that it will be able to hide its crime .
blocking the un ’ s chemical-weapons experts from entering verification is enough for assad ’ s government to conceal the evidence of the crime of the day , allowing the evidence to degrade the evidence or destroy the evidence .
the united states , france , and the united kingdom firmly believe that the intelligence and 目击 evidence is the perpetrator of the assad government .
another important point is concern about the elements of the syrian opposition .
some elements of al qaeda , led by al qaeda , have been led by al-qaeda , such as al nusra , whose proxy is as brutal as the government and its allies , iran ’ s proxy , and iran ’ s revolutionary guard .
but the west ’ s intelligence agencies believe that there is no evidence that these rebel groups have launched chemical weapons .
in such an environment , a no-fly zone would not only enable syrian warplanes and missiles to go away from the sky , thereby reducing the scale of the slaughter ; it would also be like assad and his supporters that he is weak .
generals ordered to use chemical weapons would have to reckon with the risks that the assad regime has been brought to the court , and that they were brought to court in war crimes .
of course , the benefits are not limited to that , if russia and china favor the security council to implement it – to protect peace and prevent war crimes .
in the case of assad ’ s use of chemical weapons , he will continue to support russia ’ s position in the arab world as a protector .

欧佩克 opec ?
dubai – in september 1960 , representatives from iran , iraq , kuwait , saudi arabia , and venezuela gathered in baghdad to form the organization of petroleum exporting countries .
as the world ’ s dependence on oil grows , so did opec ’ s power .
today , many developing countries , including most middle eastern countries , have become the world ’ s leading labor exporters , and should consider creating a similar cartel of migrant workers like opec ?
opec successfully protected the common interests that individual member states can not protect individually .
when markets have structural distortions , the political tools and collective action that opec offers are more effective than public policy .
today ’ s labor-exporting countries were not very different from opec ’ s founding members in 1960 .
they are also weak performers .
rich importers of labor and poor labor exporters have mutually dependent relationships ; but labor importers can unilaterally tighten or loosen immigration or labor-market rules , and labor exporters always face uncertainty .
this imbalance could cost labor exporters huge costs .
remittances from diaspora remittances are important lifeblood for many developing countries – more important than any other financial crisis , including foreign direct investment and aid – often to balance a country ’ s books .
indeed , according to the world bank , remittances accounted for 20-30 % of the philippines and indonesia ’ s gdp in 2013 , and 42 % in tajikistan , 32 % in kyrgyzstan , 48 % in kyrgyzstan , and 6.6 % in yemen , yemen , and morocco .
for many developing countries , labor is a strategic component of production , just as commodities are in resource-rich economies .
when we talk about migrant labor , we think of low-skill jobs in agriculture , construction , services , and domestic affairs .
but countries such as jordan and lebanon are education workers , enabling them not only to pursue domestic chores , but also to become skilled expatriates .
today , labor-exporting countries need to protect their investments in human capital , which are the most effective way to do so .
if these countries want to join china , mexico , india , and other major labor exporters , they must make collective bargaining through wages , visa , and other conditions – some of which will benefit non-member countries as a result of changing global norms .
labor importers need competition to enter the common market , and countries that gain access to the right to access to power will gain a huge comparative advantage .
the cartel would prevent labor-exporting countries from sacrificing their own interests , which is often the case in bilateral arrangements .
for example , if a separate agreement with the gulf cooperation council is to be concluded , southeast asia ’ s southeast asian countries would compromise one another , and the ultimate result is a much worse deal .
with a cartel , governments would turn to a minimum wage rate for different professions and transactions , as well as for different skill levels .
as exporters train migrant workers , demand for these labor will increase , boosting competition on the demand side rather than supply chains , thereby creating a virtuous cycle of higher wages and more skills training .
and , because all of this will occur in global markets , the price of some skills will become more transparent in training agencies , students , employees , and employers .
in this new system , importing countries will collect taxes – based on the new minimum wage – and remittances will continue to be untaxed .
from this perspective , the cartel would have a double international trade union , providing bargaining power for workers in countries where unions are weaker or blocked .
a labor-exporting cartel would have far-reaching implications for the existing system .
cartel members will have the ability to reward and penalize third-party parties .
moreover , more important , the workers themselves will be able to recapture their dignity in the current system , and that their rights are long denied .
indeed , the world ’ s xenophobia will wane , as it is expected to be a privilege with foreign workers .
according to the new negotiation arrangement , labor-exporting countries or will create incentives to curb free riders and illegal immigrants , and labor importers or incentives to legalize and maintain illegal migration .
one possible objection to this proposal is that low-skilled labor costs will increase , which will stimulate automation .
but the jobs that have been driven out of the production sector , driven by automation , will shift to the leisure sector , as demand for household , 侍应 , gardener , and the 园丁 increases .
the cartel will make changes in these markets more clear , so labor exporters will be able to respond and adjust workers accordingly , increasing the ability of labor importers to hire workers more well suited to available jobs .
all told , the labor-exporting cartel will impose order on industries that have long been locked in the dispute , undermining the reputation of many importers of labor importers .
it will change the dynamics of the labor supply and supply of labor , enabling workers ( who will gain new protections ) and importers ( which will be able to acquire a 拉动力 labor force to adapt to rapid changes in economic conditions often due to technology ) .

so please don ’ t pander to israeli extremists and hawks .

this process , as in the past , must finally be achieved with an independent and democratic palestine , and a safe israel .
another asian wake-up call
new haven – the global economic recovery is at risk again , in three years .
in 2008 , the culprit was the subprime crisis in the united states .
this time , it is europe ’ s sovereign-debt crisis .
the alarm bells in asia should be heard clearly – export-oriented region can not be indifferent to repeated shocks to the two largest sources of external demand .
in fact , both shocks have long-lasting repercussions .
in the us , consumers ( which account for 71 % of us gdp ) are struggling with a japanese-like balance-sheet recession .
in the 15 quarters since the beginning of 2008 , real consumer spending has grown at an average annual rate of just 0.4 % .
as the world ’ s largest consumer , the us has never experienced such a chronic weakness .
unless us households make significant progress in cutting the burden of debt , restoring personal savings , and , at the current pace , it will be difficult to overcome the us economy ’ s balance-sheet constraints , the us economy will continue to suffer from a slow growth spurt .
the situation is similar in europe .
even under current very optimistic assumptions – the eurozone will remain – the european economic outlook is bleak .
the crisis-torn peripheral economies – greece , ireland , portugal , italy , and possibly spain – have fallen into recession .
and , as the leading indicators suggest , germany and france , which have been a significant drop in the data on german orders , were also threatened by economic growth in germany and france , with initial signs of weakness .
moreover , fiscal austerity may affect aggregate demand in the years ahead , with capital shortages likely to tighten credit – a serious problem for europe ’ s 银行 system of credit intermediation .
the european commission recently revised its 2012 gdp growth forecast to 0.5 % , teetering on the brink of full-blown recession .
the official forecasts will most likely reduce further in the future .
it is difficult to see how asia can become an oasis of prosperity in the global economic climate .
but denial is deep , and momentum appears strong .
after all , asia has done well in recent years , and too many people believe that , whatever the rest of the world , the region can stand up .
asia ’ s vulnerability to external shocks has intensified .
prior to the great recession of 2008-2009 , exports accounted for a whopping 44 % of asia ’ s total gdp as a share of gdp , fully ten percentage points below the asian crisis of 1997-1998 .
so , while asia ’ s initial decade after the crisis was focused on repairing financial vulnerability to its financial vulnerability to it – a way to accumulate massive foreign-exchange reserves – it has failed to rebalance the economy ’ s macroeconomic structure , and to reduce excessive exposure to short-term capital inflows .
indeed , asia ’ s economic growth has become more dependent on exports and external demand .
as a result , when the shock hit in 2008-2009 , all of the region ’ s economies either experienced a major slowdown or fell into a severe recession .
this is likely to happen again in the months ahead .
emerging asia ’ s share of gdp has declined sharply from 2008 to 2009 , but now it is back to 44 % , meaning that the region ’ s exposure to external demand shocks is as large today as it was in the run-up to the sub-prime crisis .
china – the long-term engine of growth in asia – is typical of asia ’ s potential vulnerability to shocks to developed-country shocks .
indeed , europe and the us collectively account for 38 % of china ’ s total exports in 2010 , the two largest foreign markets .
the latest data inevitably show that asia is beginning to feel the brunt of the recent global shock .
the same is true of china three years ago , with annual export growth falling from 31 % in october 2010 to 16 % in october 2011 , and will likely fall further in the coming months .
in hong kong , exports actually contracted by 3 % in september , and 23 months on year .
south korea and taiwan have also shown a similar slowdown in exports .
even an economy that has long been considered asia ’ s most resilient economy – india , export growth from 44 % in august 2011 to 11 % in october 2011 .
like three years ago , many hoped that asia is a “ decoupling ” from the global shock .
but , with gdp growth now slowing in asia , it seems wishful thinking .
the good news is that a strong investment-led drive partly offset declining export growth and left asia from a hard landing to a soft landing .
but , if the eurozone breaks down , europe ’ s goodwill will be dashed , and asia ’ s goodwill will collapse .
this is asia ’ s second wake-up call in three years , and this time asia needs to be taken seriously .
the us , together with europe , has faced a long way of recovery , with asia ’ s emerging economies unable to establish robust growth based on external demand , based on advanced-country external demand .
if they don ’ t want to allow growth to slow , allowing labor to continue to be absorbed , the risk that social instability will become increasingly destabilizing , and that they will have to move decisively to the region ’ s 3.5 billion consumers .
the most urgent need for consumer-led asia is the need for a consumer-led asia .
another balkan high noon
with the world focused on iraq , north korea , and the prospect of a confrontation with iran over nuclear weapons , kosovo has gone out of its sights .
the situation is coming to an end , and decisions about the province ’ s fate are looming .
the us and its european friends have repeatedly demonstrated their intention to make decisions about whether to separate kosovo from serbia before the end of the year .
this decision is crucial to the future of this unstable region , and will test western determination and unity .
this year , the united nations brokered by the united nations brokered a consensual settlement of the “ final status ” problem between serbia and kosovo .
negotiations continue , but , as un negotiators and former finnish president martti ahtisaari diplomatically told the security council , negotiations actually end .
indeed , serbian nationalism , prime minister vojislav kostunica , has struggled to weaken kosovo ’ s interim government .
he is rushing to hold a referendum this month on a new constitution without serious parliamentary debate and a general public education .
the main purpose of his new constitution is its preamble , which declared kosovo an inalienable part of serbia .
kosovo ’ s ethnic albanians have declared that they will not accept any connection with serbia , however fragile the link .
throughout the 1990 ’ s , they were effectively divorced from the serbs of kosovo by creating parallel institutions .
in 1999 , when they forced large-scale relocation , nato intervened , which ended serbia ’ s rule and established a 准 国家 country .
at some point in the next two months , the balkans group , the united states , the united kingdom , germany , italy , and russia will consider the question of kosovo ’ s final status as a question of the security council , and that it will have to make a proposal to the security council .
in an open forum , all contact groups are trying to make the final status issue unresolved , but in private , the united states and some of its allies told them that they will be scheduled for independence this year .
some members of the security council , especially russia and china , have opposed imposing a solution , or , in fact , on suspicion .
whether the security council approve independence will depend largely on avoiding russian votes , which requires a substantial diplomatic effort .
the nature of the independence granted is also important .
an independent kosovo must be secure , and its minorities must be protected .
north kosovo is now largely under belgrade ’ s control , so , beyond nominal , it can not divide .
to reduce the blow to serbia , the security council must avoid giving kosovo independence , so that new states can not function .
if the security council fails to make decisions on its final status , it will have a serious situation .
if this happens , the serbs of northern kosovo could declare their independence .
at the very least , serbia would strongly oppose recognition .
indeed , serbia ’ s government has tried to persuade the west to postpone its decision by 2007 .
it claims that , given kosovo ’ s independence , radical nationalism will take power in the next general election ; and it believes that this year will allow the contact group to postpone a proposal to the security council .
moreover , the government encouraged the leaders of bosnia ’ s serb democratic party to threaten their own referendum on a 全民公决 bosnia .
and they continue to pursue ahtisaari ’ s job to delay the vienna talks , but did not .
the timing of the constitutional referendum appears to be part of a delaying strategy .
some hope that postponing decisions will inspire violence in kosovo and further encourage the west to reconsider its independence .
this tactic may be working .
many eu countries worry about the implications of taking a country ’ s territory , and kosovo ’ s independence to serbian democracy .
given serbia ’ s political instability , they question the damage caused by short-term postponement , though most of them are self-inflicted .
but delay only offers more room for kostunica to find ways to make the security council decisions more difficult .
the west must ignore belgrade ’ s warning .
serbian politics will be messy and unstable in the foreseeable future , and serbia ’ s politicians will attempt to act as an excuse to avoid losing kosovo .
but , at the end of kosovo ’ s final status , the situation will be even worse in the balkans , which will prevent serbia from close to the west and finally gaining the eu ’ s membership , which would jeopardize kosovo ’ s minority minority and undermine fragile states like bosnia and macedonia .
beyond independence , there is no realistic solution to kosovo .
if serbia wants to join the west , it should not be trapped in its nationalist past .

the great britain ’ s failed experiment
florence – british politics has always been a test for the developed world .
in the 1970s , the british model became the poster child for the postwar economic collapse .
the political base of this model was based on consensus-building , underpinned by keynesian demand management .
today , the collapse of our eyes is the “ 轻 ” system , with the establishment of a party that presented itself as a party for “ new labour , ” and , in particular , loosened financial markets .
in the 1960 ’ s , keynesian economic policies created a 幻影 fantasy : high employment levels , high wage growth , and 英伦三岛 , 英伦三岛 , 披头士 , 风 , and 粉彩 , all of which have been 。 .

cambridge – 2008 was a year of volatile exchange rates .

so what will happen next year ?
while only sustained high volatility is safe , we are in an unusual moment , with very different short- and long-term trends .
in the short run , the yen and the dollar continue to benefit from public dissatisfaction with risk , because panicked investors seek to hide .
when other central banks continue to cut interest rates to a very low level , the yen and the dollar are appreciating , and interest rates on the yen and dollar have already taken place .
so , while the us and japan will not raise interest rates in the short run , lower foreign rates still make the dollar and yen more attractive .
commodity prices will remain weak , holding back commodity currencies , especially in the yen , because resource-poor japan is so dependent on imports .
normally , the direction of short-term and long-term exchange rates is consistent .
in fact , a large number of studies show that , for most major currencies , the exchange rate for next week ’ s exchange rate , next month ’ s exchange rate , or next year ’ s exchange rate will be the most accurate forecast of today ’ s exchange rate .
given the dollar ’ s status as a safe haven , continued fiscal crisis is putting upward pressure on the dollar .
commodity prices are also plummeting .
yet the financial crisis will eventually end , and the global recession will end .
and you need to know that neither will soon end soon , and another seven or eight months could be , if not longer .
but , when more normal growth is actually restored , the recent trend toward supporting the dollar and the yen will disappear .

but investors still fear what happens when money is actually going to be .
many emerging markets will also want to engage in countercyclical macroeconomic policies , but concerns about fiscal sustainability and fear of sharp inflation have left them constrained .
europe ’ s fiscal policy is constrained by the maastricht treaty , and european monetary policy is focused on price stability .
to be sure , china ’ s vast foreign-exchange reserves , like the rest of the world , are rich in macroeconomic policy .

at the same time , as bold monetary easing moves down the price of price stability , today ’ s decline in prices ( or “ deflation ” ) will eventually become inflation .

the new natural nature
york – six million years ago , a celestial body hit the planet and wiped out the dinosaurs .
that is the space for the growers to endure , and eventually develop tools for armed , linguistic , 直立 apes , and some believe that their power is almost as large as that of 那颗 objects .
as we enter the so-called anthropocene , human activity dominates climate and environmental impact , and we must examine how we use this power .
many believe that the world is becoming increasingly “ unnatural ” – tainted by humans .
but , given that humans evolve into the world ’ s ecosystems , everything that we do – 杀绝 species , destruction of forests , the atmosphere of pollution – can be seen as a natural product of evolution .
according to this logic , the world has not become so natural because we changed it .
to be sure , environmentalists and conservationists have been tempted to make the environment more resilient to the past .
the reality in today ’ s world is that there is simply no way to distinguish the human race from humans from humans .
across the globe , ecological and evolutionary processes have been the way to survive from environmental changes .
so , instead of automatically opposing this change , environmentalists and conservationists should distinguish between “ good change ” and “ bad change . ”
the challenge is to define good and bad .
most people would agree that a single species would be a bad thing .
but when it comes to the disappearance of some species , such as birds who are prone to 染病 islands , we can choose not to intervene , because reality is that it is difficult to stop the “ higher ” model that they have been evolving into “ higher . ”
nonetheless , conserving as many species as possible makes sense .
today ’ s descendants of today ’ s species will continue to form all future ecosystems – in which they form peculiar conditions for human or planetary processes – and thus have an obvious advantage .
in fact , more species create “ spare parts ” of the environment , which protects a long-term environmental insurance .
more contentious is shifting species to new ecosystems .
the gardener prefers to plant species in its backyard , but local populations often see “ foreign ” plants that are often growing in their backyard as invaders – a dangerous deviation from the past .
sometimes , these plants are not even herbicides .
resistance to this change is so strong that the uk will wait for about 1,000 years , such as the rabbit , as a local species .
in australia , the 澳洲 – introduced centuries ago – should be thought to be a matter of local debate .
but , so far , roughly 2,000 central and local animal plants in central and eastern europe have not directly led to local extinction , mostly causing little harm or no harm .
indeed , over the last few centuries , imported species have increased biological diversity in much of the world in the region .
these regional biodiversity increases – a 20 % increase in the number of wild species in europe and the united states , and the increase in plant species in the archipelago and other pacific islands – should be viewed as positive developments .
given this – and it is not realistic to repatriate most foreign species – new species should be accepted immediately .
this is certainly a more meaningful debate than the protracted debate on them in the name of an idealized old world .
this is not backward , because new species have been producing a new species , especially through the hybridization of migration .
over the last three centuries , the 杂种 crop in the uk – such as grass grass and 猴 面花 – is more polluted than the entire european population ( 记录 ) .
there is something similar in north america .
this new evolution in human endeavor means that , in the anthropocene , we are the creators of the old biological diversity , as well as the creators of new biological diversity .
we no longer rely on the planet ; we are now changing the planet .
recognizing this , we should certainly be clearly not all of the changes that are “ bad . ”
but there should be more acceptance and even active action for biological changes that make species meet .
i , in my new book the earth ’ s heirs : the earth ’ s “ natural boom , ” argues that we live in a “ new natural nature . ”
it remains as ecologically and evolutionary as it was in the past .
the difference is that this dynamic is now largely attributable to the activities of a human race , which is growing .
species will enter the new human environment , and evolve with us .
we should make them work .
perhaps we should even help them .
agriculture ’ s bad medicine
san diego – most of us are oblivious to the threat posed by our actions , without which the existence of these threats will not be thought .
the use of antibiotics is so .
but the efficacy of antibiotics is being squandered by their imprudent use in agriculture .
today , more than half of the use of antibiotics worldwide is used in food production .
farmers use antibiotics to treat infections .
the problem is that they often end up with antibiotics , or they use them to remedy inappropriate agricultural practices – such as overcrowding to factory farms – or to use them to accelerate growth and lower production costs .
while such practices may be impossible to do , their overall effects are dangerous .
antibiotic resistance is exacerbated by the environment that people eat through food or animal waste .
and that has an adverse impact on human health .
every day , in hospitals and clinics around the world , patients are treating bacterial infections with antibiotics , gonorrhea , or pneumonia .
others are using antibiotics , in order to avoid bacterial infections in the basic situation or treatment ( such as chemotherapy ) .
unfortunately , many widely used antibiotics are losing their ability to protect patients , treatments for diseases ; and the key reason is that agriculture ’ s daily abuse is a daily abuse of antibiotics .
shortly after the scottish 微生物学家 alexander fleming discovered a fungus capable of killing bacteria , it recognized that overuse of antibiotics would cause resistance .
as he warned in 1945 , “ the people who use penicillin are morally responsible for the death of those who die with penicillin for infection . ”
large-scale misuse of antibiotics in agriculture is one of the most notorious forms of “ 轻率 use . ”
in 2015 , the national pigs discovered a new antibiotic-resistant bacterium , and the chinese patients were then in such cases .
two types of variant , then discovered that the genes that make these bacteria resistant to antimicrobial resistance could be found in the world ’ s farms and hospitals – the so-called “ 流动性 ” – now found in farms and hospitals around the world .
if the reckless use of antibiotics in agriculture continues , the impact on people will be severe .
fortunately , there is a solution .
more than a decade ago , the eu banned agricultural use of agricultural agriculture , excluding treatment infections .
moreover , while the rule is imperfect , it helps to reduce the use of antibiotics .
in denmark , for example , the use of antibiotics for antibiotics has declined , despite a slight increase in antibiotic use for treating 猪瘟 drugs .
these gains , however modest , are encouraging – and should be further encouraged .
the problem of antimicrobial resistance is a global threat , so only multilateral cooperation – the form of a new treaty or trade agreement – can ensure that farmers are subject to the minimum standards of the minimum – without unnecessary use of antibiotics .
in december 2015 , a study by the british government , jim o ’ neill , led by jim o ’ neill , found that altering the most effective means of behavior is to limit the use of antibiotics , but allowing individual countries to try to use taxes or regulations to achieve that limit .
moreover , i argued in other papers that farmers should be asked to obtain prescriptions before the livestock use .
although the eu ’ s ban includes this provision , the rule is not the rule of law .
if a global consensus – for example , through the g20 or the united nations general assembly – chooses to raise taxes on agricultural antibiotics , countries that choose to tax agricultural antibiotics can drive the shift in alternative farming operations .
money could also be used to finance research and development in vitro meat , which dramatically reduced the suffering of animals and the burden of infectious diseases .
most important , the new treaty must allow signatories to meet their farmers ’ diverse needs .
the goal of global action should be to incentivize farmers to reduce antibiotic use , not to punish them .
while the world has a long way to go from this goal , the us has shown that the us has a way to change its approach if it is encouraged and encouraged by the us .
still , most of us remain blind to the unintended consequences of our decision .
unless people voluntarily stop consuming factory farms , we must rely on governments and multilateral organizations to keep us right .
antibiotics for effective antibiotics
mexico city – from the discovery of penicillin in 1928 to the last major antibiotics in the 1960 ’ s , humanity ’ s ability to fight 病原菌 has changed dramatically .
but , over time , the number of antibiotics with the bacteria is gradually declining , and some pathogens have reacted resistant to most or all existing drugs .
as a result , the infections that could once be treated are becoming lethal .
currently , antibiotic resistance causes roughly 700,000 deaths per year , resulting in financial losses worth tens of billions of dollars .
because antibiotic resistance continues to affect our treatment of cancer , transplant organs , and implant prosthesis , the loss of antibiotic resistance will be even more severe .
the rise in antimicrobial resistance is caused by many factors .
bacteria can reproduce and mutate quickly , and can create a network of similar “ genetic internet ” that allows some to “ download ” antibiotic-resistant genes .
moreover , most antibiotics are natural products of soil bacteria , and antibiotic resistance can occur naturally in the soil .
when large-scale antibiotics are introduced , bacteria with resistance become increasingly prevalent .
today , humans release about 100,000 tons of antibiotics annually .
if these antibiotics are applied properly and save lives , reasonable cost-benefit analysis may be possible .
but about 70 % of antibiotics are being used to accelerate the growth of farm animals .
the remaining 30 % , though used for treatment , are often inaccurate or unnecessary .
and , because most of the drugs used in wastewater have been released into the environment with wastewater and dung , bacteria in soil , water , and wildlife can also be exposed .
if this misuse of antibiotics does not end soon , we will soon find that there is no drug available for bacterial infections .
but while some measures are taking place – a high-level meeting in the united nations high-level meeting last september – they are not enough .
what humans really need is an immediate global ban on agricultural use of antibiotics .
moreover , the clinical 使用指南 of antibiotics , which now parallel to how to choose a relationship with the medical profession , must be reviewed and enforced .
these two measures alone – both of which can be enacted by government regulators – could reduce the use of antibiotics by nearly 80 % , thereby slowing antibiotic resistance considerably .
of course , it is not easy for governments to implement these policies , because they are contrary to strong economic interests , most notably the pharmaceutical industry , which sells $ 40 billion per year in antibiotics .
while large 药企对 continues to abuse the interest in antibiotics , it is not interested in developing new antibiotics against drug-resistant bacteria .
the bottom line is that antibiotics can treat cancer and chronic diseases .
so the big pharmaceutical companies demand “ incentives ” to develop new antibiotics , such as extending patents for patents or tax cuts ; another is to provide astronomical prices for new drugs .
but these incentives provide the benefit of pharmaceutical companies far more than actual r & d costs ; as a result , it is a tool to make public money available to private money – precisely the problem .
but , beyond these carrots , societies should consider using a stick .
i call it nanbu ( no antibiotics , no business ) .
nanbu would add rankings to companies that are actively involved in new antibiotics .
companies that do not manufacture or sell antibiotics for agricultural purposes , or to refuse to promote antibiotics in areas where they do not need such drugs , are also available .
and firms that engage in the opposite behavior – selling antibiotics as livestock “ growth 促进剂 ” or actively encouraging physicians to prescribe patients – will lose scores .
at first , almost all pharmaceutical companies will lose scores .
but , over time , the rating can be adjusted , and it is based on the reasonable advice of an independent group of experts .
the ratings can then be used to guide decisions .
for many types of relevant drugs , there are several options for producing a similar efficacy and safety .
as a result , clinicians could use drugs from highly rated companies to avoid market access to the market .
patients should encourage such decisions , and follow suit on the same principle .
over time , antibiotics could once again gain stronger profitability , because the companies can sell more other drugs , so that they gradually reduce demand for expensive incentives .
the key to nanbu ’ s success is to ensure widespread awareness of the threat posed by antimicrobial resistance and its related responses .
this would promote patients and doctors to consider nanbu ratings when deciding how to use them , and to force their governments to take more forceful action .
the pressure to use public propaganda to strengthen governments ’ ability to implement necessary but difficult policies has been successful – examples that include advances in forest and fisheries sustainability .
public propaganda is a priority for the un conference .
but to advance this global effort , we need new global institutions to take responsibility .
nanbu as an international ngo could live in the face of most multinational pharmaceutical companies and be protected by domestic lobbying or political pressure .
antibiotic-resistant bacteria are a global threat , and thus can not be addressed by domestic policies alone .
the world must think together and act together to protect the enormous benefits and benefits of antibiotics for humanity .
a fair war on antimicrobial resistance
brighton – existing anti-microbial drugs are becoming increasingly effective .
if current trends are allowed to continue , we may be able to recapture the conditions of antibiotics before we are allowed to become a major killer .
meeting the challenge of drug-resistant microbes will not be easy , which requires large-scale investment in new anti-microbial drugs , and to control and limit new treatments to ensure that medicines are effective .
as with climate change , international coordination is based on any effective strategy .
in particular , there must be coordination of pharmaceutical companies , government payers , and the global poor .
indeed , the key to success is encouraging the poor to participate .
low- and middle-income countries are an important source of drug-resistant bacteria .
a crowded housing , poor sanitation , and compromised immune systems are fertile ground for infectious diseases , whether because of malnutrition or 慢性感染 .
the poor quality of antibiotics is misused to make bacteria an opportunity to generate resistance .
moreover , a significant improvement in transportation infrastructure , which has significantly improved rural and urban areas , has led to rapid 基因 of drug-resistant genes around the world .
in many countries that are prone to infectious diseases , the government ’ s health-care systems can not meet demand , so the gap is filled with suppliers from health-care experts to the informal providers of regulation .
such an arrangement would be useful .
for example , a recent study by bangladesh shows that antibiotics provided by the so-called “ village doctors ” that are operating on the border have helped to reduce mortality rates for 败血症 sepsis and childhood pneumonia .
but there are also considerable evidence that the drug quality is rife and is frequently abused .
many people have not been able to use their medicines for a process .
one response would be to develop and enforce legislation that is only buying antibiotics for doctors .
but it would likely severely limit the access to antibiotics for the poor , raising the death rate , and thus both politically unacceptable and politically unacceptable .
the alternative is to develop new strategies to improve antibiotic treatment through informal channels .
for starters , it is safe to invest in a reliable 监测数据 of common infections .
the treatment guidelines must include such information , and will give them all providers of antibiotics .
moreover , high-quality antibiotics must be provided at reasonable prices .
counterfeit products must be eliminated from markets , and in the form of partnerships between governments , pharmaceutical companies , and civil-society groups to control quality .
there is a strong way to ensure that drug prices are low ; in some cases , public subsidies may be necessary .
lower prices need to be aligned with provisions to prevent abuse .
packaging innovations that produce a full range of combinations of drugs could simplify treatment decisions .
similarly , developing low-cost diagnostic technologies can reduce demand for treatment based on symptoms .
the biggest challenge is to encourage suppliers of antibiotics to change their behavior .
this requires certification , amending payment mechanisms , and encouraging intermediaries to provide technical support and monitor effectiveness .
these institutions could include ngos , religious institutions , social entrepreneurs , and companies that distribute drugs .
such activities are unlikely to achieve commercial interests , so the support of the government , philanthropy , and drug producers becomes necessary .
at the same time , reliable information and advice must be made to the right use of antibiotics .
it is especially important if citizens rely heavily on their own resources to cope with the disease .
implementing a systematic reform of antibiotics requires a national and global union .
the fundamental goal is to develop basic standards of conduct for health-care workers and pharmaceutical companies that reflect the needs of patients and communities .
governments must play an effective role in this process ; businesses that develop , produce , and sell drugs and diagnostic technologies will promote cooperation .
the premise that humans benefit is that antibiotics must be managed in a fair , sustainable manner .
the anti-democratic heart of populism
santiago – representatives of the international monetary fund ’ s annual meeting in early october agree that , “ assume that the republicans , irrespective of sexual harassment and trumped-up rhetoric , are likely to lead to populist protectionists . ”
the underlying implication is that the rise of populist forces in the us and europe is a direct consequence of globalization and its immediate effects : the negative effects include unemployment and stagnant middle-class incomes .
davos participants don ’ t like this conclusion , but they embraced it with passionate enthusiasm .
but there is another more persuasive argument : while economic stagnation can fuel voters ’ entry into populist camps , economic conditions are not necessary and sufficient to suffer .
on the contrary , princeton political scientist stuart mueller has proposed in his new book : populism is a “ shadow ” that is “ never out of touch . ”
populism is not the essence of taxation ( or employment or income equality ) .
its essence is representation – and who will speak to the people .
proponents of democracy are often ridiculed as 唱赞歌 .
abraham lincoln , for example , has proposed “ government , by the people , the people , and the people . ”
but modern representative democracy – or any democracy – is inevitably in the short run .
four years after the election , a candidate who campaigned on partisan machines is hard to think about abraham lincoln ’ s words .
as mill put it , the goal of populism is to achieve the broken promises of democracy that italy ’ s democratic theorist 波 比奥 calls the broken promises of democracy , “ just like people can agree on consensus . ”
as if they were a man , it is as if people elect the right representatives to make the fate of their destiny in their hands .
populism is based on a toxic triad : denial of complexity , pluralism , and distortion .
most of us believe that social choice is complex , and there is a natural and reasonable view of future measures .
but populists deny this .
as ralph 伦多夫 once said , populism is simple ; democracy is complex .
in the populist view , only one is right – the perception of people .
if so , the complex mechanisms of liberal democracy and its emphasis on delegation and representation are unnecessary .
the parliament does not need endless debate : a unified will can easily be expressed in a single vote .
so populists are keen on plebiscites .
brexit , remember ?
not just anyone can represent the people .
they advocate absolute representation .
remember trump ’ s boast in the republican national convention : “ i alone can fix it . ”
politics is always about morality , aristotle told us .
but populists favor what mueller calls a particular political ethic .
those who are right about the world are moral ; everyone else is corrupt and corrupt .
this is precisely what hugo chávez , venezuela ’ s ruler , promoted .
after his failure , he was expected to push the country ’ s economy into an american imperialism .
the truth is that we are against them .
from this perspective , populism is not an effective corrective to democracy and an effective corrective to democracy , as marine le pen , rafael correa , recep tayyip erdoğan , or various western intellectuals want you to believe .
on the contrary , it is intrinsically anti-democratic , so it can threaten democracy itself .
so what is to be done ?
my prescription ( not mueller ’ s , but my ) is that democrats must ( and can ) beat populists in areas where they excel .
the toxic triad can be translated into beneficial elements .
first , the complexity of the situation must be acknowledged .
only one thing to do with voters , like being deceived , is the same thing as to their children .
people living in hard life must know that the world is complex .
they don ’ t mind it .
they were adults , and they should be talking with adults .
second , don ’ t treat many ideas and identities as technical issues that need to be addressed .
on the contrary , respecting these diversity is a moral feature of social morality .
in fact , we are not exactly the same as we can live with a great democracy .
we should promote it vigorously .

the new socialism of fools
berkeley – according to mainstream economic theory , globalization will “ make all boats breakfast , ” and there is little impact on broad income distribution .
but “ globalization ” is not just an import barrier to the elimination of tariffs and other 生产商 producers with rent-seeking advantages .
as harvard economist dani rodrik frequently points out , economic theory predicts that the elimination of tariffs and non-tariff barriers does bring net benefits ; but it would also create a massive redistribution of barriers , which would eliminate the relative benefits of smaller barriers .
globalization , for its purposes , is different .
it should be understood as a process , and , in the process , technological advances that reduce the cost of transportation and communications make the world increasingly interconnected .
to be sure , this form of globalization has enabled foreign producers to export goods and services to distant markets .
but it also opens up export markets for the other side , lowering costs .
in the end , consumers have bought more and less before .
according to standard economic theory , redistribution will occur only if the inputs needed for a country ’ s exports are vastly different from their imports .
but there is no such difference in today ’ s global economy .
in the us , the financial balance of financial balances means that more americans are engaged in construction workers , capital-goods producers , and nurses , as well as health aides and family health aides .
likewise , the surplus of services means more americans than in 钢筋 大厦 ( and 高薪 ) advisory work , as well as 门卫 and cleaners .
meanwhile , the manufacturing deficit could create more overseas manufacturing jobs for countries with relatively low labor costs ; but it did not destroy much employment , because us manufacturing is already a highly capital-intensive industry .
as stanford university economist robert hall has been emphasizing for three decades , in the us , there is more than the number of workers who produce cars .
the us imports from abroad to import relatively unskilled labor , but they do not displace much of america ’ s unskilled labor force .
as a result , at least in theory , us employment shifts from manufacturing to construction , services , and nursing industries may have some impact on overall income distribution of gender , but not for class income distribution .
so why is there so much resistance to globalization in the twenty-first century ?
i see four reasons .
first and foremost , it is easy for politicians to blame the country ’ s problems on foreigners and migrants who do not vote .
in 1890 , the habsburg empire of the habsburg empire blamed the economic ills on the jewish people as a famous observation : the austrian dissident · 维特 famously observed that “ Der growth will rise to an anemic level of growth , ” the anti-semitism of anti-semitism .
the same is true of anti-globalization today .
people want a simple narrative to explain why they have not lived up to the prosperity that they once promised , and why the gap between the rich and the rest of the rich and others is widening .
third , china ’ s economic rise coincided with the global north ’ s struggle to achieve full employment .
contrary to hayek ’ s followers and andrew mellon , the economic rebalancing ( readjustments ) did not occur in a bankruptcy that has forced labor and capital out of low productivity , low demand in sectors that have driven labor and capital to high productivity , and to high demand .
thus , neoliberalism requires not only openness and competition , global change , and price stability .
it relies on full employment and almost constant prosperity , just as economists john maynard keynes warned in the 1920s and 1930s .
in recent decades , the neoliberal order has failed to deliver any of its conditions , most likely because , even the best politicians are in power , they can not achieve these conditions .
fourth , policymakers have failed to compensate for this failure with more radical social policies and economic and geographic redistribution .
us president donald trump ’ s recent telling northern yorkers that they should leave the region to find jobs elsewhere , simply in the past generation of politicians in the north .
the global north ’ s current political and economic woes are not very different from the 1920s and 1930s .
as keynes pointed out at the time , the key is to create and maintain full employment , so that most other problems can be solved .
and the austro-hungarian economist karl polanyi argued that the role of protecting the social economy ’ s rights is the government ’ s role .
people believe that they have a right to live in a healthy society , with stable jobs , with a decent income that increases over time .
but these presumed rights are not property rights and natural-resource rights – the currency of neoliberalism – in the sense of the new liberalism .
the global financial crisis and the “ great recession ” in the global north have been over for ten years .
governments still have not repaired the damage caused by these events .
if they do not , the “ XX ” of fools will continue to wreak havoc in the coming decades .

global cooperation as a life-and-death issue
london – the uncertainty generated by the united kingdom ’ s recent vote to leave the european union has hit global markets , and has been dominated by headlines .
but when we prepare for new political tests , we must not lose sight of the challenges that we have faced , especially the global health challenges posed by the rise in antimicrobial resistance , which is marked by economic efficiency and political stability .
as it stands , some 700,000 people die each year from drug-resistant infections .
by 2050 , the data could rise to 10 million per year , costing the world ’ s world gdp worth $ 100 trillion .
to avoid such an outcome , the review on amr , which i led in may , announced a strategy for responding to these infections , ensuring that the necessary new antibiotic development and a more effective approach to human health and agricultural production have been proposed .
four of the ten interventions we propose are particularly important :
· launch a global campaign against different regions in order to raise awareness of the amr problem .
· the market failure to provide a one-time market-entry reward for the development of new antibiotics in research and development for successful new drugs , while ensuring that the global level of research and development is fully available to research and development .
· advance innovation and improve the application of diagnostic technologies to support the efficient use of antibiotics .
· implement country-level targets aimed at reducing unnecessary use of antibiotics in agriculture and human health .
with the final report completed , commentary will continue to urge international political leaders to act directly .
for example , as chairman of the review , i recently convened the world health assembly in geneva to discuss our advice at the united nations and us policymakers in new york and washington .
in these discussions , it is remarkable that policymakers have become increasingly aware of the dangers of amr .
just two years ago , the topic of drug-resistant infections was often met with “ what is amr , ” or “ why should finance minister be responsible for a health crisis ? ”
few understood the scale and multifaceted nature of this challenge ; and the need for a comprehensive approach .
i asked me a similar question when british prime minister david cameron first invited me to lead the amr review .
the situation has changed considerably since then .
policymakers in countries with diverse economies and political institutions are engaging in the amr problem , with some countries already taking targeted steps .
all of this brings hope to people , who may start to initiate real change in 2016 .
but hope is one thing ; action is very different .
while the high-level meeting of the bacteria ’ s amr raises the right spirit , we can not succeed in translating the current momentum into concrete action if the united nations summit in two countries , from the united nations summit in september to the united nations summit , began with the united nations summit in september .
while recent discussions suggest that such meetings are likely to reach a deal , such an agreement would be uncertain .
at the g-20 summit , the necessary agreement should aim to develop a global mechanism for a new global market for affordable , accessible new antibiotics .
the un ’ s goal should be to implement the slogan “ access , not glut , ” to sign a deal to reduce unnecessary use of antibiotics , and launch a global campaign campaign .
investing more money in new antibiotics and diagnostics is also vital to tackling amr .
crucially , the agreement must have teeth .
for starters , tackling amr should be incorporated into broader economic-development strategies , including by implementing the un sustainable development goals .
and progress on targets should be measured regularly , not only for policymakers , companies , and health-care systems , but also by other countries .
to do that , we may need new metrics for calculating the impact of amr .
although it sounds technical ( and that is true ) , the reality is that the most prominent amr problem is to identify a common indicator that can alter countries ’ approaches to their own goals and make us better measured in the coming years .
finally , to prevent changes in political objectives and figures , we need to set the same advocates in the fight against amr .
for example , a united nations envoy to amr could be appointed to make the case for sustained propaganda , and to monitor the importance of countries to do their part .
without a coherent reminder of the rise in amr , let alone timely progress , the world is likely to be disrupted by other problems , and thus will miss the opportunity to push the necessary reforms to prevent drug-resistant infections from rising .
over the last few years , governments , businesses , and international organizations have made significant progress in dealing with amr .
but now we need to make real decisions .
if the slow-motion car crash that is to be avoided is to be avoided , our leaders must take action quickly .
we know what should be done ; now we must get there .
tackling amr with the imf
london – this month marks the first anniversary of the united nations high-level meeting on antimicrobial resistance ( amr ) , which the united kingdom ’ s independent review on amr helped to organize .
because i am chairman of amr , i was also because of my team and the united kingdom ’ s health minister , davis davies .
last year ’ s high-level meeting , the member states ’ representatives will convene again in two years to assess progress – and thus in september 2018 .
the conference also called for an interagency coordination group to guide efforts to contain amr in two years .
the group was convened by a group of highly committed people .
more broadly , policymakers at the national and international levels are starting to focus more on the threat of amr .
indeed , after the un high-level meeting , the g20 has made lofty efforts to curb amr .
at the g20 ’ s summit in hamburg in july , governments agreed to establish a “ r & d partnership , ” and to phase out the use of antibiotics to use antibiotics in agriculture .
the united kingdom ’ s review on amr recommended an additional $ 2 billion in early-stage research on amr , so the effort to establish a r & d center is a welcome welcome .
but the agreement to limit the use of antibiotics in agriculture is even more significant .
in the past , the g20 ’ s major members rejected such commitments .
and , in a document based on the un high-level meeting , agriculture has not been mentioned , owing to fears that the final agreement was stillborn .
the pace of the un and the g20 is encouraging .
but the fight against amr is far from over .
looking ahead , one of the biggest challenges lies in individual countries and multilateral organizations , such as the un itself .
how can we determine whether governments and institutions follow through on their lofty declarations ?
first , we can look at the intersection of economics and public health .
in my view , the international monetary fund should lead the way .
the research that peter 桑兹 and his colleagues published in the lancet in may 2016 shows that outbreaks of infectious diseases produce enormous economic costs , but they are seldom considered to account for the macroeconomic risk .
the imf has already had regular assessments of the country ’ s economic health , and financial markets ’ analysis is high .
for economic health , too , the imf can make excellent performance in tracking progress on amr .
more than a decade ago , the eu announced that it would prohibit the use of antibiotics for livestock growth .
but , beyond the occasional investigation of journalists ’ attention , who really has to do the same , and to investigate the progress of the member states ?
in the united kingdom , my colleagues from amr and the government reactions raised by our advice have been deep , especially in reducing prescriptions for antibiotics , preventing 住院 infections , and limiting antibiotic use in agriculture to 毫克 牲畜 .
over the past year , i have spoken publicly about the threats of amr in several british universities .
i have been encouraged to meet with academic researchers who are more subject to the problem than in the past .
but , by asking audiences , i realized that few people understand the government ’ s policy response .
this may be just because my audiences don ’ t know ; but i doubt it .
more likely , the government has failed to deliver on its promises .
the imf is ideally positioned to solve the problem as part of its conventional economic assessment .
its economic analysis is far less valuable for a richer country , and in these countries , preventing outbreaks of infectious diseases can boost long-term economic growth .
at a anniversary of the first anniversary of the un high-level meeting , my last concern is that policymakers still have not approved a market-entry reward for encouraging the development of new drugs and diagnostics .
these innovations will be crucial to preventing and discovery amr , and incentives to stimulate these innovations are increasingly viewed as the right way .
here , too , the imf can provide valuable advice .
the social science of medicine
davos – when i was a medical student in the 1980 ’ s , i was in my 新几内亚 巴布亚 .
this is a terrible experience .
my temperature soared , and was anemic .
but i eat the medicine and got it right .
this is not a pleasant experience , but thanks to cheap and cheap malaria , i have never been in danger .
the pills i cured – chloroquine is no longer useful today .
even when i took them , the parasite ’ s many parts of the world have already had resistance to chloroquine .
now , chloroquine has basically disappeared from our medical lists .
the growing resistance to antibiotics and other antimicrobial drugs is becoming the biggest crisis in contemporary health care – a crisis that can not be solved by science alone .
other drugs are following chloroquine ’ s wake .
multi-drug-resistant strains of tuberculosis , e. coli , and salmonella are already commonplace .
superbugs like the 甲氧 aureus ( mrsa ) and 艰难 aureus ( mrsa ) and hard times are proliferating .
in india , antibiotic-resistant infections killed more than 58,000 newborns in 2013 .
today , malaria is often used by artemisinin ( a drug that china uses as a whole ) and other antimalarial drugs .
but these revolutionary drugs are most likely to go to the end of chloroquine ; resistant strains of malaria have been recorded in southeast asia .
this is not just a medical problem ; it is a potential economic disaster .
according to the economist jim o ’ neill , if current trends continue , drug-resistant infectious diseases will kill more than 100 million people in 2050 , costing the global economy $ 10 billion over the next 35 years .
even such a serious prediction could significantly underestimate the situation , because it includes the immediate loss of the lives and wellbeing of the disease .
cancer patients receiving chemotherapy are designed to suppress bacteria that would otherwise destroy their weakened immune systems .
many surgical units that are now viewed as routine means , including joint replacements and caesarean sections , can be implemented only if antibiotics are preventable .
the origins of drug resistance are well known .
if pathogens are exposed to the pressure of selective toxicity , they eventually adapt to this drug .
the wellcome trust , which i am managing , has invested hundreds of millions of dollars to study these mechanisms , improve diagnoses , and create new drugs .
to address the problem effectively , this effort must be extended beyond the realm of science , and entry into areas traditionally associated with medicine .
in rich and poor countries alike , we are systematically abused .
the key to countering resistance is to delay the pathogen ’ s adaptation .
but , given the failure to perform the necessary courses of antibiotics , we are making the bacteria just the same kind of 药量 that can encourage resistance .
as a result , we actually help germs in the form of drugs that we hope to fight against them .
that is because we have always seen antibiotics almost entirely as consumer goods – we ask physicians to give us a prescription , and take steps when we feel appropriate .
even the most knowledgeable patients do not make such excellent medicines .
the uk study found that even those who know how drug resistance can develop , and often use antibiotics or to give their medicines to family members , exacerbate the problem of resistance .
changing this disruptive behavior requires a better understanding of the social and cultural factors that underlie it .
disciplines like history , psychology , sociology , anthropology , economics , market research , and social marketing can help .
this is not just the case with antimicrobial resistance .
the same is true of outbreaks like ebola .
fighting the virus requires us to understand the biology of the virus , the infectious diseases that transmit them , and the drugs and vaccines that can be used to combat it .
but it also requires understanding the behavior that makes infectious diseases endemic in liberia , sierra leone , and guinea .
explaining why these societies are so vulnerable requires understanding the region ’ s recent history and understanding why people there are deeply distrustful of public authorities .
while patient segregation and infant security can contain the key to ebola , the implementation of the two measures will require cultural sensitivity – not just the scientific explanation behind them .
today ’ s great public-health threats have far-reaching economic consequences .
science provides powerful tools .
but we need more than science to use these tools effectively .
what is the battle against amr ?
london – to commemorate the second anniversary of the british government ’ s review on antimicrobial resistance ( amr ) , which i had had the right time to assess the group ’ s mandate , i was published with two other 成员 成员 , the group ’ s two other members .
in this book , we discussed the group ’ s ten original interventions – which i call the ten “ ten commandments ” – while considering what progress has been made , and what remains to be done .
the first part of the new book specifies that we understand bacteria and drug resistance , and point to evidence that drug resistance is now likely to be much faster than we might expect .
for example , colistin , who is widely viewed as the last available antibiotics after the failure of other data fails , is rapidly losing its 失效 , owing to excessive use of animals .
equally disturbing is the increasing frequency of drug-resistant strains of gonorrhea .
in assessing the report , we predict that if current trends are allowed to continue , there will be some 10 million deaths per year by 2050 , costing about $ 100 trillion worth of damage from the 2015 global economic output .
but there is now reason to fear that the situation may turn out to be worse .
to avoid this scenario , the second part of the book focuses on solutions , and together the assessment of many experts ’ opinions .
progress has been made on two of the three “ supply ” interventions recommended by our recommended interventions .
first , funding for early-stage research and development is increasing .
until recently , the 英中 and the wellcome trust , the wellcome trust , the united states ’ biomedical advanced research and development authority , and denmark ’ s pharmaceutical company have created new funding packages .
if such support is sustained , the assessment that the panel ’ s recommendations will increase $ 2 billion over the next five years is feasible .
second , the number of researchers focused on amr seems to be increasing .
indeed , i like to joke that in northern england , the research center for amr is now more likely than the city ’ s northern powerhouse , which is now likely to agree on devolution .
the progress made in these two regions has enabled me to make similar progress elsewhere .
but further progress will require less talk of government and industry leaders and more action .
this is especially true of the pharmaceutical industry – the target of the third supply-side intervention that we have proposed .
instead of focusing solely on short-term profits , the pharmaceutical industry must invest more in r & d and produce new treatments .
i know that representatives of the top 25 biggest pharmaceutical companies around the world met at the world economic forum ’ s annual meeting in davos this year to discuss amr and agree to the problem .
in other words , they agreed to do nothing .
the industry ’ s lofty rhetoric is becoming increasingly frustrating to any concrete action .
this 25 largest pharmaceutical companies could easily persuade major governments to evaluate the market ’ s recommendations for market-entry rewards .
as long as the $ 1 billion prize in new treatments for amr or a larger grant for amr can lead to more companies to start exploring .
this also suggests that governments need to act further .
in assessing the group ’ s efforts , the review on amr will finally be incorporated into the g20 ’ s agenda in hangzhou , china , in 2016 and last year ’ s summit in hamburg , germany .
this year ’ s g20 summit will be held in buenos aires in argentina , and we can only hope that world leaders will begin to fulfill their commitments in the last few years , especially to establish a market-entry prize .
two years ago , we had asked western countries to begin demanding quick fixes to all amr prescriptions by 2020 .
as a result , no government welcomed such ideas .
but unless health systems do better to implement effective diagnostic methods , we can not reduce unnecessary antibiotic use and ensure effective treatment for patients with real demand .
as a result , innovations in diagnostic methods should be incorporated into the 奖 .
some progress has been made to improve public awareness , improve sanitation , and improve regulation , and dramatically reduce the use of antibiotics in agriculture – but not enough .
the world bank , the world health organization , and the international monetary fund need to be exposed to countries that do not invest in their health-care systems .
the united nations needs to follow the targets outlined at the high-level meeting on amr in september 2016 .
this means taking steps to strengthen regulation and monitor compliance , and urge the un ’ s 193 member states to implement the “ same health ” national action plan agreed in 2015 .
in agriculture , some major western food producers and distributors have made it clear that the plan for amr is possible .
to that end , they should agree to start labeling their meat and fish products to make clear that antibiotics are used in the production process ; and they should refuse to purchase or sell for any products that use colistin .
defeating the amr threat is entirely possible .
but confronting the challenge requires us to turn words into action .
as long as the comfort zone is taken now , we can avoid worse conditions in the coming years .
the seed treaty at odds
stanford – in september , the united states ratified the international treaty on genetic resources for food and agriculture , which also called the international seed treaty .
like many international agreements under the auspices of the un , the agreement has serious problems .
in fact , the seed treaty can be said to be a political right , but not a failed treaty against technology .
to be sure , the treaty concluded in 2004 was intended to be laudable .
but it has turned into a 一堆 hope , and has translated into harsh legal constraints on the exchange of genetic resources ( mainly seed ) among countries .
the ctbt ’ s formal statement reflects the treaty ’ s unreal : “ the benefits of protecting and using genetic resources for all food and agriculture plants , and the benefits of the adoption of the convention on biodiversity and food security , and the long-term lasting durability of agriculture and food security . ”
in short , the guiding principle of the treaty is that genetic resources belong to the “ sovereign right ” of member states .
this would amount to a clear denial of the long-term explanation of the “ common heritage of human beings . ”
it violates the idea that some of the global resources deemed beneficial for all people should not be exploited and monopolized by individuals , states , businesses , or other entities , and past wisdom is that these resources should be managed in ways that benefit all people .
the seed treaty was driven by fear of “ biopiracy ” – the 偷盗 of the world ’ s genetic resources , which would then demand patents and exercise monopoly control .
but while charges of biopiracy may be in some of the mood for some , a fair analysis shows that such an approach does not exist .
in fact , biopiracy is rare – and thus can be addressed directly .
instead , the world has created a complex , bureaucratic , politicized system that imposes limits on scientific research , plant breeding , and intellectual property creation .
the seed treaty achieves this by establishing multilateral systems that restrict access to agricultural genetic resources .
the seed treaty ’ s signatories and secretariat also control 15 studies of the international agricultural research consultative group ( cgiar ) , which has global influence .
the same rules are not much helpful .
unfortunately , as the seed treaty , countries treated their country ’ s genetic resources with a dog to highlight the obstacles : even in their own scientists and plant breeding , most international genetic resources have been stagnant in the last twelve years .
the international consultation panel for international agriculture can continue to exchange the genetic resources , but it is now much more complicated and demanding than the seed treaty before the seed treaty entered into force .
the precise impact of the seed treaty on the us is difficult to estimate , especially because the treaty contains the 空泛 and vague wording of its meaning and rules .
what is clear is that the experience of the treaty is not particularly positive , unless they are highly tolerant of bureaucratic regulatory regimes that stifle innovation and development in the name of lofty goals .
the seed treaty is similar to the same anti-capitalist , anti-science , 的 convention on biodiversity .
it also mirrors the flagrantly unscientific and 遗传工程 cartagena protocol , the cbd .
moreover , it has much in common with a 样板 model of compensation and supplementary compensation for the cartagena protocol in cartagena , which , in addition to intimidating potential entrepreneurs from agricultural biotechnology , has little to do with the agricultural biotechnology techniques .
the agreement stipulates excessive , complex , and chaotic – in short , the innovation that can benefit the world ’ s poor .
the seed treaty violates science , agricultural development , and intellectual property .
this is the equivalent of a 一记 臭球 in policymaking .
the us senate , which ratified the seeds of the seed treaty , should reconsider the treaty ’ s article 32 .
since then , the us state department should inform the treaty ’ s secretariat , and would be formally withdrawn a year later .
donald trump , the author of the art of trading , has promised to americans that he would repeal unwise decisions .
the withdrawal of the seed treaty from the seed treaty would be a good choice .
