market monopolies and antitrust antitrust
london – this year ’ s world economic forum annual meeting in davos comes at a moment of confusion among the world ’ s economic and financial elites .
despite the global economy ’ s recent performance , voters are still rebelling against them .
despite some well-known challenges and weaknesses , the economic good news has proliferated in recent years .
since 2009 , with globalization and technological progress , global per capita gdp grew by 2.5 % per year – lower than before the great recession , but historically high levels .
over the last 35 years , the share of people living in poverty worldwide has dropped from 40 % to just 10 % .
perhaps the biggest grievance in the past year comes from inequality .
but , globally , inequality is falling .
and , while inequality has increased within some advanced economies , the increase is not particularly dramatic , and it remains reasonable .
according to the latest transition report by the european bank for reconstruction and development ( ebrd ) – a period based on the world bank and the ebrd ( which i am chief economist ) – people feel far more unequal than the realities outlined in formal data ( often based on household surveys ) .
in the 34 countries where households are surveyed , most of the respondents surveyed believe that inequality has increased in the last few years .
but official data show that the gini coefficient ( standard measure of inequality ) is only small , with inequality falling in most countries .
one might think that when data and feeling conflict , the data always have data .
but , in this case , it is the data that are wrong – or , more accurately , that we use the wrong data .
unlike ordinary citizens who see the homeless in the streets and the billionaire who are in the news , a household survey that is based on inequality indicators is not enough to cover the top and the bottom of the income distribution .
another data compiled by the french economist thomas piketty may provide a more accurate picture of today ’ s inequality : tax records .
these data suggest that income growth for the super-rich has lately far outpaced the rest of the population .
philippe 阿吉翁 , the harvard university de france and the college de france de france , and his co-authors have confirmed this finding , arguing that while inequality among the bottom 99 % of rich countries has not increased , the top 1 % are already in place .
as piketty and others point out , concentration of wealth at the top is likely to be dangerous .
if the political system is weak , wealthy tycoons can use money “ captured ” government officials to tilt economic regulation to them .
with the newly acquired comparative advantage , they can accumulate inappropriate profits and reinvest their ill-gotten assets into capturing more unfair rents .
the concentration of wealth will be difficult to control , and over time , smaller entrepreneurs will be crowded out .
of course , in a country where political systems are strong enough , even the super-rich can not distort the rules of the game .
in this context , those who can accumulate the most wealth are those most talented and lucky entrepreneurs who are rewarded for driving innovation and growth benefiting the entire economy .
unfortunately , in the ebrd ’ s 36 member countries , political systems are not strong enough .
this is reflected in the fact that commodities and natural resources comprise most billionaires in the ebrd countries , which suggests that resource rents are not just available , but also that they are not taxed adequately .
clearly , the unfair political influence of the super-rich is needed .
most directly , this means making political contributions more transparent , more intrusive , and effective .
but it also means removing the use of media to manipulate politics for themselves .
as zingales zingales pointed out in 2012 , oligarchs could use media ownership to consolidate their political status , using political status to ensure rents and use the rents to fund the media .
former italian prime minister silvio berlusconi , zingales argues , was a factor in this regard .
but many oligarchs in the former communist countries are doing the same thing .
some oligarchs would say that they have the media better than the government , at least they are competing with other oligarchs .
this is nonsense .
yes , media ownership is dangerous to make a kleptocratic or authoritarian government access to media .
but it is equally dangerous for oligarchs who can collude with one another to protect their collective interests – their interests may be very different from the rest of society .
the media are the cornerstone of modern democracy .
as a result , media ownership should be transparent , and , ideally , media owners should prohibit possession of other assets .
of course , such an antitrust policy would face significant political resistance .
and even if this policy is implemented , tycoons will continue to work on the media by , say , 定价 advertising contracts .
and , in some ways , some media may welcome oligarchic subsidies as a way to meet the challenges that traditional business models face .
addressing these issues requires a strong independent regulatory authority .
at the same time , transparent and politicized public subsidies can help support the social wealth of honest news media .
implementing an effective media antitrust framework will not be easy .
but this is still more difficult than ever to lose faith in democracy and open markets .

a path through europe ’ s minefield
london – earlier this week , nearly 100 european celebrities sent a letter to the leaders of all 17 member states in the eurozone .
the letter directly expressed the point of saying that europe ’ s leaders seem to have known what they know : no longer the use of “ 拖字 . ”
indeed , europe ’ s banking problems and sovereign-debt problems are mutually reinforcing .
the fall in the price of government bonds exposes the banks ’ capital shortfalls , while the government ’ s prospect of financing bank recapitalization has boosted the risk premium on government bonds .
now that the price of bank shares is less than book value , raising new capital will give banks a means to reduce their balance sheets by cutting credit lines and reducing their loan portfolios .
europe ’ s leaders are considering the response , and their next step will determine europe ’ s fate – or let the market resume calm or push markets toward new extremes .
everyone agrees that greece needs an orderly restructuring , because a disorderly default could derail the eurozone .
but , when things are involved , i suspect that eurozone leaders are considering implementing some inappropriate measures .
specifically , they are talking about recapitalizing the banking system , rather than guaranteeing the banks .
moreover , they are prepared to do so at the national level , not at the eurozone level .
this is understandable : germans are reluctant to pay for the recapitalization of french banks .
but , with german chancellor angela merkel ’ s inherent rationale for insisting on it , it is inevitable .
let me explain how to do so in a 密集 minefield .
the banking system needs to be guaranteed first , and then recapitalized .
governments can not afford to recapitalize the costs now , providing insufficient funding to address sovereign-debt problems .
it is far less costly to recapitalize banks after the crisis , government bonds , and bank shares returned to normal levels .
but the government has the power to tax it , so it can provide credible guarantees .
the eurozone needs a new , legally binding agreement – not attempting to change the treaty of lisbon , which is too many – to mobilize this power , and the new treaty ’ s consultation and approval will take time .
but , during this period , governments could demand that the ecb act – the european central bank ’ s share of the total guaranteed by eurozone members .
in exchange for guarantees , the eurozone ’ s major banks must agree to accept the ecb ’ s guidance .
this demand is radical , but it is now in the context of the environment .
the ecb has embraced member states ’ mandates , with enough persuasive advice : it can shut down the discounted window for banks , and governments can sanction financial institutions that refuse cooperation .
then there is the ecb ’ s request for banks to maintain credit lines and loan portfolios , while strictly monitoring the risk of bank accounts .
this would eliminate one of the two main drivers of current market turmoil .
the european central bank will also be able to deal with another dynamic : the lack of financing for sovereign debt is to reduce the discount rate , encourage distressed governments to issue debt , and encourage banks to bank subscriptions .
these bonds can sell to the ecb at any time , in exchange for cash ; but , as long as their yields exceed the ecb ’ s deposits , banks hold a profit .
during the emergency , governments can borrow at very low cost at very low cost , and the ecb would not violate article 123 of the treaty of lisbon .
such measures would be enough to calm markets and pull the crisis out of emergency .
recapitalization of the bank will not wait until then ; only greece ’ s debt restructuring will need to be filled quickly .
according to germany ’ s request , the additional capital comes from the market , and then from national governments , and the financial stability facility in europe will be in the last , so it will not be wasted .
the new eurozone agreement , negotiated in a calmer fashion , can not only act in an emergency period , but also a foundation for economic growth .
a peace agenda for global development
monrovia – this week , the 27 members of the high-level panel on the post-2015 development agenda will gather in monrovia , liberia , for un secretary-general ban ki-moon .
at the meeting , the panel will establish a vision of a “ bold and realistic ” vision of joint development .
the discussion was shaped by liberian president ellen johnson , indonesian president susilo bambang yudhoyono , and british prime minister david cameron , where the sahel and the great lakes region were still plagued by violence and conflict .
indeed , mass displacement and deep human suffering are occurring in many african countries ( not to mention syria and elsewhere ) , threatening the continent ’ s unprecedented economic progress over the past decade .
the group ( as one of my members ) must seize the opportunity of the monrovia meeting to show a global development agenda that addresses the vicious cycle of conflict and poverty that undermines economic activity and undermines human wellbeing .
for more than a decade , the un millennium development goals ( which expire in two years ) provide the framework for international development cooperation , focusing on combating poverty worldwide .
in developing new comprehensive catch-up agendas , global leaders must recognize that the millennium development goals have left millions of people out of illiteracy , disease , and hunger , and the impact of the millennium development goals has not yet been shown , particularly in countries divided by fragmented and conservative conflicts .
the world bank data show that no conflict has reached a single millennium development goal , suggesting that this arrangement can not be addressed effectively by the problems that organized violence and lack of security .
that is why the post-2015 agenda must be centered on a fear of peace , security , and freedom from fear .
it should aim to bring justice and prosperity to every point .
it should reflect a belief that without peace , without development , without peace , peace and sustainable development can not be sustained without respect for human rights and the rule of law .
moreover , the monrovia meeting ’ s theme , “ the national building base , ” notes that the post-2015 global development project should emphasize support for national measures , in order to achieve strong , stable , and long-term prosperity .
strategies that help countries to overcome domestic insecurity and conflict , achieve economic transformation , and full development of their potential include strengthening governance systems and the rule of law , ensuring participation , and ensuring that all citizens can equal equal access to justice .
international support for this effort means giving african leaders and stakeholders the opportunity to beat behind , stimulate prosperity , and create responsibilities .
moreover , while eliminating poverty is still one of the point after 2015 , the focus must shift from national averages to local disparities .
measures must go beyond overall social needs to spur progress in productive employment creation and income formation .
conflict-affected countries must work hard to promote reconciliation and prevent violence .
in recent years , liberia has made success in post-conflict reconstruction and human development ( the country ’ s previous civil war ) , so it is a fitting setting for the development agenda .
since 2003 , domestic vision and commitment have been accompanied by international support , enabling liberia to hold democratic elections , rebuild basic public services , reestablish public finances , and make progress in addressing local corruption , rebuilding public institutions , and reviving national infrastructure .
the panel should use liberia to ensure sustained efforts to secure peace , maintain stability , and guide economic and social transformation as a blueprint for successful post-conflict transformation .
other inspiring models are rwanda , mozambique , and sierra leone .
the panel will work to create a bold , clear , and feasible agenda for sustainable development .
the process will be open , inclusive , transparent , and consider the views and experiences of experts and stakeholders representing young people , women , the elderly , the disabled , and the authorities .
the group will also take advantage of comprehensive online and offline efforts to interact with the people of the world , take insights into what they see as the future of their eyes .
their view will broaden the group ’ s vision , helping to develop an agenda that addresses the priorities they perceive .
in a world of conservative conflict , development efforts are inadequate .
the post-2015 global development agenda must take a comprehensive perspective with the elimination of efforts to eradicate poverty , together with the economic transformation that helps to build peace .
that way , global leaders will begin to lay the foundations for prosperity , justice , and sustainable development worldwide .
the asian paradox
seoul – as the asia-pacific economic cooperation forum comprises 54 % of global gdp and 44 % of world trade , the agenda for this month ’ s apec summit will cause global attention .
but the only question that everyone has asked is whether chinese president xi jinping and japanese prime minister shinzo abe will meet on the sidelines of the sidelines , with a substantive discussion that will ease bilateral tensions if they meet .
this is not entirely unreasonable , of course , because both countries are critical to shaping the future of east asia .
indeed , the uncertainty about whether two key leaders of apec will be communicated underscores the grim reality of asia ’ s international relations today .
the so-called “ asian century ” is plagued by a paradox : deep economic interdependence can not alleviate strategic mistrust .
recently , sino-japanese relations have deteriorated – a trend that has intensified since japan ’ s purchases of the senkaku islands ( diaoyu from the diaoyu islands ) in japan to prevent japanese nationalists from controlling the islands .
a meeting between abe and xi – for the first time since taking office – will give greater hope .
the japanese government has made a significant diplomatic effort to arrange a meeting , and former prime minister yasuo fukuda visited beijing in july to ease tensions .
according to some media reports , to ensure that china agreed to participate in a meeting at the apec summit , abe would even be willing to acknowledge japan ’ s claim to the senkaku islands .
such a move would mean that china ’ s claim to the senkaku islands may have some legitimacy , so it is not irrelevant ; it may even mean that abe would agree to restore the state of the past .
if that is true , one hopes that xi will follow deng xiaoping ’ s counsel , putting the issue “ stranded for some time , ” allowing the “ smarter ” generation to “ find ways to find acceptable solutions . ”
today , it looks like a realistic possibility .
indeed , xi ’ s recent rhetoric has softened , and the diplomatic line may be so .
for example , he allowed li 小林 , the daughter of china ’ s former president , to meet with abe to meet abe , who watched china ’ s performance in tokyo .
chinese state council premier li keqiang shook hands with abe on his recent milan meeting .
abe and xi ’ s recent display of flexibility , which may reflect changes in both countries ’ domestic politics , have created a more equal balance between conservatives , nationalist groups , and more internationally oriented commercial interests .
two leaders have been overcoming their domestic opponents and consolidating power over the last two years , and now they may have gained confidence in a compromise .
in japan , abe ’ s cabinet has satisfied conservative supporters by agreeing to expand the right to self-defense .
although there are still many objections to its new security doctrine , there is no influential political bloc capable of challenging abe ’ s approach .
now , with japan ’ s economic recovery stalled , japanese business has begun to pressure abe ’ s government to try harder to mitigate the deterioration of relations with china .
china ’ s government reports that in the first half of 2014 , japan ’ s direct investment in china fell by nearly 50 % a year in the first half of 2014 – a clear indication that japanese business leaders are worried about the future of japan ’ s second-largest market .
at the same time , in china , xi has gained considerable confidence through his massive anti-corruption campaign , with penalties for top officers indicating that he has mastered control of the pla .
as a result , xi may think that there is now more room for dealing with china ’ s economic slowdown , including by mitigating the damage caused by antagonizing japan .
if this analysis is correct , it is clear whether the next question is whether abe and xi will move toward better progress , pleasing the business community without losing support for their nationalists .
for abe , his choice is whether to cool down nationalist rhetoric and moderate his position on contentious historical issues .
this would include stopping the need to travel to the controversial yasukuni shrine , the “ comfort women ” of south korea ’ s “ comfort women , ” which gave up sexual services to the country ’ s forced service of the japanese army .
how abe will decide may depend on his confidence in his political position .

the economics of ordinary people
new haven – we are in the midst of a rising tide of popular economics : books about economics , articles , blogs , and speech are greeted with popular excitement .
i recently participated in a panel panel on this phenomenon in the united states ’ economic association .
the group ’ s members recognize this kind of contradiction : the rise of popular economics is precisely what is at odds with people ’ s distrust of professional economists , because most economists fail to foresee ( or even alert ) the greatest economic crisis since the great depression .
so why are the masses buying books written by professional economists ?
the most interesting explanation i heard is that economics is more interesting because it seems no longer a perfect and closed discipline .
if one book tells you that economic forecasts would be best left to computer models , and as a common reader , you have to have a ph.d. to hide the models , just how tedious it is .
the fact is that the public is right : while these models are more or less consistent with scientific science , they have been spectacularly wrong .
sometimes , we would be wise to close our 导航仪 instructions and think for ourselves , especially when it comes to the personal intelligence of the crisis .
in the first half of the spectrum , the agreement was agreed : popular economics has become a medium of communication with the general public – a kind of communication that reflects unprecedented significance .
after all , most economists failed to foresee the crisis because they have completely escaped the idea and actions of people in the real world .
successful popular economics will view readers or listeners as a participant .
obviously , this means that economists must be willing to embrace original theories that are not yet recognized by academics .

there is a rigorous and rigorous academic assessment mechanism for new treatments , and peer journals with high levels of professional journals .
any attempt to bypass the process to extend untested new ideas to the public is a violation of ethics .
in the decades before the crisis erupted , economists used these criteria to look at themselves and their profession , and research trends have contributed to this .
for example , when the university of chicago was invented a common computer tape that can accommodate the price of millions of shares in the 1960 ’ s , a large number of scientific research was used to validate “ efficient markets hypothesis . ”
the competitive forces that scientists find in exchange exchanges seem to force all stock prices to converge toward their true value .
as a result , any deal based on the hypothesis was regarded as either foolish or outright frauds .
science has triumphed over stock-market theory – at least for it .
but the ensuing financial crisis struck a resounding blow to overly confident scientific economists .
one explanation for this is that the economics profession has not fully understood the economic content of the economy – one that is not reducible to mathematical analysis .
and that is a small group of economists who have been warning about the current crisis : not just the literature , but also the personal judgment : gut the current situation with some historical scenarios ; and the moral objective of speculative transactions , price bubbles , and market confidence ;
these judgments come from economists who know the business community – those whose machinations , beliefs , gamesmanship , and rationalizations – are well known .
these scholars ’ views can never be published on scholarly journals or are treated like a new medical treatment .
there is no existing scientific procedure to justify these views .
of course , economics is indeed a science in many ways , and the contributions of these scholars and their computer programs are not extinguished .
but , as the economist edwin R put it in 1903 : “ economics is a social science , in other words it focuses on ethics , in other words , the science of ethics , which has different economic ethics , as well as the science of science . ”
for me , and for the rest of my term , the search for economic uncertainty is a public dialogue with the public , and that they learn from them , learn from them , and ask : are i most likely to believe that the theory is really near reality ?

a portfolio approach to climate change
the world ’ s efforts to reduce carbon emissions under the kyoto protocol have been minimal .
a huge effort to put the protocol on the kyoto treaty shows how much work will be needed to reach the next agreement that would be adopted in december 2009 .
environmental organizations call for tougher and far-reaching policies , but some countries will resist such policies in order to ensure their own economic dynamism .
a new round of negotiations would have an advantage over previous efforts , because governments now recognize the need for a portfolio in adaptation , mitigation , and research .
a new study conducted by my colleagues and i at the center for denmark ’ s copenhagen consensus has explored the effectiveness of a different response to the global challenge , but for several reasons .
we also know that the effects of climate change are not evenly performing in the world .
in some places , if changes in precipitation patterns are not negative and irrigation remains available , a slightly warmer temperature can lead to higher food production .
even if temperatures rise above 0.6 , many crops in africa and south asia are almost immediately cut , and will eventually be more vulnerable to epidemics .
these effects are clearly the biggest impact of the poorest people on the planet , despite the burden of disease , poverty , war on war , and malnutrition .
ensuring that adaptive capacity is broadened and developed is thus an important challenge for us to become .
long-term development will enhance the ability of countries to mitigate climate change for environmental and civic health , but the poorest people on the planet urgently need the help of rich populations .
our analysis has explored the benefits of a more targeted policy in the short run : for example , the bed nets for children who suffer the most from climate change , and the provision of oral cancer therapy , in order to tackle some of the marginal health effects of global warming , in order to tackle some of the fringe health effects of global warming .
such jobs will almost immediately produce benefits , but as the economy grows slowly .
even if the economy ’ s terms are improved , it is becoming increasingly important to reduce carbon emissions from the long term as climate change has become more severe .
given that the effects of climate change are observed in many parts of the world , how to reduce climate change makes sense everywhere .
but we found that the impact of mitigation alone on mitigating climate change does not meet costs .
we assumed that the annual cost of climate policy has kept pace with global gdp by 2100 , starting with annual costs of $ 18 billion .
the discounted costs incurred by fixed annual costs amounted to $ 800 billion , but the damage avoided by this approach is only $ 685 billion .
copenhagen consensus has also tested a portfolio chosen by the united nations intergovernmental panel on climate change .
we assume that research on greener technologies is $ 50 billion , and the economic costs of adapting and adapting to climate change are $ 750 billion .
reducing the cost of carbon emissions and carbon emissions has been reduced , and the tax on carbon cuts will become more effective .
as a result , research and development programs , combined with the total discounted benefits of $ 800 billion , are expected to exceed $ 2.1 trillion .
ensuring that research and development become part of the world ’ s portfolio response to climate change will make efforts to mitigate climate change more effective , and will strengthen the impact of its efforts to reduce carbon emissions significantly in the next century .
but these favorable net benefits reflect a very conservative estimate of emissions reduction and the very conservative predictions that developed countries are “ actively acting . ”
for a long time , investing in 优化组合 could raise the discounted benefits more than one-third .
if we make the potential for climate change more sensitive to climate change , we are expected to generate higher interest rates , even though it would have to be assumed that the benefits of climate change will be higher .
fighting climate change is a useful investment , though neither mitigation nor adaptation is sufficient to “ solve ” this conundrum .
to bring about change , especially in the near term , the world is working to reduce and adapt to climate change , while increasing research and development efforts to reduce carbon emissions and carbon sequestration , which in turn requires designing and exploring market-based incentives .
a post-nuclear euro-atlantic security order
washington , dc – as 2011 begins , the euro-atlantic region has become a strategic strategy for research .
over the past 20 years , the geopolitical dimension of the atlantic from the atlantic to the urals has changed .
we have seen this in the darkest days of our lifetime before the cold war ’ s darkest days , and the threat of a devastating and nuclear war in europe during the cold war ’ s era of devastating and nuclear war has been removed .
but , while things turn out to be good , two regional powers , such as the us and russia , still cling to thousands of nuclear weapons , accounting for more than 90 % of nuclear weapons worldwide .
many of these weapons remain designed or deployed in the euro-atlantic region .
a massive strategic nuclear force that is highly vulnerable to the high alert and the deployment of tactical nuclear weapons in some parts of nato and russia created the possibility of accidental , unauthorized , or mistaken launch of nuclear weapons .
so security vigilance is a top priority .
in response to this challenge , the three of us agreed on the plan for action , adopted in 2010 without treaty review conferences , and set a series of urgent but practical steps toward long-term implementation .
this includes :
· prolonging the time and timing of the launch of the nuclear ballistic-missile launch ;
· create missile defense and early-warning systems ;
· ensuring the highest safety standards for nuclear weapons and materials ;
· launch a dialogue on tactical nuclear weapons in russia , the united states , and nato ;
· launch processes that facilitate the comprehensive nuclear-test-ban treaty ;
· developing international and multilateral programs for managing the risks of civilian fuel production ;
· push for nuclear disarmament in the us and russia .
as former us secretary of state george shultz , former us secretary of defense william perry , former us secretary of state henry kissinger and the united states former us senator sam 基辛格 and the us former us senator sam nunn put it in 2007 , “ there is no way to be fully informed and desirable .
if it can not be put in place , the vision of denuclearization will not be realistic and workable . ”
perhaps the most critical step toward achieving this goal is to redouble efforts to address regional rivalries and conflicts that produce the emerging nuclear powers .
large swaths of the country from north america to europe can play a vital role in stabilizing the increasingly fragmented and fragmented international order .
these countries , however , will be able to make their own geographic regions a truly inclusive and vibrant security community that can be achieved .
otherwise ( we do not ) , the euro-atlantic countries and their organizations will be in the process of dealing with the twenty-first century ’ s security challenges , including nuclear proliferation , which is often insufficient .
recently , several heads of state , such as russia , the us president , and nato secretary general , have begun to embrace the idea of european security community and highlight the importance of shaping a stronger and more inclusive european security order .
it is time for this change , because the euro-atlantic family has entered a critical period .
on november 19 , nato ’ s heads of state have approved a new “ strategic doctrine ” that will guide the direction of organizing direction in the next decade , while russian president dmitri medvedev and his nato partners have issued joint declarations that support the common security challenge of the twenty-first century , and to determine the threat of missile defense .
two weeks later , european security and cooperation organization ( osce ) heads of state met in astana , kazakhstan , to develop the osce ’ s next phase of development .
concerted action to mitigate the nuclear threat must be a key element in the direction of a strong and stable global leadership in europe .
the real cooperation plan on missile defense will address our common threat , helping to eliminate fears that the security community has created .
similarly , europe ’ s atlantic countries can strengthen the international atomic energy agency ’ s safeguards , thereby ensuring that nuclear energy programs are not shifted to other uses , thereby creating a new mechanism for opposing the threat of nuclear terrorism , and establishing a new mechanism to protect key facilities from attack .
these efforts are essential to protect the countries ’ national-security and mitigating the nuclear threat .
implementing proposals to extend warning and decision-making time for all of the euro-atlantic region ’ s countries would add stability to the nato-russia relationship .
adjustments in the norms of strategy , tactics , and conventional forces are a step in the end of the militarized framework of the two .
if governments do want to build a stronger , more inclusive european security order , mitigating and ultimately eliminating the consequences of nuclear weapons , this is only part of what must be done .
the three are working with the leading organizations in the euro-atlantic region to develop these and other concrete steps that are essential to establishing a true security community , covering areas like economics , energy , and the environment .

where has the water gone ?
manila – we live on a parched planet .
farmers 耕作 farm pastureland , and policymakers fret over empty reservoirs , dry rivers , and cities .
and that is just the surface of the world ’ s water problem .
subterranean aquifers , which play a role in the world ’ s aquifers , are running dry .
if this continues , especially for water-stressed and fast-growing asian countries , the consequences could be dire .
subterranean aquifers are essentially water water underground , stored in deep rock , soil , and 沙砾 .
they contain roughly 100 times the amount of water they contain in the face of the earth ’ s surface , lakes , rivers , and wetlands .
if you live in central africa , south america , or some parts of europe , you can live with subterranean aquifers in several hundred feet .
surface water resources , including 脱盐 waters and recycled wastewater , are not the global gap between water supply and demand – a gap that is expected to reach 40 % between 2030 and 2030 .
as a result , subterranean aquifers are increasingly being used to supplement agriculture in urban areas , where agriculture , electricity generation , and rapid economic growth are growing daily ( about 120,000 people per day in asia ) .
today , around 30 % of global liquid freshwater comes from subterranean aquifers .
one-third of the 37 largest aquifers studied by the university of california between 2003 and 2013 were severely depleted , and they are virtually non-existent .
some of the most stressed aquifers are in the driest regions , including asia , with 88 % of the water burden in the region .
asia has a land of groundwater irrigated around one-third of the world , with india , china , and pakistan being the biggest consumers .
south asia alone accounts for half of global groundwater consumption .
on the contrary , water tables are becoming deeper and water tables are falling .
in pakistan ’ s punjab province , over-pumping of over-pumping led to a drop in groundwater levels a year ( 20 inches ) , because it is difficult to continue growing food and water security for plants like sugarcane and rice .
asia ’ s surging population – which could grow by 25 % and reach 50 billion by 2050 – will cause food , energy , and water supplies to increase further .
globally , by then , food demand will be 60 % higher than it is now , and increasingly scarce freshwater resources will be absorbed .
climate change will worsen the situation further .
but the problem is not limited to water depletion .
over-pumping of groundwater leads to soil 沉降 , causing some asian cities to sink .
by 2030 , up to 80 % of north jakarta ’ s north may be below sea levels .
some estimates indicate that parts of beijing are sinking each year .
moreover , depleted aquifers close to coastal areas are vulnerable to contamination of seawater , causing soils to become 贫瘠化 .
some aquifers are contaminated by arsenic , and arsenic occurs deep underground .
natural earth physics estimates that more than 60 % of groundwater in the ganges aquifer is contaminated or polluted by arsenic .
in bangladesh , water contaminated by arsenic is blamed for more than 40,000 deaths per year .
the first step in remedying the status quo is precisely how much groundwater is available , and how it is used – and that is not easy , but not entirely impossible .
nasa ’ s gravity recovery and climate experiment satellite provides information that results in changes in the earth ’ s gravity .
by applying 遥感技术 to river basins , we can determine how much surface surface surface and surface surface usage .
another important step is to improve the pricing of groundwater .
china has already engaged in a pilot program for the extra use of farmers ’ excess water .
similar measures have worked well in australia and mexico .
but such measures are politically difficult to implement .
the key to success is not only to help countries develop the right policies , but also to help them establish the legal frameworks needed to establish and enforce them .
the political difficulty of eliminating electricity and gas subsidies is even more difficult , with subsidies encouraging farmers to pump groundwater per day .
if such subsidies can not be eliminated , there is an alternative program for innovation that can stop over-pumping .
in gujarat , india , for example , the government controlled groundwater by adding power per day .
farmers can acquire the power they need , but they can not pump the day long .
another way is to buy surplus power from farmers and 充回 the grid .
doing so would not only reduce over-pumping , but also complement rural incomes .
efforts to replenish aquifers could also be taken .
a pilot project in uttar pradesh , india ’ s uttar pradesh state , collects excess water into the water table , injecting them into the water table .
some 80 % of wastewater is released into rivers and caused pollution .
doing so would be far simpler or politically than to protect this behavior from logic or politics .
subterranean aquifers are the reservoir of last resort .
if we protect today , our children will pay dearly – or even survival – at the cost of today .
