this political skill , together with morocco ’ s improved economy , helps the regime to weather today ’ s turbulent and future violent upheaval .
but the government must also implement the political reforms that it promised in 2011 ; relaxing its grip on the economy ; and promote inclusive growth and prosperity , including deep regional disparities .
when complacent kings and “ elected ” autocrats do not respond to popular protests , they inevitably face more bottom-up , bottom-up revolutions .
for arab countries , whether subsidized or suppressing threats , the political genie can not be restored to the bottle .
learning arab online education
dubai – education has long been the problem in the arab world , with high-quality schools lacking a shortage of skills gaps , leaving many young people ( and even university graduates ) losing their lives to their lives .
in a region plagued by conflict and chaos , addressing these problems will not be easy .
but if a bold and innovative approach is made , it can be done .
of course , there is no strategy to ensure the arab world ’ s education challenges .
the recent establishment of abdullah al ghurair ’ s education fund , which has $ 1.1 billion in capital , is an opportunity to expand its opportunity for arab youth to expand their opportunity – and cost efficiency – for all possible approaches .
the result stands out : online learning .
arab countries have made rapid progress in expanding internet access .
by 2018 , the arab world is expected to have 2.26 million internet users , which account for more than 55 % of the population – nearly 7 % higher than the global average .
but most young people use the internet for social media , not for economic or educational purposes .
in this sense , they are missing a major opportunity , especially given the great strides made in improving online learning and attractiveness .
and , contrary to popular belief , these courses are not a practical and 长达 online lecture .
instead , they contain short 视频教程 , interactions in the practice of practice , and peer assessments and peer assessments that provide valuable feedback to students .
thanks to these rapidly developed models , online learning is now a better option than traditional education .
this is encouraging news .
after all , access to education through technology technology can address some of the core issues facing arab countries ’ education systems .
the first is the sheer number of young people who need access to cheap education .
once communities have access to internet access ( the arab world ’ s growing progress on this front ) , they can be scaled up at relatively low cost , to reach millions of young people who are in school or can not access access to high-quality education institutions .
the arab world ’ s only few institutions of higher education certainly can not accommodate so many students .
and , even with this capacity , they may choose to choose .
we have seen how the region ’ s universities and universities around the world have closed their doors to refugees in syria and beyond , forcing them to overcome huge bureaucratic and financial obstacles .
the second problem is the very low quality of education currently available .
for too long , the region ’ s institutions of higher education need not be shown to provide the international quality and quality requirements that they provide .
online learning will significantly reduce the difficulty of progress , and ensure that students are able to learn useful knowledge and skills .
moreover , online learning can facilitate the introduction of innovative education and learning methods .
for example , the reduction in traditional lectures and rote learning can create space for 自学 and personalized learning and assessment tools , with several professors now using these tools on a massive open online course and other online online platforms .
third , the arab world faces the challenge of delivering continuous education services .
to adapt to today ’ s fast-changing economic environment ( that is , the use of technology makes many jobs redundant and encouraging greater specialization ) , workers everywhere must continue to upgrade and expand their skills .
as the current status quo is , only young people from the rich world have sustained continuous learning in ways that do not require their families and jobs .
open online courses can provide an enabling level of expertise to promote personal careers by creating a level playing field .
given all of this , we have created the al ghurair open teaching scholarships program , which aims to provide the world ’ s best education programs through online degrees programs .
we have developed high standards by working with mit , the leader of open online learning .
together , mit and the open teaching scholarships are set to launch two new “ 硕士 ” programs , including those that have not yet taught the so-called stem cell ( science , technology , engineering , and mathematics ) that the arab world has not yet taught .
one hopes that such programs , open to young people in the arab and other countries , will mobilize students and receive strong support from employers .
but to maximize the impact of investment , we must also change the idea of online learning , which requires a concerted effort by educational institutions and the private sector .
indeed , arab educational institutions must begin exploring the development of high-quality online programs .
for its part , the government should reconsider the position of recognition that reliable and internationally accredited institutions provide online learning .
for private actors , the key is to reward employees with degrees and certifications through online programs .
at the same time , abdullah al ghurair ’ s education fund will embark on concerted action to provide innovative stem degrees ( science , technology , engineering , and mathematics ) to the world ’ s top universities .
not doing so would allow most arab youth to be left behind .
in 1999 , leaders in jordan , morocco , bahrain , and syria died in a short period , beginning with a generational realignment , and the death of yasir arafat and the united arab emirates ’ s longtime leader , sheikh 宰德 , died .
the region ’ s population is younger than the world average , but their political leaders are older than the world average .
this process of generational displacement is likely to be a key factor in determining whether the reforms in the arab world are effective .
at the moment , four political generations in the region have a political map .
the outgoing generation of leaders – that is , arafat , king hussein , or hafez al-assad , france ’ s king , and president hosni mubarak ’ s generation – had been born until 1935 , from the 1970 ’ s to the middle east .
the generation of leaders in this generation worked in decolonization and began their careers .
they grew up in gamal abdel-nasser ’ s 阿拉伯 nationalist education , and , for them , the most important political event was the arab defeat in the 1967 arab-israeli war .
this generation sought a strong , capable arab leader with israel .
they also believe – or at least pretend – that various forms of socialism and state socialism , democracy , and civil rights are not the first to issue .
the next generation was born between 1935 and 1955 , in many ways “ transitional . ”
most of this generation has invested in economic growth and more educational opportunities for the 1970s .
at the same time , politics remains dominated by the last generation , and the last generation will never be willing to put down power .
naturally , most of the generation was dissatisfied , and many are seeking an islamic system that alternative mainstream political institutions .
the generation , however , will not decide on the next two or three decades , but it is likely to be the next generation of people born between 1955 and 1975 .
this is the generation of syria ’ s president bashar al-assad , jordan ’ s king abdullah , and morocco ’ s king muhammad vi .
some call this the “ generation of sons ” – sons of leaders who led their countries for decades .
this generation has not been influenced by the arab-israeli war or the conflict in the middle east .
instead , their political education was in the gulf war in 1991 , with the arab-israeli peace process of the 1990 ’ s , including its crisis and bust .
in addition to the leaders of syria and jordan , abu barghouti , the leader of the west bank fatah , is a representative of this generation .
the generation is more familiar with the concepts of globalization and economic reform than socialism and revolution .
beyond palestine , they have lived independently and relatively stable lives within their respective countries .
in the palestinian context , the 一代 al , a generation of the first ( first and second ) palestinian uprising , will be a cornerstone of the generation .
but the importance of generational problems in the arab world is the fourth cohort .
together , the entire three generations are just one-third of the arab population .
almost 60 % of arabs are under the age of 20 , with roughly 70 % under the age of 30 .
this raises a key question : what would happen if the current generation of people who are now in power , as mubarak , assad , and hussein , insisted on without losing power , will be in the “ baby boom ” ?
assad , king abdullah , and gamal mubarak – whose son , king abdullah , and gamal mubarak – are less coherent than the outgoing generation of leaders , is less coherent than the outgoing generation of leaders .
many of the older generation were engaged in military careers , and many of their aides and partners were engineers and civil servants .
the social community of new elites is more broadly professional .
there are also more traditional politicians : figures representing specific societies or economic interests , rather than 政治 technocrats .
the new leadership leadership is more global in many ways than its predecessors ; the average education level is higher ; and some have been given foreign degrees .
the role of women has also increased .
developments in morocco , bahrain , and jordan do seem to suggest that changing leadership can help to mitigate rigid political structures and allow more people to participate .
but generational change is not necessarily accompanied by economic reforms and political emancipation – witness north korea under kim il-sung ’ s son , kim jong-il .
indeed , from experience , there is no reason to think that a modern way of talking , the willingness to liberate the economy , and urge technology development automatically represents the democratization of democratization .
it is more true to see the new elites in the arab elite using the power of the state to eliminate the economic agenda , while consolidating the power of the 其刚 .
this is certainly not a risky road .
if there is no significant increase in opportunities for participation , including a truly competitive election , the chasm between a predominantly young population and a narrow ruling elite will deepen .
this continued political inertia will ultimately lead to an increasingly young arab population , with the appeal of extreme ideologies , while driving the most capable of seeking development elsewhere .
arab fathers and sons
the succession of succession in the arab secular republics highlights the dilemmas they face when they turn to the post-revolutionary era , because regimes that fail to create a strong system tend to trigger a systemic crisis .
while the decision to make a transition within the family may lack democracy , it is not entirely irrelevant .
to be sure , such a choice would facilitate economic modernization , end political infighting , and further political change .
the liberal movement that is being supported by the west for years to come to power in office stifles the infant , and any abrupt free election has turned into a dangerous imposition of islamist democracy .
such a democracy has led to a government led by hamas , hezbollah , or the muslim brotherhood , which inevitably inevitably fights against the west and opposes the “ peace process ” that the us championed .
syria has sought to secure the regime ’ s continuation through a hereditary succession of similar monarchies , with hafez al-assad handing the regime to his son , bashar al-assad .
there are indications that egypt will follow suit , and mubarak ’ s son , gamal , will inherit .
likewise , libya ’ s muammar el-qaddafi could also make his son 赛费尔 伊斯兰 .
as a product of a revolutionary military coup , these secular nationalist regimes failed to produce popular legitimacy , but rather to return to the dynastic succession that they overthrew .
the center of dynastic succession is to seek peace and stability , which , when hafez al-assad agreed to achieve a peace deal with unprecedented intentions .
as a few months later , he has a sense of urgency that is a sense of urgency for an agreement , so that his inexperienced son will not be pressured to fight the fight for the golan heights .
assad has remained loyal to his father ’ s legacy .
unlike the provocative nuclear strategy of north korea and iran , assad ’ s “ axis of evil ” has called for dialogue with the us , rather than making the decision to invade them , and a compromise with israel , rather than a war with it .
in egypt , mubarak ’ s failure to heed nasser ’ s revolution and his grand strategic design was a matter of stability .
as a result , he will not accept america ’ s awkward democratic agenda , but rather to occupy the stage at the center of arab diplomatic support for the annapolis peace conference .
after all , the kind of sympathy that the palestinian predicament evokes among ordinary egyptians is a dangerous source of instability .
mubarak ’ s succession is in a particularly complicated way .
unlike assad in his father ’ s death , his son ’ s succession is far from certain .
he was widely trusted to set the country ’ s agenda , and the master of the liberal economic reforms that have enabled egypt ’ s economy to take a high-quality ride since 2004 .
perhaps , as mubarak ’ s critics put it , this long-delayed process of democratization is intended to prevent any possible challenge .
but , with secular nationalism and the rise of islamism , the muslim brotherhood ’ s hidden electoral power is a mortal threat to the regime and its strategic alliance with the west .
as a result , the regime refuses to take any risks .
qaddafi ’ s decision not to be excluded from the international community is not entirely unrelated to his desire for a country that wants to be left to his son .
his grim human rights record is not eliminated , but the lavish “ guide of the revolution ” has stopped dealing with weapons of mass destruction and global terrorism in exchange for ending sanctions and returning to the international family .
as a patient who challenged the challenges of the islamist opposition , he recognizes that the international community ’ s ostracism , and domestic problems , would be too dangerous to be dealt with .
algeria is particularly difficult .
as a last survivor of the revolutionary generation , bouteflika will have to find ways to bring about his country ’ s civil war to end his country ’ s civil war .
the infant democracy may well lead to a victory for islamists as it did in 1991 .
the transition to democracy in the past through revolutionary arab regimes can not be put in place by the western model , nor can it be enforced by F fighter jets .
but , as countries like egypt , syria , and libya have shown , dynastic succession is not an internal response .
instead , it means shifting to the 革命 transition , and economic modernization and integration with the international community may be a recipe for greater political change in the future .
the silent arab majority must speak up
algiers – since the united nations development program began to compile the arab human development report in 2001 , the situation in many arab countries has deteriorated .
indeed , the region ’ s cooperation today is unlikely .
this is unfortunate , because a new common goal for arab citizens , especially arab youth , is a prerequisite for achieving peaceful prosperity in the middle east and north africa .
the first arab human development report was published in 2002 by explicitly blocking three “ development deficits ” in the middle east : knowledge , women ’ s empowerment , and freedom .
the report , described as “ arabs for arabs , ” has made clear that regional development prospects and national elites speak of social problems .
after the first ahdr , there is reason for optimism about the future .
israel withdrew from gaza in 2005 , following its withdrawal from lebanon in 2000 .
the new arab leaders – such as abdullah ii in jordan , mohammed vi in morocco , and bashar al-assad in syria – have come to power , with hope of change .
saudi arabia announced the first municipal elections in 2003 , and was completed in 2005 .
egypt and iraq both held democratic elections in 2005 .
thanks to high oil prices throughout this period , algeria ’ s efforts to quell prolonged civil strife have largely succeeded .
the arab spring revolutions that began in december 2010 were widespread in 2011 , when the undp began to compile the 2015 ahdr , focused on the plight of arab youth .
i was a member of the 2015 arab human development report , and there are about 30 intellectuals and activists in the arab world .
the 2015 arab human development report similar to the 2002 report , but this time we directly engage with influential arab youth in order to acquire the full range of data that we have , and focused on the consequences of the wars engulfing the region .
the 2015 report was finalized in may 2015 .
what i can say in the 2015 report is that the arab world ’ s “ silent majority ” of thinking is freer , especially among young people .
a generational comparison of global opinion polls reveals this hopeful trend .
arab youth have more access to information from outside the outside world than ever before , and they are receiving the values that young people share in other countries .
specifically , arab youth yearn for membership in civil society , emancipation from rigid hierarchies and more space for personal creation .
while the curriculum is not liberated in the same way as the rest of the world , it is not the same as the rest of the world .
given these polls ’ outcome , the 2015 report recommended that national , regional , and international progress support the liberation of power , which is the key to ensuring a domestic solution to the many challenges that have been found in effective governance , skills , and flexible societies .
the only way to bring large-scale change in the arab world is to launch innovation and creativity – and that requires an unrestrained civil society .
basic citizenship , a deep reform of the education system , reform of the family law , and more open space for media and culture .
the 2015 report , which i hope will be forthcoming , will encourage rational and constructive regional dialogue .
the report begins with such a warning : “ the 僵化 of the 年轻人 regime that led to the marginalization of young people has deepened . ”
unless the government realized this reality , they will face far more than a few extremists . ”
the collapse of the old order led to a political vacuum that is filled by extreme suicide and 暗流 , with the strongest defense force in the face of such a delicate defense force .
reform-minded arabs must focus on expanding the center , rather than trying to bridge the gap between extremists .
the silent majority must break the silence .
otherwise , resistance to the status quo will continue to be dominated by extremists , who can only hate , without aspirations .
the arab world of the early 2000s was hopeful , and we see hope again for young people today .
arab civil-society reformers must speak out , or risk losing another generation .
economic growth after the arab spring
cambridge – five years after the arab spring uprisings , egypt , jordan , morocco , and tunisia have all achieved considerable political stability .
but economic growth remains tepid , and the international monetary fund expects it to grow by no more than 1.5 % per capita this year .
the region ’ s catch-up potential is large and large , and it is strange to wonder why .
one obvious explanation is that , despite significant progress in building a stable government , these countries are still beset by political risks that discourage private investors .
but these risks were high before 2011 , and private investment was mediocre .
there must be other explanations .
look at these countries ’ economic history , and we can get insights into this question .
market economies are relatively new things for the middle east and north africa , until the country ’ s dominant economic growth in the 1980 ’ s was followed by inefficient , and resulting debt .
but , unlike latin america or eastern europe , arab countries liberalized their economies without liberalizing politics .
with western powers , dictatorship is deeply entrenched .
thus , even if the reforms of the 1990 ’ s transformed the country ’ s economic role – in egypt , where national spending declined from 60 % of gdp in 1980 to 30 % in the 1990s – politics is still around the market .
in egypt , for example , 32 businessmen were closely connected to former president hosni mubarak , who gained more than 80 % of total credit to the formal private sector in 2010 , earning 60 % of total total credit , but only 11 % of the country ’ s labor force .
in tunisia , former president zine el abidine ben ali received 21 % of the 2010 private sector ’ s total profits , even though their firms employed only 1 % of tunisia ’ s labor force .
not surprisingly , this system has only modest growth .
political loyalty has not translated into economic efficiency , and the spectacle of autocratic leaders failed to create a world-class world-class company .
the potential competitors are at a disadvantage , so there is no incentive to innovate or invest enough .
and failure to realize its growth potential is not limited to traditional rent-seeking sectors , such as real estate and natural-resource .
in the tradable sector , such as manufacturing and utilities , rents are created through non-tariff protection and subsidies , leading to weak export growth .
as a result , jobs are scarce in sectors where jobs are rarely more than 20 % of the workforce .
with few good jobs reserved for the group ’ s relationships , a growing number of educated young workers can only find low-quality jobs in the informal sector .
add to that low quality of service and social mobility .
intensifying social discontent is met with escalating repression .
as political risk increases , autocrats ’ cronies demanded higher returns .
ultimately , the system can not control the streets and the private sector , ultimately leading to mass protests and political revolutions .
governments from the ashes of the arab spring inherited a broken and closed trading system .
inadequate property rights impede investment , but , thanks to the petty corruption and polarization of petty bureaucrats , it is not realistic to move toward fairness and enforcement in the current environment .
these countries could try to replicate the country ’ s economic success in 2000-2010 , with the ruling party and a large number of dynamic small and medium-size enterprises forming a political union that tripled exports .
the challenge is to find the right investors who can boost growth and create jobs without just the right investors to provide political support .
here , morocco and jordan have made some successful successes , with their monarchies demonstrating the capacity to manage the provision of political acquiescence and economic support .
but , while these countries ’ governments have made some success in expanding their business union , traditional rent-seeking groups are fighting progress .
concessions to them would mean reducing investment in the tradable sector , thereby undermining export growth considerably .
unlike morocco ’ s model , it has expanded its export sector by attracting foreign direct investment , while opening its domestic services sector to its own smes .
but it still needs to face the challenge of economic liberalization , and trade unions protect inefficient incumbents from the impact of intensifying competition .
egypt , for its part , relied on private firms with close ties with the military , as well as financing support from the gulf cooperation council ( gcc ) .
but , given falling gcc oil revenues – not to mention disappointment with the arrangement ’ s inefficiency – this path may not work .
in all four countries , employment growth will remain constrained for some time to come .
improving economic inclusion without threatening political leaders will not be easy , requiring a more inclusive governance arrangement .
for morocco and tunisia , the convergence between moderate islamists and liberals offers some hope .
but this hope is currently lacking in egypt and elsewhere in the region .
why economists fail to foresee the arab spring
unlike in previous years , no one commented that those shook the arab world , and that it seemed to have promised it , have been transformed .
of course , novelty will always disappear over time .
but the waning interest of the arab uprisings reflects a deeper change : the hope of a new , more representative political system is no longer , and as the expected revolution evolved into counter-revolution , civil war , state failure , and deteriorating religious extremism , despair is desperate .
but , as much as so far , the arab spring uprisings must be focused on the arab spring uprisings .
like any landmark event , they have new problems .
one of the most important questions is why economists have failed to anticipate the unrest .
forecasting political upheaval is not easy .
even in predicting the economic crisis , economists ’ record is not uncommon .
but this forecasting failure may reflect a deeper problem with economic assumptions and frameworks .
on the eve of the fall , some arab autocrats were actually being applauded by the world bank and the international monetary fund to praise the so-called success of their “ right ” economic policies .
in the wake of the arab spring , the world bank recognized that the wrong policy prescriptions for the arab regimes were problematic .
this raises many other questions .
are economists concerned about the wrong indicators ?
are they misled by false analogies ?
or are they not paying enough attention to potential pitfalls ?
in short , is it a matter of data or analysis ?
failure to foresee political revolutions , at least partly , is the lack of ideas .
mainstream economics tends to focus on rational choices about rational economic selection , which seeks marginal benefits equal to marginal costs .
this conceptual framework can not be used to tackle social and political upheaval , which is not a marginal change .
empirical economics is also partly responsible for this forecasting failure .
many data suggest that economic conditions in the middle east and north africa ( mena ) are good .
in the decade before the uprisings erupted in the arab spring , the region ’ s economy grew reasonably well , to around 4-5 % .
given that these growth is diluted partly by population growth , real per capita gdp growth is hovering around 2-2.5 % .
nonetheless , the mena economies have improved considerably in the 1980s and 1990s , when the mena economies were far behind .
according to traditional standards , the human development indicators in the mena countries have improved considerably , some of which have declined in some countries .
for example , egypt ’ s gini coefficient has declined .
moreover , despite the data , the mena poverty rate has been the lowest in developing countries , and the countries that have swept across the arab spring – mainly in tunisia – continue to decline .
the benefits of direct or indirect benefits from years of international oil prices – especially in 2002 , when oil prices reached a record of $ 5.7 per barrel – benefited from the recent upswing in business cycles .
of course , neither good news nor good news .
unemployment – especially among young people – is very high .
autocrats have not made social justice a high priority .
nonetheless , the fact remains that the mena countries continue to improve relative prosperity , without facing a recession or stagnation .
this is equivalent to a number of conventional thinking , which suggests that the masses rose up with economic hardship , with a relatively quiet period of relative prosperity that should be matched by a popular political movement .
aristotle ’ s stated interpretation of the relationship between economic performance and political stability is a very different interpretation of the relationship between economic performance and political stability : “ to ensure power , the tyrant must remain poverty , and keep them on the sidelines . ”
this is not to say that revolution is the privilege of the rich , but rather that a relatively prosperous growth might lead to greater loss of freedom , causing opposition to poor governance .
to some extent , history bears this out .
in 1979 , the iranian revolution , as well as the arab spring uprisings , followed an unprecedented period of economic growth ( quadrupled in 1973-1974 ) .
even after the revolution , previous improvements in prosperity could play a role .
according to the american sociologist james c. davis ’ s so-called j-nomics theory , revolution – such as the russian revolution of 1917 and egypt ’ s revolution in 1952 – has occurred in a long and abrupt period of economic and social development .
in other words , it is not direct economic hardship , but a dismal gap between expectations and reality that awaken the masses .
the arab spring shows that improved economic performance can not be viewed as a policy to prevent political instability .
learning that lesson may help us avoid being blindsided by future political upheaval .
it may even enable us to avoid the disappointment and despair emanating from the arab spring .
arab spring and western winter
beirut – there are many striking parallels between the arab spring , which began in 2010 , the brexit referendum , the election of us president donald trump , and the recovery of the european right .
each of these cases involved the collapse of the old order , and progressive parties are too weak to attack the form of governance and xenophobia , such as authoritarianism and xenophobia .
the resulting discontent with the status quo , which led to the rise of the arab uprisings in 2010-2011 , has varied widely , and the opposition has pursued progressive and conservative opposition .
the middle class is dissatisfied with losing dignity in the hands of an unaccountable elite .
young people are unhappy with their parents ’ generation of their parents ’ future .
the islamic state ’ s resistance to the loss of ethical values against social ethics has been tempered by islam .
in the growing number of disaffected whites , displaced workers , and frustrated young people in the west , this is a recurring theme in the long debate .
over time , as economic liberalism crowds out the principles of equality and social solidarity , the vast gap between rich and poor has eroded the politics of many western countries .
moreover , globalization and technological innovation have a huge negative impact on some social groups , while public policy has failed to mitigate it .
it is now urgently urgent to adjust to far-reaching policies , especially because climate change is posing a deadly threat to the world .
but what adjustments will be made , and who will be implemented ?
so far , the popular revolt against the streets and voting sites in the streets has failed to establish a credible alternative framework for addressing political , social , and economic issues , and now the west and the middle east are drowning in these issues .
the explosion of popular anger in the arab world has led to a long-standing regime ’ s anger .
but the old autocrats worked hard to prevent the opposition from a credible opposition .
instead , the military , tribal groups , sectarian groups , and religious parties are quick to take the stage .
egypt is now undergoing a restoration of autocracy .
yemen , syria , and libya are mired in civil war .
lebanon and iraq are fragmented .
oil producers that try to extinguish the region ’ s fire by pouring money into the region are running large fiscal deficits .
turkey is also moving toward strongman rule ; and progressive forces in iran are weakening .
only tunisia is still a full transition to democracy ; but , even there , economic reform is not enough to address the challenges facing the country .
the new autocrats in the middle east are consolidating power by divide-and-rule tactics along sectarian and identity lines .
given widespread lack of personal security , many people chose sectarian groups rather than security and civil rights .
in today ’ s west , populist politicians who do not actually plan for a better future are emulating the middle east autocrats .
by stoking fear of the “ other ” – including refugees , muslims , or foreign terrorists – they have promised to gain power to gain power .
once in power , they began to consolidate their rule in the same way .
democracy may be able to adapt to populist governance ; but , as we have seen in the us , these institutions will soon be tested , and they are not sure that they will be weakened without any means of doing so .
the same is true of international relations .
the middle east ’ s geopolitical landscape is being redrawn by hostile states like iran and saudi arabia , which is redrawing the middle east ’ s geopolitical landscape , as well as external intervention in regional conflicts .
likewise , the west ’ s populist leaders are undermining their countries ’ interests relative to china , russia , india , and northern europe , and the post-1945 international order will be challenged by the world ’ s post-1945 international order .
moreover , political forces can not provide such an alternative .
the dominant theory of global dominance has changed .
most people no longer believe in the future defined by progress in economic dynamism , global integration , and social democracy .
a more pessimistic view is that globalization , unfettered markets , labor-saving technological innovations , and global warming are eroding our future .
restoring optimism in the middle east and the west will depend on whether intellectuals , unions , progressive parties , and civil-society groups can establish a common political base and establish a shared vision for the future .
this requires not only a new solution to the ongoing problems , but also a credible approach to implementing democratic change .
at the very least , this new era of resistance and revolution has led to the constant openness of the past .
as a result , we know that economic policy should be oriented toward inclusion ; material consumption must be cut ; and it protects democratic institutions from the negative effects of wealth and vested interests .
to be sure , these are huge challenges ; but if we know it , we can begin to take action .
and success in a region could be a model for all other regions .
the right of the next tens of millions of people to go to cairo ’ s streets on the street ’ s call for peace may not be the result of · 自焚 , but the riots in istanbul , the us president , or progressive political parties in europe .
how can the arab world avoid the abyss ?
cairo – a series of startling events in november highlights the abysmal situation in the arab world .
one of the missiles launched from yemen to saudi arabia ’ s capital , riyadh , launched a major anti-corruption campaign and affected dozens of high-profile figures .
meanwhile , egypt has experienced the worst terrorist attacks in memory , killing more than 300 civilians and injured .
videos from libya ’ s alleged slave auctions have underscored the persistent chaos and turmoil that followed the country ’ s total collapse .
the success of a military struggle against the islamic state and reconciliation between palestinian factions in gaza and the west bank have failed to moderate the region ’ s collective anxiety .
these positive developments have failed to inspire people to believe that the arab world can escape the abyss .
foreign interference in syria , lebanon , iraq , and yemen has also become commonplace .
and the ongoing debate about identity politics and the border of the levant marks the beginning of a serious challenge to the future .
indeed , the situation in the middle east is not surprising , because , in recent years , no arab country has tried to resolve the ongoing conflict in libya , syria , and yemen .
in many conflicts , the influence of arabs is less than foreigners .
historically , from the crusades to european colonialism , the middle east has been the target of numerous foreign invasions .
this is the natural resource that has been corrupted by greed , and it was a proxy for proxy wars during the cold war .
even today , arab territories are being occupied .
but while there are several reasons to blame foreign powers for the region ’ s dangerous state of affairs , blaming others – or even one another – can not solve the problem .
after all , there are many problems in the arab world itself , including inefficient and ineffective governance , unholy alliances , and weak national capacities .
any region that decides no future will only face disaster , and the majority of citizens everywhere feel disenfranchised .
although the arab world has traditionally been conservative , its population is under 35 years old , while young people have become victims of high unemployment in most countries .
this is not only a massive waste of resources , but also a source of serious , long-term sociopolitical problems .
and it is just one of the many domestic challenges facing the region .
arabs must take control of their future plans and hold their own future in their own hands to their own .
of course , they should continue to engage with the outside world and strengthen their strategic relationships with the outside world .
but they must learn less to rely on foreigners .
first , governments need to develop their own national security capacities to guard against threats and to prevent the expansion of the hegemon .
this , in turn , will strengthen its political influence and give them more diplomatic tools to resolve regional problems and prevent military conflict .
moreover , arabs must defend their national identities .
the national system in the middle east remains to be completed , but it is far more likely than a religious or ethnic faction that threatens to threaten regional stability further .
to avoid such an outcome , the region ’ s existing nation-states will need strong institutions to provide social inclusion and effective governance .
unfortunately , the vast majority of arab institutions do not have the capacity to do the job .
looking ahead , arabs should recognize that the best way to prevent foreign interference and maintenance of national interests is to pursue domestic reforms .
the arab awakenings over the last few years have revealed a neutral middle-class yearning for change .
but this is unlikely to change the fact that these movements have been fueled by a long period of mismanagement , with citizens expressing their anger over arab leaders ’ failure to promote incremental reforms .
arabs also need to develop more economic , political , and security solutions to adapt to changing circumstances .
the world is no longer bipolar or eurocentric .
indeed , it is not just the westphalian national system itself that is being tested for rapid technological , economic , and social change , but also the geopolitical model established by the post-war era .
finally , the arab world must confront regional hegemony and illegal occupation of arab lands .
addressing the current problem must respect people ’ s expectations of national and sovereign sovereignty , while not just the technical and transactional way to mitigate short-term difficulties .
after all , any policy that can not protect basic rights can not succeed .
both alone and as a group , arab countries need to develop a comprehensive strategy to address the existential threat that threatens its sovereignty and security over the next few years .
it is time for arab leaders to portray the vision of the future relationship with arab countries and develop plans to cooperate with non-arab neighbors to meet regional challenges and opportunities .
finally , but equally important , arab leaders must show how they can provide better domestic governance to their citizens .
if the arab world is to retain its own voice in its own future , it can not be complacent about the status quo .
leaders and citizens in the arab world must now work on plans for planning .
rethinking the government ’ s role in the arab economy
washington , dc – the arab world has a long tradition of commerce and business .
but , since independence , many arab countries have adopted state-led development models , leading to excessive reliance on economic activity .
this is unsustainable .
despite major setbacks in the 1990s , economic models in the arab world continued , owing largely to government hiring and providing universal subsidies .
this eliminates the risks that people face in economic life , strengthening their dependence on government while stifling innovation and entrepreneurship .
it has also undermined the provision of public services , resulting in mistrust of a severe dependency on the government .
the arab world ’ s state-led development model is now likely to reach a tipping point , as hundreds of millions of young people prepare to enter the labor market for decades to come .
because the public sector is unlikely to absorb these new entrants , it is urgently needed to create a dynamic private sector that requires not only adoption , but also requires technological innovation , thereby enabling workers to achieve inclusive and sustainable economic growth .
these strategies are consistent with the sustainable development goals , adopted by all un member states , including arab countries , to require .
achieving the sdgs – targets ranging from eradicating hunger and poverty to protecting the environment – will require a dynamic private sector capable of delivering technological solutions and willing to provide key financing .
financing the private sector – for example , the infrastructure projects required to target sustainable development – is particularly important in the arab world , where many governments are already burdened by debt .
to help fund financing , the world bank group has launched the largest financing 促发展 program .
of course , governments must also maximize their own resources .
in the past , high investment and energy income limits the willingness of tax revenues .
but as government money becomes depleted , the world ’ s most efficient arab countries are under increasing pressure to push for meaningful reforms .
arab governments must also increase their spending efficiency .
to improve the government ’ s ability to regain their citizens ’ trust – if it can help the tax – arab governments should integrate the concept of “ value ” into public administration .
such a framework for assessing the costs of public-sector behavior would require the collection , assessment , and disclosure of data in a transparent way .
mechanisms such as feedback loops would then allow the authorities to find the quality of quality and quickly correct them .
in this area , the world bank group is taking steps to help .
given that investment in human capital is the most important long-term move that governments can take , the focus on human capital projects is to identify the factors that are undermining investment in the field .
even before the full range of data sets , some way to improve public spending and 管理效率 is already apparent .
in particular , arab countries can emphasize the localization of development .
by boosting local governments ’ ability to plan and provide vital services , including health care and education services , countries can do the money to boost the value of their money , boost confidence , and make significant gains in achieving the sdgs .
the final area where reforms are necessary is regulation .
in many arab countries , existing public and private sectors – particularly in key sectors such as financial services , telecommunications , and energy – enjoy obvious advantages , including direct protection , blocking new entrants into markets , and inadequate restrictions on natural monopolies .
this hampers market competition for market competition , impeding the diffusion of general-purpose technology , and impeding the adaptation and evolution that the dynamic private sector needs .
instead of controlling the economy directly , arab governments should promote an independent and accountable regulatory body capable of improving economic outcomes .
of course , if history offers anything , we can know that the transition from state rule to regulation is a difficult process .
but past experience provides useful lessons for guidance .
in any case , we must not choose the regulation of the status quo , which would bring arab youth to unemployment and disenfranchisement .
this is all the more true at a time when tech giants like facebook , amazon , tencent , and alibaba are driving a shift to “ 超 ” a shift through digital technology .
against this background , the creation of a dynamic private sector capable of providing young workers in the arab world will need to operate under the framework of wisdom , thereby creating a more alarming and effective regulatory body that addresses issues like data collection and use .
it is often said that private innovation is driving developing countries across the future .
but this narrative can not be allowed to obscure the extreme importance of the wisdom and innovation that support such progress .
the government ’ s role in the arab economy must be improved , not less .

why have central banks started experimenting ?
london – over the last decade , central banks have been on a rollercoaster ride , from heroes to bear and becoming heroes .
in 2006 , when alan greenspan retired from the fed chair of the federal reserve board , the reputation was high .
he steered the us economy through boom-and-bust cycles , carefully crossing the potential growth threat posed by the terrorist attacks of september 11 , 2001 , with gdp and productivity growth .
at his last board at the fed board , timothy geithner , the chairman of the new york fed , told greenspan that he now looks embarrassing to greenspan , saying that greenspan ’ s reputation will continue to rise rather than decrease .
a mere three years later , the nobel laureate economist paul krugman has borrowed a python sketch of monty python ’ s 鹦鹉 , saying that greenspan was now discredited .
central banks were widely viewed as being in the early years of this century .
they have allowed global imbalances to take over over time , with 亲切 watching a large credit bubble , ignoring dangerous signals in the mortgage market , and 赞美 the innovative but toxic financial products created by overpaid investment bankers .
the early reactions to deepening the crisis are also puzzling .
the bank of england talked about moral hazard as the bank of england talks about the collapse of the banking system , and the european central bank continues to struggle with imaginary inflation when almost all economists consider the eurozone collapse and the associated credit crunch .
but , despite these missteps , the central bank , once viewed as part of the problem , was seen as a key part of the solution .
they gained the power of the new regulatory system , and are encouraged to adopt new , highly interventionist policies to contain depression and deflation .
central banks ’ balance sheets have expanded dramatically , and new laws have strengthened their mandate considerably .
in the us , dodd-frank has allowed the fed to enter its regulatory system in which it has never been regulated , giving it power to take over and settle failed banks .
in the united kingdom , banking supervision was separated from the boe in 1997 , and , in 2013 , the bank of england , which was also a prudent supervisor for insurance companies – its role was greatly expanded .
at the same time , the ecb is now a direct supervisor of more than 80 % of the eu ’ s banking sector .
over the last five years , central banks have become the world ’ s fastest-growing industries .
the central bank seems to have reversed the number of attacks , making great strides .
they sometimes produce innovative measures that help the world economy recover .
but , for now , this power expansion may be producing ambiguous results .
in fact , some central banks are beginning to worry about its expanding role , potentially counterproductive .
there are two related dangers .
the first danger can be summarized by the title of mohamed el-erian ’ s book the only game in town .
central banks are expected to assume more post-crisis adjustment burdens .
their large-scale asset purchases are a life-support system for financial economies .
but they can not solve fundamental problems like global imbalances and large debt overhangs .
indeed , they may be blocking the other adjustments needed to address the economic recovery , including fiscal adjustment and structural adjustment .
this is particularly true in europe .
the ecb has managed to maintain the euro by what mario draghi called “ whatever costs ” success , but the government has done little .
if the ecb continues to prescribe heavier doses of heavier doses from its currency , why should it make tough decisions ?
the second danger is that it is sometimes called the problem of “ too powerful citizens . ”
quantitative easing is one of them .
it blurs the line between monetary and fiscal policy – which is clearly the subject of elected governments – with unease .
we can see this in germany , with many germans questioning whether the ecb is too strong and independent , independent , and unaccountable .
similar criticism is driving those who want to “ audit the fed ” – often demanding that monetary policy be subject to congressional oversight .
there are also concerns about financial regulation , particularly the new macroprudential tools that central banks are 亮闪闪 .
in the new book the end of alchemy , mervyn king , the former governor of the bank of england , points out that using credit to intervene directly should be subject to political decisions .
others , notably axel weber , the former president of germany ’ s bundesbank , argue that central banks directly supervise banks .
what matters is financial markets , and supervisors are blamed .
if central banks are put on the front line , contagion risks are contagious , and the risk of a lack of confidence in monetary policy .
this brings the greatest concern .
central banks ’ monetary-policy independence is a hard-won prize .
this independence has brought enormous benefits to our economies .
but there is a need for a different form of political accountability in a way that uses public money to buy bonds , determine whether mortgages are available , and that the banks are costly to their shareholders .
the danger is that hasty post-crisis decisions to make the central bank more function could have unforeseen consequences .
in particular , strengthening political oversight of these functions could affect monetary policy .
for this reason , whatever new mechanisms of accountability are adopted , it must be carefully designed .
immunization on the front line

a recovery for all
new york – over the last two years , most countries in the world have chosen to expand public spending , buffer the global financial crisis for their economies and citizens .
but this year , with signs of economic recovery beginning , developed countries quickly shifted from fiscal stimulus to fiscal consolidation .
even developing countries are now joining the consolidation .
unicef ’ s survey of 126 countries shows that a large number of low- and middle-income countries are expected to cut public expenditures in 2010-2011 .
it is now time to restore the timing , because governments have just pledged to achieve development goals , such as reducing poverty and reducing infant mortality , at the united nations millennium summit last september .
for most low- and middle-income countries , the incipient economic recovery is fragile and uneven .
indeed , many low- and middle-income countries are vulnerable to commodity-price volatility , weak financial systems , low demand for world markets , weak external financing , overseas development assistance , and investment shortfalls .
more importantly , according to the un and the world bank , the impact of the global economic crisis continues to reflect hunger , unemployment , and social unrest .
rising food and fuel prices have weakened poor households ’ purchasing power , as well as the social services and employment opportunities they enjoyed .
moreover , poor households have begun to reduce food consumption , according to the united nations food and agriculture organization ( fao ) .
in addition to the hundreds of millions of people who already have reached poverty in 2008-09 , the long-term cumulative impact of the financial crisis will add another 64 million to extreme poverty in 2010 .
in the 1980 ’ s , the adjustment program forced the state to cut education , health care , water supplies , agriculture , and other areas in areas like other areas .
as the late tanzanian president , nyerere nyerere , has called for : “ do we starve our children to pay for debt ? ”
infant mortality rates rose in many low-income countries , and inequality is growing .
as a result , unicef has proposed a life-threatening adjustment program , and has proposed that children are protected in the economic crisis .
it argued for more expansionary macroeconomic policies , creating jobs for the poor while creating opportunities for job creation and public investment .
similar responses have been repeated after three decades , and we should take the same approach .
the poor in developing countries have once again been forced to shoulder the worst consequences of the crisis .
the key is that this time can not be transformed into another lost decade , and poor households , especially children , can no longer suffer as they did in the 1980s .
that is possible .
unicef surveys for 126 developing countries showed that , in nearly half of the country ’ s public spending , the usual adjustment measures include public-sector wage cuts , elimination of food subsidies , and restrictions on the already meager social security system .
these adjustments are often implemented without serious studies of social impact .
how many poor children in food and health-care services can suffer or die ?
how many children have a shortage of teachers , or poor children , who are forced to work for their children ’ s job ?
adapting public spending to the risk of a recovery in the recovery would exacerbate inequality in developing countries further .
premature fiscal austerity and/or cancellation of the threat of a countercyclical economy threaten public finances that are essential to restoring recovery from the worst affected by the crisis .
as the global recession improves , the need for recovery is the most urgent need for recovery , and the recovery must be taken to everyone , expanding employment , improving inequality , and continued development .
the goal is achievable .
but it needs to maintain assistance for poor countries ; the government needs to focus on supporting expansionary macroeconomic policies that support employment and broader economic activity ; a new program to expand health-care delivery and social protection ; and need education , water supplies , health , agriculture , and food security .
springtime for fascism
new york – are we seeing a new dawn of fascism ?

few people actually understand what fascism actually meant .

does the democrats really do better for the us economy ?
cambridge – in recent months , hillary clinton has repeatedly claimed that , in the democratic party , the us economy was performing significantly better .
but the truth is that she is absolutely right .
there is no doubt that the president is just one of many factors shaping the economy , and some presidents are certainly more fortunate than others .
but this does not mean that clinton ’ s statement , as some media outlets have shown , is only “ half half half , ” according to the 事实 机构 institution .
the difference between the democrats and the republicans ’ total economic performance is persistent and significant , and it is clearly higher than the threshold for statistical significance .
princeton university economist alan blinder and mark watson confirm this democratic dividend in a recent study .
their starting point is a observation : world war ii ( from harry truman to barack obama ) , average annual gdp growth averaged 4.3 % during democratic administrations , compared to 2.5 % during the republican period .
if it goes back , it would also include hoover and franklin d. roosevelt .
even the first three months of the presidency , or the first three quarters of the country ’ s office , have been a similar outcome .
but this is not all .
in the 256 quarters of the 16 post-war presidential term , the us economy has suffered a 1.1 quarters of recession during the democratic presidential administration , and 4.6 quarters in the republican party ’ s administration .
the likelihood of such a large gap is less than one in 100 .
and this trend is not confined to gdp .
since 1945 , the unemployment rate has fallen by 0.8 percentage points under democratic rule , while the republicans rose by 1.1 percentage points – the gap reached 1.9 percentage points .
the structural budget deficit ( about 1.5 % of potential gdp ) under democratic presidents is smaller than the republicans ( 2.2 % ) , though this did not prevent republicans from criticizing excessive republican spending .
even the standard & poor ’ s is significantly higher under democratic rule – 8.4 % versus 2.7 % .
( but the share of stock prices is so volatile that this disparity is not statistically important . )
in the economy ’ s economic performance , it is extremely unlikely that the mere impossibility of luck – without requiring fancy econometric to illustrate this .
consider the recession record .
if the recession began with the equal opportunity of the democratic and republican presidents , the possibility of a fourth four recessions began with one of the republicans ’ party during the republican party ’ s rule – a number of 朝上 heads .
such possibilities are low , but they have been in the past 35 years .
if you go back ten business cycles and assume that the recession begins with the democrats and the republican presidency , it would be less likely .
with nine of the last ten recessions in the last ten recessions , it is only one at one point when one or two of the ten .
but the truth is that , as it stands , the committee for business cycles identified the committee .
the more shocking truth is that the two parties have been eight weeks old .
during the four transitions in the republican party , gdp growth slowed ; in other four , the democratic party came to power .
this would amount to a row on eight coin tosses – a 256 with a 256 .
the democrats ’ success is therefore not a matter of luck .
( in fact , blinder and watson have also observed that , when democrats control congress or appoint fed chair , the us economy performs better , though the main determinant remains the president ’ s party . )
what is then , then , is the partisan performance gap .
but there is no telling how much of these factors are influenced by us president policies .
more unknown , the other 44 % of the performance gap is due to the factors .
in assessing clinton ’ s claim on this topic , the fact is that many of the people who have cited blinder and watson ’ s findings : contrary to popular assumptions , fiscal and monetary policies were no more “ 增长 ” or expansionary in the democratic party ’ s tenure than in republican presidents .
but with much fiscal and monetary stimulus , the president will have many policy decisions – energy , anti-trust , regulatory , trade , labor , foreign policy , and so forth .
it can not be tested by econometric tests .
it is this uncertainty that has prompted the fact that the fact-checkers call clinton a 半对 .
but she never attempted to explain performance differences with specific policies .
what she says is that the us economy fared better under democratic presidents .
that is 100 % right .
is economists right ?
new haven – since the global financial crisis of 2007-2009 and recession , criticism of the economics profession has intensified .
only a few professional economists foresaw the looming crisis – and the fallout from the crisis continues to be a major contributing factor in the economics profession .
what if economists can not foresee events that are so important to human wellbeing ?
to be sure , economics failed to anticipate most of the major crises of the last century , including the 大崩盘 of the 大崩盘 , 1980-82 recessions , and the worst of the 1929 stock-market crash .
the news coverage of the year before these recessions was explored , i found that there was virtually no warning of a serious crisis from economists .
instead , newspapers emphasize the views of corporate executives or politicians , who are always optimistic .
the closest to real warning is the 1980-82 recession .
in 1979 , us federal reserve chairman paul volcker told the us congress that the us faced “ disturbing economic conditions , ” and “ need to make tough decisions and make a tough decision , if necessary , to make a sacrifices . ”
the fed is likely to have to take drastic measures to contain high inflation , and , in the aftermath of the 1979 oil crisis , the major recession is taking place .
nonetheless , during all of the crisis during the last century , economists ’ broad agreement was not a crisis .
for my discovery , few economists – even a giant like keynes , friedrich hayek , and fisher – have publicly predicted that the depression was in the offing .
as the historian douglas irving ’ s record is , a remarkable surprise is that swedish economist 卡塞尔 卡塞尔 , in a series of lectures in 1928 , warned of “ a worldwide depression . ”
but his technical 讨论 ( focused on monetary economics and the gold standard ) did not constitute a new consensus among economists , and the news media have completely failed to warn of stories of depression .
interestingly , there is no evidence in contemporary news record that public anger against economists after disaster struck in 1929 .
so , why did the recent crisis make the economics profession so different ?
why did this time – unlike previous forecasting failures – giving economists so much mistrust ?
one reason may be the perception that many economists are smugly promoting “ efficient markets hypothesis ” – a theory that excludes the possibility of a collapse in asset prices .
the market , they argue , is always the most concise of the news , ignoring warnings from a few 凡人 and 凡人 about the overheating of stock markets and housing prices .
following the collapse of two markets , the economics profession ’ s credibility was directly hit .
we do not blame doctors for failing to predict all diseases .
most of our cases are random , even if our doctors can not tell us what we are in the next few years , or that we can not eliminate all our suffering when we are sick , but we are happy to accept the help they offer .
likewise , most economists are committed to problems , not building consensus on stock markets or unemployment .
we should thank their work .
as robert litan of the brookings institution pointed out in his new book , the us dollar economist , the economics profession “ creates trillions of dollars in income and wealth for the rest of the world . ”
that sounds like a pretty decent contribution , especially if we do some simple arithmetic .
the us association , for example , is now elected only 20,000 members ; if they created , say , $ 2 trillion in revenue and wealth , the equivalent of $ 100 million per economist is created .
skeptics might ask , “ why aren ’ t they the richest people ? ”
the answer is simple : most economic ideas are public goods that can not be patented or treated by the inventor .
most economists do not mean that they did not make many people richer .
what litan ’ s book is interesting is that he reveals many fascinating little ideas about how to run business or manage the country .
they exist in areas such as optimal pricing and marketing mechanisms , monopolies , natural-resource management , public goods , and development .
none of this is worth a trillion dollars , but litan ’ s conclusion is compelling .
in 2010 , the “ economics of things , ” the economics of 学好 , emphasized the impact of these innovations on the real-world effects : carbon trading , earned income ( earned ) , lower trade tariffs , 工作 , and 延迟 , 使用 , and 延迟 .
the innovations described in litan ’ s and 西格 ’ s books suggest that the economics profession has produced a great deal of valuable work , characterized by a genuine effort to provide real evidence .
yes , most economists fail to foresee the financial crisis – just as doctors did not predict disease .
but , like doctors , they have made life much better for all .

the assassination of the head of iraq ’ s governing council makes clear that the us failed to establish the minimum legal and order needed to transfer power to power on june 30 .

it is clear that this piece of paper is worthless .

but the kurdish kurdish zone in northern iraq has been completely different . over the last decade , the protection of a no-fly zone , especially after saddam hussein was overthrown , has succeeded in establishing and maintaining a 政府 government .
they overcome ethnic and partisan differences , and have done very well in areas such as education , irrigation , and construction , and , above all , the kurdish government has avoided violence .
confronted with the collapse of the rest of the arab world , one must ask the question : the us-led coalition is not a referendum on the kurdish region , asking the government what kind of government they want .
in any case , the kurds have the right to determine their fate , according to any internationally accepted standard .
historically , while the kurds have much to do with arabs in terms of language , culture , and history , they have never been able to have a say in court .
after a great war and the fall of the ottoman empire , a victorious coalition promised them to establish their own countries – a pledge that was shameful about the interests of britain ’ s imperial empire .
since then , kurds have suffered under a hostile ethnic rule .
the same is true of the rest of iraq : the united states is convincing the un to transfer power to legitimate iraqi government , but the chances of obtaining a de facto mandate are paltry , with no party in iraq .
why are they punished for the kurdish people ’ s legitimate government , and did not participate in murder , attack mosques , and suicide bombing for schoolchildren ?

but if a universal standard of human rights is carried out from the universal standards of human rights , what is the right to determine the country ’ s internal development ?
after all , no one acknowledges the principle of israel ’ s opposition to palestine in the west bank and gaza .
so should attitudes toward turkey .
if turkey gives domestic kurdish minorities more cultural and linguistic rights , allowing kurdish political rights to exist in turkey ’ s parliament , it would reduce the willingness of turkey ’ s kurds to oppose ankara .
in the nineteenth century , the common interest of the authoritarian russia , germany , and austria prevented the eventual birth of free poland : such unholy alliances will place no place in the twenty-first century .
the recent referendum on the cyprus future , supported by the united nations , is in the island ’ s greek and turkish neighborhoods .
the outcome of the referendum is paradoxical , and it is not in the early stages of the referendum ’ s sponsors : the collective right to decide the future was recognized .
why not in iraqi kurdistan ?
in order to calm political anger and take pride in international rules , any plebiscite in the kurdish region initially may be the reference point .
but this would give legitimate expression of legitimate rights to people who have long been oppressed , with the right to place a place in the sun .
such a referendum could also agree on a sunni-shia agreement between iraq and shia in iraq , and it is seen as a violent violence .
perhaps they will recognize the negative effects of violence and the subsequent penalties , beginning with the kurds ’ example of stopping violence .
even if iraq ’ s unity fails , the injustice suffered by the kurds for generations will be changed .
