is foreign investors welcome ?
over the last 20 years , the world has experienced rapid growth in fdi , from $ 40 billion in the 1980s to $ 900 billion last year .
the cumulative sum of fdi is already close to $ 10 trillion , making it the most important way to deliver goods and services to foreign markets : sales of foreign branches roughly $ 19 trillion , compared to just $ 11 trillion in exports .
at the same time , the liberalization of fdi in almost every country has become a driving force for corporate trade – a direct investment in the emerging international manufacturing system , which accounts for one-third of world trade .
but is this golden age over ?
fdi can bring a range of benefits , but it can also pay the price .
in the 1970 ’ s , international multinationals , which direct investment abroad , had just noted that the costs of direct foreign investment exceeded its benefits , and thus took control of foreign investment .
in the 1980 ’ s , the pendulum began to swing in the advanced countries , guided by the balance of direct foreign investment .
foreign direct investment , which was previously considered the problem , is slowly becoming a driver of economic growth and social development .
according to reports from the united nations conference on trade and development , the number of 156 changes occurred between 1991 and 2004 , and 93 % were in the direction of creating a more favorable investment environment for multinational companies .
but now we are facing a real risk of rebalancing once again , leading to a reversal of the liberalization process .
direct foreign investment in the advanced countries ( and also in emerging markets ) often takes a form of cross-border mergers ( m & a ’ s ) .
resistance to such mergers is increasingly common when it comes to domestic firms that are perceived by politicians as “ national leaders , ” or for national security , economic , development , and cultural peculiarities .
the increasing involvement of private assets in mergers and acquisitions is likely to fuel further controversy , as such deals are often considered purely speculative .
in the name of “ economic patriotism , ” security , and other minorities , a growing number of countries will resist the acquisition of their own laws .
the us senate committee , for example , recently attempted to block legal provisions for relaxing foreign investment restrictions on airlines , but it has just been reinforced by the european project ’ s restrictive enforcement laws .
moreover , when it comes to censorship of foreign companies , governments have become more muddled in implementing existing regulations .
these emerging markets have become a “ new player on the economic stage , ” owing to the rise of protective action by emerging-market multinational multinational corporations .
established multinational companies and their sources of origin need to adjust to the challenge of new powers , and to adapt to the changes brought about by the world market .
as we know in many cases , it is not easy to adapt to new changes : as long as the analogy between france and the united states and the united states is to merge chevron or 米塔尔 , it is clear that this is all too clear .
once the development of the offshoring of services accelerates , another form of protective action is likely to begin to emerge – a time when fdi will be challenged .
all signs suggest that offshoring has reached a tipping point , with further offshoring of foreign investment .
if foreign countries are not pressing for appropriate regulatory mechanisms to meet the rapidly rising challenges of working in the service of services , the backlash against this outward foreign investment will become inevitable .
the unease raised by fdi is now largely confined to developed countries .
but there are signs that this concern is spreading to emerging markets .
particularly when it comes to big projects , some host countries are asking questions about their relationships with multinational corporations , and the host government is censoring these contracts , owing to their belief ( whether they are wrong ) that they are not treated properly .
around two-thirds of the international arbitration cases involved in the known 219 involve international arbitration cases , which have been proposed over the last three years .
dealing with fdi has changed , and the future may be changing again , depending on how the government views the balance between costs and benefits .
this balance involves not only economic factors , but also a strong desire to maintain national security and control of their economies .
to this end , the concept of “ twenty-first century , ” proposed by ollanta humala , peru ’ s presidential candidate , is reminiscent of the “ economic patriotism ” of french prime minister dominique de villepin .
a conservative attitude toward fdi ( as in any foreign affairs ) is widespread in all countries , and politicians can make such conservative sentiments the result of protectionism .
nonetheless , it would be ironic if the advanced countries , led by the past 20 years , have led the way to liberalize fdi by leading fdi movements .
let us hope that the anti-globalization backlash in developed countries could be effective in the way that the rest of the world is to be effective , avoiding the consequences that we all want .
hope for america
new york – in the midst of a fiercely elected election – spending more than $ 2 billion in total spending – many observers believe that us politics has not changed much : obama remains president , the republicans still hold a majority in the house .
is the us facing a “ fiscal cliff ” – automatic tax increases from 2013 to spending cuts , which will most likely tip the economy into recession unless there is bipartisan agreement on an alternative fiscal solution , and a much worse political stalemate ?
in fact , the general election has produced many beneficial factors – except to prove that unbridled corporate money can not buy elections , and that the demographic shift in the us has been handed down by the republican population .
the republicans ’ explicit request to deprive some states of voting rights – for example , in pennsylvania , who had managed to increase african and latino americans – backfired : voters threatened by the threat of suffrage were forced to step back .
some of mitt romney ’ s advisers have been stymied by obama ’ s victory : wasn ’ t the election ?
they confidently believe that the us would forget that the republican party ’ s passion for deregulation pushed the us economy into the brink of ruin , and that voters will not notice that the republicans ’ intransigence in congress has made it more effective in the aftermath of the 2008 crisis .
voters , they argue , will focus only on the current economic malaise .
the republicans should not ignore americans ’ obsession with denying issues like disenfranchisement and gender equality .
these issues hit the us value of values – the boundaries of democracy , the boundaries of government intervention individuals , and , in many cases , economic issues .
as i argue in the price of inequality , a large part of the us economy ’ s economic inequality can be attributed to the rich ’ s impact on government , and to use it to shore up their rich wealth .
clearly , issues like reproductive rights and gay marriage have an important economic impact .
after considering the economic policy of the next four years , the main reason for the election is that the us avoided the possibility that it could push it toward a recession , aggravate inequality , and make millions of americans more difficult to secure .
beyond that , the americans should hope to improve the fiscal position in america ’ s fiscal position by stimulating the “ employment ” bill , which promotes economic , economic growth , and a strong “ employment ” bill that would reduce unemployment , restore growth , and create much more than costs .
americans might also hope to have a housing plan that ultimately addresses america ’ s foreclosure crisis .
equally necessary , there must be a comprehensive plan to increase economic opportunities and reduce inequality , which should aim for the next decade to be the most unequal and socially liquid countries in the developed world .
this means that a more progressive tax system , including not limited to all , would be able to pay a lower tax rate that would enable speculators to work less effectively than they work to earn a working living , thereby allowing the rich to use the cayman tax system to avoid paying a reasonable tax burden .
the us and the world can benefit from increasing domestic production by increasing domestic production and reducing reliance on imports by reducing consumption , and that it should benefit the us and the world .
moreover , america ’ s technological policy must reflect the recognition that its long-term living standards depend on productivity growth , while productivity growth reflects a technological advance based on solid research .
finally , the us needs a financial system that serves society , not as it seems to be in itself .
this means that the financial system ’ s center should shift from speculative and proprietary trading to borrowing and job creation , which requires regulation and adequate reinforcement of financial-sector regulation , antitrust , and corporate governance , in order to ensure that markets do not become rigged casinos .
globalization has made all countries more interdependent , in turn requiring greater global cooperation .
we may hope that the us can be reformed on the global financial system by supporting tougher international regulations , the global reserve system , and a better restructuring of sovereign debt , and more leadership in international economic institutions , as well as providing assistance to poor countries .
americans should hope for all of this , though i am not optimistic about how far the us will be able to muddle through – an end to the bush-era tax cuts for students and homeowners , but not on a comprehensive , across-the-board tax reform , but no major progress on global warming .
the euro crisis may persist , so america ’ s continued malaise is hardly good for global growth .
worse still , without strong leadership from the us , long-term global problems – from climate change to the international monetary system needed to reform – will continue .
still , we should be grateful : it is not a mistake to go further .
is home prices a house of cards ?
the big cities boom began in london in 1996 , when boom psychology went to los angeles , new york , and sydney to los angeles in 1997 , to miami , moscow , and shanghai in 2002 .
these and its cities have since boomed , with prices rising from at least 50 % in 2000 .
this is a big windfall for homeowners , but it is bad for those who are planned .
the rise in home prices in some of these cities is now weakening , and the price increase in london and new york has fallen sharply over the past year , with real increases in real terms in the second quarter of 2004 .
in sydney , house prices actually fell in the second quarter .
is the boom booming ?
nobody foresaw this boom in advance , so predicting it will be full of risks .
housing prices have shown strong upward momentum in the face of warnings that the party is about to end .
if the boom is to be predicted , it is important to understand why it is happening in so many cities .
surprisingly , there is no universally accepted explanation for this question , because the boom is ultimately more psychological .
economists would rather talk about interest rates or unemployment statistics as specific and knowable factors .
these indicators , of course , have a role to play in explaining housing markets , but it is not enough to explain the recent boom .
there are three psychological traits : first , in a changing world economy , understanding the source of value in the world economy is strong ; second , the public ’ s sense of `` charismatic '' cities has strong confidence ; and , third , speculative bubbles have 眼花缭乱 .
we need to understand all these factors more deeply if we are to understand current conditions for housing markets and discern future price trends .
first , the world economy seems to be more chaotic than it was a decade ago .
since the devastating fall in asset prices in most countries in 2000 , financial assets no longer give the previous sense of security , spurring the real-estate sector to `` pursue the quality of the quality . ''
moreover , terrorism is a problem for everyone today , with a series of tragedies in indonesia , spain , and russia .
people are found to be investing in the safest , without worrying about the risks that are uncertain .
the upward trend in home prices is thus accompanied by panic , showing strong momentum .
second , as the internet and mobile phones come to light , global communications have grown at an explosive pace , and public perceptions of charismatic cosmopolitan cities are growing .
just as people are increasingly admired for international celebrities , they also believe that the world ’ s 家喻户晓 centers of commerce , the world ’ s leading commercial centers , technology centers , and cultural centers are uniquely valuable .
with fear of terrorism , and skepticism about volatile asset prices , these cities ’ geographic watches are converging , and the more famous they are in new york , paris , and london .
third , the speculative contagion that led to this economic bubble is also an important factor .
when the rising price inflated the economic excitement , and thereby pushing for higher prices in the city , other cities , and even on the other side of the hemisphere , the current boom is seen in markets and markets .
the shanghai people may not talk about london ’ s house prices , but shanghai ’ s observers know what is happening in london , and london ’ s rising house prices seem to have made the shanghai housing boom look plausible and appropriate .
in contrast to the other two psychological causes , speculative contagion is akin to a single day .
given that speculative bubbles maintain their lives by responding to price increases , it will not survive forever .
so what is the answer ?
two psychological reasons are suggesting that strong upward momentum in home prices will continue , and the third reason is that this trend will eventually end , but it does not specify when it is .
i believe that some high-flying glamour cities will continue to witness rising home prices and eventually decline .
historically , house prices have shown their strong momentum , and home prices in all of these cities continue to rise rapidly , even as they are slower than in a year or more .
from this trend , home prices in most of these cities will continue to rise in a year or more for more than a year .
a year later , when momentum no longer plays an important role , psychology is more important for long-term forecasts .
and now that enthusiasm for investment in real estate is likely to decline as the housing price declines , prices could fall downward .
in the next recession , or when local economies are hit seriously , housing prices are likely to fall sharply in large cities .
is humanity better ?
melbourne – watching headlines about war , terrorism , and the brutal government of the brutal government , the 宗教 of religious leaders lamented that the standard of behavior in public and private behavior is fading , which is easily the impression that we are living in an age of moral collapse .

for one thing , the ability to think rationally gives us a clear evolutionary advantage , which allows us to solve and plan to circumvent risks , thereby raising the likelihood of survival .

in particular , reason can enable us to find things similar to that of other things that we have seen in our own moral context .
thus , excluding them from the realm of moral considerations that we should be morally reprehensible , or simply wrong .

in households , neighborhoods , tribes , and states have reduced violence .

many will doubt that .

is humans worse than chernobyl ?
朴茨茅斯 – nearly three decades after the nuclear accident , the nuclear accident has been nearly three decades old , and the scientific community is still debating the impact of radiation around the reactor .
not long ago , i and other scientists studied the animals of human exclusion around the nuclear power plant .
as a result , the consequences of human habitation seem to be worse than the impact of radiation on animals .
such an outcome can not be avoided by reminding people : human beings ’ simple activities are worse than the worst environmental catastrophe of the twenty-first century .
we studied animals of animals in the near two square kilometers ( 85 square kilometers ) of belarus ’ s “ 波萊谢 , ” “ 波萊谢 . ”
before the disaster , there were 22,000 people in the region , with 92 villages in 92 villages mainly developing and forest resources .
a few days later , the government had evacuated its residents and farmed animals to protect them from high doses of radiation .
although radiation levels fell by almost 100 times a few months after the accident , the region was still judged to be unfit for human habitation .
few reported the accident ’ s impact on wild animals , but we know that some hot spots have died in trees and wildlife .
some might think that nearly 30 years later , the site is still a 荒芜 region , and occasionally a generation of chronic radiation and genetic impairment .
the reality is very different .
indeed , just a few years after the accident , the abandoned regional data collected by 科学家 scientists in belarus have shown that the number of wild boar , 麋鹿 , and 狍子 has increased significantly .
moreover , the region ’ s wildlife number increased over time , owing to the use of facilities that humans abandoned .
crops , gardens , and orchards provide abundant food .
abandoned houses and 农舍 provided ready-made 窝巢 .
by 1993 , the number of wild boar had increased sixfold , but then by about three times since the outbreak of the disease and the growing wolf population .
our research shows that the number of large mammals in chernobyl is comparable to that of 污染 reserves in belarus – except for wolf , where the wolves live in the site of the reactor .
the region has also found the region even 几头 .
moreover , there is no link between radiation levels and mammals ; the number of mammals and pollution in the most contaminated regions is at least as high as it is anywhere else .
to be sure , the chernobyl region ’ s animal boom does not represent radiation for wildlife .
radiation does cause dna damage , and , so far , the effects of individual animals are not entirely excluded .
but the contrast with the affected regions is instructive .
whatever the damage caused by radiation , human habitation is less than human habitation .
in fact , in the exclusion of the human exclusion zone and the natural nature of the natural market , the country ’ s major socioeconomic changes have fueled a dramatic reduction in rural poverty and wild boar .
the lesson of the chernobyl disaster is that there must be space for nature to thrive .
the main reason for declining global biodiversity is the habitat of human activity and fragmentation .
for example , people are cutting demand for biofuels .
we may be using high-tech – even genetically modified – agriculture to meet human food needs with smaller land , leaving more space for wildlife .
there is no simple solution , of course , and the world ’ s population will complicate any effort to address it .
but one thing is clear : as a species , we must think carefully about the impact of the anthropogenic animal species , and thus better shape our economic and environmental policies .
violence and innovation
abu dhabi – in the 1949 british film , the third man , harry 莱姆 observed that , in the midst of the renaissance , the country had “ war , terror , murder , and bloodshed . ”
but it produced michelangelo , 达芬奇 , and renaissance .
and , by contrast , the swiss , with 500 years of democracy and peace , has said nothing of the clock .
the implication is that innovation and creativity can be seen only as extreme – indeed , in switzerland – as one of the world ’ s innovative leaders .
although peace , order , and political stability are widely regarded as essential prerequisites for invention , entrepreneurship , and economic development , this rule has many exceptions – especially in terms of creativity and innovation .
the us has been on the top of the world ’ s top ten global innovation index , including the global innovation index .
but , in the global peace index , it ranked only 88 countries .
similarly , the united kingdom and the netherlands rank fifth and sixth in the innovation index , but are ranked at 28 and 29 .
instead , bhutan is one of the 20 most peaceful countries , but it is on the hook in the innovation index .
of course , crime , terrorism , conflict , and severe political instability that led to a comprehensive breakdown of law and order would impede creativity and innovation considerably .
but some countries show strong resilience against large-scale violence and instability .
for example , mexico and south africa have widespread violent crime , but they are at the top ( measured in terms of patent filing and 注册商标 ) .
to consider terrorism indicators , lebanon , turkey , jordan , and israel are the most resilient innovators .
just as peace and stability do not always lead to creativity and innovation , wars and uncertainties do not always impede creativity and innovation .
though peace , political stability , and a civilized order are important considerations for the operation of large-scale foreign production and services , these factors are much less important in providing creativity and related investments .
in particular , innovative industries such as animation , art , design , and software – mostly based on personal competence and talent – are more resilient to conflict .
officials , investors , and business leaders seeking revolutionary ideas , cutting-edge solutions , and the development of talent for talent should not be overly influenced by some social unrest or the tranquility of others .
in fact , fixing the zone ’ s comfort zone would have significant benefits .
there is evidence that large-scale uncertainty can spur competition , thereby sparking innovation .
moreover , societies with low levels of consensus and more violent violence may be more likely to catalyze fundamental innovation than a harmonious society .
lebanon ’ s experience supports this assertion .
despite its long-standing political instability , its creative industries are expanding .
the 世界知识产权组织 in lebanon in 2007 , based on 版权 industries , showed that the main challenges facing lebanon ’ s 软件业 – an important part of its economy – include limited markets , competitive competition , a brain drain ( the loss of human capital ) , inadequate government incentives , and widespread piracy .
violence is completely absent from the list of challenges .
but countries like lebanon are vulnerable to violence – for example , through creative industries – to reduce their negative impact on economic , social , and intellectual development .
in 2005 , 10 % of lebanon ’ s new businesses were creative industries , and 产业 industries contributed 4.75 % of gdp .
likewise , despite extremely volatile politics , nigeria produces more than 1,000 films annually .
indeed , nigeria ’ s film is already the world ’ s third largest , behind the us and india , second to the country ’ s economic influence , after the oil sector .
according to the 2010 united nations ’ innovative economy report , global trade in creative goods grew at a rate of 14 % per year .
at the same time , innovative goods exports from developing countries – which are more violent – grew at an annual rate of 13.5 % , with total exports totaling $ 275 billion ( 43 % of the world ’ s creative industries ) in 2008 .
though global trade fell by 12 % in the same year , trade in creative products and services is widening .
this has a huge impact on political and business leaders – especially in turbulent areas like the middle east .
in order to boost economic growth and innovation amid conflict and instability , policymakers and investors should heed the creation of innovative industries .
the resilience and adaptability of innovative industries will be critical to supporting long-term economic growth and job creation .
is services new ?
princeton – the recent global debate about growth in the developing world has changed dramatically .
the hype and excitement of the rapid catch-up of the advanced economies in recent years has been missing .
few serious analysts still believe that the dramatic economic convergence that asian countries experienced , and the less dramatic convergence that most latin american and african countries experienced in the coming decades , will continue to exist in the coming decades .
the low interest rates , high commodity prices , rapid globalization , and the post-cold war stability of the cold war are unlikely to persist .
the second realization is that developing countries need a new growth model .
the problem is not only that they need to escape from the vagaries of fickle capital inflows and commodity booms that are often vulnerable to shocks and crises .
more important , the best path to riches in history – export-oriented industrialization – is likely to come to an end .
since the industrial revolution , manufacturing has been a recipe for rapid economic growth .
countries like germany , the united states , and japan , which eventually catch up to the uk , are all built through their manufacturing industries .
two rapid economic convergence emerged after world war ii : the european periphery in the 1950 ’ s and 1960 ’ s ; the rest of east asia has since the 1960s .
both economic convergence is based on industrial manufacturing .
china , which became the poster child for this growth strategy since the 1970 ’ s , was also headed for this approach .
but manufacturing today is not previously manufacturing .
today ’ s manufacturing capital is far more capital-intensive and skill-intensive , so the potential to absorb a large number of rural labor has narrowed considerably .
global supply chains have facilitated access to manufacturing , but they also reduce the benefits of domestic value-added accumulation .
thanks to changes in demand and environmental concerns , many traditional industries , such as textiles and steel , may face shrinking global markets and overcapacity .
one downside of china ’ s success is that many other countries are struggling to build more than a niche of manufacturing .
as a result , developing countries began to industrialize , with services relying on services – a phenomenon that i call premature de-industrialization .
services account for much of the developing world ’ s gdp , even in low-income countries that traditionally rely heavily on agricultural contributions .
young workers who leave the farm to cities are increasingly absorbed by urban services rather than manufacturing jobs .
international trade expansion is also growing faster than trade .
the world bank ’ s 加尼 and stephen o ’ rourke are optimistic , and , in the latest paper , they argue that services can become an escalator to growth , and that the manufacturing sector has traditionally played its role .
in particular , they argue that services have exhibited “ unconditional convergence ” in productivity .
that is , labor productivity in countries where labor productivity is falling is the most productive .
this is very good news , but there is reason to be cautious .
the 加尼 ’ s evidence includes the data that began in the early 1990 ’ s , when developing countries were experiencing economy-wide convergence , driven by historically historic capital inflows and commodity booms .
it is unclear whether their conclusions extend to other times .
two factors determine the difference between services and manufacturing .
first , while some segments of the services sector are tradable , and increasingly important in global commerce , these areas are highly skill-intensive , with little ordinary workers .
banks , finance , insurance , and other business services , as well as information and communications technology industries , are a high-tech industry .
they can play the role of growth escalators in economies where labor is adequately trained .
but developing economies tend to be predominantly low-skilled labor .
in these economies , tradable services can not absorb much labor supply .
that is why , despite the success of india ’ s information and communications technology sector , it is not the main driver of economic growth .
by contrast , traditional manufacturing can provide a large number of jobs that have just emerged from the manufacturing sector , where productivity is high than in agriculture .
in today ’ s developing countries , most of the excess labor force is absorbed by non-tradable services such as retail trade and domestic households , where productivity levels are low .
in principle , many of these activities can benefit from more advanced technologies , improved organizations , and more formalization .
but here , the second difference between services and manufacturing comes out .
partial productivity gains in non-tradable activities will eventually limit themselves , because the activities of individual services can not be extended without restricting their trade ’ s adverse terms of trade – that is , holding down their prices ( and profit ) .
in manufacturing , small countries can thrive with a few export successes and diversification to thrive – first 衬衫 , then assemble their televisions and microwave ovens , and finally move to the skills and value chains .
on the contrary , in manufacturing , the market is constrained by domestic demand , and continued success requires complementary productivity gains in the rest of the economy .
focusing on a few sectors can not generate rapid prosperity .
thus , growth has to rely on a much slower pace of economic capacity – the accumulation of human capital and institutions .
as a result , i doubt that a services-led model can deliver rapid growth and good jobs for the manufacturing sector .
even if the techno-optimists are right , it is difficult to see whether this will enable developing countries to sustain rapid growth in the last few decades .
“ reset ” relations with europe ’ s backyard
stockholm – the “ reset ” button for diplomatic relations in the united states is a popular fashion today .
although the relationship between the eu and its eastern neighbors has not yet been strained by the need for “ reset , ” a deep strategic reconstruction is quietly being pursued .
the eu ’ s launch of a new “ eastern partnership ” in may is intended to facilitate further integration with armenia , azerbaijan , belarus , georgia , moldova , and ukraine .
in the context of the global financial crisis , it is urgently needed to update , and more powerful , policies in eastern europe ’ s eastern neighborhood .
equally important , all relevant countries have expressed their desire to move closer to the eu .
the eastern partnership ’ s initiative stems from a 联合行动 joint operation , which invited six countries to deepen and strengthen cooperation with the eu in key areas .
in trade and economic relations , it clearly establishes the goal of establishing a comprehensive free-trade area between the eu and its partners .
it is committed to achieving a comprehensive visa liberalization ( while also offering visas to promote agreement ) , promising to strengthen cooperation on energy security , diversification , and efficiency , and develop plans and programs to help the eastern part of the east ’ s eastern neighborhood .
sweden ’ s presidency this month , as the eu ’ s rotating president , helped drive it .
but at a time when the eu ’ s eastern neighbors face serious challenges , many partners have been hit hard by financial and economic crises .
the sharp drop in global demand and trade has severely undermined ukraine ’ s steel industry .
georgia ’ s economic success is largely attributable to direct fdi , but direct foreign investment today has no appetite for further investment .
with a relatively low partner in the global market , such as moldova , the crisis is relatively slow , but it may be as bad as it may be .
the eastern partnership does not quickly fill the consequences of the crisis .
but it can provide a political framework and institutional support to improve the vulnerability of these countries ’ vulnerability to the crisis : incomplete market economies , weak national institutions , and sustained corruption .
the eastern partnership ’ s proposal for deeper integration with the eu in areas like trade and energy has been accompanied by a significant transformation .
most partners are also experiencing a political crisis .
in most countries , democratic development has not yet reached the level of the usual components of a political life that can be silenced without endangering the state .
democratic values , human rights , and the rule of law are built on the eastern partnership .
political integration with the eu , together with the integration process under the partnership , will drive reforms in these critical areas .
sweden ’ s rotating presidency , the european union ’ s rotating presidency , will begin to work – the basic component of the partnership .
a “ comprehensive institution-building program ” aimed at supporting key institutional reforms of each partner should be launched before the end of the year .
some flagship initiatives in the european commission will eventually come to light , and it may be possible to develop new projects and programs .
sweden will pay special attention to energy efficiency , because such programs would not only improve energy security , reduce costs , and contribute to the fight against climate change .
along with the european commission , sweden and the european commission , together with the european commission , seek the first meeting of the eastern partnership for democracy in the east this year .
we want to launch parliamentary cooperation , as well as cooperation between local and regional authorities in the eu and its partners .
by the end of this year , the foreign ministers of the european union and six partners will review progress in the past , and to guide future actions further .
the eastern partnership is aimed at fostering eu integration , allowing six countries closer to the eu ’ s values , law , and way of work , and to support and assist the eu .
russia sometimes sees such a perspective , arguing that this partnership is against it .
but this , of course , is unfounded .
the eastern partnership can not solve all of the problems and difficulties facing the six partners .
but it does represent a clear commitment from the eu to support its transition and reform – a process that deserves prosperity and stability throughout the region .
is the saudis fanatics ?
terrorist attacks have not only raised doubts about the saudi government ’ s survival prospects , but also the idea that the kingdom is dysfunctional , as a destructive state .
the persistence of violent fanaticism seems to be spreading in saudi society , which is rooted in extreme orthodoxy .
the fact that 15 of the 19 hijackers in the us in september 11 , 2001 , hit the us , made it clear that the kingdom is a bastion of authoritarianism and extreme opinion .
to some extent , this view is wrong , but it is not appropriate to describe the broad saudi public .
on the contrary , it would be a grave mistake to assume that islamism defines the full implications of saudi religious attitudes .
between 2001 and 2003 , i was a member of the group , a broad survey of values in saudi arabia , egypt , iran , and jordan .
the results show that the saudis have a big difference between view and the conventional wisdom .
compared to those of the rest of the middle east , the saudis have generally been less religious , and their views on democracy and arranged marriage suggest a subtle 暗流 .
to be sure , all four countries are generally religious and more than 90 % of subjects believe that they believe in divine life , faith in life , and think of heaven and hell .
but , compared to other muslims , the saudis seem less religious .
62 % of saudis believed that they were religious , and 82 % , 85 % , and 98 % , 85 % , and 98 % , respectively .
americans seem to be much more religious than saudis , with 81 % describing themselves .
some differ from different countries ’ understanding of piety , like americans ’ belief that religiosity might be different from the middle east , and that they do not emphasize religion ’ s faith in religion .
this can also partly explain the difference between muslim countries .
but the gap between the saudis and the iranians , jordanians , and egyptians , as well as egyptians , is so large that it poses a challenge to saudi arabia as a highly conservative and religious society .
in fact , the message is less than words : only 28 % of saudis said they participate in weekly religious observance , with 27 % , 44 % , and 42 % , 44 % , 42 % , and 42 % in the us .
these findings , while contrary to popular perceptions of saudi culture , are not so surprising .
scholars of religious societies have long argued that the public ’ s overall religiosity is declining in the face of a single religious , or religious , state with the state .
that is why some argue that , because the national authorities imposed strict codes of conduct , so that they are no longer supportive of official religious institutions , such a view would have its own point .
so it is not surprising that living in egypt and jordan , who live in a state without coercion , is more religious than the saudis or iranians , who have had to beware of the `` `` righteous police '' that they face .
even when it comes to marriage , the views of many saudis are striking .
when it comes to arranged marriage , the subjects were almost 一半一半 , half thought that marriage should be followed by marriage , and 48 % thought that love was the basis for marriage .
this finding seems to reveal a strong desire for more personal freedom in the absence of rigid gender segregation and patriarchal 环境 .
finally , the result is that the saudis strongly support democracy , which is a source of conflict with saudi conservatism .
in the saudis , 58 % believed that democracy was the best form of government , 23 % disagreed , and 18 % do not express them .
in a country with a lack of realistic and historical context , the majority of the population ’ s support seems to contradict common sense .
democratic supporters are less religious , more integrated into secular , and more tolerant of others .
beyond survey data , historical experience shows that freedom will become even stronger when the autocratic monarchy governs with religious infrastructure .
in the late ottoman empire , the cult of religion in the late nineteenth century was a strong liberal nationalist in the late nineteenth century .
at the same time , anti-establishment and secular movements representing constitutionalism are gaining ground in iran - a powerful response to the authoritarianism of the iranian king and religious institutions .
with historical parallels with saudi arabia ’ s current situation , we can not rule out the possibility of reform .
the findings now show that the saudis are likely to begin demanding more transparent political and interventionist religions .
is america ’ s middle class really stagnating ?
cambridge – the challenge of raising the middle class ’ s household income has become an important focus of the presidential campaign in the united states .
everyone agrees that incomes for those at the top have been soaring for decades , thanks to huge gains from high-tech education and rising stock prices .
improved programs to help those who are in poverty – such as food stamps and 退休金 pension benefits – are generally supported .
but the public debate focused on how to help the larger ( and politically more important ) middle class .
to this end , improvements in existing government programs could help : expand closer access to market training , increase married women ’ s entry into the workforce , and reduce the tax rules to raise the need for older workers to hire older workers to raise productivity and wages .
but , while such programs should be a priority , they should not ignore the actual performance of middle-class households in the last few decades .
unfortunately , political debate has been distorted by misleading statistics , which grossly understate the benefits of middle-class families .
it is often said , for example , that average household incomes have grown slowly in the last few decades ( or even stagnation ) .
some us census figures seem to support this conclusion .
but more accurate government data suggest that the real incomes of households in the middle of the income distribution have increased by about 50 % since 1980 .
if a more appropriate adjustment against the cost of living is made , the benefits of the middle class will be substantially higher .
the us census bureau estimates that the total currency income of all sources of households , and to identify the 50 % distinction between the distribution of income distribution and the 50 % norm .
this is the median household income .
in order to compare median household income to a different time , the authorities value the dollar ’ s value from the consumer price index dividing the real median household .
the numbers show that the cumulative increase in income from 1984 to 2013 was less than 10 % , equivalent to less than 0.3 % per year .
every adult who has lived in the us during this period recognizes that the number of people in the united states has generally underestimated the benefits of the household .
one indicator of this number suggests that the government is also estimating that real hourly compensation for employees in the non-farm business sector rose 39 % from 1985 to 2015 .
the official census estimate suffers from three key problems .
first , it fails to recognize the changing composition of the population ; today ’ s families differ significantly from their families 30 years ago .
moreover , the census bureau ’ s income estimates are based on the assumption that middle-class households receive more than a growing number of government transfers and benefit from lower income-tax rates .
finally , the price index used by the census bureau does not reflect the important contributions of new products and products to us living standards .
consider the changing composition of households .
when the nonpartisan congressional budget office ( cbo ) conducted a detailed study of changes in household income from 1979 to 2011 , it expanded the definition of income , as well as 福利 benefits like food stamps and 实物 benefits like health care .
the study also subtracted federal taxes , compared to 19 % of middle-income households in the middle class in 1980 , to 11.5 % in 2010 .
in order to convert annual income to real incomes , the cbo uses consumer spending index , which many believe is better than the consumer price index .
the cbo also conducted a separate analysis of household size .
from traditional monetary income , the cbo found that real median household income increased by just 15 % between 1980 and 2010 , with the census bureau ’ s estimate .
but if the definition of income expands , the benefits of the tax cuts include , the cbo found that median household incomes increased by 45 % .
adjusting for household size would boost this gain to 53 % .
and even this much more significant increase may significantly underestimate the increase in real living standards .
in the sector ’ s calculations , dollar revenues are translated into a measure of real income by producing a price index that reflects changes in existing goods and services .
but this price index does not reflect new products or improvements in existing goods and services .
so , if all of the money ’ s income increases by 2 % a year ago , the price of all goods and services increased by 2 % , and officially estimated that real incomes are not changing , even if new products and important quality improvements increase our wellbeing .
indeed , the us government has simply not calculated the value created by internet services such as google and facebook , because these services are not purchased .
no one knows how much of these innovations and improvements to make us more benefits .
but assuming that these benefits are equivalent to just 1 % per year , the last three decades could have caused 35 % growth .
the amount of benefits that will be compared to the cbo estimates that real median household income is at close to 2.5 % per year over the last 30 years .
so the us middle class has performed much better than the statistical pessimists believe .
and , if there is a better policy , these families will be better off .
is it five years wiser ?
at the fifth anniversary of the september 11 , 2001 , attacks on the united states , the new attacks on the us are approaching .
these attacks , and their reactions , have already produced mutations of international relations , but there is no reason to think that further atrocities are less likely .
why is our security less secure than it was five years ago ?
within a week of the attack , president george w. bush declared a “ war on terror . ”
one unique advantage of the war is that it is clear and powerful that the us needs the intense counterattack that it needs .
moreover , the metaphor of war has been added to active mobilization , which is not just a country that suffered from attacks , but also its allies .
of course , no one doubts the us right to defend itself .
the legitimacy of violent counterattack has never been doubted .
but the metaphor of war is also unavoidable : when it comes to terrorism , it is misleading and counterproductive .
when we resort to war , it means a fight against people , people , or states .
it means that both territories and the people living there are considered adversaries .
in all of these cases , the concept of war , with us defense secretary donald rumsfeld , is not helpful .
even in the case of september 11 , 2001 , only the us military seems capable of coping with the challenges that the us military , rather than the international threat , should use police expertise instead of military tactics .
the negative consequences of this mistaken vision quickly became apparent .
it is now widely known that the us government is likely to be unconscious ( partly ) accepting the image of a terrorist organization with a strong command system – an image that the us military can attack and destroy .
but al – the term “ al qaeda ” or “ camp ” means that it is a place where it is more like a 琢磨不透 sphere of influence , a major area of influence , and a small number of small grassroots grassroots grassroots groups , which have few small , grassroots grassroots grassroots groups .
there is no evidence of the terrorist attacks in london , madrid , or bali after the september 11 , 2001 , terrorist attacks , or attacks on the us embassy “ 柯尔号 ” in 2000 , reflecting a “ center ” of coordinated action or order .
it is also wrong to conflate islamic terrorism with the basque 组织 organization , sri lanka ’ s tamil tigers , or the irish republican army .
these groups have a regional base and focused on the realization of national goals , while islamist terrorism seems to be a “ humiliation ” for a few centuries of attempts to implement the “ humiliation ” of the muslim world for centuries of colonization , economic development , and political weakness .
the goal of islamist terrorists is nothing less than the destruction of “ hegemony ” in the western world , though many muslim countries want to cooperate with the international community and cooperate on the creation of effective development strategies .
the most viable strategy against the threat of fighting islamist terrorism is , and it will continue to be the coherence of leaders in a coordinated manner , including cooperation among the police , which is necessary to isolate , weaken , or destroy them .
this is a long and difficult enterprise , but there is no alternative .
in reality , the metaphor of war continues to define the response of the us and its several allies .
the attraction of this metaphor may be attributable to the belief that americans are not just about their troops ( understandable ) , but also disproportionate faith in broad force .
in any case , the war on terror led us policymakers to double up violence against violence , which is unlikely to win the hearts and minds of the muslim world .
afghanistan is the only case where a military response can be understood : its government gave “ al qaeda ” a temporary 驻扎地 .

likewise , the appeal of war rules out the prospect of serious negotiations between israel , syria , and lebanon .
