is we ( again ) in the oil crisis ?
oil prices are rising well above $ 50 a barrel , partly because the conflict between iraq ’ s conflict and the nigerian labor policy , and the short-term oil supply shocks of the recent hurricanes , as well as the recent hurricanes in florida .
once these shocks were removed , oil prices may fall , but the speculative factors could keep them relatively high , thereby giving the world economic and stock-market weaknesses .
high oil prices encourage public discussion of future oil prices .
any public discussion will not produce a clear conclusion , but it risks exaggerating rumors of the risks that higher oil prices pose .
experts may say that recent price increases are due to supply factors , but the price increase will undoubtedly add credibility to more outrageous long-term rumors .
the current moment of exaggerated rumors is about developing countries , particularly china and india , which are experiencing rapid economic growth , and , owing to the absence of restrictions on emissions from the kyoto protocol , both countries are seen as 引起 demand .
the story ’ s assumption is that , with hundreds of millions of people chasing a big housing and a big home , we will run out of oil faster than we might expect .
is it based ?
to be sure , china , india , and several other emerging countries are experiencing rapid growth .
but experts find it difficult to identify the long-term effects of this development on energy markets .
many factors remain fuzzy : the growth rate of these countries ’ energy needs , the discovery of new oil fields , the development of technology , and the eventual replacement of oil by other energy sources .
but , for now and for the foreseeable future , it is people ’ s understanding of this story , not the uncertainty underlying them .
if people think that future oil prices will be higher , the price of oil is now higher .
that is how markets work .
if people generally believe that oil prices will be higher in the future , owners of the oil fields will postpone huge investments in development and expansion , and they may be able to keep oil production below capacity .
they would rather be able to invest and invest in oil prices , so they will contain growth in the supply of oil .
these expectations can be achieved as a result of nature , with rising oil prices and speculative bubbles .
but if owners of the oil fields think that oil prices will decline in the long run , they would now have the incentive to develop oil and expand production to sell more oil before the fall .
the resulting increase in oil supplies would reduce the price of oil , thereby strengthening expectations of further declines , and leading to the exact opposite of a speculative bubble : oil-price collapse .
the point seems obvious , but we do not want to think that oil prices are shaped by expectations of future oil prices .
for example , when the first world oil crisis began in january 1974 , oil prices doubled within days .
the immediate reason is that israel ’ s stunning victory in the yom kippur war has led arab oil producers to retaliate as retaliation .
the second crisis , in 1979 , was supposed to have caused the gulf ’ s oil supplies to the gulf ’ s oil supply and the subsequent iran-iraq war .
why , then , did the real oil price that followed the inflation rate remained or above its 1974 level ?
this is likely to be the case for speculative pressure , affecting opec and other oil producers .
while the changes in market psychology are difficult to understand , the main factors underpinning this irrational exuberance are almost always clear .
for example , scientists , including the computer pioneer jay 莱斯特 , published the limits of growth in 1972 .
the book ’ s question is whether the world will be subject to an international debate about whether oil and other natural resources are facing severe economic problems , and that opec ’ s failure to reduce output in 18 months appears to portend the emergence of these problems .
the second crisis was followed by the nuclear reactor , the nuclear reactor of march 1979 , which revived the atomic fuel movement .
the atomic energy regime was supposed to be the main technological bulwark against the world ’ s oil resources - suddenly suspected of being depleted by the end of the year .
after 1979 , fear of limits to growth and nuclear power ebbed .
but the current price increase reflects people ’ s eagerness to believe that the `` depleted oil run '' - this time attributed to china and india – even in the short term .
indeed , the international energy agency ( iea ) noted that the relationship between oil prices and inventory levels was decoupled from this september ’ s , and the price of actual oil is much higher .
the iea ’ s report calls this a `` structural shift in the market . ''
but the same changes in oil prices have occurred after the 1973 oil crisis , which , in both cases , remained high after the peak , undermining the growth of stock markets , housing markets , and the world economy .
let ’ s hope that the impact of the current spike in oil prices will not last .
but let ’ s hold not your breath ( but also for permanent preparation ) .
are we still evolving ?
new haven – many public policies are based on assumptions about “ human nature , ” and the recent enthusiasm is about how evolution shapes human behavior and psychology .
but that raises a number of important questions : are humans still evolving – if , if so , our biological properties are changing – or that modern civilization has made our evolution stall ?
in some of our traits , we do not need to speculate – for now , for several generations , as well as studies of thousands of samples .
although such studies have not yet been covered by most of the physical traits that people are interested in , they have also studied some of their properties .
so what are those studies ?
scientists use two approaches to study the sequence of genetic dna that is based on a particular health problem , and to compare the difference between them and others .
the genetic method can be measured by the evolutionary effects of hundreds and thousands of people who have accumulated in the generation , and the results are clear : humans are evolving in a relatively short period , and others chose different paths , depending on their environment and other specific circumstances .
through this approach , we recognize that the ability to digest milk in adults is actually the result of evolution in nearly 10,000 years – and has evolved repeatedly – and emerged from civilization , the goats , and the cultures that understand a lamb .
similar studies have also revealed the sensitivity of the sensitivity of alcohol to alcohol , as well as our immunity to malaria and leprosy .
some scientists , including me , have chosen another .
rather than seeking to find the genetic characteristics that have been accumulating and eventually manifest , we measure natural selection directly .
this approach can reveal the evolution of evolutionary choices , which can be reduced to a generation – and thus to answer whether modern civilization is a problem for evolutionary stagnation .
the message was clear : natural selection continues to operate in modern cultures .
whether such a choice will continue enough is long enough to bring about a major genetic change that will be answered only by next generations .
nevertheless , it is interesting to see where natural selection will shape humanity .
some of the answers are surprising .
we have measured natural selection in the us in massachusetts , massachusetts , where the long-term medical research on heart disease is based on the state of heart .
we have taken the example of a woman born from 1814 to 1956 as a sample of natural selection , and it was expected that women ’ s height will be a paltry two , and that women ’ s height will be only five years old , and the time for them will be five months old .
the study is surprising , given that , thanks to better nutrition and a variety of factors ( cultural factors also involve ) , women in developed countries are gaining height .
so why is this local woman ?
three :
first , we know that the lower age of the child ’ s baby , the risk of infant mortality increases , but modern medicine and health science have made it much less likely , reducing the risk of 低龄 children .
and we are expected to be shorter and shorter for women than they were in the first place .
in five other research projects , scientists found that women in the developing world ’ s two most sophisticated developing countries were shorter than ever ( and three other projects did not measure height ) .
while it is too early to say that this is a general trend , all signs point to this .
second , we found that the effects of natural selection have been the result of shorter and older women who are shorter and older .
but genes are only one of many factors affecting height and 头胎 age .
individual choice , nutrition , income levels , education , and religious affiliation will eventually be a factor in which factors like the one factor can be played .
when we estimate how much variation a person has occurred in a person ’ s body , the answer may be less than 5 % .
this means that 95 % of the variation in the variation comes from cultural influences and individual choices .
but for people living in such a complex modern culture , the impact of biological factors on certain characteristics , though small , will eventually become apparent in the long run and soon after .
third , these traits are often the result of genetic and environmental interactions .
one woman may carry a gene that is higher than average in her average , but she could eventually become a 矮个子 , given the children ’ s 缺乏营养 .
even if evolutionary processes continue and eventually change the genetic basis of height and death , we may not be able to see even more sophisticated women in ten years , because the factors of nutrition and culture are likely to offset or even conceal the role of genes .
so , even as we focus on the simple physical properties of height , natural selection of human selection turns out to be a multifaceted and nuanced process .
those affecting human behavior and psychology are more complex and more complex than our research capabilities .
in these areas , humans may be wiser than speculation .
the roots of argentina ’ s surprise crisis
new york – the currency scare that argentina experienced last month has shocked many .
indeed , the argentine government has made a series of risky moves since december 2015 , increasing its vulnerability .
what was not clear was when argentina ’ s economy will be put on trial .
when the test was tested , argentina did not .
when president mauricio macri took office in 2015 , argentina needed to address many macroeconomic imbalances .
early measures include eliminating exchange rates and capital controls and lowering exports of goods .
argentina returned to international credit markets after more than ten years of debt dispute with so-called vulture funds .
the macri government ’ s new macroeconomic approach is based on two pillars : gradually reducing the primary fiscal deficit , and an ambitious inflation-targeting regime , aimed at reducing annual price growth in just three years .
markets cheered .
the popular view that argentina ’ s government is eager to push for is that it has done what it needs to achieve faster and faster economic growth .
foreign direct investment should follow .
yet not .
by contrast , argentina fell into stagflation in 2016 , followed by a recovery in 2017 .
then , a few weeks ago , markets stopped cheering , expectations soured , and capital fled .
the peso fell 19 % against the us dollar in the first three weeks of may .
contrary to macri ’ s hopes , his reforms attracted short-term capital and financing in the form of short-term capital and financing , both foreign and currency , rather than foreign direct investment .
with the central bank ’ s negative responsibility , its policy is largely ineffective in keeping inflation below target ( annual inflation still stands at around 25 % in annual inflation ) , fueling speculative capital inflows , worsening its external imbalances , and increasing argentina ’ s vulnerability to external shocks .
as part of the inflation-targeting policy , the central bank ’ s central bank , through the sale of a central bank bond ( lebacs ) , relied on the bulk of the monetary base to expand the monetary base .
this means that the public sector is effectively financing a large primary budget deficit by issuing short-term central-bank debt ( 4.2 % of gdp and 3.83 % of gdp in 2016 and 2017 ) .
LEBCAS volumes are large , soaring by 345 % since december 2015 .
this may be sustainable if expectations for argentina were realized .
there are obvious trade-offs .
less aggressive hedge can stem the growth of the central bank ’ s debt that is currently dangerous , and it would block upward pressure on exchange rates ; but it would also lead to higher inflation .
nonetheless , attempting to reduce inflation and fiscal deficits at similar speeds should be a more prudent approach .
after all , macroeconomic policy decisions should not be based on the most optimistic scenario when they are expected to incur high costs .
ultimately , the currency crisis revealed argentina ’ s vulnerabilities .
looking ahead , argentina will face multiple risks .
first , the stock of lebacs remains large .
in the larger number of cases , argentina will have to look at financial markets .
this would increase the expected exchange-rate volatility , create opportunities for speculative investments in speculative finance , but discourage investment in the real economy .
second , because the public sector ’ s dollar-denominated debt increased significantly more than two years ago , the rise in exchange-rate risk has raised the sustainability of public-sector debt .
assessing the potential for argentina ’ s crisis after the crisis must emphasize several salient features of the crisis .
first , central banks lost 10 % of their total stock of foreign-exchange reserves within a month .
second , the annual nominal interest rate has increased to 40 % – the highest in the world , and could lead to a 滚雪球 of central-bank debt .
third , with the argentine shock most , macri announced that argentina would seek a spare agreement with the international monetary fund .
as a result , if argentina ’ s public sector is to run into debt crises in the coming years , it must accept the imf ’ s 督导 – the imf itself – as well as international creditors .
at that point , the imf ’ s financing exchanges often cause serious damage .
most worrying , the inflation-targeting approach that exacerbated argentina ’ s external imbalances has been reaffirmed .
so it is not surprising that a new round of real exchange-rate appreciation will be followed by a new round of real exchange-rate appreciation in 2019 .
next year , the presidential election will be good news for macri ; but the future of argentina is not .
ultimately , because macri has so far failed to bring down argentina ’ s economy to a path of sustained growth , it has increased argentina ’ s dependence on international creditors , and its government still needs to avoid a debt crisis .
to protect economic activity , tackling the vulnerabilities of fragility , and gradually reducing the primary fiscal deficit , should be maintained .
this means that the eventual recognition that trying to do more than lower inflation has led to costly risks .
a prudent approach also requires a gradual reduction in the stock of lebacs , recognizing that even greater inflationary pressure in the short term is the price of minimizing the risk that external imbalances will exacerbate and devalue the exchange rate further .
and it is certainly a mistake for macri ’ s government to continue reducing the soybean tax .
further tax cuts would increase the deficit , benefiting sectors that already enjoy rents .
the change in macroeconomic policy is not enough to put argentina on a path of inclusive and sustained economic development ; it is necessary .
at the outset of macri ’ s administration , he warned that he had chosen a high-risk approach .
unfortunately , these warnings were ignored .
the strategy we propose also carries its own risks .
but we believe that it provides a viable and more reliable path forward .
the way out of argentina ’ s new crisis
santiago – the late mit economist rüdiger dornbusch famously told his students that the world ’ s four countries , the world ’ s four countries , were rich , poor , japanese , and argentina .
no one worries that japanese money is buying control of the world .
but the world is worrying again about argentina .
argentina ’ s currency has just suffered another textbook attack .
on april 24 , ten-year yield on ten-year yield has been a mere 3 % since 2014 .
on the same day , investors began dumping argentine pesos and buying a soaring dollar to seek safety .
in order to stabilize the exchange rate after the peso ’ s depreciation , argentina had to raise interest rates to 40 % , while seeking help from the international monetary fund .
after all the turmoil , markets calm two weeks .
it is time to assess what went wrong , and what the country can – and must – do to prevent instability .
since december 2015 , a market-friendly reformer has governed argentina .
compared to the 骗子 and demagogues who have previously served ( after a long time ago , one of the millions of cash ) , president mauricio macri and his trained technocrats represent significant progress .
because macri ’ s team had no one in office , analysts and investors initially underestimated their political capacities .
so far , macri has shown that he is both a shrewd politician and a competent manager .
the currency crisis can not occur in better people .
but it did .
all of this began last december with a set of news conferences that were bound to be inconsistent with bad luck in the event of the 2018 inflation target to 15 % .
the revised figure has rightly acknowledged that previous goals were impossible without undermining the economy .
but , given macri ’ s chief of staff ’ s release from the economic team , the public fears about political interference .
two subsequent interest-rate cuts , totaling 150 basis points , have failed to redeem the associated loss of credibility .
but , in late march , argentina ’ s central bank began to intervene again , as it feared the impact of currency weakening on inflation , and it seems to be putting the exchange rate at around $ 20 .
investors naturally question whether this is tantamount to the changes in the policy mechanism .
given the failure of multiple economic “ shock therapy ” failures , macri decided to address the fiscal mess he inherited .
he has cut fuel and electricity subsidies , and some unnecessary spending , but simultaneously decided – a very plausible decision – to reduce the export tax rate .
as a result , fiscal deficits , while falling , remain stuck at 5.5 % of gdp .
governments have to borrow massively to cover the gap .
critics claim that fiscal adjustment is too slow to assuage markets , while markets do not seem to care about the country ’ s neighbors , and the overall budget gap is about 8 % of gdp .
yes , argentina ’ s current-account deficit exceeds 5 % of gdp , while brazil ’ s external position is essentially balanced .
but this merely shows that argentina ’ s private sector is investing in investment , while brazil ’ s private enterprises are rapidly deleveraging , with little investment or even almost non-existent investment .
in argentina , gradual fiscal adjustment seemed to be a viable response until the us interest rate soared and the dollar soared .
with renewed fears about emerging markets ’ credibility , the first hit argentina and turkey .
while the turkish government is panicking and the situation continues to deteriorate in the country , the argentine government 咬紧牙关 a bold act .
to the imf ’ s request for a political price , it must be done : only if argentina can persuade investors to be able to repay their debts , and the peso will not continue to plummet .
now the battle for deterrence is a shock to deterrence .
a sharp rise in domestic interest rates would help not only stabilize the peso , but also to attract investors to roll over large quantities of pesos that will expire in early may .
the rollover succeeded , and the peso stabilized at 25 .
what should be done next ?
it is attractive to carry trade nowadays , especially for long-term bonds , because this time has been the slowest real exchange rate for decades .
if the argentine peso turns out to be stronger than the real exchange rate ( presumably in the case of that ) , investors would gain handsomely .
so smart investors now bet on the peso , not vice versa .
but 40 % of interest rates can not be sustained for a long time without harming credibility .
the market must be persuaded to lower interest rates both reasonable and sustainable .
to avoid unsustainable 雪球 , central banks are likely to cut interest rates gradually after the details of the imf package are announced .
one good news is that the rollover risk of domestic bonds is not as large as some media headlines , because most of the bonds of most bonds are local banks and entities with large and stable liquidity needs .
the imf must act as soon as possible .
but it also must understand that too abrupt a fiscal adjustment could trigger a political backlash , jeopardizing the credibility of the entire package .
the peronist opposition , which has so far been weakened and divided , is hoping for a return to a backlash against the budget cuts and further increases in energy prices .
precisely because the international monetary fund is an international institution that transcends local politics , it should be more cautious , so that it should be prudent to avoid whatever ammunition it needs to prepare the party for the next presidential election in october 2009 .
this does not mean handing the argentine authorities a blank check .
at a time when inflation targeting and floating exchange rates are severely misaligned , occasional interventions are not uncommon .
the central bank has an obligation to ensure that market participants understand this .
the success of liberal reform in argentina extends far beyond the country ’ s borders .
populists of the left and the right , some of them authoritarian tendencies , are leading opinion polls in the run-up to the presidential election in brazil and mexico later this year .
with populists in power in the united states , europe , and asia , the return of the two most populous latin american countries will generate global influence .
with the right policies and strong support from the international community , argentina could prove to the world another viable way forward .
the destructive power of inflation
cambridge – when i was in argentina last week , i learned the destructive power of high inflation .
argentina ’ s annual inflation rate is about 20 % today , compared to about 40 % last year .
the central bank has worked hard to keep the economy on inflation , with the goal of achieving 5 % inflation in three years .
inflation in argentina is much higher in the past .
in the 15 years from 1975 to 1990 , annual inflation stood at 300 % , meaning that the average price level doubled every few months .
in 1989 , prices rose at an explosive annual rate of about 1,000 % , and inflation is finally under control .
in fact , inflation has largely disappeared .
i remember in argentina in the mid-1990s that there was little inflation .
at the time , the argentine peso was 盯准 , two currencies in the streets of buenos aires .
but the peso has since been pegged to the us dollar , with dollar contracts forced to convert into peso contracts by exchange rates .
in 2003 , the annual inflation rate was 40 % .
it fell to 10 % in subsequent years .
but , during néstor kirchner and his wife and successor , cristina fernández de kirchner , inflation rose to 25 % .
finally , the 2016 inflation rate returned to 40 % , and , in the meantime , distortionary price subsidies used to conceal the real inflation rate were canceled .
the recent high inflation rate , as well as the public ’ s memory of a higher rate of inflation in the past , has hurt argentina ’ s economy .
in order to compensate for high inflation , market interest rates rose , causing even the government to pay 25 % interest rates for short-term pesos .
lenders are reluctant to provide long-term credit for long-term credit , because the inflation surge will affect their bonds and loans .
households and businesses are reluctant to finance long-term investments in loans or loans to finance long-term investments , because the inflation surge would cause their interest payments to rise sharply .
in fact , argentina ’ s history of high and variable inflation has destroyed domestic mortgage markets , which can not be purchased through mortgages .
businesses are also reluctant to borrow , because they remember that previous inflation – and thus interest rates – contributed to a healthy business landscape .
life insurance has been undermined by high and uncertain inflation .
no one knows that the peso ’ s value in the future is worth the value of the peso , so who will buy insurance today ?
but when the inflation rate changes rapidly , even the current inflation rate is difficult to pin down .
the previous government tried to raise the public by issuing inflation estimates , and experts agree that the government ’ s publication is far below the real rate of price growth .
one argentine friend explained that the statisticians who tried to provide accurate measures to measure inflation would be fired by the government , with political allies that produce a low inflation figure .
they said that they “ will turn government data from technological matters into 行为艺术 . ”
when the government allows the argentine people to convert their pesos into dollars and carry out them , those with financial assets would invest in the us .
some told me that the us is investing in argentina ’ s wealth more than it invests in argentina .
thanks to this outflow of money , investment in argentina is low , undermining productivity and growth .
total capital formation represents only 17 % of gdp in argentina , compared to 23 % in china and mexico .
although president mauricio macri ’ s new administration is determined to reduce inflation and achieve price stability , doing so would have a high political price .
tight money and high interest rates depress investment , causing real gdp to shrink .
at the same time , there is no feeling that inflation has turned from 20 % to 15 % .
for that , the government must pay short-term political costs to achieve long-term economic benefits .
argentina ’ s experience holds two key lessons for other countries .
first , price stability is fragile , and inflation is likely to rise sharply .
second , high inflation will remain in the public ’ s memory and has long-lasting negative effects .
achieving price stability is important , but it is also important to maintain price stability by managing monetary policy and targeting a low inflation rate .
promise and peril for argentina ’ s g20 presidency
washington , dc – in june 2016 , argentina ’ s president , mauricio macri , seemed to be welcoming .
the g20 is just approved as the g20 chair in 2018 .
the us presidential race is growing , but hillary clinton won the democratic nomination and his election in november .
macri is optimistic that he will push his international agenda together with like-minded allies .
fast-forward to today .
macri must be worried about a more challenging international environment than he expected .
but the upcoming g20 presidency in argentina is not fraught with difficulties .
to be sure , confronting us president donald trump and his “ america first ” agenda will not be easy .
at last month ’ s g20 summit in hamburg , trump , trump has separated himself from other 19 leaders , including macri , who firmly supported the decision to withdraw from the paris climate agreement – an agreement that almost all of the international community believed would be irreversible .
likewise , trump has demanded renegotiation of the north american free trade agreement .
the renegotiation of the process began this month , and it would be impossible to end , with the us and canada ’ s relations with mexico and canada affected .
moreover , trump is not the only factor macri can control , but it will affect his ability to preside over the g20 .
likewise , the various conflicts in the middle east , the humanitarian disaster in africa , and the deteriorating situation in venezuela are likely to cause the consequences of crossing national borders .
latin america ’ s g20 members are coming to elections , and that is another source of uncertainty .
argentina will hold legislative elections this october , and mexico and brazil will hold presidential elections next year , and the populist candidates will have a strong performance .
so what can macri do to maximize argentina ’ s chances of a successful g20 presidency ?
trump , for his part , could use them to take advantage of the friendship that they had been turning into politics .
but this relationship also carries some risks , involving trump ’ s business relationships in argentina .
what is promising is that macri can and should work closely with civil-society groups and activists to ensure adequate space for engagement .
in hamburg , violent clashes with protesters led to nearly 200 police injured , and german insurance companies have paid $ 1,200 million .
the argentine g20 team must recognize the possibility of disruption , especially given the unpopularity of some of its government ’ s austerity measures , which now have a popular protest .
in broad terms , argentina ’ s g20 presidency remains an important opportunity to drive macri ’ s emphasis on international cooperation .
with mexican president michel temer ’ s final year in office , brazilian president michel temer was caught in scandals , with macri likely to aim to define argentina as a regional leader in latin america .
this leadership role could enable macri to revitalize the ailing mercosur , including several latin american countries , which would support national plans to reduce poverty through increased trade and investment .
if the uk-eu trade agreement is to succeed in this december , this plan – and argentina ’ s broader g20 agenda – will gain additional fuel .
argentina could also use its g20 presidency to develop a climate and energy program agreed by the united states , which excludes the us .
macri has declared 2017 “ renewable energy for renewable energy , ” promising argentina to deliver by 2025 by 20 % of its electricity demand through renewable energy .
moreover , the argentine government has joined the ambitious coalition coalition , a coalition that ensures the success of the 2015 paris climate agreement .
this is an informal organization , including germany , brazil , and the marshall islands , which have declared “ unwavering ” adherence to the paris agreement .
argentina is the first country to submit a more ambitious national climate change program than the paris agreement .
macri should use the credibility of these moves – and , of course , argentina ’ s progress on renewable energy targets and reducing deforestation – to encourage other countries to revise their commitments .
the timing is very good .
because the current commitment will not be enough to limit the rise in global temperatures to the “ significantly lower ” target of the paris agreement , the un will be in particular special talks in 2018 , encouraging countries to make more ambitious commitments by 2020 .
argentina can also link its g20 employment and technological goals with the goal of building a low-carbon economy .
to combine these agendas together , a key element is the completion of argentina ’ s long-term low-emission development strategy before the 2018 g20 summit .
after all , progress in these strategies – which are part of the paris agreement – sends a strong signal to investors seeking to reduce climate-related risks and take advantage of new opportunities in renewable energy , electric vehicles , and batteries .
there is no doubt that global instability will affect argentina ’ s g20 presidency .
but argentina ’ s own actions will also have an impact .
to maximize the chances of success in the g20 , macri should focus on working closely with argentina ’ s european and latin american allies , while strengthening its government ’ s credibility on the issue of the world .
argentina is not climate leaders
内乌肯 – argentina ’ s president , mauricio macri , said that the reserves of oil and gas in argentina – the world ’ s second largest – are not just critical to reviving argentina ’ s economy , but also a “ bridge fuel ” support for the climate transformation .
under argentina ’ s leadership , the g20 has signed a communiqué this summer to highlight the role of natural gas in “ support for the transition to a low-carbon energy system , ” which “ promises to expand significantly in the coming decades . ”
macri ’ s government has set a plan to attract $ 12 billion in investment in fossil fuels each year , predicting that revenues from oil and gas exports would exceed the current largest agricultural sector in argentina .
argentina does have huge reserves to be exploited : estimates of a whopping 6.1 billion barrels of crude oil , 583 trillion cubic feet of gas , are concentrated in 瓦卡 穆尔 .
but it is entirely illusory to use these resources to benefit environmental benefits .
developing argentina ’ s shale resources will not only require dangerous and expensive hydraulic fracturing ; it will also produce about 500 billion tons of co2 emissions .
according to a study by the oil change international organization , exploration of the gas emissions emitted by argentina ’ s shale reserves would limit global warming to 1.5°c above pre-industrial levels – a goal set by the paris climate agreement – which is the goal of the paris climate agreement .
the united nations commission on economic , social , and cultural rights recommended that argentina ’ s government “ reconsider ” unconventional hydrocarbon resources .
but , if argentina receives enough investment to build the infrastructure needed to make 穆尔 muerta a profitable – pipelines , railways , 石英 mining , and waste – argentina could be expected to be able to be fully exploited .
the possibility is increasingly likely that the world ’ s largest companies – including the united kingdom ’ s oil producer , which has a 50 % stake in the second largest oil producer in argentina – are already in the process of extracting ( Total ) , 壳牌 ( Total ) , shell ( Shell ) , norway , and malaysia .
and it will be not just climate .
the economic impact of the argentine gas program has led to a shift in household , business , and national resources to fossil-fuel companies .
argentina ’ s government has cut subsidies for private gas and oil heating for the g-20 .
meanwhile , macri ’ s government has increased the price of gas ( the dollar ) .
add to that a sharp fall in the peso ( which has depreciated by more than 50 % this year ) , and the price of gas for households and businesses in argentina over the last 24 months has risen by 13 % .
not surprisingly , many companies and households are unable to afford energy bills .
the price of the price has been devastating , and all opposition parties unite , demanding that tariffs return to the laws of november 2017 .
macri vetoed the law in may , and then replaced his energy minister .
households and businesses suffer , and oil and gas companies are still making money .
in fact , companies that are deliberately exploiting shale reserves have paid lavish subsidies , with other benefits : gas plans guarantee natural prices of unconventional natural gas ; and the reduction in the cost of a 协议 agreement with the major trade unions .
one result of these “ generosity ” arrangements is the shale-gas extraction company ’ s failure to deliver on its promised economic benefits .
according to a study by the argentine social environment and the energy justice coalition , while the annual investment in gas companies operating in 瓦卡 in 2016 is lower than in 2015 , the jobs they offer are still more profitable .
beyond trade unions ’ violations of labor rights , shale-gas extraction violates the rights of indigenous communities .
for example , indigenous people ’ s community protests against the situation they knew in advance are in their territory .
moreover , while more than 60 municipalities have passed local regulations banning drilling , the courts ruled that some of them were unconstitutional , because they abused public power – a violation of local democracy .
thus , argentina ’ s shale project undermines efforts to address climate change , threatening local democracy and indigenous rights , and without the economic benefits promised by proponents .
at the same time , macri ’ s government , hosting the g20 ’ s annual summit this week , has used the g20 forum to use natural gas as a sustainable energy alternative .
this is not climate leadership .
in terms of shale-gas ambition , however , argentina is hardly alone .
from china to the united kingdom , the g20 governments are developing large-scale industrial strategies centered on shale gas .
instead of exploring shale reserves , the world needs to stop new fossil-fuel projects , phasing out existing fossil-fuel projects , and implement ambitious clean-energy investments that focus on providing decent jobs and respect for their own development .
only by adopting and promoting such an approach can argentina credibly demonstrate climate leadership .
argentina ’ s big bang
frankfurt – last week , the newly elected argentine president mauricio macri launched an ambitious plan to revive , struggling , and plagued by high inflation .
in a dangerous environment , we can not underestimate the importance of this move to argentina and other countries . other leaders are watching carefully how to respond to their economic difficulties .
thanks to years of economic mismanagement , argentina ’ s economy has been underperforming for decades .
the previous government tried to avoid difficult policy choices , obscuring fundamental issues , and implement ineffective controls , leading to a massive misallocation of resources , destabilizing the country ’ s access to the foreign-exchange earnings needed to import bills , and the domestic shortages .
the recent fall in commodity prices has exacerbated this , depleting the economy ’ s remaining growth dynamism , while worsening inflation , deepening poverty , and spreading economic insecurity and financial instability .
in principle , governments facing this situation have five basic options to contain the crisis , waiting for measures to revive growth and employment engines .
· the financial reserves and wealth accumulated by the economy ’ s performance are better off .
· borrow from domestic and foreign lenders .
· direct cuts in public-sector spending , while creating incentives to induce lower private-sector spending .
· raise taxes by raising taxes and taxes and raising revenues abroad .
· use price mechanisms to accelerate the entire economy and the adjustment of trade and financial interactions with other countries .
by design and sequencing , this five measures would not only help to address the current economic and financial problems , but also create conditions for higher long-term growth , job creation , and financial stability .
through such arrangements , they can contain the spread of economic hardship , protecting the most vulnerable people , and provide better footing for future generations .
in practice , however , governments often face complex conditions that constrain these measures .
if policymakers are not careful enough , in particular , two problems could reinforce each other , potentially derailing the economy .
the first problem is that specific factors – whether real or perceived – lead to some options that can not be adjusted for adjustment .
some measures are likely to be ineffective : the country may not have any wealth or reserves available , and its leaders may be reluctant to do so .
other measures , such as fiscal adjustment , must be implemented carefully to avoid undermining growth targets .
the second problem is timing , which is difficult to ensure in the right sequence .
effective implementation requires understanding the key features of economic and financial interactions , including the feedback of feedback mechanisms , including the 行为学 aspects of the private sector .
all of this must be closely coordinated with the pursuit of supply-side reforms that can spur robust , durable , and inclusive growth .
that is where macri ’ s government has become a historical exception .
macri ’ s inauguration as president was an enormous step , with a bold – and highly risky – strategy , which will liberalize prices and eliminate quantitative controls as a central place in the five measures associated with demand management and financial assistance .
already , exports and currency controls have been lifted , income taxes have been cut , and exchange rates have been relaxed , allowing the peso to depreciate by 30 % .
in history , few governments have taken such a sequence , with few governments pursuing such a degree ; indeed , most governments are hesitant , especially when it comes to monetary liberalization .
when other governments adopt similar measures , they often wait until financial injections and measures to contain demand .
they worry that , if these problems are to be found , reform efforts will be derailed , and the public support needed to continue reform will be affected .
to revive argentina ’ s economy sustainably , the macri administration will need to act quickly to mobilize massive external financial support , opening new domestic resources , and implement deeper structural reforms .
if they do , argentina ’ s ambitious economic strategy will be a model for other countries , both now and in the future .
but if this approach fails – because it is not the right sequence or a surge in popular dissatisfaction – other countries will be even more hesitant to deregulate and achieve monetary liberalization when they are liberalized .
the resulting policy confusion is bad for everyone .
macri ’ s disappointing 首年
new york – argentina ’ s economy is struggling .
last year , the economy stagnated , with gdp falling by 2.3 % and inflation at nearly 40 % .
poverty and inequality are rising ; the unemployment rate is rising ; and foreign debt grew at a staggering rate and has not improved .
at least for president mauricio macri , this year ’ s performance was truly disappointing .
to be sure , macri faced a daunting challenge when he took office in december 2015 .
with the inconsistent macroeconomic policies of the previous president , cristina fernández de kirchner , the national economy had fallen into an unsustainable orbit .
the imbalances that result from these policies have weakened economic competitiveness and foreign-exchange reserves , putting the country in a balance-of-payments crisis .
but macri also has a flawed macroeconomic policy approach .
his government was supposed to address fiscal and external imbalances without undermining the social inclusion of the past decade .
but he has failed to do so based on four key pillars .
first , macri ’ s government abolished exchange-rate controls and shifted argentina to floating monetary policy , allowing the argentine peso to depreciate by 60 % relative to the dollar in 2016 .
second , macri ’ s government has reduced taxes on goods exports that the previous government was heavily placed on , and rescinded some import controls .
third , the central bank of argentina announced that it would pursue a system aimed at controlling inflation , rather than continuing to rely on taxes to finance the fiscal deficit .
finally , macri ’ s government has reached agreement with the so-called vulture funds and other holdout creditors that have been blocking the country from international credit for more than a decade .
in the wake of the agreement , the emerging market ’ s biggest debt problem ended , and argentina could begin to borrow heavily from new external borrowing to help resolve its considerable fiscal deficit .
while argentina has just lost an expensive lawsuit under the legal framework of new york ’ s law ( which was borrowed through this framework ) , the authorities would still choose to issue new debt under the framework .
macri ’ s macroeconomic policy approach , including the uncontrolled price of public services to freeze public services , and an amnesty program that would bring more revenue to the government – all based on controversial assumptions .
most important , the dramatic change in the policy process should be to create conditions for dynamic growth .
in these assumptions , currency depreciation can be encouraged to encourage the production of trade goods , aided by lower export taxes , thereby addressing external imbalances .
trading with the 秃鹰 fund should reduce the cost of financing , boosting investor confidence , thereby attracting foreign direct investment .
investment-led growth would help the entire economy .
these assumptions have not yet been borne out .
contrary to the government ’ s expectations , the peso ’ s depreciation has had a significant impact on consumer prices – as critics warn .
the central bank ’ s renewed focus on inflation is unlikely to help the problem , because it would undermine economic activity and deepen the suffering of the most vulnerable , for whom unemployment is higher than rising prices .
moreover , argentina ’ s fiscal deficit increased , owing to the decline in government revenues .
as macri ’ s critics have cautioned , the uncertainty surrounding his policies impedes investment , and the inflows of foreign direct investment have not yet changed significantly .
but the government has done the right thing : it rebooted the national bureau of statistics and census , which had lost its reputation under previous government intervention .
but the overall picture remains bleak .
in the end of macri ’ s first job , argentina faced the same macroeconomic imbalances as when it came to office , and the burden of external debt was mounting .
moreover , popular anger is heating up , because macri ’ s policies have enabled wealth to move away from the working wage .
protest movements abound , and even lead to delay .
on april 6 , the government faced the first nationwide strike .
as it stands , argentina ’ s prospects are uncertain .
external borrowing is becoming a serious problem , and it may intensify , as the fed ’ s continued interest-rate hikes exacerbate the cost of debt repayment .
unstable macroeconomic dynamics are reproducing similar imbalances .
for example , capital inflows associated with external borrowing are driving the peso to strengthen , threatening to create an important economic sector that creates jobs .
in the parliamentary election this year , macri ’ s government could try to stimulate economic activity by taking on more debt .
but this debt recovery is bound to be unsustainable and will sow the seeds for a more serious debt problem .
to avoid continuing debt turmoil , argentina must reduce its fiscal deficit .
but this can be achieved only if economic activity is sustainable and inclusive , and that will require more competitive economies .
under current circumstances , attempting to address problems through fiscal contraction will only exacerbate the recession .
macri ’ s government should adopt a sound and controversial economic presumption that builds on long-term macroeconomic strategies .
otherwise , in the absence of substantial medium-term corrections , argentina would only be trapped in a destabilizing debt path that leads nowhere .
getting fair for sovereign debt
the united states federal reserve debt
the decision has been heated , affecting bonds issued by various regions , which suggests that us courts can shape contracts in other countries .
since then , lawyers and economists have tried to clarify the implications of griesa ’ s decision .
does the authority of us courts really extend beyond america ’ s borders ?

this decision is a salutary retort of the decision by us judges , who seem not to understand the complexities of global financial markets , sends some important messages .
first and foremost , argentina ’ s debt negotiations are being put in place by a us court – but the fact that a british court has been countered by a british court – is a sharp reminder that a solution to market-based sovereign-debt crises could cause significant chaos .
before the griesafault , people often mistakenly assume that solutions to sovereign-debt repayment should be achieved through decentralized negotiations , without a strong legal framework .
but simple change , such as contract modifications , can not be overcome .
multilateral debt sometimes involves conflicting legal laws in different jurisdictions , a basic formula for creditors ’ votes – a basic formula that advocates of market-based approaches – do not solve complex bargaining issues .
nor is it certain to be used to exchange the exchange rate on debt issued by different currencies .
if these problems leave the market to the market , the strong bargaining power , rather than efficiency or ownership , will determine the outcome .
the consequences of these deficiencies are not just inconveniences .
delaying a debt restructuring could deepen and prolong the recession , as greece illustrates .
this brings us to the second lesson of the british decision .
the stakes are high , and the system is broken , so the market has no reason to do so .
the us has always prided itself on its “ rule of law , ” which makes wall street the largest sovereign-debt market .
but grillo ’ s ruling is based on special interpretations of some of the terms of argentina ’ s contract – a interpretation that , according to us , is likely to be around the court ’ s court decision .
grandiose us rule of law is no longer robust .
it protects the powerful against the weak .
“ the griesafault is a matter of several times complicated and complicated , ” even if it is revealed that it has not yet been revealed .
the us is better off taking action before the sovereign-debt market abandons new york .
china should be ready to pick up the situation .
today , china saves far beyond the us and is trying to bring shanghai to global financial centers .
given the collapse of the us system in the aftermath of the 2008 financial crisis , the viability of this ambition is stronger .
but , if shanghai is to become a leader in sovereign lending markets , china should understand weaknesses in other regional legal frameworks and design more efficient , fairer alternatives .
the final implication of the british court ’ s decision is that all countries should note .
it is urgent that the un should re-establish a multilateral legal framework for sovereign-debt restructuring .
while the us is working to undermine , the british ruling reminds us that us judges are not the world ’ s judges .
finally , this is likely to leave wall street uncomfortable ; but , for many countries that depend on sovereign debt , it is good news for the rest of the world .
argentina ’ s bumpy ride
santiago – when our planes are about to enter the country ’ s skies in argentina , it has been suggested that , “ please are wearing it , because it is a bumpy ride . ”
“ we ’ re not . ”
investors who want to do business in argentina often hear similar warnings .
this is a country where scholars are models of financial crisis .
the country ’ s greatest financial crisis in 2001 destroyed the entire local banking system and triggered a default on government debt .
at the time , the economy collapsed by a whopping 18 % , while unemployment soared to above 22 % .
latin america ’ s largest banks in latin america predict that argentina ’ s gdp growth next year is 3.2 % , significantly below 6 % in 2011 .
there is also the problem of inflation .
official data have lost their citizens ’ trust , while private analysts estimate that the price index is rising at an annual rate of 25 % .
although all of these are the result of serious assessments of serious economists , one must again have reservations about these economic projections .
since the crisis began a decade ago , argentine policymakers have almost violated the principle that all economic-policy textbooks must abide by .
at the same time , both local and foreign economists have warned that if this extreme move continues , the consequences will be serious .
but argentina achieved rapid growth , and per capita income has doubled since 2002 .
energy policy is a perfect example of wrongheaded government decision-making .
argentina ’ s government insists on freezing gas prices with inflation .
the price was artificially driven down , so that consumers don ’ t care too much , and investors stop pouring money .
as a result , argentina , once a major exporter of natural gas , seeks gas imports to cover domestic shortages .
in the last decade , argentina has been a highly favorable external environment , with rising global commodity prices and technological innovation making agricultural output significantly higher .
the boom in neighboring brazil has also raised demand for a wide range of argentine products .
with tax increases and the debt burden after a decade default , the government began a consumer binge : real public spending grew at double-digit rates since 2002 .
at the same time , central banks maintain low interest rates , so the cost of lending is essentially zero or negative at a zero rate .
in this environment , argentine consumers are naturally consuming , and corporate profits rose .
not long ago , i met a number of foreign investors in argentina .
their programs everything from paper mills to supermarkets .
after listening to the stories that they were trying to do , they asked why they were forced to invest in argentina .
the consensus i received is “ because they make a lot . ”
the question now plaguing argentina is whether this era of prosperity has reached an end .
you can ’ t feel any of the air ’ s pain in buenos aires ’ s lifetime , and it can not be inferred from voters ’ behavior by voters ’ behavior this october , because they seem to support president cristina kirchner ’ s reelection president in october .
but signs of economic deterioration are already visible .
while import imports remain strong , commodity prices are falling sharply in argentina , owing to slower global growth .
investors are also in the throes of a weakened peso , fearing a weaker peso .
capital is flowing out of the country , and government reserves are being depleted .
to contain the outflow of dollars , the central bank is forced to raise interest rates .
this , together with the gloomy international outlook and the need to move toward fiscal austerity after the election , will slow .
a bumpy ride can be acceptable , if only smoothly .
for the central bank , however , it will be a challenging period .
the vultures ’ victory
new york – the recent decision by the united states to appeal to the court of appeals could put global sovereign-debt markets at risk , even if the us is no longer viewed as an ideal place to issue sovereign debt .
at the very least , it has made it impossible to restructure all debt under the standard debt pact .
in the process , the basic principle of modern capitalism , once the debtor can not repay its creditors , is subverted .
trouble has emerged more than a decade ago , when argentina had no choice but to devalue its currency and default .
under the existing system , argentina is in the midst of a rapidly declining downward spiral in greece and the rest of europe .
the unemployment rate soared , austerity , rather than restoring fiscal balance , only to amplify the economy .
devaluation and debt restructuring are effective .
in the years since the start of the 2008 financial crisis , argentina ’ s annual gdp growth was 8 % or higher , one of the world ’ s fastest-growing countries .
even previous creditors benefited from argentina ’ s economic rebound .
argentina adopted an innovative and innovative approach to new debt for new debt – roughly 30 cents per dollar of the dollar – plus the gdp-linked bond index .
the faster argentina grew , the more it paid to the size of its former creditors .
the interests of argentina and its creditors constitute a consensus : both sides want growth .
this is akin to the “ chapter 11 ” restructuring of us corporate debt , which used bonds to pay for equity , with bondholders becoming new shareholders .
debt restructuring usually creates conflict among people .
that is why countries need bankruptcy laws and bankruptcy courts to address domestic debt disputes .
but there is no such system in international debt disputes .
once upon a time , such contracts were forced by force intervention , with mexico , venezuela , egypt , and others learning the lesson in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries .
in the aftermath of the argentine crisis , the bush administration vetoed proposals to establish a mechanism for sovereign-debt restructuring .
as a result , we are not even trying to engage in fair and effective restructurings .
poor countries are at a severe disadvantage when they are in bargaining for multilateral lenders , which are often backed by strong domestic governments .
normally , debtor countries will be paid hard to pay so much that they are bankrupt after a few years .
economists tried to avoid this outcome by restructuring the depth of the bonds associated with gdp-linked bonds .
but some “ vulture ” funds , particularly the billionaire 对冲 基金 , led by the billionaire paul singer , have taken argentina ’ s agony as an opportunity to capture huge profits for the sake of argentina ’ s people .
they bought old bonds at a fraction of their face face , and then try to force argentina to pay the same bonds by litigation .
americans see how financial firms put their own interests ahead of these countries – and the world .
the vultures created a new level of greed .
their litigation strategy took advantage of the standard contractual clause ( called pari passu ) , which was intended to ensure that all creditors receive equal treatment .
if this principle is applied , no one would accept restructuring .
this is not a fresh start – and it involves myriad disturbing consequences .
in the debt crisis , blame often falls on debtors .
they borrowed too much .
but creditors ’ responsibility is as much as a debtor – and too little , too cautious .
indeed , lenders should be experts on risk management and assessment , and , in this sense , responsibility should be borne by them .
default or debt restructuring should make creditors more cautious in lending decisions .
the consequences of this injustice may be long-term .
after all , the development of china , which accounts for the long-term benefits of the people ’ s long-term interests , should be prepared to be prepared by issuing bonds in the us financial system , and the us courts – and many other parts of its political system – seem to have superseded the public interest .
one good advice that countries will receive is no longer terms of pari passu in the future debt compact , at least not more specifically .
the pact should also include cacs , enabling vulture funds to hold up debt restructuring .
when enough creditors approve the restructuring plan ( in argentina , 90 % of the country ’ s debt holders agreed to restructure ) , and others will be forced to agree .
the fact that the imf , the us justice department , and anti-poverty ngos all joined to the vulture funds is telling .
but the same is true of the court ’ s ruling , which has little to do with their views .
for those in the developing and emerging markets , there are now new reasons to oppose the globalization of rich countries , particularly its financial sectors , to protect rich countries ’ interests .
after the global financial crisis , the panel on reform of the international monetary and financial system urged us to create an effective and fair system for restructuring sovereign debt .
america ’ s courts have a heavy economic cost and demonstrated why we need such a system now .
argentina ’ s energy dilemma
buenos aires – president cristina fernández ’ s announcement of almost all of the spanish energy producer ypf at the argentine energy producer ypf , which has raised legal alarms around the world .
indeed , without massive investment in the energy sector , this will not solve argentina ’ s energy problem .
repsol acquired full control of ypf in 1999 ; in february 2008 , it transferred some equity to the peterson group , which now stands at 25 % .
repsol now holds 57 % of the shares , with the rest owned by stock-market investors .
argentina ’ s government will expropriate 51 % of shares , leaving repsol with just 6 % .
in the 2008 stock sold , two major stockholders agreed to distribute at least 90 % of future profits in cash .
the decision was intended to enable the peterson group to pay for the debt of the bank and to repsol , and , in the stock of purchases , the peterson group did not pay , instead of paying them .
such a dividend is very high in the world oil industry .
over the last decade , ypf ’ s oil reserves fell sharply ( as were most oil companies operating in argentina ) , because investment in oil exploration was slashed .
meanwhile , gas accounts for 51 % of energy consumption , with oil accounting for 32 % , 17 % of coal , renewable energy , and 17 % .
worldwide , gas accounts for only about one-quarter of total energy consumption – for example , at 27 % in the united states , and 9 % in neighboring brazil .
of course , in other countries ( qatar , algeria , the united arab emirates , iran , and russia ) , gas also accounts for more than half of energy consumption , or even more than 60 % .
but their situation is very different from that of argentina : they all have the reserves of at least a dozen years .
argentina , which is highly dependent on natural gas , is shrinking its reserves , with roughly eight years of production .
using imports to offset the decline in reserves – about half of reserves and oil reserves are already being used – it would cost more than $ 300 billion per year .
indeed , after two decades of cheap , plentiful energy supplies ( and even available available access to exports ) , new expensive , scarce , and imported energy cycles have begun to decline by one-third since 1998 , and gas production has fallen by 15 % since 2004 .
today , argentina ’ s biggest challenge is to maintain self-sufficiency through heavy investment in land and mining .
meanwhile , argentina must change its consumption model , relying more on hydroelectric , nuclear , and wind power .
while the potential for unconventional resources is unlimited , the cost is high , requiring investment in the next five years .
most likely , in the short term , increased imports of liquefied natural gas and other 冉柳 will continue to increase pressure .
last year , the external energy deficit reached more than $ 3 billion , and this year will likely double .
one important question is whether the argentine government ’ s decision to nationalize the country ’ s YPF51% 股权 is the best way to restore self-sufficiency to oil and gas production , which is the best way to attract the capital needed to explore conventional energy exploration .
argentina also has tremendous potential to produce unconventional gas resources , because it has the world ’ s third largest reserves , after china and the united states .
but , alongside argentina ’ s conventional resources , the resources are to be developed , not themselves .
argentina ’ s warning to 准
buenos aires – the united states and germany have taken the lead .
recently , the growing tensions between the eurozone ’ s northern and southern countries have exacerbated the euro crisis , which has exacerbated the euro crisis , which has led some to consider the option of the past : perhaps only some countries ’ withdrawal can save the euro .
indeed , talk of exit from the eurozone , particularly in some southern european countries , is urgently needed to regain competitiveness , but first consider the real costs of exiting the euro .
but , with a new devaluation of the financial turmoil , the euro was a complete 另一回 , with most economists having no idea that , in the first three months of argentina , the argentine peso had depreciated by 30 % in the first three months of the country ’ s exchange rate .
despite the obvious differences between argentina and the european economies , the argentine exchange-rate roller-coaster episode provided a lesson for european leadership .
will europeans also want their own version of the “ peso ” ?
europe ’ s leaders should , at least , be able to do “ salvation ” contracts , which would impose restrictive restrictions on commercial banks ’ business , ( c ) debt restructuring , which ( d ) , and impose strict controls on capital and exchange rates .
let ’ s take closer look at each step , first and foremost for the creation of a new currency , in order to establish its position , which will require the creation of prices , currency , and financial contracts , and the imposition of exchange-rate and financial contracts .
as a result of severe asymmetric balance sheets , there is a massive redistributive effect of wealth and wealth redistribution .
argentina ’ s “ restructuring ” of bank deposits on deposits is based on the sacrifice of large depositors , resulting in social unrest .
second , once a country exits from the eurozone , a bank panic would trigger a bank panic , depositors scramble to run a run , and move their money into foreign currencies .
in fact , a year before argentina ’ s exit from its exit system , people began to argue that capital was on the rise , and , in turn , it accelerated the decoupling process in the peso and the dollar – and even faster in the eurozone ’ s economic integration .
as a result , selective deposit freezes would be the only option for avoiding bank failures .
here , argentina is a case in point .
when all deposits were frozen on all deposits in november 2001 , the financial crisis was exacerbated by the absence of liquidity in the market .
third , while “ 化 ” eliminates the loss of domestic foreign-currency debt in balance sheets , foreign debt can not be restructured unilaterally .
exit from the dollar would require restructuring national and corporate debt .
in fact , argentina ’ s government default on the currency board ’ s exchange-rate regime , while repealing the erm , was a long process .
ultimately , most companies are not bankrupt , mainly owing to the fourth : capital controls for companies ’ foreign debts and legal protections .
of course , regulation is necessary .
the devaluation of the currency is also intended to boost exports and regain market competitiveness .
but , in the short term , the change in the dynasty ’ s transformation is uncertain , with no return to a debt renegotiation of capital markets , which will require a relatively small amount of controls on capital flows , and some controls are more stringent .
for europe , controls on capital flows are the only way to avoid offshore finance , following the freeze on bank deposits and currency convertibility .
after all , it is impossible to say that exiting the euro while not regulating capital flows is a chimera .
some observers suggest that , given the lessons of argentina ’ s case , it would be used to introduce the depreciation of its own currency in terms of the price and price of a certain product , without abandoning the euro altogether .
i believe that this is not feasible .
at the time , argentina did issue the money and maintain a stable exchange rate against the us dollar before abandoning even a 2001 exchange-rate regime .
indeed , one can imagine that such a monetary regime would be difficult to avoid as a result of the currency ’ s lower exchange rate , which ultimately failed .
argentina ’ s exit from the dollar is a disaster , leading to a large number of contracts , wealth redistribution , bankruptcies , depositors run bank runs , exchange rates , and restrictive restrictions on capital flows in the short run .
even so , it would be better than introducing a new greek “ drachma . ”
because argentina ’ s currency board never shut down the peso , the demand for the peso is still high .
for countries that leave the euro , they will have to create demand for new money – a far more chaotic situation .
a rio report card
new york – the world ’ s best scientific publications , one of the world ’ s good publications , have just been released in the run-up to the rio+20 summit on sustainable development next week .
if the three major treaties signed by the first rio earth summit in 1992 were followed : climate change ， , biodiversity - F , 防治 , prevention of desertification – can humanity avoid being expelled ?
a generation has known that the world needs to change course .
we need to capitalize more on low-carbon alternatives like wind , solar , and geothermal power , rather than continue to rely on fossil fuels to fuel the world economy .
we need to adjust agriculture and fisheries to meet the capacity of the environment , rather than hunting , fishing , and clearing trees without regard for the impact on other species .
we need to end extreme poverty and reduce the rapidly growing fertility rate in the poorest parts of the world , without allowing services , education , and basic health care to be excluded from the family .
in short , we need to recognize that today ’ s seven billion people are likely to reach nine billion in the middle of the century , and that all of the high-tech global economies that are driving their high-tech global economy have a strong capacity to destroy their planet ’ s life-support systems .
but the consequences of individual behavior are so far removed from our daily life that we may be overwhelmed by the cliff .
when we opened our computers and lights , we do not know how much carbon emissions will be created .
when we eat our meals , we don ’ t know how much deforestation contributes to unsustainable farming .
when billions of small 小事 causes the rest of the planet to famine and floods , there is a basic awareness of the dangers of the world ’ s poorest people , such as mali and kenya , who are most vulnerable to the global network .
the agreement reached in 1992 in the first rio summit was good : thoughtful , far-sighted , public-spirited , and focused on global priorities .
but the agreement has not saved humanity .
these treaties are overshadowed by the shadow of our daily political , delusional , and media cycles , which , year after year , have been conducted to implement these treaties , but they do not ignore , delay , and debate legitimacy .
for two decades , our efforts have yielded only three failing grades .
so , did there be no other way ?
international law involves lawyers and diplomats , but it does not attract engineers , scientists , and community leaders in the frontier of sustainable development .
it is rife with technical provisions concerning oversight , binding obligations , 附件 一及 countries and thousands of other jurisprudence , but without a language to discuss their own survival .
we have thousands of documents , but they can not be candid .
do we want to save ourselves and our children ?
why not ?
we must speak decisively at rio+20 at rio+20 , and thus to address and act , rather than bickering and defensiveness .
because politicians follow public opinion , rather than lead public opinion , they can not count on elected officials to save the public without the public ’ s knowledge of the public .
few people can be heroic , so it is impossible to wait for politicians to make decisions .
so , rather than a new treaty , binding provision , or political commitment , it calls for action around the world .
the world ’ s unanimous demand for sustainable development over the center of global thought and action , especially to help young people cope with the challenges of the triple temperature , will determine their defining nature .
what we need is not a new treaty , but a special development goal that will motivate a generation to act , or the sdgs .
as the millennium development goals make us aware of extreme poverty and contributed to an unprecedented global effort to fight aids , tuberculosis , and malaria , the sdgs could bring today ’ s young people acutely aware of climate change , biodiversity loss , and desertification .

arms , or allies ?
riga – when many in latvia are surprised to sell a fraudulent assault on the boat to russia , other eu member states have begun to view russia as a potential military purchaser .

the eu council ’ s common position on arms exports is legally binding for all member states .
indeed , under the “ 瓦森纳 arrangement , ” the member states can choose whether to export weapons .
the eu ’ s common position on arms exports has brought more information to us , higher transparency , and closer consultation , while coordinating a series of treaties and arms controls associated with arms exports .
but the potential of this mechanism remains incomplete .
consultations are currently confined to the two countries , while failing to guide guidelines for consultation – and not to demand any final agreement on arms exports .
the effectiveness of this consultation mechanism is extremely difficult to assess .
according to a common position clause , one would have to consult with other member states that previously refuse to grant a similar license to permit a similar license .
but the relevant provisions are not clear .
more important , it does not require that exporting countries consult with other countries that might be concerned about the exports .
the question of arms exports to third countries has always plagued the eu .
at the heart of the problem is the core interests of the member states ’ interests – the competition among european arms producers , and the strategic importance of defense markets – and the lisbon treaty , which focuses on strengthening and consultation mechanisms .
if we want the spirit of the lisbon treaty , solidarity must be viewed as an important political tool , with a european defense policy that serves the collective interests of the collective good .
the pursuit of national policies on technology transfer is contrary to the goal .
it is therefore necessary to articulate a clearer definition of the consultative mechanism , and eu member states that export arms must consult with all stakeholders , not just those that have issued ( or banned ) licenses .
by agreeing on the predictability and stability of third countries ’ actions , the eu could finally build a common policy toward arms exports .
but the process of establishing a common policy toward third countries is not isolated , but also a common and internationally competitive european defense market .
this means that cooperation with non-eu countries can not be undermined by cooperation and common principles within the eu .
consultations will help to defuse misperceptions – often in the media ’ s 添油加醋 , even though transactions are far from being reached – and thus strengthen solidarity among eu members .
the eu should play a more important role in situations where member states disagree .
for example , member states can consult on sensitive or contentious issues within political and security committees .
this would strengthen the eu council ’ s common position , which has already raised some principles for the export controls on military technology and equipment .
for nato , the question of the alliance ’ s deliberations has been defined by the north atlantic treaty ’ s april 4 declaration : “ whenever any one party believes it is full of a country ’ s territory , political independence or security is threatened . ”
but article 4 is just about imminent threats .
the decision by a nato member state can affect other allies .
military equipment and technology transfer in third countries could affect regional security , and therefore will be reassessed .
the north atlantic council can certainly serve as a forum for increased solidarity among member states , and to avoid misperceptions and avoid misperceptions .
at the bottom , the political and partnership committees and/or national military chiefs can be used as preliminary consultations .
these issues are at stake in all of these countries , so discussion should not be confined to two countries .
given that arms trade and technology transfer will undoubtedly lead to many moral and ethical questions , it must also be discussed openly and strengthened .
solidarity can not be achieved if many important institutions are excluded .
toward a world of immunization
abu 纽约 york – for a child , vaccination vaccines are just a few tears ( perhaps a few tears ) .
