together with the abu dhabi 阿勒纳哈扬 al Zayed al thani , we will say the great significance of a global summit to ensure that all children gain access to vaccines , which will be held this week in abu dhabi .
vaccines protect people for lifelong protection .
they are the cheapest investments in the world .
vaccines have eradicated smallpox , eradicated polio , and saved millions of children from measles , diphtheria , tetanus , and other deadly diseases .
thanks to the vaccine ’ s role , the number of children dying before five years old died from 2000 to 2001 , and it was achieved in terms of a massive increase in the planet ’ s population .
disease will erode the most of the world ’ s closest : people ’ s energy and talent .
the costs are particularly high for poor countries seeking to gain a foothold in the global economy .
and when children are healthy , households can escape from heavy health care , and spend more money on food and education .
healthy children can attend school and acquire better learning capabilities , and become more productive adults .
new research shows that vaccines improve the cognitive development of children , improve labor productivity , and help a country ’ s overall economic growth .
but more than 22 million children lack access to basic vaccines , and the basic vaccines are granted benefits for high-income countries .
these children live in the poorest and most remote communities , and the risk of disease is highest .
children born in low-income countries are 18 times more likely to die before their fifth birthday than children in high-income countries .
ending this inequity is the largest and most successful project in history – the millennium development goals .
in 2000 , leaders gathered in the united nations for eight millennium development goals , agreed to reduce extreme poverty and hunger , fight water security , improve water security , and more rights , expand access to education , and empower girls and women .
the achievement is remarkable , but much remains to be done – and now is not nearly 1,000 days away .
the increase in global immunization coverage will accelerate the development of the millennium development goals and create momentum for the post-2015 development agenda .
representatives of the world health assembly , representing the world health organization ’ s 194 member states , agreed on a shared vision of a vaccine that has been called a decade of vaccines – a decade of vaccines – to create a world without vaccines , and the entire benefits of immunization are reaching everyone , regardless of who is , where .
eradicating polio will be a milestone on this vision .
the summit will launch a new , comprehensive plan , and the world will have a clear roadmap to build a polio-free world in 2018 .
the plan goes hand in hand with the overall effort to improve immunization coverage of measles , pneumonia , and rotavirus .
indeed , we are witnessing a strong immune system to protect our fight against polio in the fight against polio , providing access to the world ’ s most vulnerable mothers and children , for new vaccines and basic health services .
if we succeed , we will save 20 million lives by the end of 2000 , prevent nearly a billion disease , and save $ 120 billion alone .
and , in the process of lifting people out of the disease burden , we can unlock immeasurable human potential .
the millennium development goals and a decade of vaccines have shown that the goal of working together will have far-reaching differences .
they demonstrate the strength of cooperation among the un , governments , development agencies , civil society , foundations , and the private sector .
let us start with a shared vision that promises to achieve all our children ’ s access to a fair start with vaccines .
this generation will thank us – as will the next generation .
arrogance and authority
washington , dc – the recent hearing is that the heads of the us and european central banks have done what they did in the 2007-2008 crisis : “ we have done well .
in their view , the government ’ s behavior to help stabilize the financial system has helped to stabilize the situation .
and what can be blamed for the us federal reserve ’ s asset purchases , which have since turned to the us treasury ( and then to the us treasury ) ?
but it is problematic to define this issue in the sense that it is a mistake to say that the short delusion is misplaced ; and , in the end , it would create an arrogance of arrogance and the ultimate erosion of the central bank ’ s authority .
indeed , the real cost of that crisis can not be measured by profit losses from any central bank , or by a series of actions by the us treasury ’ s troubled asset relief program .
if the real costs were to be taken , the us loses 800 million jobs , and employment fell by 6 % from the peak – the difference between the two largest and the worst of the recession after 1945 .
another cost is the increase in net federal government debt in the hands of the private sector – the most accurate measure of government debt .
with the us congressional budget office ( in january 2008 ) and the post-crisis forecast in the aftermath of the crisis , the increase in the volume of the debt amounts to an astonishing 40 % of gdp .
indeed , the cause of the fiscal crisis that led to america ’ s current fiscal crisis ( and the prospect of a further reduction in government spending ) is simple : the crisis in the united states has made the us public costly , and a huge negative impact on the global scale .
much of the public debt in the us and other countries is not the result of unbridled fiscal stimulus , but from the tax cuts that have triggered the recession ( plus the bush administration ’ s tax cuts for the richest , and the country ’ s long-term fiscal policy , which has kept the country ’ s budget on the top ) .
the final cost is millions of homeless people and livelihoods , some of which will have some impact on their entire lives .
but the problem is not whether the fed or other central banks should seek to prevent the collapse of their banking systems .
if the consequences of the banking crisis are to be understood , the best example is the 1930 ’ s ( and that of bernanke ’ s research field ) .
if there are two options for any particular period : either the government is bailed out or letting it collapse , the former will be the choice .
but , more broadly , just as the president of the federal reserve bank of atlanta has pointed out last week at a public forum organized by the organization of the organization , we should not attempt to run a banking system built on “ private gain , ” much less in the form of “ private gain , ” which is largely inefficient .
by contrast , the private gain can be measured directly by executive compensation .
from 2000 to 2008 , the managers of the us ’ s 14 financial institutions received a total of $ 26 billion of cash grants ( including wages , dividends , and stock sales ) .
by now , the top five of the top income has been collected by nearly $ 2 billion , and they happened to be the result of creating the entire risky structure of assets and pushing the financial system to the brink of an abyss : 花旗集团 花旗集团 , a major driver of the us treasury , and the us treasury and bear ( lehman brothers and bear stearns ) .
the public ’ s losses are enormous : if only the federal government ’ s debt growth is assessed , perhaps $ 6 billion would be .
but the bank bosses insist that they should be allowed to run a more leveraged global business , and pay for their compensation – regardless of risk – to pay for them .
there are some of the world ’ s most top independent financial researchers , and we have seen such issues in the long run , and we have studied the situation in recent years , according to anat admati of stanford business school .
in their view , big banks should have more reserves – roughly 30 % of their capital .
but bankers are strongly opposed to this advice ( because they may well reduce their income ) , while central bankers hold similar positions ( they are persuaded by bankers ) .
with an independent central bank run by professionals from the political class , there are many benefits .
but when those who govern in the financial institutions insist that they are doing well in the crisis , claiming that all problems will be resolved , allowing the financial behemoths of the crisis to go unpunished , their credibility will inevitably be undermined .
all of this should worry central bankers , because their credibility is all they are .
congress has created the fed , and can dissolve it .
by ignoring the damage that large leveraged banks can create , a crisis of “ bad things ” is a symptom of the mounting political pressure on central banks .
artificial intelligence and globalization
today ’ s conventional wisdom is that the rise of india and china will be the only important factor driving global jobs and wages in the twenty-first century .
wealthy workers in rich countries will see the erosion of their competitive edge in the hands of a highly managed contender from asia , latin america , and even one day in africa .
this is a good thing , full display of power politics and a dramatic human life .
but i want to know that there will be another factor in the coming decades whether there is another factor for our careers : the exponential growth of ai applications .
i have a narrow range of contacts with ai : for more than 500 years of chess .
you may have no interest in chess , long considered the ultimate intellectual movement .
even so , the remarkable developments of the chess world over the past decade have been enough to raise your attention .
chess has been the centerpiece of research in ai .
although in principle , chess is solvable , its calculations are far more complicated than anyone ’ s imagination .
it is only a slight exaggeration to say that the methods that played out in chess games are more than atoms in the universe .
for most of the twentieth century , programmers were conspicuously unsuccessful in designing chess computers that could compete with the top human .
the intuition , imagination , and sequencing of human chess master can easily outweigh the brute force of computers .
the computer was gradually progressive , but it is still far from that of the top humans .
so we think .
then , in 1997 , when it was destined to be remembered as a historical milestone for modern human history , ibm ’ s “ deep blue ” computer had triumphed over world chess champion kasparov kasparov .
perhaps a proud kasparov was more stunned than anyone , and he was sure that ibm ’ s team was bound to do so .
he told journalists that he felt “ the hand of god ” is guiding his computer opponent .
but the ibm team was not cheating .
by contrast , by combining the original software and powerful parallel capabilities , they have managed to create a real entity with silicon 晶片 , which is so sophisticated that the machine has so elaborate 技巧 skills that all of the world ’ s chess master ( including me ) has been stunned .
since 1997 , the computer has been so progressive that programmers could turn the fight against humanity as unimportant .
is it just a game ?
you may be right , but let me tell you : 30 years ago i had my career ( i represented my team in my dealings with the world champion chess champion ) , and i felt that i could know the personality of the man by looking at the person ’ s personality .
until recently , i can easily distinguish between computer and human opponents .
now everything has changed .
computer chess can even be simulation of well-known human players – including their shortcomings – that only a professional actor ( and sometimes the next computer ! ) can tell the difference .
more than a half-century ago , the godfather of artificial intelligence , alan turing , suggested that the brain ’ s function could be fully attributed to mathematics , and that one day the computer could reach human intelligence .
“ turing tests ” were the holy grail of ai research .
for me , chess plays a hard part .

education in the second machine age
munich – artificial intelligence has been confined to science fiction , but it is now changing our lives .
cars will drive themselves .
drones are programmed to deliver packages .
computers are learning to diagnose diseases .
the economists erik brynjolfsson and andrew mcafee have described these recent advances as examples of their so-called “ second machine age . ”
that name – the first machine age – suggests a epochal change .
indeed , if predictions are credible , these technological advances have a profound impact on our lives .
one widespread prediction is that as increasingly advanced robots replace workers , labor costs will become less important , and manufacturing will return to rich countries .
another forecast is that increasingly intelligent machines will reduce demand for advanced skills , and that the economic advantage of those skills will shrink .
the first of these two hypotheses remains far-fetched .
but there is evidence that the second hypothesis is becoming reality , with huge implications for the modern economy ’ s challenges .
to be sure , there are plenty of anecdotal evidence that “ reshoring ” – that is , the return of jobs from low- and middle-income countries to high-wage countries .
in a recent survey of 企业 companies in the eurozone ’ s 企业 companies , two-thirds said that some 动作 moves have been implemented over the past year , and 50 % said that they were prepared to do so next year .
but there is no sign of reshoring .
in fact , the trend is still in the opposite direction .
offshore has fallen since the 2008 global financial crisis , but then rebounded , accelerating the pre-crisis level .
the return of manufacturing to rich countries is still a prediction , not an outcome .
evaluating the second hypothesis is more complicated .
at first glance , the evidence supports the possibility of falling demand for advanced skills .
in the last 17 years , there have been less wage differentials between skilled workers and unskilled workers in all western countries than in the us and germany .
one possible explanation is that european education levels exceed the pace of technological change , and the advanced skills are excessive .
in austria , the proportion of people with a university degree or the equivalent grew by 250 % between 1996 and 2012 .
in the united kingdom and italy , that share has nearly doubled .
in spain , the ratio is 70 % , and france is 60 % .
by contrast , the share of 拥有者 ratios in the us and germany has increased by just 25 % .
but another possibility that the wage gap between skilled and unskilled workers reflects the increasingly intelligent nature of machines .
here , the us is a classic .
america ’ s educational attainment enrollment rate has increased only slightly since the turn of the century , so we should expect the wage gap to rise sharply , as it did in the 1980s and 1990s .
on the contrary , the wage gap is largely unchanged , adding to the unemployment rate for skilled workers , which doubled in the us and the united kingdom in 2011-2012 .
before the 1980 ’ s , about 70 % of income belonged to labor income , and 30 % were capital income .
but , since then , the share of income per labor has declined in all rich countries .
today , that share is 58 % of gdp .
according to research by economist lucas 卡拉 and brent neiman , half of the decline is attributable to cheaper information technology , with access to information technology replacing workers with computers .
the implications are serious .
if these are indeed the first signs of the second machine age , we may be fighting a false war .
as the scarcity of human capital becomes increasingly important , rapid education may not be the answer to globalization ’ s challenges , as we want .
the promise and pitfalls of ai
brussels – as with any revolutionary trend , the rise of artificial intelligence ( ai ) poses a major opportunity and difficult challenge to address .
but the gravest risks are not the most often discussed .
according to a recent study by the mckinsey global institute ( mgi ) , ai has the potential to increase overall economic productivity considerably .
even given the transition costs and competition effects , it could increase total output by $ 13 trillion by 2030 , while increasing global gdp by about 1.2 % per year .
perhaps the most problematic issue in artificial intelligence is that its future will likely replace more jobs than it creates .
but , according to the mckinsey global institute , the adoption of ai may not have a significant impact on net employment .
by 2030 , additional investment in the sector could contribute 5 % of jobs , while the extra wealth created could drive up demand for labor and increase employment by 12 % .
but , while the overall picture is optimistic , there is no good news .
for starters , the benefits of ai may take time – especially in terms of productivity .
in fact , mgi ’ s research suggests that ai ’ s contribution to growth could be five times higher than that of the next five years by 2030 .
this outcome aligns with the so-called solow computer paradox : productivity gains lag behind technological advances – a notable phenomenon during the digital revolution .
partly because , initially , economies faced high levels of travel and transformation costs , which tend to be ignored by research on the impact of ai .
mgi ’ s simulation shows that these costs will account for 80 % of potential benefits in the next five years , and to about one-third of potential gains by 2030 .
another troubling potential feature of the ai revolution is that the benefits that it produces are unlikely to be equitably distributed .
the resulting “ ai divide ” would reinforce the digital divide ’ s gap between economic inequality and disruption .
these differences may come from three areas .
the first difference is likely to emerge at the company level .
the innovative frontier firms that fully adopt ai technologies could double their cash flows by 2030 – a result that could well lead to hiring more workers .
these firms will be far removed from companies that are unwilling or unable to adopt ai technologies at the same rate .
in fact , firms that do not adopt ai technologies may be able to drop around 20 % of cash flows because of loss of market share , leaving them vulnerable to layoffs .
the second difference concerns skills .
the proliferation of ai technologies will enable labor demand to shift away from repetitive tasks that can easily be automated or outsourced to more social or cognitive drivers .
the mckinsey global institute shows that jobs characterized by repetitive operations and low digital skill are likely to fall from 40 % of employment to only about 30 % by 2030 .
at the same time , the work of 重复性 labor or high-level digital technologies is likely to rise from about 40 % to more than 50 % .
such a shift could lead to a widening wage gap , with about 13 % of total wage payments likely to shift to 重复性 jobs that require high levels of digital technology .
workers who are engaged in repetitive and 数字 positions may experience wage stagnation or even decline , causing them to fall from 33 % to about 20 % .
the third ai divide is already evident among countries , and is set to widen further .
these countries , most of them developed in developed countries , define themselves as ai leaders , and are likely to gain 20-25 % of the extra economic revenue from today ’ s than today , while emerging economies may increase by only 5-10 % .
advanced economies have a significant advantage in ai applications , because they can go further in implementing previous digital technologies .
they also have powerful incentives to use ai technology : low productivity growth , population aging , and relatively high labor costs .
by contrast , many developing economies have inadequate digital infrastructure , with weak innovation and investment capacity , and lack a strong technological basis .
add to that a low low-wage motivation and ample room for productivity catch-up , and these economies seem unlikely to keep pace with ai applications .
the rise and expansion of these ai divides are not inevitable .
at the same time , companies can play a more active role in supporting education upgrading and continuous learning in order to ensure that they meet changing demand needs .
moreover , the existence of these differences is not necessarily negative .
redistributing resources to a better business can make economic development healthier , enabling them to compete more strongly with competition from other countries .
but the risks posed by these differences must not be underestimated .
foresight and perseverance are critical to the success of the ai revolution , because it will create short-term pain before the long-term benefits are .
if these suffering occurs in the context of an ai penetration rate , and frustrated by people ’ s frustrations , the backlash against technology is likely to lead to strong resistance to technology , which is a virtuous cycle of productivity , income , and employment needs .
the promise of ai in the developing world
london – a common misperception among observers of digital trends is that consumers in developing countries do not benefit from technological advances .
whether there is a 最新款 or “ hiring ” robot , the ability to acquire innovation is one of the most visible differences between rich and poor countries .
this gap has become even more pronounced because of the emergence of artificial intelligence .
for example , the vast majority of home “ smart 音箱 , ” such as amazon ’ s alexa , have gone to rich countries .
in 2017 , more than 80 % of global smart 音箱 出货量 went to north america .
but while technology may deepen global inequality , it can also mitigate global inequality .
this is because ai can achieve many appliances ’ inability to function ; it is also likely to revolutionize the way that health care , disaster mitigation , finance , logistics , education , and business services are achieved worldwide .
around the world , ai has begun to change developing countries .
in nepal , machine learning is mapping and analyzing post-earthquake reconstruction needs .
across africa , ai tutors are helping young students catch up to catch up .
humanitarian aid agencies use big data analytics to optimize the provision of supplies for refugees fleeing conflict and other hardships .
in my country , india , farmers use ai applications to improve crop yields and increase profits .
these innovations make us closer to achieving the sustainable development goals , which are reaching the united nations in eradicating poverty , eradicating health inequalities , increasing access to schooling , and combating global warming .
and ai can contribute only to a tiny fraction of what ai can contribute to human progress .
to harness ai ’ s power to drive development , we must find new ways to apply them .
in the right support , for example , they can transport medicines to remote hospitals in developing countries .
rwanda ’ s rural sector has already done so , the ministry of health and silicon valley tech startups , which have been working together to help find a message to the region ’ s clinics to achieve a text message , and in a few minutes .
since the initiative began in october 2016 , delivery time has been reduced by a factor of five , saving hundreds of lives .
nonetheless , while ai innovations like these are impressive , it is not for granted .
unless we can overcome the pervasive false fears that ai is more harm than good , the incredible progress that tech companies will bring to the global south will increasingly slow .
many measures can be taken to avoid this outcome .
first , programs like the united nations “ benign ai ” campaign aimed at achieving a dialogue about how to benefit from technology should be supported by policymakers .
but , most important , dialogue on ai development for humanitarian purposes can not be conducted only between aid organizations , charities , and governments .
technology investors must also be involved .
for too long , tech entrepreneurs focus on solving problems in the global north , while ignoring issues traditionally associated with developing countries .
but mobile technology is opening the door for new opportunities , with the goal of targeting ai solutions in places outside the west and beyond .
as a result , i founded a $ 100 million investment firm , which supports start-ups and robotic companies engaging in key social issues .
Rewired companies work with firms with machine consciousness – the ability of robots to understand and interpret the physical world .
companies that invest in our investments are committed to replicating human smell , the development of affordable prosthetics , and creating portable machines that improve manufacturing processes .
our goal is to fund the potential firms to improve the quality of life everywhere .
i believe that this will be ai ’ s unifying characteristic .
the machines that we create today can not only be profitable ; it is also a step closer to solving some of the world ’ s biggest challenges .
economists and scientists differ over long-term growth
cambridge – most economic forecasters have largely ignored recent developments in artificial intelligence ( such as the great leap demonstrated by deepmind ’ s 自学 chess program last december ) , arguing that the impact on long-term growth has been minimal .
even if the us interest rate on ten-year bonds has risen by 0.5 % over the last few months , this pessimism is one reason why real ( inflation-adjusted ) interest rates are still very low .
if supply-side pessimism persists , america ’ s recent massive tax and spending programs could only further increase inflation , rather than boost investment .
even if the corporate tax rate is justified ( though there is still problems in terms of tax cuts ) , there is plenty of reason to oppose the recent us fiscal policy .
above all , we live in an era of growing inequality , and labor ’ s share of income is declining relative to capital .
governments need to do more – not less – to redistribute income and wealth .
it is hard to know what us president donald trump is thinking about when he declared that his policies will achieve up to 6 % growth ( unless he is talking about prices , not output ! ) .
but if inflationary pressure really becomes reality , the current growth may well be much longer than the forecasters and the city .
in short , the focus of economists ’ pessimism is long-term growth .
their stance is based on this belief : the advanced economies are unlikely to repeat the dynamism enjoyed by the us in 1995 , and in the early 1960 ’ s , much less in the days of the 1950s and 1960s .
but the doubters should consider the fact that many scientists from every domain are not .
young researchers , in particular , would argue that progress in basic science will be a long way off , even if it takes a long time .
in fact , a small but influential group has been advocating the “ singularity ” theory of the hungarian mathematician john von 诺依曼 ’ s “ singularity ” – so complex that they could become so complex that they could be invented in the absence of any other machines for intervention .
if so , perhaps we should worry about the ethical and social implications of faster material growth than human spirit can be acceptable .
the angst over ai focuses mainly on inequality and the future of work .
but just as science fiction writers have long warned us , the potential threat posed by the emergence of “ life ” forms to be feared .
it is not easy to know who is right : economists and scientists in the long term are 出过 .
but the future of productivity will be justified in the next five years if there is no possibility of an existential fight between man and machine .
in the last 10-15 years , the advanced economies have been flat in these three areas .
owing to falling birth rates , growth in the labor force has slowed sharply , and even the us , before trump came to power , can not count on immigration .
the influx of women into the workforce played an important role in promoting growth in the latter part of the twentieth century .
while governments can do more to support women ’ s participation and pay payments , this advantage is largely exhausted .
likewise , global investment since the 2008 financial crisis has collapsed , lowering potential growth .
at the same time , productivity growth has declined everywhere , in the run-up to the tech boom in the mid-1990 ’ s .
little wonder , then , that real interest rates in the global real world are so low , and the big post-crisis savings have become increasingly scarce .
the best option , however , is that ai and other new technologies will eventually have a greater impact on growth than they have so far .
it is well known that businesses may need a long time to redesign productive processes to use new technologies : railways and electricity are two major examples .
the rise in global growth could become a catalyst for change , creating incentives for businesses to invest and introduce new technologies , some of which will replace labor and thus offset the impact of slowing labor productivity .
with the fallout from the financial crisis fading , ai may start gaining traction , with us output growth likely to remain strong in the coming years ( and certainly recession ) .
for central bankers , the rise in real global interest rates could be tricky .
in the best of circumstances , they will be able to “ wave a wave , ” as alan greenspan famously did in the 1990 ’ s , despite having more inflation .
the bottom line is that neither policymakers nor markets should assume that slow growth in the past decade will be driven by the next .
but this is not a one-way good news .
if scientists are right , we may feel regret for ourselves .
charting the future of ai
brighton – artificial intelligence ( ai ) has played an important role in human economies and societies , and it will be even more important in the coming years .
as a result , the future of ai is to acknowledge that the future is ai .
this is partly due to progress in “ deep learning , ” which began with 多层 networks that began in the 1980s .

employment in the age of artificial intelligence
washington , dc – pressing questions abound .
there are 1.6 billion people living in extreme poverty ; some 7.8 million adults are illiterate .
the grim problem extends beyond developing the developing world : “ desperate deaths ” raise death rates for white males in the us .
even if advanced economies grow , they are not everyone .
high-income groups are becoming increasingly good , while lower-income households and minorities have been falling behind .
some analysts argue that new forms of computer programming will exacerbate these developments , which will destroy the middle class , robotics , and self-driving cars , and worsen inequality .
even the 总称 of such technologies – artificial intelligence – sounds ominous .
the human brain may be the “ most complex object in the known universe , ” but , as a species , we are not always collective intelligence .
best-selling science fiction writers have long predicted that we will someday invent our machines .
technologies that create this dystopian future may not even be in the shadows .
but recent breakthroughs in artificial intelligence technologies do provide the potential for significant positive progress in a range of applications from transportation to education and medicine .
our computing power can help the planet and its most vulnerable citizens .
we can now find a new model that is less easily detected for observers of human observers – a way that has brought down energy consumption and co2 emissions .
we can increase the efficiency of our factories and reduce food waste .
more broadly , we can improve forecasting outcomes far more than usual .
in many activities , 的 warning can play a large role , and even save lives .
but fear remains : does these improvements mean abandoning all jobs – or most of the good jobs ?
in fact , there is no chance of job distress for three reasons .
the first is 莫拉维 paradox .
hans 莫拉维 and other computer scientists pointed out in the 1980s that things are easy to do for us , and it is difficult for the most advanced ai to be difficult ; conversely , ai often can easily do what we think .
most people can walk , manipulate objects , understand complex language in the early age , and never have to pay attention to how much to do and energy .
smart machines can do so far more than humans , but they can not easily jump above chairs , open doors , and navigate a valve .
a soccer ball can not play a soccer game .
second , today ’ s algorithms are adept at 模式识别 , if they can provide big data sets – such as identifying a youtube video in a youtube video – but they would be significantly less efficient if they meet the unconventional environment that is inconsistent with conventional models , or simply “ noise ” or “ noise . ”
to do so , you need skilled people to use his experience , intuition , and social consciousness .
third , the latest system can not explain what they have done , or why they recommend action .
in these “ black boxes , ” you can not read code to analyze what is happening or check whether there is hidden bias .
in the case of a 解释性 – for example , in many medical applications – you need a trained person in the decision-making loop .
but the nature of work will change .
today ’ s jobs are different from 50 or even 20 years ago .
and the new computer algorithm takes time to penetrate the economy fully .
rich industries , such as digital media and e-commerce , have just begun to unleash the capabilities created by ai .
the emergence of a narrow ai application that could affect jobs in sectors such as health care , education , and construction may be a long time horizon .
indeed , it may be time – an aging population in advanced economies that will reduce labor in the coming decades – and the need for personal care will increase .
public policy debates will affect the ai age .
we need opportunities and competition , not a powerful monopolist ’ growth , so that technological progress will not leave many people behind .
this will require improving access to various forms of education – and at low cost , at low cost – for education .
as competitors from advanced economies , including china , invest heavily in ai , policymakers should strengthen support for basic research , ensuring that countries have the physical and human resources needed to invent and manufacture them .
we should not underestimate humanity ’ s ability to inflict damage on our societies , the environment , and even the entire planet .
perhaps one day , apocalyptic fiction writers will be vindicated .
but , at the moment , we have a powerful tool for enabling all people to live better lives .
we should use it wisely .

ben bernanke ’ s global legacy
washington , dc – the world continues to digest alan greenspan ’ s legacy in 1987 as chair of the federal reserve board .
so it is too early to see the legacy of his incoming successor , ben bernanke .
but the key international role that bernanke and the fed played during his tenure – and that of domestic economic weakness – should not be ignored .
we consider each .
whatever the impact of qe on the us economy , its impact on the rest of the world is generally modest .
the first round of qe was undoubtedly beneficial , because it minimizes , or eliminated , the tail risks of global depression after the collapse of lehman brothers in september 2008 .
to be sure , the fed ’ s subsequent actions have been mixed in the rest of the world .
in 2010 and 2011 , qe brought capital to emerging markets , fueling accusations of a form of currency manipulation in the us .
in may 2013 , bernanke signaled the possibility of an exit from qe , which led emerging economies to face the opposite pressure : capital outflows and sharp exchange-rate volatility .
in both cases , the fed ’ s complaint mostly reflects macroeconomic mismanagement in affected countries .
brazil , for example , has the largest capital base for capital inflows , because its currency is appreciating in a very short period , but the culprit is domestic wage increases and overheating , not the fed ’ s policy .
likewise , india suffers from bernanke ’ s suggestion that the fed would “ taper ” qe , but only because its economy has experienced high inflation and large budget and external deficits .
emerging markets seem to have forgotten that they are vulnerable to the fed ’ s policy implications , which they secure when they join financial globalization .
at the same time , the fed is well aware of its international responsibilities , which will play a constructive role by increasing the dollar ’ s liquidity during periods of extreme financial stress .
after the collapse of lehman brothers , the fed provided dollar liquidity to brazil , mexico , singapore , and the central bank of korea .
at the same time , it provided almost unlimited amounts of liquidity to european central banks and the bank of japan .
these actions have eased extreme tensions and corresponding market volatility .
the fed ’ s support for emerging-market central banks is remarkable , because most of these countries have not borrowed from the international monetary fund ’ s loans to the international monetary fund in the wake of the asian financial crisis of the 1990 ’ s .
these countries are more willing to deal directly with the us federal reserve by the federal reserve , and the fed clearly does not have the imf ’ s stigma .
in fact , the us federal reserve ’ s support , timing , and effectiveness has made the imf a similar mechanism .
the fed ’ s support for europe has also been remarkable , given that the rest of the us government was in fact left out of the eye – with no real cash to the eurozone ’ s distressed economies .
even efforts to increase the imf ’ s resources are lost because of the political gridlock in the us .
all other major economies , including the us , have adopted the legislation needed to strengthen the imf ; but , given congressional resistance , the us has never experienced similar moves since 2010 .
the fed has achieved extraordinary gains in a period of sustained us international leadership , a simple reason : though the us economy is weak , and american politics is paralyzed by polarization , demand for the dollar remains .
in this context , bernanke effectively used his role as a powerful dollar in the printing press known as the “ fed . ”
the dollar ’ s hegemony will not last forever , and it is already increasingly being challenged by the renminbi , which i have described in my book the erosion of china ’ s economic dominance .
but the residual power of american hegemony made bernanke a constructive and effective international leader .
as his departure , people began to give him the title of “ helicopter ben ’ s , ” because it injected large amounts of cash into the us economy .
but history will not forget the key global role of “ ambassador ben . ”
spain ’ s human-rights dilemma
new york – spain ’ s mps want a legislation to prevent some of spain ’ s judges from exercising the right to a similar license , in the spanish court to prosecute the human-rights abuses that occur around the world .
in a recent case , a spanish judge called for arrest warrants directed against former chinese president 蒋泽明 蒋泽明 and former state council prime minister 李鹏 李鹏 , who had been accused of 犯有罪行 in tibet .
spain ’ s mps have proposed a view that allowing a country ’ s prosecutors to sue for a country with no clear legal ties to spain would be to politicize the proceedings .
but the core principles underpinning these prosecutions are also important : the concept of universal jurisdiction .
in fact , this concept has a long history , and has a vital role to play in global human-rights protection action .
universal jurisdiction originated in the greek and roman eras of fighting piracy .
because pirates are acting on crime in the high seas , the high seas are the territorial enemy , so that they are enemies of humanity , and any country can prosecute them .
in the seventeenth century , dutch academic hugo Hugo , who was considered the drafters of international law , argued that pirates could be prosecuted in the interview , regardless of where their crime is .
following the vienna conference of vienna in 1815 , some countries have applied this concept to slave dealers , as well as many of their crimes outside national jurisdictions .
later , nazi crimes played a critical role in gaining broad acceptance of the concept of universal jurisdiction .
at the end of world war ii , nazi leaders fled and scattered across the world .
in countries such as canada and australia , countries such as canada and australia have made it possible to establish a state authority in their national courts in their own territory .
since then , this concept has been enshrined in treaties that nearly all countries have approved .
the 1949 geneva conventions call for countries to hunt for war crimes , and to prosecute them in their own courts and to extradite them to others who are prepared to prosecute them .
likewise , in 1984 , the 1984 convention against torture requires countries to establish their own jurisdiction to prosecute perpetrators of crimes in the country and to prosecute criminals who are not practicing their crimes .
at a time when universal jurisdiction is currently under key test in senegal , one of the continent ’ s brutal dictators , the ruler of chad in 1982 , the ruler of chad ( Hiss ) , was set to be indicted .
according to a survey committee , al-hanashi ’ s regime was guilty of torture and responsible for the deaths of some 40,000 people .
al-hanashi fled to senegal in a large part of the country ’ s property , with a comfortable life with a large family and key supporter .
for years , africa ’ s human rights activist , aided by human rights watch , has been working to 问责哈 breivik .
now , with the support of the african union , al-hanashi is finally taking the trial of his crimes in chad .
the us has taken action , and the victims of human-rights crimes in the country have filed civil suits against the perpetrators of the us .
in the early 1980 ’ s , a large number of us courts have ruled to provide compensation to the victims .
the common jurisdiction is commonly cited as being accused of war crimes , crimes against humanity , or genocide , but where criminal sites and sites are not located in the same country .
this is compatible with the principle that such crimes can not be safe haven .
if spain is to join this demand in law and provides some other reasonable connections , such as those in the victims , it will overcome the 伸得 of the judges ’ reach .
such reforms remain in the principles of justice that underpin the concept of universal jurisdiction .

the scientific method for sustainable development
paris – tens of thousands of people around the world recently marched on fact-based , rather than fictional , worldviews , the latest example of popular support science .
they understand that science really can save the world , because it can help us solve the biggest health and development problems .
these issues constitute the centerpiece of the united nations sustainable development goals ( sdgs ) , which in 2015 agreed to a more prosperous , equitable , and healthy planet by 2030 .
the 17 sdgs include 169 specific targets , which constitute an ambitious agenda that aims to address all problems , from gender equality to sustainable cities and climate change .
in short , they provide an inclusive vision for sustainable development in the twenty-first century .
but integrity can be sacrificed as a result .
few people can speak to the sdgs , let alone explain how countries can achieve them in the next 13 years .
experts around the world – including this week ’ s gathering at the united nations ocean conference in new york – are setting their sights on their smaller objectives and goals .
integrating these efforts is still a daunting challenge .
if our leaders really want to achieve the vision of the world in the sdgs , we need a roadmap that guides them to complex policymaking areas .
scientists are ideal candidates for this roadmap , because they know how to make the right questions , design experiments , create evidence-based conclusions , and apply new information to known knowledge .
better , scientists are happy to share one another .
the international scientific council ( icsu ) recently convened 22 scientists in different areas – including oceanography , epidemiology , agronomy , and energy economics – to set the sdgs for world leaders .
by studying how different goals and targets relate to each other , we developed an independent research framework to help leaders prioritize priorities in their respective countries .
some sdgs are mutually reinforcing , and one of them will be easier to achieve other .
at the same time , there are some sdgs , and progress on a goal may be at the expense of other goals .
while we have long known that the sdgs are interconnected , the icsu study is the first time that it will be quantified .
for example , we chose four sdgs relating to hunger , health , energy , and ocean , and then identified all possible interaction between them and the goals of other large sizes .
then we developed a 系统 system , with a given set of goals or small targets that strongly advance another , with the goal of achieving a goal that would lead to another goal .
by applying this rating system to different sdg relationships , we can answer some important questions .
we can , for example , determine whether protecting the oceans will curb economic growth and urban development in a country and region .
and we can be sure whether increased agricultural output will make it harder for natural resources to manage ; or , whether expanding renewable-energy sources will deplete water supplies in dry water .
one exciting discovery we received is that most sdg targets are actually mutually reinforcing .
for example , helping the world ’ s poorest people escape traditional fuels such as firewood , charcoal , and animal dung would reduce the death and illness caused by air pollution , especially women and children .
and when different objectives are incompatible , policymakers can be adjusted according to need .
for example , we found that increasing agricultural yields could harm the oceans , if that exacerbates nutrition loss or other forms of pollution ; that , in turn , could undermine health and long-term food security .
moreover , the benefits of our approach are not just plain quantitative outcomes , because it brings together scientists from different disciplines .
this is not easy : scientists are critical consumers of information , and they do not always agree with one another .
breaking down disciplinary silos and bringing together different voices is a remarkable achievement .
it can serve as a model for leaders in government , business , and civil society .
so what can we learn from here ?
our analytical framework can help countries identify which sdgs benefit other goals , and which is the opposite .
in doing so , policymakers can prioritize priorities and investments ; clarification of existing resources and find budget gaps ; and establish mechanisms for sharing data and information across sectors .
more generally , each country needs to monitor progress on the sdgs and change its approach when needed .
this requires all policymakers to work together .
but the potential return on investment – at least for future generations – is immense .
whether science really can save the world remains to be seen .
but we know that scientists can put us in the right direction .
asean for 50
singapore – we live in a troubled age , where pessimism persists in most of the most prosperous areas of the planet .
many believe that the international order is unraveling .
some fear that a clash of civilizations is imminent , and even already .
but , in a bleak middle east , southeast asia offers a glimmer of hope for hope .
the region has made progress in recent decades , achieving peace and prosperity that previously could not be imagined .
and this success owes much to the association of southeast asian nations ( asean ) , which will mark 50th anniversary this month .
southeast asia is one of the world ’ s most diverse regions .
its 6.4 million people include 240 million muslims , 120 million christians , 150 million buddhists , and millions of hindus , 道教徒 , confucian , and communists .
indonesia , the region ’ s most populous country , has some 130 million people , while brunei is only 45 million .
singapore ’ s per capita income is high , $ 52,960 per year , and laos is 倍 .
this diversity has given southeast asia a serious disadvantage in creating regional cooperation .
when asean was founded in 1967 , many experts argued that it will not last for a few years .
at the time , southeast asia was a poor and problematic region , and british historians , fisher , called the balkans .
the vietnam war was not over , and the more war started .
many of the five non-communist countries that will form asean – indonesia , malaysia , the philippines , singapore , and thailand – see a domino crash as long as a neighbor , or mired in civil strife , would collapse .
but asean has broken these predictions into the world ’ s second successful regional organization , after the european union .
each year , the association of southeast asian nations ( asean ) will have to deepen cooperation in areas such as education , health , and diplomacy .
asean signed free-trade agreements with china , japan , india , south korea , australia , and new zealand ( fta ) , and created an asean economic community .
as i argue in my new book the asean miracle , multiple factors have established the region ’ s success .
for starters , anti-communism provided powerful incentives for cooperation .
strong leaders , such as indonesia ’ s suharto , former malaysian prime minister mahathir mohamad , and singapore ’ s founding father , lee kuan yew , have kept the organization together .
the us , china , and the united states , the strategic interests of the united states , china , and the member states in the late 1960 ’ s were right .
but even after the cold war ’ s end , the region was not in conflict with the balkans .
the association of southeast asian nations countries has maintained cooperative habits , and in the 1970s and 1980s , cooperation has become the norm in southeast asia .
indeed , asean ’ s previous communist enemies – cambodia , laos , and vietnam – decided to join .
so did myanmar , which ended decades of isolation .
asean ’ s policy of embracing myanmar has led to western criticism , but it helped lay the stage for a peaceful transition to military rule .
( in contrast , the west has taken an isolated policy toward countries like syria , which clearly can not achieve the same outcome . )
to be sure , asean is far from perfect .
in the short term , its actions are like a 螃蟹 – two steps forward , one step back , and a step forward .
but asean ’ s long-term success is undeniable .
its combined gdp increased from $ 95 billion in 1970 to $ 2.5 trillion in 2014 .
it is also the only reliable platform for geopolitical geopolitics in the asia-pacific region , with its unique capacity to convene all of the world ’ s great powers – from the united states and the eu to china and russia .
asean still faces serious challenges .
territorial disputes in the south china sea have created deep divisions , and the intensifying geopolitical rivalry between the us and china has led to greater cohesion .
domestic politics in countries like malaysia and thailand is increasingly chaotic .
but asean ’ s history suggests that the region can withstand these storms .
its impressive resilience is rooted in the culture of consultations that indonesia led ( musyawarah ) and the consensus culture .
imagine if other regional organizations , such as the gulf cooperation council , the south asian association of regional cooperation , can benefit from a similar norm if they are able to adhere to similar norms .
the eu was once the gold standard for regional cooperation .
but it seems to be in a series of seemingly endless crises , with anemic economic growth .
moreover , the uk is about to leave the eu from the eu , and it seems that the search for other cooperative models is the right question .
asean , despite its flaws , provides an attractive model .
in 2012 , the eu was awarded the nobel peace prize .
but asean ’ s approach is likely to represent the future , enabling other turmoil in the region to build strong cooperation .

liberating asean
singapore – next year is the 50th anniversary of asean ’ s creation of the 50th anniversary of asean ’ s failure to agree on its territorial claims in the south china sea .
while all decisions that make the decision based on consensus make it possible for disparate member states to unite and protect national interests , this limits asean ’ s effectiveness in dealing with new security threats .
the consensus rules explain why asean has failed to take a joint stance in the united states in september 11 , 2001 , when it faced a terrorist attack and the subsequent us-led war on terror .
likewise , north korea ’ s provocations – such as continuing nuclear testing and the 2010 attack on south korea ’ s cheonan ’ s cheonan ’ s stunted cheonan – have remained silent , because some members sympathize with the north korean regime .
but the territorial disputes in the south china sea have shown how asean ’ s consensus principle is limited to its effectiveness .
the problem is far more divisive among asean members than any previous problem .
in 2012 , asean ministers , for the first time in history , failed to develop a joint statement , because cambodia was not allowed to mention any incident in the south china sea .
in july 2016 , asean foreign ministers failed to mention a landmark decision by the international arbitral tribunal in the joint communiqué .
asean ’ s failure to act as a result of the south china sea has led to questions about the organization ’ s capacity to “ maintain and strengthen peace ” – the first goal of the asean charter ’ s first goal .
moreover , the recent stalemate may force some member states to address the problem by other means , ultimately affecting asean ’ s regional and international importance .
asean must address this consensus , either through procedural reforms or through institutional innovation .
first , asean should follow the advice made by asean ’ s senior advisory group in 2006 , introducing a majority of decision-making rules .
as asean ’ s activities expand , consultants observe that it should “ consider other flexible decision-making mechanisms , ” including voting .
the eu has long taken this governance mechanism , and , even within asean , there is a precedent for voting decisions , particularly on geopolitical and security issues .
in 1995 , for example , the treaty of southeast asia ( nwfz ) established the commission , with a two-thirds majority on the basis of “ no consensus . ”
when asean is unable to agree on a consensus , they should distinguish between two types of issues that are clearly influenced by the question of member states ’ sovereignty , territorial integrity , and independence ; and questions about the composition of regional security .
asean member states should seek consensus on the former issue , unless the country has another decision .
but , in the latter case , they should choose a majority rule .
accordingly , if a matter of regional security is a matter of considerable regional security , without endangering sovereign sovereignty , territorial integrity , and political autonomy , it should not allow the country to block all other member states , sacrifice regional security .
another way to overcome the consensus challenge is to adopt a new institutional framework .
for example , the establishment of a territorial dispute in the south china sea , which operates according to a majority rule , could establish asean ’ s position on the issue and address disagreements in china .
alternatively , asean member states that have territorial claims in the south china sea can be allied and to absorb asean members with unrelated benefits .
in the south china sea , the south china sea group established its own common position before the association of southeast asian nations ( asean ) conference formed its own common position , more likely to produce an asean consensus .
if these choices fail , all regional positions are similar , regardless of whether they have territorial claims in the south china sea or whether asean members , with a common position to demonstrate common ground through regional forums such as asean forums and eas summits .
integrating non-member countries into the association of southeast asian nations could affect asean ’ s unity ; but if asean members decide to adhere to the principles of consensus , it is a trade-off that must be accepted .
nonetheless , the consensus principle should not be abandoned .
it is in asean ’ s interest to agree on the asean interests of any conceivable question – including the south china sea dispute , if it is not a serious threat to regional peace .
here , asean members should establish more trust , cooperation , and dialogue with china and china .
all asean countries must strike a balance between national interests and greater regional interests .
china , for its part , should be more sensitive to security issues than asean countries , and it prefers to turn the south china sea into a haven of peace and prosperity , rather than tension and antagonism .

the dark heart of asean
washington , dc – at the summit of california next week , us president barack obama will head to the top group of southeast asian nations , asean ’ s most important regional grouping .
the meeting was the first time in the united states , which has been touted as a sign of growing interest in southeast asia .
the question is whether the united states , which has invited all asean members , will be able to overwhelm the principles .
the upcoming summit is a recent testament to the obama administration ’ s strategic “ pivot ” to asia , which is obama ’ s national security strategy , with us military , economic , and diplomatic resources going to pacific rim countries .
in many ways , this shift in relations is highly important .
first , some asean countries ’ tensions with china are escalating , owing partly to the growing assertiveness of china ’ s disputed territorial claims in southeast asia , led by president xi jinping ’ s most autocratic leader since president xi jinping .
a similar decision two years ago led to massive anti-china riots in vietnam .
and concern is not just vietnam .
malaysia , singapore , and the philippines are both trying to upgrade their navies and coast defenses .
indeed , after two decades of expulsion from the fact that the us forces the us power , the philippines has brought back the us military , as part of a new military cooperation agreement .
even countries that depend on china are worried .
china is laos ’ s largest donor and trading partner ; but , in laos , the ruling communist party last month was said to have no 亲华派 .
burma also relies heavily on chinese aid and trade with china , but fear of becoming a chinese satellite is a key reason why the burmese military junta transferred power to civilian government in the early 2010s .
in addition to security challenges , america ’ s economic interests in southeast asia are growing .
together , the asean countries comprise america ’ s fourth-largest trading partner .
some evidence suggests that the new asean economic community ( regional freedom agreement ) is helping southeast asian countries weather increasingly unstable global economic conditions .
but the upcoming us-asean summit has a serious problem .
southeast asia ’ s political system has been sharply regressive since the us launched its pivot to asia in 2011 .
in the last few years , thailand has become a military rule from flawed democracy , which could continue until 2018 .
likewise , malaysia was a two-party democracy in 2011 .
today , opposition leader anwar ibrahim is jailed for dubious sodomy charges ; the government passed legislation that essentially authorizes it to detain critics indefinitely ; and prime minister najib razak is mired in economic and political scandals .
in 2013 , the opposition coalition won almost a victory in cambodia ’ s general election , and cambodia seemed to be a political breakthrough .
but over the last two years , cambodian prime minister hun sen has returned to his political dominance .
opposition leader sam rainsy , fearing arrest , chose to exile .
then there is myanmar .
while the obama administration has touted it as a shining example of democratic change , real democracy is still far over .
true , the longtime opposition party won the general election last november .
but the military still controls many ministries and a quarter of parliamentary seats .
moreover , civil war erupted in myanmar , where gangs and other radical groups massacre muslims .
laos , vietnam , and brunei are both the world ’ s most repressive countries , with no sign of political openness .
and , despite progress in indonesia , the philippines , and singapore , progress is slow ; in singapore , the ruling party continues to dominate the political system .
there are many reasons for the weakening of democracy in southeast asia .
the region ’ s first generation of elected leaders , such as former thai prime minister thaksin shinawatra , ended up no more than a democratically elected dictator who uses the support of the majority of people to suppress the opposition and suppress the use of the available instruments .
indeed , thailand ’ s cyber repression has intensified under the junta , which has now blocked more than 100,000 websites .
weak institutions mean that many countries , such as malaysia , are struggling with political crises ; in thailand , the military has taken over as a stopgap exercise .
the trouble is that the obama administration has been strengthening ties with southeast asian autocrats , reinforcing this destructive trend .
obama has maintained good relations with malaysia ’ s najib ( the two were reportedly 高尔夫球 buddies ) .
during obama ’ s visit to malaysia last year , he barely mentioned anwar ’ s imprisonment .
the obama administration has also been silent about the violations of brunei , laos , and vietnam , which last july invited general secretary general to visit washington .
in recent months , the obama administration has begun to rebuild ties with thailand , including by renewing the high-level strategic dialogue , which has been frozen since the september 2014 coup .
but , according to human rights watch , “ thailand ’ s military junta tightened its grip on power , severely persecuting fundamental rights . ”
and , so far this year , there has been no sign of change .
some of the upcoming us-asean summits – such as hun sen , ruled in cambodia for 25 years – were previously thought to be too brutal and authoritarian , not to begin with us territory .
now , it seems that security and economic considerations have exceeded democracy and became the first determinant of foreign policy in southeast asia .
for the people of southeast asia , such an approach would ultimately create more risks than benefits .
can asean translate geostrategic and technological disruption into challenges ?
geneva – is the association of southeast asian nations resilient enough to thrive in the current regional and global transformations ?
while the global economy continues to expand broadly , disruptive economic , geostrategic , and technological forces may threaten asean ’ s growth in recent years .
in order to survive , asean members must make important decisions about the role of the organization in regional affairs .
and , through the right choice , the region could turn the disruption into a resilient future .
asean has undergone an impressive turnaround over the last five decades .
that tumultuous and conflict-ridden region is now one of the success of political and economic success .
this is due largely to countries ’ efforts to build their neighborhoods under asean .
but the region also benefited greatly from the global architecture and institutions that followed world war ii , which promoted foreign investment and foreign exports .
this global backdrop is now in a state of profound transformation .
the benefits of free and open trade are questioned , and the international system is challenging , with new geopolitical powers rising , and the global economy will continue to drift toward emerging markets ( even if the middle will remain exhausted ) .
all of this creates an opportunity for a new , competitive vision of how to operate and manage the world .
beyond growing geopolitical uncertainty , asean countries must address the fourth industrial revolution .
the exponential development of technologies such as artificial intelligence , advanced robotics , precision medicine , and self-driving cars is transforming economic , corporate , and social .
asean members will feel the impact of the fourth industrial revolution acutely .
consider the development of employment , which is increasing by 1.1 million daily per day , and will continue to grow in the next 15 years .
and in this demographic expansion , many existing jobs are being replaced by intelligent automation and artificial intelligence .
a tax system based on labor income would be under pressure .
the national budget will be challenged by the fact that asean member states must invest more in 培训 workers and develop infrastructure for this new age .
for asean , the shift from centralized global supply chains to localized production systems could have a serious impact on exports and related investments .
in response to these disruptive shifts , asean must strengthen its role in the community .
economically , by establishing a real single market , regional adaptability can be strengthened : asean has a population of 亿 billion in consumption .
taking full advantage of asean ’ s economic community is crucial .
with a strong regional market , asean can dominate its own economic destiny rather than rely on external markets , and would be better insulated from potential protectionist shocks .
creating a single market for services is essential .
in particular , asean members must address the fourth industrial revolution , addressing issues such as rules governing the use of data .
